There are ravishing set dance pieces crammed into the ballet. The absence this season of the second-act D'Jampe dance for eight harem women has, in fact, caused a controversy among some fans who miss the dance. And the dancers of American Ballet Theater gave ''La Bayadere'' the kind of performance, on Friday night and Saturday afternoon at the Metropolitan Opera House, that further enhanced the ballet's place in the classical pantheon.

title: MUSIC: KADRI GOPALNATH
description: KADRI GOPALNATH plays South Indian classical music on the alto saxophone. A western listener, trying to imagine this, might expect something like the sinuously bluesy playing of a few jazz saxophonists, notably John Handy, in encounters with Indian musicians. But Mr. Gopalnath's approach is quite different. He originally played the nadaswaram, a large, throaty South Indian reed instrument, and has been able to transfer the bends, slurs and quavers of the traditional instrument to the western one with remarkable thoroughness. He is more or less reinventing the alto saxophone, using it to do things neither its western classical exponents nor the jazz players who have perfected it as an expressive instrument could have imagined.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Auto Racing Allison Takes Dover 500: Davey Allison beat Bill Elliott, the only other driver on the lead lap, by 6.87 seconds to win the Budweiser 500 stock car race yesterday at Dover Downs International Speedway in Delaware. Allison, a rookie from Hueytown, Ala., averaged 112.952 miles per hour for 500 miles. Terry Labonte was one lap down in third.(AP) Senna First, Prost Foiled: Ayrton Senna of Brazil easily won the Monaco Grand Prix yesterday, as Alain Prost of France failed in a bid for a record 28th Formula One victory. Prost dropped out with only two laps left after running third most of the race. Senna capitalized on the engine problems of Nigel Mansell of Britain. Mansell, who started from the pole, led for 30 laps before suffering a broken turbo. Another Brazilian, Nelson Piquet, finished second, 33.212 seconds behind.(AP) Michael Andretti First: In Milwaukee, Michael Andretti took advantage of the misfortunes of his father, Mario, and Roberto Guerrero to win the Miller American 200 Indy-car race. Mario Andretti was leading when the rear wing snapped off his Lola. The car crashed, but Andretti was not badly hurt. Guerrero chased Michael Andretti until Guerrero's engine blew. Bobby Rahal finished second. Derek Daly was third.(AP) College Baseball Stanford 3, Georgia 2: Stanford's scratch runs and the pitching of Jack McDowell and Steve Chitren held off Georgia in the first round of the College World Series in Omaha, Neb. It took more than 12 hours to play the game, which was delayed and then suspended after six and one-half innings by thunderstorms Saturday night. Stanford led, 3-1, at that point after picking up two runs in the second on two singles, a stolen base, an error and a balk, and getting its third run on a triple and a ground out in the fourth. When play resumed, Georgia came back with two runs on Derek Lilliquist's two-out double in the eighth, but Chitren got Rich Bielski to fly out to end the inning with runners at second and third. McDowell (12-4) was the winner after five innings of four-hit pitching Saturday night. Lilliquist (14-3) was the loser for Georgia. (AP) Montclair St. 13, Wisconsin-Oshkosh 12: Leroy Horn's two-run homer in the bottom of the 10th lifted Montclair State to a comeback 13-12 victory in the Division III championship game at Marietta (Ohio) College yesterday. Montclair trailed, 11-10, in the bottom of the ninth inning until Jim Fasano's bases-empty homer sent the game into extra innings. Wayne Masters, who entered the game in the 10th as the fifth Montclair State pitcher, got the victory and raised his record to 6-1. Brain Wessley (8-3) was the loser.(AP)

title: Q&A
description: Q.Can fiber-optic telephone lines be tapped? A.Fiber-optic telephone lines -microscopic filaments of glass fiber through which voice and data are sent on beams of laser light - can be tapped but only with great difficulty. And the party who receives the call can detect the eavesdropping. According to Dr. Edmond Murphy, a researcher at the integrated optic components division of Bell Laboratories, the least complicated tapping method is to cut open the cable and find a single optical fiber. This fiber is wrapped tightly around a narrow rod. The light flowing through it migrates to the outer portion of the fiber where it can be picked up with a light detector and its information deciphered. Tapping a fiber-optic line reduces the strength of the signal and the receiver would know almost immediately that the line was being monitored. Q.Is baldness confined to the top of the skull or can it occur on the chin? A.The most common form of baldness is male-pattern baldness of the scalp. It affects mainly men from age 18 to 50 years and is the result of heredity and normal hormonal variations. But other medical conditions can cause baldness elsewhere on the body, according to Dr. John Romano, a physician at New York Hospital, Cornell Medical Center. For example, thyroid disease can cause a thinning of head and body hair. Dr. Romano said that once the thyroid condition was controlled, the hair thickens. Forms of baldness or alopecia, such as areata, totalis, and universalis, cause hair loss in patches on the scalp, on the face and over the entire body. Dr. Romano said that there were no general cures for these but that steroids often were effective.

description: Assuring further delay in a lawsuit over the wartime detention of 120,000 Japanese-Americans in prison camps 45 years ago, the Supreme Court dealt a procedural setback today to survivors who are suing the Government for billions of dollars in compensation.

title: Garbage Barge to Get Anchorage on Hudson
description: The garbage barge in search of a home has apparently found one - for the time being -but the garbage has not.

description: * Aluminum Co. of America, Pittsburgh, raised its prices for a number of products, including an increase of 8 percent on aluminum beverage-can body stock, end stock and food product sheet.

description: Residents of inner-city Los Angeles will vote Tuesday on whether to approve a special tax on themselves to increase police protection in their area, but the plan's sponsor has now disavowed it.

description: Friday night at Shea Stadium, Mary Jane Watson - an actress, model and computer businesswoman - will be married to the Amazing Spider-Man, a superhero also known to comic-book cognoscenti as Peter Parker, a freelance photographer for the mythical Daily Bugle in Manhattan. Stan Lee, publisher of Marvel Comics and creator of Spider-Man, will officiate.

title: BARBIE TRIAL TOLD HOW CHILDREN DIED
description: The final minutes in the lives of most of the 44 Jewish children taken from their refuge near Lyons in France and killed at Auschwitz were recounted by a witness here today as the trial of Klaus Barbie resumed after a four-day recess.

title: 3 in Jersey Found Slain In Luxury Apartment
description: Three people were found shot to death Sunday night in an apartment at a luxury complex overlooking the Hudson River here, the police said today.

title: BEAM FALLING FROM MANHATTAN TOWER KILLS MAN
description: A pedestrian on Eighth Avenue was struck and killed yesterday afternoon by an 8-foot wooden beam that fell from a condominium tower being built across the street, the authorities said.

title: Fibreboard Suits Settled
description: The Louisiana-Pacific Corporation has settled lawsuits regarding asbestos-injury claims against its Fibreboard Corporation subsidiary.

title: INSIDER'S GUIDE TO TRIVIA
description: THE earliest mention of the word ''computer'' dates to 1646, when it referred to people who calculated the passage of time and drew up calendars.

title: Beastie Boy Seized After Concert Melee
description: A member of the Beastie Boys was arrested and charged with assault Sunday in connection with a melee that abruptly ended the final concert of the New York rock group's British tour, the police said.

title: Mitchell Stanley Weds Miss Sterritt in London
description: Kathleen Joan Sterritt, an assistant features editor of The Washington Post Magazine, and Mitchell Fanning Stanley, the special assistant to the Secretary of Commerce, were married in London yesterday at the Queen's Chapel of the Savoy, of the Church of England. The Rev. John H. Williams performed the ceremony.

title: Upgrading the Nielsen Family
description: Forty years ago, when all the world went to the movies on Saturday nights, the famous producer Harry Cohn told a tableful of screenwriters his infallible method for separating moneymakers from clinkers. If a movie was good, he could sit still. If not, he said, his backside wiggled in his chair. Today's technology and market research are presumably a big improvement on Mr. Cohn's decidedly subjective method. Presumably.

title: Opening Day for Draft
description: Starting today, and continuing through Thursday, college and high school baseball players throughout the nation will be having some important questions answered. For many, the 1987 major league baseball summer free-agent draft will offer insight into how good they really are, and to whether or not they have a future in baseball. For others it is just a matter of where they will play.

title: For Heroin Addicts, and the Rest of Us
description: There are 200,000 heroin addicts in New York City and only 35,000 slots in treatment programs, all full. Every day, addicts seeking treatment are told to fill out forms to get on a waiting list. The wait for methadone maintenance treatment at Beth Israel Hospital in Manhattan is one to three months. In hospitals in the other boroughs, it ranges up to a year. Turning away addicts who want to kick the habit is not only inhumane to addicts. It is, for a society bruised by crime, stupidly self-defeating. Yet a proven, moderate-cost way to contain addiction waits to be adopted.

title: PTL'S DUAL VIEWS OF TV
description: The PTL ministry uses television in two ways, both as a buyer and as a seller.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: TUESDAY, JUNE 2, 1987
description: International A3-16

title: AIDS FEARS LEAD TO BAN ON RECORD
description: George Michael's new single, ''I Want Your Sex,'' has become the first record to run into censorship problems because of fears that it might be too sexually explicit for the age of AIDS.

title: Measles Proves Stubborn
description: ELIMINATION of measles from the United States is proving to be a more difficult goal than many specialists had expected. A decade ago, Federal health officials announced a national goal of eliminating the infectious disease, by immunizing all children against the virus that causes it. But the number of cases has been climbing each year since the all-time low of 1,497 cases reported in 1983.

title: INDIANS TO SEND CONVOY TO SRI LANKA
description: India announced today that it would send a convoy of unarmed ships to northern Sri Lanka on Wednesday to provide ''humanitarian assistance'' to ethnic Tamils besieged by a weeklong offensive by Government forces.

title: SCIENTISTS DEVISE 'GUIDED MISSILES' FOR DRUGS
description: ANTIBIOTICS and other drugs have revolutionized modern medicine. But for all their advantages, they continue to have two serious drawbacks: they are rapidly cleared from the blood system and they may be toxic to healthy cells as well as those they are meant to attack.

title: Advertising; Kentucky Fried's Plans For a Smaller Product
description: In July, Kentucky Fried Chicken will introduce Chicken Littles with $40 million worth of advertising over three months.

title: 'ISRAEL: THE PRICE OF VICTORY'
description: THE Middle East war of June 1967 brought Israel control, among other territories, of 2,000 square miles of the West Bank of the Jordan River containing a million Arabs. It was at the time a cause for celebration among Israelis. In recent years, however, some of those celebrating have come to see the famous victory as a defeat for the values that a Zionist state once represented.

title: FALWELL SAYS PTL SURVIVED EMERGENCY
description: The PTL ministry has survived what it called its ''May emergency'' with the collection of more than $7 million in a fund drive that ended Sunday, ministry officials said.

title: For Hurricane News, It's (900) 410-NOAA
description: When tropical storms or hurricanes threaten this year, Americans will be able to get updates on the telephone.

title: Advertising; A System To Sharpen Campaigns
description: ONE of the ad agencies preparing to go into battle for the $200 million Burger King account could well be armed with a very special weapon. Appropriately called Conquest Advertising, it is the creation of Lawrence S. Silverman, and is a joint venture between him and Dun & Bradstreet's Donnelley Marketing Information Services.

title: MAXWELL SUES TO BLOCK HARCOURT'S $3 BILLION PLAN
description: Signaling his continued interest in acquiring Harcourt Brace Jovanovich Inc., the British publisher Robert Maxwell sued yesterday to stop the company from carrying out its $3 billion recapitalization plan.

title: Laser Maker Rejects Offer
description: Spectra-Physics Inc., the world's largest maker of lasers, today rejected a $32-a-share takeover offer from Ciba-Geigy Ltd. and filed a lawsuit against the Swiss pharmaceuticals giant.

title: Thatcher and Reagan
description: Margaret Thatcher and Ronald Reagan are often treated, especially in the United States, as if they were political twins. They do have ideology in common. But in the way they do the work of politicians, getting elected and running governments, they could hardly be less alike.

title: Dresser to Sell Insurance Unit
description: Dresser Industries, a diversified oilfield services company, said it had agreed to sell its insurance unit to RSL Holding Company, a unit of the private New York investment firm of Rosenkrantz & Company. The terms of the sale, which is subject to governmental approval, were not disclosed. However, estimates of the price ranged from $200 million to $250 million in cash. The company expects the sale to be completed by November.

title: BONN'S DIPLOMATS SAY PILOT IS CALM
description: West German diplomats today visited the young pilot who flew from Finland to the Kremlin and described him as bearing up calmly after nearly four days in the K.G.B.'s Lefortovo Prison.

title: CONCERT: MANHATTAN ORCHESTRA
description: AS a graduation project at the fledgling St. Petersburg Conservatory, Tchaikovsky was assigned by Anton Rubinstein to compose a cantata based on the Schiller poem, ''An die Freude,'' which served as the text for the last movement of Beethoven's Ninth Symphony; a translation by Konstantin Sergeyevich Aksakov, which followed closely the cuts Beethoven had made for his score, was to be used. Tchaikovsky had a few weeks in late 1865 to complete the ''Ode to Joy.'' Its first performance took place on Jan. 10, 1866, at a public graduation ceremony.

title: LENDL AND BECKER HITTIING STRIDE IN PARIS
description: Ivan Lendl and Boris Becker, the world's top two tennis players, each made discoveries today that could lead them to a final-round confrontation at the French Open.

title: Early Humans in Australia
description: Evidence has been found that humans reached Australia 5,000 years earlier than previously found materials, according to the Australian Government's Science Newsletter. The evidence, stone tools found along the Nepean River near Sydney, is 43,000 to 47,000 years old, scientists say.

title: Breast-Feeding Linked to Straighter Teeth
description: BREAST-FEEDING may contribute to straighter teeth because it leads to different growth patterns in the mouth than those in bottle-fed babies, according to a new study at the Johns Hopkins School of Public Health.

description: To the Editor:

title: The Cessna Landed in Every Capital
description: The flight of Mathias Rust's Cessna into Red Square is no occasion for finding comfort in the Soviet Union's discomfort. The young pilot sent a message to us about our defense system - especially about ''Star Wars'' - and to other nations about theirs, too.

title: Bradley to Be Roasted
description: Senator Bill Bradley of New Jersey has been manfully resisting efforts to persuade him to take a few practice shots at the 1988 Democratic Presidential nomination, but he has now agreed to appear on the same platform with seven declared or active competitors later this month. He will not be debating his party colleagues, however, but defending himself at a fund-raising ''roast'' at the Sheraton Washington hotel June 23.

title: Our Towns; Fear of Morels: Outdoor Eating Hits Ho-Ho-Kus
description: Claude Baills, the French chef who runs the elegant restaurant in the 18th century Ho-Ho-Kus Inn, must have just the right food for the moment. He gets his crabs overnight from Maryland, his snails by U.P.S. from Oregon. When morels came in season, he had his public relations firm send out a press release to all food writers that began: ''MEDIA ALERT -APRIL SHOWERS BRING FRESH MORELS TO THE HO-HO-KUS INN!''

title: F.W. ZIESING, 75, EX-TRUSTEE
description: Faith Whitney Ziesing, a former trustee of Sarah Lawrence College, died of cancer last Friday at her home in Princeton, N.J. She was 75 years old.

title: Babcock Withdraws
description: Scratch one name on the list of candidates for the job of Knicks' general manager and add another. After several meetings with Madison Square Garden officials, Pete Babcock, the Denver Nuggets' director of basketball operations, said yesterday that he was out of the running.

description: Tamil guerrillas stopped a bus in eastern Sri Lanka and killed 33 passengers, including 29 Buddhist priests, the Government said today.

description: The State Athletic Control Board today told 35 boxers they will no longer be allowed to box in New Jersey because future bouts could endanger their health.

title: Seoul's Trade Surplus
description: South Korea's trade surplus was basically steady in May, at $348 million, compared with $349 million a year earlier, but the results so far ths year remain well ahead of 1986 levels, the Government said today. South Korea posted a trade surplus of $1.8 billion in the first five months of this year, in contrast to a deficit of $340 million a year earlier, the Trade and Industry Ministry reported.

title: PAYMENT IN DOUBT ON 2 AIDS AILMENTS
description: Thousands of people suffering from AIDS-related illnesses will not automatically qualify for the Social Security disability benefits that they had expected to receive under an expanded definition of AIDS.

title: DU PONT, A LONG SHOT, GAINS IN G.O.P. DERBY
description: Quietly but persistently, serious Republicans are asking this question: Is Pierre S. du Pont 4th on the way to becoming a serious contender for the Republican nomination for President?

title: THREE DEFIED DRUG-DEALING BAN BY GAMBINO FAMILY, JURY IS TOLD
description: A younger brother of John Gotti and two of Mr. Gotti's close associates defied the Gambino crime family's prohibition against dealing in drugs, a Federal prosecutor told a Brooklyn jury yesterday.

description: Prime Minister Errol W. Barrow died at his residence today, the Government announced. He was 67 years old.

title: Advertising; Eric Mower Wins Hair and Shoe Accounts
description: The New York office of Eric Mower & Associates has won a couple of exotic assignments that will care for it head and toe.

title: Ford, Matsushita, Mazda in Venture
description: The Ford Motor Company said it would establish a joint venture in Japan to build heating and cooling units for use in Mazda cars. Ford, the Mazda Motor Corporation and the Matsushita Electric Industrial Company will hold equal shares in the venture, to be called the Japan Climate Systems Corporation. It is to be headed by Akira Toriyama, a former Mazda president, and based near Mazda headquarters in Hiroshima.

title: BOND PRICES RISE MODERATELY
description: Bond prices rose modestly for the third consecutive session yesterday and have now advanced on six of the last seven trading days.

title: Wonders in Red Square
description: The first wonder in the tale of Mathias Rust was the picture of the little Cessna parked in front of the fantastical onion domes of St. Basil's Cathedral. A 19-year-old West German really had flown into the heart of Moscow, buzzed Lenin's tomb and landed beside the Kremlin Wall.

title: RESTAURANTS FINDING WAYS AROUND SMOKING LAW
description: Restaurateurs upset about a two-month-old ban on smoking are getting around the ordinance by redefining large sections of their establishments as bar areas.

title: TWO HELL'S ANGELS ARRESTED
description: Two men described by the police as members of the Hell's Angels motorcycle gang were arrested in Manhattan yesterday after they smashed a motorist's windshield, apparently upset that the driver was honking the horn, detectives said.

description: To the Editor:

title: CAMPFIRE BLAMED FOR RAGING FIRE IN CALIFORNIA

description: From casual black Persian lamb jackets fastened and decorated with industrial zippers to hooded floor-length evening coats in black broadtail trimmed with mink, a wide range of styles have been introduced for fall during fur shows in the last two weeks.

description: The last substantial vestige of Scovill Inc., the consumer products company that the Belzberg brothers of Canada took over 18 months ago, will soon be sold, ending their proclamation to use Scovill as a springboard to build up a large manufacturing business.

title: Market Place; Bonds Finding Support Again
description: PLUMMETING bond prices rattled investor nerves for much of April and May. But now that the dollar has stabilized somewhat and bonds have recouped part of their losses, some brokerage firms are taking a more favorable view of fixed-income securities.

title: TOP COURT UPHOLDS SEVERANCE PAY FOR WORKERS WHOSE PLANTS CLOSE
description: The Supreme Court today upheld, 5 to 4, a Maine law requiring employers to pay severance benefits to some workers laid off in plant closings. The ruling could encourage passage of similar laws by other states hard hit by foreign competition and economic dislocation.

description: Debt

title: METS CONSIDER SEAVER RETURN
description: They don't know if he can still pitch at the age of 42, but their pitching staff has been decimated by injuries, so the Mets are talking to Tom Seaver about the possibility of returning to the team for the second half of the season.

title: Careers; Volunteers Who Aid Scientists
description: VOLUNTEERS for Earthwatch are seldom too young or too old.

description: The Reagan Administration is inclined to reappoint Paul A. Volcker as chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, a senior official suggested today.

title: RASHID KARAMI, COOL PERSUADER IN A LAND OF STRIFE
description: Rashid Karami, who was assassinated in an explosion aboard his helicopter yesterday, was an adroit, flexible pro-Syrian politician who had been the Prime Minister of Lebanon 10 times since 1955.

title: National Distillers
description: An investment group led by Robert M. Bass of the wealthy Fort Worth family has lowered its stake in the National Distillers and Chemical Corporation to 3.6 percent, from 5.3 percent. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the Bass group said it had sold 567,800 National Distillers shares on the open market for prices ranging from $59.94 to $63.44 a share. The Bass group did not give a reason for the sale.

title: Ford's Credit Unit Is Offering Notes
description: The Ford Motor Credit Company is offering $200 million of 9.30 percent notes due in 1997 at a price of 99 3/4 to yield 9.34 percent. The underwriters are led by Salomon Brothers rather than Goldman, Sachs & Company, which manages most note financings for the Ford unit.

title: U.S. PUSH FOR ARMS EMBARGO ON IRAN HITS U.N. DEAD END
description: The five permanent members of the Security Council have failed to agree on an American proposal to impose a global arms embargo against Iran, diplomats in Washington and at the United Nations said today.

title: A Bust of Rockefeller Is Unveiled in Capitol
description: Friends and relatives of Nelson A. Rockefeller gathered this morning in a small corridor off the Senate chamber to unveil a marble bust of the late Vice President and New York Governor.

title: NEW TV STATIONS SEEK TO BE FOUND BY VIEWERS
description: Because Bruce David Klein likes Bela Lugosi movies, thousands of Long Islanders watched half a dozen of them last summer. Because he likes Humphrey Bogart, viewers will have the chance to watch ''Dark Victory'' tonight.

title: Wedtech Inquiry Said to Cover Conduit for Bribe
description: The investigation into the Wedtech Corporation has expanded to include a former Republican office-seeker from Brooklyn, who, law-enforcement officials said, was a conduit for the payment of a bribe to a Federal official.

title: State Dormitory Agency Sets Top Yield of 8.09%
description: The New York State Dormitory Authority is offering $500 million of bonds to finance new facilities for the City University of New York.

title: Advertising; Douglas G. Hearle
description: Right on top of some of the recent more exotic travel news is word that Suffolk Waste Distillation of Southold, L.I., has hired Douglas G. Hearle & Associates of New York to do its public relations. As the 1990 deadline for closing landfills in the county approaches, Suffolk Waste wants communities to know about its system of turning municipal waste into carbon char that occupies 10 percent of the space of the original mass. This is done without burning. Without burning?

title: THOMAS J. REGHANTI
description: Thomas J. Reghanti, who retired from the Fruehauf Corporation in 1986 as president and chief executive officer, died here last Thursday. He was 62 years old.

title: IRELAND'S BOOK OF KELLS IS FACSIMILED
description: Accompanied by bagpipe music and a videotaped explanation of a complex photographic technique, the librarian of Trinity College in Dublin yesterday unveiled what he called the first ''true facsimile'' of the Book of Kells, the medieval Irish illuminated manuscript of the gospels that is one of the most famous works of its kind in the world.

title: G.M.'s Truck Unit Gets Added Duties
description: The General Motors Corporation said it would concentrate the administration of its medium-duty truck operations in its G.M.C. Truck division. Until now, the Chevrolet division had handled the nearly 1,000 Chevrolet dealerships that sell medium trucks. There are about 660 G.M.C. medium-truck dealers.

description: The Island State

title: Honors for Old Hand
description: Friends of Joseph L. Rauh Jr., which means labor leaders, civil libertarians, lawyers and surviving liberals generally, are giving the 76-year-old lawyer, a fixture on the Washington political scene since the New Deal, a lunch today. It marks his return to the Washington scene after an uncharacteristic period of limited activity due to hip replacement surgery last January. The Alliance for Justice, an association of public interest lawyers, is giving him its distinguished service award at the Capital Hilton, where speakers will include Arthur Schlesinger Jr., the historian, and Representative John Lewis, a Georgia Democrat. Advance intelligence has it that Mr. Rauh will predict that President Reagan's nominee for the next vacancy on the Supreme Court, should one occur, will be Senator Orrin G. Hatch, Republican of Utah, a prospect not likely to draw applause from the audience. Tensions in the gulf have risen since 37 American sailors were killed two weeks ago when an Iraqi jet attacked the American frigate Stark. Since then, Mr. Reagan has also announced plans to place American flags on 11 Kuwaiti tankers, apparently in an attempt to discourage attacks by Iran.

title: William Feinberg, 87, A City Center Founder
description: William Feinberg, a founder of City Center who for 15 years served as vice president, then secretary of Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians, died Saturday at Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 87 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Bottoming Out
description: The San Diego Padres halted a seven-game losing streak Sunday with a 1-0 victory over the Mets, but the immediate future looks perilous for the team with the worst record in baseball. The Padres, who have won only 5 of 24 road games, will play 13 in the next two weeks in Montreal, Atlanta, Houston and San Francisco. Over all, San Diego's winning percentage of .235 is on pace with the worst record in modern baseball history, recorded by the Philadelphia Athletics in 1916. title: SOVIET 'VOICE' JAMMERS SHIFT TO 'LIBERTY'
description: The throbbing, irritating hum and static of electronic jamming ceased on May 23 for Soviet listeners to Voice of America broadcasts.

title: CONTRA INQUIRY INTO ABUSES IS DISPUTED BY COMMANDERS
description: A sharp dispute has broken out between Nicaraguan rebel military commanders and their own human rights organization.

title: FOR BRITAIN, A CAMPAIGN MADE FOR TV
description: On a drowsy Sunday morning, one of the first great tourist hordes of the summer assembled outside Buckingham Palace for the changing of the guard. Meanwhile, a scant half-mile away, a livelier and more unusual scene - a scene with its own historic overtones - was being staged in St. James's Park for the lucky few who stumbled upon it.

title: BONN'S COALITION AGREES TO ENDORSE MISSILES' REMOVAL
description: Chancellor Helmut Kohl's ruling coalition agreed today to endorse Soviet-American moves to eliminate missiles with a range of over 300 miles from Europe.

description: Vice President Bush, addressing the opening of the largest scientific meeting ever held on AIDS, today pushed for broader testing at both state and Federal levels to detect individuals who are infected with the AIDS virus.

title: NEW VIRUS TIED TO AIDS IS FOUND IN AFRICA
description: The discovery of a new virus that causes a disease in humans resembling AIDS was reported here today at a conference on the disease by Dr. Robert C. Gallo of the National Cancer Institute.

title: House Votes Monument Status at Lava Sites
description: The House of Representatives voted today to establish a national monument to protect ancient lava flows and archeological sites in northwestern New Mexico. The unanimous vote capped an 18-year effort to protect the region, which will be known as the El Malpais National Monument and the Grants National Conservation Area.

title: U.S. ROWER JOINS ELITE FLEET
description: In the single sculls race at the 1985 world rowing championships, with 200 of the 2,000 meters left to row, the leader was neither Pertti Karppinen from Finland nor Peter Michael Kolbe of West Germany, who had been exchanging this championship for the past decade.

title: Porex and Medco Plan to Merge
description: The Porex Technologies Corporation agreed to merge with its partly owned subsidiary, the Medco Containment Services Inc., in a deal valued at $300 million in cash and Porex common stock. Medco's shares rose 50 cents, to $35.50, in over-the-counter trading today.

title: HART, FINANCIALLY BELEAGUERED, FACES A BIG VOTE BY ELECTION PANEL
description: A preliminary vote by the Federal Election Commission this week on whether Gary Hart's 1988 campaign can receive Federal matching funds could be crucial in determining whether he can resolve the mounting financial troubles of his two Presidential bids.

title: Jews Are Said to Leave Soviet at a Higher Rate
description: A total of 871 Jews emigrated from the Soviet Union in May, the highest monthly figure since May 1981, the National Conference on Soviet Jewry announced today.

title: Bridge: Foray Into Tournament Play Brings a Title to 4 Veterans By ALAN TRUSCOTT
description: Experience paid off last week in Manhattan for four players who have had long experience at the rubber bridge table and make occasional forays into the tournament arena.

title: HUDSON INEFFECTIVE 3D STRAIGHT TIME
description: The Charles Hudson balloon lost a little more air last night.

title: AT TIBET FRONTIER, CHINA AND INDIA SQUARE OFF
description: As tension along China's easternmost border with India continues, China is pouring tremendous numbers of soldiers and weapons into the sparsely populated mountainous area along the two countries' disputed border.

title: Walsh Takes 2-Year Lease
description: The independent counsel in the Iran-contra case, Lawrence E. Walsh, has moved his staff into new offices with a two-year lease and an option for a third year, officials said today.

title: Tax Watch; System Really Is Simpler
description: WAGNER, as a critic once observed about the famed composer's music, is really better than it sounds. Likewise, the Tax Reform Act of 1986: It will prove simpler for most taxpayers than the new tax forms look.

title: Small Business Help Expands
description: The concept of state authorities acting as bond financing conduits for small businesses has been expanded to the national market, according to officials at American Development Finance Inc. and Shearson Lehman Brothers.

title: Advertising; People
description: * Peter Engler has been named executive vice president at Siegel & Gale, a subsidiary of Saatchi & Saatchi.

title: COMPUTER CHAIN SALE ANNOUNCED
description: Capping a year of speculation and rumors, the Computerland Corporation, the world's largest personal computer retailer, said today that an investment group led by E.M. Warburg, Pincus & Company had agreed to acquire the company.

title: INQUIRY ON AMBULANCE CONTRACTS FINDS NO EVIDENCE OF CRIMINALITY
description: The New York City Investigation Department said yesterday that there was no evidence of criminality in the way the city's Health and Hospitals Corporation has purchased ambulances since 1980.

title: Poorly Paid Home Health Care Workers Subsidize an Industry
description: To the Editor:

title: AFTER 3 WEEKS, U.S. SAYS TURNOUT BY ALIENS IS LESS THAN EXPECTED
description: In the three weeks since the new immigration law took effect, far fewer illegal aliens have applied for citizenship than was expected, Federal immigration officials said yesterday.

title: Burlington Stake Is Reduced
description: The New York investor Asher B. Edelman and Dominion Textile Inc. have lowered their combined stake in Burlington Industries to 12.3 percent, from the equivalent of 13.4 percent.

title: METS AND LEACH BEAT VALENZUELA
description: The stars were still absent from the cast, but the Mets got another extravagant pitching performance from one of their understudies tonight and won for the sixth time in seven games on the long and dangerous road west.

title: 93 DEGREE DAY SIGNALS TROUBLE FOR UTILITIES
description: Dozens of students were felled by heat exhaustion, air-conditioning sellers were mobbed, and demands for power surged to near-record levels yesterday as temperatures soared into the 90's for the fourth straight day across the New York metropolitan region.

title: GOETZ DIDN'T SHOOT YOUTHS IN BACK AS THEY RAN AWAY, WITNESS SAYS
description: A former New York City medical examiner testified yesterday that he believed none of the four people shot by Bernhard H. Goetz on a subway car in December 1984 was hit in the back while running away from Mr. Goetz, as the prosecution has contended.

title: NISSAN'S REVOLUTION IN BRITAIN
description: The sprawling new car factory here on a verdant flatland in northeast England is a source of jobs where they are badly needed, and it provides political and economic benefits for its Japanese owner, the Nissan Motor Company. More significant than jobs or investment, the Sunderland plant is a sharp break with the class-ridden ways of Britain's industrial past.

title: LEBANESE PREMIER IS ASSASSINATED IN COPTER BLAST
description: Prime Minister Rashid Karami was assassinated today when an explosion attributed to a bomb ripped through a military helicopter in which he was traveling.

title: Fox Network Lines Up 'Late Show' Guest Hosts
description: Fox Broadcasting has announced several of the stars who are to serve as guest hosts on ''The Late Show,'' replacing Joan Rivers.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I think that organized crime was filtered into the teamsters' union a long time before I came there, and it'll be there a long time after I'm gone.'' - Roy L. Williams, Former teamster president. [ A1:3. ]

title: Governor's Arts Awards To Be Presented June 10
description: Governor Cuomo and Matilda Cuomo will be the hosts at ceremonies honoring the winners of the 1987 New York State Governor's Arts Awards on June 10 at the Museum of Modern Art.

title: Tokyo Stocks Advance
description: Prices on the Tokyo Stock Exchange rose to a record close today for the third session in a row, led by buying of brokerage-house shares. The market index ended at 24,992.78, up 91.19 points.

title: Investors Vow Bid for Allegis
description: The small group of investors holding a 13 percent stake in the Allegis Corporation said yesterday that they would continue to seek control of the company in order to liquidate it or sell off its divisions. The group, Gollust, Tierney &

title: Stern and Penderecki Share $100,000 Prize
description: The violinist Isaac Stern and the Polish composer Krysztof Penderecki were awarded 1987 Wolf Prizes for the arts Sunday by President Chaim Herzog and Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir. The two musicians will share a $100,000 prize.

title: M.I.T.
description: The Massachusetts Institute of Technology in Cambridge, Mass., awarded degrees to 937 undergraduate and 825 graduate students at the 121st commencement held in Killian Court.

title: DANCE: NANCY MEEHAN OFFERS 'INTO SUMMER'
description: NANCY MEEHAN'S ''Into Summer'' was an excursion into a mysterious but attractive choreographic realm, and the journey was aided by a shimmering score by Eleanor Hovda, who played wind and percussion instruments and plucked the strings of a piano. ''Into Summer,'' a new work, was offered Sunday night at the Emanu-El Midtown Y by the Nancy Meehan Dance Company.

title: SULTAN IS SEEKING CONTRAS' MILLIONS
description: The Sultan of Brunei is seeking to recover $10 million intended as a donation for Nicaraguan rebels that was mistakenly deposited in the account of a wealthy Swiss businessman, a judge said today.

title: MOYNIHAN ASSAILS USE OF SHELTERS
description: Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan used the dedication yesterday of a privately financed shelter for homeless families to denounce the conditions in New York City's welfare hotels as ''a scandal, an outrage, an ulcer.''

title: LEGISLATORS DEADLOCKED OVER TEXAS BUDGET PLAN
description: What was billed as one of the most critical legislative sessions in Texas history ended here today with legislators and Gov. Bill Clements deadlocked over a solution to the state's budget crisis.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: TUESDAY, JUNE 2, 1987
description: Companies

title: Scientific Software
description: ALTHOUGH the personal computer would seem to be a natural tool for scientists and engineers, most commercial software is geared toward the business world: spreadsheets, word processors and other corporate productivity tools. Surprisingly little focuses on natural or applied sciences.

title: Emery Air Fills Key Job At Its Purolator Unit
description: The Emery Air Freight Corporation, which acquired controlling interest in the Purolator Courier Corporation April 28, has appointed John J. Kilcullen, a Purolator executive, to be the unit's chief operating officer.

title: Stocks Slip a Bit as Trading Slows
description: Stock prices eased in a listless session yesterday, as concerns about the trade situation, the dollar and interest rates continued to hover over the market.

title: KEY RATES
KOCH SUGGESTS SITES TO KEEP NBC IN MANHATTAN
description: Mayor Koch said yesterday that officials of the National Broadcasting Company should consider relocating to one of several Manhattan locations, including Battery Park City and the site of the current Madison Square Garden.

title: Serge Kotlarsky, 94, Violinist Who Toured U.S. With Caruso
description: Serge Kotlarsky, a violinist who toured the United States as a child prodigy with Enrico Caruso and who performed in the Soviet Union with David Oistrakh, died Friday at the Williams Residence in Manhattan. He was 94 years old.

title: ANTICIPATING 100 AND THE NEXT SHOW
description: Noting the fact that George Abbott will turn 100 years old on June 25, the Great Lakes Theater Festival here is presenting two vintage Abbott shows: ''Broadway,'' the racy 1926 backstage drama that Mr. Abbott wrote and that he directed for this production, and the Richard Rodgers-Lorenz Hart-George Abbott musical ''The Boys From Syracuse,'' staged by the festival's artistic director, Gerald Freedman.

title: ASTRONAUTS DISCOVER POLICY ROLE IS LIMITED
description: ASTRONAUTS who entered the space agency management with missionary zeal after the Challenger disaster have found that their ability to correct problems with space technologies and to strengthen the agency's safety planning is severely limited.

title: Security Pacific to Add to Loan-Loss Reserves
description: The Security Pacific Corporation, parent of the nation's sixth-largest bank, said today that it would add $500 million to its reserves for possible losses on loans to developing countries.

title: SUPERIORS KNEW OF CONTRA HELP, C.I.A. MAN SAYS
description: The head of the Central Intelligence Agency office in Costa Rica has told Congressional committees that his immediate superiors at the agency in Washington knew he coordinated air drops of weapons to the rebels in Nicaragua, according to testimony made public today.

title: LESTER D. EGBERT
description: Lester D. Egbert, a former chairman of Brown, Crosby & Company, a Manhattan-based insurance brokerage firm, and a former trustee of Columbia University, died Sunday at Montclair (N.J.) Community Hospital. He was 95 years old and lived in Montclair.

title: John H. Grady Is Dead at 59; Former Executive of I.B.M.
description: John Henry Grady, a former vice president of I.B.M., died of cancer Sunday at Greenwich (Conn.) Hospital. He was 59 years old and lived in Greenwich.

title: STAGE: 'A MAN'S WORLD'
description: IN Greg Mehrten's ''It's a Man's World,'' the closing play in the Mabou Mines season at the Apple Corps Theater, the disintegration of Joey Fontina is almost as quick as his rise to fame. A romantic star of a daytime soap opera, he is precipitately dropped from the show, apparently because of his homosexuality. He finds himself unemployable.

title: Prices of Biotech Stocks Fall
description: A recommendation against Government approval of a key drug manufactured by Genentech Inc. was bad news for the biotechnology sector on Wall Street yesterday.

title: TITLE BRINGS RELIEF TO OILERS
description: There was an air of deliverance in Edmonton's champagne-splashed locker room as the players basked in their third Stanley Cup victory Sunday after defeating the Flyers, 3-1, in a tense finale to a seven-game series.

title: TO LAKERS, CELTICS LOOK FIT
description: As far as the Lakers are concerned, Robert Parish is ready to run a marathon. Kevin McHale is in peak physical condition, as are Dennis Johnson, Danny Ainge and, of course, Larry Bird. Tired legs? Injured bodies?

title: What Illiteracy Isn't
description: CAN you define quarks? If not, you are guilty of scientific illiteracy.

title: Mr. Reagan's AIDS Test
description: ''This is a battle against disease, not against our fellow Americans.'' In his first speech devoted to AIDS, President Reagan made plain that his heart was in the right place. What's less evident is why he ignores the best advice of public health officials and recommends compulsory AIDS testing that has little relevance to the incidence of the disease.

title: SHAMIR ASKS INQUIRY IN SECURITY CASE
description: Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir of Israel formally requested today that the Supreme Court president, Meir Shamgar, appoint a judicial commission to examine the conduct of agents of Shin Beth, Israel's internal security service.

title: Curry Fight July 18
description: Donald Curry (27-1, with 20 knockouts), the former undisputed world welterweight champion, doesn't believe he can get down to the 147-pound limit anymore, but he has agreed to fight Mike McCallum (31-0, 28 knockouts), the low-profile World Boxing Association junior-middleweight champion, next month in Las Vegas, Nev., for HBO. The junior middleweight limit is 154 pounds.

title: DANCE ARCHIVE NAMED FOR ROBBINS
description: Members of the dance and theater worlds gathered yesterday to name the film and video section of the New York Public Library's Dance Collection at Lincoln Center in honor of Jerome Robbins.

title: Yacht Race Planned
description: The single-handed yacht race around the world was such a success that the BOC Group plans to sponsor another one beginning and ending in Newport, R.I., sometime in the future. No date has been set, according to Richard Giordano, the chairman. At an award program on Saturday night, Philippe Jeantot of France, who finished first in overall time and first in Class 1 for boats of 50 to 60 feet, received $15,000. Mike Plant of Jamestown, N.Y., took first in Class 2, for boats of 40-50 feet. Titouan Lamazou, another Frenchman, received $10,000 for finishing second in Class 1. Jean Luc Van Den Heede, also of France, received $10,000 as skipper of the top unsponsored boat.

title: PHIL NIEKRO HELPS SET MARK
description: Phil Niekro ended his five-game losing streak tonight as the Cleveland Indians beat the Detroit Tigers, 9-6, giving Niekro and his brother Joe a major-league record of 530 combined victories.

title: AIDS CASELOAD BURDENS 2 NEW YORK AGENCIES
description: Two New York City welfare and hospital agencies said yesterday that they were overburdened with the rising AIDS caseload.

title: West German Officials Call Flight 'Foolhardy'
description: The West German Government today called the episode in which a Hamburg youth made a landing near Red Square in Moscow a foolhardy action that could have had tragic consequences.

title: Advertising; Show Business Luring Adman
description: Just before his 45th birthday, which is Thursday, Marshall Karp, creative director of Lowe Marschalk, has opted for a second career.

title: SOFTWARE GIANTS PLAN MERGER
description: The leading supplier of mainframe computer software, Computer Associates International Inc., said yesterday that it would acquire the second-biggest company in the field, the Uccel Corporation, in a stock swap valued at $779.5 million.

title: THE COMPANY LINE: A C.I.A. STATION CHIEF DESCRIBES ASSISTANCE TO CONTRAS
description: The joint Congressional committee holding hearings on the Iran-contra affair today made public a transcript of testimony given in closed session on Friday by Joe Fernandez, the Central Intelligence Agency station chief in Costa Rica. Following are excerpts from the transcript; some material was deleted by C.I.A. censors before the transcript was made public. A Juggling Act

title: Delta Sets Seoul Flights
description: Delta Air Lines plans to start regular service between Atlanta and Seoul in the fall, a Transportation Ministry statement said today. It said the Atlanta-based carrier was seeking permission to operate six flights a week between the two cities via Portland, Ore., and Tokyo.

title: Salvador Amnesty Offer
description: President Jose Napoleon Duarte offered amnesty today to political prisoners and leftist guerrillas who join the democratic process. Mr. Duarte, in a speech marking the start of his fourth year in office, gave no details of the amnesty plan, and there was no immediate response from the various rebel groups that form the Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front. In 1983, 540 political prisoners and 224 guerrillas accepted a two-month amnesty offer. Since then all releases have been through prisoner exchanges.

title: O'NEILL'S QUIET STYLE REFLECTS A CONTENTED CONNECTICUT
description: When a 10-day strike shutting down nearly all highway work in Connecticut was settled last week, the man considered the catalyst behind the agreement shied away from the television cameras and stayed in his office.

title: Bias Trial Hears Defense
description: Defense attorneys in the trial of Brian Tribble, the man accused of providing Len Bias with the cocaine that killed him, opened their case with two witnesses today.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Stung by the unexpected resignation of Dick Motta and spurned in their attempts to hire Don Nelson, the Dallas Mavericks interviewed the former Phoenix Suns' coach, John MacLeod, yesterday, but he said it could be a week before he gets another call. . . . The Los Angeles Rams' owner and president, Georgia Frontiere, announced that Coach John Robinson's contract has been extended by four years. . . . Larry Parrish, who batted .393 and drove in 35 runs for the Texas Rangers in May, has been named American League Player of the Month. . . . Ron Hassey, the Chicago White Sox catcher, ruptured a muscle in his left arm and will be lost to the club for at least two months following surgery, the team said. . . . Joe Namath, the Hall of Fame quarterback, has joined NBC as a National Football League analyst, the network announced. He will be paired with the play-by-play announcer, Marv Albert, on N.F.L. broadcasts next season. . . . Billy Martin, the 6-7 forward from Georgetown's 1984 N.C.A.A. championship team, and Dirk Minniefield, the 6-3 guard out of Kentucky who started 52 games for the Houston Rockets last season, have signed to play with the Staten Island Stallions of the United States Basketball League. . . . Luis Aguayo, the Philadelphia shortstop who strained a thigh muscle Sunday in Los Angeles, was placed on the Phillies' 15-day disabled list.

title: Argentina Steps Backward
description: LEAD: Capt. Alfredo Astiz, accused of murdering a teen-age girl and two French nuns - of being one of the most infamous torturers in Argentina's history - would go forever free and unpunished under the so-called due obedience bill that the Argentine Senate passed last Friday.

title: R.J. Reynolds Cancels Sale
description: The R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company said today that 16 million cigarettes containing more herbicide than is allowed by American law would not be sold in Japan, where they were shipped, or anywhere else. Reynolds said the Winston

title: Ali Gets the Boot
description: What becomes a boxing legend most? Well, if you are trying to sell shoe polish, nothing less than full, nationwide distribution in all of a retail sales chain's outlets. That is the position taken by a company known as Muhammad Ali's Champion Brand Industries, which last week staged a media event at K Mart's annual shareholders' meeting. It happened last Tuesday when the former world heavyweight champion - accompanied by the motorcycle daredevil, Evel Knievel, and the president of the Ali shoe polish concern - stalked into a packed auditorium at K Mart headquarters in Troy, Mich. The three shoe-polish advocates arrived in a convoy of police-escorted white limousines. Neither the champion nor his business adviser, Arthur Morrison, deigned to address the gathering. However, Evel Knievel read a short statement protesting K Mart's recent decision to suspend distribution of Ali's shoe polish in all of its 2,200 stores.

title: ANTI-JAPAN TRADE BARS REVIEWED
description: The President's top economic policy team met today to examine reports that could persuade the President to remove or relax the trade sanctions that he imposed on imports of $300 million in Japanese goods, officials disclosed today. ''We may have something to say in the next day or two,'' an American trade official said.

title: APRIL PACE OF BUILDING GREW 0.4%
description: Construction spending edged up four-tenths of 1 percent in April as weakness in government and residential projects was offset by gains in construction of shopping centers and factories, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: 9 Are Injured as Sidewalk Grating Collapses Outside Brooklyn Court
description: Nine people who had been removed from the Criminal Court building in Brooklyn after a bomb threat yesterday were injured when part of a sidewalk on which they were standing collapsed.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: MOSCOW 2042. By Vladimir Voinovich.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: LAST week, most short skirts at Bonwit Teller's flagship store on East 57th Street were still at 23 to 25 inches, just above the knee and just about 4 inches longer than skirts other stores were selling. But change is stirring the specialty-store chain's formerly stuffy air, since it was sold last month to the Hooker Corporation, an Australian real-estate development company.

title: PROFITS OF SHUFFLING A CREW
description: In most team sports, changing the lineup, replacing one athlete with another, is not so unusual. But with an eight-oared crew, it represents upheaval. And woe to the coach if change fails to increase speed.

title: Field Workers Strike Education Association
description: Field organizers for the National Education Association went on strike against the union today in a dispute over salaries, pensions and what the strikers contend is a management attempt to take back existing benefits.

title: Why the Food Initiative for Mozambique
description: To the Editor:

title: Two Rhinoceroses Due
description: The capital will become richer by two one-horned or Asian rhinoceroses tomorrow when Prince Gyanendra of Nepal presents the pair to the National Zoo. The number of Asian rhinos has declined 84 percent since 1970 because of illegal hunting and loss of habitat, according to the World Wildlife Fund.

title: 30 YEARS LATE, SOVIET'S UNION OF WRITERS HONORS PASTERNAK
description: Lidiya Chukovskaya, who was expelled from the Soviet Union of Writers 13 years ago for defending two outcast authors, Boris Pasternak and Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn, emerged from official obscurity this weekend to take part in the first official ceremonies in the Soviet Union to honor Pasternak.

title: ABRAMS TODAY: WHAT TO LOOK FOR
description: Friends of Elliott Abrams, the State Department's combative Assistant Secretary for Inter-American Affairs, say he has an unusual zest for a good argument.

title: TOSHIBA CASE DELAYS U.S. CONTRACTS
description: The Defense Department has delayed the award of several electronic and computer contracts until Japan completes its investigation of the Toshiba Corporation's role in a diversion of high-technology goods to the Soviet Union, Pentagon officials said yesterday.

title: HELPING HAND IS OFFERED TO MAN WHO SAVED A LIFE
description: Gonzalo Delgado, a bread-truck driver and Special Forces veteran of Vietnam, may have lost a 12-speed bicycle to a thief, but he found a lot of friends.

title: Calvin Klein Officer Goes to Leslie Fay
description: Joel H. Newman has left as president of Calvin Klein Industries to join the Leslie Fay Company as vice chairman and chief operating officer.

title: REAGAN TO PRESS ALLIES ON GULF SHIPPING
description: President Reagan indicated today that he would press Western allies at the Venice economic summit meeting to become involved in the efforts by the United States to protect ship movements in the Persian Gulf.

title: GRAND JURY HEARS MEESE ON LOBBYING
description: Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d testified today before a Federal grand jury investigating actions taken by him and a former White House aide, Lyn C. Nofziger, in behalf of the Wedtech Corporation, a military contractor linked to scandals.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Golf Gary Player and Douglass Share Title: Gary Player shook off a bogey on the 17th hole to sink an 8-foot birdie putt on No. 18 yesterday to tie Dale Douglass for the championship of the first Iowa Seniors Golf Classic at Des Moines. The two PGA Senior Tour members each shot a 1-under-par 71 at the wind-swept Wakonda Club and won $5,250 each. Gay Brewer finished at even-par 72, while Billy Capser, Lee Elder and Bob Brue were next at 73. Douglass birdied the final two holes, then quickly returned to his home in Colorado. Player, who was last on the course, finished more than an hour later. Because a playoff wasn't possible, Douglass and Player split the total first- and second-place money from the $30,000 purse. Player appeared to be out of the running when he hit his tee shot over the green on the par 3, 171-yard 17th hole. He ended up with a 4, which put him at even par. But, he recovered quickly. His second shot on the par-4 hole from about 90 yards away landed 8 feet from the cup and he rolled his putt directly into the middle of the hole for the birdie. Douglass sank a 3-foot putt for his birdie on 18 and was left with an easy putt on No. 17 after using a 6-iron to drop his tee shot 4 feet from the cup.(AP) Horse Racing Bold Mate Wins at Belmont: Bold Mate, a stakes-winning 3-year-old filly making her first start since Feb. 7, caught Shiering Gal, the heavy favorite, and went on to a three-length victory in the featured Cresta purse yesterday. Rajiste was second to complete a $107.80 exacta, and Shivering Gal faded to third, 1 1/2 lengths behind the runner-up. Bold Mate, who took the Busanda Stakes at Aqueduct Jan. 11, won for the sixth time in 11 career starts. The daughter of Nasty and Bold and the Verbatim mare Idiomatic, owned by the Meadowhill Stable and trained by Richard Dutrow, paid $9.40 for $2 to win and covered the six furlongs in 1:11 3/5 under Jose Santos.

title: ASSEMBLY PASSES BROAD ELECTION LAW
description: The State Assembly today approved broad legislation that would reduce the maximum contributions individuals can make to candidates for state office, and provide public campaign financing for candidates in New York's primary and general elections.

title: Chess: Dlugy Shows the Difference Between Banking and Chess
description: Europe's newest international tournament, the Volksbank Open, in Bern, was won by Maxim Dlugy of Leonia, N.J. The 21-year-old grandmaster scored 7 1/2- 1/2 to top a Swiss-system field of 100 players that included 5 grandmasters and 13 international masters.

title: Justices Seek Oil Tax View
description: The Supreme Court today asked the Reagan Administration for its view of a ruling that states may tax income derived from the sale of oil extracted from the outer continental shelf.

title: General Electric
description: A new assembly line to produce General Electric brand television sets at the Bloomington RCA plant has begun operation. The new assembly line follows a decision in February to move production of 500,000 G.E. brand color television sets to the Bloomington plant from Japan. The company said the plant's RCA brand production schedule had not been affected by the decision to assemble the G.E. sets in Bloomington.

title: ONE WEST BANK PLAN: MIX CONCRETE AND YUPPIES
description: Ron Nachman's critics call him a one-man obstacle to peace. His neighbors just call him Mayor, friend and ''hey, you.'' He calls himself a simple pioneer for the Likud bloc, Israel's large nationalist party.

title: Holocaust Monument Defaced by Swastikas
description: A Holocaust monument was defaced with swastikas today, one day after its dedication to six million Jews and other victims of the Nazis during World War II.

title: The Coloring of Bird
description: On the eve of this championship series that makes the basketball fan tingle with expectation - another in the enduring, bruising Laker-Celtic series, the clash of Magic and Bird, the hobbling Parish and McHale who maybe should be in traction versus the quadragenarian Jabbar, the numerous Coopers who seem to reproduce themselves on the court versus D. J., of whom there is only one, and who is rarely anywhere except in the right place at the right time - with all this, an unfortunate note has been raised.

title: ALFRED A. GROSS
description: Alfred A. Gross, a former ethics professor and founder of the George W. Henry Foundation, which provided job training and legal assistance to the indigent, died of a heart attack Thursday at St. Luke's Hospital. He was 91 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: BELMONT GETS MYSTERY HORSE
description: It just wouldn't have felt like a Belmont Stakes without an 11th-hour mystery horse, and a pair of owners from Suffolk Downs obliged yesterday by announcing they will run a colt named Manassa Jack in the final leg of the Triple Crown Saturday.

title: Boeing to Acquire Argosystems Inc.
description: In a bid to gain a larger share of the lucrative military contract business, the Boeing Company said today that it would acquire Argosystems Inc. of Sunnyvale Calif., a manufacturer of defense electronics systems, for about $275 million.

title: CULTIVATING CONTCTS AT GRASS ROOTS
description: The Presidential candidate has been invited to visit a high school. He has been invited to many high schools already in the early stages of this primary campaign. He has accepted this invitation.

title: EX-TEAMSTER CHIEF TELLS JURY MAFIA CONTROLS UNION LEADERS
description: A jury heard testimony yesterday from Roy L. Williams, a former president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, who admitted being controlled by a top leader of the Mafia.

title: The U.N. Today: June 2, 1987
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Advertising; Canada Dry Pursues More Mature Audience
description: There is no talk. An attractive man and an attactive woman, both unsmiling and serious, begin to undress slowly. The camera does not intrude long enough to be improper, just long enough to catch her having a sip of Canada Dry Ginger Ale. Then it leaves the room to show us two youngsters in nightclothes staring at their parents' closed bedroom door.

title: 'THERE WERE TIMES'
description: ON WNET at 10 o'clock this evening, ''There Were Times, Dear'' is such a small and modest production that the long -and only partial - list of financial contributors in the final credits might seem puzzling. But the hourlong drama is about Alzheimer's disease and the executive producer, Linda Hope, had to struggle long and hard for financing. Getting Shirley Jones and Len Cariou to play the leads helped considerably. ''There Were Times, Dear,'' produced by Flora Lang and directed by Nancy Malone, was made as a project of the American Film Institute's Women in Film Foundation. The list of major contributors is headed by Sandoz Pharmaceuticals (Harry Cauley's script notes in passing that although the disease is still uncurable, some drugs can be helpful in treatment).

title: GULF & WESTERN INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
CALNY INC reports earnings for Year to Feb 24
description: b-Includes a loss of $4,316,893 from discontinued operations. c-Net income and after a loss of $374,456 from discontinued operations. The company said the loss for the latest quarter resulted from several non-recurring accounting adjustments primarily to reflect anticipated losses in connection with the proposed sale of all of the company's Seattle- area Taco Bell restaurants and La Petite Boulangerie bakeries.

title: Surgery for Slaney
description: Mary Slaney, the distance-running star, underwent arthroscopic surgery on her right Achilles' tendon yesterday, forcing her out of the Prefontaine Classic Saturday. She underwent surgery on the same tendon last November. Slaney, who holds the American women's record at every distance from 800 through 10,000 meters, hasn't had a major track race since she dropped out of the sport two and a half years ago for the birth of her daughter.

title: GEPHARDT ON THE ECONOMY
description: One of Representative Richard A. Gephardt's surest applause lines is, ''We're going to have another arms race with the Soviets, and the Japanese are going to win it.''

title: Motion to Block Viacom Bid Denied
description: Viacom International Inc. said a Federal District Court in Manhattan had denied a motion to block its proposed $3.4 billion buyout by a subsidiary of Sumner M. Redstone's National Amusements Inc.

There is none of the normally serene and rather austere atmosphere of the school, which is on the third floor of the Juilliard School building at Lincoln Center. There is speculation about whether Mikhail Baryshnikov, director of the American Ballet Theater, chose any school dancers at a recent audition for the company. title: Arrow Kills Pregnant Woman

The arrow that killed Jewel Foster Lyles, who was nine months pregnant, was launched from the bow of Andre William, who intended to shoot a man with whom he had been quarreling, the police said. Mrs. Lyles's baby, unharmed by the arrow, was delivered by Caesarean section and died today of respiratory complications at Johns Hopkins Hospital, a spokesman said. Mr. William, 20 years old, was charged by the police with first-degree murder and attempted murder on a baby.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: TO THE SARGASSO SEA. By William McPherson. 461 pages. Simon & Schuster. $18.95. IN his graceful first novel, ''Testing the Current'' (1984), William McPherson looked at pre-World War II America through the watchful, curious eyes of an 8-year old boy named Tommy MacAllister. The upper-class, Midwestern realm of his parents is an old-fashioned world, where genteel hypocrisy cloaks adultery and racial bigotry, where decorous manners enable everyone to hold onto the illusion of their innocence. While Tommy is warned about the perils of venturing too quickly into the complexities of the grown-up world - represented by the swirling rapids of the neighboring river - the novel ends with his venturing, tentatively, ''into the currents of time.''

At the time, no records were kept for yards rushing in one half of an N.C.A.A. Division III game, but his yardage total was only 63 yards short of the record for an entire game.
