description: The effort to revise the welfare law, despite earlier talk of sweeping changes and broad agreement, has come up against the realities of budget constraint and political conflict.

title: Gerace Confirmed for Post
description: The former State Agriculture Commissioner, Joseph Gerace, was unanimously confirmed today by the State Senate as director of the newly created State Office of Rural Affairs. Mr. Gerace was nominated by Governor Cuomo in January after he resigned as Agriculture Commissioner during a dispute over the licensing of a New Jersey company to sell milk in New York City. Mr. Gerace, who is 59 years old, is a former Chautauqua County Executive. He had been Agriculture Commissioner since 1983.

title: COMPANY NEWS;
description: The McDonnell Douglas Aerospace Corporation said it had been awarded a $480 million contract to test a neutral particle-beam weapon in space in the early 1990's as part of the Strategic Defense Initiative.

title: SENATE REPUBLICANS PROPOSE CURBS ON PAC'S
description: In a move to reduce support for a Democratic bill calling for public financing of Senate campaigns, Senate Republicans today introduced a measure that would ban political action committees from contributing to candidates for Congress.

title: CROP GENETICS INTERNAIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
ZIM ENERGY reports earnings for Year to Jan 31
description: b-Includes writeoff of $1.5 million in costs, mainly associates with an unsuccessful merger plan. The year-ago results are for the period ended Dec. 31. The company changed its fiscal year to Jan. 31 from Dec. 31.

title: WIESEL TESTIFIES AT BARBIE'S TRIAL
description: The writer Elie Wiesel testified at the trial of Klaus Barbie here today, speaking to the judges and jury of personal memories of Auschwitz, of the silence of millions of victims and of what he called the unique nature of the Nazi campaign to wipe out the Jews.

title: Sales Under Pressure After Volcker's Action
description: With bond prices pushed sharply lower by the news of Paul A. Volcker's resignation as chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, corporate debt sales came under pressure yesterday.

title: STAGED 'OLIVER' ON BROADWAY
description: Peter Coe, a British director who reached a career peak in 1961 when he had three hits running simultaneously in London's West End - ''The Miracle Worker,'' ''The World of Suzie Wong'' and ''Oliver!'' - was killed in an automobile accident in England on May 25, his family disclosed. He was 59 years old.

title: DAWSON DRIVES IN 7 AS CUBS WIN, 13-2
description: Andre Dawson drove in seven runs with two home runs, a triple and a single and made two outstanding defensive plays as the Chicago Cubs routed the Houston Astros, 13-2, today.

title: DIANA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 28
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $1,043,000 for the latest year and an extraordinary loss of $1,119,000 for the year-earlier period; the year-earlier period also includes net of $84,000 from discontinued operations.

title: Factory Orders Up 0.2%; Military Purchases Rise
description: An increase in military purchases enabled factory orders for manufactured goods to edge up two-tenths of 1 percent in April, the smallest gain in three months, the Commerce Department said today.

title: IN HIS 8 TURBULENT YEARS, VOLCKER SEEMED MORE ADEPT AT CRISIS CONTROL THAN REFORM
description: Paul A. Volcker's legacy is an economy that he freed from its worst predicament since the Depression - the long-brewing inflation that had turned virulent as he was taking office at the end of the 1970's. The durability of Mr. Volcker's contributions as chairman of the Federal Reserve Board for eight years is uncertain. He has proved an astute political gamesman and crisis manager, not a reformer. With real success, he battled the gyrations of the dollar, the crises over Latin American debt and the collapse of the Continental Illinois National Bank three years ago.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: DEANNA WENBLE gave a small dinner party the other evening. There was an abundance of leftovers, and she thought it would be a good idea to share them with some of the homeless people on Madison Avenue in her neighborhood. With care and concern, she made tidy packages of the food.

title: Tokyo, Bonn Firm on Rates
description: Japan and West Germany are not planning further interest rate cuts, officials said today, despite the pressure for reductions expected at next week's summit meeting in Venice.

title: Baruch College
description: Baruch College of the City University of New York conferred 1,689 undergraduate and 498 graduate degrees at its commencement yesterday, held at the Felt Forum of Madison Square Garden.

title: FABRI-CENTERS OF AMERICA INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 2
description: b-Includes an after-tax gain of $209,000 from the sale of closed store leases.

title: LAKE TO BE A STATE PARK, ENDING A 17-YEAR BATTLE
description: Governor Cuomo marked the end of a 17-year struggle over Lake Minnewaska today by accepting the deed to the 32-acre glacial lake and its unspoiled surroundings as part of the state park system.

title: Keep the Indian Museum in New York
description: When the Smithsonian Institution recently announced it would try to acquire New York's Museum of the American Indian, Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan said he hoped the bid would finally ''concentrate [ the ] minds'' of New Yorkers on finding a new home for the museum here. It looks as if nothing short of moving vans at the rear of the museum will do that.

title: PETRIE STORES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 2
description: The year-ago first quarter results include operations of Miller-Wohl Co. and Winkelman Stores Inc. for a 14- week period, compared with a 13- week period in the latest first quarter as a result of the company's change in its fiscal year to a 52-53-week fiscal year ending the Saturday closest to Jan. 31.

title: BILDNER, J & SONS reports earnings for Qtr to April 19
Bonn Subsidies For Airbus Jets
description: West Germany will announce Wednesday that it will give Airbus Industrie, the European aircraft consortium, new subsidies worth nearly $2.7 billion, official sources said today. The announcement, which has been expected, would remove the last obstacle to a new program opposed by the United States.

title: On Courage and Frailty in Engineers
description: Samuel C. Florman, a civil engineer, has earned a following for writing sensitively about the profession, and art, of engineering. This is from his latest book, ''The Civilized Engineer.''

title: PRAB ROBOTS reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net income

title: B. Altman Promotion
description: Fisher, Jackson, Levy, Flaxman is the agency behind ''The Men of Summer'' ad campaign that will be promoting B. Altman's on TV tomorrow through June 19. The three commercials will be used on five TV stations and in conjunction with the campaign the store will be staging such special events in the men's store as windsurfing, sailing and golf demonstrations.

title: MOLDER OF U.S. BUSINESSMEN
description: Georges Frederic Doriot, a professor at the Harvard Business School for four decades who was widely credited with inspiring and training more leaders of American corporations than any other person, died of lung cancer in Boston yesterday. He was 87 years old and lived in Boston.

title: Off We Go . . .
description: Air Force Secretary Edward C. Aldridge has just ordered the restoration of a cherished token for his combat pilots: the leather flight jacket of yesteryear. Dropped from the regulation uniforms worn by pilots some time ago, the jackets, which can cost more than $200, are being reintroduced as a morale booster. In an interview, Mr. Aldridge, who has been Air Force Secretary for about a year, said he is troubled by trends now being seen in the recruitment and retention of pilots. The jackets are just one part of a plan to keep more experienced pilots in service, he said. The Air Force also hopes to be able to pay pilots more, since the main competition comes from civil airlines, which offer higher salaries. Mr. Aldridge said that retention of pilots with seven to 11 years of service has dropped significantly below the 60 percent mark, and that this necessitates training new pilots at a time when the pool of young men is shrinking.

title: New-Home Sales Rose 7.6% in April
description: New-home sales soared 7.6 percent in April, the Government reported today, in what analysts said was a panic response by buyers to close deals in anticipation of higher mortgage rates.

title: F.D.A. ASKED TO CHANGE FIBER LABELING RULES
description: A consumer organization has petitioned the Food and Drug Administration to require that nutrition labels on prepared foods include the dietary fiber content. The consumer group, the Center for Science in the Public Interest, noted that both the Surgeon General and the National Cancer Institute had urged Americans to consume more dietary fiber, such as that found in whole wheat. The group said that the public had no reliable way of knowing how much fiber was present in foods and said that many products listed crude rather than dietary fiber, which is an inaccurate and obsolete measure. The measurement for crude fiber fails to account for the kind of fiber that can be utilized by the body.

title: PHILLIPS-VAN HEUSEN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 3
description: The company said the latest first quarter net included a decrease in pension expenses of $879,000 pretax from an accounting change and a decrease in interest expense of $382,000 from a loan prepayment. It also said it had a pre-tax LIFO charge of $1,461,000 in the latest quarter, compared with a LIFO credit for the year-ago period. The amount of the credit was unavailable.

title: U.S. WARSHIPS TO SET SAIL FOR GULF DUTY
description: The Pentagon said today that a fleet of Navy ships, including three vessels bound for the Persian Gulf, would sail from East Coast ports on Friday and Saturday.

title: British Currency Reserves Up
description: Britain's currency reserves rose by $4.76 billion in May, reflecting the Bank of England's strong buying of dollars in an effort to support the United States currency and keep the value of the pound from rising too quickly.

title: TIMBERLAND INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $30,000. c-Net loss and after a loss from discontinued operations of $54,000.

title: ONCOR INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Strength, and Promise, at the Fed
description: If the Federal Reserve Board has to have a new chairman, President Reagan could not have made a better choice than Alan Greenspan. Paul Volcker's departure is disappointing, but not a disaster. No one can immediately match his stature or depth of experience. But Mr. Greenspan has judgment and intellect, tested by public and private responsibilities.

title: Markets Shocked By Volcker
description: Paul A. Volcker's decision to step down as Federal Reserve chairman yesterday shocked the financial markets, sending bond prices into a tailspin as the dollar fell sharply.

title: JERSEY COMPANY SETS DEADLINE ON NBC LAND DEAL
description: The company that is seeking to lure NBC to Secaucus, N.J., has given the network until the end of this month to decide if it wants to complete the deal.

title: COMP-U-CARD INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $1,197,000. Year-ago results do not include certain companies that were acquired during 1986.

title: SOSNOFF RAISES BID FOR CAESARS WORLD
description: For the second time since starting a bid to take control of Caesars World Inc. in March, the Wall Street investor Martin T. Sosnoff has raised his offer to the company's investors, to $35 a share in cash and equity securities.

title: Wilbur Evans Is Dead; A Singer on Broadway
description: Wilbur Evans, a singer and actor who starred opposite Mary Martin in the London production of ''South Pacific,'' died Sunday at his home in Mullica Hill, N.J. He was 81 years old.

title: A Shift on Unesco?
description: Prince Sadruddin Aga Khan, the uncle of the current Aga Khan, the spiritual leader of millions of Moslems of the Ismaili sect, largely in India, Iran and Kenya, has emerged as a favorite among United States officials to become the next Director General of the United Nations Scientific, Educational and Cultural Organization, or Unesco.

title: TEXAS AMERICAN ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Bill Would Put Insurers Under Antitrust Law
description: A coalition of consumer, labor and banking groups and leading Democratic senators gave their support today to a proposal to end the insurance industry's 42-year-old exemption from Federal antitrust law.

title: Dallas Police Officials Urge Outside Evaluation of Work
description: Administrators of the Dallas Police Department are recommending that a team of outsiders, including a psychologist and an expert in firearms, review the department's training and policies on the use of deadly force.

title: BURLINGTON COAT FACTORY WAREHOUSE reports earnings for Qtr to May 2
Queens College
description: Queens College conferred 2,500 bachelor of arts and graduate degrees at its 63d commencement on the campus quadrangle in Flushing.

title: A TASTY OLIVE IS A WARM OLIVE
description: DO not worry about particles or clouds in olive brine; they are normal. Do not store olives in the refrigerator, for they do not taste as good cole. Keep them at room temperature covered with oil, except for the wrinkled Thasos olives. These should be kept in a cool cupboard in a tightly closed jar.

title: WHITTAKER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net loss and includes losses from discontinued operations of $3,056,000 for the quarter and $4,873,000 for the 6 months.

title: SOUTH KOREA PARTY CHOOSES SUCCESSOR FOR THE PRESIDENCY
description: President Chun Doo Hwan has chosen Roh Tae Woo, a close associate, as the ruling party's candidate to be his successor, a presidential spokeman said today.

title: VILLAGE SUPER MARKET INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 18
Productivity Rises Slightly
description: The productivity of the nation's businesses improved slightly during the first quarter - but much less than previously thought, the Government said today.

title: CML GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to May 2
MOB PROSECUTORS ARE DENOUNCED
description: Defense attorneys at the Federal trial of Angelo Ruggiero, a reputed Mafia ''capo,'' and nine other defendants attacked the Government's case yesterday, asserting it was based on speculation, misleading fragments of recorded conversations and the testimony of untrustworthy witnesses.

title: Rainier Makes Provision for Losses
description: The Rainier Bancorporation, following larger banking companies, said today that it would add $58 million to its reserve for possible losses on loans to developing countries. The provision is expected to produce a second-quarter loss of about $19 million.

title:
WITH WEAK DOLLAR, THE COST GOES UP FOR DINING ABROAD;
PARIS
description: LEAD: EUROPE remains a favorite summer destination for many Americans, and dining well remains a favorite occupation when they get there. Happily, restaurants on the Continent are as good and as numerous as ever. What has changed this year is their value. Unhappily, Americans looking forward to a memorable meal at their favorite Michelin two-star can count on paying more for it than at any other time in the last few years.

title: Sikh Bomb Kills 4 in India
description: A bomb being planted by a Sikh extremist exploded outside a movie house today, killing 4 people and wounding 10, the police said. A police spokesman said the Sikh was among those killed at Jullundur in Punjab state, where Sikh extremists are fighting to secede from India.

title: MACDERMID INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
William Feinberg, 87, A City Center Founder
description: William Feinberg, a founder of City Center who served for 15 years as an official of Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians, died Saturday at Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 87 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: GEPHARDT LOOKING BEYONG TRADE ISSUE
description: Representative Richard A. Gephardt, a Democratic Presidential hopeful, traveled through some of the most affluent circles in California a few days ago and talked about the challenge of reviving the nation's economy.

title: Lear Siegler Unit
description: Lear Siegler Inc. has agreed to sell its Peerless Division to a group of managers and private investors in a leveraged buyout, a company executive said today. The president of Peerless, Bart Hoemann, said the sale awaited approval by the company's board. The private investors are led by Sequoia, a leveraged-buyout firm based in San Mateo, Calif., he said. Terms were not disclosed.

title: U.S. Shifting the Way It Limits Air Pollution
description: The Environmental Protection Agency is revising its clean air standards, tightening the limits on small particles in the atmosphere.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: WEDNESDAY, JUNE 3, 1987
description: International A3-15

title: Netherlands Dance Theater
description: The Netherlands Dance Theater, under the direction of Jiri Kylian, will begin a weeklong engagement at the Metropolitan Opera House on June 22. All of the dances on the program have been choreographed by Mr. Kylian and, with the exception of ''Les Noces,'' are United States premieres. Other works in the repertory are ''Heart's Labyrinth,'' ''Six Dances,'' ''Silent Cries,'' ''L'Enfant et les Sortileges,'' ''L'Histoire du Soldat'' and ''Stamping Ground.'' The opening night performance begins at 7 P.M. Tickets range from $7 to $40. Information: 363-6000.

title: Anderson Ends Career
description: The Cincinnati Bengals' quarterback, Ken Anderson, a four-time selection to the Pro Bowl, also announced his retirement yesterday after a record-setting 16-year career. Anderson, 38 years old, said a medical examination three weeks ago showed that his right shoulder had deteriorated in the last year and that he could risk permanent damage.

title: WEBB, DEL E INVESTMENT PROPERTIES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Complete the Missile Treaty
description: West Germany's imminent acceptance of the Soviet Union's pro-posal to eliminate shorter-range missiles in Europe should provide new impetus to complete a treaty on intermediate-range nuclear forces. Such a treaty numerically favors the West and would make a modest but important contribution to the security of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. Yet ultraconservatives and former statesmen (many of them nominally in favor of arms control) will undoubtedly continue to criticize the deal. Why?

title: Panel Gets Testimony By Levine
description: Members of a Congressional subcommittee investigating the insider-trading scandals on Wall Street said today that they would focus their inquiry on the role of Dennis B. Levine's supervisors at the Wall Street firms where he worked.

title: CHEFS: CHARITY FIND OF THE YEAR
description: WHEN Zachary Bruell opened his restaurant in Cleveland he devoted the first four nights to raising money for cancer research in memory of his father, who was to have been his partner. Emotionally, he said, the benefit made the opening easier; it also helped introduce Z-Contemporary Cuisine.

title: Help Wanted: Ex-Fed Chief
description: Because of the prestige his name carries and his access to senior decision-makers around the globe, Paul A. Volcker would be an enormously valuable asset to any number of universities or corporations, especially a financial institution. In the last several years, Mr. Volcker has been approached by a number of financial institutions and universities. And several Wall Street executives said yesterday that Mr. Volcker would be hotly pursued by a number of leading Wall Street firms. The executives said that Mr. Volcker could easily command a salary of far more than $1 million a year, in addition to large amounts of stock in the firms. They added that, in the international realm, where securities firms have been spending heavily to expand, Mr. Volcker could provide a decisive advantage.

title: Chicagoan in Austria Seized as Nazi Suspect
description: The Austrian police said today that they had arrested Martin Bartesch, a Chicago janitor who came to Austria after American officials charged him with having been an SS guard in a Nazi death camp.

title: This Board Needs Correcting
description: More than ever, New York City's jails need an active watchdog to uphold standards as officials try to cope with dangerous overcrowding. The agency in place to play that monitoring role, the Board of Correction, has been behaving more like a lapdog than a watchdog.

title: Best Seat in Sports
description: Adrian Dantley tried to push himself up from the floor, his eyes fluttering as some deep corner of his competitor's mind told him there was still a game to be played.

title: Coors's Cutbacks
description: After a first-quarter report that indicated sales were below projections, the Adolph Coors Company has imposed a hiring freeze. The freeze began May 15 in Coors's brewing division, which then had 5,931 employees, a company spokesman said. While falling behind projections, Coors's first-quarter shipments of 3.05 million barrels were 2.8 percent higher than during the corresponding period last year. In 1986, the company produced a record 15.24 million barrels of beer.

title: Fatemeh Pahlevi Dies at 58, A Half Sister to Shah of Iran
description: Princess Fatemeh Pahlevi, half sister of the Shah of Iran, has died in London, the Daily Telegraph reported today. She was 58 years old.

title: Letter to the President
description: Following is the text of Paul A. Volcker's letter to President Reagan, announcing he planned to resign as the Federal Reserve Board's chairman when a successor is ready to take over:

title: Cuba Asks U.S. to Return Boy Brought by Defecting Father
description: The Cuban Government has asked the United States to return the 15-year-old son of an air force general who defected to the United States last week, diplomats said today.

title: WOMEN'S CAUCUS PUSHES FOR BENEFITS
description: The Congressional Caucus on Women's Issues today introduced a legislative package aimed at improving job opportunities, salaries and benefits for working women and their families.

title: IRAN DEPLOYS HIGH-SPEED CRAFT IN GULF
description: Iran, increasingly belligerent over Kuwait's effort to obtain superpower protection for its oil tankers, has supplied its Revolutionary Guards with a fleet of fast cabin cruisers, complicating the defense of Persian Gulf shipping.

title: Hanson Trust Net Up
description: Hanson Trust P.L.C., one of Britain's largest companies, said today that its profits virtually doubled in the first half of its financial year after aggressive expansions on both sides of the Atlantic. Hanson Trust is a conglomerate with interests ranging from bricks to batteries, garden tools, furniture, shoes, clothes and hot dogs. Pretax profits jumped to $:312 million, or the equivalent of $508 million, in the six months to the end of March, from $:158 million a year earlier. Sales were worth $:3.47 billion ($5.66 billion) in the six months, up from $:1.55 billion a year earlier.

title: BUSH REPORT SEES GAIN ON TERRORISM
description: A special committee headed by Vice President Bush reported today that ''progress has been excellent'' in the battle against terrorism and that credibility lost by America as a result of the Iran-contra affair had been renewed.

title: WHAT THE DESK CLERK SAW: HISTORY IN THE LOBBY
description: There is only one place in Nicaragua where foreign guerrillas conspire over breakfast, journalists trade rumors at lunch, diplomats give evening receptions and adventurers of all kinds tell outrageous stories late into the night.

title: Japan-Europe Trade Tension
description: Japan is disappointed at recent threats of trade retaliation from the European Community just as the situation is improving, Hajime Tamura, the Japanese trade minister, said today.

title: 'LIFE IN THE FAST LANE,' FACT AND FANCY
description: THERE'S plenty of avoirdupois jiggling through ''Life in the Fat Lane,'' a lightweight treatment of overweight that can be seen on Channel 4 tonight at 10. It massages the subject for a mildly stimulating hour. Connie Chung, the narrator, lays out the figures - 34 million Americans are overweight and millions of others think they are, and they are spending millions of dollars a year to do battle with their fat cells.

title: 'Cop II' Retains Lead In Box Office Sales
description: ''Beverly Hills Cop II,'' starring Eddie Murphy, held on to the top spot at the box office for the second week in a row, earning $17 million to bring its two-week gross to a total of $64.8 million.

title: SHULTZ FORSEES NATO UNITY ON MISSILE PACT
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that Western nations would forge a common position on a new treaty to eliminate medium-range and short-range missiles during a meeting of NATO foreign ministers next week.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: AS one of millions of children whose parents and grandparents were all too familiar with hunger and deprivation, I was a constant concern to my family because of my leanness and picky eating habits. My grandmother was especially persistent in her efforts to fatten me up, offering me sticks of butter, packages of Velveeta, cans of evaporated milk and double-decker ice cream cones at every opportunity, none of which added even a fraction of an inch to pinch on my skin-and-bones body.

title: THE STAGE: 'MOVING ON'
description: ED HEATH'S amiably ramshackle musical, ''We're Moving On,'' folds a comic folk tale into a gospel service to make a show in which vaudevillian playfulness and gospel fervor become thoroughly intermingled. Exuberantly performed at La Mama E.T.C. by an 11-person cast whose members belong to the Arena Players, a 34-year-old, Baltimore-based black theater organization, ''We're Moving On'' presents a broad comic cross-section of parishioners in a Baltimore storefront church. The most vivid include Mama Luise Livingstone (Verna Day), the church's crotchety matriarch; her son, Jessie Livingstone (Mr. Heath), now the local pastor, and his bride, Sister Rose-a-Lee Barnes (Martha Baker).

title: MERRILL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
WHY A CONGRESSMAN TOLD OF HIS HOMOSEXUALITY
description: On paper, Representative Barney Frank's decision to go public about his homosexuality ought to have been relatively painless.

title: Leonard Intervenes
description: At the request of a suspect the police said was being uncooperative, Sugar Ray Leonard, the World Boxing Council middleweight champion, intervened in a domestic crisis Monday and led Washington police to a missing child.

title: Broome Coach Retiring
description: The Broome Community College basketball coach, Dick Baldwin, who established a record last season for victories in a college coaching career, has decided to retire after 40 years at the school in upstate Binghamton.

title: ROY WINSOR, WRITER AND A TV PRODUCER OF DAYTIME SERIALS
description: Roy Winsor, a television writer and producer who created ''Search for Tomorrow'' and wrote mystery novels, died of a heart attack Sunday at his home in Pelham Manor, N.Y. He was 75 years old.

title:
WITH WEAK DOLLAR, THE COST GOES UP FOR DINING ABROAD;
ROME
description: LEAD: EUROPE remains a favorite summer destination for many Americans, and dining well remains a favorite occupation when they get there. Happily, restaurants on the Continent are as good and as numerous as ever. What has changed this year is their value. Unhappily, Americans looking forward to a memorable meal at their favorite Michelin two-star can count on paying more for it than at any other time in the last few years.

title: Floating Point Lays Off 400
description: Floating Point Systems, the troubled manufacturer of scientific computing systems, said today it would lay off about 400 workers, reducing its total work force to about 800 worldwide. The cost-cutting measures are part of a restructuring to increase efficiency and reduce operating expenses.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Baseball Ventura Extends Streak: Jimmy Barragan hit a homer in the seventh inning to break a tie, Marv Rockman shut out Louisiana State over the final seven innings and Robin Ventura extended his hitting streak to 58 games yesterday to lead Oklahoma State to an 8-7 victory in the winner's bracket of the College World Series in Omaha. The game had been suspended by rain in the bottom of the fourth inning Monday and was resumed yesterday. Oklahoma State will next play Stanford, which defeated Texas, 6-1, in the double-elimination tournament. L.S.U. will play Arkansas, and Texas will meet FLorida State today in loser's-bracket games. Ventura extended his N.C.A.A.-record hitting streak with a double down the right-field line in the sixth inning that drove in a run and tied the score, 7-7. Ventura hit into a double play, walked and reached on an error in his first three times at bat. He struck out swinging in the eighth and is now batting .432.(AP) Golf Bogart Leads Seniors: Despite a 90-minute rain delay and soggy conditions, the United States Seniors' Golf Association managed to move nearly 500 amateurs around three golf courses in the opening round of its 83d annual championship. Ralph Bogart of Chevy Chase, Md., led with a 70, followed by William Bogle of Dutchess County with 72. Dr. Edgar S. Updegraff, a Tucson urologist, and John Owens of Lexington, Ky., tied at 73. The record field of 494 is playing in seven age brackets ranging from 515 to 85-plus on three courses: Apawamis in Rye, Blind Brook in Purchase and Round Hill in Greenwich.

title: ROYAL BANK OF CANADA reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: The bank is listed on the Toronto, Montreal and Vancouver stock exchanges. The results are in Canadian dollars.

title: BANK OF NOVA SCOTIA reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: Results are in U.S. dollars. The company is listed on the Toronto Stock Exchange.

title: CIRCUS CIRCUS ENTERPRISES reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
SENATE VOTES TO REQUIRE TEST OF ALIENS FOR AIDS VIRUS
description: The Senate voted overwhelmingly today to require immigrants to be tested for the AIDS virus and to exclude them if they showed evidence of infection.

title: In Flatiron Area, Cafe Expansion
description: A HANDFUL of the city's pioneering advertising agencies have been credited with discovering a few years ago the large spaces and cheap rents in the former loft buildings that line lower Fifth Avenue and Broadway. Since then they have been joined by publishing and public relations companies, architectural and design firms and, more recently, retailers and restaurateurs.

title: ALVARADO SEEKS TO OBTAIN POST IN CITY SCHOOLS
description: LEAD: Anthony J. Alvarado, the former New York City Schools Chancellor who is seeking to return to the city's school system, has applied for the superintendent's position in three community school districts in Manhattan but has already been rejected by one.

title: On the Record: Conflict and Contradiction
description: Lewis A. Tambs: May 28: The former Ambassador to Costa Rica testifies he had been instructed by Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North to set up a southern front for the contras. Mr. Tambs says he discussed this with Mr. Abrams in a hallway outside a meeting in September 1985.Mr. Tambs: ''It was obvious to me, at least as I understand it, that he knew as much about it as I did.'' Elliott Abrams: June 2: Asked whether he had ever discussed with Mr. Tambs the idea that he was to open a southern front, Mr. Abrams says, ''At no time whatsover.'' He adds it is ''bizarre'' for the committee to ''rely on a remark that is allegedly made in a corridor.'' Mr. Abrams: ''I don't think we discussed any such thing in a corridor or anywhere else.'' Lewis A. Tambs: May 28: Says he was directed to help the contras by a Restricted Inter-agency Group consisting of Mr. Abrams, Alan D. Fiers, the chief of the Central Intelligence Agency's Central America Task Force, and Colonel North. Those three, he says, were part of larger group. Elliott Abrams: June 2: Says the group was composed of 15 to 20 people and that ''it was not a decision-making or policy-making body - it was a coordinating body.'' Mr. Abrams, referring to Mr. Tambs's statement that three people worked as a subgroup: ''He doesn't know what he's talking about, and never attended a RIG meeting.'' John K. Singlaub: May 20: Testifies that before he traveled to Asia to solicit money for the contras from South Korea and Taiwan, he met with Mr. Abrams to ask that a message be sent saying the solicitation was legitimate. Mr. Abrams agreed to ''be the one that would give the signal,'' General Singlaub says. General Singlaub says he was telephoned by Mr. Abrams when he reached those countries and told to make the request. Elliott Abrams: June 2: Asked whether he met with General Singlaub before his departure to Asia, Mr. Abrams replies ''no.''

title: WALKER ENERGY PARTNERS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After writedown of $4,453,000 of the value of its oil and gas properties.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: WEDNESDAY, JUNE 3, 1987
description: A Shift at the Fed

title: Royal Academy Selects Work by Prince Charles
description: A watercolor by Prince Charles was chosen today for the summer show at the Royal Academy. The work was entered anonymously and went through a selection process that rejected about 90 percent of the entries.

title: 2 IN EVANGELIST'S LIBEL SUIT CITE CONGRESSIONAL PRIVILEGE

title: Q&A
description: Q.Our house foundation has had a crack for a couple of years. Now there is a new crack in the foundation in the front. I don't know how serious this is, nor what should be used to seal the cracks. Can we do this ourselves? If not, who should we call in? A.Since you don't mention it, I assume water is not coming through the cracks. So the problem is probably not serious - unless the cracks keep growing, or open up after they have properly filled. If the old crack seems to have stabilized and is not getting bigger, you should be able to repair it yourself. Use a hydraulic patching cement, sold for use on concrete basement walls. Cut out the cracks to widen them slightly, and undercut them so they are wider below the surface than at the surface. Clean out dust and chips with a stiff brush or vacuum, and follow the package directions for mixing and application. If you do want a professional, a good mason can do the job. Q.A cinder-block extension that is just 9 by 22 feet was built onto my house some years ago. I want to gut the inside and renovate it. I also want to add insulation, but because the area is so narrow, I want to put the insulation on the outside. What can I use for this? A.You don't specify what is now on the outside or whether you plan to rip any existing siding off. It is probably best to put rigid sheets or boards of foam insulation on the outside of the cement blocks. Usually made of Styrofoam or similar plastic foam, these insulation boards are applied to the masonry with mastic cement and some masonry nails or anchors. The sheets are then covered with siding. If the outside of the blocks is painted or stuccoed, the insulation can go directly over this. However, if the outside has siding, it must be removed before the insulation can be applied. Q.My house cellar has a dirt floor, and after a heavy rain it can accumulate standing water. I want to finish this space, but a concrete slab floor would be prohibitively expensive. Someone suggested decking, as long as it is firm and level. I could use redwood or cedar, but would prefer pressure-treated lumber, to save money. I am told that this can give off an odor when used indoors. Can it be used in such a damp area? A.No reason why not. Pressure-treated lumber is often used in enclosed places; one type is even used for foundations and basement walls instead of concrete. Be sure to buy the type treated for constant contact with damp soil. If you want to use the cellar for storage, or for any other purpose, cover the dirt with a vapor barrier of heavy sheet plastic or roofing felt before the decking is put down. Otherwise the cellar will always be damp and will eventually cause the house to be damp. It will also probably cause a musty odor that is very hard to get rid of.

description: Stock prices soared broadly yesterday on a positive reaction to the nomination of Alan Greenspan to succeed Paul A. Volcker as chairman of the Federal Reserve Board.

title: Baldrige Finds Hope on Trade
description: Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige said today that Japan had shown signs of opening its market to semiconductor imports. Referring to United States trade sanctions against Japan, he said, ''We hope we can lift them soon, but we have to see the facts first.''

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: Anniversary Addresses

title: MacLeod Off List
description: The Knicks can cross off John MacLeod from their list of candidates for coach and general manager. At least, that is how MacLeod feels so long as he remains a leading candidate for the coaching vacancy in Dallas. MacLeod has canceled a Friday appointment with the Knicks in the hope that it will convey his desire to coach the Mavericks. ''I just didn't want to start putting teams against each other,'' he said yesterday. ''Dallas came to me right away. I told Jack Diller that I appreciated the sentiment.'' Diller is the assistant to Richard Evans, the Knicks' president.

title: GASES OUST WYOMING RESIDENTS FROM HOMES
description: Nearly 180 families have until July 31 to abandon their homes near here because of deadly gases seeping from a coal deposit. Some residents accused the authorities of dragging their feet.

title: Aviation Agency Marks Start on $400 Million Control Network
description: The Federal Aviation Administration yesterday dedicated the first of 20 computers that will make up a $400 million network the agency says is needed to cope with the predicted growth in air travel.

title: LYDIA LUNCH EXPANDS THEATRICAL BOUNDARIES
description: ''A friend of mine said, 'Don't kill time - kill yourself,' '' Lydia Lunch said the other day. ''I don't look at suicide as the coward's way out, but as the brave way. I'm just another jerk who doesn't have the nerve to snuff it.''

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * British Satellite Broadcasting, London, said it had awarded a contract for $:200 million, or about $328 million at current exchange rates, to Hughes Aircraft, a General Motors subsidiary, to build two satellites for television broadcasting.

title: THE FUTON'S COMFORT IS WINNING CONVERTS
description: ''FIVE years ago futons were purchased as space savers,'' said Nancy Wykstra, owner of the Futon Shop on lower Broadway. ''Now people have discovered them as comfortable beds.'' Irv Weider, owner of Arise Futons, said buyers used to be primarily the avant-garde, but now a wider range of people are interested in the Japanese sleeping mats.

title: No Headline
description: Sales of American-built cars fell 1.9 percent in late May on a daily rate basis, the eight domestic manufacturers reported today. Light-truck sales continued to improve, rising 13 percent.

title: ARBOR DRUGS reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Digital, Cray Joining Forces
description: The Digital Equipment Corporation and Cray Research Inc. said today that they would cooperatively develop and market computer products that link their respective systems. The agreement will link the leader in scientific and technical computing, Digital, with the world's dominant manufacturer of supercomputers, Cray.

title: Sports Picture
description: Can the mystique of sports be related in cinematic style? Do sports stars share the same celebrity status as movie stars? Was ''The Babe Ruth Story'' an accurate portrayal of the Yankee slugger, or was it an open distortion of the baseball hero's character?

description: These are other projects planned or under construction on the New Jersey shore of the Hudson River: JERSEY CITY

title: A Trip to Philadelphia Is the Junket of Choice
description: The booming voice of Representative William H. Gray 3d could be heard far down the corridor the other day as he delivered a pep talk urging his colleagues to visit Philadelphia, his home city, for the bicentennial celebration of the United States Constitution.

title: Best by Average
description: When Wade Boggs of the Boston Red Sox lined a single in Seattle on April 30, he qualified for major league baseball's list of leading batters with at least 1,000 hits. Boggs, with a career average of .352, is now the fourth leading hitter in baseball history. Among active players, his nearest rival is George Brett of the Kansas City Royals who has a career average of .314. The dozen major leaguers since 1900 who have batting averages of at least .340:

title: U.S. Diplomat Indicted In Scheme to Sell Visas
description: A former senior diplomat at the United States Embassy in Madrid has been charged with conspiring to sell false American entry visas to Iranians.

title: 2 Named to Holocaust Panel
description: President Reagan said Tuesday that he would nominate Barbaralee Dismonstein-Spielvogel of New York City and Richard M. Rosenbaum of Rochester to fill two openings on the United States Holocaust Commission. Mrs. Dismonstein-Spielvogel, a television interviewer and producer who is the author of 13 books, will succeed Edward Sanders. Mr. Rosenbaum, counsel to the chairman of Integrated Resources Inc., will succeed Terrence Des Pres.

title: ANITEC IMAGE TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
SPREAD OF AIDS VIRUS IS UNABATED AMONG INTRAVENOUS DRUG TAKERS
description: The spread of the AIDS virus among intravenous drug users continues unabated, an expert reported today, despite some success in persuading drug users to avoid contaminated needles and syringes.

title: FIGURING OUT THE FATES OF 'COP II' AND 'ISHTAR'
description: In the only way that matters to Hollywood, ''Beverly Hills Cop II'' and ''Ishtar'' are polar opposites. One is making money. The other is losing it.

title: KEVEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $141,000 and $369,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Net loss

title: ZYMOS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Coming Back In Fine Style
description: Jim Eisenreich, who left the Minnesota Twins in June 1984 and dropped out of organized baseball for more than two seasons because of nervous disorders, is doing splendidly so far in a comeback attempt. After his waiver contract was purchased for $1 last October by the Kansas City Royals, the 27-year-old outfielder was assigned to the Memphis Chicks of the Class AA Southern League.

title: 22 Years: The Wedtech Story
description: 1965: John Mariotta, whose parents came to New York from Puerto Rico, starts up Welbilt Electronic Die Corporation, a South Bronx machine shop, later renamed the Wedtech Corporation. 1980: Wedtech hires the law firm of Biaggi & Ehrlich. April 1981: Army officials reject Wedtech proposal to produce small gasoline engines as too expensive. Spring 1981: Wedtech recruits E. Robert Wallach, a California lawyer and close friend to Edwin Meese 3d, then the White House Counselor, to assist the company in its efforts to get the contract. Jan. 15, 1982: Two White House aides meet with Army and Small Business Administration officials to press the Army to award the contract to Wedtech. The Army does not go along. May 19, 1982: Wedtech officials attend a White House meeting with officials of the Army and of the S.B.A. Mark Bragg, a partner of a former White House aide, Lyn Nofziger, also attends. James E. Jenkins, a top aide to Mr. Meese, presides. September 1982: Wedtech is awarded a contract, under a special program for minority-owned companies, that will total $32 million to produce engines for the Army. 1983: Wedtech goes public and Mr. Mariotta becomes a multi- millionaire. Mr. Wallach receives about $1 million in stock and cash. Mr. Nofziger and Mr. Bragg receive a similar amount. The law firm of Biaggi & Ehrlich receives about $3.6 million in Wedtech stock. March 1984: President Reagan, campaigning in New York, says ''people like John Mariotta are heroes for the '80's.'' April 1984: Wedtech is awarded, without competitive bidding, a $135 million contract to make pontoons for the Navy. April 1985: Mr. Wallach arranges for W. Franklyn Chinn to become a financial consultant to Wedtech. May 1985: Mr. Wallach arranges for Mr. Meese to invest about $60,000 in a company controlled by Mr. Chinn. August 1985: Mr. Chinn is named a Wedtech director. Early 1986: Mr. Jenkins, formerly Mr. Meese's top aide, goes to work as Wedtech's director of marketing in Washington. Fall 1986: The United States Attorney in Manhattan and the District Attorneys in Manhattan and the Bronx open investigations into Wedtech. December 1986: Wedtech files for reorganization under Federal bankruptcy laws. January 1987: Four Wedtech officials plead guilty in United States District Court in Manhattan and tell prosecutors they bribed as many as 20 Government officials. February 1987: A special prosecutor is named in Washington to investigate Mr. Nofziger's links with Wedtech. April 1987: Two former Maryland officials and a contract officer with the United States Postal Service are charged in Baltimore with accepting bribes from Wedtech. May 1987: The special prosecutor's investigation is expanded to include Mr. Meese's ties to Wedtech. June 3, 1987: Representative Mario Biaggi and six others are indicted by a Federal grand jury in Manhattan.

title: Europe's Air Profits Up
description: Leading European airlines expect a 40 percent higher profit this year after a ''traumatic'' year in 1986, according to figures released by the Association of European Airlines. The association, which groups 21 major European airlines, said today that the combined profit of its members was expected to rise to the equivalent of about $550 million in 1987, up about 40 percent from $400 million in 1986. Karl-Heinz Neumeister, the association's secretary general, said 1986 was a ''traumatic'' year for European airlines, when the fear of terrorism, the Chernobyl nuclear disaster and the fall of the dollar led to a drop of one million North American tourists.

title: U.S. Impotence on the Cambodian Genocide Issue
description: To the Editor:

title: The Judge Who Became a Partisan
description: When Abraham Sofaer left his Federal judgeship two years ago to become legal adviser to the State Department, some people wondered why. After making such a name for himself on the bench in New York, why become a low-profile Government lawyer? One answer soon became clear: Mr. Sofaer didn't see the new job quite that way. Indeed, he has turned the position into an aggressive policy-making job.

title: Merc Stiffens Penalties
description: Directors of the Chicago Mercantile Exchange approved a range of measures yesterday intended to deter trading abuses in its financial futures pits.

title: Elton John Needs Rest After Throat Surgery
description: The rock star Elton John said today that he needed to rest his voice for a year because it had become lower in pitch after a throat operation.

title: CONGRESS MIGHT NOT AID CONTRAS IF ABRAMS CONTINUES IN HIS POST
description: Senior members of Congress questioned today whether Congress would approve new assistance for the Nicaraguan rebels if Elliott Abrams remained Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American Affairs.

title: FLEET IN THE GULF: OUTCOME OF FUROR OVER IRAN... OR A MOVE TO DRAW U.S. INTO WAR
description: Kuwait's effort to gain American and Soviet protection for its oil fleet, in the view of diplomats here, is a maneuver designed to draw the superpowers into the Persian Gulf war in hopes they will find a way to end it.

title: Staff Openings Loom at Fed
description: Although Alan Greenspan should not face a mass exodus when he arrives at the Federal Reserve Board, he might have to fill several top positions vacated by those who have been particularly close to Paul A. Volcker, the current chairman, according to those who follow the Fed.

title: Arizona Utility
description: The Arizona Public Service Company is offering $125 million of 9 7/8 percent first mortgage bonds due in 1997 at a price of 100 through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc. Nonrefundable for five years, the bonds yield about 1.24 percentage points more than Treasury securities with a similar maturity. The issue is rated Baa-2 by Moody's Investors Service and BBB+ by Standard & Poor's.

title: BOND PRICES SHAKE OFF FED JITTERS
description: The bond markets strengthened yesterday, recovering more than half the decline that occurred Tuesday after the announcement that Alan Greenspan would replace Paul A. Volcker as chairman of the Federal Reserve Board.

title: American Women's Colleges Need Not 'Go Coed or Go Under'
description: To the Editor:

title: Reader's Digest Grants To Performing Groups
description: The Reader's Digest Dance and Theater Program has awarded 16 new grants to American dance and theater organizations in the second year of a three-year, $3 million program supporting the creation and production of new works. The new grants total $140,000.

title: Massachusetts Church To Sell Headquarters
description: The Bible Speaks, a church ordered to return $6.5 million to a former member, has decided to sell its headquarters to raise the money, court documents show.

title: Warring Over Wetlands: Battle on S.I. Intensifies
description: Property owners have delivered a truckload of dirt to the Department of Environmental Conservation to prove that their Staten Island property - designated by the state as wetland - is actually dry.

title: Dawkins, Ex-General, Plans Senate Race in Jersey
description: Peter M. Dawkins, the retired brigadier general and Heisman Trophy winner, said today that he intended to seek the Republican nomination to run for the United States Senate next year against the Democratic incumbent, Frank R. Lautenberg.

title: Unlocking the Files
description: There is important and good news in the making at the United Nations. It now looks likely that the dogged determination of one small country and its envoy and a decision taken in a Washington office may put an end to a shame of the United Nations and its members - the locking of the war crimes files.

title: MYSTERY: CAR'S FATE
description: Now you see it, now you don't.

title: Japan Forklifts Cited in Ruling
description: In a preliminary ruling, the International Trade Commission in Washington, D.C., today found that the United States forklift industry has been materially injured by imports from Japan of small to medium-size forklifts with internal combustion engines.

title: MAIL-ORDER CATALOGUES: SPECIAL PLANTS
description: LEAD: ''IN the last 10 years I've seen specialty mail-order nurseries increase by 50 percent'' said Thomas Powell, editor of The Avant Gardener, a monthly garden newsletter. Rather than offering a broad spectrum of flowers, vegetables, shrubs and trees, these smaller nurseries concentrate on only a few plant varieties.

title: Soviet Cloth Irks U.S. Mills
description: The Soviet Union has adopted a policy of exporting huge quantities of textiles to the United States, Senator Strom Thurmond said today.

title: They Went Whichaway?
description: The Lakers repeatedly hit the open man against the Celtics here in the first game of the N.B.A. Finals. You couldn't help wonder, where are all these open men coming from?

title: Bridge: Death of Dick Kahn, at 76, Ended a Long Partnership
description: The longest-lived expert bridge partnership in the United States, and perhaps in the world, came to an end last month when Dick Kahn of Manhattan died at the age of 76.

title:
TALKING DEALS;
A Coup Seen In H.C.A. Plan
description: LEAD: THERE probably is not a corporation in America that would not love to divest itself of underperforming assets without having to take a financial bath in the process. And if it can cut a deal that also scores points with employees and Wall Street, then it is clearly ahead of the game.

title: CANADA'S LEADERS SIGN FEDERAL PACT
description: The leaders of Canada's national and provincial governments met in a refurbished railroad station in Ottawa today and signed an accord to end Quebec's boycott of the Constitution.

title: Cult Figure Denied a New Trial
description: A Federal district judge has refused to grant a new trial to a former member of the People's Temple on charges of aiding and abetting the murder of a Congressman in Guyana in November 1978.

title: POSITION OF STARK FOCUS OF DISPUTE
description: Iraq is maintaining that the American frigate Stark was inside an exclusion zone near Iran when the ship was mistakenly attacked by an Iraqi jet, but the United States has strong evidence that the Stark was outside the zone, the Pentagon said today.

title: JAPAN LETS 4 U.S. BANKS UNDERWRITE SECURITIES
description: Japan said yesterday that it would permit four major American commercial banks to establish securities underwriting and trading operations in Tokyo.

title: COMMITTEE IS UNLIKELY TO PUT OFF VOTE IN GRANTING NORTH IMMUNITY
description: The Congressional committees investigating the Iran-contra affair indicated today that it was unlikely they would substantially delay a vote on granting immunity to Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North.

title: Witness Says She Saw Barbie Set Up Death Train
description: A witness today told the court trying Klaus Barbie for crimes against humanity that she had seen the wartime Gestapo chief of this city personally organizing a deportation train from Lyons to Auschwitz that took about 600 people to their deaths.

title: FILM: 'MORGAN STEWART,' A CONFUSED TEEN-AGER
description: IF energy and charm were enough to rejuvenate the poor-little-rich-boy story, Jon Cryer could have saved ''Morgan Stewart's Coming Home.'' In ''Pretty in Pink,'' he even managed to make a character named Ducky believable -he was the misfit who pined for Molly Ringwald and laughed at himself before anyone else did. But Mr. Cryer can't yet carry a film on the strength of his snaggletoothed smile, and the people and events around him in ''Morgan Stewart'' lack the quirky feel of real life.

title: PANEL MEMBER SEES SELF-DEFEATING U.S. POLICY
description: At one point in the hearings, Representative Lee H. Hamilton, Democrat of Indiana and chairman of the House committee on the Iran-contra affair, offered some comments on the testimony of Elliott Abrams.

title: FOR GREENSPAN, NO DEARTH OF TESTS
description: When Alan Greenspan takes over this summer as chairman of the Federal Reserve, his most important job will be to prove to a somewhat skeptical international banking and investment community that he can take the right actions - particularly to combat inflation - rather than just prescribing them for others, various analysts said today.

title: China's Deficit Reduced
description: Soaring textile exports and rising prices for Chinese oil and gold have improved the country's foreign-trade performance this year. The China Daily said today that textile exports were worth $3 billion in the first five months of 1987, up 40 percent from the corresponding period last year. It attributed the boom to expanding world demand and the improved quality and prices of Chinese textiles, with domestic producers using designs and brands provided by foreign partners. China posted a trade deficit of $1.7 billion in the first four months of 1987, down from a $4.5 billion deficit in the corresponding period last year. In 1985 and 1986, the country's combined deficit totaled nearly $26 billion.

title: MITCHELL ENERGY & DEVELOPENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
AROUND AMERICA, GARDEN FEVER TAKES HOLD
description: LEAD: AMERICANS have a new favorite pastime: the gardening of perennials, which they have taken up with the gusto they once reserved for cooking or running. New gardeners bone up on the subject in the proliferating literature and discuss it at dinner parties where the words Clematis paniculata would once have raised eyebrows or inspired yawns.

title: Arrests of Aliens Drop
description: Arrests of illegal aliens dropped about 60 percent here last month compared with arrests a year ago, immigration officials have reported. They said the decrease was part of a downward trend since President Reagan signed immigration reform legislation in November.

title: Trump Renews Attack on Koch On TV City Site
description: Donald J. Trump renewed his attack on Mayor Koch yesterday and offered what he called a new plan to keep the National Broadcasting Company in New York City.

title: ONCOGENE SCIENCE reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: TVI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Peacock Is Honored
description: Eulace Peacock, the former sprinter and long jumper, and Martha Watson, a four-time Olympian, were among four athletes named to the National Track and Field Hall of Fame in Indianapolis. Peacock led the voting announced yesteray by The Athletics Congress, the national governing body for track and field. He was a rival of Jesse Owens for much of his career and was a co-holder of the world 100-meter record at 10.3 seconds. Peacock, now living in Yonkers, had 234 votes and Watson had 226. Bud Held of Lakeside, Calif., a former world-record holder in the javelin, and Jim Bush, the former U.C.L.A. coach now living in Culver City, Calif., were also voted into the Hall of Fame.

title: Fire Destroys Two Churches
description: Two Alcorn County churches were destroyed by fire within minutes early today, and two men have been charged with burglary and arson. Sheriff Bill Gant said John Harold Miller, 25 years old, of Michie, Tenn., and Eddie P. Brandon, 28, of Glen, Miss., had admitted setting the blazes. The first blaze was set to cover up a burglary, the Sheriff said.

title: Electronic Imaging Offered by Kodak
description: The Eastman Kodak Company entered the emerging field of electronic photography with the introduction of seven products designed for professional or commercial use. Electronic still cameras create pictures using the same technology as video cameras. The quality is lower than in pictures that use chemicals, but the images can be altered, stored and transmitted more easily.

title: HORTICULTURE BOOKS ARE NOW BIG SELLERS
description: AMONG the best indications of the important role gardening has taken in the lives of many Americans are the phenomenal sales of serious garden books.

title: JAZZ: THE GROUP
description: THE GROUP started out as an all-star quintet of contemporary jazz musicians. Now they are working to become an all-star team. In its first set Tuesday at Carlos 1, 432 Avenue of the Americas, at 10th Street, where the Group performs through Sunday, the quintet played arrangements a step above jam-session, theme-solos-theme formats, working toward an ensemble sound without slighting soloists -and shifting easily in and out of free jazz.

title: 2 Killed in Helicopter Crash
description: A helicopter crashed and burned this morning in a cornfield, killing both people aboard, the authorities said. The victims' identities were not immediately available. The Robinson R22 helicopter, which belonged to Northeast Helicopters of Ellington, crashed as it appeared to be heading to Ellington Airport, officials said. Northeast runs flight training courses.

title: Frequent Flyers' Hands in the Corporate Till
description: To the Editor:

title: EVERETT J. PENNY
description: Everett J. Penny, a former vice chancellor of the New York State Board of Regents, died of respiratory failure Tuesday at the King Street Nursing Home in Port Chester, N.Y. He was 83 years old and lived in Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: SULLIVAN ASKS END OF BUSINESS LINKS WITH SOUTH AFRICA
description: The Rev. Leon Sullivan, who created a code of conduct under which American companies continued to operate in South Africa, said yesterday that the effort had failed to undermine apartheid, and he called on the companies to end all commercial ties with South Africa.

title: Soldier to Stand Trial In AIDS Assault Case
description: A court-martial will be held for a Fort Huachuca soldier accused of having had sex with other military personnel even though he knew he was carrying the AIDS virus, the Army announced today.

title: FILM: 'QUIET HAPPINESS'
description: Film Forum 1 began a weeklong festival of seven recent Czechoslovak films yesterday that will be shown in rotation. Dusan Hanak's ''Quiet Happiness,'' the only one of the seven I've seen, will be shown nightly at 8, while three of the six others will make up the rest of each day's bill.

title: WILANDER, BECKER, MECIR IN SEMIFINALS
description: LEAD: The French Open got its men's final four today as Mats Wilander, Boris Becker, and Miloslav Mecir joined Ivan Lendl in the semifinals. This is not only the most talented group in the tournament but also the most interesting from the standpoint of what is, in effect, the world clay-court championship.

title: Optimism Increases on Surviving Atom War
description: A new Federal study indicates that more Americans could survive a nuclear war than was previously estimated. Civil defense officials say they may use the results to lobby for increased spending for measures to protect the population in event of an attack.

title: Luther Greene Is Dead; Landscaper, Producer
description: Luther Greene, a landscape designer and former theatrical producer, died Sunday at his apartment in Manhattan. He was 78 years old. He essentially had two careers -producing Broadway plays, starting in 1935, and designing country and rooftop gardens, starting in the mid-1950's.

title: DeBusschere Files Suit
description: Dave DeBusschere has filed a breach-of-contract suit against Gulf and Western, which owns the Knicks. DeBusschere, who was dismissed as general manager in January 1986, is accusing the company of refusing to allow him to exercise options to buy stock under the terms of his contract. The suit, filed in State Supreme Court in Manhattan, asks damages of $131,643.75, the difference between the market value of the stock and the option price.

title: Lewis Smith, Designer, Dies; Created Lighting in Churches
description: Lewis Smith, a retired lighting designer who worked on the lighting of more than 400 churches, died of emphysema May 27 at the Camden (Me.) Health Care Center, a nursing home. He was 83 years old and had lived in Camden since his retirement three years ago.

title: THE CHAMPAGNE OF MERGERS
description: And now, a conglomerate for the carriage trade.

title: Howser in Hospital
description: Dick Howser, the former manager of the Kansas City Royals who has had three operations for a cancerous brain tumor, was admitted to St. Luke's Hospital in Kansas City, Mo., yesterday. Howser, who is 51 years old, was taken by ambulance from his home in Lee's Summit in a ''nonemergency situation,'' according to Denise Buening, a spokeswoman for St. Luke's. Dr. Paul Meyer, the Royals' team physician, said Howser was admitted by Dr. Charles Clough, a neurosurgeon who operated on Howser last July to remove parts of a malignant tumor. ''I'm not sure the reasons he was admitted,'' Meyer said. ''I couldn't tell you a thing. Dick has been pretty weak.''

title: THE NEW PHILANTHROPY: MONEY TO SCHOOLCHILDREN INSTEAD OF TO SCHOOLS
description: A new kind of educational philanthropy, in which benefactors give money not to schools but to individual schoolchldren to inspire them to work harder, is taking hold in several American cities.

title: REDS BEAT CARDINALS ON ESASKY'S HOMER
description: Nick Esasky hit a three-run homer to help Pat Pacillo of Cincinnati earn his first major league victory tonight as the Reds beat the St. Louis Cardinals, 6-4.

title: Turner Deal Comes Just in Time
description: Turner Broadcasting System Inc., saddled with debt as a result of its $1.78 billion purchase of the MGM/UA Entertainment Company, completed the sale today of 37 percent of the company to a group including 26 operators of cable television systems and Time Inc.

title: TIRE PLANT FINDS WAYS TO REVIVE WORK ETHIC
description: Nearly everything at the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company's eight-year-old plant here focuses attention on hard work.

title: APPALACHIAN OIL & GAS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The comparable year-ago results are not available because the company changed its fiscal year-end to June 30 from Feb. 28.

title: SOVIET OFFERS TO ALLOW SOME ON-SITE TEST MONITORING
description: A senior Soviet official has offered to let American experts make direct measurements of some Soviet nuclear tests if the United States agrees to start negotiations to set further limits on testing, Administration officials said today.

title: AUDIENCE AS PLAYWRIGHT'S CONSULTANT
description: The stage is blacked out, but the moans and cries arising from the rumpled bed in the middle are unmistakably those of a man and woman making love. The sounds crescendo, reaching a peak that rivets the attention of everyone in the theater, and then begin to subside into whimpers and sighs. Not a word has yet been spoken, but already the audience is wholly engrossed in the most intimate of experiences being recreated onstage.

title: Failing the Tests
description: When people become frightened, terrible things can be done in their name.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: GORBACHEV'S CHALLENGE. Economic Reform in the Age of High Technology.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: College Baseball L.S.U. Eliminates Arkansas: Gregg Patterson of L.S.U. pitched a four-hitter and Jack Voigt hit a tie-breaking two-run homer in the seventh inning yesterday to eliminate Arkansas from the College World Series in Omaha. Patterson (11-2) struck out five and walked three for his second victory in the double-elimination tournament. Voigt's 16th home run, which capped a four-run rally, came off Bob Edwards, a relief pitcher, and made a loser of John Cebuhar (11-2), the starter. In the second game, another losers'-bracket contest, Texas eliminated Florida State, 6-4, in 10 innings. L.S.U. will play Stanford tomorrow, and Texas will meet Oklahoma State. Stanford will play Oklahoma State in the winners'-bracket final tonight. (AP) Horse Racing Reference Point Wins Epsom Derby: Reference Point, the 6-4 favorite ridden by Steve Cauthen, led from start to finish to win the Epsom Derby. The horse, who had an operation to cure a sinus problem two months ago, posted an electronically timed course record for the mile-and-a-half race as he held off Most Welcome by 1 1/2 lengths with Bellotto three-quarters of a length father behind. Reference Point's winning time was 2 minutes 33.9 seconds, one-tenth of a second slower than the hand-timed record set by Mahmood in 1936. (AP) Rugby United States Eliminated: Peter Winterbottom scored a try in each half to lead England to a 34-6 victory over the United States in a World Cup match at Concord Oval in Sydney, Australia. A try is a scoring play worth 6 points in which the ball is grounded on or behind an opponent's goal line. The victory moved England into the quarterfinals on Monday. The United States, which had one victory - over Japan - and two losses in its three first-round matches, was eliminated from the first 16-nation tournament by the loss. In other matches, Australia struggled to a 42-23 victory over Japan, but moved into the quarterfinals against Ireland, which defeated Tonga, 32-9.(AP) Golf Remsen Wins Again: Richard Remsen of Locust Valley, L.I., won his third senior tournament in three weeks, this one the 83d annual championship of the United States Seniors' Golf Association, an organization of 1,000 amateur golfers aged 55 and over. His total of 147 consisted of a 75 Tuesday at the Apawamis Club in Rye, N.Y. and 72 yesterday at the Round Hill Club in Greenwich, Conn. Ralph Bogart of Chevy Chase, Md., shot 148 for second place. A record field of 494 was divided into seven age brackets ranging from 55 to 85-plus. Players over age 75 played both their rounds at Blind Brook in Purchase, N.Y., and the others alternated between Apawamis and Round Hill.

title: 2 GROUPS LIST CANDIDATES' VIEWS ON ABORTION
description: It would take ''a small miracle'' for Republican Presidential aspirants to change their anti-abortion views by 1988, but Democrats are virtually certain to nominate a candidate who favors a choice on the issue, according to two groups favoring abortion rights.

title: Mets Don't Expect Dr. K Right Away
description: Like everybody else, the Mets don't know what to expect when Dwight Gooden returns from drug therapy and takes the mound Friday night in Shea Stadium before a sellout crowd and a wondering public.

title: Unit of Marine Midland In $600 Million Offering
description: The Marine Midland Automotive Finance Corporation, a subsidiary of Marine Midland Banks, is offering $600 million of securities backed by automobile loans through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers.

title: PESSIMISM GROWING IN BONN ON RELEASE OF PILOT BY MOSCOW
description: West German officials have grown more pessimistic about an early release of Mathias Rust, the young flier held in Lefortovo Prison in Moscow for his illicit flight across the Soviet frontier, a German official said today.

title: 2 Rockwell Deals
description: The Rockwell International Corporation has received two contracts totaling $233 million for work on the ''Star Wars'' interceptor system, the Air Force said. The work is part of the Reagan Administration's research into possible development of a system to shoot down attacking nuclear missiles. The larger of the two contracts awarded to Rockwell was for $209 million, for work on a possible space battle platform that would fire small projectiles at enemy rockets during or shortly after their lift-off toward targets.

title: ANIMED INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net loss

title: HENRY F. ARGENTO
description: Henry F. Argento, an executive of the electronics industry for many years, died May 23 at his home in Far Hills, N.J. He was 77 years old.

title: German Jobless Rate
description: Unemployment in West Germany fell to 8.3 percent in May from 8.8 percent in April, the Federal Labor Office said today.

title: Quotations of the Day
description: ''If Wedtech was the proverbial American success story, these charges raise serious questions about the way we practice politics and conduct business in this city, state and nation.''

title: Pact Reached on $160 Million Improvement of Penn Station
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority and Amtrak have agreed on a plan to operate Pennsylvania Station jointly, clearing the way for $160 million in improvements for the crowded and prematurely aging building.

title: E.P.A. Revises Standards on Air Pollutants
description: The Environmental Protection Agency, using a new method to calculate pollution, today adopted revised national standards for clean air.

title: MORGAN'S SELECTIVE APPROACH
description: WHEN an advertiser's target audience is four-tenths of 1 percent of the United States population, media choice must be terribly selective or terribly wasteful.

title: Will Sampson, 53, Portrayed An Indian in 'Cuckoo's Nest'
description: Will Sampson, the 6-foot-7-inch actor who played the silent Indian in the film ''One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest,'' died Wednesday, 43 days after undergoing a heart-lung transplant. He was 53 years old.

title: Stocks at Peak in Tokyo
description: Japanese stocks reached a record high today, mainly on speculative buying that began after the market shook off the news that the United States Federal Reserve Board chairman, Paul A. Volcker, was stepping down, brokers said. The index climbed 146.77 points, to 25,049.40.

title: F.C.C. Renews Licenses Of 5 Hispanic Stations
description: The Federal Communications Commission has agreed to renew the licenses of five television stations owned by the Spanish International Communications Corporation, clearing the way for their purchase by Hallmark Cards Inc.

title: House Unit Backs Statehood For the District of Columbia
description: A House committee today approved legislation to grant the District of Columbia statehood with full voting representation in Congress.

title: City to Meet Builders Over Safety
description: The New York City Buildings Commissioner said yesterday that he would meet soon with major contractors in the city about safety at job sites and ways to keep debris from falling.

title: FROM EXPERT GARDENERS, FAVORITE PERENNIALS
description: KNOWLEDGEABLE gardeners find that certain plants catch their fancy from year to year. Here, garnered from an informal survey of garden designers, horticulturists and amateurs, are some of the perennials enjoying popularity now. There has been a rush for most of these mail-order plants, so do not be surprised if they are not all available this season. But there is always next year. Aster frikartii ''Monch.'' One of the finest aster hybrids, the clear-blue autumn flowers cover a three-foot mound. Source: White Flower Farms, Litchfield, Conn., 06759-0050; 203-496-9600. Boltonia asteroides ''Snowbank.'' A fall bloomer, it looks like a roadside aster. It does not faint in the heat and needs no staking. Source: Holbrook Farm and Nursery, Route 2, Box 223B, Fletcher, N.C., 28732; 704-891-7790. Crambe cordifolia. This plant has a large mound of dark greenery with stout five-foot stems that branch into a cloud of small white scented flowers. Source: Wayside Gardens, Hodges, S.C., 29695; 800-845-1124 (in South Carolina, 803-223-1968). Dicentra eximia ''Alba.'' A woodland plant with white flowers, it is rarely used in American gardens. Worth a trip to Frederick McGourty, Hillside Nursery, Norfolk, Conn., 06058; no phone. Hosta ''Frances Williams.'' Sumptuous, large blue leaves banded in creamy yellow form a clump two feet across in a shady garden. Source: Shady Oaks Nursery, 700 19th Avenue, N.E., Wasseca, Minn., 56093; no phone. Rosa rubrifolia. Rugged by nature, with coppery foliage and pale-pink star-shaped flowers, the plant's graceful form works well at the back of a border. Source: Pickering Nurseries Inc., 670 Kingston Road, Pickering, Ontario, Canada, L1V1A6; 416-839-2111.

title: Salvadoran Rebels Step Up Actions in the Capital
description: Carrying out a pledge they made last year, leftist rebels and their supporters have sharply stepped up their political and military activities here in the Salvadoran capital in the last month, seriously harassing the Government.

title: Correction
description: The caption yesterday with a picture of Elliott Abrams's mother watching as he testified at the Iran-contra hearing gave her first name incorrectly. It is Mildred.

title: BRAMALEA LIMITED reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
U.S. TO HIRE MORE AIR TRAFFIC WORKERS
description: The Department of Transportation said today that it planned to divert $51.5 million and hire 955 more air traffic controllers, supervisors and managers to meet next year's traffic growth.

title: Protesters Seized in Picketing Of BASF Corp. Headquarters
description: About 150 demonstrators picketed the headquarters of BASF Corporation in Parsippany, N.J., yesterday on the third anniversary of what the Oil, Chemical and Atomic Workers Union calls a lockout at a BASF plant in Louisiana.

title: Kidder Expected to Pay $25 Million in Settlement
description: Kidder, Peabody & Company is prepared to announce today that it is paying more than $20 million to settle civil charges by the Securities and Exchange Commission that it profited illegally from trading on inside information, according to people with knowledge of the settlement.

title: CITY AND COUNTRY FURNITURE
description: NORBERT BINOTTI, a 28-year-old interior designer, opened Antiques Mart a month ago, featuring furniture made in the 1920's in southern France. Nearly all the furniture is walnut and there are two styles: provincial and urban. The provincial furniture has carved motifs of fruits and vegetables, and was made for homes in the countryside. ''The more streamlined Art Deco furniture that was devoid of carved ornament was made for a more sophisticated clientele, who lived in Paris or Nice,'' said Mr. Binotti, shown below. The walnut dining-room set in the photograph consists of a 45-inch round table with two leaves, six chairs with leather seats and two carved cabinets with marble counters; it is $2,600. An Art Deco mahogany dining table, above right, is 51 inches by 39 inches and is $1,200. A steel-frame chandelier, below right, has tulip-shaped shades and is $580. Antiques Mart is at 343 West 54th Street, on the second floor.

title: SEIS PROS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
SOUTH AFRICA REACTS ANGRILY TO SULLIVAN CALL
description: The South African Government reacted angrily tonight to a call by the Rev. Leon Sullivan for American companies doing business in South Africa to quit the country within nine months.

title: Market Place; DATA SERVICES FOR SMALL USER
description: THE rising cost of data-processing operations faced by many financial institutions has created a growing business for, and investment interest in, third-party companies that provide updated services more efficiently and at lower cost.

title: ROBERT-MARK INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
STERLING INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 2
description: b-Net loss

title: EDISON BROTHERS STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 25
description: b-Net income

title: COOPER LASERSONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net income and after income from discontinued operations of $1,205,000 and $2,287,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: Rumors Swirling Around Gillette
description: Rumor springs eternal, so Wall Street is ever on the prowl to find out just what is going on when a stock starts to move. The latest example is the Gillette Company, the maker of Paper Mate pens, Right Guard deodorant and, of course, razor blades.

title: TISCHES GIVE $10 MILLION TO MET FOR NEW GALLERIES
description: Laurence A. Tisch, the chief executive of CBS Inc., and his brother, Preston R. Tisch, the Postmaster General of the United States, both natives of Brooklyn, yesterday donated $10 million to the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York City for the construction of new galleries.

title: PROPERTY-TAX RELIEF BILL DEFEATED IN CONNECTICUT
description: The General Assembly adjourned late tonight after a five-month session that saw legislators approve a $5.64 billion budget but fail to pass a late bill on property-tax relief.

title: KEY RATES
ALYSHEBA SHORT IN ODDS, BUT LONG ON DOUBTERS
description: What price Alysheba?

title: SUIT DISMISSED IN NEWSPAPER FEUD
description: A California judge has dismissed a suit brought by a member of the feuding family that owns Freedom Newspapers Inc., possibly ending a legal battle that could have led to the dismantling of the publishing company.

title: NEW I.B.M. LINE STIRS SHOW
