description: Manufacturers of small computers, still uncertain about how to react to I.B.M.'s announcement of a new line of personal computers, had more to say than to show at a major desktop computer trade show here.

title: AS OUTPUT GAINS, WAGES LAG
description: It used to take Gary Adair four hours or more to retool the computerized machines that assemble tires so they could make ones of a different size. But with the help of fellow workers at the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company plant here, Mr. Adair has cut that time to three hours. Such accomplishments are significantly increasing the number of radials the plant can produce.

title: Article 314787 -- No Title
description: The financial organizer of the arms sales to Iran testified today that he had set aside $200,000 for the personal use of Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North and his family. The witness, Albert Hakim, told the Congressional commitees investigating the Iran-contra affair that he had not directly told Colonel North about the money. Records show that Colonel North, a former assistant on President Reagan's National Security Council staff, never drew on the account and that the money, plus interest, is still there.

title: The Polar Bears Fell Victim to a Meaningless Show of Force
description: To the Editor:

title: DEPORTED BY U.S., HE TELLS OF LIFE IN SOVIET JAIL
description: An Estonian who was deported from the United States to face a conviction in the Soviet Union for Nazi war crimes has written to his daughter in Virginia, saying it appears he will not get a new trial on a death sentence handed down 25 years ago.

title: New Penguins Coach?
description: Pierre Creamer, who is credited with helping to develop the talent that carried the Montreal Canadiens to the 1986 Stanley Cup, has reportedly been hired to coach the Pittsburgh Penguins. Paul Martha, vice president of the Penguins, refused to confirm the action. But three Montreal radio stations reported that Creamer had already signed a three-year contract with the Penguins and would be given a free hand to hire his own assistants. Creamer would replace Bob Berry, who was dismissed by Pittsburgh six weeks ago after the Penguins' second consecutive fifth-place finish in the Patrick Division.

title: NASA TOLD TO RELEASE TAPE OF CHALLENGER CREW'S LAST WORDS
description: A Federal district judge ruled yesterday that the National Aeronautics and Space Administration must make public the audio tape recorded in the launching of the space shuttle Challenger.

title: Celtics Hobbled by McHale's Injuries
description: The Celtics spent today trying to find some semblance of a silver lining amid the deluge that overwhelmed them Tuesday night. It wasn't easy.

title: TEMP-STIK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
CIGARETTE SALES TO JAPAN JOLTED
description: The disclosure that 16,000 cases of Winston Lights cigarettes shipped to Japan contained illegally high levels of a herbicide could threaten a major effort to sell American cigarettes in Japan.

title: Former St. Louis Official Acquitted in Cable Case
description: The former president of the St. Louis Board of Aldermen has been acquitted of trying to extort money from cable television companies seeking a city franchise.

title: Convicted Judge Appeals
description: Walter L. Nixon, only the second Federal judge convicted of crimes while in office, has asked a Federal appeals court to reconsider its ruling upholding his perjury conviction. Judge Nixon was sentenced last year to five years in prison for lying to a Federal grand jury regarding a drug suspect who was the son of a business partner. He is currently free pending the appeal.

title: Bonn's Double Take at Double Zero
description: West Germany's center-right coalition took six wrenching weeks to endorse a proposed Soviet-American missile pact in Europe. Chancellor Helmut Kohl will announce that welcome decision today, bringing opportunity for arms control and risk for West German political stability.

title: HOUSE APPROVES LAW ON FAIRNESS IN BROADCASTING
description: Despite opposition from the Reagan Administration, the House of Representatives overwhelmingly approved legislation today that would write into law a policy requiring broadcasters to cover community issues and present differing views on controversial topics.

title: Calendar; A Royal Boudoir Re-Created
description: First International Decorators Showcase, Ritz-Carlton Hotel, 2100 Massachusetts Avenue NW, Washington; 202-636-8743.

title: Debates Are Debated
description: Efforts on Capitol Hill to break the impasse over the sponsorship of next year's Presidential debates have failed, according to participants at a recent meeting held in the office of Senator Alan K. Simpson of Wyoming.

title: Albert J. Lowry In Bankruptcy
description: Albert J. Lowry, a supermarket butcher who made millions by buying rundown real estate and sharing his get-rich-quick tips in seminars and books, has filed for bankruptcy.

title: U.S. INDICTS BIAGGI, SON AND 5 OTHERS IN WEDTECH BRIBES
description: A Federal grand jury indicted Representative Mario Biaggi, his son and five others yesterday on charges of transforming the Wedtech Corporation into a criminal racketeering enterprise that paid millions of dollars in bribes to win military contracts.

title: La Roche-Lilly
description: Officials of Eli Lilly & Company and Hoffmann-La Roche Inc. have reached a license agreement covering a human growth hormone. Lilly began marketing the hormone in late March. A statement issued by Hoffmann-La Roche said the agreement had been reached ''as an alternative to litigation.''

title: Article 351187 -- No Title
description: The Senate Labor and Human Resources Committee today approved bills that would allow the spending of nearly $3.3 billion in 1988 for a variety of education, health and science programs.

title: U.S. Copter Sale to Colombia
description: The Pentagon notified Congress today that it had approved the sale of UH-60 Blackhawk helicopters to Colombia for use by its military in fighting drug traffickers. If there are no Congressional objections, the Pentagon said Colombia would be offered a package deal including either five or six helicopters for a total price of $36 million.

title: CITIZENS GROWTH PROPERTIES (CO) reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After extraordinary credits of $23,000 for the latest first quarter and $13,000 for the year-ago period.

title: Management Deal For Morse Shoe
description: Morse Shoe Inc., rejecting the overtures of the investor Asher B. Edelman, said today that it had agreed to be acquired by a management group for about $263 million in cash. The agreement, unanimously approved by Morse's board and recommended to shareholders, said that within five business days a newly formed corporation led by Manuel Rosenberg, the company's chairman, president and chief executive officer, would start a tender offer at $47 a share.

title: WEINBERGER WARNS OF PERIL IN NATO
description: In a speech marking the 40th anniversary of the Marshall Plan, Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger warned today that the Western alliance faced ''threats from within,'' and he called for strengthening of NATO to offset the ''military and political power of the Soviet Union.''

title: FLEET IN THE GULF: OUTCOME OF FUROR OVER IRAN...
description: After months of disclosures, investigations and personnel changes, the Reagan Administration's efforts to recover from the covert White House operation to sell arms to Iran have now begun to have an important effect on foreign policy.

title: The U.N. Today: June 4, 1987
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: ITALY'S BIGGEST PARTY STRESSES RELIGIOUS LINK
description: ''Giu-lio, Giu-lio!'' about 5,000 neatly dressed young people shouted over and over again in an ecstatic chant.

title: Hildegarde Flanner Monhoff, Poet and Author, Dead at 87
description: Hildegarde Flanner Monhoff, a poet and author, died of a heart attack May 27 in her home in Calistoga, Calif. She was 87 years old.

title: Antony Tudor Tribute In Words and Dance
description: A memorial for Antony Tudor, who was choreographer emeritus of American Ballet Theater, will be held July 9 at 10 A.M. at the Juilliard School, 155 West 65th Street.

title: SOUTH KOREAN WITH FUTURE: ROH TAE WOO
description: In handpicking the man virtually assured of becoming his successor, President Chun Doo Hwan of South Korea settled this week on a trusted friend who had helped him gain power and hold onto it.

title: INTERMEDICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 3
description: b-Includes an extraordinary credit of $2,282,000 for the quarter and a tax credit of $3,976,000 for the 6 months. c-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $2,686,000 for the quarter and income from discontinued operations of $12,223,000 for the 6 months; an extraordinary credit of $6,992,000 for the quarter and a tax credit of $7,070,000 for the 6 months; the quarter also includes a gain of $15,384,000 from disposal of discontinued operations.

title: Becor Western Postpones Vote
description: Becor Western Inc. said it would delay a shareholder vote, originally scheduled for Thursday, on the $238.1 million buyout proposal from a group of its senior management, led by Goldman, Sachs & Company. The vote will be delayed until ''all the parties have an opportunity to review the details'' of the new proposal by the Lynch Corporation, a Becor spokesman said.

title: DANCE: GABRIELA DARVASH'S 'COPPELIA'
description: THE emphasis is on dancing more than on dramatic and production values in Gabriela Darvash's ''Coppelia.'' But there was some very good dancing to be seen in a performance on Saturday evening at the Martin Luther King Jr. High School auditorium by guest professionals and by advanced ballet students from the Darvash Studio in Manhattan.

title: Port Authority In Japan Deal
description: Japan's Kansai International Airport Company said today that it would soon sign contracts with four foreign airport authorities, including the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, to help draw up a blueprint of its planned terminal in the west of the country.

title: SENATE DEBATES CURBS ON CAMPAIGN SPENDING
description: The Senate opened debate today on a Democratic bill to limit donations to political campaigns, with Republicans and Democrats predicting a long floor fight.

title: IMAGES WROUGHT IN GLASS
description: ''THE theme was mystery,'' said Douglas Heller, a co-owner of the Heller Gallery, ''but it was promptly ignored.'' Mr. Heller was talking about a crafts competition of glass perfume bottles sponsored by the French manufacturer Brosse et Cie, which makes bottles for many perfumers.

title: Cardinal Considers Hospitals for AIDS Only
description: John Cardinal O'Connor said last night that he would try to convert two or three hospitals in the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York for the treatment of AIDS patients exclusively.

title: Minnesota Crusader
description: Among Capitol Hill's lonely crusaders is Senator Rudy Boschwitz, a Minnesota Republican who has been taking the Senate floor weekly to argue for bringing back favorable tax treatment for capital gains.

title: Use of a Troop Barge As Prison Is Weighed
description: Governor Cuomo ordered state prison officials tonight to consider purchasing a troop barge used by the British Government to billet soldiers in the Falkland Islands, according to the state corrections chief.

title: RULE BY MINORITY PERSISTS IN BURUNDI
description: There is a land in Africa where an ethnic minority relies on rigged elections, press censorship, police violence and bans on public meetings to stave off majority rule.

title: R.J. Reynolds Plans Large Cuts in Staff
description: The R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company, citing increased competiton and declining cigarette consumption, said today that it would reduce its domestic work force significantly by year-end.

title: INSIDE
description: Revamping Penn Station

title: Stiff Penalties For Subway Crime Backed
description: The State Senate approved a measure today that would establish a mandatory penalty of at least two years in prison for anyone who commits a serious crime in a subway or on another form of public transportation.

title: BIRD INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary credit of $462,000. c-Net loss

title: MEDTRONIC INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $14,025,000.

title: PRESIDENT IN VENICE FOR PARLEY
description: President Reagan arrived here today for a meeting of the seven major industrial democracies prepared to make specific suggestions on how allied nations can become more involved in the Persian Gulf, White House officials said.

title: Update on Slaney
description: Mary Slaney, the runner who underwent arthroscopic surgery on her right Achilles' tendon Tuesday, might miss the 1987 season because her injury was more serious than doctors had expected. Dr. Stan James, who performed the surgery, said a considerable amount of scar tissue had to be removed. ''The gist of it all is that it's going to require a very slow, progressive rehabilitation,'' Dr. James said. ''She'll be under a pretty rigid training program.'' She will miss the national championships later this month, and she will not make the United States team that will compete in the World Championships in Rome later this year. Her coach, Luis de Oliveira, said it was not crucial for her return to competition this year. The real goal, he said, is to make sure she is fit for the 1988 Olympic Games.

title: FINAL TEST INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: THE NANNY SCHOOL SEEKS SOLID FOOTING
description: In a stately academy here, four women were citing Freud and Erik Erickson, analyzing the teething process and debating the flaws of baby powder. The women are part of a small but growing movement to create a cadre of American Mary Poppinses, nannies who can handle colic and fevers, make snacks out of wheat germ and perform the Heimlich maneuver on their 2-year-old charges. Preparation ranges from intensive eight-week courses to two-year programs that cover subjects as various as infant care and personal etiquette.

title: Security Pacific Retains Rating
description: The Security Pacific Corporation has retained its high-quality Aa-2 long-term debt rating, Moody's Investors Service announced yesterday.

title: McGOOHAN A SPY ON 31
description: WHILE the nation's public-television system continues to fret about financing and ideology, WNYC has decided to fill up some of its schedule gaps with what looks like a Patrick McGoohan festival. The station has done well by several runs of ''The Prisoner,'' a first-rate Kafka-esque series Mr. McGoohan did in the late 1960's for Britain's commercial ITC organization. Now, weeknights at 11 o'clock, Channel 31 is offering the earlier ''Secret Agent,'' an ITC series that had its premiere in 1965. In this one, done in black and white, Mr. McGoohan plays John Drake, a British ''special security agent'' traveling the world in search of adventure, although most of the filming was done at the MGM Studios in Boreham Wood, England.

title: SUN ELECTRIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After tax credits of $421,000 for the quarter and $844,000 for the 6 months. c-After tax credits of $130,000 for the quarter and $240,000 for the 6 months.

title: PRACTICAL, ESOTERIC, STYLISH FURNITURE AND ACCESSORIES
description: A VERY serious stainless-steel cabinet, a purely decorative 60-million-year-old petrified snail, and an esoteric table with feet made of elk-horn tips are some of the new objects on display around New York. The expensive, stylish wares, shown in two gallery exhibitions and a boutique, are barometers of the current tastes in furniture and accessories, which range from the craftsman's esthetic to exotic treasures.

title: Erik Bruhn Is Given Posthumous Award
description: A new award for ''exemplary contributions to Canada and its culture'' has been granted posthumously in Toronto to Erik Bruhn, the Danish-born artistic director of the National Ballet of Canada who died last year.

title: Jetliner, 63 Aboard, Barely Avoids Crash With Military Plane
description: A Northwest Airlines jet and a four-engine military jet came within about a quarter-mile of colliding Tuesday in the skies west of Rapid City, S.D., according to Government officials.

title: STAGE: 'SONGS ON A SHIPWRECKED SOFA'
description: MANY of the members of the creative team responsible for that enchanting cameo musical ''Goblin Market'' are reunited at the Vineyard Theater for ''Songs on a Shipwrecked Sofa'' - with one notable absence. The original author of ''Goblin Market'' was Christina Rossetti; the source for ''Shipwrecked Sofa'' is Mervyn Peake. Though Mr. Peake has his loyal admirers for his Gothic fantasies (the Gormenghast trilogy of novels), as an unwitting lyricist in the musical theater he is far outclassed by Rossetti, T. S. Eliot and others.

title: SPOLETO FESTIVAL U.S.A. COMPLACENT IN SUCCESS
description: THE Spoleto Festival U.S.A. concludes its 11th season in Charleston, S.C., on Sunday with the annual fireworks display, having presented its customary assortment of opera, jazz, chamber and orchestral music, dance, theater and, of course, puppet shows. Earlier this year, Gian Carlo Menotti, founder and director of the festival, announced that he would like Spoleto's board to begin a search for his successor, and while no one seems to believe he actually means it, there is in his statement perhaps the implication that Mr. Menotti feels he has taken Spoleto U.S.A. as far as he can. Where is that? Where many other arts festivals in the country are at the moment.

title: Cadillac Fairview Sale Keeps Purchaser Busy
description: Michael V. Prentiss is so busy completing a $450 million purchase of properties from the Cadillac Fairview Corporation that ''I've had a hard time doing anything else.''

title: GILDED-AGE SPLENDOR: A MANSION'S NEW LIFE
description: ALEC WEBB remembers games of hide-and-seek in the Main Hall of the Big House at Shelburne Farms, home-cooked meals eaten family style in the echoing Marble Room, a pet crow flying through some of the 110 rooms.

title: OUTDOOR CHIC: THE BRITISH TEAK BENCH
description: LEAD: WEIGHING in at 60 to 100 pounds, the English teak bench is a hefty piece of garden furniture that has long been a staple of British parks and public places. Lately, it has endeared itself to many Americans, who are buying it for their backyards, patios and gardens.

title: INDIAN FLOTILLA IS TURNED BACK BY SRI LANKAN NAVAL VESSELS
description: An Indian flotilla of fishing boats bound for northern Sri Lanka with food and medicine for ethnic Tamils abruptly called off its mission tonight and turned back after Sri Lankan naval vessels barred it from proceeding.

title: Datapoint Chooses A Chief Executive
description: The Datapoint Corporation has announced that Robert J. Potter will succeed Doris D. Bencsik as chief executive of the computer maker in San Antonio.

title: IT ALL STARTED WITH FUR TRADERS; NOW IT'S IN COURT
description: After a hundred years of petitioning for restitution of their ancestral lands, the Indians of Canada's remote northwest have brought their tale of dispossession to a courtroom in this quiet valley town.

title: GROUP SEEKS TO BUY DESIGNER'S PAPERS
description: A GROUP of designers, historians and writers has begun an urgent appeal for funds to purchase the archives of the designer Raymond Loewy, which are scheduled to be auctioned in Rambouillet, France, June 20 and 21.

title: The Greater Danger
description: To the Editor:

title: Space Aide to Leave Military
description: Lieut. Gen. Forrest S. McCartney, director of the Kennedy Space Center, will retire from the Air Force on Sept. 1 but will seek to keep his present job as a civilian, officials said today. General McCartney has been director at the center since Oct. 1, when he replaced Dick Smith. He has been active in the space center's recovery from the Jan. 28, 1986, shuttle Challenger explosion that killed seven astronauts.

title: SHAER SHOE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
'BEGONIA BANDIT' MYSTIFIES COURT STAFF
description: The Federal Courthouse in downtown Brooklyn -the home base of the United States Attorney for the Eastern District of New York and a Justice Department organized-crime strike force - has been hit in recent weeks by a series of bold thefts: Someone has been stealing begonias from outside the building.

title: MINNTECH reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a tax credit of $210,000. c-After tax credits of $72,000 for the quarter and $198,000 for the year.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Two Nations' Concern For a Caribou Herd
description: To the Editor:

title: STUARTS DEPARTMENT STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 2
description: b-Net income

title: TRUTH, IMPRESSIONS OR LIES? SEARCH FOR INTENT BEHIND REPLIES
description: Following are excerpts from Elliott Abrams's and Albert Hakim's testimony yesterday at the Congressional hearings in Washington on the Iran-contra affair, as recorded by The New York Times: ELLIOTT ABRAMS Lessons on Truth

title: MICRO GENERAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 29
KEY ISSUE IN COMPLEX WEDTECH CASE: WHEN DOES LOBBYING BECOME BRIBE
description: The 84-page indictment against Representative Mario Biaggi can be boiled down to two questions: Did he sell his influence to executives of the Wedtech Corp.? Or was he merely conducting business as usual in the murky waters where industry and government intersect?

title: Accounts
description: Maxwell Communication Corp. has retained Broadford & Maloney, Greenwich, Conn.

title: Sontag Heads PEN Center
description: Susan Sontag was elected president of PEN American Center yesterday at the organization's annual meeting. She succeeds Hortense Calisher as president of the group, the largest of the 86 centers of International PEN, the worldwide association of writers, translators and editors. Ms. Sontag, a member of the American Academy and Institute of Arts and Letters, is the author of many books, including ''Against Interpretation,'' ''On Photography'' and ''Illness as a Metaphor.''

title: Boston Bank Lifts Reserves
description: The Bank of Boston said yesterday that it had added $300 million to its reserve for possible credit losses because of concern over loans to certain less developed countries. Its total reserve for credit losses is now $700 million, the bank said.

title: So Much for Meese's 'Original Intention'
description: LEAD: Does anyone remember the ''Jurisprudence of Original Intention''?

title: Two Museums, Two Steps Forward
description: Two of New York City's most distinctive museum buildings - the Guggenheim and the Whitney - their storerooms bulging with masterworks, need to expand without overwhelming their East Side neighbors. Their plans to add space, revised to placate critics, will improve their surroundings as well as their own mission. Both proposals deserve the needed approvals from city agencies.

title: Iraq Voices Hope for Peace
description: With the United States and the Soviet Union showing increased interest in the Persian Gulf war, Iraqis say they hope the superpowers can bring the seven-year-old conflict to an end.

title: VOTERS DECLINE TO PAY FOR POLICE IN INNER-CITY AREA OF LOS ANGELES
description: Residents of an inner-city section of Los Angeles decisively rejected a ballot proposal Tuesday to add police officers by raising their property taxes above what other city residents pay.

title: YANKS' BULLPEN SAVES THE NIGHT
description: If a sterling shutout relief effort by Rich Bordi could overshadow another poor start by Dennis Rasmussen, then the Yankees might have walked away from last night's 9-3 victory over the California Angels feeling elated.

title: RECITAL: ELIZABETH RICH
description: ELIZABETH RICH is a pianist whose specialty is the reorganization of music by the German Romantics and Classicists into novel programming sequences. Monday evening she gave the first of two Merkin Concert Hall programs devoted to the music Beethoven wrote in 1802, a year of confrontation and struggle with his advancing deafness.

title: Murray Wins in 10,000
description: Patricia Murray, a Western Illinois senior, won the women's 10,000-meter run tonight as the National Collegiate Athletic Association began its 66th annual outdoor track and field championships.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of an editing error, a Washington dispatch yesterday about legislation on airline safety misstated the reason for a surplus in the airport trust fund. A surplus has been created by revenues that were higher than expected; since Sept. 30, $1.25 billion has been spent from the fund.

title: OHIO PAPER STIRS STORM ON GOVERNOR'S SEX LIFE
description: On Wednesday, The Plain Dealer in Cleveland, in an article that covered the top of its front page, said that Gov. Richard F. Celeste of Ohio, a Democrat who is considering a run for the Presidency, had been ''romantically linked'' with at least three women other than his wife, one as recently as 1985. The women were not identified and the information was attributed to ''several sources close to the Governor'' who were also not named.

title: MOSES' STREAK IS ENDED AT 122
description: Edwin Moses' 122-race winning streak, the longest in the history of track, ended today when Danny Harris, another American, beat him in the 400-meter hurdles at an international meet here.

title: FARM GROUPS URGE U.S. TO END WORLD BANK AID
description: Asserting that American farmers are being hurt by loans to less developed countries, some of the nation's most influential farm organizations today called on the United States to withdraw financial support from the World Bank and three other international development banks.

title: Computer Music
description: The Hub, a computer-music group, is to play a concert for computers linked by telephones Saturday and Sunday at 9 P.M. simultaneously at the Experimental Intermedia Foundation, 224 Centre Street, at Grand Street (212-431-5127), and at the Clocktower, 108 Leonard Street (212-233-1096). The performers and composers will be Chris Brown, John Bischoff, Mark Trayle, Tim Perkis, Scot Gresham-Lancaster and Phil Stone. Admission is $5.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the dedication of the first computer in a $400 million air control network misstated the role of Donald D. Engen, head of the Federal Aviation Administration.

title: State Controllers
description: Tucson High School won the Arizona state baseball championship last week, defeating its crosstown rival, Sahuaro High School, 11-3, at Tempe Diablo Stadium. That was the 28th state title for the team, and it added to the school's national record in that category.

title: Thompson Gets a Lift At Effies
description: THE J. Walter Thompson Company, whose people could certainly use the boost in morale, took five gold prizes last night as the most effective advertising of 1986 was honored at the 19th annual Effie Awards at the New York Hilton.

title: Segovia Was Here
description: ''Anyone who desires to survive into vigorous old age,'' Donal Henahan, the Times music critic, wrote last year, ''can improve his chance dramatically by arranging to be born with extraordinary talent as a musical performer.'' The master guitarist Andres Segovia, like Pablo Casals and Arthur Rubinstein, made such an arrangement. When he died this week at 94, he was watching television with his 17-year-old son - and perhaps wondering when he could reschedule the Carnegie Hall appearance he'd had to cancel last month.

title: Fairs and Festivals
description: Today CRAFT SHOW, #42d Street, between Fifth Avenue and Avenue of the Americas. Today, 10 A.M. to 6 P.M. Leather goods, jewelry, pottery, clothing. Through December. STREET FAIR, Public School 11, 21st Street between Eighth and Ninth Avenues. Today, 5 to 8 P.M. Games, crafts, flea market, toys, auction. FEAST OF ST. ANTHONY, Sullivan and West Houston Streets. Today through Sunday, noon to midnight. Through June 14. FEAST OF ST. ANTHONY, East 187th Street and Arthur Avenue, the Bronx. Today through Sunday, 7:30 to 11 P.M; sponsored by the Church of Our Lady of Mount Carmel. Food, rides, entertainment. Through June 14. Information: 295-3770. Tomorrow CRAFTS AND HEALTH EXPO '87, Public School 41, Avenue of the Americas and 11th Street; sponsored by the Circle of Light Institute. Tomorrow and Sunday, 11 A.M. to 7 P.M. Crafts, books, psychic readings. Admission $5 ($8 for both days.) Information: 564-2477. WASHINGTON SQUARE OUTDOOR ART EXHIBIT, University Place from 14th to Bleecker Streets, and Fifth Avenue from 10th Street to the Washington Square Park Arch. Tomorrow and Sunday, 11 A.M. to dusk. CHILDREN'S CARNIVAL, Little Red School House and Elizabeth Irwin High School, 196 Bleecker Street. Tomorrow, 10 AM. to 3 P.M. Crafts, games, books, food. Information: 477-5316. 15TH MURRAY HILL BLOCK PARTY, East 35th Street between Madison and Lexington Avenues. Tomorrow, noon to 6 P.M. Crafts, food, Caribbean music. Information: 532-3292. PLANTATHON, Broadway from 72d to 79th Streets; sponsored by the Federation of West Side Block Associations. Tomorrow, 10 A.M. to 6 P.M. Plants, crafts. Rain date, Sunday. Information: 799-9782. STREET FAIR, #78th Street between York Avenue and the East River; sponsored by the Tenants' Association of City and Suburban Housing. Tomorrow, 11 A.M. to 5 P.M. Antiques, toys, clothing, records, food and entertainment. Rain date, Sunday. FLEA MARKET, Holy Name of Jesus School, 245 Prospect Park West, between Windsor Place and Prospect Avenue, Windsor Terrace, Brooklyn. Tomorrow, 10 A.M. to 4 P.M. More than 80 vendors. Rain date, June 20. Information: (718) 788-7124. STREET FAIR FOR KIDS, Brooklyn Heights Promenade, below Orange Street; sponsored by the Penny Bridge Players. Tomorrow, noon to 3 P.M. Games, food, clowns. Information: (718) 855-6346 or (718) 858-9152. ANTIQUE FLEA MARKET, Ridgefield Community Center, 316 Main Street, Ridgefield, Conn. Tomorrow, 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. Admission, $2.50. Information: (203) 438-6962. Sunday SERVICE MANHATTAN FAIR, two locations - Educational Alliance, 197 East Broadway; and the Washington Heights/ Inwood Day Program, 3333 Broadway, between 133d and 135th Street; sponsored by the Manhattan Mental Retardation Developmental Disabilities Council. Sunday, noon to 4 P.M. Information on services for those who are mentally retarded or have developmental disabilities. Information: 741-3860. EIGHTH ANNUAL ART SHOW AND SALE, Brooklyn Botanic Garden, 1000 Washington Avenue, Crown Heights section. Sunday, 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. Rain date, June 21. Information: (718) 622-4433. HARMONY STREET FAIR, Borough Hall, St. George, S.I.; sponsored by the office of the Staten Island Borough President. Sunday, 11 A.M. to 6 P.M. International food, crafts, entertainment. RICHMONDTOWN FLEA MARKET, Richmondtown Restoration, 441 Clarke Avenue, Richmondtown, S.I. Collectibles, paintings. Sunday, 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. Admission, 50 cents (25 cents for those 6 to 12 years old; free for those under 6.) Information: (718) 351-1617.

title: How to Preserve the Milk Victory
description: Milk has become a symbol of triumph for New York City consumers. Since a Federal judge ordered the state to allow Farmland Dairy of New Jersey to sell milk in the city, the price has fallen 41 cents a gallon. But victory is not yet assured. As the Attorney General and consumer protection chief warn, low milk prices depend entirely on a single dairy that defies the local milk cartel.

title: ELECTION PANEL BARS MATCHING FUNDS FOR HART DRIVE
description: The Federal Election Commission today denied public matching funds for Gary Hart's abandoned effort to gain the Democratic Presidential nomination. This left his 1984 and 1988 campaigns with little immediate hope of settling $1.6 million in debts.

title: HOSPITAL TOLD TO DRAFT POLICY ON CARE AT END
description: The main agency that accredits hospitals in the United States said today that it would require them to have formal policies specifying when doctors and nurses may refrain from trying to resuscitate patients who are terminally ill.

title: NEW CHIEF FOR BANKERS TRUST
description: Charles S. Sanford Jr., who played a major role in turning the Bankers Trust New York Corporation into one of the most profitable of the nation's major banking institutions, yesterday was named chairman and chief executive of the company and of its subsidiary, the Bankers Trust Company. The appointment will become effective July 1, when Alfred Brittain 3d, the current chairman and chief executive, retires. Mr. Brittain will reach the mandatory retirement age of 65 in July.

title: Build Up Regular Forces
description: As allied support grows for an accord to reduce medium- and short-range nuclear forces in Europe, I am reminded of a brief conversation I had at the Reykjavik summit meeting with Marshal Sergei F. Akhromeyev, chief of staff of the Soviet armed forces.

title: ATTACK ON THE STARK COMPLICATES U.S. MILITARY TIES TO SAUDIS
description: The Iraqi missile attack on the United States frigate Stark last month has complicated Washington's military relationship with Saudi Arabia, whose pilots declined to intercept the Iraqi plane after its strike.

title: U.S. COURT UPHOLDS FINES AGAINST BISHOPS' GROUPS
description: A divided Federal appeals court yesterday affirmed a lower-court decision that imposed a $100,000-a-day fine against the two principal organizations of Roman Catholic Church bishops in this country.

title: '88 FESTIVAL SIGNS UP MANY ARTISTS
description: More than 25 dance, theater, music and film programs from 16 nations have been engaged for the first New York International Festival of the Arts next June, Martin E. Segal, chairman of the festival, announced yesterday. Negotiations are under way for some 60 more.

title: Japan Funds Seen For BankAmerica
description: Japanese banks appear ready to invest between $100 million and $300 million in BankAmerica Corporation securities according to a source close to the negotiations.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: FRIDAY, JUNE 5, 1987
description: MARKETS

title: HAKIM SAYS NORTH MUST HAVE KNOWN OF FUND FOR HIM
description: Albert Hakim, an Iranian-born businessman, testified today that he thought Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North must have been aware that a secret $200,000 Swiss bank account had been set up for him and that Mr. Hakim had made him a beneficiary in his will for $2 million.

title: Let the Drug Addict Have Clean Needles
description: To the Editor:

title: GOETZ JUDGE PONDERS CRUCIAL ORDERS TO JURY
description: Every morning for nearly six weeks, the judge in the trial of Bernhard H. Goetz has carried the same manila file folder under his arm as he strides to the bench in State Supreme Court in Manhattan.

title: EDWARD A. EPPINGER
description: Edward A. Eppinger, who built a fishing-lure empire through the sale of the Dardevle lure, died Monday at his home here. He was 82 years old.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Our goal is to avoid the useless prolongation of dying. This is not a quality-of-life issue, a question of what the patient's life will be like if he gets better.

title: WEST GERMAN PARLIAMENT BACKS PLAN ON MEDIUM-RANGE MISSILES
description: The West German Parliament today formally endorsed the Government's decision to support Soviet and American efforts to eliminate medium-range land-based missiles from Europe, though Chancellor Helmut Kohl came under fire from both left and right.

title: Bridge: Title Last Week for Stayman Was One He Captured in '40
description: Few people in the history of the game, or indeed of any competitive recreation, have won the same major title with an interval of 47 years.

title: Jersey Chooses Ocean County To Store Radium
description: The state's environmental commissioner today ordered 15,000 barrels of radium-contaminated soil that have been stored in Montclair and Kearny moved to state-owned land in Jackson Township.

title: TONY BIRD AT SPEAKEASY
description: Tony Bird, an East African songwriter, is to perform songs tonight at Speakeasy, 107 Macdougal Street (598-9670), with Sonya-San, an a capella singer, opening. Tomorrow, Dave Van Ronk is to sing, with Riverrun, a folk group, opening. Sets are at 8:30 and 11 P.M.; admission is $6 with a two-drink minimum.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE
description: Bucks Name Harris

title: ALYSHEBA 8-5 PICK TO DRAW 3 OF A KIND
description: Alysheba was rained out of his final workout yesterday morning, then drew post No. 4 in a field of 10 and was installed as the 8-to-5 favorite to become racing's 12th Triple Crown winner by winning the Belmont Stakes tomorrow at Belmont Park.

title: One Question Too Many
description: To the Editor:

title: The U.N. Today: July 5, 1987
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Forbes Spoofs Business Week
description: It's double-take time at the newsstands once again. This time, it's not similar covers on Time and Newsweek, but it's Forbes aping the cover format of Business Week with its June 15 issue. And it's really an inside joke. William Donald Garson, public relations director of Forbes, said it was the magazine's way of retaliating for what he called Business Week's copying of Forbes's idea for an issue on chief executives. Mark Dacey, ad director of

title: NEWS SUMMARY: FRIDAY, JUNE 5, 1987
description: International A2-11

title: The Sharp Rise Of Shoe Shares
description: IN an equity market that seems lately to have lost its sense of direction, several shoe stocks -considered a ''niche'' industry by most Wall Street standards - have moved ahead briskly.

title: Atlanta Talks On Exchange
description: A group of 23 corporations and financial institutions was asked today to join in a study of the feasibility of opening a 24-hour-a-day stock exchange in Atlanta.

title: LET'S NOT TORPEDO THE GROWTH OF JOBS
description: Many people who believe - wrongly - that America is creating primarily low-skill, dead-end jobs are devising schemes for job protection and Government intervention. Such schemes have been tried in Europe and have failed; indeed, several countries attending next week's economic summit conference are now busily attempting to reverse interventionist policies that have prevented the creation of new jobs.

title: Winning Coach Looking for a Job
description: After more than a quarter-century during which he guided basketball teams at St. Agnes Cathedral High School in Rockville Centre, L.I., to 471 victories in 593 games and to 10 Nassau-Suffolk Catholic League championships, Frank Morris is suddenly a basketball coach without a job. And at the age of 53, he says that his employment prospects are uncertain.

title: KLAN'S CAROLINA MARCH KINDLING FEAR AND UNITY
description: Ranks of robed Ku Klux Klan marchers plan to parade through the streets of Greensboro Sunday in their first public demonstration here since a bloody shootout between armed Klansmen and leftists in 1979 left five people dead.

title: Our Towns; Forget the Jokes: Looking Good In Secaucus
description: If NBC moves to Secaucus, its news crews should be warned they won't get the kind of footage from the big developer here - Eugene Heller - that they now get by going around the corner and talking to Donald Trump.

title: GANDHI OPPONENTS BACK MOVE
description: Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi won opposition support for India's air drop of relief supplies for the Tamils in northern Sri Lanka Thursday night and moved to explain and defend the Indian action to leaders of other nations.

title: One Test Deserves Another
description: It's a true piece of fortune that Edward Koch is Mayor of New York and not, say, Secretary of State. Consider his suggestion that all foreign tourists to New York be barred if they test positive for the AIDS virus. Consider how ill considered this idea turns out to be.

title: Gooden Returning to a 'Circus' at Shea
description: The night will belong to a couple of superheroes, one found in the funny pages, the other a young pitcher known as Dr. K, both attempting to overcome the pitfalls of the real world.

title: Gerber Gets Offer For Trucking Unit
description: The Gerber Products Company said the management of CWT Inc., its trucking subsidiary, had offered to purchase the business. Gerber had declared its interest in selling the unit two months ago. It said acceptance of the deal depended on CWT management's obtaining financing for its leveraged buyout offer.

title: PROPER CHANNELS
description: ESPN's coverage of the seventh game of the Stanley Cup championship series between the Edmonton Oilers and the Philadelphia Flyers on Sunday received a 5.0 rating from the A. C. Nielsen company and attracted the fourth largest viewing audience - 2,140,000 million homes - in ESPN's eight-year history. The game, which Edmonton won, 3-1, was the only hockey game among ESPN's 10 most-watched events. Homes are in millions.

title: Trios at Sweet Basil
description: Cedar Walton on piano, Ron Carter on bass and Billy Higgins on drums play trios tonight through Sunday at Sweet Basil, 88 Seventh Avenue South, above Bleecker Street (212-242-1785). Sets are at 10 and 11:45 P.M. and 1:30 A.M; there is a $12 cover and a $6 minimum.

title: TRAIL OF 2 LOST TIGERS ENDS IN THE BRONX
description: Two rare white tigers in the back of a parked truck were abducted on the West Side of Manhattan yesterday morning, apparently by someone who was unaware of the truck's cargo. Five hours later, after a citywide search by the police, a safety alert by health officials and a news alert by television and radio stations, the tigers were found unharmed in the back of the truck, which had been abandoned in the Bronx.

title: RESTAURANTS
description: AMERICAN HARVEST, the showcase restaurant at the Vista International Hotel in the shadow of the World Trade Center, bills itself as a star-spangled celebration of home-grown provender prepared with allegiance to our culinary heritage. O.K., maybe the Pilgrims didn't garnish salmon steaks with juniper berries and lemon mayonnaise, but why be persnickety and spoil the party? Part of the oversized menu with its colorful photographs of seasonal produce changes from month to month to reflect the progression of the harvest.

title: 4 LABS ACHEIVE NEW GAINS ON CONDUCTING ELECTRICITY
description: At least four laboratories are now reporting tests in which synthetic materials show signs of losing all resistance to electrical current at close to room temperature of about 70 degrees Fahrenheit. The findings have further encouraged hope that the components with total loss of resistance can be isolated and used for a multitude of revolutionary applications.

title: Andersen Tales
description: A reading of ''Hans Clodhopper,'' the Hans Christian Andersen story, is to open the 31st season of free storytelling at the Hans Christian Andersen statue tomorrow at 11 A.M. in Central Park, near Fifth Avenue and 72d Street. The reading will be given by Diane Wolkstein, with musical accompaniment by Shirley Keller, a guitarist. The sessions feature a different storyteller each week and will run every Saturday morning through Sept. 26.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: GOLF

title: MAKING DANCE FUNNY: SANDRA CHIN
description: YOU wouldn't guess it from her offstage manner, but Sandra Chinn feels more comfortable as a cockroach than as a butterfly.

title: SABERHAGEN STOPS MARINERS TO WIN 10TH
description: Bret Saberhagen became the first 10-game winner in the major leagues, pitching a seven-hitter tonight as the Kansas City Royals beat the Seattle Mariners, 6-1.

title: Syria Is Reported to Curtail Abu Nidal Group's Activities
description: Syria has closed offices of Abu Nidal's Palestinian organization and forced many of his followers to leave the country, The Jordan Times reported today.

title: IRANIAN ON TOUR URGING U.S. ALLIES TO REBUFF MILITARY PLANS IN GULF
description: A senior Iranian diplomat urged Washington's allies in Europe today to reject plans to safeguard shipping in the Persian Gulf, warning that an increased American military presence there would prove dangerous.

title: Ex-Boesky Official in Suit
description: Reid Nagle, an investment banker formerly employed by Ivan F. Boesky & Company, filed suit yesterday in New York State Supreme Court against Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc., charging that it failed to honor an employment agreement.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: THE place was the Museum of Modern Art Sculpture Garden, where Blaine Trump let out a hearty but ladylike cheer at Wednesday night's fund-raising Party in the Garden. Carolyne Roehm had just told her that the Victorian Boating Party had been postponed.

title: L.I. EXECUTIVES PLEAD GUILTY TO STEALING PIPES FROM CITY
description: Two operators of a Long Island company pleaded guilty yesterday to Federal charges that they stole $1 million of pipes owned by New York City and then sold the pipes to contractors working on the city's sewer and water mains.

title: COURT OVERTURNS CONVICTION IN L.I. MURDER CASE
description: New York State's highest court today overturned the murder conviction of a Long Island youth serving 25 years to life in prison for killing a 13-year-old boy by stuffing rocks into his mouth.

title: Violin-Viola Concert
description: Israel Chorberg, a violinist, and Harold Coletta, a violist, are to perform works by Mozart, Paul Chihara, Villa-Lobos and others, Sunday at 3 P.M. at Merkin Concert Hall, 129 West 67th Street. Tickets are $7. Information: (212) 362-8719.

title: ELIZABETH MORGAN
description: Elizabeth Morgan, a veteran actress and longtime officer and board member of the American Federation of Television and Radio Artists, died of a stroke on Sunday at her Manhattan home.

title: Yiddish Entertainment Locally and on Tour
description: Two presentations of Yiddish theater - one by members of a troupe from the Soviet Union - are planned at two locations in the city this weekend.

title: LAXALT DROPS SUIT OVER NEWS ARTICLE
description: Former Senator Paul Laxalt of Nevada and the McClatchy newspaper chain announced an agreement yesterday to dismiss competing lawsuits that have been seen as a barrier to Mr. Laxalt's plans to run for President.

title: Mets Return With Few Scars
description: The Mets came home from California yesterday to set the stage for the return of Dwight Gooden tonight. ''We're through the worst of it,'' Dave Johnson said. ''We got past the road trip. We pieced the pitching together, and we bought time.''

title: MORE ANSWERS ON MONEY FOR THE NORTHS: SEEKING A WAY TO TRANSFER FUNDS
description: At the hearings in Washington on the Iran-contra affair, the Congressional committees heard yesterday from a new witness, David M. Lewis, and continued their questioning of Albert Hakim. Here are excerpts from their testimony, as recorded by The New York Times. DAVID M. LEWIS Opening Statement

title: AGENCY FIGHTS BILL TO REVISE PROGRAM THAT HELPED WEDTECH
description: The head of the Small Business Administration today strongly opposed a bill to revise the Federal program that enabled the Wedtech Corporation to obtain hundreds of millions of dollars in Government contracts.

title: TITLE PICTURE NOW IN DISARRAY
description: When Sugar Ray Leonard announced his conditional retirement from boxing last week, it set off a scramble among middleweight contenders in the suddenly wide-open division.

title: BLENDING CLASSIC AND NEW IN A BUSTLING DANCE SEASON
description: THE spring dance season is bustling along its hectic way with the kind of variety and quantity that have made New York the dance capitol of the world. But this is also a weekend that offers a distinctive blend of the old and the new. The seasoned veteran and the newcomer take to the stage in dance that ranges from performances of 19th-century ballet rarities to the antics of exuberant children and adolescents.

title: Treasury Prices Up Slightly
description: Bond prices were stable to slightly higher yesterday as many market participants waited for fresh economic data and next week's economic summit meeting.

title: A 5.3% Stake In Texas Air
description: The New York investor George Soros has purchased 2.13 million shares of the Texas Air Corporation, a 5.3 percent stake in the nation's largest airline, for $85.5 million.

title: AND IN THE 14TH GENERATION, WILL FARMING PERISH?
description: The bright green rice shoots stand in the flooded paddies of Furukawa; the spring planting is over and in a few months the harvest will begin.

title: Nomination Is History
description: John T. Agresto, deputy chairman of the National Endowment for the Humanities, has notified the White House that he is withdrawing his candidacy to become Archivist of the United States.

title: Roy Eaton
description: Roy Eaton, a pianist, is to present an all-Chopin program Sunday at 3 P.M. in Alice Tully Hall. Tickets are $15. Information 362-1911.

title: SECOND VIRUS OF AIDS SPREADING FROM AFRICA
description: A second AIDS virus, previously reported spreading in West Africa, has been detected in Europe and Brazil, Dr. Luc Montagnier of the Pasteur Institute in Paris said here today.

title: COURT ORDER MUZZLES 2 USUALLY FORTHCOMING WEDTECH PROSECUTORS
description: No matter how many ways they phrased the questions, reporters could not lure the two prosecutors, Rudolph W. Giuliani or Mario Merola, to make broad comments on greed and corruption in the Wedtech case.

title: NORTH TO BE GRANTED LIMITED IMMUNITY
description: Over the objection of the special prosecutor, the Congressional committees investigating the Iran-contra affair voted today to compel testimony from Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North by granting him limited immunity from prosecution.

title: Fort Greene Tour
description: Private homes, a church, a concert hall and a park can be visited on Sunday during a tour of the Fort Greene section of Brooklyn. The tour, sponsored by the Fort Greene Landmarks Preservation Committee, begins at noon at the Williamsburg Savings Bank, 1 Hanson Place, off Flatbush Avenue. Admission is $6 (advance tickets) or $7 on the day of the tour ($5 for the elderly.)

title: SPORTS PEOPLE
description: Hitting Streak Ends

title: A NEW SHOW CHRONICLES RESURGENCE OF BERLIN ART
description: THROUGH the first part of the century, Berlin was a city in which culture flourished - not just art movements like German Expressionism and Dada, but also music, literature and theater. Under Hitler, Berlin was the Nazi headquarters. During World War II, it was almost leveled. In 1961 it was divided in two by the Berlin Wall. At about that time, artists began returning to their Expressionist and Dada roots. Art in Berlin revived. Now, nearing the end of the century, West Berlin is again a cultural center.

title: U.S. Court Rules Against Aquino
description: A Federal appeals court today overturned a ruling freezing assets of the former President of the Philippines, Ferdinand E. Marcos, and his wife, Imelda, saying the Philippine Government had little chance of regaining $1.5 billion it claims the couple stole.

title: Panel Refuses to Block Sale Of Jets by U.S. to Honduras
description: A House subcommittee refused today to block the sale of 12 F-5 jet fighters to Honduras, a decision that legislators said would effectively end Congressional attempts to halt the deal.

title: State to Drop Tribble Charge
description: A prosecutor said today that the state would drop its case against Brian Lee Tribble, who was acquitted of all charges of supplying the cocaine that killed Len Bias, the Maryland basketball star.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday CHAMBER SYMPHONY

title: Specter of Chernobyl Looms Over Bangladesh
description: It is said here, adapting an old folk expression, that Chernobyl is seven seas and 13 rivers away from Bangladesh. But these days it seems much closer.

title: MUSIC: ROGER MILLER
description: ''THE next song, 'Scratch,' requires four alligator clips, a bolt, a comb and a guitar slide to make it sound just right,'' Roger Miller said Wednesday night at CBGB. He calmly placed those objects on the strings of a Yamaha electric grand piano and -using reverberation and distortion devices, a synthesizer and a tape-loop echo-repeat system - played another plinking, clanking, crunching, howling song.

title: Morgan Grenfell Official Joins Unit of Citicorp
description: John B. Fraser, the president of Morgan Grenfell Inc., the New York-based subsidiary of the British merchant bank, has left to become a managing director in the mergers and acquisitions department of the Citicorp Investment Bank.

title: House Members Reject Compromise on Budget
description: House Budget Committee members today rejected a compromise on the 1988 budget that would have given the Defense Department $8 billion more than the House approved.

title: TOURING THE WHITE HOUSE WITH HOPE AND AN IRANIAN
description: At one point in his testimony, Albert Hakim described a tour of the White House that he and Lieut. Col. Oliver North gave to a contact in the Iranian Government who came to be known as the ''second channel.''

title: SPORTS PEOPLE
description: Penguins Hire Coach

title: Graf and Navratilova Reach French Open Final
description: Steffi Graf and Martina Navratilova won semifinal matches today at the French Open, setting up what promises to be an emotion-charged final.

title: KEY RATES
Gone to Its Reward
description: An unpopular Congressional experiment has died a quiet death. Last year, under pressure from a new budget-balancing law, Congress started charging the public for bills, committee reports and other official publications.

title: JERRY ROBERTS
description: Jerry Roberts, a veteran broadcaster, died May 24 at the Hackensack (N.J.) Medical Center. He was 71 years old and lived in Lyndhurst, N.J.

title: JURY RECOMMENDS LIFE TERM FOR LEADER OF CALIFORNIA CLUB
description: A Superior Court jury today recommended a life sentence with no possibility of parole for Joe Hunt, the founder of a business and social group calling itself the Billionaire Boys Club, in the murder of a Beverly Hills man.

title: ART: THE METAMORPHOSIS IN CARLO CARRA'S WORK
description: IN 1908, Carlo Carra (1881-1966) produced ''Riders of the Apocalypse,'' a torrid piece of Symbolism featuring three mounted figures, two of whom are nymphs. Two years later, the artist was a Futurist, extolling machinery, speed, violence and other manifestations of the male principle.

title: AS TIMES DROP, PRESSURE RISES
description: A few weeks ago, in her Villanova dormitory, Vicki Huber spotted a copy of Track and Field News. As she thumbed through the magazine, she noticed a list of athletes in the National Collegiate Athletic Association championships.

title: Cigarette Packs as Art
description: Wrappings and ribbons from tobacco packaging of the late 19th century are included in the exhibition ''Tobacco Roads: The Popular Art of an American Pastime,'' on view at City Gallery, 2 Columbus Circle. The display, organized by the Museum of American Folk Art, features about 70 items that illustrate the relationship of the tobacco industry and folk art. It will run through July 24. Hours are Monday through Friday, 10 A.M. to 5:30 P.M.

title: BOTHA IS WELCOMED IN BLACK TOWNSHIP
description: President P. W. Botha was mobbed by hundreds of cheering blacks today when he visited this bleak township, where 69 protesting blacks were killed by the police in 1960.

title: Florida Lottery Set Jan. 15
description: Gov. Bob Martinez signed the Florida lottery bill into law today, with a starting date of Jan. 15. The bill was approved by the Legislature seven months after voters passed a referendum to use lottery games to finance education. The lottery is expected to raise an estimated $144 million in the last half of the fiscal year 1987-88 and become a billion-dollar business in its first year.

title: Building 'Tracker' Organ Is Focus of Film on 13
description: ''In the 18th century, the tracker organ was the most complex machine assembled by Western man.'' That arresting thought comes from an hourlong documentary to be shown tonight at 10 on Channel 13 entitled ''The Wind at One's Fingertips.'' The subject is a Nebraska organ builder, Gene R. Bedient, and the yearslong process by which he and his crew of craftsmen researched, designed, built and installed an 18th-century, French-style, tracker-action organ at St. Mark's Church in Grand Rapids, Mich.

title: STRICT NEW RULES FOR AIRLINES ASKED
description: Faced with mounting consumer complaints and moves in Congress to pass new laws, the Department of Transportation acted today to press airlines to improve baggage handling, operate closer to schedule and reduce cancellations.

title: Kraft to Purchase General Host Unit
description: The General Host Corporation, a diversified retailer, said Kraft Inc. will purchase its majority-owned All American Gourmet Company subsidiary for $296 million. All American Gourmet, which makes the Budget Gourmet frozen food label, had sales of $195 million in the year ending in April. General Host -whose subsidiaries include Frank's Nursery and Crafts Inc., the Flower Time chain of retail garden stores, and Hickory Farms - owns about 75 percent of the frozen-food company's 16.4 million shares.

title: WHEN A TRIUMPH ROSE FROM ASHES
description: ''There aren't many of us left,'' observed Clark M. Clifford, the silver-gray eminence who has served as a counselor to Presidents for more than 40 years.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE
description: MacLeod Joins Dallas

title: ROME HONORS A FRIEND OF CHILDREN IN NEED
description: A 74-year-old Irish prelate, Msgr. John Patrick Carroll-Abbing, who founded Boys Town and Girls Town of Italy 40 years ago, was made an honorary citizen of Rome this evening, the third non-Italian in modern history to be so honored. The others were Presidents Woodrow Wilson and Franklin D. Roosevelt.

title: FILM: GERMANY'S 'THEATER IN RUINS'
description: HARDLY had Nazi Germany died in 1945 than Berlin's theaters began to come to life. The need for diversion seemed almost as great as any of the other many needs of the residents of a destroyed and conquered city. People lined up at box offices, much as they lined up for water or fuel, some having walked for two or three hours to see a production of ''The Gay Parisienne.'' ''Theater in Ruins,'' Irmgard von zur Muehlen's absorbing documentary now at the Thalia SoHo, begins at that point and goes on to tell, with clips and stills from productions of the time, how the re-emergent theater was divided, along with the rest of Berlin, into political zones.

title: DOING 'LAMBETH WALK': A VOTE FOR BRITAIN'S POOR
description: Mention the slums of Lambeth and the average English voter might only smile and hum the show-stopping tune ''Lambeth Walk,'' envisioning this city's doughty Cockneys happy with a meager lot in life as they coarsely needle their social betters.

title: BREWERS BAFFLE YANKS, WIN 6TH IN ROW
description: The most up-and-down team in baseball, the Milwaukee Brewers, was up tonight and sent the Yankees down to defeat, 9-3.

title: Texas Instruments
description: Sweden's telecommunications giant L. M. Ericsson said it had signed an agreement with Texas Instruments Inc. Under the deal, Texas Instruments will design and produce semiconductors for use by Ericsson. In return Texas Instruments is to receive more business from Ericsson. No financial transactions are involved, Ericsson said. The company said this cooperation would allow the two companies to market new technology before it becomes obsolete in an extremely fast-moving market.

title: U.S. WON'T JOIN SUIT AGAINST ROCKET COMPANY
description: The Justice Department said yesterday that it would not join a lawsuit against Morton Thiokol Inc., maker of the space shuttle's solid-fuel booster rockets. The suit charges the company with defrauding the Government by knowingly providing defective rockets.

title: ART: THE HUGE IMAGES OF GILBERT AND GEORGE
description: THE two London-based artists who call themselves simply Gilbert and George made their debut, many a long year ago, in two quite different ways. As performance artists, they painted their faces and hands bright gold and turned themselves into human automatons, miming by the hour to a tape of a once-popular English music hall song called ''Underneath the Arches.'' This they did in many parts of the world, and with hallucinatory success.

title: INSIDE
description: No Matching Funds for Hart

title: ART: ASHLEY BICKERTON AND WORK AS COMMODITY
description: THIS is a time when many young artists feel compelled to stress the commodity status of the work they produce. They let us know they know that their art is in part made to be bought, installed and viewed, that it may bring its maker fame and fortune and its owner pleasure and status. Few artists make this knowledge evident with as much chutzpah and technical finesse as Ashley Bickerton, who has dedicated his second one-person exhibition at International With Monument (111 East Seventh Street, near First Avenue, through Sunday) to Robin Leach. Mr. Bickerton seems to have had a good year, and when he plasters ''Ashley 'Wildcat' Bickerton'' acrossthe front of one of his pieces, which also bears the label ''Season 86-87,'' he seems to both revel in and ridicule this fact.

title: A Crucial Deadline for New York Toxic Victims
description: To the Editor:

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A picture caption on Wednesday about the removal of a sculpture from Astor Place for restoration incorrectly described donations being made under the Adopt-a-Monument program. Dan Neale, who adopted the sculpture, is paying for restoration but not for annual maintenance; the Cooper Union has assumed that responsibility. The caption also mislocated the Lippincott Foundry, which is in North Haven, Conn. One sponsor of the program was omitted; it is the New York City Art Commission.

title: GUNMAN KILLS QUEENS LIQUOR STORE OWNER, HIS WIFE AND A PATRON
description: A gunman held up a liquor store in Queens last night and fatally shot the owner, the owner's wife and a customer, then fled on foot, the police said.

title: Officer Quits Calvin Klein
description: Calvin Klein Industries has lost its second high-ranking executive this week. Edward M. Jones 3d has resigned as president and director of international licensing at the company's Classics division, the fashion designer Calvin Klein said yesterday.

title: BRITISH TROOP BARGE PROPOSED AS A PRISON
description: The head of New York State's prisons said today that he would recommend the purchase of a decommissioned British troop barge for use as a 700-bed minimum-security prison.

title: AIDS EXPERT SEES NO SIGN OF HETEROSEXUAL OUTBREAK
description: A top Federal expert, in an effort to calm some of the increasing anxiety over AIDS, emphasized here today that surveys had found no sign that a major spread of the AIDS virus had begun among heterosexual Americans.

title: ARTISTS RALLY TO FIGHT AIDS
description: Never underestimate the power of a movie star. Especially a superstar like Elizabeth Taylor. Once she attached her name to the American Foundation for AIDS Research, it became not only acceptable but desirable for other celebrities to become involved in the cause.

title: REAGAN SEEKS NEW U.N. PUSH IN GULF
description: President Reagan will seek support at the economic summit meeting here for a United Nations resolution threatening Iran and Iraq with an arms embargo if they refuse negotiations to end their war, White House officials said today.

title: AIDS Is by No Means the Only Threat
description: To the Editor:

title: JOSEPH LICITRA
description: Joseph Licitra, managing partner of the Garden City, L.I., law firm of Shaw, Goldman, Licitra, Levine & Weinberg, died Wednesday at Winthrop-University Hospital in Mineola, L.I., after a long illness. He was 57 years old and lived in Garden City.

title: American to Direct Jardine Matheson
description: The Jardine Matheson group, one of the oldest and biggest trading companies in Asia, yesterday named an American lawyer as its managing director.

title: Union Organizers Back Pact
description: The National Education Association's professional organizers ratified a new contract today, ending a three-day strike that had hobbled activities at the union's national headquarters. Barry Abel, a spokesman for the 63-member Association of Field Service Employees, said the three-year contract provided annual raises of 5 percent and improvements in the pension plan.

title: 2 SCANDALS MEET AT CHURCH IN BRONX
description: The vectors of two seemingly unrelated scandals intersected this week at an East Bronx church, appropriately named the Cross Road Tabernacle.

title: Late Show Film Series
description: More than 30 films by artists and film makers from the East Village are to be shown this weekend at the New Theater, 62 East Fourth Street. The films are part of the Late Show Film Series, which will be offered at the theater for the next four weekends. Screenings this weekend are at 8 and 10 P.M. today and tomorrow. Admission is $5 per showing. Information: 473-1167.

title: A MAESTRO'S EVOLUTION: DePRIEST'S DIFFICULT PATH
description: ''MAKE the music accessible and let the people decide whether they want to come hear it or not,'' said James DePreist, talking by phone the other day from his home in Oregon about the program with the New York Philharmonic he conducts tonight and tomorrow at 8 P.M. in Avery Fisher Hall.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Buckeye Financial Corp., Columbus, Ohio, a holding company, said it had accepted an offer in which First Financial Group Inc. would acquire each common share of Buckeye for a package consisting of $9 in cash, $8 in First Financial debentures, and $3 in preferred stock.

title: WHITE HOUSE WILL BE ASKED IF 3 ARE LINKED TO IRAN AFFAIR
description: The chairman of a House subcommittee said today that he would ask the White House to reveal the duties of three Small Business Administration employees working at the White House without the consent of their agency.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Super African Festival 1, Beacon Theater, 74th and Broadway (496-7070). Lilting, deftly interlocked electric guitar riffs and hearty choral singing in thirds characterize the brand of African pop music that dominates Zaire. Tabu Ley Rochereau has been the style's most consistently successful singer for a decade or more, and recently a series of duet recordings with the sparkling young singer M'Bilia Bel have given his popularity an added boost. Together they should put on quite a show, and Mr. Rochereau's 20-piece band is one of Africa's best. Dallol, a reggae band from Ethiopia, and Djimo Kouyate, playing the 21 stringed kora harp-lute of Senegal, are also on the program, which begins Saturday at 8 P.M. Tickets are $18 in advance, from the Beacon Theater box office, Ticketron (399-4444), and Teletron (947-5850); they will be $20 at the door.

title: Dow Up 16.39; Volume Still Modest
description: Building on the previous day's sharp rally, the Dow Jones industrial average added 16.39 points yesterday, to close at 2,337.08, its highest level in a month.

title: Trouble Spots Are Listed for Weekend Traffic
description: The New York City Department of Transportation has listed these trouble spots for weekend traffic:

title: Big Time Sarah
description: Big Time Sarah, a blues singer, is to perform tonight and tomorrow at Tramps, 125 East 15th Street (212-777-5077), with sets at 9:30 P.M. and midnight. There is a $10 cover and a two-drink minimum.

title: FOR GARIN, ALL MUSIC IS FAIR GAME
description: MICHAEL GARIN, a droll, 32-year-old musical comic whose sense of humor is a bit too refined for comedy clubs, has written what may be the ultimate parody of a certain style of self-pitying cocktail song. In clubs and variety showcases around New York over the last several years, Mr. Garin has regularly performed his languid, tinkly love ballad, ''My Hand,'' whose verses echo the deadpan musical humor of Tom Lehrer.

title: New York City Sales Up 8.2%
description: Retail sales in New York City rose an average 8.2 percent in May over the year before, a spot-check found yesterday, while sales in the metropolitan area were up an average of 7.7 percent.

title: FILM: 'HARRY,' THE STORY OF A SENTIMENTAL BIGFOOT
description: Attention must be paid when a movie is as aggressively awful as ''Harry and the Hendersons,'' though it's so pin-headed that it could be the last of its inbred line. It's not likely to spawn.

title: Iran-Contra Hearings Undermine Foreign Relations
description: To the Editor:

title: New Chief Executive Is Named by Wedtech
description: The Wedtech Corporation announced yesterday the appointment of a new chief executive officer as the South Bronx military contractor struggled to stay in business.

title: 'The Magic Flute'
description: The newly formed American National Opera Company is to present Mozart's ''Magic Flute,'' in English, conducted by James Kay, tonight and tomorrow at 8 P.M. and Sunday at 3 P.M., and again June 12 through 14 at the same times, at the Brooklyn Conservatory, 58 Seventh Avenue, near Flatbush Avenue, in the Park Slope section. Tickets are $10. Information: (718) 622-3300.

title: CUOMO FAULTS ETHICS PROPOSAL BY LAWMAKERS
description: Opening a new front in his confrontation with state legislators over new laws on ethics in government, Governor Cuomo said today that an ethics bill now under negotiation would be inadequate to prevent corrupt practices in state government.

title: INSURERS TO LIMIT POLICIES OF BUYERS REFUSING AIDS TEST
description: Several of the nation's largest insurance companies are planning drastic reductions in the amount of life insurance they will offer to anyone who refuses to take blood tests for the AIDS virus.

title: Marshall Plan, As Seen Today
description: A FEW days before President Reagan took off for Venice this week, he spoke in the East Room of the White House in honor of the memory of George C. Marshall on the 40th anniversary of the Marshall Plan. On June 5, 1947, General Marshall, then the Secretary of State, delivered the commencement address at Harvard University, offering American help for the reconstruction of war-scarred Europe. ''Our policy,'' he said, ''is not directed against any country or doctrine but against hunger, poverty, despotism and chaos.''

title: A FLORIST STARTS A BROOKLYN RENOVATION
description: For the last 25 years Martin J. Orlofsky has sold chrysanthemums and gladiolus in his flower shop in downtown Brooklyn, at the corner of Fourth and Flatbush Avenues, while the area around him has ridden an economic roller coaster.

title: Living With AIDS
description: After being offered a job at the New York City Planning Department last August, Tucker Ashworth told his prospective employer there was something he ought to know: he had AIDS. The offer, director of public affairs, stood; he accepted.

title: Gospel Concert
description: The No Name Gospel Singers, the Golden Sons and the Brooklyn Skyways are to sing a gospel concert tonight at 8 P.M. at the Washington Square Church, 135 West Fourth Street (212-206-1050). Admission is $7.

title: TOASTING A LEGACY OF ECCENTRICITY
description: In this self-proclaimed ''colony of the arts'' - and one of America's most famous small towns - the scent of history hangs on almost everything.

title: Japanese Back Project Including Chrysler Plant
description: The City of Detroit has lined up Japanese investors to finance the early stages of a $1.2 billion economic development project that includes a new assembly plant for the Chrysler Corporation.

title: BELZBERG ACCUSATION EXPANDED
description: Marc Belzberg and his family's investment company - accused of using the chairman of Bear, Stearns & Company to avoid Federal disclosure rules when the wealthy Canadian family amassed a stake in Ashland Oil Inc. in 1986 - employed the same tactic earlier in the year when the Belzberg company bought shares of the Hartmarx Corporation, according to the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Coast Guard on Lakes Limits Boat Boardings
description: The Coast Guard is backing off from a policy of intensive boardings of pleasure boats on the Great Lakes that grew out of a mandate to become involved in the campaign against drug trafficking.

title: Diane Chaplin Recital
description: Diane Chaplin, a cellist, is to play works by three American composers - Horace Wadham Nicholl, Charles Wakefield Cadman and Arthur Foote - tomorrow at 8:30 P.M. in Weill Recital Hall. The program also includes pieces by Boccherini and Hindemith. Emily Wong George is the pianist. Tickets are $8, $4 for students and the elderly. Information: 864-3137.

title: BROADWAY
description: ONE of the encouraging notes for the Broadway season coming up is that Lanford Wilson's new play, ''Burn This,'' is scheduled for the Great White Way as of Oct. 15. The comedy had a limited run this year at the Mark Taper Forum in Los Angeles, where it was one of the biggest hits in its history, and by the Circle Repertory Company, which opened its 22 performances to subscribers only.

title: 'Lucia di Lammermoor'
description: The West End Opera Theater is to present Donizetti's ''Lucia di Lammermoor'' tonight and tomorrow at 8 P.M. and Sunday at 2 P.M. at the American Theater of Actors, 314 West 54th Street. Tickets are from $8 to $10. Information: 799-0101.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: ''Waldo's All New 1927 Revue,'' Symphony Space, 2537 Broadway, at 95th Street (864-5400). Terry Waldo, a pianist, and the Gotham City Jazz Band head a variety show that evokes the spirit of the 20's, mixing hot jazz, classic ragtime, eccentric dancing, comedy and vocal numbers. The cast includes Patty Holley, who was featured last fall in Duke Ellington's ''Queenie Pie'' in Philadelphia and at the Kennedy Center in Washington, as well as Betsy Baytos, an eccentric dancer, and Danny Willis, a 23-year-old baritone who came to New York in hopes of making 78 rpm records. Mr. Willis plays ukulele and sings hot jazz vocals in the manner of Cliff Edwards, who was known as Ukulele Ike. Mr. Waldo's Gotham City Jazz Band is an all-star collection drawn from the young generation of jazz archivists who have been reviving a variety of early jazz and vaudeville styles in recent years. The musicians are Peter Ecklund and Randy Reinhart, trumpets, Dan Barrett, trombone, Chuck Wilson and Ken Peplowski, reeds, Andy Stein, violin, Frank Vignola, banjo, Jim Lawyer, bass, and Arnie Kinsella, drums. Tickets for tonight's performance at 8 P.M. are $15 and $12. They can be bought at the box office or reserved by phone at 864-5400.

title: Fallon and Chiat/Day Win at the One Show
description: Fallon McElligott of Minneapolis and Chiat/Day of Los Angeles, San Francisco and New York were the big winners at the One Show last night at the Palladium.

title: South Korea Resolves Press Censorship Case
description: Two journalists who disclosed information that embarrassed the South Korean Government have been found guilty by a judge in Seoul. But the judge released a third defendant and gave the other two light sentences.

title: RUSSIANS AND COMRADES
description: One of the ironies of Mikhail Gorbachev's ''openness'' and ''restructuring'' program is the impact on the Soviet bloc.

title: Dining Out Guide: Downtown
description: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. GAYLORD, #87 First Avenue, at Sixth Street (529-7990) - *(Feb. 20, 1987) The silk-garbed doorman and the purple, pink, yellow, blue and aqua ceiling lights may look uptown, but this 100-seat Indian restaurant is definitely downtown, with prices that agree. There are many fresh and zesty options on the menu. Good starters, both of which include puffed poori bread, are shrimp in a sauce of onions, hot peppers, bell peppers and coriander and lump crab meat sauteed with mixed spices and tomato. Other good choices are fried chickpeas spiked with chili powder and coriander and chicken chat combining shredded meat with cucumber in a tamarind sauce. Main dish options are chicken dhansak, boneless meat in an aromatic lentil sauce; lamb curry, and fish tandoori, which is mako shark marinated in hot mixed spices and roasted. Main dishes $5.95 to $14.95. Friday to Sunday, noon to midnight. KING FUNG, #20 Elizabeth Street, south of Canal Street (964-5256) -

title: OVERSIGHT OF SHELTERS IS UPHELD
description: In a major decision broadening the legal rights of homeless families, New York State's highest court ruled yesterday that courts had the power to set requirements for safe and sanitary conditions.

title: A SPACE, FOR ART'S SAKE
description: The people who saved one of the city's most desirable dance and theater rehearsal spaces from commercial development held a victory celebration yesterday in the turn-of-the-century building.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: ON READING RUSKIN. Prefaces to La Bible d'Amiens and Sesame et les Lys with Selections from the Notes to the Translated Texts. By Marcel Proust. Translated and Edited by Jean Autret, William Burford and Phillip J. Wolfe, with an introduction by Richard Macksey. Illustrated. 173 pages. Yale University Press. $18.50. THE OAK IN THE ACORN. On Remembrance of Things Past and on Teaching Proust, Who Will Never Learn. By Howard Nemerov. 153 pages. Louisiana State University Press. $16.95.

title: Taft Approves Bid Of $157, Up $2
description: The Taft Broadcasting Company said its board had approved a sweetened takeover proposal for the media company from a partnership of Taft's major shareholders. The partnership is led by the FMI Financial Corporation, of which the Cincinnati financier Carl H. Lindner's American Financial Corporation owns 72 percent. The group also includes the Texas investor Robert M. Bass and Dudley S. Taft, vice chairman of Taft Broadcasting and a member of the company's founding family. Together the investors already own 42 percent of Taft Broadcasting's 9.3 million common shares outstanding.

title: ACTIVIST GENERAL IN LINE FOR TOP MARINE POST
description: Lieut. Gen. Alfred M. Gray Jr. has been recommended by Navy Secretary James H. Webb as the next Commandant of the Marine Corps, replacing Gen. P. X. Kelley when he retires this month, according to Pentagon officials.

title: Sensational Abrams, Hero North
description: Two patterns emerge starkly from the Iran-contra hearings: of deception and self-enrichment. The Reagan Administration admits, with painful reluctance, that it misinformed Congress and the public about its secret activities in Nicaragua. Just as reluctantly, participants in the arms supply operation to the Nicaraguan rebels reveal how they used the cloak of secrecy for private gain.

title: East African Songs
description: Tony Bird, an East African songwriter, is to perform songs tonight at Speakeasy, 107 Macdougal Street (212-598-9670), with Sonya-San, an a capella singer, opening. Tomorrow, Dave Van Ronk is to sing, with Riverrun, a folk group, opening. Sets at 8:30 and 11 P.M.; admission $6 with a two-drink minimum.

title: World Bank Sets Bonds in Sterling
