description: The World Bank announced yesterdaythat it is offering the largest issue ever of fixed-rate Eurobonds denominated in sterling.

title: Noel P. Fox, 76, Dies; Former Federal Judge
description: Former Federal District Judge Noel P. Fox, whose career included a controversial ruling allowing Indian tribes to fish commercially in the Great Lakes without Government interference, died Wednesday at the Villa Elizabeth Nursing Home, where he had lived since February 1986, Mary Ann Greenhoe, director of nursing, said today. He was 76 years old.

title: Flute Force
description: Flute Force, a quartet of flutists, is to perform works by Bach, Roger Reynolds, Jeremy Beck, A. Leroy and David Jones on Sunday at 4 P.M. at 100 Grand Street. Tickets are $8, $6 for students and the elderly. Information: 866-3594.

title: Instrumental Rock
description: A night of instrumental rock and improvisation by Peter Gordon and the Love of Life Orchestra, Zozobra, No Safety and Dr. Nerve is to take place tomorrow at CBGB, 315 Bowery, at Bleecker Street (982-4052), beginning at approximately 10 P.M. Tickets are $8; for exact set times, call the club.

title: Witnesses Identify Barbie in a Deportation of 650
description: Rolande Clair, a tall, slightly graying 63-year-old woman from Lyons, kept a 43-year-old promise today.

title: KIDDER AGREES TO PAY $25 MILLION TO SETTLE INSIDER TRADING CHARGES
description: In a step that broadens the scope of the Wall Street scandals, Kidder, Peabody & Company agreed yesterday to pay a record $25.3 million to settle insider-trading charges.

title: ANN LANDERS'S FOOTSTEPS: 4 FEET WILL FILL HER SHOES
description: Looking for someone to lend advice on the problems of the day, The Chicago Sun-Times in the 1950's turned to a housewife from Iowa named Eppie.

title: PICK-IT-YOURSELF TIME FOR STRAWBERRIES
description: IF you have been disappointed lately with the lack of taste in strawberries bought in supermarkets, take heart: ripe, red berries with the old-time flavor are now ready for picking in nearby New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

title: TONY AWARDS, WITH ANGELA LANSBURY
description: WILL there be an anti-British - or, rather, an anti-French - backlash this year? Would August Wilson's play have a better chance to win as best play if it were called ''Les Fences,'' or would ''Les Liaisons Dangereuses'' have a better chance if theatergoers could pronounce the title properly and also spell it?

title: INDIA AIRLIFTS AID TO TAMIL REBELS
description: Defying the Sri Lanka Government, India sent transport planes and jet fighters over the country's northern territory today and dropped 25 tons of food and medicine by parachute into areas held by embattled insurgents.

title: Safeway Will Sell Liquor Barn Unit
description: Safeway Stores Inc. has agreed to sell its 104-store Liquor Barn division to Majestic Wine Warehouses Ltd., a British wine and spirits retailer. Majestic, along with and equity partner M.J.H. Nightingale & Co., and several investment firms, will pay slightly more than $100 million in cash for the stores in Arizona and California, Esme Johnstone, president and co-founder of the British company, announced on Wednesday.

title: Biden's Adrenaline
description: Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr., who will formally declare his candidacy for the Democratic nomination next week, was asked about his ''reputation as a hothead'' yesterday. ''I think there are certain things that warrant being angry,'' said the Senator from Delaware, who distinguished between being angry and losing one's temper.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE
description: Pact for Pitino

title: Wasting British Minds
description: ''Our elite is going overseas,''

title: AUCTIONS
description: PRECIOUS objects and architectural relics - a rare gold box awash with jewels by Tiffany & Company, sections of a cast-iron staircase by Louis Sullivan, a silver-plated clock by Josef Hoffmann of Vienna and a gold musical automaton watch by Carrisol of Geneva - are among the highlights in auctions taking place tomorrow and next week at Sotheby's and Christie's.

title: LAWMAKER DOUBTS SCHOOL BOARD HAS SKILL TO RUN CAPITAL PROGRAM
description: The head of the State Senate Investigations Committee, calling the maintenance and renovation of New York City's school buildings ''tragically inadequate,'' expressed doubts yesterday about trusting the Board of Education with a planned $4.5 billion building program.

title: PILOTS REVEAL PLAN TO RESHAPE ALLEGIS
description: The pilots' union of United Airlines yesterday asked the management of the Allegis Corporation, United's parent company, to spin off its car rental and hotel divisions and turn the airline over to United's employees, with Allegis shareholders keeping a 20 percent interest.

title: BILL SEEKS NEW RULES ON MERGERS
description: A group of leading Democratic senators introduced legislation today that would outlaw or severely restrict a host of devices frequently used in corporate takeover battles.

title: APARTMENT HOUSE CARTER HELPED REBUILD IS REVIVIFYING PRIDE
description: On the desolate block of East Sixth Street between Avenues C and D -where homeless families have built a fragile shantytown and where countless windows of an unfinished city-sponsored housing project have been lost to vandals - No. 742 is on its way to becoming a neighborhood shrine.

title: Japan Shapes Market Plan
description: In advance of next week's Venice summit meeting, Japan yesterday elaborated on the steps it is planning to liberalize its capital markets.

title: GOSPEL: LINDA HART AT BALLROOM
description: LINDA HART is a singer equally at home in two very different musical milieus. One is the brassy, bawdy contemporary vaudeville world of Bette Midler, with whom she has sung backup as a member of the Harlettes. The other is the world of her own evangelical Christian background. From the age of 3, the singer toured with her family group, the Harts, a Texas Baptist ensemble, in churches and revival meetings around the country.

title: Byrd and Petrucciani
description: Donald Byrd, a trumpeter, is to lead a quartet featuring James Williams on piano, and Michel Petrucciani, a pianist, leads a trio tonight through Sunday at the Blue Note, 131 West Third Street (212-475-8592). Sets begin at 9 and 11:30 P.M. through Sunday, plus a 1:30 A.M. show tonight and tomorrow; there is a $15 cover and a $5 minimum at tables, or a $7.50 charge at the bar.

title: U.S. AND JAPAN: ATTITUDES SHIFT
description: A majority of Japanese described United States-Japan relations as unfriendly in a poll conducted last month by The New York Times, CBS News and the Tokyo Broadcasting System. That represented a dramatic shift in attitude from a poll in April 1986 in which less than a third of the Japanese characterized relations with the United States as unfriendly.

title: Weekend of Champions
description: Four-legged thoroughbreds are hard enough to analyze, but just try thinking about the two-legged champions: Can Dwight Gooden regain his form on his home course? Should the Mets encourage Tom Seaver to remain in pasture? What made Isiah Thomas turn snappish on his way back to the barn? Can Larry Bird carry the whole Celtics team on his back?

title: The Witness File
description: Name: David M. Lewis Age: 40 Position: Partner in the Washington law firm of Finkelstein, Thompson, Levinson & Lewis, practicing primarily securities law. Role: Mr. Lewis was approached by Willard I. Zucker, an American lawyer who, in effect, ran one of the Swiss companies involved in the secret transfers of funds from the Iranian arms sales to the Nicaraguan rebels, to help design a fund for Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North's wife, Betsy. Mr. Lewis testified that the amount in the account was to be approximately $70,000, but that nothing came of the conversation.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE
description: Resch Retires

title: Rockwell, Marietta Win 'Star Wars' Job
description: The Pentagon has selected two teams of contractors to pursue research and demonstration work on one of the most important elements of the proposed ''Star Wars'' antimissile system - the use of orbiting ''killer'' rockets.

title: Louisiana Candidate Killed in Plane Crash
description: Noel Baum, a candidate for Governor of Louisiana, died Wednesday when the small plane he was piloting crashed more than 500 miles from his intended destination, the authorities said today. He was 49 years old. Mr. Baum, an insurance executive, may have suffered a heart attack while flying the single-engine Cessna P210, said Lieut. Charles Rumble of the state police.

title: BROAD REDEVELOPMENT IS URGED FOR CONEY ISLAND
description: An ambitious redevelopment program for Coney Island, including new amusement and shopping malls, a new boardwalk and stages for concerts and festivals, is recommended in a new study conducted for New York City parks officials.

title: Money Fund Assets Off
description: Assets of the nation's 383 money market mutual funds decreased by $423.1 million, to $238.91 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Assets of the 94 institutional funds were down $431.2 million, to $64.43 billion. Assets of the 199 general purpose funds were up $536.5 million, to $69.11 billion. The 90 broker-dealer funds were down $528.4 million, to $105.36 billion.

title: Larry Coryell
description: Larry Coryell, a guitarist, is to lead a quartet tonight through Sunday at the Village Vanguard, 178 Seventh Avenue South, at Perry Street (212-255-4037). Sets begin at 10 and 11:30 P.M. and 1 A.M.; there is a $12 cover and a $6 minimum.

title: Villainy vs. Villainy
description: To the Editor:

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: DEBT

title: New Zealand Enacts Ban on Nuclear Ships
description: Parliament approved legislation Thursday banning nuclear-armed and nuclear-powered ships from New Zealand's ports, putting into law a policy that the Labor Government adopted nearly three years ago.

title: MUSIC: GERSHWIN AND ELLINGTON WORKS
description: AS a special post-season event at Avery Fisher Hall, the New York Philharmonic is offering a program entitled ''Gershwin and Ellington: American Masters.'' The concerts are conducted by James DePreist, with Leon Bates as piano soloist, Dexter Gordon on saxophone and supporting roles for two other noted jazz musicians, Tommy Flanagan, pianist, and Ron Carter, double bassist. The first concert was last night, with repeats scheduled for tonight and tomorrow.

title: ATHENS LINKS BASES TO TURKEY ISSUE
description: Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou has proposed that negotiations on the continued presence of United States military bases in Greece be linked to this country's long-running dispute with Turkey and that any accord with Washington be put to a referendum.

title: Diner's Journal
description: THE Sindoni clan, whose pint-size Sicilian restaurant, Azzurro (84th Street and Second Avenue), turns out some wonderfully pristine pastas and seafood, has branched out on the Upper West Side with Baci, on Amsterdam Avenue between 79th and 80th Streets. The sparkling little cafe, seating about 55, serves the same bright, fresh food as the original.

title: POLICE FIND KIDNAPPED INFANT AND A SUSPECT
description: A picture of a young woman striding with a baby in her arms down a deserted corridor was released last night by the police, who said it was taken by a security camera at Lincoln Hospital in the Bronx Wednesday night as the woman kidnapped the child.

title: LAKERS PRODUCE A SMASH SEQUEL
description: ''Sweep! Sweep! Sweep!''

title: TRIP BY POPE STIRRING ISSUE OF UKRAINIANS
description: When Pope John Paul II returns on his third papal visit to his native land this month, no group will be more eager to see him than Poland's 300,000 Ukrainian Catholics, whose church has affirmed papal dominion for nearly 400 years, often with piety, risk and sacrifice.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A brief article yesterday about a memorial service for the choreographer Antony Tudor misstated the date. It will be at 10 A.M. next Tuesday - June 9, not July 9 - at the Juilliard School, 155 West 65th Street.

title: A CORNERSTONE CAN BE BURDENSOME
description: For globe-trotting diplomats, the Vienna Convention on Diplomatic Relations is read almost as scripture.

title: Il Piccolo Teatro
description: Il Piccolo Teatro dell'Opera is to present a double-bill of Mozart's ''Impresario'' and Lukas Foss's ''Introductions and Goodbyes,'' conducted by Mr. Foss, today at 10:30 A.M. and tomorrow at 8 P.M. in the Carey Playhouse of the Brooklyn Academy of Music, 30 Lafayette Avenue, at Ashland Place, in the Fort Greene section. Maurice Edwards directs the cast, which includes the tenor Douglas Perry. Tickets are from $10 to $15. Information: (718) 855-4751.

title: PENNZOIL CHIEF HINTS ABOUT SUITORS FOR TEXACO
description: Several companies and investors, including some well-known corporate raiders, are considering buying major stakes in Texaco Inc., the chairman and chief executive of the Pennzoil Company said today.

title: BRUNO BERNARD
description: Bruno Bernard, a photographer known as Bruno of Hollywood, died of cancer Wednesday in Los Angeles. He was 75 years old.

title: Young Playwrights
description: ''Saturday Night,'' a play about how a group of young adults spend their Saturday evening, is to be presented this weekend by the Walden Theater Conservatory at the Park Avenue Christian Church, 1010 Park Avenue, at 85th Street. The play was written by members of the conservatory's young playwrights program. Shows are at 8 P.M. today, tomorrow and Monday. Tickets are $6. Information: 473-3675.

title: THOMAS EXPLAINS COMMENTS ON BIRD
description: Isiah Thomas, who has been caught up in a furor over comments he made about Larry Bird last week, made a public plea for understanding today in the company of the Celtic forward.

title: Expert Sees Oil Buffer For U.S. in Gulf Cutoff
description: Even a complete cutoff of oil from the Persian Gulf might cause no shortages in the United States for two months, the head of the industry's biggest trade association said today.

title: At the Movies
description: A Growing Empire

title: FILM: 'SHADEY,' A COMEDY
description: MAYBE ''Shadey'' is meant to be a spoof on formula movies. Snoo Wilson, who wrote the British feature that opens today at the Quad Cinema, has tossed elements of many formulas into his brew - science-fiction, spy thriller, screwball comedy, black humor, political satire, psychosex, fantasy and more - and mixed ill. The result has little fizz and leaves a sourish aftertaste.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE
description: McNab Leaving

title: NEW NASA SYSTEM AIMS TO ENCOURAGE BLOWING THE WHISTLE
description: Space agency officials announced yesterday that they had established a new confidential system to encourage ''whistle blowers'' to report safety concerns about the space shuttle and any other operations.

title: Nonguardians of the Law
description: To the Editor:

title: Stubbs Painting Brings Record Price at Auction
description: George Stubbs's ''Baron de Robeck Riding a Bay Cob'' (1791), which depicts an aristocrat on a rearing horse, was sold yesterday at Sotheby's for $2.42 million, a record at auction for a sporting picture and for a painting by the British artist. The buyer, who was not identified, bid over the telephone.

title: FRANK E. HEDRICK
description: Frank E. Hedrick, former president of the Beech Aircraft Corporation, died of cancer Thursday. He was 76 years old.

title: Alysheba Faces Two Obstacles in Final Step to Triple Crown
description: Alysheba will earn $3.9 million if he wins the Belmont Stakes today, but none of his nine opponents can bank more than $1.3 million. So it seems only fair that Alysheba must pass two tests today.

title: WEAKENDED YANKS CRUSH BREWERS, 13-1
description: All of the off-field movement this afternoon, and a 9-3 pounding Thursday night, might have left the Yankees frazzled.

title: Trudeau the Spoiler
description: After 20 years of argument, Canada's quarreling parliamentarians joined in a prolonged ovation when Prime Minister Brian Mulroney announced on May 1: ''What we now have is a whole country.'' Quebec had finally compromised and signed a new Constitution in return for recognition of its status as a ''distinct society'' among Canada's 10 provinces. After initially cabling congratulations, former Prime Minister Pierre Trudeau emerged from reclusive retirement to denounce Mr. Mulroney as a ''weakling'' who had balkanized Canada.

description: b-Net loss

title: POWER FAILS AT NEW YORK HOSPITAL AND INFANT ON A RESPIRATOR DIES
description: New York Hospital was thrown into chaos for 22 minutes early yesterday when electrical generators failed during a scheduled repair of the main power plant, causing the death of a baby, hospital officials said yesterday.

title: DAIRY MART CONVENIENCE STORES reports earnings for Qtr to May 2
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $143,000, or 3 cents a share. c-Net loss The company said the latest quarter results include Conna Corp., which was acquired in October 1986.

title: IRAN PANEL LIKELY TO RECALL SECORD ON DESCREPANCIES
description: Leading members of the Congressional committees investigating the Iran-contra affair said today that Maj. Gen. Richard V. Secord would probably be recalled as a witness to resolve serious conflicts arising from his testimony last month.

title: U.S. Notes, Bonds Rise Again
description: Treasury note and bond prices rose for the third consecutive day, returning to levels that prevailed before Monday, when the market's were shocked by the announcement of Paul A. Volcker's resignation from the Federal Reserve Board.

title: Bridge; An Entry in Canadian Event Showed Some Sharp Bidding
description: When 20 teams assemble this weekend in Quebec for the finals of the Canadian Grand National Team Championship, one of the pairs involved will be thinking back to an earlier stage of the event. Irving Litvack of Willowdale, Ontario, and Joe Silver of Montreal solved a bidding problem that would be likely to defeat the best players in the world.

title: PROSECUTOR REVEALS A LINK BETWEEN BIAGGI INDICTMENTS
description: A connection between two companies named in the corruption indictments of Representative Mario Biaggi was revealed yesterday for the first time in a Federal courtroom in Brooklyn.

title: AIRGAS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss c-After a loss from discontinued operations of $865,000 for both the quarter and year. The fiscal 1987 results includes 11 months of distribution operations.

description: The Economy

title: LTX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Warner Books Acquires Andy Warhol Diaries
description: Warner Books has acquired the diaries of Andy Warhol, the Pop artist who died in February, and plans to publish them in the fall of 1988. Lawrence J. Kirshbaum, president of Warner, said the published diaries would consist of some 200,000 words that Mr. Warhol dictated on an almost daily basis between 1976 and 1987 to Pat Hackett, who met the artist when she was a college student.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: Another State

title: JACKSON HEIGHTS LAMENTS KILLING OF 2 MERCHANTS
description: As neighborhood residents and merchants expressed shock, Queens detectives hunted yesterday for the robber who, firing execution style, killed the elderly owners of a Jackson Heights liquor store and one of their customers Thursday night.

title: A Soviet Warning On the Perils of Rock
description: Rock fans who do not get a regular ''fix'' of music develop trembling hands and an unstable pulse as if they were drug addicts, a Soviet psychologist said today.

title: Robertson TV Network Lays Off 500 Workers
description: The Rev. Pat Robertson announced today that he had laid off 500 employees from his Christian Broadcasting Network.

title: 3 More Officials Quit Allegheny
description: The chief financial officer and two other top executives have resigned from Allegheny International Inc., the troubled consumer products company has disclosed.

title: JOINT EFFORT TO BUY ALLEGIS IS HINTED
description: The Allegis Corporation's stock price jumped $2.375 to a new high of $89.875 yesterday as the company said it would study a restructuring proposed by the pilots' union of its United Airlines subsidiary.

title: Europe Unemployment
description: Unemployment in the European Community dropped 2.6 percent in April from the previous month, in the largest decline between March and April since 1980, the trading bloc's statistical office reported today. Eurostat said the seasonally unadjusted average jobless rate for nine member countries, excluding Spain, Portugal and Greece, fell to 11.2 percent in April, from 11.5 percent in March. The total number of unemployed in the nine countries fell to 12.9 million, from 13.3 million, during the same period. The jobless count for all 12 members was 16.3 million people, down from 16.7 million in March.

title: CURT McDOWELL
description: Curt McDowell, a prominent underground film maker, died of AIDS Wednesday in his San Francisco home, according to The Associated Press. He was 42 years old.

title: DE LAURENTIIS ENTERTAINENT GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-After a gain from the sale of stock of $6,505,000 for both the quarter and year. c-Net loss The company said the latest year results include a $21.9 million reduction in costs. The company also said the loss for 1987 is primarily due to increased selling, general and administrative costs required to support its increased production and distribution efforts.

title: Boxer Set to Fulfill A Boyhood Dream
description: The homes stand in proximity on Waterman Avenue. They are modest two-story dwellings, most with small, neatly tended lawns and economy-model cars in the driveways.

title: MARCOS WINS ROUND IN COURT
description: A United States appeals court here has delivered a setback to opponents of Ferdinand E. Marcos in their attempt to recover billions of dollars in assets they say were plundered while he was President of the Philippines.

title: Poles' Own Plight
description: To the Editor:

title: BARBIE, FORCED TO APPEAR AT TRIAL, IS IDENTIFIED BY 2 OF HIS ACCUSERS
description: Klaus Barbie was forced to appear at his trial today for the second time and was formally identified by two of his accusers, one of them weeping and the other trying to taunt him in front of the court.

title: Threadgill and Bang
description: Billy Bang, a violinist, is to lead a quintet and Henry Threadgill, a saxophonist, leads his Windstring Ensemble today at 9:30 P.M. at the Merkin Concert Hall, Broadway at 67th Street (206-1050). Tickets are $12 and $15.

title: 8 DIE IN SOUTH AFRICA MINE CLASH
description: Six black miners and two white security officials were reported killed and 45 miners were wounded in clashes today at a gold mine owned by the Anglo American Corporation, the mining conglomerate.

title:
Patents;
Apparatus To Detect Eye Flaws
description: LEAD: AN apparatus for the photographic detection of eye defects, especially among children, was patented this week for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. It is already being manufactured under license.

title: CANADA PLANS BIG BUILDUP FOR ITS SUB FLEET AND ARMY
description: Canada today announced a 15-year program to upgrade the country's armed forces that would include the purchase of 10 to 12 nuclear-powered submarines, new battle tanks, six more frigates and the addition of nearly 30,000 men to military reserves.

title: Boyd Sent to Farm Club
description: Boston's Dennis (Oil Can) Boyd, sidelined all season with arm problems, was sent yesterday to the Red Sox's International League team at Pawtucket and is scheduled to pitch at Syracuse Monday.

title: STANLINE INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: The year-ago share earnings were restated to give effect retroactively to the 5 percent common stock dividend paid by the company in December 1986.

title: AMERICAN OUTRAGED BY SOVIET ARTICLE
description: The director of the United States Information Agency, Charles Z. Wick, today cut short a meeting with a top Soviet editor after a heated exchange over a Soviet article asserting that American agents had developed a lethal gas that kills black people but not whites.

title: Details Gets New Owner
description: An investor group led by Alan Patricof has bought majority control of Details, a monthly magazine that chronicles the New York fashion, art and club scene.

title: Henry U. Harris, 87; Ex-Chief of Brokerage
description: Henry U. Harris, the retired chairman of Harris Upham & Company, a major Wall Street brokerage, died Thursday at his home in Glen Head, L.I., after a long illness. He was 87 years old.

title: NEW YORK TAX SLEUTH IS DISMISSED FOR FILING NO '84 OR '85 RETURNS
description: The New York City official responsible for exposing tax cheats was dismissed yesterday after admitting that he had failed to file his state and city income tax returns for 1984 and 1985.

title: MAKAROVA ON PROGRAM WITH KIROV DANCERS
description: Natalia Makarova will appear on the same program with dancers from the Kirov Ballet tonight, for the first time since the former Kirov ballerina defected from the Soviet Union in 1970. Irina Kolpakova and Sergei Berezhnoi, leading dancers with the Kirov Ballet, are among the dancers from several countries who will perform, along with Ms. Makarova, in a gala benefit for Ballet British Columbia at the Queen Elizabeth Theater in Vancouver.

title:
Patents;
Blood Pressure Monitor
description: LEAD: A noninvasive blood pressure monitor manufactured by the Cortronic Corporation in Ronkonkoma, L.I., was patented this week. The company's president, Ted W. Russell, was granted Patent 4,669,485. The APM770 monitor is designed to measure blood pressure continuously while displaying a pressure wave form and is intended to disclose any displacements of the arterial walls.

title: Comings and Goings
description: The San Francisco Giants have bought the contract of Ivan DeJesus, an infielder, from the St. Louis Cardinals' Louisville affiliate. DeJesus, 34 years old, mostly a shortstop during 13 years in the major leagues, hit .276 in 40 games for the Redbirds. . . . The Green Bay Packers have released Joe Shield, a quarterback from Trinity College in Hartford, who signed with the Packers last Nov. 18 and finished the season with Green Bay.

title: Israeli Accord Reported Near On a New Envoy for the U.S.
description: Israel's Ambassador to Mexico, Moshe Arad, has been summoned to Jerusalem to be interviewed by Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir about possibly becoming Ambassador to the United States, Government officials said today.

title: MONTCLAIR SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Includes gains on securities transactions of $50,000 for the quarter and $52,000 for the 6 months. c-Includes gains on securities transactions of $464,000 for the quarter and $981,000 for the 6 months. The company converted to stock form from mutual on March 12.

title: CONTINUING REVOLUTION FOR DANCE FESTIVAL AT DUKE
description: ''Modern dance is an ongoing revolution,'' says Charles Reinhart, the director of the American Dance Festival. Mr. Reinhart himself exudes the commitment of a revolutionary; he has helped modern dance triumph on the campus of Duke University in Durham, N.C., home of the festival for the last 10 years.

title: Plane Passenger in San Juan Demands a Flight to Cuba
description: A passenger aboard a small commercial seaplane that landed at San Juan's international airport demanded that he be flown to Cuba tonight, the Federal Aviation Administration said.

title: Norway's Foreign Aid
description: Norway provided more foreign aid to developing countries as a percentage of its gross national product than any other Western industrialized nation, a Foreign Aid Ministry spokeman said today. He added that Norway gave almost six billion crowns, or $900 million - 1.16 percent of its total of goods and services - in aid last year to United Nations bodies, the World Bank and other organizations. This was a higher percentage of G.N.P. than any other country in the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, a 24-nation grouping of industrial countries, he said.

title: SCHROEDER CONSIDERS RUNNING FOR PRESIDENT
description: Representative Patricia Schroeder of Colorado said today she was considering becoming a candidate for the Democratic Presidential nomination.

description: Revenue represents contract revenue.

description: The Speaker of Parliament, Hussein al-Husseini, resigned today, five days after the assassination of Prime Minister Rashid Karami.

description: The authorities have freed a former Nazi death-camp guard after attempts to return him to the United States failed, the Interior Ministry said today.

description: A North Carolina court yesterday issued a preliminary injunction barring Asher B. Edelman, the New York investor, and Dominion Textile Inc. from carrying out their $2.5 billion bid for Burlington Industries. The injunction is to continue until certain litigation between the parties is settled.

description: The Cannon Group said today that a group including its founders was preparing a financial restructuring plan for the troubled independent film production company.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, a Venice dispatch yesterday on United States plans to seek a resolution threatening Iran and Iraq with an arms embargo if they refuse talks to end their war misidentified the body in which the measure is being sought. It is the United Nations Security Council, not the General Assembly.

title: One Night's Relief For a Besieged Team
description: Everywhere Dwight Gooden turned last night, the camera crews were sure to follow, from the dugout to the batting cage and back again, peering over his shoulder as he sipped from the water fountain before disappearing down the runway leading to the locker room. ''The Return of Dr. K'' gave Shea Stadium a festive air that - for one night, anyway - overshadowed the problems the Mets have been having in the year after they played ''baseball like it oughta be.''

title: HART OFFERING BOOK ON CAREER
description: Gary Hart is inviting bids on a book about his career in public life, but the 15-page outline submitted to publishers makes no mention of the events that ended with his resignation last month from the race for the Democratic Presidential nomination.

title: DON'T JUDGE YELLOW PAGES BY THEIR COLOR
description: MOST people think that the yellow pages are the yellow pages and that the only thing they need to look for when they reach for a copy is the color. Not anymore. New York became a town with two yellow-page telephone directories in November, and consumers have learned that they are not alike.

title: 20 Killed in Afghan Shelling
description: Twenty people were killed and 14 wounded in two bouts of Afghan shelling into the Kurram area of northwest Pakistan last weekend, the Pakistani news agency reported today. It said the Afghan armed forces fired 13 missiles on Saturday, killing 12 Afghan refugees and a Pakistani at Shalozan. About 200 artillery rounds were fired at Ghoz Garhi on Sunday, killing 7 Afghan refugees and wounding 12.

title: THIEF WITH A TRUCK KEY MAY HAVE STOLEN TIGERS
description: The theft of a rental truck containing two rare white tigers may have been carried out by a professional thief, the police said yesterday.

description: LEAD: Chinese patents and trademarks may now be obtained through a new agency in New York City. China Patent and Technology Trade (U.S.A.) Ltd. has opened an office at One World Trade Center in Manhattan.

title: AIDS PRECAUTIONS TAKEN BY DENTISTS
description: With rising anxiety over AIDS, increasing numbers of dentists in New York City are taking such recommended precautions as wearing masks, gloves, eyeglasses or goggles for the treatment of all patients.

title: IS IT REALLY THE PRESIDENT? THE WAITER THINKS SO
description: Some people thought that the man staying at Villa Condulmer, a three-story 17th-century country hotel with bright green awnings, was a double, and that the real American President was in Aviano, a town in Friuli to the east.

title: New York University
description: A mile-long academic procession opened New York University's commencement yesterday in Washington Square Park. The university awarded almost 10,000 undergraduate degrees, master's degrees and doctorates.

title: STAGE: 'LIFE OF THE LAND'
description: Reunion and reconciliation are the themes of ''Life of the Land'' by Edward Sakamoto, produced by the Pan Asian Repertory Theater at Playhouse 46. Mr. Sakamoto continues the exploration - begun in ''Manoa Valley,'' seen here several years ago -of how families keep their ethnic and cultural identity even though members move away from one another in many ways.

title: Pratt Institute
description: The Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, Samuel R. Pierce, spoke yesterday at the 98th commencement of Pratt Institute, which awarded 700 bachelor's degrees in ceremonies at its Brooklyn campus.

title: THE STAGE: 'VINDICATOR,' A NEWSPAPER COMEDY
description: A man and his mother are talking in a sort of personal code at the start of ''The Johnstown Vindicator,'' Quincy Long's first full-length play to be produced in New York. ''That's the Waikiki of it,'' she says, or something like that. ''That's the very Waikiki of it.'' You can't quite catch the drift at first, but it's plain that their relationship would not please the definers of mental health. He is too adoring, she too alluring. That's no way for a mama to behave or a son to respond. Then we're in a newspaper office, where the son, Vern, is city editor, looking for a scoop: ''We're talking big dog here. Big dog. Dane. Dane. Double Dane.'' These are peculiar people.

description: The Federal Government announced today that it would take blood samples from about 45,000 randomly selected people as part of a national survey to determine the number of Americans infected with the AIDS virus. Participation is to be voluntary and anonymous.

description: Women in Film today presented the 11th annual Crystal Awards to a three-time Academy Award-winning costume designer, Dorothy Jeakins; an actress, Ann-Margret, and the first woman to be president of the Producers Guild of America, Renee Valenti.

description: Ivan Lendl softened up a counterpuncher while Mats Wilander knocked out a heavyweight today in the semifinal round of the French Open.

description: A 75-foot cross put up in a busy intersection for the visit of Pope John Paul II has set off a national debate that recalls Uruguay's historically stormy relationship with the Roman Catholic Church.

description: Share earnings and shares outstanding have been adjusted to reflect the 3-for-2 split of the company's common stock effective Jan. 15, 1986.

title: JERSEY BANKS AWAIT MERGERS
description: The New Jersey banking industry, for years a financial backwater where competition was gentlemanly, is being jolted by the breakdown of barriers to interstate banking. Both the state's bankers and industry analysts predict that the number of independent banks, now about 85, will be cut in half within two or three years.

title: GALANOS SHAPES FUR LIKE FABRIC
description: The luxury is unmistakable. How could it be otherwise when the furs he uses are mainly mink, sable, lynx and broadtail? But James Galanos has gone a step further. He has handled the furs imaginatively, as if they were fabric. He has smocked and quilted the surfaces, nipped the waistlines and used drawstrings, ruffles and capelets to give a strong fashion slant to all that opulence.

title: View From Batter's Box
description: The Pirates were not looking forward to playing a supporting role in the Dwight Gooden story last night. He entered the game with a 6-0 career record against them and improved upon it.

title: Navy Awards Blimp Order
description: The Navy awarded a $168.9 million contract today to the Westinghouse Electric Company and Britain's Airship Industries to demonstrate whether blimps can help defend the fleet from sea-skimming missiles.

title: Security Pacific Cuts Training Unit
description: Security Pacific National Bank, the nation's seventh largest, said it had shut its respected bank officer training program to refocus on sales and service instead of credit. The move, which affects about 200 people, is part of the bank's broader effort to restructure its internal operations. The 200 officer candidates, who were being groomed for jobs as branch managers and executives, have been offered jobs as clerks or tellers at $18,000 a year.

title: New York to Propose Safety Net Legislation
description: Legislation to require safety netting at construction sites to catch the type of falling debris that killed a pedestrian Monday will be presented to the City Council within 30 days, the New York City Buildings Commissioner said yesterday.

description: The voices in this rural township are tinged with the accents of urban neighborhoods long left behind, and today they were raised in anger over a decision by the state to store 15,000 drums of radium-contaminated soil in a local wildlife preserve.

description: The House of Deputies gave final approval early today to a bill that would end prosecution of most military officers accused of rights abuses in the ''dirty war'' against leftists in the 1970's.

title: Outdoor Eating Voted In
description: Advocates of eating outdoors have won a victory in Ho-Ho-Kus, N.J. By a 5-to-2 vote, the zoning board Thursday granted a variance to allow an outdoor cafe at Claude's Ho-Ho-Kus Inn. Borough law prohibits lunch wagons, diners, road stands or ''any eating place rendering service other than inside the premises.'' In granting the variance, the board majority agreed that the 18th-century inn, run by the French chef Claude Baills, is unique in Ho-Ho-Kus. The chef's wife, Dolores, said the cafe would open ''as soon as Claude puts the tables together,'' probably this weekend.

description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson today named Richard Hatcher, former Mayor of Gary, Ind., as director of a group to explore whether he should run for the Presidency. He also rejected suggestions that he had become the current Democratic front-runner ''by default.''

description: The United States Life Insurance Company announced today that it would move about half of its staff, or 500 people, from its headquarters in Lower Manhattan to new offices in Neptune, N.J.

title: Playland Becomes Landmark
description: The Playland Amusement Park here has been designated a national landmark by the United States Department of the Interior, the Westchester County Executive, Andrew O'Rourke, said today. The 279-acre park, opened in 1928 and built in an Art Deco style, was the first totally planned amusement park in the country, according to county officials. Mr. O'Rourke said designation as a landmark extends to the park safeguards and benefits provided by the National Historic Preservation Act of 1966 and other Federal laws protecting historic properties.

title: DANCE: TUDOR'S 'DARK ELEGIES,' BY BALLET THEATER
description: Antony Tudor's ''Dark Elegies,'' one of our century's most unusual ballets, received its first performance this season by American Ballet Theater on Wednesday night at the Metropolitan Opera House. ''Dark Elegies'' is totally plotless yet emotionally rich. And, though its choreography derives from ballet technique, it looks like modern dance. Created for London's Ballet Rambert in 1937, it received its American premiere during Ballet Theater's first season in 1940, and it remains one of the company's treasures.

title: NOVELL INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 2
description: The latest second quarter includes almost $1 million of acquisition expenses. All results were restated to reflect the March 1987 combination of Novell and CXI Inc. in a transaction accounted for as a pooling of interests. The results for the latest second quarter and 6 months also reflect the March 1987 combination of Novell and Softcraft Inc. in a transaction accounted for as a pooling of interests. The shares outstanding also reflect Novell's March 31, 1987, 2-for-1 stock split.

description: Jimmy Key pitched a five-hitter and George Bell, Cecil Fielder and Jesse Barfield hit home runs tonight, pacing the Toronto Blue Jays to their third straight victory, 6-2 over the Baltimore Orioles.

description: Jasper Garrison, the nation's oldest war veteran, a man described by his daughter as a straight-laced person who never smoked or drank, died Thusday at the age of 107, the Veterans Administration said today.

description: President Reagan urged today that his counterparts at a seven-nation economic summit meeting set a goal of eliminating agriculture subsidies by 2000.

description: A former state revenue clerk was convicted Thursday in the theft of tax records of the Lieutenant Governor in a bitter gubernatorial primary race last year.

title: STUDY SEES LOW AIDS RISK FOR WOMEN IN SINGLE EPISODE
description: A report issued here Thursday estimated that a woman's odds of being infected with the AIDS virus from a single episode of sexual intercourse with an infected man were about one in 1,000.

title: Agency Orders the Airlines To Limit Carry-On Baggage
description: The Federal Aviation Administration imposed regulations today requiring airlines to limit carry-on baggage.

title: INSIDE
description: New Era at University Club After years of resistance, members of the 122-year-old, all-male club have voted to admit women as members.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Golf Morse Ahead by 1: Cathy Morse retained a one-shot lead in the $500,000 L.P.G.A. McDonald's Championship with a round of 70 in the second round yesterday in Wilmington, Del. Morse was at six-under 136, one shot ahead of Sherri Steinhauer. Sherri Turner, was at 138 after a 71. (AP) Crampton Tops Seniors: Bruce Crampton used an eagle putt and a sand wedge shot to help in a record eight-under par 64 and a three-shot lead after the opening round of the $200,000 Senior Players ReUnion Pro-Am Tournament in Dallas.(AP) Perry Takes Lead: Chris Perry, son of the former major league pitcher Jim Perry, shot a five-under-par 66 to take the second-round lead in the $700,000 Kemper Open in Potomac, Md. Perry, at 10-under 132 after 36 holes, was one stroke better than Howard Twitty. (AP) College Baseball Stanford Stops L.S.U.: Paul Carey of Stanford brought Louisiana State's season to an end yesterday in Omaha when he hit a grand slam in the bottom of the 10th to clinch a 6-5 victory that eliminated L.S.U. from the College World Series. Stanford will play Texas today. The Longhorns topped previously unbeaten Oklahoma State, 6-5, last night in the double-elimination event. The Cowboys will meet the Texas-Stanford winner Sunday for the title. (AP) Tennis Mayotte Upset: Tim Mayotte, ranked among the world's top 20 players, was upset, 7-5, 7-6, by Jeremy Bates of Britain at the Northern Grasscourt Championships yesterday, in Manchester, England. Stefan Edberg of Sweden, ranked third in the world, breezed into the semifinals with a 6-4, 6-1 victory over Marcel Freeman of Los Angeles.(AP)

title: 'RIVER'S EDGE' DEFIES EXPERTS' EXPECTATIONS
description: According to the Hollywood experts, ''River's Edge'' was a movie that would never appeal to audiences. The tale of a teen-age boy who kills his girlfriend, the movie was considered so bleak that not even the small distributors would touch it.

title: IMPERIAL SET TO BUY STAUFFER
description: Imperial Chemicals Industries P.L.C., the huge British industrial company, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the Stauffer Chemical Company from Unilever, the British-Dutch consumer products company, for $1.69 billion. The deal is the latest in a wave of purchases of American chemical companies by Europeans.

title: NEW YORK HAS RECORD SURPLUS OF $666 MILLION
description: The Koch administration said yesterday that the city would finish its fiscal year June 30 with a surplus of $666 million, its largest ever and $152 million more than estimated a month ago.

title: Credit Up Strongly In April
description: Americans took out $2.93 billion more in credit than they paid off in April, the biggest increase in six months, the Federal Reserve reported today.

title: Crazy Eddie Inc.
description: The board of Crazy Eddie Inc. met yesterday, but it took no action on two pending takeover offers. The offers have been submitted by Eddie Antar, the founder and chairman, in combination with First City Capital Corporation, and by Entertainment Marketing Inc., an electronics distributor based in Houston. A committee of the company's outside directors has yet to name a financial adviser. Separately, sources close to the company said that three executives have recently resigned. They are Sam Antar, executive vice president and father of Eddie Antar; Allen Antar, Eddie Antar's brother who was described as a junior executive, and Abe Grinberg, a merchandiser. Their departures were said to reflect company pressure to cut expenses.

title: DOW DROPS 10.93
description: Stock prices fell a bit in some of the slowest trading of the year yesterday, leaving analysts divided over just what tune Wall Street is singing these days.

title: DANCE: FOUR OFFERINGS BY KENNETH RINKER
description: Kenneth Rinker quotes Shakespeare in the program copy for his dance ''Night Trippers.'' In the piece, which alludes to ''A Midsummer Night's Dream,'' Mr. Rinker certainly does ''rock the ground whereon these sleepers lie.'' But the same could be said for all three of the other dances on a program presented by the Kenneth Rinker Dance Company on Wednesday at the Marymount Manhattan Theater. And at times the rocking nearly did away with the choreographic ground on which Mr. Rinker's performers danced.

title: ABRAMS'S TESTIMONY: PANEL ANGRY, BUT NOT BOSS
description: At one point during the Congressional investigations into the Iran-contra affair, Secretary of State George P. Shultz called in Assistant Secretary of State Elliott Abrams to ask him if he had been illegally involved in funneling aid to the contras.

title: Bosworth's Choices
description: Brian Bosworth has informed all National Football League teams that he would sign with only 5 of the 28 franchises that might select him in a special supplemental draft next Friday. In letters sent out last Tuesday, Bosworth - an all-America linebacker from Oklahoma - said he would play only for the Los Angeles Raiders or Rams, the Giants, the Jets or the Philadelphia Eagles.

title:
Patents;
Coding Device Prevents Transfers by Computer
description: LEAD: An electronic device to prevent computer crime has been patented by Prof. Mark R. Titchener of the University of Auckland in New Zealand. The invention, which does coding and decoding, can be used by banks, insurance companies and government agencies to guard against fund transfers and protect confidential data from electronic intruders.

title: Your Money; Charitable Gifts And Tax Law
description: WHEN the new tax law was first enacted, many people thought that contributions to educational, charitable and religious institutions - particularly gifts of appreciated property - might decline. They cited two key elements of the law, lower tax rates and the elimination of the deduction for non-itemizers, as major reasons for the expected drop in giving.

title: JOB TOTALS SHOW THIRD GOOD MONTH IN NEW YORK AREA
description: The New York region is a ''picture of an economy in strength,'' with unemployment rates below 6 percent, record numbers of residents employed and job prospects for teen-agers the best in a decade, the Labor Department said yesterday.

title: PRODUCER IS LEAVING 'TODAY' SHOW
description: Steve Friedman, the man often credited with making the ''Today'' show No. 1 in the morning ratings, is leaving as executive producer of the program. He has been with ''Today'' eight years and with NBC a decade longer.

title: U.S. EXHIBIT IN MOSCOW DRAWS HIGH-TECH CROWD
description: The opening of a United States Government-sponsored exhibition of Western consumer electronics products drew more than 4,000 curious Muscovites today, including some technically sophisticated young people who brought their own floppy disks in the hope of obtaining black-market software.

title: Melissa M. R. Price Marries Alexander Anton in London
description: Melissa Marie Rhoden Price, a stepdaughter of Charles H. Price 2d, United States Ambassador to Britain, and a daughter of Mrs. Price, was married in London yesterday afternoon to Alexander Anton, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Graeme Anton of Kidderminster, England. The bride is a daughter also of the late Clark S. Rhoden of Kansas City, Mo. The Very Rev. Alan B. Webster, Dean of St. Paul's Cathedral, performed the Church of England ceremony at St. Paul's Church in the Knightsbridge section of London, assisted by the vicar, the Rev. Christopher Courtauld.

title: INDIA SEEKS TALKS WITH SRI LANKA
description: India proposed talks with Sri Lanka here next week to resolve their bitter dispute over Indian assistance to the Tamil population in Northern Province in Sri Lanka, where the Government is fighting Tamil separatist guerrillas.

title: THE UNIVERSITY CLUB VOTES TO TAKE WOMEN AS MEMBERS
description: After years of resisting change, the 122-year-old University Club, the largest of the all-male clubs in New York City and one of the most prestigious, has voted to admit women as members.

title: The Charlotte Hornets
description: The National Basketball Association franchise that will begin operations during the 1988-89 season in Charlotte, N.C., will be known as the Hornets as a result of a contest that drew more than 9,000 fan ballots. George Shinn, a managing partner of the team, said yesterday that the top vote-getters among six suggested nicknames were Hornets 2,916, Knights 2,467, Cougars 1,493, Spirit 776, Crowns 736 and Stars 698.

title: REAGAN MAKES FUN OF IRISH
description: President Reagan warmed up for a taping of his weekly radio address today by telling an Italian-Irish joke, unaware that his remarks were being picked up on broadcast monitors.

title: ELECTION OPENS OLD WOUNDS IN TRIESTE
description: Trieste is an Italian port city designed by Austrians, and by Italian standards its streets are a bit too straight and its citizens a little too orderly, inclined to pay their taxes punctually and to stop at pedestrian crossings when the lights are red.

title: Fading Celtics Seek Home-Court Edge
description: The Celtics didn't need it when they eliminated the Chicago Bulls from the opening round of the playoffs in three lopsided games. But when confronted with two exhausting seven-game series in subsequent rounds, the defending league champions had to summon their grit and resolve to overcome injuries and fatigue and eliminate Milwaukee and Detroit.

title: On Jan, a Friend Who Was Slain
description: LEAD: On a Thursday night at the end of April, one of my husband's college roommates, Jan, was on his way to meet some people at a bar in Washington. He never got there, and the next day the police called his current roommates - he was a first-year student at Georgetown Law School - to say that he had been shot and killed.

title: NATHAN RAPOPORT, SCULPTOR OF WORKS ON HOLOCAUST, DIES
description: Nathan Rapoport, a sculptor best known for his Holocaust-related monuments and edifices, died Thursday of a heart attack in St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center. He was 76 years old, and was a resident of Manhattan and Ramat Gan, Israel.

title: HOMELESS OUSTED FROM A SKID ROW
description: Hundreds of homeless people abandoned their makeshift shelters as a line of about 40 police officers swept through Skid Row Thursday night, tossing belongings into the street and threatening to arrest those who refused to move.

description: Airbus Industrie, the four-nation European aircraft group, formally announced today that it would develop and build its A340, which is a long-range plane with four engines, and its A330, a medium-range plane with two engines.

title: KEY RATES
Former Laxalt Sister-in-Law Is Found Dead in California
description: The former sister-in-law of former Senator Paul Laxalt of Nevada has been found dead on the banks of the Napa River, an apparent suicide, officials say.

title: LAWYER'S AILMENTS CAUSE POSTPONEMENT OF A GOETZ HEARING
description: A hearing on the judge's instructions to the jury in the trial of Bernhard H. Goetz was canceled yesterday after one of Mr. Goetz's lawyers, Mark M. Baker, asked for an adjournment because of a neck injury. Mr. Baker's partner, Barry I. Slotnick, was also ailing and complained of laryngitis brought on by the air-conditioning in the courtroom.

title: COUNCIL PANEL REJECTS A SLATE KOCH OFFERED
description: In a rare display of independence that caught Mayor Koch's office by surprise, a City Council committee yesterday disapproved nine of Mr. Koch's nominations to city boards and postponed action on two others, refusing even to hear testimony from the stunned candidates and their supporters.

Allan McArtor, an executive at Federal Express, was named by President Reagan today to head the Federal Aviation Administration, a hot spot in which the nominee faces the formidable task of trying to restore the public's confidence in the safety and reliability of the commercial airline system.

description: A Jesuit priest who said he was ordered to leave the Rockville Centre Diocese because he criticized Roman Catholic Church rules and procedures said today that the Jesuits had told him to quit the order if he refused a new assignment.

ALIEN LAW CAUSING SHORTAGES OF LABOR IN SOME INDUSTRIES

title: 'Great to Hear Those Roars'
description: More than a quarter of a century ago, Sir Edmund Hillary and his Sherpa guide, Tenzing Norgay, ascended the 29,028-foot summit of Mount Everest in less than a month. But it took Dwight Gooden more than two months of rehabilitation from cocaine use to climb atop the 18-inch pitcher's mound at Shea Stadium last night. Up on Mount Everest, only the howling of the Himalayas wind was heard. But as Dwight Gooden stood on the mound, he was surrounded by a standing ovation of hope and encouragement from the Mets' parishioners in the congregation of 51,402.

title: Rep. Cheney Rises in G.O.P.
description: Representative Dick Cheney moved up in the ranks of the Republican leadership today and predicted the party would capture control of the House in the 1992 elections. Mr. Cheney, in his fifth term as Wyoming's only member of the House, was elected chairman of the Republican Conference, the No. 3 position in the leadership. He replaced Representative Jack F. Kemp of upstate New York, who stepped aside to devote more time to his Presidential bid.

description: Mortgage rates rose sharply in the latest month, propelled by concern about inflation.

description: The economy generated more than 600,000 new jobs in May, but the nation's labor force grew by a comparable amount so that the unemployment rate remained at 6.2 percent.

Lucas, a subsidiary of Lucas Industries P.L.C., a British corporation, said the purchase would expand its annual sales to about $500 million, half of it in the aerospace business.

title: ACT OF VANDALISM THREATENS RARE BROOK TROUT IN MAINE LAKE
description: Later this summer, biologists will drag a fine mesh net through Prong Pond near this scenic northern Maine town to see if their worst fears have come true: that white perch illegally stocked in the pond three years ago are flourishing.

title: Do You Like All the Home Runs This Years
description: Although more hitting in general is good for fan enjoyment, the disproportionate increase in home run production only lessens its impact and drama. Now, the smaller, less powerful players swing for the fences more often instead of accepting their roles as ''table setters'' for the true home run hitters following in the lineup. If the ball has in fact been made livelier, as statistics suggest, it will gradually serve to relegate the home run, once special and truly exhilarating, to a level of ordinariness. DANIEL HELLER Woodside, Queens

The Very Rev. Alan Jones, dean of Grace Episcopal Cathedral in San Francisco, performed the ceremony at the home of Mr. and Mrs. John Hooper, an uncle and aunt of the bridegroom, in Woodside, Calif.

title: Pirate Attacks on Vietnam Refugees Fall Sharply
description: Vigorous police work in southern Thailand has sharply reduced pirate attacks on Vietnamese refugees fleeing their country by boat, diplomats and relief-agency officials say.

title: EXPLORING AYUTTHAYA BY CANAL BOAT
description: Four hours upriver from Bangkok on the Chao Phraya River - or perhaps 60 minutes, if you decide to risk your life in one of those pencil-slim, waterborne Concordes currently favored by Thailand's gondoliers - lies a most spectacular ruin, much visited, but very little known. Ayutthaya was the capital of Siam for more than four centuries - from 1350 until 1767, when the Burmese sacked it and trampled everyone to pieces with their elephant cavalry. Now it is one of the great ruins of Asia, and as such it appears in all the tourist leaflets and is as obligatory a stop on a tour of central Thailand as is Wat Arun or a live sex show in Patpong II.

title: WILL COLORIZING REVITALIZE OLD TV SERIES
description: CONTROVERSY CONTINUES TO rage over the colorization of classic black-and-white movies. At recent Congressional hearings in Washington, major film makers including Woody Allen and Sydney Pollack spoke out against the tinting of films like ''It's a Wonderful Life,'' ''Casablanca'' and ''The Maltese Falcon.'' Yet, while these protests seem to be growing in intensity, the undeterred colorizers are moving quietly toward phase two; they are turning to forgotten old television series and hope to give them a brand new life by infusing black-and-white images with color.

title:

description: LEAD: IT has been exactly two months since Al Campanis, the former Dodger executive vice president, revealed to the world a hint of baseball's racist philosophy when he commented on blacks' qualifications for managerial positions. title: CELEBRATING THE EAST END'S JEWISH HERITAGE
description: Today, London's East End is famous mainly as the setting for Britain's most popular soap opera, but for generations it was the undisputed focus of Jewish life in England. According to a pioneering sociological survey, ''Life and Labour of the People in London'' (1887), Whitechapel, at the heart of the East End, was quite simply ''the dwelling place of the Jews - tailors, bootmakers and tobacco workers, and the center of trading both small and large.'' At its peak, early this century, the East End Jewish community may have numbered as many as 130,000.

Miller - already the possessor of a bachelor's degree in business from the University of Florida - finished his two-year R.O.T.C Air Force stint as a first lieutenant on April 1, 1953, and went to work for the big J. title: Music
description: Every week of the New York season is packed with concerts given at halls large and small by artists who names mean little to people outside the musical profession. The concerts often feature new or out-of-the-way music; they rarely feature performers destined to become superstars. Some of the music would just as well be left buried, and some turns out to be enormously rewarding. Some of the performers are dutiful drudges, and some of them are thoughtful, musical, animated and involved artists. Listeners who attend these concerts regularly tend to amass private lists of the performers in the second category.

title: THE EXECUTIVE COMPUTER

But that wasn't the end of it. This particular machine was tied into a voice mail system, so I was also told that if I really needed to speak to a human being, I could reroute my call by pressing the zero button on my telephone followed by the one for the number sign. I would then be connected with someone to whom I could actually speak.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: STORIES IN ANOTHER LANGUAGE. By Yannick Murphy. (Knopf, $15.95.) The language of Yannick Murphy's spare, stark vignettes is, for the most part, that of childhood. And while she concentrates on depicting the shadows of violence, the disingenuous flirting with taboos that can make these years distinctly unpleasant, there is also a strain of longing underneath the harsh surfaces of her fiction that usually keeps it just within range of our sympathy and understanding. The most successful of these 17 stories, like ''Ball and Socket,'' illuminate the web of love and sexual tension that must be broken by a father and his growing daughter, or, like ''Believer in Death,'' explore the tentative camaraderie of a mother and daughter who pass up Fourth of July fireworks for a nocturnal foraging trip to the junkyard. But almost always there is an unpleasant jolt of some kind: a sea of rats blocks the way to the dump; a father-daughter stroll is interrupted by the discovery of a boy's body hanging from a tree. Meant to be disturbing and provocative, Ms. Murphy's revelations, especially in such brief scenarios, can also seem gratuitous. And yet, despite their unevenness, the stories in this debut collection from a 24-year-old New Yorker have a surprising assurance. More surprising is the ease with which Ms. Murphy moves from down-home country landscapes to gritty city streets, then highlights these characteristically American settings with glimpses of wartime China, of bloody Saigon. Such bold dexterity suggests that, like the heroine of ''The Escape,'' a woman fleeing in a tightly sealed train from fighting in Manchuria, this writer may be ready to pull down the boards that wall up the windows of her prose, to try for a big picture instead of a handful of artfully shocking snapshots.

title: WINNING BACK A CHILD
description: On April 12, this magazine published an article by Peter Maas concerning an Indiana-born dentist, Kenneth Taylor, who bludgeoned his wife, Teresa, to death in their New Jersey home. The story told of the bitter fight that ensued for custody of their infant son, Philip, a fight between Taylor's parents in Indiana and his deceased wife's sister and brother-in-law, who live in Staten Island, N.Y. In desperation, the latter couple retained Janice Miller, a lawyer who herself was once a battered wife, and last August, a New Jersey court awarded custody to her clients. But just days later, Taylor's parents defied that order and secretly adopted Philip during the child's visit with them in Indiana. Now, Janice Miller was in a new battle to retrieve Philip. This is what happened next.

title: Man Charged in Road Death
description: An 18-year-old Queens man was charged with vehicular homicide yesterday afternoon after his car struck and killed a 6-year-old girl who had run into the street, the police said. The driver, John Cochrane of 215-05 104th Avenue in St. Albans, was also charged with driving while impaired. The police said the accident occurred at 4:20 P.M. in front of the girl's home at 99-15 217th Street in Queens Village. The girl, Dede Ayisah, was pronounced dead on arrival at Mary Immaculate Hospital in Jamaica, the police said. They said she had been struck by a 1977 Oldsmobile driven by Mr. Cochrane.

title: EXCESS BAGGAGE AND THE MOVIES

That baggage consists of whatever nonessential information you may have picked up concerning the fiscal, professional or amorous peculiarities of those who made the film, or miscellaneous tidbits that are even more marginal. Was so-and-so lately sighted with a baby and a stroller in Central Park? Is movie star X being outrageously overpaid? Does Y produce nothing but surefire spinoffs? It's seldom fair to keep such data in mind while watching a film. More to the point, it's seldom helpful.

title: LIGHT VERSE: DEAD BUT REMARKABLY ROBUST
description: IN the kingdom of literary animals, where each genre takes the form of an individual species, light verse is probably represented by the Carolina parakeet. This comely bird, which according to Audubon offered a ''welcome intimation that our darkest forests and most sequestered swamps are not destitute of charms,'' was an amicable neighbor to our pioneer forebears not only in the Carolinas but all up and down the East Coast, from New York to Florida. A creature of private habits, for all the fire of its orange, yellow and apple-green plumage, it apparently found the hurly-burly of our emerging nation disagreeable - and not being the sort of creature to air its disagreements in public, it quietly began to disappear. The last confirmed sighting, on the southern shore of Florida's Lake Okeechobee, occurred in 1904. More than three-quarters of a century later, dubious sightings will still occasionally trickle in to arouse ornithologists - who, with skeptical intellects but hopeful hearts, continue to entertain visions of the bird modestly flourishing around some brackish backwater.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: BARONS OF LABOR: The San Francisco Building Trades and Union Power in the Progressive Era. By Michael Kazin. (University of Illinois, $24.95.) This welcome labor history covers broad trends in San Francisco in the Progressive Era: building trades union and business interplay, the personalities and careers of the ''labor barons,'' mayors of San Francisco who came out of the labor movement and the decline of labor influence prior to World War I. San Francisco's story is unique and is one that has not been told until now. The Great Earthquake of 1906 and the Panama-Pacific International Exposition of 1915 provided a wealth of construction work and arenas of influence for San Francisco's building trades. ''In the years from 1912 through 1915,'' Michael Kazin writes, ''every public event in San Francisco took second place to the Panama-Pacific International Exposition. The exposition was unmatched as a device to boost the good name of San Francisco and the morale of its citizens. . . . It promoted a growing American commercial empire around the rim of the Pacific. It even made a profit.'' This, in spite of intense haggling between laborers and business promoters to control the exposition builders' conditions. The Progressive labor leaders in San Francisco displayed a class consciousness not evident in any other American city in the early 20th century, a time when most Eastern labor movements were weakened by internal issues. Mr. Kazin, who teaches history at American University, suggests his book ''may prove enlightening to readers concerned with the severe crisis facing contemporary unionism: an aggressive corporate elite, a dwindling membership, and an increasingly hostile political environment, the very same problems faced by unions seventy years ago in San Francisco.''

title: LEARNING AND LIVING THE CONSTITUTION

Nearly a year later, on Sept. 13, 1788, following ratification of the Constitution by 11 states, the Continental Congress passed a resolution that put the new Constitution into operation. In January 1789, Presidential electors were selected; the first Congress was convened in March, and on April 30, George Washington was inaugurated as the first President of the United States. Our Government was born.

title: Living Together, in Sickness and Health

And at death, they do not automatically inherit a share of their deceased partner's property. If they inherit by bequest, the property may be subject to estate taxes, which are not imposed on assets that pass to a spouse.

title: THE DANCE: SALLY GROSS'S DOMAIN
description: SALLY GROSS might have been a witch or magician in other times. All she has to do to weave a spell, it seems, is walk onto the stage and begin to move in that strangely drowsy but focused way of hers. The elements are simple, with much of the dancing performed in silence. She has gathered around her other women performers who form a kind of understated family group. But her dances, two of which were performed on Thursday at the Dia Art Foundation in SoHo, have the kind of powerful eloquence that comes with art pared down to its most lucid essentials.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: IN VISIBLE LIGHT: Photography and the American Writer: 1840-1940. By Carol Shloss. (Oxford University, $24.95.) Like John Berger and Susan Sontag, Carol Shloss views an artist's approach to his subject as an exercise of power. ''In Visible Light,'' an extended meditation about the politics of seeing, examines the complex, often uneasy exchange that takes place between photographers and writers and their sources. There are artists, Ms. Shloss writes, who make a personal connection with their subjects, creating art as a way of bearing witness. And there are those, like Diane Arbus, who remain detached. For them, vision is ''a kind of theft,'' a tool to be exploited for purposes of power or personal gain. The author of ''Flannery O'Connor's Dark Comedies,'' Ms. Shloss is concerned with questions of voyeurism and power, how and when observation becomes transgression - or worse, political manipulation. For this reason she uses photography, a medium in which problems of ''approach'' are explicit, as an analogue to the more veiled ways in which writers work. She begins this comparison by drawing parallels between writers and photographers of the 19th century, including Henry James and Alvin Langdon Coburn. However, her thesis is most persuasive in the latter sections devoted to the American realists of the 1930's - Theodore Dreiser and Alfred Stieglitz, James Agee and Walker Evans, John Steinbeck and Dorothea Lange. Unfortunately, because Ms. Shloss views all esthetic issues in strictly political terms, what begins as a scholarly analysis ultimately becomes an assertion of ideology. For those who believe art offers something beyond polemics, her argument will seem too confining.

title: Speaking of Losing

His 122-race winning streak was the longest in the history of track. ''I ran a good race and the guy that beat me is 10 years younger and ran the race of his life,'' said the 31-year-old hurdler.

title: The Volcker Era Draws to a Close
description: The Fed will have a new chairman after eight years of Paul A. Volcker. His decision to step down unnerved markets temporarily, but the financial community soon began to seem comfortable with the designated successor, Alan Greenspan. Even though he is an admirer of the libertarian philosophy of Ayn Rand and in the past has spoken favorably of the gold standard, Mr. Greenspan is considered a pragmatist who gives doctrine a very low priority. He is widely expected to continue the anti-inflationary emphasis of Mr. Volcker.

He leaves his London hotel, and there they are with photographs of him in the toupee he used to wear for the role, clamoring for his signature. He arrives at a Hertfordshire golf course for a charity tournament, and there they are en masse, waving little books in his direction. For many, he's clearly the once and forever Bond, however admirable his successors and however assiduously they may have been promoted by their publicity machines.

title: HI-FI, OR AT LEAST HIGHER-FI, IS IN FOR TV COLOR
description: THE CONCEPT OF FIDEL-ity, passionately pursued by audio fans, is treated more casually in video. In fact, they are usually unaware that the colors seen on home video sets are usually quite different from the colors actually televised.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: THE GREAT PRETENDER, by James Atlas. (Penguin, $6.95.) Ben Janis, the young hero of James Atlas's first novel, is a Chicago boy, educated at Harvard and Oxford, who is torn between high and pop culture. The book ''kept me laughing throughout,'' Leslie Fiedler said in The Book Review last year. ''But,'' he said, ''I was never quite sure who the joke was on - and to tell the truth, I was afraid to find out.'' CECIL BEATON: A Biography, by Hugo Vickers. (Primus/Donald I. Fine, $12.95.) Hugo Vickers's life of the photographer, designer, artist and writer Cecil Beaton (left) is ''an enormous, sloughing, tireless, unsparing, inch-by-inch trench-warfare chronicle of an English snob's progress through the 20th century,'' Tom Wolfe said here in 1986. The book piles up ''a breathtaking accumulation of . . . snobbish data and dropped names'' and is ''as rich, dense, thick and tasty as a fruitcake, and at times as cloying.'' A PERFECT SPY, by John le Carre. (Bantam, $4.95.) John le Carre's tale of a high-ranking British Intelligence officer who goes into seclusion after his father's death is ''a first-rate espionage novel, perhaps the best of his already impressive oeuvre,'' Frank Conroy said in The Book Review in 1986. Its structure is straightforward, he said, and readers who have found some of Mr. le Carre's works ''overly Byzantine - to the point of self-indulgence - will have no trouble on that account.'' THE BIG TIME: The Harvard Business School's Most Successful Class - and How It Shaped America, by Laurence Shames. (Mentor/New American Library, $4.50.) The Harvard Business School's class of 1949 rode the crest of the postwar industrial wave to the upper echelons of corporate America. Laurence Shames' study of the class is a ''lively account,'' Louis Uchitelle said here last year, told ''with a novelist's eye for description.'' It bogs down, however, in exploring the responsibility of the '49ers for the country's subsequent manufacturing decline. FIRST LOYALTY, by Richard Lourie. (Dell, $3.95.) A Russian scientist stumbles upon a life-extending drug and tries to smuggle his secret to the West in Richard Lourie's suspense novel. The author ''is sometimes beautifully apt and original in his ideas,'' Joseph Hone said in these pages in 1985, ''as well as quick and very chilly in his handling of action.'' CRABGRASS FRONTIER: The Suburbanization of the United States, by Kenneth T. Jackson. (Oxford University, $8.95.) This history of the suburban boom and the forces that brought it about is the most comprehensive so far, our reviewer, Grady Clay, said in 1986. The author ''is at his best in analyzing the various Federal subsidies, most notably for the single-family house, that made suburbia possible and its expansion inevitable.'' NIGHT, by Edna O'Brien. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $4.95.) In a nightlong soliloquy, the narrator of Edna O'Brien's novel lies awake recalling her rural Irish childhood and a life of loves and losses. ''It is all tremendously rich,'' Sara Blackburn said here in 1973. THE EATING OF THE GODS: An Interpretation of Greek Tragedy, by Jan Kott. Translated by Boleslaw Taborski and Edward J. Czerwinski. (Northwestern University, $14.95.) The Polish writer Jan Kott's study of Greek tragedy examines the relations between gods and men in the works of Aeschylus, Sophocles and Euripides from a modern perspective. ''He sights at Greek tragedy . . . along the smoking chimneys of Auschwitz,'' one reviewer said in 1973. ''Howls of pain and madness echo through these pages.'' THE CAR THIEF, by Theodore Weesner. (Vintage, $6.95.) This portrait of a young felon, Theodore Weesner's first novel, is ''so modestly precise and so movingly inevitable that before I knew what was happening to me I felt in the grip of some kind of thriller,'' Joseph McElroy said here in 1972. ROMANTIC IMPRISONMENT: Women and Other Glorified Outcasts, by Nina Auerbach. (Columbia University, $13.) The literary critic Nina Auerbach offers a collection of essays, written over a 17-year period, on Austen, the Brontes, Dickens, George Eliot, Ellen Terry and others. They add up to ''a fascinating overview of the evolution of feminist criticism,'' Angeline Goreau said here in 1986. THE MAN WHO LOVED LEVITTOWN, by W. D. Wetherell. (Avon, $3.95.) W. D. Wetherell, the author of these 10 short stories, displays ''a sharp, fresh eye and a complicated view of our dislocations, pains and dreams,'' Robert Ward said in The Book Review in 1986. Some of the tales, he said, are ''unforgettable.'' MARIE BONAPARTE: A Life, by Celia Bertin. (Yale University, $12.95.) Princess Marie Bonaparte (1882-1962), the great-granddaughter of Napoleon's younger brother and the wife of Prince George of Greece, was a patient and pupil of Freud's and helped establish psychoanalysis in France. ''Her story is fascinating and is told with perceptive skill'' in this ''excellent biography,'' Anthony Storr said in these pages in 1983. HARD RAIN FALLING, by Don Carpenter. (Ballantine, $3.95.) Jack Levitt is a loser, from his illegitimate birth and abandonment through a felonious life of reform school, San Quentin, prizefights and marriage to a bitter socialite. Don Carpenter's novel ''preserves the events of a life in prose polished flat,'' Webster Schott said here in 1966. He ''writes about pool, boozing it up, smashing faces and furniture, and taking the ride to Q as if he were Hemingway describing Caporetto.''

title: RUNNING DOGS AND CREDIT CARDS: CLASS STRUGGLE AND A CHINESE DICTIONARY
description: THE patterns of color formed by the bindings of books on the shelves in my study have become as familiar and deeply ingrained in my memory as the composition of any painting with which I have lived. There is a vein of yellows and greens where the novels are gathered on the higher shelves above my desk. Splashes of orange and red proliferate to the right where books on China's Cultural Revolution reside. To the left, there is a drab wasteland of white, brown and gray that marks the repository of documents issued by the various plenums and sessions of People's Congresses and Central Committees of the Chinese Communist Party. And, just above my desk are the blues and greens of the dictionaries, encyclopedias and other reference works.
