title: Faking It on Film
description: This book offers a fascinating look at the cinema that flourished between 1895 and 1915 in America, before movies could be mentioned in family newspapers. Driven by a furious demand for ever-new product, what these early silent films lacked in technical sophistication they more than made up for in imaginative exuberance. Their titles alone are tantalizing: ''Smashing a Jersey Mosquito'' (1902), ''Electrocuting an Elephant'' (1903) and ''Princess Nicotine; or, The Smoke Fairy'' (1909). These and some 60 other short films of the period -several lasting as little as 17 seconds - are represented in BEFORE HOLLYWOOD: Turn-of-the-Century American Film (Hudson Hills Press, in association with the American Federation of Arts, $35) by frame enlargements showing crockery painted on kitchen walls and other delightful oddities. There are also stills from faked ''actualities,'' news events filmed with models on Manhattan rooftops or, as was the case with ''The Battle of Manila Bay'' (1898), table tops. The accompanying essays are uneven, but those by recognized scholars of early American film, such as John L. Fell and Charles Musser, are enlightening. The piece by Judith Mayne, ''Uncovering the Female Body,'' uses a one-minute film called ''What Happened on Twenty-Third Street, New York City'' (1901) - in which a young woman's dress is lifted by a blast of air from a grate - to provide a brief but fascinating summation of feminist film theory. The real stars of the show, however, are the priceless frame enlargements, augmented by Richard Koszarski's excellent photographic essay, ''Offscreen Spaces,'' showing nickelodeons, studios, fan magazines, posters and shots of early enthusiastic audiences.

title: OSAKA'S FLAVORFUL FEAST OF NOODLES
description: Osaka goes crazy over food - in Japanese, ''kuidaore no Osaka,'' meaning literally, ''Osaka, which collapses from eating its brains out.'' Osakans boast of this passion, noting that they are unlike the people of nearby Kyoto, who discreetly spend their money on luxurious clothes and furnishings. While Osaka shouts out its gluttony unashamed, Kyoto eats in silence, shielding its mouth with a delicately raised hand. Sei Shonagon, the 11th-century lady-in-waiting who described the manners and mores of the imperial court in her miscellany, ''The Pillow Book,'' remarked that one of the sights that disgusted her most was that of a group of workmen near the palace eating their lunch. The aversion to public displays of eating persists today not only in Kyoto but also throughout the higher levels of Japanese society. But pick up any book or magazine written by Osakans on the subject of their regional food, and that phrase, ''kuidaore no Osaka,'' inevitably appears, if not on the cover then at least within the first few pages.

title: AN EPIC STRUGGLE FOR GOLD
description: It is a staggering scene, seeming to belong in a time in which slaves built monumental works for pharaohs and kings. The ancient, frenzied dream of gold has drawn 400,000 people across the wilderness of Brazil. Digging in the Amazon forests, diving into rivers and gnawing at mountainsides, they move with the rainy season and rumors of new sites. Serra Pelada, in the northern state of Para, is the largest and richest of these improvised mines. Since a peasant found the first nuggets there in 1980, a mountain has been reduced to a hollow 600 feet deep and half a mile wide. It has yielded 42 tons of gold. Bars, brothels and stores have sprung up nearby; 100,000 people now live alongside the pit. On the following pages, photographer Sebastiao Salgado provides startling images of Serra Pelada, where fortune-seekers have moved a mountain on their backs.

title:
GARDENING;
A TIME FOR GROWTH AND PROPER CARE
description: LEAD: WITH the growing season well under way, early gardening efforts should have begun to yield dividends. New plantings should be taking hold, the result of fertilizer applications should be evident, and early vegetables should be ready to harvest.

title: A Faulkner Flirtation
description: In the wake of the news media's exploitation of Gary Hart's and Jim Bakker's sexual intrigues, Leslie Aldridge Westoff's article ''A Faulkner Flirtation'' (May 10) does not seem out of place. It is just as inappropriate for The New York Times Magazine to indulge itself, however ''tastefully,'' in Mrs. Westoff's ''invitation to have sex with the greatest living American writer'' as it is to expose the needless details of an evangelist's one-night stand.

title: Patricia Mulry Marries
description: At the Roman Catholic Church of St. Paul the Apostle in Brookville, L.I., yesterday Patricia Mary Mulry, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas C. Mulry of Locust Valley, L.I., was married to Douglas Dane Morgan, a son of Mrs. Lacy L. Morgan of Scottsdale, Ariz., and the late Mr. Morgan. The Rev. Mario Costa performed the ceremony. The bride is a caterer in Waitsfield, Vt. Mr. Morgan is executive chef at the Phoenix Restaurant in Sugarbush Valley, Vt.

title: EXPANSION OF SERVICES TO YOUTHS IS SOUGHT
description: LEAD: THE Westchester Youth Bureau has instituted a major three-year effort to extend youth-development and delinquency-prevention programs, which are already operating in local urban areas, to other parts of the county. Particularly targeted is northern Westchester, where youth workers both in and out of government say needed services have been slow to develop and municipal officials have at times been reluctant to admit that youth problems - such as drug abuse and teen-age pregnancy - exist.

title: GORBACHEV SEIZES THE CHANCE TO RESTRUCTURE THE MILITARY
description: LAST July, Mikhail S. Gorbachev assembled the officer corps of the Far Eastern Command in Khabarovsk to discuss problems in the military. ''How is discipline?'' the Soviet leader asked the district commander.

title: BET TWICE WINS BELMONT BY 14 LENGTHS; ALYSHEBA IS 4th AS TRIPLE CROWN BID FAILS
description: Bet Twice, a narrow runner-up in both the Kentucky Derby and the Preakness, reversed those decisions with a vengeance in the 119th running of the Belmont Stakes yesterday to deprive Alysheba of racing's Triple Crown.

title: A NEW DISIGN FOR A NEW KIND OF LAW SCHOOL
description: THIS IS A STORY ABOUT A SMALL project, with relatively modest architectural ambitions, that in its own way instills a degree of faith in New York, faith in architecture and faith in the human race that few buildings of greater scope have been able to bring forth. The building is not tall, it is not dazzling, and it is not in Manhattan. It is not even new, though it has been newly renovated. It is impressive as much for its program, for what goes on inside it, as for its architecture - although the careful, sensitive relationship between the architectural design and the activities that go on within the building could stand as a model for other projects elsewhere.

title: STREET NAMES MIX HISTORY AND POETRY
description: THERE'S no telling what bothers people. Take the residents of Gay Street in West Seneca, N.Y. More than half of the families living there petitioned for a street name change. From now on they want to be called Fawn Trail.

title: 'CALIFORNIA SUITE,' SLIGHT BUT COOL
description: NEIL SIMON'S ''California Suite'' is the opening production this summer of the Arena Players Repertory Company in its Main Stage theater in East Farmingdale. This 1977 West Coast complement to ''Plaza Suite'' is set in a hotel in Los Angeles and consists of four short scenes, each a vignette of marital tribulation.

title: Rare Opportunity Benefits Harris
description: Two months ago, Danny Harris agreed to run a 400-meter hurdles race June 4 in Madrid.

description: ''LA SONNAMBULA'' and ''Bournonville Divertissements,'' absent from the New York City Ballet for several years, re-entered the repertory Friday night at the State Theater as ''new productions.'' The results were more than surprising and never less than interesting.

title: On Bumpy Road to Crown, Alysheba Is Left Behind
description: Instead of making history, the Alysheba contingent made do with a fourth-place finish in the Belmont Stakes yesterday as the colt's rider and trainer chided themselves for the slow, bumpy path that their horse could not gracefully survive.

title: Ms. McGuigan Marries on L.I.
description: Cathleen Mary McGuigan and David Bruce Berridge were married yesterday at the bride's summer home in Sag Harbor, L.I. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Charles A. Baldwin, the United Church of Christ chaplain of Brown University.

description: A Puerto Rican drug-rehabilitation agency in the South Bronx has won an award that it hopes will help Hispanic groups overcome the obscurity that has long hampered their search for charity money.

title: JAZZ: BYRD ON TRUMPET
description: DONALD BYRD was part of the hard-bop jazz mainstream in the 1950's and 1960's; in the 1970's, he took a lucrative detour into pop. But through this Sunday at the Blue Note, 131 West Third Street, he is playing what he said was his first New York jazz club date in 17 years, working with a quartet led by James Williams on piano. (He shares a double bill with the pianist Michel Petrucciani and his trio.) It's not strictly a return to hard-bop - the group includes a synthesizer player, Michael Doherty, who added some unwelcome pseudo-string sweetening - but it's definitely jazz, not pop.

title: RETIRING U.S. OFFICIAL ASSAILS NUCLEAR PLANT SAFETY
description: The level of safety at nuclear reactors around the country is so low that a fatal meltdown in the next 10 to 20 years would not be a surprise, according to James K. Asselstine, a retiring member of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission.

In the Region: New Jersey;
Englewood's Finally a 'Hot' Place to Build
description: LEAD: ''WE are exploding,and indications are that the activity is not about to stop soon,'' said Joseph Murphy, a city planner for Englewood, a well-established community four miles from the George Washington Bridge in northeast Bergen County. '

title: Speaking of Running
description: After nearly four years of rumored political candidacies in Michigan, Virginia, Tennessee and New York, Peter M. Dawkins, a much-decorated Vietnam War general who left the army to become an investment banker, announced last week that he would run for office - in New Jersey. Mr. Dawkins said he would seek the Republican nomination to oppose incumbent Democratic Senator Frank R. Lautenberg next year. A West Pointer who won both a Rhodes scholarship and the Heisman Trophy, college football's highest honor, Mr. Dawkins picked a state that already has a onetime sports star and Rhodes scholar in the Senate - Bill Bradley, a former Knick forward and Princeton all-American.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: TEMPTING FATE. By Laurie Alberts. (Houghton Mifflin, $17.95.) The state of Alaska, disconnected from the rest of the country, has much in common with the characters in Laurie Alberts's first novel, ''Tempting Fate.'' Alaska is separate, little explored and cold. So are many of the characters. A disconsolate Russian, a hell-bent Indian and a flaky dropout from New England move about the little island of Vladimir, salmon fishing for a living and getting potted the rest of the time in local saloons. The ragtag characters in this book have settled in Alaska for various reasons, some because fishing is in their blood, one because the name ''Vladimir'' has special significance for him, and Allie, the novel's main character, because she claims to have already ''used up'' the rest of the continent. Yet instead of being the last, great untamed frontier, the wild and woolly dreamscape that many of these people think it is, Alaska serves in this story as a sort of subarctic halfway house, a rehab center for the wayward who are presumably en route to a better life (though many, it turns out, are not). Ms. Alberts, who has traveled widely and who won a Michener award for this novel, is at her best in describing the rigors of life aboard the fishing boats; she ably evokes a climate and style of life that few will ever know, much less imagine. The scenery is vivid, as is her depiction of the life of the Alaskan Indian, whose customs and lore have been compromised by the influx of oil entrepreneurs and big business. Though limited by the sameness of its scenes (bars, boats and more bars) and an excess of pitiable characters, ''Tempting Fate'' is a perceptive work of adventure fiction.

title: Rhymes For The Times
description: In response to ''There Was an Old Lady From Spain . . .'' (with an introduction by Barbara Dubivsky, May 10): We thought that your idea was great, Making verses to mark limerick's date. So I sat down and wrote This additional note To join in and help celebrate! IRIS B. LASH Shelburne, Vt.

title: THE CONTINUING HEMLINE SAGA
description: SELDOM, IN RECENT MEM-ory, has a shift in fashion so caught the public's interest. The unfolding story of the short skirt has become news for all pages: front, editorial and advertising. Meanwhile, those people truly interested in fashion -the designers, manufacturers, retailers and customers - avidly pursue this new knee-baring trend. At the moment, there are few high-hem skirts available; they are mostly in the junior and avant-garde designer departments. In the new collections for fall, however, American designers have gone all-out for the shorter lengths; they will soon be shipping hemlines that hover above or in the middle of the knee. But the true test of bare-knees success will come next fall, in the stores. Some women, of course, will dismiss the whole movement, stick with their longer hems and look just fine. But it's a good guess that many more will be caught up in the buoyant, youthful feeling that a short skirt undeniably gives the wearer - especially if her legs are not half bad.

description: Kimberly Ann Tooley, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David John Tooley of San Diego, was married yesterday to Donald James Sutherland Jr., the son of Mr. Sutherland of New York and Glen Head, L.I., and Mrs. Jonathan Ingham of Locust Valley, L.I. description: ONCE MORE AROUND THE BLOCK Familiar Essays. By Joseph Epstein. 308 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company. $16.95.

description: THE Sunday River ski resort, which was $20,000 in the red six years ago, will spend $25 million on condominiums and other improvements this summer on its 3,000-acre property in western Maine.

title: SUMMER AND ICE
description: ICED DESSERTS DATE FROM AT LEAST THE DAYS of Marco Polo. It is said that when this celebrated traveler arrived in the Orient in the mid-13th century, he observed the natives cooling their palates with exotic fruits blended with ice that had been brought from the snowy mountains by camel pack. On his return to Italy, Marco Polo introduced the custom to his countrymen, long before the invention of ice cream.

title: WHAT'S NEW IN THE TENNIS BUSINESS
description: THE Game Plan study served some sobering statistics to the Tennis Industry Council. Of the country's 10.5 million to 11 million players, only 1.6 million -about 15 percent - are serious players and active consumers of tennis goods and services. Sixty-three percent of all players are playing less. And the report predicted that unless the industry took action, the total number of players would continue to drop significantly.

description: WILL Washington succeed in its latest grab for New York's cultural treasures? The target this time is the beleaguered Museum of the American Indian, long in search of a worthy home for its nearly one million tribal artifacts, mostly warehoused in the Bronx for lack of exhibition space.

Rappoport of New Rochelle, N.Y., and Steven Charles Witkoff, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Martin Witkoff of Old Westbury and Westhampton Beach, L.I., were married last evening at the St. Regis-Sheraton in New York by Rabbi Amiel Wohl, assisted by Cantor Helene Reps. The bride, an associate in the Manhattan law firm of Botein, Hays & Sklar, will keep her name professionally. Mr. Witkoff is president of Fortune Equities Inc., a real-estate company in Manhattan.

description: LEAD: ENTERING FIRE. By Rikki Ducornet. (Chatto & Windus/ Salem, Paper, $6.95.) The two principal characters in this unusual short novel, set mainly in pre-World War II and wartime France and Brazil, take turns with the narration; they are Lamprias de Bergerac (a descendant of Cyrano), an amateur French botanist, and his son Septimus.

description: THE two-stick Popsicle, a creation of the Great Depression, became mainly a memory a year ago in May. In its place in grocery stores, which accounted for 80 percent of the sales, appeared a one-stick version.

title: Nilsson Moving On
description: A three-year contract with the 1987 Stanley Cup champions would seem to be a nice way to round out a career, but not for Kent Nilsson. The 30-year-old Swedish-born center, who helped the Edmonton Oilers win the championship last Sunday after joining the team from the Minnesota North Stars in March, rejected an offer of a three-year Oiler pact in favor of a return to Europe. He said he would play either for Stockholm or Bolzano in the Italian Alps. Not that Nilsson has anything against the National Hockey League, the Oilers or Edmonton.

title: WHAT'S NEW IN THE TENNIS BUSINESS
description: TEN years ago, the query ''Tennis, anyone?'' elicited a roaring ''Yes'' around the country. Tennis was the boom sport of the 1970's, its popularity fed in large part by the greater visibility of professional tennis and in particular by the ballyhooed ''Battle of the Sexes'' between Billie Jean King and Bobby Riggs in 1973.

title: HOW OTHER NATIONS APPRROACH THE PROBLEM
description: Even at the seven-nation industrial summit this week AIDS will be on the agenda. In attempting to change both public health practices and private conduct, European governments have begun shaping national policies. Most require reporting of AIDS cases, as in the United States, but not testing. Most have extensive educational campaigns, though they have far fewer cases than the United States. A sampling of measures taken by foreign governments follows. France: Reporting of AIDS cases is mandatory. A few groups, including prisoners and members of the armed services, are tested for the virus in the course of normal medical examinations. A publicity campaign with TV spots and subway posters began in April, and the law has been changed to allow advertising of condoms. West Germany: The Federal Government does not require reporting of AIDS cases or testing of any groups. The state government in Bavaria has begun compulsory testing of prostitutes, prisoners, drug addicts, applicants for jobs in the public sector and most non-European Community nationals applying for residence. Britain: There is no testing or reporting requirement. Leaflets have been mailed to every household in the nation and explicit advertisements appear on television, but two researchers at the Washington conference said the campaign had had ''little impact'' on high-risk groups. Japan: The Government has proposed legislation requiring physicians to report AIDS cases and positive results from antibody tests and giving local authorities power to order exams for suspected virus carriers. Educational programs are carried out by local governments. Sweden: Testing is entirely voluntary now, but in the autumn screening of military recruits and pregnant women will begin. Reporting of positive test results is mandatory, and anyone who knowingly transmits the virus may be isolated against his will in a hospital. Recently the number of those requesting tests has declined. Soviet Union: No AIDS policy has been developed, and publicity is limited to articles in the press. Officials say they plan to require testing of all foreign students.

title: LIKABILITY CAN BECOME A LIABILITY
description: CALL IT THE LIKABILITY Factor. It's as good a yardstick as any for measuring TV entertainment. Certain forms, notably situation comedies, are almost aggressively likable. ''The Mary Tyler Moore Show'' wasn't just nice; it was adorable. That's how sitcoms are built. Even Archie Bunker had to be a ''lovable'' bigot. Weekly drama series, while more flexible, offer their own variations, among them characters you love to hate - J. R. in ''Dallas,'' Alexis in ''Dynasty.'' One curious result is that when a new series actually throws in a few characters who seem somewhat less than likable, it is inevitably hailed as a daring breakthrough. Steven Bochco, the executive producer, has had two strong NBC entries in this category: ''Hill Street Blues,'' now deceased, and ''L.A. Law,'' this past season's trendy hit. In addition to devising a new style, achieved largely with hand-held cameras and several rotating plots in each episode, ''Hill Street Blues'' captured attention with its unusual gallery of regular characters. There was the normal quota of solid types, led by the upstanding Captain Furillo (Daniel J. Travanti), but consider a couple of the oddballs on this police force: Belker (Bruce Weitz), the growling loner who would sometimes bite the people he arrested; or Renko (Charles Haid), a cheerfully bigoted, good old Southern boy, having problems with his new black partner. These were the kinds of touches that gave ''Hill Street Blues'' its distinctive edge. But that edge was gradually dulled as the series succumbed to the lure of the Likability Factor. In time, Belker became just another family man with a nagging mother problem, and Renko turned into a model of racial enlightenment. In the process, ''Hill Street Blues'' became ordinary. Unfortunately, the same process appears to be in an accelerating mode for ''L.A. Law,'' created by Mr. Bochco and Mary Louise Fisher, formerly one of the top producers of ''Cagney & Lacey.'' Here again, the good guys are on prominent display, beginning with Leland McKenzie (Richard Dysart), the law firm's senior partner and resident moral guru, and continuing down the line with Michael Kuzak (Harry Hamlin), compassionate and good looking; Ann Kelsey (Jill Eikenberry), idealistic and good looking; Victor Sifuentes (Jimmy Smits), aggressive and good looking, and Stuart Markowitz (Michael Tucker), sweet and, for a dab of variety, merely pleasant looking. Standing somewhat outside this charmed and charming orbit, at least for the first few episodes, were Douglas Brackman Jr. (Alan Rachins), the insufferable son of one of the founders, and Arnie Becker (Corbin Bernsen), the breezily manipulative expert in divorce cases. Doug and Arnie were just nasty enough to give ''L.A. Law'' its much-lauded aura of realism.

title: AWARENESS OF ALCOHOL DANGER FOUND GROWING
description: Public understanding of the dangers of alcohol has increased since 1982, according to the latest Gallup Poll.

title: Jays Win On Clout In 11th
description: Jesse Barfield hit a three-run homer with two outs in the bottom of the 11th inning today as the Toronto Blue Jays rallied for an 8-5 victory over the Baltimore Orioles.

title: SAMPLING FRANCE'S SYSTEM OF TRAILS
description: The Grande Randonnee is France's answer to the Appalachian Trail. In the past two Septembers we have logged more than 100 miles (in discrete segments) on G.R. 6, the cross-country part of France's national trail network that extends from Bordeaux to the Alps, meandering right through the section of the Dordogne where we were vacationing.

title: WHITE HOUSE CHEF TO LEAVE IN FALL
description: After five administrations, more than 250 state dinners and 21 years as the executive chef at the White House, Henry Haller will be hanging up his hat Oct. 1 despite efforts to persuade him to stay on until the end of the Reagan Administration.

title: JOPLIN MILESTONE DUE ON CD
description: HARDLY A RECORD COM-pany exists that has not been plumbing its back catalogue for treasures to transfer to compact disk. And many of these reissues, from major and minor companies alike, have indeed been treasures, from Furtwangler and Callas to Bernstein and Karajan. Now, Nonesuch finally joins the parade, with nine releases, reflecting the diversity of the label and, in a way, honoring previous overseers of Nonesuch's releases, including Teresa Sterne, who was consultant for the CD reissues. The CD's are scheduled for release at the end of this month.

title: BIRTHDAY CANDLES IN NORTH CAROLINA ARE SEEN AFAR
description: EVERYONE LIKES TO CELE-brate anniversaries, and the American Dance Festival is no exception. In 1984, the festival staged a wide-ranging international season to celebrate its 50th anniversary, harking back to its pioneering summer sessions at Bennington College in Vermont and, later, at Connecticut College. Resident at Duke University in Durham, N. C., since 1978, it is now content to mark its new season as a ''10th birthday'' in North Carolina. A giant cakewalk contest, organized by the choreographer Daniel Nagrin, will help wind up the festivities.

title: Report Calls U.S. Airline Inspections Inadequate
description: Astudy by the General Accounting Office, a research arm of Congress, says the system for inspecting the safety procedures of airlines has been inadequate.

title: LITHOGRAPHS OFFER HOPE ON HART DEBT
description: A certain sign that the aborted Presidential campaign of Gary Hart is in financial straits is that the National Bank of Washington plans to dust off a series of 92 lithographs by the American artist Robert Rauschenberg.

title: Ancestral Vineyards Bear New Fruit For The Zeccas
description: COUNT Alcibiade Zecca nods toward the red roses that grow where the grape vines end in his family's vineyard. ''They say here,'' he said, ''that the wine takes on the scent of the blossoms.''

title: Kay E. Spear, a Designer, Wed to Eric Gibson, Critic
description: At St. Luke's Episcopal Church in East Hampton, L.I., yesterday Kay Evelyn Spear, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Spear Jr. of East Hampton, was married to Eric Gibson, the son of David Gibson of Washington and the late Anne Sears Gibson. The Rev. Robert Farrar Capon performed the ceremony.

title: At a School With a 'Dreamer,' Idea of Sculptures Takes Form
description: ONCE upon a time there was a steep, rocky hill in a town called Pelham. Weeds grew on the hill, and it wasn't pretty to look at. Then one day a woman named June Slotkin had an idea. ''Let's clear the hill and put sculpture on it,'' she said. ''Then it will become a thing of beauty the town can be proud of.''

title: A.F.L.-C.I.O. SHUNS '88 ENDORSEMENT
description: Leaders of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. have virtually abandoned hope of endorsing a Presidential candidate before the 1988 primaries and caucuses begin, as they endorsed Walter F. Mondale in the last national election.

title: THE CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: LEAD: Shoe Bazaar Offers Additional Discounts The Shoe Bazaar - for eight years in Hartsdale Plaza on South Central Park Avenue and for 18 years in Briarcliff Manor at the Chilmark Shopping Plaza - usually sells domestic and imported women's shoes and handbags at 10 to 15 percent off department store prices.

title: A BLOOMING PARADE CONTINUES THE SEASON
description: TALL perennials become floppy, if not staked, particularly peonies, delphiniums, babysbreath, foxgloves and some rudbeckias. Wise pruners save some of the tallest canes and twigs for this purpose; when poked into the ground, these supports hold up floppy herbaceous stems and in time become invisibile. This is a trick used in many famous European gardens. If there are no pruning leftovers, use bamboo stakes, which are inexpensive to buy at garden centers; save nylon stockings to cut up as soft ties. Finish all planting. Put out tender tropical waterlilies in garden pools (their flowers are held high on stems well above the water). Groom rows where spinach, peas, radish and spring onions matured and replant these rows with beets, carrots, chard and, if there is room, another row of beans. Be sure the cucumbers and melons have adequate space. Straighten any corn seedlings knocked over by winds. Check tomato plants for suckers and snip out these unwanted growths between thumb and forefinger. Every few mornings, snap off faded petunias and geraniums to maintain plants and sustain bloom. QUESTIONS/ANSWERS WISTERIA

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption on the music page of the Arts and Leisure section today gives an incorrect time for ''The Meditative Chopin II'' concert today at Alice Tully Hall. It will be performed at 3 P.M.

title: Service Economy
description: To the Editor:

title: Native Plants Reviving Ravaged Landscapes
description: The fate of the silver lupine plants on San Bruno Mountain south of here is a cautionary tale about man's interference with nature.

title: Complaints
description: To the Editor: In regard to Betsy Wade's article (Practical Traveler, April 19) about letters of complaint: My own experience has been more sympathetically responsive than those she described. The difference, perhaps, is that my letters have been about establishments in England and France. I use and trust Michelin Red Guides and believe them when they state (on a form inserted in each book), ''Your opinions . . . are welcomed and will be examined by our inspectors who will revisit . . .'' Over the years I have written to Michelin expressing: (a)Serious lack at a one-star restaurant at Le Puy (France); the restaurant was not listed in the next issue of the guide. (b)Surprise at the low rating of a restaurant in Tours (France); the restaurant was given a star in the next issue of the guide. (c)Distaste at the unsavory character of clientele (not hotel guests) hanging around the hotel bar (the police arrived in the middle of the night to remove the brawlers); the hotel has not been listed since (Somerset, England).

title: Regulation 302, Broadcasters 102
description: Broadcasters had hoped that the fairness doctrine, which requires them to present differing views on controversial subjects, would wither away. That seemed possible, as the Federal Communications Commission, enforcer of the policy, had termed it pointless and probably unconstitutional. But Congress disagreed, so much so that it has now voted to turn the fairness doctrine into Federal law.

title: 6 KUWAITI SHIITE TERRORISTS CONDEMNED
description: Six Kuwaiti Shiite Moslems, two of them still at large, were sentenced to hang today for setting fires in this emirate's oilfields in support of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini's Islamic revolution.

title:
THE BASQUE COUNTRY;
AFTER CENTURIES IN TURMOIL, A REGION'S CULTURE SEEMS ON THE BRINK OF A REVIVAL
description: LEAD: FROM THE CLEAN streets of the Vitoria, the seat of the Basque regional government, to the urban centers of San Sebastian and Bilbao and the villages seemingly etched into the hills and mountains, the topic of most interest nowadays is the future of Basque culture.

title: Talking; Co-ops
description: BUYERS shopping for cooperative apartments often are surprised to learn that some co-op corporations own their buildings, but not the land on which they stand.

title: POLISH CHURCH AWAITS POPE, BEWILDERED BY ITS NEW VIGOR
description: The Roman Catholic Church of Poland, which was beleaguered and defensive when Karol Wojtyla was rising through its ranks, has grown remarkably strong in his nine years as Pope.

title:
DINING OUT;
Family's Seafood Spot in Irvington
description: LEAD: IN a recent column, we declared that the best seafood can be had in the best restaurants -the ones with excellent kitchens and, usually, high price tags. Although that theory still holds, we had forgotten about Benny's, a modestly priced, brass-tacks, family-run restaurant celebrating its 44th birthday this year, and may it live to be 120.

title: Alain Guy Chevrier Wed To Susan Sophi Garfinkle
description: Susan Sophi Garfinkle, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sandor A. Garfinkle of New York and Franklin Lakes, N.J., and Alain Guy Chevrier, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Come Chevrier of Cornwall, Ontario, were married last evening at the Pierre in New York. The ceremony was performed by Maurice G. Greenbaum, a Village Justice in Kings Point, L.I., who is the bride's uncle.

title: Hijacker of a Small Airplane Under Custody in San Juan
description: A man who had hijacked a small airplane and threatened to blow it up unless he was flown to Cuba surrendered early today.

title: INSIDE
description: Woes of the Argentine Army Argentina's armed forces, which have dominated that nation's power and politics for most of the last half-century, now feel under siege.

title: Mr. Gandhi, on Four Fronts
description: India calls it ''humanitarian aid'' to beleaguered Tamils threatened with massacre. Sri Lanka vehemently denies atrocity charges and denounces India's air drop of supplies as ''a naked violation of our independence.'' India's Rajiv Gandhi has become as much field marshal as Prime Minister, while armies mass on all the subcontinent's fault lines. It's past time for him to stop all the marching and to restart negotiations on four fronts.

title: Norfolk Southern's Risky One-Track Strategy
description: THINGS are calmer now for Arnold B. McKinnon, the new chairman and chief executive of the Norfolk Southern Corporation.

title: FOR CHILDREN: SONGS, STORIES, GAMES
description: THE WORLD OF CHIL-dren's audio cassettes has evolved into a market that corresponds roughly to the developmental stages of children themselves. There are soothing tunes and simple songs for the very young, book and cassette packages for those learning to read, and complex stories and novels for older children.

title: Commercial Property: Office Lobbies; Images of Elegance Proving a Magnet to Tenants
description: LANDLORDS of Manhattan office buildings are ripping out fluorescent tubes, stainless steel elevator doors and every other trace of the 1960's from their lobbies.

title: THE USE AND MISUSE OF UTILITY TAXES
description: GROSS-RECEIPT and franchise taxes are a fact of life for utility customers in New Jersey. They also represent big dollars. A full 13.5 percent of every electric and natural-gas bill -a higher rate than any other state's -they amount to more than $800 million annually.

title: INDIA'S AID TO TAMILS IS 'AGGRESSION' TO SRI LANKA
description: IT was portrayed by India as a mission of mercy and by Sri Lanka as ''naked act of aggression.'' But diplomats and other experts said the air drop of aid to the ethnic Tamil minority in northern Sri Lanka last week mainly underscored India's growing aspirations to regional power status. The air drop was made after Sri Lankan naval vessels turned back a flotilla of fishing boats carrying the aid. Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi's unexpected decision to dispatch 25 tons of food and medicine, most of it to territory held by Tamil guerrillas battling for an independent nation in Sri Lanka, abruptly transformed perceptions and politics in South Asia.

title: STATE AIDS PROSPECTIVE TEACHERS
description: HAVING agreed to teach in New Jersey public schools for a minimum of four years after graduating from college, 160 high school seniors from public and parochial schools throughout the state have been awarded four-year college ''scholarship loans'' by the state's Department of Education.

title: A LIGHT OPERA TROUPE RISES FROM THE ASHES
description: LEAD: IN A DINGY, KICK-MARKED, DUST-laden studio downtown, the chorus of the Light Opera of Manhattan was learning its tap routines. ''Six clogs, a toe shuffle - this one's straight out of 'Hello, Dolly!' and - ooh, I love it, I love it,'' the choreographer cried.

title: SOME HALLS ARE NOT FOR THE RECORD
description: THE RECENT REFUR-bishing of Carnegie Hall has altered its fabled acoustics - not by much, but enough to stir debate among musical New Yorkers, who can't seem to decide whether the change is for better or worse. Listeners elsewhere are also affected, for - along with other famous concert halls - Carnegie Hall serves as an occasional recording site. In fact, several of the legendary older recordings made there have just been transferred to CD, including such milestones of historic phonography as Arturo Toscanini's version of Beethoven's Ninth (with the NBC Orchestra on RCA) and Bruno Walter's version of Mahler's Second Symphony (with the New York Philharmonic on CBS).

title: Miss Holcomb Is Wed on L.I.
description: At the Old First Presbyterian Church in Huntington, L.I., yesterday, Margaret Hamilton Holcomb and James William Schubauer 2d were married by the Rev. William W. Rogers. The couple's parents, who live in Lloyd Harbor, L.I., are Mr. and Mrs. Charles R. Holcomb and Mr. and Mrs. Schubauer. Glory Crampton was the maid of honor. Peter Shaifer was best man.

title: PSYCHIATRIST, 95, STILL ACTIVE IN MILFORD
description: LEAD: SIXTY-FIVE years ago, Dr. Helen Langner walked out of the Yale University School of Medicine with her medical degree in hand. Last week she was planning to return to the campus, as the only surviving member of the Class of '22, for the school's annual reunion celebration yesterday.

title: Obscure Subject of Desire
description: To the Editor:

title: BOSTON GLOBE TARGET: NEW HAMPSHIRE
description: The Boston Globe has begun publishing on Sundays a thick section dedicated to New Hampshire, part of a direct challenge to The Manchester Union Leader and a test of the growing economic and psychological integration of New Hampshire and Massachusetts.

title:
In the Region: Long Island;
Development With an Eye to Preservation
description: LEAD: GARY RODOLITZ, a commercial developer in Westbury, has come up with a proposal that he hopes will let him build 350,000 square feet of office space next to his 225,000-square-foot Mitchel Field Corporate Center in Westbury.

title: CROAKER LEAVING PORT,MAYBE FOR NEW LONDON
description: LEAD: LHE Submarine Capital of the World will soon be down one submarine, and the Whaling City across the Thames River may have a submarine to call its own.

title: Bush's Press Secretary Quits After Four Months on the Job
description: Vice President Bush's press secretary, Larry Thomas, has resigned after less than four months on the job and plans to return to California.

title: CORRECTION
description: Dr. Theodore Goldfarb was misidentified in an article in last Sunday's Long Island Weekly section. He is associate vice provost for undergraduate studies at the State University of New York at Stony Brook.

description: A RECENT MARTYR By Valerie Martin. 204 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company. $16.95.

title:
INVESTING;
A New Way to Play the Pacific
description: LEAD: While the strong rally on the Tokyo Stock Exchange has been confined mostly to the blue chips, some investors believe that it is just a matter of time before the smaller Japanese stocks surge as well. Scudder, Stevens & Clark, the investment management firm, is among the believers. It expects to begin trading the Scudder New Asia Fund on the New York Stock Exchange in the next week or so.

title: THE INVASION OF THE COMPACT DISKS: A BATTLE PLAN
description: THE DISAPPOINTING thing about compact disks, of course, is that they aren't.

title: MEMORY SOARS AS A SWING SET DEPARTS
description: LAST weekend marked a milestone in our lives. We dismantled the swing set, acknowledging that our son was no longer a young child, but a pre-adolescent.

title: BOLD FOR SUMMER: THE ART OF CHECKS
description: BLACK is a color that traditionally asserts itself in New York later in the summer, around August. No one can say why for sure; it just happens. This year is different. This year black has arrived early. Why? Well, the French designer Jean-Paul Gaultier, known for his eye-catching and often exaggerated clothes, has come up with a winner in his architecturally cut black suit. So why wait until August to be seen wearing it?

title: MUSIC: CONCORDIA GROUP IN 20TH-CENTURY WORKS
description: THE Concordia chamber orchestra (or, as the group bills itself, ''Concordia: A Chamber Symphony'') is dedicated to that problematic American proposition, the oneness of music. As a nation that values the European musical tradition but has done only a little to extend it, while fostering a non-European popular tradition recognized the world round as valuable, we are bound to experiment with the possibility of cross-fertilization.

title: A HARD ROAD, SELDOM TAKEN
description: A mother thinks the road is long and lonely Little brother thinks the road is straight and fine Little darlin' thinks the road is soft and lovely I'm thankful that old road's a friend of mine It's snowin' on Raton Come mornin' I'll be through them hills and gone*

title: WHAT'S DOING IN: SANTA FE
description: Loosely applied, the term Santa Fe charm covers a lot - from rounded adobe walls and crystal-clear mountain air to the distinctive Southwestern atmosphere where Indian, Spanish and Anglo cultures closely intertwine and artistic creativity flourishes like a desert bloom. Until recently, also high on the list of summer charm was a confirmed room reservation in this small city of 50,000 that stretched to the seams in high season. But more than one hotelier noted the gap between available accommodations and the numbers of visitors, and suddenly new hotels and refurbished old ones promise to make this summer's search for lodgings in Santa Fe into a buyer's market. title: Spain Orders the Extradition Of 15 Italian Far Rightists
description: Authorities were seeking 15 Italian far rightists wanted by Italy on terrorism charges, the police said today.

description: Victory Garden Recipes By Marian Morash. Produced by Morash Associates. Knopf Video Books. 90 minutes. $29.95.

title: Herring
description: To the Editor: I very much enjoyed ''Cured New Herring of the Netherlands'' (Travel, April 12) because in May 1968 when we were in Amsterdam, the street vendors with their carts were everywhere. I consumed a raw herring in the approved manner and still have a snapshot to prove it.

title: Disputed Shelter For the Homeless
description: A LONG struggle to renovate a shelter for the homeless in Washington reached yet another climax in March 1986 when the Federal Government agreed to turn the building over to the District of Columbia, along with $5 million to help fix it up.

description: Jeanne E. Zavell, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Paul M. Zavell of Grosse Pointe Farms, Mich., was married there yesterday to John Christie Archibald Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Archibald of Rumson, N.J. Msgr. Francis X. Canfield performed the ceremony at St. Paul's on the Lake Roman Catholic Church. He was assisted by the Rev. Edward V. Zavell, a Byzantine Catholic priest who is the bride's uncle.

title: WHEN BABY DOES SOMETHING CUTE

title: WOMEN'S GROUP TALLIES SUCCESSES
description: A ONCE-SMALL networking group for middle-management women that started in Stamford seven years ago now has become so successful that over 60 percent of its 250 members earn more than $50,000 a year and close to one in five tops $90,000.

description: This city of almost hallucinatory beauty, nestled in its protective lagoon, is one of those places that belongs to all the world.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK;
Rock Hall, Md.: Thumbs Down To Developers
description: LEAD: By a 4-to-1 vote, the residents of this economically depressed Chesapeake Bay fishing village have blocked plans to turn the center of town into a haven for owners of expensive boats and condominiums.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: LEAD: BREAKING THE RING. By John Barron. (Houghton Mifflin, $17.95.) With all the furor over the Marines' ''good men'' and the porosity of our Moscow embassy, one is in danger of forgetting the implications for national security posed by the John A. Walker case, which broke in 1984. Mr. Walker, his brother, son and a sidekick, Jerry Whitworth, were all Navy people and all, on the whole, rather prosaic individuals.

title: THE STORY UNFOLDS
description: Conflicting stories were common currency in last week's Congressional hearings on the Iran-contra affair. Highlights of the week's developments follow.

title: AS IT WAS, SO IT IS (MOSTLY)
description: NOTHING much changes out here. Despite all the nostalgia as I get older, I realized the other morning that it was just the same then as it is now. Or vice versa. Take the Long Island Rail Road. It's been six months since my last trip on that hallowed institution. But as I got on the other day, the seats were still uncomfortable. It was still $5.75 one way.

title: Mother Sentenced to Prison For Killing of Adopted Son
description: The jury that found a woman guilty of inflicting abuse that killed her 3-year-old adopted son in 1965 ruled Friday that she was sane at the time, and she was sentenced to prison.

title: NEW YORK SETS UP SPECIAL COURTS TO DEAL WITH RISE IN DRUG CASES
description: Faced with an unrelenting rise in narcotics arrests, New York City court officials are establishing special courts that will try to dispose of felony drug cases through plea bargains within six days of an arrest.

description: The Cathedral of St. John the Divine was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Shelly Diane Guyer, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David Leigh Guyer of New York, to Thomas Menefee Huntington, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Hugh Huntington Jr. of Pacific Palisades, Calif. The Very Rev. James Parks Morton, dean of the cathedral, performed the ceremony in the great choir.

title: Michele Mangan Is Wed
description: At St. Paul's Roman Catholic Church in Stone Harbor, N.J., yesterday, Michele Marie Mangan, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edmund L. Mangan of Falls Church, Va., and Stone Harbor, was married to Christopher Emmett O'Brien, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward A. O'Brien Jr. of Nantucket, Mass., and Arlington, Va. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. John F. X. O'Connor. The bride is associate director of admissions at Marymount College in Tarrytown, N.Y. The bridegroom is a senior sales representative for the Dataline Corporation, a computer concern in Wilton, Conn.

title: Catherine Taylor Is Bride
description: Catherine Shawhan Taylor, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. John Arthur Taylor Jr. of Bronxville, N.Y., was married yesterday to John Gordon Hawkins, a son of Patricia Hawkins of Chestnut Hill, Mass., and David Hawkins of Brookline, Mass. The Rev. John A. Klingelhofer performed the ceremony at the Reformed Church of Bronxville.

description: LEAD: EILEEN and William Drower will literally be up the creek with their 2l-foot sports-fishing boat this year unless the Long Island Lighting Company and New York State can come to terms on dredging Wading River Creek.

title:
ABOUT WESTCHESTER;
GETTING READY
description: LEAD: IT was the perfect setting for a genteel party. The living room, with its restful, pale aqua walls, was filled with the sound of soft laughter and conversation. Canapes - tiny shrimp-salad sandwiches, mushroom puff pastries and pieces of ham rolled around cream cheese -were passed on platters among the guests.

title: Art
description: Joan Miro was a major figure in European art for the greater part of his very long life. He could do whatever he wanted. He could paint. He could make prints. He could build constructions that still astonish us, after more than 50 years, by their freshness and originality. He could design for the theater. He could make ceramics. He could make enormous decorations for public places. And then, when already well on in years, he made his debut as a sculptor.

title: Stars & Stares
description: HE'S been hauling boats for 29 years, and he's accustomed to the admiring glances from passing motorists, but Max Dudley, a trucker from Sumner, Wash., never had a cargo that created as much sensation as the one he agreed to haul from Seattle to San Diego last week. ''Everyone drives past and slows down when they see the name on the boat,'' Dudley said at a truck stop near the California border where the boat, temporarily marooned while awaiting a permit to continue the journey on California roads, was surrounded by curiosity seekers.

title: Forced AIDS Tests. Then What?
description: Of course, says everyone from the President to Mayor Koch. It's obvious: Test people for AIDS. Testing, whether called mandatory or sugared with the term ''routine,'' has suddenly become the politicians' cure for this incurable disease. But testing is no more obvious than it is a cure. The underlying question, lost in all the clamor, is not whether to test but when, and why.

title: OF CRIME, RACE, URBAN LIFE AND GOETZ
description: LEAD: EARLY on in case of Bernhard H. Goetz, Rudolph W. Giuliani, the United States Attorney in Manhattan, considered and rejected filing Federal charges against Mr. Goetz for violating the civil rights of four teen-agers he shot aboard a subway.

title: GOODYEAR'S TRANSMUTATIONS OF ZEN AT THE PRINCETON GALLERY
description: TAKE a sheet of graph paper and fill selected squares with different colors. It's a recipe for child's play, but in the hands of John Goodyear it yields results that could hardly be more sophisticated.

title: FARMLAND PRESERVATION SEEN AS BACKFIRING
description: LEAD: NEW JERSEY voters approved a $50 million bond issue in 1981 to pay for farmland preservation programs, and the state has been losing ground ever since.

description: LEAD: THE Mason Gross School of the Arts at Rutgers University will hold the most extensive summer arts festival in its history from June 16 to Aug. 9.

title: 50 MORE TOP CD'S TO TICKLE YOUR LASER
description: IT'S THAT TIME OF YEAR AGAIN -time for another list of recommended compact-disk releases. As with the previous four lists (counting today's, 300 titles have now been recommended), this is a group of releases, not disks; one release can comprise many disks, as with Neville Marriner's complete Mozart symphonies or Alfred Brendel's complete Beethoven piano sonatas.

title: First-Name Fixation
description: I SPENT A FEW HOURS in Washington where life is hard to bear. Everybody was saying ''Ollie.'' It reminded me why life in Washington is hard to bear. It's that habit they have of calling newsy people by first names or nicknames.

title: Only Sanctions Can Dismantle Apartheid
description: THE last fig leaf has now been stripped from United States corporations continuing to operate in South Africa. The Rev. Leon Sullivan, whose principles the companies used for over a decade to justify continuing profits from apartheid, has told them to get out - lock, stock, license and franchise.

title: CHEERFUL AND CASUAL ITALIAN
description: DOES New Haven need yet another Italian restaurant? Emphatically yes, when it's as good as Claudio's.

title: Spanish Socialists Slip in Pre-election Surveys
description: Two weeks ago, the Socialists were overwhelming favorites to retain their hold on city halls and regional governments in local elections next Wednesday.

title: A WALK IN THE WEST COUNTRY
description: Sheltered by flowering hedgerows, we felt the June sun beat warmly on our backs. As my husband and I turned and twisted along a narrow path, we could hear bees buzzing among the tangled gorse, dog roses and red campion above our heads. Teased by a tang of salt air, we tried to guess how far ahead lay the open sea, but gaps in the thick hedge only showed us rolling meadows and scattered sheep.

title: HARVARD TOPS YALE
description: Harvard's varsity heavyweight crew had to wait until dusk this evening to test their rowing skills against Yale. But after a two-hour postponement because of high winds, the Crimson won in decisive fashion, by 32.9 seconds, or eight boat-lengths, in the traditional 4-mile race.

title: The Lessons of the Marshall Plan
description: LEAD: NOT long after World War II, Charles Kindleberger overheard two Government drivers chatting in a State Department washroom. ''I was up all night working on the Marshall Plan,'' one driver proudly told the other. To Mr. Kindleberger, an economist who was himself working on the Marshall Plan, the driver's comment illustrated ''a national resolve'' to help rebuild shattered European economies.

title: SUMMER JOBS: MORE OPENINGS, FEWER APPLICANTS AND HIGHER PAY
description: LEAD: WITH record low unemployment and a wealth of help-wanted signs on Long Island, high school and college students should find summer job hunting relatively easy this year, although many may have to settle for less than their first choice, according to labor experts and employers.

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: LEAD: PLANS for a land-emplacement facility to store hazardous waste have suffered at least a temporary setback, a result of the state's Hazardous Waste Facilities Siting Commission's having eliminated from consideration the last of its initial proposed sites.

title: ARGENTINE ARMY, AFTER HALF-CENTURY AS THE POWER, FINDS ITSELF UNDER SIEGE

title: AN ONTARIO TOWN'S ARCHITECTURAL LEGACY
description: When Dickens saw Cobourg in 1842, he thought it a ''cheerful, thriving little town.'' To a visitor in 1987, this town of 15,000 on the northern shore of Lake Ontario still looks cheerful, if not exactly thriving. It has no significant tourist attractions or memories of national prominence, although since Dickens's day it has had two brushes with power and affluence. What it does offer, un-selfconsciously and in a delightfully walkable compass, is a living sampler of practically every style of 19th-century domestic architecture, from workers' cottages to antebellum mansions. There are actually two Cobourgs - one is an unspoiled 19th-century town, and the other, more shadowy, is ''Newport North,'' an American resort in the grand style.

title: CRIME
description: There are some nice things about NOWHERE MAN by Jerry Oster (Harper & Row, $15.95). There also are some exasperating things. In many respects this is a virtuoso piece of work, animated by very bright, sophisticated New York dialogue, some of it quite funny. But the author asks us to believe in some remarkable coincidences. He also can get carried away with his own prose, and at those times the result can be stuffy and overambitious.

title: Parents Charged in Death
description: A 5-year-old boy who the police said was locked in a room and fed bread and water for three months died Friday. His father, George Clarke, and stepmother, Melanie Ann Clarke, were charged with first-degree murder by aggravated child abuse. The youth, George Clarke, was comatose and weighed 22 pounds when his father sought medical help for him Thursday, said a spokesman for the Hillsborough County Sheriff's Department.

title: Hospitals Must Define Policies On Resuscitation
description: As medical advances make it easier to extend the lives of terminally ill patients, doctors have increasingly made use of the do-not-resuscitate order. When patients quit breathing or their hearts stop beating, doctors can often use drugs, electric shocks and mechanical respirators to keep them alive. But if a patient's file is marked ''D.N.R.,'' no extraordinary measures will be taken. In the past, such decisions have often been made informally by physicians. Some hospitals have defined procedures, others do not.

title: IN SEARCH OF AUDIO HEAVEN

Whether these manifestations of technology's power are equally desirable may be debated. Let me merely suggest that any device capable of increasing the decibel level in New York's subways cannot be automatically regarded as a blessing.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: UNDER THE LAKE. By Stuart Woods. (Simon & Schuster, $17.95.) Authors, journalists, greeting-card versifiers and anyone else who writes on deadline might have problems relaxing into this slick supernatural mystery. The hero's writing block would surely give that tribe more anxiety than the apparitions that haunt the lakeside cabin in rural Georgia where he has gone to work on a book. Granted, ghostwriting the autobiography of a chicken-franchise merchant is hack work quite unworthy of John Howell, a Pulitzer Prize-winning reporter, but a job's a job. It's hard for us to concentrate, however, on mysterious lights from under the lake and wan child-ghosts beckoning at the window when we're worrying how the hero is going to meet his deadline. After taking a hefty fee from the chicken-plucker, he scoots into town to drink all day with the boys at Bubba's Cafe and to carry on at night with a sexy undercover colleague. Mr. Woods spins a pretty tale about an unhappy family of Irish immigrant ghosts that keep popping out of the lake to tell their woeful story to the reporter on those rare occasions when he's in residence. But a good ghost story must have the power to tug the reader away from all worldly preoccupations and entice him into a bond of belief with the storyteller - ''meeting me halfway among the primeval shadows'' is how Edith Wharton put it. Mr. Woods, like his hero, is easily distracted. The supernatural sequences are too few and too perfunctory to sustain the suspense, and the ghosts themselves never come alive, so to speak. There is more flesh on the locals, a secretive group of inbred rustics similar to those specimens from ''Chiefs,'' an earlier book by Mr. Woods that was turned into a television mini-series. But we still can't forget the chicken-and-egg man, who will never know how we agonize over the writing of his autobiography.

description: AS the AIDS epidemic spreads through the nation's consciousness, rising public alarm is forcing the issue to the top of the legislative agenda. Acquired immune deficiency syndrome has become not only a devastating medical problem but an increasingly political one as well. Leaders from both parties are beginning to confront the difficult public-policy implications of the disease, which they predict will be a pressing concern during the remainder of the 100th Congress and next year's election campaigns.

In many parts of the world, admirers of Joyce celebrate June 16 as Bloomsday, and many go to Dublin to retrace Bloom's steps.

title: A 5-DAY HIKE IN THE VALAIS OF SWITZERLAND
description: The Valais is a region of soaring beauty. Visible from its trails are Switzerland's highest mountains and two of Europe's most formidable peaks, Mont Blanc and the Matterhorn. But for ordinary hikers the lure is the series of north-south valleys forged by the tributaries of the Rhone. These allow access to gentler summits and scenic treks from village to village in a single day.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Harness Racing Jate Lobell First: Jate Lobell avenged his only defeat by easily beating Run The Table in last night's New Jersey Classic for 3-year-old pacers at the Meadowlands in East Rutherford, N.J. Jate Lobell took command after the half-mile and stretched his lead to finish 6 1/2 lengths ahead of Run The Table, covering the mile in 1:51 2/5. The time was one-fifth of a second faster than his previous best. Driven by Mark O'Mara, Jate Lobell paid $2.80 for $2 to win. Nuklear Weapon was nine lengths in back of Run The Table in third. Jate Lobell, owned by Joe M. McCluskey of Battle Creek, Mich., and the Kentuckiana Farms of Kentucky, earned $250,000. (AP) Track and Field School Athletes Compete: Joe Galeano, Shola Lynch and Rich Thompson shared the spotlight yesterday in the New York State boys and girls championships at Baldwinsville. Galeano, a senior at Centereach (L.I.) High School, set a state automatic time record of 13.46 seconds in the 110-meter high hurdles and won the high jump at 6 feet 11 inches, the state's leading height this season. Lynch, of Hunter College High School in Manhattan, won the 800-meter run in 2 minutes 11.3 seconds and the 1,500-meter run in 4:31.7. Thompson of Woodlands won the long jump Friday with a leap of 24 feet 5 3/4 inches, the best in the state this year. Yesterday, he was first in the triple jump at 48-7 and ran second leg on the winning Woodlands 400-meter relay. Record in 400 Meters: Diane Dixon of the Atoms Track Club set a meet record of 51.3 seconds in winning the 400-meter run in the Metropolitan Athletics Congress championships at Downing Stadium, Randalls Island. Dixon also finished second in the 200-meter dash won by teammate Grace Jackson in 22.81. Jackson won the 100 in 11.5 for the only double victory of the meet. Boating Accidents Mar Race: Three men were hospitalized yesteday after their 24-foot powerboats flipped over on the choppy waters of Lake Ponchartrain during the Popeyes Offshore Grand Prix in New Orleans. The race was abruptly canceled a short while later because of hazardous lake conditions. Injured were Byron Hill of Fort Myers Beach, Fla., driving Panama Jack; John D. D'Elia Jr. and Brad Cox, both of Cos Cob, Conn., both aboard Breakaway. Hill was in stable condition at Humana Hospital with chest and abdominal injuries. D'Elia was in stable condition at Charity Hospital with possible abdominal injuires and a possible fractured shoulder. Cox was in good condition at Charity. (AP) Tennis Edberg Wins Grass Title: Stefan Edberg of Sweden, playing in a swirling wind, beat an American, Kevin Curren, 6-3, 6-4, to win the men's singles title yesterday at the Holiday Inn Northern grasscourt championships in Manchester, England. Edberg broke Curren's serve in the fourth game of the first set and the third game of the second. (AP) Golf Mayo Edges Former Champion: Paul Mayo ended Peter McEvoy's hopes of winning the British Amateur title for a third time, winning by 3 and 1 over two rounds at the Prestwick course yesterday in Prestwick, Scotland. Mayo, 24 years old, beat Len Mattiace of the United States in the semifinal Friday in a match that ended in gathering darkness on the fourth extra hole.(AP) Auto Racing Rahal is winner: Bobby Rahal slipped past Michael Andretti nine laps from the end and went on to win yesterday in the second round of the International Race of Champions in Lexington, Ohio. Rahal started fifth in the field of 12 identically prepared Chevrolet Z-28 Camaros at Mid-Ohio Sports Car Course and worked his way to the front in the 29-lap event, which has 2.4 miles per lap. He averaged 85.702 miles an hour for 69.6 miles. Wally Dallenbach finished second, and Andretti was third.(AP) Baseball Stanford wins semifinal: At Omaha yesterday, Al Osuna of Stanford pitched eight and two-thirds innings of scoreless relief as the Cardinal beat Texas, 9-3, in a College World Series semifinal game. Stanford (52-17) meets Oklahoma State (59-12) in the championship game today. The Cowboys beat Stanford, 6-2, in the winners bracket final Thursday to earn an automatic berth in the championship game. Texas (61-11) took a 3-0 lead in the top of the first off the starter, Lee Plemel, who gave up four hits and pitche to only five batters. Osuna (9-2) came on to scatter nine hits and strike out eight. (AP).

title:

description: SEARCH SWEET COUNTRY. By B. Kojo Laing. (Beech Tree/Morrow, $18.95.)

title: Ann Biester Is Married to Gary Deane
description: Ann Meredith Biester, the daughter of Judge and Mrs. Edward G. Biester Jr. of Furlong, Pa., was married last evening to Gary Kenneth Deane, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Maurice A. Deane of Kings Point, L.I., at her parents' home by Rabbi Robert Alper. Joan Foster Gamble was the matron of honor, and Dr. Leland Marc Deane was his brother's best man.

title: STUDENT RAID ON CORPORATIONS
description: LIKE plagues of locusts, student interns descend on corporate America during academia's vacations - summer, Christmas and spring. At best they are a highly visible nuisance; at worst they impede productivity and depress morale.

title: More Bad News For PTL Ministry
description: The Rev. Jerry Falwell announced last week that the PTL ministry's ''May Emergency'' had become a ''May Miracle.'' Under Mr. Falwell's stewardship, the debt-ridden evangelical organization had collected $8.5 million in donations, enough to keep it alive, at least temporarily.

title: TRAGEDY STILL SHAPES MOOD OF BRIDGEPORT
description: LEAD: MORE than a month after the last body was recovered from the rubble of the L'Ambiance Plaza apartment complex in Bridgeport, William McKiernan stared at a memorial to the 28 construction workers who died in the collapse and relived the tragedy.

title: Barbara A. Woike Marries Jerry Yulsman, a Novelist
description: Barbara Ann Woike, a picture editor for The Associated Press in New York, and Jerome Quincy Yulsman, a novelist, were married yesterday at their home in Brooklyn. The Rev. Barbara Hebner, a Unitarian minister, officiated.

title: 'Summer Evenings' Series Warming Up
description: SUMMER Evenings at Sarah Lawrence College, the consistently high-level series, is about to begin its 12th year of bridging the concert gap from the end of the spring season to the beginning of the summer festivals. Big man on campus this time is Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart. Three programs are devoted entirely to his music, and at least one Mozart work figures in five of the six remaining concerts. The exceptions are a dance and drama pageant re-creating the artistic life at the Versailles Court of Louis XIV and a ''Jazz Jam Session.''

title: Another Point For Thomas
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: GORMLEY OPTIMMISTIC ON 4 SHORE PROJECTS
description: LEAD: THE four major projects designed to help cope with the casino industry's tightened market and meet the city's convention needs will be operating within five years, according to State Senator William L. Gormley.

title: HOME VIDEO: MOVIES
description: Bandolero! Starring James Stewart, Dean Martin, Raquel Welch, George Kennedy. Directed by Andrew V. McLaglen. 1968. Playhouse Video. 106 minutes. $19.98.

title: WIESEL: OF HOPE AND THE ABYSS
description: LEAD: On Wednesday, the 92d Street Y will stage a benefit gala, starting at 8:15 P.M., for the Y's arts programs. The gala, at which such artists as the cellist Yo-Yo Ma, the pianist Joseph Kalichstein and the soprano Dawn Upshaw will perform, will have as a centerpiece a cantata, ''A Song For Hope,'' commissioned by the Y for the occasion from the composer David Diamond, with text by the Nobel Peace Prize laureate Elie Wiesel.

title: HEAT WAVE PUTS POWER TO THE TEST
description: LEAD: IN the first test of the hot-weather season, the imported and domestic electrical supply that powers Long Island met rising demand during sultry weather Monday without voltage reductions or depleted reserve margins.

title: STRAWBERRIES ROT IN OREGON'S FIELDS
description: Up to a third of Oregon's strawberry crop may rot in the fields because the fruit is ripening early and a new immigration law has discouraged Mexican workers from coming here, officials and workers say.

title: ISRAELI COALITION SHAKES BUT DOESN'T BREAK
description: HOW much longer can it go on like this? That is the question asked most frequently in Israel about the country's ''national unity'' Government.

title: Comings and Goings
description: THE honorary team captains for the All-Star Game July 14 will be a pair of newly elected members of the Baseball Hall of Fame - Billy Williams, a former Chicago Cub slugger, and Jim (Catfish) Hunter, a former pitcher for the Oakland A's and the Yankees. . . . Perry Turnbull, who started his career with the St. Louis Blues, will be returning next season as the result of a trade with the Winnipeg Jets, who are getting a draft choice in exchange. . . . Jan Stephenson, who has been off the women's golf tour since suffering an injury in an automobile accident May 2, has entered the Mayflower Classic in Indianapolis this week.

title: Wichita Falls Fall, With Niagara Help
description: The original falls were washed away more than 100 years ago, but town officials have made an honest city of Wichita Falls with the grand opening of a $400,000 man-made waterfall.

title: Reagan's Band Of True Believers
description: Frances FitzGerald's contention that Frank Carlucci heralds a change to come at the National Security Council is dubious.

title: BEDFORD-STUYVESANT RENEWAL: A SPURT IN THE LOCAL ECONOMY
description: Two decades after the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn was rocked by riots, litter-strewn streets, ramshackle tenements and street corners crowded with drug dealers are still common.

title: A LAWYER COURTS BEST-SELLERDOM
description: AT A TIME WHEN YOU might think he'd be excited, enjoying the fruit of his labor, Scott Turow, in fact, feels a bit harassed. His first novel, ''Presumed Innocent,'' which took him more than six years to write, won't appear until July 15, but already the interview requests are piling up and friends are making uncomfortable jokes about the money the book has earned. Then, too, with much of the hoopla having occurred during the last, difficult days of a pregnancy, his wife is ready to clobber him.

title: PROGRAM BECOMES COMMUNITY EFFORT
description: LEAD: BY INVOLVING employers, neighbors, relatives, nonprofit agencies, sports groups and alcohol- and drug-treatment programs, the state's Intensive Supervision Program (I.S.P.) has become a community, rather than strictly correctional, effort.

title: Diane Isenberg Is Married To David Freeman in Wales
description: Diane Susan Isenberg and David Hugh Freeman were married yesterday in the registry office in Llanbrynmair, Wales. The couple's parents are Mr. and Mrs. Eugene M. Isenberg of Palm Beach, Fla., and Oak Bluffs, Mass., and Maj. and Mrs. Denis Freeman of Welshpool, Wales.

title: Lebanese Leader Is Assassinated
description: Since the civil war began in Lebanon 12 years ago, most of the 100,000 people killed have been ordinary civilians caught in a crossfire of rockets and machine gun bullets, or members of the militias that pursue the war. Only rarely have prominent Lebanese been victims.

title: PATERSON CATHEDRAL BEING RENOVATED
description: LEAD: THIS city's skyline-piercing Cathedral of St. John the Baptist was closed last week for a six-month restoration and renovation.

description: HOUSE 1. Persian Gulf: Vote on a resolution calling on the Reagan Administration to explain in more detail how it plans to protect United States interests in the Persian Gulf. Approved 302 to 105, June 2. 2.Fairness Doctrine: Vote on a bill opposed by the Reagan Administration that directs the Federal Communications Commission to continue enforcing the ''fairness doctrine'' requiring broadcasters to cover community issues and present differing views on controversial topics. title: Priscilla Hite Jennings Marries Neil Pultz Jr.
description: The marriage of Priscilla Hite Jennings, a daughter of Mrs. William Mitchell Jennings of Greenwich, Conn., and the late Mr. Jennings, to Neil V. Pultz Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Pultz of Greenwich, took place yesterday at the Rye (N.Y.) Presbyterian Church. The Rev. David Uhl, assisted by the Rev. Joseph C. Bishop, performed the ceremony.

title: Lisa Hutchings Is Married in Bermuda
description: Lisa Hutchings, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. C. H. Ford Hutchings of Tucker's Town, Bermuda, and New York, was married yesterday to Richard Carlyle Darrell Cox, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Carlyle Darrell Cox of Devonshire, Bermuda. The Rev. Fredrick W. Marshall performed the ceremony at Christ Presbyterian Church in Warwick, Bermuda.

title: Do You Like All the Home Runs This Years
description: You can pack 'em tighter, you can make the players stronger, you can move in the fences, and you can decrease wind resistance, but pitchers are always the barometer of home runs. Bret Saberhagen, Roger Clemens, and the virtual handful of excellent starting pitchers in baseball today are surrendering no more long balls than they ever did. So what we are faced with is just as much ''all the mediocre pitchers'' as ''all the home runs.'' It's just as easy to be discouraged at the dearth of dependable moundsmen as it is to take pleasure in the predominance of power. ANDREW SIFF Bronx

title: 'PLATOON' RAISING VETERANS' ANXIETIES
description: LEAD: ALTHOUGH the Veterans Administration and the Vietnam Veterans of America are often at odds, both agree that the Academy Award film ''Platoon'' has become a cultural phenomenon and may be behind a recent increase in stress among Vietnam veterans.

title: TRUE CONFESSION
description: ONE OF THE SUREST paths to literary renown these days is confession, coming out of the closet, baring the soul. Were you a Communist at Oxford? An undercover man for the F.B.I.? A morose parent? A Mondale supporter? Did you once float junk bonds? Get it down on paper. Don't leave out a thing. Riches and talk shows lie ahead.

title: VERMONT TRADITION, FROM SOUP TO NUTS
description: More than a century ago, Frank Henry Gillingham of Woodstock, Vt., aged 26 and known to all as F. H., bought out the dry goods store where he had clerked since high school. An enterprising young merchant who believed in ''large sales for small profit for prompt pay,'' F. H. began to stock all the necessities of life - ''vittles and sundry delicacies'' - along with tools for workshops, barns, gardens and fields for the village and surrounding farms.

title: Doing a Deal: Atrium on 45th
description: In a couple of years, the highlight of 45th Street between Avenue of the Americas and Seventh Avenue will most likely be an outdoor atrium -filled with cedar trees and illuminated at night - that will soar 15 stories alongside a 40-story office tower now under construction there.

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''Paul Volcker was the world's greatest financial crisis manager. Greenspan is going to be a rookie at that, so there has to be some uncertainty about how adroit he will be when the next crisis comes.''

title: Big Hit in Japan
description: UP until this season Japanese baseball's appeal to American players has been chiefly as a chance for aging former major leaguers to extend their careers. From now on, however, don't be surprised if teams in Japan start bidding for free agents at the peak of their careers. If so, give the credit or the blame to Bob Horner, a former Atlanta Braves infielder, and the major league owners who declined to make serious offers for his services when he became a free agent this year.

title: Fan's Fondness
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: A Botha Foray Across Color Line
description: It would be against his principles to live there, but President P. W. Botha of South Africa found the bleak township of Sharpeville not a bad place to visit last week. On Mr. Botha's first appearance in a major black area since 1978, Mayor Esau Mahlatsi made him an honorary citizen and about 1,000 children applauded the President and seven Cabinet Ministers before they helicoptered away from the place that has been a symbol of the struggle against apartheid since the police killed 69 black protesters there in 1960. ''It was a wonderful experience,'' said the Minister of Law and Order, Adriaan J. Vlok. ''How can they receive us like this?''

title: KUDOS FOR A COUP AND AN INVENTOR
description: IT is hard to conceive that anyone could be the world's best at two demanding intellectual activities. Such a claim can made for Alexandre Louis Honore Lebreton Deschapelles, a Frenchman born just before his country's Revolution. As a young man he was probably the world's best chessplayer but abandoned the game when outstripped by one of his students.

title: Reagan's Band Of True Believers
description: The words ''radical'' and ''anarchic'' are used repeatedly in Frances FitzGerald's article to describe Oliver North and the contragate scammers. As a member of America's oldest anarchist organization, I protest this sloppy use of language. The corruption of Government officials who are willing and eager to break the law for their own ends, and for the purpose of violent oppression, should not be linguistically confused with the goal of freedom from all government and oppression, which is the goal of anarchism. PETER CRANSTON The Libertarian Book Club New York City

title: TOWNS WANT MORE MONEY FOR BRIDGES
description: THE state is making $20 million available for public-works repairs beginning July 1, but town officials say their bridges are falling apart and they need more.

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption on page 24 of the Arts and Leisure section today and a film listing in the Arts and Leisure Guide give an incorrect opening date for ''The Believers.'' It opens Wednesday at the Orpheum, 84th Street Six, 23d Street West Triplex, National, Manhattan Twin and Bay Cinema.

title: A SPECIAL GRADUATION
description: LEAD: IT was not your usual graduation ceremony. Dr. Joseph N. Hankin, president of Westchester Community College, gave a bilingual welcoming address. The music of Scott Joplin and a spiritual replaced the usual ''Pomp and Circumstance.'' Crying infants and the voices of small children often competed with the speakers.

title: LINDSAY EASTHAM WEDS IN VIRGINIA
description: The marriage of Lindsay Eastham, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Edwin M. Eastham of Front Royal, Va., to Robert Grant Kielley, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James E. Kielley of New Canaan, Conn., and Nantucket, Mass., took place yesterday in Front Royal. The Rev. John P. Oliver, a Baptist minister, performed the ceremony in Boggs Chapel at Randolph-Macon Academy.

title: Going On in the Northeast
description: LANCASTER MUSEUM BENEFIT

title: FINDING NEW BOTTLES FOR MOZART'S OLD WINE
description: CONDUCTORS INTENT ON recording the Mozart symphonies face a daunting task - finding new things to say about works that have been amply explored on disk -yet the flow of new releases seems both constant and voluminous. Musicologists, of course, with their frequent reinterpretations and shifts in attitude, have made the task a bit easier by providing a number of alternative approaches for conductors to try. Meanwhile, the current taste for early-instruments performances has opened not only a new (and still only sparsely tapped) corner of the market, but, more importantly, an array of new interpretive possibilities that both early- and modern-instrument players can adopt. The miraculous thing about this prismatic music, though, is that despite the frequency with which it is played and recorded, it continues to yield new facets to insightful and inventive performers.

title: TO FLOAT WITH, A MONSTER OF A TOY
description: IN the beginning, or about five summers ago, there were alligators: huge inflatable water toys that seemed to be the right catch for every fashionable swimming pool. Then the sea dragons surfaced to become one of last year's best sellers in the inflatable animal sweepstakes. ''But the Locmess is this year's fantasy float,'' said Ed Curran, a manager for the Penny Whistle toy shops, which were among the first to tout the blow-up beasts.

title: Dynasties That Drive Commerce
description: WHEN Eleonora Gardini and Giuseppe Cipriani announced their engagement in Venice recently, Italian newspapers hardly knew whether to print the news on the social or the financial page.

title: 'MARRY ME A LITTLE' IN STAMFORD
description: FORMULA for an instant musical hit:

title: It Was Time to Send the Sitter Home
description: PAUL VOLCKER is a national hero - a genuine one, not the Ollie North variety. But all in all, it's a good thing he's going away.

title: KIND TO THE TASTE BUDS AND BUDGET
description: CAN a flourishing Chinese restaurant in Great Neck also flower in Smithtown?

title: Do You Like All the Home Runs This Years
description: You know something's up when Rafael Santana already has two home runs this year. Well, whether it's tighter-wound baseballs or greater strength in the major leagues, suddenly anyone has a chance to shine. Baseball is a game where the most obscure player can take the field or come to bat and return home a hero.
