If a few of these excess home runs give new and aspiring or old and struggling players a shimmering hope of being today's hero, then let's just stand up and continue to applaud. LEWIS J. KASS Brooklyn

title: BUSINESS FORUM: SOUTH AFRICA: SULLIVAN CALLS FOR A PULLOUT
description: The Principles Still Offer the Best Hope

title:
GARDENING;
A TIME FOR GROWTH AND PROPER CARE
description: LEAD: WITH the growing season well under way, early gardening efforts should have begun to yield dividends. New plantings should be taking hold, the result of fertilizer applications should be evident, and early vegetables should be ready to harvest.

title: DUCK: DIFFICULT BUT WORTH THE EFFORT
description: ROAST duck challenges the cook. As delicious as a succulent, properly roasted Long Island duckling can be, with its moist, rich flesh and crisp skin, achieving this result takes care and patience. And it is no easier for restaurants than it is for home cooks.

title: 'BROWN TIDE' THAT KILLED SCALLOPS IS ALL BUT GONE FROM BAYS ON L.I.
description: The tiny marine organisms that made up the ''brown tide,'' blamed for destroying most of the native scallops in the bays of Eastern Long Island, have all but disappeared, a marine biologist said today.

title: Dr. Sara F. Sutherland Married in Wilmington
description: Dr. Sara Faill Sutherland and Dr. Robert Eugene O'Connor were married yesterday at the Westminster Presbyterian Church in Wilmington, Del., by the Rev. James R. Bennett 3d.

title: A GEORGIA PORT WITH A ROYAL PAST
description: Most Florida-bound travelers heading down Interstate 95 usually regard Brunswick, Ga., as nothing more than the last overnight stop before crossing the border into the promised land. Yet, it is considerably more than that. In addition to being the gateway to three of the romantically described ''Golden Isles'' of Georgia, Brunswick has a legitimate claim to historic recognition.

title: Earth Sciences, Up Close and Firsthand
description: THEY battled the bugs, balanced themselves on rocks in the streams and cleared away the branches of trees - all to get accurate readings on the elevations of the land for their topographic maps.

title: TRUE BELIEVERS WHO KEEP THE FLAME OF PAINTING
description: THE 40TH BIENNIAL EXHIBI-tion of Contemporary American Painting at the Corcoran Gallery of Art is a cogent argument not only for abstract painting but also for the continuing vitality of a late modernist esthetic. It brings together 13 artists between 37 and 51 years old. All live or have lived in New York City. All are long-distance runners. The biennial is - of all things - a large museum group show of contemporary art that has nothing to do with trash, camp or kitsch.

title: HOSPITAL IS PUZZLED BY POWER FAILURE
description: Officials at New York Hospital said yesterday that they were still at a loss to explain the exact cause of a 22-minute power failure early Friday that led to the death of a critically ill 40-day-old boy on a respirator.

title: IN THE NATURAL STATE
description: LEAD: I NOSED my car into the parking area and claimed a space near the gate. I could have had a place just about anywhere, for there was only one other car in the lot designed for 20.

title: Q and A
description: Loss of a Laundry Lease Question: I own a coin laundry in Queens and the lease on the space I have for this business expires in a few years. My landlord says he does not want to renew my lease and I believe that it is his intention to take over my business. I have heard that there is a law that would keep him from opening the same business as mine for a period of two years if he refuses to renew my lease. Is this true? A. M., Queens Answer: No. There are no city or state laws that would keep your landlord from opening a coin laundry of his own or renting the space to another operator.

title: TAKING SPEECH TO ITS LIMITS
description: ''THE JOY OR THE HORRI-ble - the extremes -'' the director Joseph Chaikin gropes for words to explain what lies beneath the wild non sequiturs in ''The Bald Soprano.'' Navigating in rehearsal through Eugene Ionesco's comic ''anti-play'' of charged, disconnected phrases, the actors pick out signposts from the director's own charged, disconnected phrases. They ask Mr. Chaikin and the associate director, Nancy Gabor, for clarification, then try the scene again. This perplexing rehearsal process is not an avant-garde attempt to replicate the characters' communications havoc (though Mr. Chaikin has long been known for unconventional directing methods). It is simply the company's working adaptation to Mr. Chaikin's aphasia. Three years ago, a severe stroke shattered his ability to speak.

title: Going Gentle On My Mind
description: IT IS MORE THAN PASS-ing strange to me,'' Robert C. McFarlane told the Iran-contra investigating committee, ''that we cannot aspire to a policy which is more effective to deal with terrorism.''

title: Honeywell Shifts Group
description: Honeywell Inc., the computer company that last year bought the aerospace group of the Unisys Corporation for $1 billion, said on Friday that it had restructured its aerospace and military operations. Unisys's aerospace group was owned by the former Sperry Corporation, which one year ago merged with the Burroughs Corporation to create Unisys.

title: FIRE ISLAND PINES IN AGE OF AIDS
description: It's 8 P.M. and time for tea.

title: POOLEY READY FOR WESTCHESTER
description: Now that his first victory in seven years has taken some of the pressure off him, Don Pooley wants to erase a label that has been pinned on him.

title: LABOR STRIFE GROWS FOR G.M. IN SPAIN
description: In front of the General Motors assembly plant here, workers and visitors are greeted by ''Encuentro,'' Pablo Serrano's impressionistic sculpture depicting two figures of polished metal. The artwork symbolizes the modern industrial environment that lies within.

title: BLUEFISH ABOUND IN A MOST UNLIKELY PLACE
description: THE more one angles, the more one is reminded that patterns of fish behavior observed over decades are just that and nothing more, that one's unthinking quarry is not bedeviled by a yearning for consistency.

title: Mattel Cuts Some Staff
description: Mattel Inc., the financially troubled toy maker, has laid off 65 administrative employees and seven executives in a move intended to streamline the company and cut costs, a corporate spokesman said on Friday. The recent departure of Thomas J. Kalinske as president was not related to the cutbacks, said Spencer Boise, a vice president. Mr. Boise refused to identify the officers dismissed but said they were vice presidents or higher.

title: Not Manila-Bound Yet
description: When Secretary of State George P. Shultz arrives in Manila on June 14, one man who will be conspicuous by his absence is Nicholas Platt, the Administration's choice for the next American Ambassador to the Philippines. State Department officials say Jesse Helms, the Senate Foreign Relations Committee's senior Republican, has held up Mr. Platt's appointment.

title: Let a U.N. Task Force Guard the Persian Gulf; Why U.S. Protection?
description: To the Editor:

title: A DEAF DANCE STUDENT TAKES A LEADING ROLE
description: Onstage at the Felt Forum, hundreds of children bobbed up and down, poking one another's ribs. Portraying humans and fairies, squirrels, bees and plants, they were two days away from performing in the National Dance Institute's Event of the Year, and it was a nervous time - their first rehearsal on the big stage.

title: NO ROOM AT THE Y: CITES LOSE AN OLD WAY STATION
description: Come the end of June, the Central Y.M.C.A. in downtown Little Rock will close the last of its aging residential rooms, 35 worn cubicles with narrow iron beds and the bathroom down the hall.

title: Fire Kills 3 Children
description: Three children trapped on the second floor of a row house died in a fire today, and a 35-year-old man who had been barred from the home by his estranged wife was arrested and charged with homicide and arson. The accused, Rodney Ray Robinson, set the fire with a flammable liquid, according to the police.

title: Market Place; Contrary View Often Profitable
description: IT often pays to take a contrarian view, Bailard, Biehl & Kaiser Inc. of San Mateo, Calif., believes. The investment management firm started buying foreign stocks in 1979 and it concentrated on bonds in the spring of 1982, suddenly emphasizing a sector that had proven a disappointment for years. Both moves turned out to be profitable for clients of the firm, which emphasizes asset allocation.

title: Elizabeth Sovern Becomes a Bride
description: Elizabeth Anne Sovern, a daughter of Michael I. Sovern of New York and Lenore Sanders of Huntington Beach, Calif., was married yesterday to Raymond Ernest Conley, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Conley of Clay, N.Y. Acting Justice Rena K. Uviller of State Supreme Court officiated at Will-o-Woods, a private estate in Croton-on-Hudson, N.Y.

title: The Kinds of Americans Involved in Nicaragua
description: To the Editor:

title: OVERHAUL OF TARIFFS EXPECTED
description: After more than a quarter-century the tariff schedules of the United States are about to be revamped and updated.

title: 3 Agencies Are Given New Assignments
description: BBDO International, Scali, McCabe, Sloves and Geers, Gross Advertising all announced new assignments on Friday, from show biz to household paper products to credit cards.

title: ENTER DANFORTH, WITH TOUGH QUESTIONS
description: In one dramatic moment two weeks ago, Senator John C. Danforth thrust himself into the middle of the first full-fledged debate of AIDS in the Senate.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: Making the Grade

title: Driesell Reflects
description: Almost a year after the University of Maryland basketball star, Len Bias, died of cocaine intoxication, Lefty Driesell, the former Terrapin coach, is still having trouble reconciling himself to the tragedy.

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption on Saturday with the text of Albert Hakim's testimony at the Iran-contra hearing misidentified the panel member pictured conferring with an aide. It was Representative Edward P. Boland.

title: TAUNTS AND CHEERS FOR KLAN AS 150 RALLY IN GREENSBORO
description: About 150 Ku Klux Klan members in hoods and robes were taunted and welcomed as they marched through the streets of downtown Greensboro in their first public rally here since a 1979 demonstration that left five people dead.

title: Dr. Ellen Gloskin Marries
description: Dr. Ellen Gloskin, a dentist in West Haven, Conn., and Peter Cohen, a woodworker for the Breakfast Woodworks in Branford, Conn., were married yesterday at the Westbury (L.I.) Manor. Rabbi Albert Thaler officiated. The bride, a graduate of Queens College of the City University of New York and the New York University School of Dentistry, is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Morris Gloskin of Flushing, Queens. Mr. Cohen, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Elias S. Cohen of Carroll Park, Pa., graduated from the California Institute of Fine Arts and the Leeds Design Workshops in Easthampton, Mass.

title: SLUGGERS' RETURN IMPROVES HEALTH OF THEIR TEAMS
description: THE names of Jeff Leonard, Pedro Guerrero and Jack Clark appear often among the leaders in virtually every offensive category in the National League. For much of last season, those names appeared nowhere at all. For much of last season, those players were lost to their teams: Leonard for the last two months with an injured right wrist, Guerrero for all but 31 games with a knee injury, Clark for more than three months with a thumb injury.

title: 'La Sylphide' Changes
description: Because the ballerina Alessandra Ferri is ill, American Ballet Theater's performance of ''La Sylphide'' at the Metropolitan Opera House on Wednesday at 2 P.M. will be danced by Cheryl Yeager and Julio Bocca. Miss Ferri had been scheduled to dance with Patrick Bissell.

title: Yachts Are Maxi, In Size and in Cost
description: The push for sponsorship in yachting is making vast inroads in sailboat racing worldwide. But competition in maxi yachts is unmarked by corporate footprints, and for a reason: Most owners of maxis don't want or need outside help.

title: COURT MERGER SEEN AS DEAD IN LEGISLATURE
description: A plan to merge all of New York State's trial courts - a major initiative of Governor Cuomo and the state's Chief Judge - is almost certainly dead for this legislative session, according to key Democratic and Republican legislators.

title: Daniele Menache Weds Mark Gompertz in Capital
description: Daniele Menache and Mark Alan Gompertz were married yesterday at the Watergate Hotel in Washington by Rabbi Rolando Matlon. The bride is a daughter of Mrs. Marc A. Jacobson of Chevy Chase, Md. The bridegroom is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Gompertz of Forest Hills, Queens.

title: The Legacy of Libby Zion
description: After his 18-year-old daughter Libby died at New York Hospital in 1984, Sidney Zion, a writer and lawyer, started a campaign. Libby might have lived, he thought, had she not been left in the care of inexperienced medical residents and interns. He pressed for criminal prosecution but a Manhattan grand jury refused to indict. Now Mr. Zion can count satisfaction of a more constructive sort.

title: GREENSPAN'S SPECIAL TALENTS
description: Over the years, Alan Greenspan decided that his most marketable property was himself.

title: Pet Garbage
description: To the Editor:

title: Hyatt, Delta Link Is Set
description: The Hyatt Hotels Corporation and Delta Air Lines Inc. said on Friday they had linked their frequent-traveler programs, called Hyatt Gold Passport and Delta Frequent Flyer. Under the partnership, members of Hyatt's frequent-traveler program who fly Delta can present their airplane boarding passes upon check-in at Hyatt hotels and receive 25 percent bonuses on points earned toward Hyatt awards.

title: SCRAMBLED BELMONT RAISES QUESTIONS
description: Only 4 3/4 lengths separated the first seven finishers in the Kentucky Derby May 2, but when six of them met again in the Belmont Stakes Saturday, the spread was 34 3/4 lengths, and the order of finish was scrambled. How did Bet Twice win so easily, why did Alysheba run so poorly, and what happened to the supporting cast that had kept the first two legs of the Triple Crown so close?

title: ALBERT WIGGIN SELDEN, 64, THEATER PRODUCER
description: Albert Wiggin Selden, who co-produced ''Man of La Mancha,'' one of Broadway's biggest hits, died of cancer Saturday at his home in Santa Fe, N.M. He was 64 years old and and lived in Manhattan until moving to New Mexico three years ago.

title: AT THE FRONT IN IRAQ: HEAT, HAZE AND THE THREAT OF HUMAN WAVES
description: Dug in along a 400-foot-high ridge overlooking a no man's land of marshes, Iraq holds the high ground along this section of its battlefront with Iran.

title: HUNDREDS IN ROCKLAND BACK DOCTOR ACCUSING HOSPITAL OF RACISM
description: Hundreds of Rockland County residents have rallied around a cardiologist who says Nyack Hospital suspended his specialty surgical privileges because of racism and a personal vendetta.

title: Kuwait Asks China to Join in Protecting Shipping
description: Kuwait has asked China to join the United States and the Soviet Union in helping protect Kuwaiti oil shipping from Iranian attacks in the Persian Gulf, a senior Foreign Ministry official said today.

title: Addendum
description: * Wunderman, Ricotta & Kline, a Young & Rubicam direct-marketing company, has changed its name to Wunderman Worldwide.

title: Moet 'Marriage' 2d Best For Leader of Vuitton
description: Some do it right away. Others take their time. But, mostly, when a young man marries into a family with a growing business, his entry into it is prompt, sometimes very prompt.

title: DISABLED MODEL DEFIES SEXUAL STEREOTYPES
description: This is Ellen Stohl, a 23-year-old paraplegic and a college student, on her study of the martial arts: ''I just used it for self-defense. Your most likely attacker is going to be an able-bodied person. You can hit them with your crutch or break their ankles with your wheelchair.''

title: Bascom Timmons, 97, Washington Reporter
description: Bascom N. Timmons, a Washington correspondent who served scores of newspapers over nearly six decades, advised presidents from Calvin Coolidge to Franklin D. Roosevelt, and once sought the Vice Presidency, died today of pneumonia. He was 97 years old.

title: DANCE: SPRING CONCERT
description: IT isn't everyone who can create a dance for young dancers just at the edge of professionalism.

title: GAF Contract Fight Settled
description: An arbitration panel has awarded $2.9 million to the estate of Jesse Werner, former chairman of the GAF Corporation, ending a three-year dispute over an employment agreement.

title: Iranian Says Teheran Arranged Stark Attack
description: An official of Iran's Revolutionary Guard said today that the Iraqi pilot who attacked the American frigate Stark was acting on instructions from Teheran.

title: ATHEIST PREACHES GLASNOST, SO A PRIEST HAS HOPE
description: The Rev. Gleb Yakunin, who was stripped of his priestly office, imprisoned and exiled to Siberia for protesting limits on religious freedom in the Soviet Union, has been reinstated by the Russian Orthodox Church in a move that promises to test the state of religious freedom under Mikhail S. Gorbachev.

title: Fond Memories
description: Bob Giegengack, who died last month at age 80, coached track and field for eight years at Brooklyn Prep, eight years at Fordham and 29 years at Yale. He was sometimes droll, sometimes flippant, always erudite.

title: SCIENCE DEBATES USING TOOLS TO REDESIGN LIFE
description: Genetic engineering, the most powerful and precise biological tool for manipulating life ever devised, has reached a milestone.

title: Chief Adds a Post In Gulf States Shift
description: E. Linn Draper, president, chief executive and vice chairman of the Gulf States Utilities Company, has been named to the additional post of chairman, according to a company announcement.

title: LEADERS CAN (AND SOMETIMES DO) ACHIEVE TANGIBLE RESULTS, BUT CHANGE IS OFTEN SLOW
description: The heads of seven governments, accompanied by 2,300 journalists and entourages of ministers and aides, are assembling here to attend the 13th annual economic summit conference Monday through Wednesday. This one, more than most, will start with unusually modest prospects, and raises the question of why anyone bothers.

title: HEALTH EXPERTS FIND NO EVIDENCE TO LINK AIDS TO KISSING
description: No evidence exists that the AIDS virus can spread through tears, saliva and normal kissing, the World Health Organization said today in an attempt to calm persisting anxieties that the virus can be spread by casual contact.

title: WOMEN AND THE COURTS: SLOW PROGRESS ON BAIS
description: Vowing that a monumental report on the status of women in the New York court system would not be relegated to a shelf to collect dust, more than 300 women and supporters of their rights gathered Saturday to assess the progress made since the report was issued, and to look ahead.

title: MURDERER EXECUTED IN LOUISIANA
description: A high school dropout condemned for murdering a guard in a bank robbery was put to death early today in the Louisiana electric chair.

title: DAWSON IS LEADING CUBS AND LEAGUE
description: LEAD: SHORTLY before his last time at bat in a game against the Houston Astros here last week, Andre Dawson of the Chicago Cubs was approached by his hitting coach, Billy Williams. Williams's purpose was not to change anything his pupil was doing. Dawson had slugged two home runs the previous day and on this afternoon had already hit a single, a triple and a homer.

title: KITE WINS KEMPER ON FINAL-ROUND
description: Tom Kite overcame a lackluster front nine to shoot a two-under-par 69 today to win the Kemper Open by seven strokes.

title: BALLET THEATER: 'ETUDES,' BY 2 CASTS
description: AN interesting phenomenon occurred Saturday when American Ballet Theater presented Harald Lander's ''Etudes'' with different casts in the afternoon and evening performances. There was nothing wrong with the work of the more experienced dancers who performed the ballet in the afternoon. But in the evening, ''Etudes'' received a memorably sparkling and triumphant performance.

title: VATICAN FINDS POLISH REGIME EAGER FOR THIS VISIT BY POPE
description: Vatican officials say organizing Pope John Paul II's visit to Poland has been easy - in fact, almost too easy.

title: Norway's Foreign Aid
description: Norway provided more foreign aid to developing countries as a percentage of its gross national product than any other Western industrialized nation, a Foreign Aid Ministry spokeman said Friday. He added that Norway gave almost six billion crowns, or $900 million - 1.16 percent of its total of goods and services - in aid last year to United Nations bodies, the World Bank and other organizations.

title: INVESTIGATING A LEGEND: FRANCHISE HEAD'S REIGN
description: Morris Tarshis, who resigned abruptly under pressure last month after 21 years as New York City's Franchise Director, kept no logs of appointments, visitors or official telephone calls.

title: Developers Never Say Die
description: The first lesson in environmental protection is this: When there's a chance to make serious money out of real estate speculation or development, the speculators and developers never say die. Neither do the politicians who support and are supported by them.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: MONDAY, JUNE 8, 1987
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-13 The Venice summit meeting will convene today under the shadow of considerable political and economic uncertainty in the seven participating nations. Page A1 News analysis: The Venice summit will start with unusually modest prospects and raises the question of why anyone bothers. One reason is that the Group of Seven governments use the conferences to tackle periodic crises. A1 High and dry in Venice A8 On the border between Iran and Iraq, the Iraqi city of Amarah has established formidable defenses to halt an Iranian attack. If Iran mounts a major offensive, Amarah would be a logical new objective, military analysts believe. A1 If Iran deploys land-based missiles, the United States will view that as a ''hostile act'' that could bring retaliation, Howard H. Baker Jr., the White House chief of staff, said. A8 David Fischer received immunity from the special prosecutor in the Iran-contra affair, investigators said. He was the President's personal aide and later worked with a company linked to illegal fund-raising for the contras. A1 Rejecting austerity plans, Zambia has fueled a wide-ranging debate about the International Monetary Fund. The debate is whether the fund's policies represent the best prescription for indebted third world economies. A12 Israel's next ambassador to the U.S. has been chosen. Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir and Foreign Minister Shimon Peres agreed to appoint a career diplomat, Moshe Arad. The Cabinet also endorsed Mr. Arad's selection. A3 Organizing the Pope's visit to Poland has been easy, but has produced quandaries, Vatican officials say. The Polish Government is eager to have him come, but some say that the visit has become a propaganda tool. A13 Updates in the U.S. tariff schedule are about to be undertaken after more than a quarter-century. The new system would bring the United States in line with international standards. D1 Commons to get first blacks A3 Moscow journal A4 Kuwait asks China to help protect shipping A9 Craxi adds touch to campaign A10 French Minister scores a coup A11 NATIONAL A14-17, B6-7 A milestone in genetic engineering was reached when the Government ruled that higher life forms may be patented. The decision has prompted a Congressional committee to schedule hearings on ethics and regulations. A1 Advances in altered life forms A17 The prosecutor in the Deaver case, Whitney North Seymour Jr., strikes many who know him as a man committed to the public good. Before the Deaver assignment, he was best known for his investigations into rackets. A14 Ku Klux Klan members marched through the streets of downtown Greensboro, S.C., in their first public rally there since a 1979 demonstration that left five people dead. Five bystanders were arrested. A14 Y.M.C.A. residential units are closing across the country in favor of new buildings for health and fitness activities. The institutions served as way stations for young men migrating from the farm to the city. A14 Pittsburgh plan rescues rooms A14 George Bush's Western campaign has offered several reminders of the contrast between the Vice President and his main rival for the Republican Presidential nomination, Senator Bob Dole. A15 Political leaders' policies on AIDS concern health officials. The officials worry that the leaders, now that they realize the scope of the epidemic, may get diverted into crowd-pleasing but unproductive sideshows. B6 The spread of AIDS through kissing is not documented, the World Health Organization said in an attempt to calm persisting anxieties that the virus can be spread by casual contact. B6 Murderer executed in Louisiana B7 WASHINGTON TALK A16 Senator Danforth on AIDS Haiku public relations REGIONAL B1-6 New York City is scrambling to spend an unprecedented $1 billion in contracts by June 30. Critics say the Koch administration is lagging in awarding contracts because of mismanagement. A1 A new AIDS advertising campaign will be created by the city to encourage teen-agers to abstain from sex, Mayor Koch said. The Mayor said that the campaign is being created because even sex with a condom is not safe. A1 Morris Tarshis's lack of records of appointments, visitors or official telephone calls raise questions about his stewardship of the obscure but powerful Franchise Bureau, investigators said. B1 New York Hospital was exonerated by the results of an autopsy in the death of a critically ill infant during a power failure last week. The autopsy attributed the death primarily to the ''severe prematurity'' of the boy. B3 Efforts to evict a crack dealer from an apartment building by a group that provides housing for battered women and their children have won the support of frustrated police and city officials. B1 The fate of some 19th century tiles removed during the restoration of Central Park's Bethesda Terrace was decided when Mayor Koch said they would go back to the ceiling of the arcade leading to the terrace's famous fountain. B3 20,000 motorcylists went to a town in New York for the largest motorcyclists' gathering in the country, Americade '87. The motorcyclists left behind millions in revenue in the village of Lake George. B3 A plan to merge state trial courts in New York is almost certainly dead for this legislative session, key legislators said. The plan is a major initiative of Governor Cuomo and the state's Chief Judge. B1 Surgeon suing over suspension B2 Judge delays moving radium B2 Suffolk Democrats' candidate B2 Deaf student has leading role B4 Celebrities address graduations B5

title: Waiting, Waiting for Albany on Ethics
description: In April, Governor Cuomo rightly vetoed the loophole-ridden ethics in government bill that legislative leaders had rammed through in hopes of avoiding more substantial reform. Since then, Governor Cuomo and the leaders have remained locked in a desultory dance over terms of a better bill. Each passing day deepens the Legislature's embarrassment and tries the public's patience.

title: Advertising; Adjusting To Florida's New Tax
description: NATIONAL GEOGRAPHIC magazine announced Friday that it would drop any advertisers from its Florida circulation who wished to be removed and that it would proportionately reduce its advertising rate.

title: Meryl Pearlstein Weds J. R. Wacht
description: At Temple Israel in Swampscott, Mass., yesterday Meryl Dina Pearlstein, an account supervisor at Laurence, Charles, Free & Lawson, a New York advertising agency, was married to James R. Wacht, an associate in the New York law firm of Bachner, Tally, Polevoy, Misher & Brinberg. Rabbi Sanford Shanblatt performed the ceremony.

title: AMEX FIRMLY OPPOSED TO VOTING RIGHTS PLAN
description: The American Stock Exchange's staunch opposition to a proposed rule change for the nation's stock exchanges is rooted in a fear, many experts say, that the change could trigger an exodus of the Amex's most prestigious listings.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Alternacare Corp., Los Angeles, an operator of outpatient-care centers, said Wallace Reed had stepped down as chairman, had been named chairman emeritus and would continue to serve on the board. A successor has not been named.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of June 7, 1987: MONDAY Day International Humana Inc First Interstate Bancorp Interco Inc TUESDAY Amer Stores Premier Industrial Chesapeake Corp Toro Co Oklahoma Gas & Elec Wyle Labs WEDNESDAY General Re Corp Nicor Inc Handleman Co Quaker Oats THURSDAY Adams Express Mony RE Invstrs Centel Corp Supermarkets Genl Engelhard Corp Trinity Industries James River Corp of Va Universal Foods FRIDAY DeSoto Inc United Cable Television

title: PLISETSKAYA, BOLSHOI STAR, TEACHING IN NEW YORK
description: Dancers stand at easy attention at the ballet barres of the light-filled studio, then straighten and face front as a glamorous red-haired gypsy of a woman slips into the room and takes her place before them. The age-old, simple first exercises of a ballet class begin. But this is no ordinary teacher. Maya Plisetskaya, the world-famous Soviet ballerina, has come to teach for two weeks in New York City.

title: Canadian Jobless Down
description: Canada's unemployment rate dropped to a five-year low in May, led by employment gains in the construction, services and manufacturing industries, Statistics Canada said Friday. The Government agency said the jobless rate fell from 9.3 percent in April to 9.1 percent, the lowest since February 1982. All figures were adjusted for seasonal fluctuations. For the 10th consecutive month the number of employed increased, rising by 62,000, to 11.9 million. The jobless total fell by 23,000, to 1.19 million.

title: Mother-in-Law of Sakharov Abandons Boston for Soviet
description: Ruth Bonner, the 86-year-old mother-in-law of the Soviet physicist Andrei D. Sakharov, returned Saturday to live permanently in the Soviet Union after seven years in the West. Mrs. Bonner was greeted at

title: OFFICIALS DISQUALIFY ALABAMA'S TEAM
description: For 15 minutes Saturday night, the Alabama women's track team celebrated its apparent victory in the National Collegiate Athletic Association championships. Then the cheers turned to tears. Alabama was disqualified after having finished first in the 1,600-meter relay, giving the team title to their Louisiana State hosts.

title: BUSH VS. DOLE: THE CONTRASTS EMERGE
description: With the temperature settling at 106 degrees, George Bush arrived here the other afternoon and stood before microphones on the tarmac, confronted once again by questions that have nagged him wherever he travels.

title: WARPLANE MAKERS FEEL PRESSURE TO COOPERATE
description: When French Mirage and American F-18 fighters zoom overhead as the annual Paris Air Show begins on Thursday, the mood among the hundreds of military contractors here is expected to be as gray as Paris's skies have been in recent weeks.

title: TV and Cable Shows To Feature the Industry
description: While Marshall Pengra of Houston is in New York scouting financing for a half-hour television series on the best in creative advertising, Lawrence Brown, who had his own similar show on Manhattan Cable beginning in March 1981, is planning to bring it back to cable Sept. 1.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Horse Racing Lac Ouimet Is Winner: Lac Ouimet carried top weight of 116 pounds as the front runner in a 2 1/2-length victory over Fobby Forbes and Johns Treasure, the heavy favorite, in the $114,600 Nassau County Handicap yesterday at Belmont. Lac Ouimet, a 4-year-old son of Pleasant Colony and the Northfields mare Northern Sunset, paid $9.60 for $2 to win and ran the mile and an eighth in 1:48 1/5 under Eddie Maple. It was the horse's sixth victory in 17 career starts, and the winner's purse of $68,760 raised his career earnings to $345,117. (AP) Long Shot First: Judge Angelucci, a long shot, led the entire way yesterday to win the $328,00 Californian at Hollywood Park. Iron Eyes, another long shot, finished second a length back as the expected duel between the 1986 stars, Snow Chief and Ferdinand, never materialized. Snow Chief, last year's Preakness winner, finished third. Ferdinand, the 1986 Kentucky Derby winner, was fourth. Judge Angelucci's career total stood at $187,865 before capturing yesterday's $193,200 top prize.(AP) Auto Racing Mass and Rahal Triumph: Bobby Rahal of Dublin, Ohio, and Jochen Mass of West Germany, co-driving a Porsche 962 prototype, inherited the lead 18 laps from the end and won the Champion Spark Plug Grand Prix at the Mid-Ohio Sports Car Course in Lexington, Ohio. Rahal and Mass never led until Chip Robinson suddenly pulled his 962 onto the pit road on the 112th of 129 laps in the 500-kilometer I.M.S.A. Camel GT sports car event after a part of the car's left-rear suspension broke. He shared the cockpit with the defending I.M.S.A. champion, Al Holbert. Rahal easily held off the second-place Porsche 962 of Darin Brassfield and Bob Wollek of France. (AP) Halsmer Takes 100-Mile Race: Pete Halsmer averaged 84.629 miles and hour in a Merkur XR4Ti to defeat the pole-winner, Scott Pruett, yesterday in the 100-mile Sports Car Club of America Trans-Am race at Portland (Ore.) International Raceway. Halsmer, of Anaheim, Calif., took the lead on lap 23 of the 53-lap event to earn $11,600. (AP) Track and Field Russian Sets Record: Natalya Lisovskaya of the Soviet Union broke her world record in the shot-put with a put of 74 feet 1 3/4 inches. The record put came during the Znamensky Brothers Memorial meet in Moscow, part of the Grand Prix circuit of the International Amateur Athletics Federation. (AP)

title: 43 YEARS OF ADVANCES IN ALTERED LIFE FORMS
description: The advances that make genetic engineering possible began in 1944, when Oswald T. Avery, Colin MacLeod and Maclyn McCarthy, researchers at Rockefeller University in New York, determined that deoxyribonucleic acid, or DNA, carried the hereditary blueprint of all living things. The same year, Congress passed the Public Health Service Act, which provided grants to universities for medical and biological research.

title: FRANCE EMBRACES 'POPULAR CAPITALISM'
description: France's campaign to sell off Government-owned industry, which began last November, has generated two waves: a wave of Frenchmen rushing to buy shares in the companies, and a wave of controversy.

title: Group to Lend Cannon $10 Million
description: A group that includes the founders of the Cannon Group Inc. is preparing a restructuring plan for the troubled independent film-production company, the company said Friday.

title: PHILLIES TOP EXPOS ON 2-HITTER
description: Mike Jackson came within three outs today of becoming the first Phillies pitcher to throw a no-hitter in Philadelphia in this century.

title: INSIDE
description: Israel Picks Envoy for U.S. Israel's Prime Minister and Foreign Minister finally agreed to appoint a career diplomat the next ambassador to Washington. Page A3. Zambia Changes Its Mind Zambia's decision to end stringent austerity measures has fueled the debate over what works best for indebted third world economies. Page A12. No Room at the Y Now serving a changing population, many Y.M.C.A.'s are closing the residential facilities that once offered homes to young workers. Page A14. Haiku Diplomacy Spring departs, Rustle, rustle, In the grasses of the field. KOBAYASHI ISSA (1762-1826) Washington Talk, page A16. Court Merger in Jeopardy A plan to merge all of New York State's trial courts in an effort to cut backlogs probably will not be adopted this year, legislators say. Page B1. Lendl Wins French Open Ivan Lendl defeated Mats Wilander in four sets to capture the men's singles final in the French Open tennis tournament in Paris. SportsMonday, page C6.

title: METS 5, PIRATES 4; PIRATES 10, METS 9
description: Lee Mazzilli might have bit the hand that feeds him yesterday, but he did it for the team that raised and nurtured him.

title: Big City Ashtrays
description: Pressure not to foul the air indoors increasingly forces smokers outdoors - with the annoying side effect of more cigarette-butt litter. In New York City parks and playgrounds, sandboxes intended for toddlers begin to look like giant hotel lobby smoking urns.

title: People
description: * Robert W. Meuser has been promoted to senior vice president at D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles, Chicago.

title: CABARET: JOHN WALLOWITCH AT BACKSTAGE
description: WHEN John Wallowitch sits down at the piano, everything spills out, including what he refers to as his ''Lithuanian roots,'' his self-proclaimed obsession with Joan Rivers, his glowing admiration for Irving Berlin and Cole Porter and his unstinting joy in making songs out of everything that comes to mind.

title: China, Britain Settle Claims
description: China and Britain signed an agreement today settling all outstanding historical property claims and opening the way for China to issue bonds on the London capital market, the British Embassy said on Friday.

title: Willard Hamlin, 90, Creator Of Orange Julius Fruit Drink
description: Willard Hamlin, a real estate broker who used his knowledge of chemistry to create the fruit drink Orange Julius and helped build a worldwide chain of 700 juice stands, died here May 29. He was 90 years old.

title: Union Rejects McLouth Bid
description: The United Steelworkers Union has rejected an employee buyout offer from the majority owner of troubled McLouth Steel Products Corporation, officials said. The union called the offer by Cyrus Tang unacceptable, said Michael Zavis, a lawyer for Mr. Tang. Mr. Zavis said that Mr. Tang had asked to maintain close business ties to McLouth while keeping the right to reinvest in the new company if it proved successful.

title: KOCH ORDERS NEW AIDS ADS STRESSING SEXUAL ABSTINENCE
description: Mayor Koch has directed New York City health officials to prepare a new advertising campaign telling people -especially teen-agers - that the safest way to avoid contracting AIDS is to abstain from sexual relations.

title: Soviet Hopes and Fears
description: Snatches from three conversations:

title: Hospitals' Junior Doctors Need Senior Backups
description: To the Editor:

title: ISRAELIS AGREE ON ENVOY FOR WASHINGTON
description: Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir and Foreign Minister Shimon Peres agreed today to appoint a career diplomat, Moshe Arad, as Israel's next ambassador to Washington.

title: ERNIE: A COMMERCIAL SUCCESS STORY
description: Imagine Mr. Whipple, the squeezer of the Charmin, as the star of a full-length movie. Or think of Bartles and Jaymes, the wine cooler pitchmen, in feature films all their own.

title: Not Kiev-Bound
description: For months William H. Courtney has been waiting to see if he would actually make it to Kiev. The Administration picked him to serve as the first Consul General in Kiev. But the American-Soviet negotiations to set up new consulates in Kiev and New York have been lagging.

title: BIKERS BRING DOLLARS, NOT DEBRIS, TO RESORT
description: More than 20,000 motorcyclists politely stormed the village of Lake George this weekend, appropriating every curbside parking space in its two-mile downtown strip, occupying most of its motel rooms and leaving behind, when the exhaust cleared, millions in revenue.

title: Craxi Adds Personal Touch to TV Campaign
description: As Italy's campaign for parliamentary elections enters its last week, the Socialist Party is blitzing the airwaves with something of a novelty: four television spots showing former Prime Minister Bettino Craxi being questioned by a mock interviewer on different topics.

title: RUSSIAN SAYS DEMANDS BY U.S. DELAY ARMS PACT
description: An agreement to scrap medium-range missiles in Europe is possible soon if the United States drops ''artificial obstacles,'' a senior Soviet arms control negotiator said today.

title: Bomb Kills Israeli Soldier
description: An Israeli soldier was killed and two others were wounded today when a roadside bomb exploded in what Israel calls its security zone in southern Lebanon, a military spokesman said. The bomb went off as the soldiers were walking near Taibe village, the spokesman said.

title: Wallace Is Confined to Bed As His Health Deteriorates
description: Former Gov. George C. Wallace is in increasingly poor health and is often confined to bed, his son says.

title: NEW YORK RUSHING TO LET CONTRACTS
description: With just three weeks left in the fiscal year, New York City officials are scrambling to award an unprecedented $1 billion in contracts by June 30.

title: LENDL TOPS WILANDER IN RAIN IN
description: FRENCH OPEN FINAL

title: 'LES MISERABLES' AND 'FENCES' WIN TOP TONYS
description: ''Les Miserables,'' a musical adaptation of the 1862 Victor Hugo novel, and ''Fences,'' a drama about a black American family on the eve of the civil-rights era, swept the 41st Annual Tony Awards, which were presented last night during a live broadcast from the Mark Hellinger Theater, winning the awards for best musical and best play, respectively.

title: 2 Quiet Weeks for Treasury Sales
description: The regular Monday auctions of three-month and six-month bills are the only Treasury issues scheduled for sale this week and next.

title: ASSESSING ON-THE-JOB FAREWELLS
description: WHEN Lee Ryan left her job as a special-education teacher, all the employees at the private school in Chicago where she had taught for seven years turned out to say goodbye at a surprise luncheon. They presented her with a handmade plaque noting her accomplishments and a silver vase for her new apartment.

title: CELEBRITIES PUT THE GLITTER IN COLLEGE GRADUATIONS
description: ''A man known to us only as a celebrity in politics or trade gains largely in our esteem if we discover that he has some intellectual taste or skill.'' - Ralph Waldo Emerson, ''The Conduct of Life.''

title: STANFORD BEATS OKLAHOMA STATE FOR TITLE
description: Steve Chitren, a relief pitcher, got out of a bases-loaded eighth-inning jam by striking out the side as Stanford won the National Collegiate Athletic Association baseball title by defeating Oklahoma State, 9-5, tonight.

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: HIGH AND DRY IN VENICE
description: The first people to suffer at every summit conference are the poor souls who find themselves washed up by circumstance, like so much flotsam, in the midst of a gathering of world leaders.

title: New York Will Be a City of Access for the Disabled
description: To the Editor:

title: New Apartment Is on Wrong Side Of Paradise
description: The only sign that anybody had even visited apartment No. 5 at 4585 Park Avenue recently was a brochure that the Jehovah's Witnesses had slipped under the door.

title: MUSIC: WESTERN WIND VOCAL SEXTET
description: WHETHER the composer is Machaut, Monteverdi, Sting or Philip Glass, an aura of Americana breathes through the music of the Western Wind Vocal Ensemble. The 18-year-old a cappella sextet, comprising four men and two women, is presenting ''The Western Wind Songbook: A Cabaret,'' a 25-song program at the CSC Repertory Theater, 136 East 13th Street, through next Monday.

title: YANKEES 5, BREWERS 3
description: The Yankees will return to New York with a split in their weekend series with the Milwaukee Brewers, their division lead reduced to a half game and without four of the players they brought here.

title: SCHULTZ OF VIRGINIA TO SUCCEED BYERS
description: Dick Schultz, the University of Virginia's athletic director, will succeed Walter Byers as executive director of the National Collegiate Athletic Association, sources said today.

title: Williams College
description: Williams College awarded 522 undergraduate and 553 graduate degrees yesterday in the 198th commencement on campus in Williamstown, Mass.

title: The U.N. Today: June 8, 1987
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Committee on Peaceful Uses of Outer Space - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL United Nations Development Program, Governing Council - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Making Summer Sweet
description: Fruits and vegetables are not all that ripen when the weather grows warmer. So, sad to say, do the streets and subways of New York City. It takes the sun and heat to reveal most fully their decline into the world's biggest lavatory. Therefore, a modest proposal: That the three B's - Bendel's, Bloomingdale's and Barney's -not to mention Saks and Macy's and Altman's and Lord & Taylor - do all New Yorkers a favor and revive the vinaigrette, in the 18th-century meaning, which had nothing to do with salad dressing.

title: VERSE BEFORE TRADE PITCH
description: ''Isn't it delightful to get up early in the morning and breathe in the fragrant air of May?''

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''People understand at a gut level that there is something wondrous, and perhaps perilous, about a technology that changes the blueprint of life and will force us to make choices that are likely to be more profound than anything we, as a society, have ever faced.'' - Senator Albert Gore Jr., Democrat of Tennessee. [ A17:2. ]

title: Friedman Is Bride Of Thomas H. Mellins
description: Lisa Joan Friedman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel D. Friedman of Blauvelt, N.Y., was married at the Federal Hall National Memorial in Manhattan yesterday to Thomas Harrison Mellins, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Harry Z. Mellins of Chestnut Hill, Mass. Rabbi James Prosnit performed the ceremony.

title: GULF WAR AND AIDS AMONG THE ISSUES AT ECONOMIC TALKS
description: The 13th summit gathering of the major industrial democracies will convene here Monday under the shadow of considerable political and economic uncertainty in the seven participating nations.

title: ABUSED WOMEN'S GROUP FLEES CRACK
description: On the fifth floor of a rundown city-owned tenement in Washington Heights, Alisa Del Tufo thought she had found the unattainable commodity - two apartments that could provide safe housing for a group of battered women and their children.

title: Misery
description: In the opening pages of ''Misery,'' the protagonist wakes up from a coma in excruciating pain and tries to take stock: ''He was Paul Sheldon, who wrote novels of two kinds, good ones and best-sellers. He had been married and divorced twice. He smoked too much (or had before all this, whatever 'all this' was). Something very bad had happened to him but he was still alive.''

title: COMMONS LIKELY TO GET FIRST BLACKS
description: Diane Abbott, a Cambridge scholar with dreadlocks and an abiding interest in the civil rights politics of America, will be part of Parliamentary history Thursday when she is considered certain to be elected as one of the first blacks in the House of Commons.

title: Baker, Smith Settle Suit
description: Baker Hughes Inc. and Smith International Inc. said they had settled a patent-infringement lawsuit in which a Federal court had ruled that Smith should pay $205 million.

title: BAKER HINTS AT U.S. ACTION IF IRAN DEPLOYS GULF MISSILES
description: Howard H. Baker Jr., the White House chief of staff, warned Iran today that the United States would view Iranian deployment of land-based missiles that could threaten shipping in the Persian Gulf as a ''hostile act'' that could bring retaliation.

title: HEALTH OFFICIALS FEAR 'SIDESHOW' EFFORTS WILL HURT AIDS FIGHT
description: Six years after the first case of AIDS was reported, leaders around the world are only beginning to realize the staggering consequences of the uncontrolled spread of the lethal virus.

title: Shearson Fights Ruling
description: Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. filed a motion in a Federal District Court in Atlanta last week seeking to overturn a $10 million judgment against it awarded in late May.

title: Taiwan Cites Liberalization
description: Taiwan's central bank governor said Friday that the Government had gone a long way to satisfy American demands for economic liberalization intended to cut its huge trade surplus and that Washington should not ask for further concessions.

title: Not a Bad Thing?
description: Dressed in a sport shirt, White House Chief of Staff Howard Baker told reporters that ''it would not be a bad thing'' if we worked out a deal with the Soviet Union jointly to patrol the Persian Gulf.

title: FROM CAMBODIA CAPTIVE TO PREP SCHOOL SCHOLAR
description: Halfway around the world from the child labor camp where he grew up eating rats and working 12 hours a day in the rice fields, Sathaya Tor received his high school diploma today at Phillips Academy here and was doused with champagne by an exuberant classmate.

title: Keeping Back With the Ivanovs
description: Getting ahead: it's the American dream. The Russians want nothing to do with it, a Soviet sociologist wrote recently in Literaturnaya Gazeta. What they want is equality in pay for everyone. They want it so much, in fact, that they oppose a new law that lets people take second jobs in some kinds of work. And if there is to be such a law, they want a stiffer tax and license fees for anyone taking advantage of it, to even things out a bit.

title: ZAMBIA-I.M.F. FALLOUT MIRRORS THIRD-WORLD WOES
description: When President Kenneth D. Kaunda of Zambia recently abandoned stringent austerity measures drawn up by the International Monetary Fund, he fueled the wide-ranging debate over whether the fund's policies represent the best prescription for heavily indebted third world economies.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: MISERY. By Stephen King. 310 pages. Viking. $18.95.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: Which major league pitcher has given up the most home runs in succession?

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: MONDAY, JUNE 8, 1987
description: International Report

title: Salvador Shrimp Deal
description: El Salvador is to pay for most of the cost of a new power plant with shrimp, an official for the company that put together the deal said Friday. The spokesman for International Countertrading of Brussels said the new geothermal plant, to be built mainly by a Belgian company, ACEC, would cost more than 300 million Belgian francs, or $8 million.

title: Jeffrey Goldberg Weds Suzan Cooper in Jersey
description: Suzan Cooper and Jeffrey Goldberg were married yesterday at Temple B'nai Jeshurun in Short Hills, N.J., by Rabbi Barry Green. The couple's parents are Eugene S. Cooper of New York and Mrs. Howard Grad of Verona, N.J., and Gertrude Goldberg of Rochester and the late Mr. Goldberg.

title: Alan Jablonsky Is Wed To Ann F. Adenbaum
description: Temple Israel in New Rochelle, N.Y., was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Ann Frances Adenbaum, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David Adenbaum of New Rochelle, to Alan Jablonsky, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Jablonsky of the Bronx. Rabbi Amiel Wohl and Cantor Helene Reps officiated.

title: Linda and Susan Tabas Become Brides
description: Linda Jane Tabas was married yesterday to Murray Stempel 3d, and her sister Susan Kimberly Tabas was married to Kenneth Lewis Tepper in a double ceremony at the Twelve Caesars in Philadelphia. The ceremony was performed by Rabbi Frederick Kazan.

title: PAZIENZA SHAKEN BUT CAPTURES TITLE (uf881)
description: Vinny Pazienza came into the Civic Center ring here today resplendent in sequined robe, trunks and shoes. He left bloodied and bruised, but in shaky possession of the International Boxing Federation lightweight title, which he took from Greg Haugen in a unanimous 15-round decision.

title: NEWEST CAPER: JAMES BOND IN THE TEMPLE OF CULTURE
description: In the crowd at the Museum of Modern Art yesterday were several people who said they never would have thought of coming if the exhibit on Bond - James Bond - had not been there to entice them. There were others, however, who said they never would have thought of seeing James Bond films if the museum had not decided to show them.

title: Resorts Casino Head Reported to Have Quit
description: Marvin Ashner, who made millions selling hotel properties to casinos, has resigned as president and chief operating officer of the Resorts International Casino Hotel in Atlantic City, according to sources within the company's board.

title: 'DOTTIE,' A DRAMA ON AGORAPHOBICS
description: AT 9 this evening on Channels 13 and 49, ''American Playhouse'' dips into the popular television genre that has come to be known as ''the disease movie.'' In this instance, an 80-minute drama entitled ''Dottie,'' the disease is agoraphobia, or a fear of being in open or public places. According to a press release for the film, millions of people in the United States never venture outside their homes because of this fear. It is, the press release states, ''a problem which, in our violent high-tech world, affects more and more people every day.'' I suspect this particular panic button is, for the sake of dramatic urgency, being pressed a little too hard, but anyone who has ever experienced even a passing anxiety attack will easily identify with the problem.

title: Fleischer Marries
description: At Congregation B'nai Jeshurun in New York yesterday Madelene Lois Fleischer, an associate in the New York office of the law firm of Drinker Biddle & Reath, was married to L.Stanton Towne, a partner in the New York law firm of Towne, Dolgin, Sawyier & Horton. Rabbi Marshall T. Meyer officiated. The bride is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herman Fleischer of New York, and the bridegroom is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Milfred Towne of Rancho Mirage, Calif.

title: Few Clues on Rates, Economy
description: The credit markets weathered the storm that followed the decision by Paul A. Volcker to step down as chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, but they were still beset by a dense fog surrounding developments in the American economy and the foreign exchange market.

title: Chirac Blinks in Facedown With Culture Minister
description: Francois Leotard, France's popular and ambitious Culture Minister, appears to have scored a significant tactical victory over Prime Minister Jacques Chirac in a campaign to establish himself as a major conservative leader - and perhaps Mr. Chirac's heir - before the presidential elections next year.

title: FOLK: THE ROCHES
description: WHEN the Roches, a New York folk trio, released their first album in 1979, they became pop music's critical darlings of the moment. Plaudits were heaped on the songwriting brilliance of Maggie Roche, the eldest and quirkiest writer of the three sisters - Maggie, Terre and Suzzy -whose full-bodied but precise vocal blend suggested a folkish, new wave-flavored update of the Boswell Sisters. The unhappy irony of the Roches' moment of glory lay in the fact that here was a group at the dawn of its career, yet in terms of adulation, it had nowhere to go but down.

title: AUTOPSY LAYS INFANT'S DEATH TO PREMATURITY
description: New York City's Chief Medical Examiner yesterday released the results of an autopsy that he said largely exonerated New York Hospital in the death of a critically ill infant during a power failure last week.

title: REAGAN'S FORMER PERSONAL AIDE IS GIVEN IMMUNITY IN IRAN AFFAIR
description: The special prosecutor in the Iran-contra affair has granted complete immunity to President Reagan's former personal assistant, David C. Fischer, in exchange for his cooperation, according to Federal investigators and Mr. Fischer's lawyer.

title: First Guidry, Now Seaver?
description: THERE were times, Tom Seaver remembered, when he would come back to the dugout after the first inning and he would say to himself, ''That's it. The game is over. Forget it.''

title: T. S. Robinson, Editor, Is Wed to Jan Andrew
description: The marriage of Jan Andrew, a public relations account executive at Barbara J. Hendra Associates Inc., and Timothy Sumner Robinson, editor in chief of The National Law Journal, took place yesterday in the Cranford Rose Garden of the Brooklyn Botanic Garden. Acting Justice Richard Goldman of State Supreme Court performed the ceremony.

title: THE INDEPENDENT STYLE OF DEAVER'S PROSECUTOR
description: Every year on July 4, Whitney North Seymour Jr. gathers the dozen or so other members of his family on Cape Cod. One by one, each reads a sentence or a paragraph from the Declaration of Independence. Then, after each reading, the entire clan joins in a discussion of the meaning and significance of that section of the document.

title: Accounts
description: * Fanny Farmer Candy Shops, Wakefield, Mass. to Altman & Manley, Boston, for national retail advertising.

title: TIGER HOMERS HELP BEAT RED SOX, 18-8
description: Matt Nokes hit two home runs and drove in four runs, and Chet Lemon hit a homer and drove in four runs in leading a 21-hit attack today as the Detroit Tigers routed the Boston Red Sox, 18-8.

title: Product Movers to Try Direct Mail in Baltimore
description: Product Movers of New York, which says it can never be sure that The Sun will distribute its free-standing inserts, will use direct mail to reach 500,000 Baltimore households beginning Jan. 10. The mailing list has been developed by Harte-Hanks to approximate the demographics of The Sun's readership.

title: DEVELOPERS RESCUE PITTSBURGH'S ROOMS
description: When Ernie Dozier moved into the Y.M.C.A. here, he figured he would stay just a few months. Instead it has been his home for 17 years, a measure of security in a life supported by minimum-wage jobs.

title: Dr. Kathryn E. McGoldrick Is Married
description: Dr. Kathryn Elizabeth McGoldrick, an anesthesiologist, was married yesterday to Dr. Jonathan Mardirossian, a retina surgeon. The Rev. Michael G. Pierce performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Cathedral of the Holy Cross in Boston.

title: Gray & Rogers Sale
description: There are big doings in Philadelphia. Lewis, Gilman & Kynett, a subsidiary of Foote, Cone & Belding Communications, will buy Gray & Rogers, which has been part of Philadelphia advertising since 1929. Both agencies will continue to operate under their current names and managements. L.G.& K., which is 45 years old and ended last year with billings of $113 million, is the biggest show in town. Gray & Rogers ranks 11th, with $26.5 million in billings.

title: KITE UNLIKELY HERO IN VICTORY BY CELTICS
description: Boston Garden, where the Boston Celtics seldom lose, and the deafening support of a capacity crowd of 14,890 both figured to be pluses today in the Celtics' attempt to recoup from what Dennis Johnson termed ''two embarrassing losses'' to the Lakers in Los Angeles.

title: RECITAL: SHIRLEY LING, PIANO
description: WHY do so many pianists, against their own best interests, feel compelled to program Liszt at the end of recitals? Shirley Ling gave only a rough approximation of the knottier passages in the Petrarch Sonnet and Hungarian Rhapsody by Liszt that closed her program Saturday afternoon in Weill Recital Hall.

title: Shooting for Pool
description: It was in 1975, when he became swimming coach at Fort Hamilton High School in Brooklyn, that Tom Greene had his little brainstorm. Wouldn't it make sense, he suggested, if the school swimming team had a school pool to swim in?

title: KOCH TO RESTORE RARE TILES TO CEILING OF LANDMARK
description: The question of what to do with 16,000 rare 19th century tiles removed during the restoration of Central Park's Bethesda Terrace was decided yesterday when Mayor Koch said he would put them back where they came from: on the ceiling of the arcade leading to the terrace's famous fountain.

title: KITE FILLS A GAP FOR THE CELTICS
description: At the end of a playoff game, the opposing coaches are escorted to an interview area where they are grilled for several minutes by a contingent of reporters. Then, a player whose performance stood out is brought in. Usually, it has been Larry Bird or Earvin (Magic) Johnson or James Worthy.

title: How I'd Testify on an Arms Treaty
description: I have been wondering how I would testify on a new arms treaty with the Soviet Union -a treaty, for example, on intermediate-range nuclear weapons, which is now so much in the news.

title: Shift by Japan On Car Imports
description: Japan has agreed to relax inspection procedures on automobiles imported from Europe, ending seven days of negotiations with delegates from the European Economic Community, the community's office here said on Friday.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: When Big and Small Science Vie for Dollars
description: To the Editor:

title: DANCE: BALLET STUDENTS PERFORM AT WORKSHOP
description: THE School of American Ballet, which is the official school of the New York City Ballet, began giving its students performing showcases as far back as 1934. Barely six months after his arrival in the United States from Europe, George Balanchine assembled his first group of advanced students in that school and put them on display in ''Serenade,'' the first ballet he choreographed in this country.

title: Bridge: At 23, Lapt Chan of Queens Has Reached the Top Ranks
description: The fastest rise through the New York ranks in many a year has been achieved by Lapt Chan of Woodside, Queens, a 23-year-old computer science student at City College.

title: Harrods Plans A Giveaway
description: British Airways has had a couple of tie-ins with Harrods, the London department store, in the past, but it has never had one as elaborate as a proposed promotion to overcome the slack business-traveling days in July and August.

title: Let a U.N. Task Force Guard the Persian Gulf
description: To the Editor:

title: Ending Real Constructive Engagement
description: Most black leaders in South Africa have long viewed foreign business presence, no matter how well intended, as tacit support for the ruling white elite. Now they are joined by the Rev. Leon Sullivan, who had worked for years to fight apartheid through business activism. Last week he called for an economic embargo of South Africa.

title: ANTIGUA IS SWEPT BY BUILDING BOOM
description: Thirty-eight years ago Vernon Nicholson sailed to this Caribbean island with his wife and two sons aboard the 70-foot schooner Mollihawk, looking for a new life after serving as a British naval officer in World War II.

title: Business and the Law; Patent Fight Over Genetics
description: WHEN the gavel goes down in the High Court of Justice in London's Old Bailey today, it will mark a new chapter in the war between biotechnology companies over the valuable rights to drugs created by genetic engineering.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week. Monday None Tuesday None Wednesday None Thursday Retail Sales...May Friday Merchandise Trade Balance...April Producer Prices...May Inventory-Sales Ratio

title: Shots in Park Kill Girl And Wound Another
description: A teen-age girl was shot dead and a 6-year-old girl critically injured this afternoon in a pool jammed with visitors at an amusement park outside Charlotte.

title: Herman R. Lantz, Dies at 67; Sociology Scholar in Illinois
description: Herman R. Lantz, professor emeritus of sociology at Southern Illinois University at Carbondale, died Wednesday of acute myocardial infarction at his home in Carbondale. He was 67 years old.

title: A WARY RECEPTION FOR SULLIVAN STAND
description: The Rev. Leon Sullivan's call Wednesday for a near-total embargo on trade with South Africa, and the withdrawal within nine months of American companies doing business there, is getting a cautious response from the institutional investors on whom he is counting for support.

title: SRI LANKA GUNMEN TRY TO OVERRUN POSTS NEAR TWO AIRPORTS
description: Several gunmen tried to overrun military outposts near Colombo's two civilian airports early today, the Government said. Three attackers and one soldier were reported killed in the clashes.

title: MOVE OF TAINTED SOIL DELAYED
description: New Jersey environmental officials are not certain what they will do now that a judge has temporarily barred them from moving 15,000 barrels of radium-tainted soil from northern New Jersey to an Ocean County wildlife preserve, an attorney for the state said yesterday.

title: SUFFOLK RACE REFLECTS NATION'S SUBURBAN CONCERNS
description: Democrats in Suffolk County have endorsed their candidate for County Executive, opening a campaign that will focus on many of the most serious issues facing suburban communities across the country.

title: EQUION CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $712,158 for the quarter and $2,019,018 for the 9 months. c-Includes tax credits of $448,681 and $2,630,474 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively; the 9-month also includes a gain from an accounting change of $621,763. The company said the 1987 results for both the third quarter and 9 months include the operations of Tramco Manufacturing Corp. The company also said the 1986 results for both the third quarter and 9 months are restated to reflect an accounting change.

title: Gunmen in Philippines Ambush Former Rebel
description: Gunmen ambushed a former Communist rebel leader, Bernabe Buscayno, as he drove through a Manila suburb tonight, killing a television cameraman riding with Mr. Buscayno, who was lightly wounded, the police said.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: Fifth Avenue Shine

title: Sanyo Unit Opens U.S. Apparel Plant
description: Sanyo Sewing House, a subsidiary of Sanyo Shokai Ltd., the Tokyo-based apparel company, has opened a $4.2 million manufacturing plant in Oneonta, N.Y. - the first Japanese apparel manufacturing plant in the United States.

title: EDITH MONROE MOE
description: Edith Monroe Moe, a writer, died of pneumonia Friday at St. Joseph's Hospital in Yonkers. She was 91 years old and lived in the Riverdale section of the Bronx.

title: CHESTER CROCKER: INSIDE, MAKING POLICY ON AFRICA
description: Chester Crocker has experienced the vast difference between being an outside critic and a Government policymaker in Washington. It has been a painful six-year lesson for Mr. Crocker, the principal architect of the Reagan Administration's highly visible southern African policy.

title: CONGRESS VOTES TO RESCIND $1 STATUE OF LIBERTY FEE
description: The House of Representatives gave final Congressional approval today to a bill rescinding the $1 admission fee imposed earlier this year on visits to the Statue of Liberty.

title: Few Test Wells in Texas
description: Exploratory oil and gas drilling in Texas remains slow. In the first four months of this year, 133 wildcat oil wells and 89 gas wells were drilled, according to the Texas Railroad Commission, down from 181 oil wells and 270 gas wells a year earlier.

title: WALLACE COMPUTER SERVICES reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
ULTRASYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: Revenue represents contract revenue.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article on strawberry picking in Weekend last Friday gave an incorrect phone number for Brookview Farms in Somerville, N.J. The correct number is (201) 526-8083.

title: STAY IN NEW YORK? CORPORATE PUZZLE
description: When officials of companies based in Manhattan sit down to make a final decision on whether or not to leave New York, they confront the same basic questions that many other major corporations have faced before them.

title: Silverstein Group Signs Accountants
description: The accounting firm of Oppenheim, Appel, Dixon & Company will lease 240,000 square feet at 7 World Trade Center, a $300 million project being developed by Silverstein Properties Inc. The long-term lease represents a commitment of more than $200 million, according to analysts.

title: CONTINENTAL AND UNITED LIFT FARES AVERAGE OF 5%
description: Continental Airlines and United Airlines, two of the nation's largest carriers, announced price increases yesterday of between $3 and $7 one way on all tickets.

title: CORCORAN'S EX-DIRECTOR TO JOIN KNOEDLER
description: Michael Botwinick, who resigned in December as director of the Corcoran Gallery of Art in Washington, will become the senior vice president of Knoedler-Modarco in New York City. The company, whose board chairman is the industrialist Armand Hammer, owns the M. Knoedler and the Hammer art galleries here.

title: ATI MEDICAL reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
MEESE DETAILS PLAN
description: In the first stage of President Reagan's new plan to combat the AIDS epidemic, Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d today announced details of programs to test Federal prisoners and would-be immigrants for infection with the deadly virus.

title: FUTURES EXCHANGES WEIGH TIE
description: Momentum to merge New York's two largest futures exchanges, the New York Mercantile Exchange and the Commodity Exchange, appears to be building.

title: MORE PARTS OF THE PUZZLE: A WHITE HOUSE LAWYER, THE COLONEL'S SECRETARY
description: As the Iran-contra hearings in Washington began their sixth week, the Congressional committees heard yesterday from Bretton G. Sciaroni and Fawn Hall. Here are excerpts from their testimony, as recorded by The New York Times. BRETTON G. SCIARONI Opening Statement

title: 'FRONTLINE' DOCUMENTARY, 'DEATH OF A PORN QUEEN'
description: ''DEATH OF A PORN QUEEN'' is an account of the short, sad career of an 18-year-old who fled her Minnesota home in 1982, found success in Hollywood's pornography industry, developed a taste for cocaine and killed herself at the age of 20. The question worried on tonight's ''Frontline'' offering, on Channel 13 at 10 o'clock, is how a nice girl like Colleen Applegate could have been transformed into Shauna Grant, star of ''Flesh and Lace,'' and why she should have committed suicide.

title: WHY A FOOTBALL COACH DINES WITH MME. CHIRAC
description: As a mirror of mainstream American culture, there is little that can match the guest list for a White House state dinner.

title: California Housing Bonds
description: The California Housing Finance Agency is tentatively offering $175 million of single-family home mortgage revenue bonds with a maximum yield of 8 1/4 percent for bonds due in 2017.

title: Foreign-Denominated Iowa Offering
description: The first offering by a local government of securities denominated in a foreign currency is expected within two weeks by the State of Iowa, Goldman, Sachs & Company announced yesterday.

title: Mild Temblor in California
description: A mild earthquake shook residents awake today but brought no reports of damage, officials said. The earthquake, which registered 3.4 on the Richter scale of ground motion, occurred at 5:29 A.M. It was centered one mile northwest of Long Beach, which is 20 miles south of downtown Los Angeles, said Robert Finn of the California Institute of Technology in Pasadena. An earthquake of that magnitude is capable of causing slight damage in the immediate area.

title: STAGE: WALDO '27 REVUE
description: TERRY WALDO, a pianist and singer who has been exploring the music of the ragtime era and the 1920's for over two decades, assembled some of that music and the performance styles of the period in ''Waldo's 1927 Revue'' at Symphony Space on Friday evening. It included jazz, vaudeville and a small-scale version of the once-popular musical spectacle ''The Burning of Rome.''

title: JUSTICES UPHOLD REGULATION LIMITING DISABILITY BENEFITS
description: The Supreme Court today upheld, 6 to 3, a Social Security regulation that has been used to deny hundreds of thousands of disability claims in recent years, particularly those of older workers whose conditions prevent them from doing physical labor.

title: On a Soviet Decision to Jam and Not to Jam
description: To the Editor:

title: Yanks Take a Pounding
description: Talk about the old one-two punch.

title: Utility Fund's Top Item: GTE
description: At the end of January, Duff & Phelps Selected Utilities Inc. began business with $1.3 billion of cash to invest primarily in securities of electric, gas and telephone utilities. Having sold 130 million of its common shares at $10 apiece, this closed-end fund at the time ranked as the nation's largest initial public offering.

title: AIDS Test Procedure Is Taking Too Long
description: To the Editor:

title: Small Drop in Treasury Prices
description: Treasury note and bond prices fell slightly in listless trading yesterday as market participants waited for fresh economic statistics and the conclusion of the Venice economic summit meeting.

title: Gleckler & Company Opens for Business
description: Gayle Gleckler, chairman of Gleckler & Spiegel Advertising from 1979 to 1986, has now started her own agency, Gleckler & Company, with two executive vice presidents, David Wenman in charge of creative and Jack Oxee in charge of account service. They are at 19 West 21st Street.

title: BLACKS TELL OF ANGER AS DAILY NEWS BIAS CASE STARTS DAMAGES PHASE
description: Four black journalists said yesterday in Federal District Court in Manhattan that they had felt rage and humiliation as a result of racial discrimination by their employer, The Daily News.

title: LAWYERS UNEASY
description: The Supreme Court decision upholding arbitration in brokerage disputes will save the securities industry time and money while providing investors with a fair way to resolve disputes, executives of securities firms said yesterday.

title: Federal Judges Handed Down Stiffer Prison Terms in 1986
description: Federal judges handed down stiffer prison sentences last year than they did in 1979 as the average length of sentences increased 32 percent, a Department of Justice agency said Sunday.

title: Beijing Ad Congress Likely to Attract 1,200
description: At least 1,200 people are expected to be in Beijing for the opening of the Third World Advertising Congress, according to James L. Fleury, the director, who called last week from Hong Kong with his report.

title: Noranda Mine Kept Idle
description: Noranda Inc. will not resume mining at its fire-damaged plant here while copper prices are so low, the company said today. Four hundred employees will be offered a severance and relocation package. One miner died in the fire on April 1.

title: A Venice Lifeboat for Drowning Debtors
description: Brazil, Argentina and Uruguay have urged the countries attending the summit meeting in Venice to consider the problem of international debt. As debtors - sometimes defaulting debtors - their request may seem self-serving. As leaders in the struggle to consolidate new democracies, they are making a request that we ignore only at risk to our prosperity, security and commitment to democracy.

title: Mullen Comes Home
description: Brian Mullen, one of the pro hockey brothers from Manhattan's West Side, was acquired by the Rangers in a trade with the Winnipeg Jets yesterday.

title: American Playhouse' Appoints Lynn Holst
description: Lynn Holst has been named director of program development for ''American Playhouse,'' public television's weekly drama series. Ms. Holst will develop between 10 and 20 new projects a year for ''American Playhouse,'' including television dramas, stage plays and films.

title: USPCI REJECTS TAKEOVER BID
description: USPCI Inc., an Oklahoma City-based hazardous-waste disposal concern, today rejected a $43-a-share takeover offer from the Union Pacific Corporation that was valued at $361 million.

title: Mrs. Thatcher: A Record to Run on
description: Britain's 1979 and 1983 election victories foreshadowed American political swings; this week's vote is unlikely to do the same. President Reagan, were he eligible, would be a much weaker candidate than in 1984, hurt by the Iran-contra scandal, deficit debacle and Congressional scorn. Margaret Thatcher has antagonized many Britons with her abrasive manner but is still favored to win a third term, because of her record. Like it or not, she has built one to last.

title: EX-SENATOR SAYS WHITE HOUSE RENEGED IN DEAL ON JUDGESHIPS
description: Slade Gorton, a Republican who lost his Senate seat after casting an unpopular vote for a Reagan judicial nominee, today accused the Administration of reneging on its part of the bargain that led to that vote.

title: CONCERN OVER GENETICS PROMPTS A NEW COALITION OF CRITICS
description: The dispute over patenting of animals created in the laboratory, the latest twist in a debate that has occupied scientists, ethicists, religious leaders and environmentalists for two decades, has served as a catalyst for the formation of a loose coalition opposed to the further use of genetic engineering in animal husbandry.

title: Pay 'N Pak To Be Acquired
description: Pay 'N Pak Stores Inc., brushing aside a sweetened bid from the investor Paul A. Bilzerian, agreed today to be acquired by a management-led group in a deal worth about $210 million.

title: Staying Tuned In
description: It was a year ago that Gary McCord, the pro golfer, stood before 500 guests at the Metropolitan Golf Writers' national awards dinner and made a confession. He had been asked to say a few words about playing in the United States Open.

title: AIRPORT GUARDS CHARGED WITH SMUGGLING ALIENS
description: Twenty-one former Wells Fargo guards and supervisors and six associates were charged yesterday in a scheme that extorted money - and, in some instances, sexual favors - to allow illegal aliens apprehended at Kennedy International Airport to avoid deportation.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: POLK AUDIO reports earnings for Qtr to March 29
description: The share earnings reflect a 4-for-3 stock split effective Dec. 29.

title: Head for Business
description: One political talent that seems to flourish in Washington is the ability to capitalize, rapidly and ruthlessly, on the misfortune of another player. Hours after Gary Hart's picture had appeared nationally with the former Senator wearing a T-shirt inscribed ''Monkey Business Crew,'' two young local entrepreneurs decided copies would be a salable item.

title: Out of His League
description: From England comes news that Prime Minister Thatcher humiliated Bascom Jasper last week in a news conference.
