title: Q&A
description: Q.Why does hair on the head turn gray? A.There has been little research into the cause of gray hair, but it is obviously related to age. Scientists have learned that melanocytes, the cells that produce pigment in hair, gradually lose their ability to manufacture it and eventually die. Dr. Arthur K. Balin, a dermatologist at Rockefeller University, said that about 25 percent of all men and women had some gray hair by 25 years of age and that about 28 percent eventually became totally gray. Q.Why do newborn elephants weigh so little? A.Although elephants are among the largest mammals on earth, their babies are significantly smaller, relative to the adult's size, than are other newborn mammals. The average weight of an elephant calf is 200 pounds at birth; its mother weighs about 8,000 pounds. This compares to an 8-pound human baby with a 110-pound mother and a 1,000-pound cow with a 70-pound calf. Dr. Michael Schmidt, a veterinarian at the Washington Park Zoo in Portland, Ore., said one possible reason that elephant babies weigh so little is that the female elephant has a 4-foot-long, sloping birth canal. Dr. Schmidt said that in early times, much larger calves probably encountered difficulty traveling the canal so elephant babies evolved to a much smaller size.

description: To the Editor:

title: Continental To Sell Unit
description: The Continental Illinois Corporation said that it would sell its Toronto subsidiary, Continental Illinois Bank of Canada, to the Swiss Bank Corporation's Canadian unit. Terms were not disclosed, but Continental said that its gain would not have a material effect on operating results.

title: WILTON ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After tax credits of $303,000 for the quarter and $1,248,000 for the 9 months. c-Net loss

title: Asia Fights Book Piracy
description: China is drafting laws against book piracy, and Indonesia plans to protect foreign films, music and books, officials of those countries said today. Song Muwen, a Chinese publishing official, was in Hong Kong on his way to a book festival in Singapore. From Jakarta, Justice Minister Ismail Saleh said a copyright bill would be signed into law by October.

title: BALLOTS, BALLYHOO AND THE BRITISH WAY
description: For the past few weeks, Harvey Thomas has been rattling around Britain in a dusty sedan, making sure that the halls used for Margaret Thatcher's rallies could accommodate motor-driven lecterns and the clean, pre-selected camera angles he calls ''Harvey's wedge.''

title: Group Submits New Allegis Plan
description: A group of investors seeking control of the Allegis Corporation has indicated that it was now seeking the removal of all incumbent Allegis directors. The group - Gollust, Tierney & Oliver - delivered to the company a new stockholders consent form calling for the election a new slate of directors.

title: Fordham Star Signs
description: Pete Harnisch, Fordham University's star pitcher, has signed with the Baltimore Orioles' organization. Harnisch, the second pick on the second round of the draft, had a 21-3 career record for the Rams, a 2.29 earned run average and 213 strikeouts in 204 innings.

title: RUGBY ALL-STARS SHOW THEIR SKILLS
description: The first United States college all-star rugby team has been chosen, assembled and played its first game.

title: REAGAN, IN VENICE, LIFTS PART OF TARIFF ON JAPAN
description: President Reagan, after meeting with Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone, announced today that he had lifted part of the tariffs on electronic goods imposed on Japan in April.

title: NORTH AMERICAN HOLDING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: SCHLESINGER SAYS MOSCOW BUGGING MEANS EMBASSY MUST BE REBUILT
description: The new United States Embassy must undergo a major reconstruction because it is riddled with bugging devices so sophisticated that American intelligence agents do not fully understand them, the American assigned to investigate the problem said today.

title: Enough Fourth-Class Service on Third-Class Mail
description: LEAD: The United States Postal Service is drowning in junk mail. The average postal carrier delivers more junk mail, or third-class letters, than first-class mail. The result is a rapid decline in the quality of all postal services.

title: U.S. PAYS 10 RICE FARMS AT LEAST $1 MILLION EACH
description: Ten of the nation's largest rice farms received Government payments of more than $1 million each under the Reagan Administration's program to subsidize rice growers, according to a study published today by the Agriculture Department.

title: CHANGES AT NBC NEWS
description: John J. Lane, the No. 2 executive at NBC News, will leave the newtork to become news director at NBC's local station, WNBC, it was announced yesterday.

title: Computer for Chinese
description: Apple Computer Inc. has introduced a Chinese operating system for Macintosh personal computers. This Zhongwen Talk system, the company said today, allows computer input and output in Chinese by means of the Pin Yan phonetic method, stroke ordering or coding.

title: Schultz Takes N.C.A.A. Post
description: Richard Schultz, the director of athletics at the University of Virginia, received a five-year contract yesterday to succeed Walter Byers as executive director of the National Collegiate Athletic Association.

title: Ex-Boxer Sentenced
description: Samuel Serrano, the former World Boxing Association junior-lightweight champion, was sentenced in San Juan, P.R., yesterday to 15 years in jail and fined $100,000. The 34-year-old Serrano pleaded guilty in March to possession of 750 grams of cocaine with the intent to distribute.

title: Pilot's Parents Say Peace Was His Goal in Moscow
description: Mathias Rust's parents were quoted as saying today that the 19-year-old West German pilot made his flight to Moscow May 28 because he was determined to meet Mikhail S. Gorbachev to discuss peace.

title: Seventeen Magazine Names a Publisher
description: Triangle Communications has promoted Ira S. Garey, 54, to publisher of Seventeen magazine from associate publisher/advertising.

title: JAVELIN INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
IN VENICE, WASHINGTON'S PARTNERS RESIST ECHOING TOUGH TALK ON THE GULF
description: Leaders of the major industrial democracies reacted cautiously today to the Reagan Administration's tough comments on the situation in the Persian Gulf, an issue that has threatened the seven-nation summit conference here.

title: American General Buys Properties
description: The American General Corporation, with the Newland Group Inc., said that it had agreed to buy the domestic residential projects of Genstar Land U.S.A. for about $200 million. Genstar, based in San Diego, is a subsidiary of Imasco Ltd. of Canada, a consumer products and services company that also owns Hardee's Food Systems Inc., Peoples Drug Stores Inc. and Imperial Tobacco. Last year, Imasco bought Genstar, which includes properties in the United States and Canada, and had indicated that it would seek to divest it of certain assets.

title: Budget Reprieve Urged for U.N. Rights Effort
description: Western governments are seeking to spare the United Nations human rights enforcement system from deep budget cuts stemming from the failure of the United States to pay its assesed budget share, according to diplomats and officials at the organization's European headquarters.

title: EXAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After tax credits of $1,376,000 and $2,885,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Net income The company said the latest quarter includes writeoffs related to the relocation of Exar's operations, excluding manufacturing, from Sunnvale to San Jose, Calif. The aggregate amount of writoffs, reserves and allowances taken in the fourth quarter totaled about $3 million.

title: CITY BALLET: 'KAMMERMUSIK NO. 2'
description: George Balanchine was an astonishingly versatile choreographer. Anyone seeking proof for that claim could have found it Sunday night at the New York State Theater when the New York City Ballet danced Balanchine's ''Walpurgisnacht Ballet'' and ''Kammermusik No. 2.''

title: COMPANY SUES ITS WORKERS' DOCTORS
description: From 1980 until 1984, only a handful of workers at the Dayton-Walther Corporation's flagship foundry in Dayton, Ohio, filed workers' compensation claims for occupational diseases. But from late July 1984 until early March 1985, while the plant was idle, the company was hit with more than 100 claims from workers who said they had occupational diseases such as silicosis, which impedes breathing, or hand and arm injuries from using vibrating tools.

title: Japan Stock Futures Set To Trade
description: Trading in Japanese stock futures will begin on Tuesday, with a package of 50 of Japan's leading stocks.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Whatever incentives New York offers, we've got an advantage. We're over here, and they are over there.'' - Borden R. Putnam, New Jersey Commissioner of Commerce and Economic Development. [ A1:6. ]

title: NEW AMERICAN NOMADS: THE RETIRED PULL UP STAKES AND TAKE TO THE ROAD
description: When they retired in 1983, Boyd and Ethel Bentz could not abide the idea of sitting around the house and watching television all day.

title: Writer and Teacher to Head Socialist's Ticket for 1988
description: The Socialist Party USA has nominated a writer from Michigan and a teacher from New York as its candidates for President and Vice President.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article last Wednesday about New York State's acquisition of Lake Minnewaska in the Catskills misstated the circumstances under which the state obtained it. The property was purchased for $6.75 million after eminent-domain proceedings were dropped.

title: INTERNATIONAL ROBOMATION INTELLIGENCE reports earnings for Year to Feb 1
Payton Goes Shopping
description: Walter Payton, pro football's career rushing leader, is taking a step toward his goal of becoming the first black owner of a National Football League team. Jerry Richman, the agent for the Chicago Bears' running back, said Payton planned to meet soon with civic leaders in Oakland, Calif., to discuss buying an N.F.L. franchise that would play in that city.

title: Met Is Second at First
description: Jack Clark of the St. Louis Cardinals holds a slim lead over Keith Hernandez of the Mets in the voting to be the starting National League first baseman in the All-Star Game. Clark has 228,113 votes in the fan balloting, while Hernandez has 220,986.

title: SCIENTISTS DEPICT MOLTEN SEA FAR BENEATH EARTH'S SURFACE
description: BENEATH the earth, within the heart of the planet, lies a long unexplored ocean of molten iron whose currents and undulating upper boundary are only just beginning to be discovered through a new arsenal of scientific tools.

title: India's Goa Is Winning Its Struggle for Identity
description: To the Editor:

title: CITY BALLET: ROBBINS'S 'DREAMER'
description: THE opus number in ''Opus 19/ The Dreamer'' is that of Prokofiev's Violin Concerto No. 1 in D major, to which this ballet is set. ''The Dreamer'' provides a clue to the content of the Jerome Robbins work, which the New York City Ballet danced Saturday afternoon at the New York State Theater.

title: ORION RESEARCH INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 28
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $999,000 (of which $729,000 resulted from a loss on the sale of Orion's wholly owned subsidiary, Orion Scientific Instruments Corp.) for the quarter and $1,212,000 for the year. c-After income of $93,000 for the quarter and a loss of $97,000 for the year, both from discontinued operations. The net loss figures include income of $111,000 in 1987 and $104,000 in 1986 from the operation of Orion Resdel Corp., which is expected to be sold this year.

title: Restaurant Shut After Death
description: A historic restaurant in Fairmount Park has been closed after the death of a diner who apparently received an electrical shock from an air-conditioner cord, the police reported. William Shrader, 66 years old, of Flourtown, died Saturday evening at Chestnut Hill Hospital. The restaurant, the Valley Green Inn, was ordered to remain closed until electrical violations were corrected, the authorities said.

title: SHACKS OF LAOTIAN REFUGEES OFFEND MINNESOTA NEIGHBORS
description: Some residents say shacks built by Laotian refugees who farm in this east-central Minnesota community are embarrassing and should be replaced.

title: China to Try Student; Earned Degree in U.S.
description: A visiting Chinese official has disclosed that a Chinese student who was arrested in protests in Shanghai would be tried for criminal activities soon.

title: OPTIONS SOUGHT TO DEADLY FORCE
description: A 16-year-old in Clark, N.J., had just stabbed his brother. Cornered by the police, the youth slashed at them with the knife and threatened to kill them. The police officers might have shot him. Instead, an officer carrying a special weapon that resembled an oversized nightstick fired a cloth beanbag filled with lead pellets at the youth. The beanbag hit him in the stomach, he doubled over, dropped the knife and surrendered. His only injury was a small bruise.

title: HERLEY MICROWAVE SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Della Femina Handling Zinka Sunscreen
description: Now that the wacky commercial for a wacky product called Zinka is already on MTV, Jerry Della Femina, chairman of Della Femina, Travisano & Partners, is stepping forward to take credit for it.

title: Shifting Costs To Employees
description: EVER since the Depression, employers have been bearing more and more of the costs of their workers' medical care.

title: SPIRIT OF GUTHRIE: 'PEOPLE'S MUSIC' IN THE CATSKILLS
description: Friday night, musicians from all over the country began arriving at the wooded camp here in the Catskills.

title: Billing Study On Northrop
description: The House Armed Services Committee has scheduled for Wednesday a hearing to investigate allegations that the Northrop Corporation overcharged the Government for building a guidance system for the MX missile.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: IT was not the best week for Calvin Klein. On Monday, the president of his Calvin Klein Industries resigned, and Mr. Klein dismissed two designers he had hired to develop tailored men's clothing. Then on Tuesday, the president of the Calvin Klein Classics division quit.

title: AS LAND SINKS INTO DEBT, CAN POOR STAY AFLOAT?
description: Every workday around 7 A.M. they begin to gather at the main downtown square here, the tools of their trade propped in front of them: plumbers, electricians, painters, carpenters, bricklayers, all hoping that someone will come along and offer them a day's work.

title: DOCTOR'S ORDERS: REST FOR MATTINGLY
description: Don Mattingly, one of the two Yankee stars who are missing the important series with the Toronto Blue Jays this week, was able to bend over and touch his toes yesterday, but it will be at least two more weeks before he can bend over and field a ground ball in a game.

title: New Currency To Be Delayed
description: The Treasury Department said today that technical problems would force a delay of up to two years in issuing the first redesigned American currency in a half-century.

title: OPEC Output Is Called High
description: OPEC members as a whole are producing well above the oil output quota set last December, and complacency in the oil market could be rudely shattered by oversupply, the Middle East Economic Survey warned today.

title: Lighter Military Satellites
description: Questioning decades of dependence on large military satellites orbiting the earth, Pentagon scientists are quietly studying a switch to swarms of small, lightweight, low-cost satellites that would be more likely to survive war in space.

title: Apple Names Sales Executive
description: Apple Computer Inc. said today that it had promoted Charles M. Boesenberg to senior vice president and group executive, United States sales and marketing. Mr. Boesenberg, 38 years old, succeeds William V. Campbell, who in April was named president of Apple's new applications software subsidiary.

title: Officer Resigns At Crazy Eddie
description: Mitchell Antar has resigned as executive vice president and chief operating officer of Crazy Eddie Inc., the consumer electronics concern that is the target of two takeover bids.

title: STANLINE INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: The year-ago share earnings were restated to give effect retroactively to the 5 percent common stock dividend paid by the company in December 1986.

title: Stop Homelessness Before It Starts
description: The cost of housing New York City's 4,800 homeless families is $125 million a year and counting. That spending, by Federal, state and city agencies, is urgently needed but it's not cost effective. It's much cheaper to keep a family from becoming homeless in the first place, which is good reason to welcome an experiment that provides services to families at risk.

title: Bank Losses in Japan
description: Japanese banks have reported losses totaling $243.6 million in connection with loans to Mexico, banking sources said today. The 28 banks sold $580 million of Mexican loans to a company they jointly own in the Cayman Islands at 58 percent of book value, a move that helps them get tax relief from the Government. Japanese banks' exposure to Mexican debt totals about $11 billion.

title: POPE, IN POLAND, BACKS HUMAN RIGHTS
description: Pope John Paul II, arriving in his native land today, urged the Polish leadership to follow a policy that insures respect for human rights and human dignity and allows wide citizen participation in public life.

title: No Headline
description: Dana Buchman is a name to remember. It belongs to a 35-year-old designer who recently showed her first collection of sportswear to several hundred store buyers and fashion executives who had to stand around in an unfinished showroom.

title: TEACHING ENGINEERING: BUDGET WOES
description: Engineering students are suffering because the need for expensive computers is leaving colleges without adequate laboratory equipment, according to a results of a survey presented to a congressional subcommittee recently.

title: MANHATTAN INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: The share earnings and shares outstanding were adjusted for 4 percent stock dividend payable on July 1, 1987, to shareholders of record on June 10, 1987. Non-recurring items include gains on the termination of pension plans of $946,000 for the latest first quarter and $5,157,000 for the year-ago period. The net income for the latest quarter is after a tax provision of $500,000, and an offsetting extraordinary tax credit of $500,000, or 9 cents a share.

title: Nuclear Panel Is Re-examining G.E. Documents
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission is re-examining documents of the General Electric Company that raised questions about the safety and design quality of some of the company's nuclear plants.

title: HENRY J. MALI
description: Henry J. Mali, chief executive officer of the nation's oldest and largest manufacturer of billiard table cloth, died yesterday at his home in Manhattan. He was 87 years old.

title: DURO-TEST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
RESEARCH-COTTRELL SALE TO INVESTOR GROUP SET
description: An investor group headed by Odyssey Partners, Allen & Company Inc. and First Chicago Venture Capital has signed an agreement to buy Research-Cottrell Inc. in a leveraged buyout for $43 a share, or $293 million, the builder of water, air and waste treatment plants said yesterday.

title: HEAR THE THUD? YANKS FALL TO 2d
description: They clung to first place for 25 days, but last night the Yankees finally relinquished their hold. In the aftermath, they talked about the relative insignificance of one game in the midst of a long, hot season; what they could not ignore was the growing source of their troubles.

title: U.S. Moves to Reclaim 3 Historic Park Sites
description: The Interior Department has announced a program to save a historic Pennsylvania mansion, a West Virginia hiking trail and a Tennessee-Kentucky recreation area from harm caused by abandoned coal mines.

title: OFFICER ACCUSED IN HOSPITAL CLASH
description: A New York City police officer was suspended without pay yesterday pending the outcome of an investigation by the Police Department's Internal Affairs Division into charges that he drew a gun during a dispute with a doctor at Harlem Hospital last week.

title: Flyers' Hextall Honored
description: Ron Hextall, the Philadelphia Flyers' 23-year-old rookie goaltender, accepted Sport Magazine's Most Valuable Player Award for the Stanley Cup final in Manhattan yesterday. Hextall received a trophy in the form of a silver-plated skate along with a station wagon.

title: Harvard Scholar in Sit-In Over Tenure Cases
description: Harvard Law School's first tenured black professor today began what he says will be a four-day sit-in in his office to protest the school's denial of tenure to two faculty members who adhere to a controversial left-wing ideology on legal studies.

title: VOLT INFORMATION SCIENCES reports earnings for Qtr to May 1
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $3,165,000 for the quarter and 6 months. c-Net income The latest quarter net from operations includes gains on the sale of securities of $719,000, or 7 cents a share, compared with similar gains of $600,000, or 6 cents a share, for the year-ago period. The latest 6 months' net from operations includes gains on the sale of securities of $1,462,000, or 14 cents a share, compared with similar gains of $679,000, or 7 cents a share, for the year-ago period. The latest quarter and 6 months' results also include a pretax charge of $1,070,000 for losses in connection with a change in the methods of operations in Europe. In the year-ago 6 months, translation losses were recorded as a direct charge to stockholders' equity. The latest 6 months' results include a pretax profit, net of expenses, of $2,382,000 on the settlement of an insurance claim in the first quarter arising from a fire loss in a foreign branch.

title: WORLD CONTAINER CORP reports earnings for Year to Feb 28
GANDALF TECHNOLOGIES reports earnings for 13wks to May 2
description: The company said the main reason for higher net income was a reduction in manufacturing costs. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Questions for Driesell
description: The University of Maryland will ask Lefty Driesell, its former basketball coach and now an assistant athletic director, to clarify his comments that cocaine can be ''performance enhancing'' for some athletes. ''Our reasons are kind of fundamental; we're basically interested in the health of the individual who is taking drugs,'' the university's vice chancellor, Dr. A. H. Edwards, said yesterday. ''It's a detriment to health, I think that's clear.''

title: 3 at Kidder Linked to Inquiry
description: The Government is investigating three current or former officials of Kidder, Peabody & Company for their possible role in an illegal stock ''parking'' scheme with Ivan F. Boesky, according to several people with knowledge of the investigation.

title: ANTI-DRUG EFFORTS GAINING IN SWEDEN
description: During her trip to Sweden this week, Nancy Reagan, America's best-known drug fighter, has viewed one of the most comprehensive and effective national efforts to combat drug abuse in the world.

title: TRANSNATIONAL INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net income

title: Coalition Planning Hearings On Racism in New York City
description: A coalition of 60 civil-rights, civil-liberties and religious organizations has announced that it will hold a series of public hearings this month on racism in New York City.

title: Canada to Lift Offshore Ban
description: British Columbia and the Canadian Government are working on the final stages of a plan to lift a 16-year-old moratorium on oil and gas exploration off Canada's west coast.

title: Tough, Not Smart, in the Gulf
description: It's time to get tough in the Persian Gulf, says the Reagan Administration. Beyond keeping warships on patrol, it wants to put the American flag on Kuwaiti oil tankers and thus offer American protection. And it threatens retaliation if Iran deploys Chinese-made Silkworm missiles against American-flagged vessels and warships.

title: Arms and Politics
description: Two elected officials who have said recently that they are mulling over joining the crowd running for the Democratic Presidential nomination addressed a rally Monday night in the capital of advocates for a ban on nuclear arms tests.

title: Electronic Data To Withdraw
description: The Electronic Data Systems Corporation said today that it would withdraw from a competition for a 10-year, $4.5 billion contract to build a telecommunications network for Federal agencies.

title: SIZELER PROPERTY INVESTORS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The year-ago results are not available; the company commenced operations during the first quarter of 1987.

title: Winter Wheat Crop Up
description: The Agriculture Department said today that 1987 winter wheat production was estimated at 1.58 billion bushels, up 4 percent from last year's harvest of 1.52 billion bushels, and 2 percent more than forecast a month ago. The average yield, based on indications as of June 1, was estimated at 40.6 bushels per acre, compared with last year's 35.2 bushels per harvested acre, and 39.9 bushels indicated in May. Farmers are expected to harvest about 38.9 million acres this year, down 10 percent from 43.2 million acres in 1986. Winter wheat is planted in the fall and harvested the following summer. It makes up about three-fourths of the total American wheat production.

title: INACOMP COMPUTER CENTERS reports earnings for Qtr to May 2
Election Panel Terms Bush Eligible for Matching Funds
description: Vice President Bush is eligible to receive Federal matching funds in his race for the Republican Presidential nomination, the Federal Election Commission said today.

title: PANEL SUGGESTS LAWS TO PROTECT BATTERED WOMEN
description: A panel of women's rights advocates, public officials and civic leaders yesterday recommended new laws and criminal-justice revisions in New York State to protect battered women and to help the police, the courts and other agencies in assisting victims of domestic violence.

title: INSIDER CITED IN BURLINGTON BID
description: Dominion Textile Inc. was uninterested in pursuing a hostile takeover of Burlington Industries until it received valuable information about the company from a former Burlington executive, according to a Federal court's ruling.

title: JOHN K. SCHEMMER
description: John K. Schemmer, a New York lawyer, died of cancer Monday at his home in Pawling, N.Y. He was 70 years old and also lived in Manhattan.

title: The U.N. Today: June 10, 1987
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: John I. Taylor, Ex-President Of Boston Globe, Dies at 75
description: John I. Taylor, a former president of The Boston Globe, died Sunday at his home in Natick, Mass. He was 75 years old.

title: Nathan Leites Is Dead at 75; Was Expert on Soviet Union
description: Nathan C. Leites, an expert on the Soviet Union who did detailed studies of leaders and policies for the United States Government, died Friday in France, where he was living in retirement. He was 75 years old.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: WEDNESDAY, JUNE 10, 1987
description: International A3-15 At the Venice summit, the leaders of the seven major industrial democracies issued a declaration endorsing freedom of navigation in the Persian Gulf. It fell short of the Administration's wishes for a stern warning to Iran. Page A1 The President is suffering setbacks at the seven-nation summit conference in Venice, according to American and other participants. Officials said no noteworthy economic policy proposals were likely. A1 News analysis: The Venice summit was predicted to have had ''important developments'' by the White House chief of staff. But other key aides to President Reagan sounded a good deal more defensive, especially in private. A10 News analysis: Important questions about the Iran-contra affair remain unanswered. Precisely what President Reagan knew and did will not be known until Rear Adm. John M. Poindexter and Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North, testify. A1 Fawn Hall testified about details of how she helped Col. North alter, shred or remove documents implicating him in the Iran-contra affair. It was her second day of testimony. A15 In Britain, the Labor Party leader has used stinging sarcasm as a penetrating weapon against Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's self-assurance. But Neil Kinnock's combativeness counts for only so much. A1 Accusations stir protests in Panama

title: Court Picks Trump In Fight for Resorts
description: A Florida probate judge cleared the way yesterday for Donald J. Trump, the New York developer, to buy control of Resorts International Inc., the hotel and gambling casino operator, for $101 million in cash.

title: IT'S MAGIC! SHOT WITH :02 LEFT GIVES LAKERS 3-1 LEAD
description: A 12-foot running hook shot by Earvin (Magic) Johnson with 2 seconds remaining tonight enabled the Los Angeles Lakers, trailing by 16 points in the third period, to edge the Boston Celtics, 107-106.

title: RECITAL: CHORBERG AND COLETTA
description: FOR better and worse, the veteran violin-viola team of Israel Chorberg and Harold Coletta played at their recital Sunday afternoon in Merkin Concert Hall as though performing was as casual to them as breathing.

title: KDI Sells 3 Units
description: The KDI Corporation said it had sold three of its businesses for a total of $34.2 million in cash. KDI said it had agreed to sell its two chemical distribution businesses, the Nerbert-Verkamp-Calvert Chemical Company and the M. J. Daly Company - to an investor group that includes the president of the unit, Dean Gaudin. In addition, the company said it would sell its KDI Composite Technology Inc. unit to Allied-Signal Inc. The three units had total sales of $45.5 million in 1986, the company said.

title: WOMAN SLASHED IN KNIFE ATTACK AT BROWNSTONE
description: A 26-year-old woman was slashed in the face with a knife as she returned to her brownstone in Brooklyn Heights early yesterday. Moments later, a group of pedestrians, alerted by her cries for help, chased and cornered the suspect until the police arrived, the authorities said.

title: BREAKTHROUGH REPORTED ON ALBANY ETHICS CODE By JEFFREY SCHMALZ
description: After months of bitter dispute, Governor Cuomo and leading legislators announced a breakthrough today on a major issue that has held up agreement on a stricter government ethics code.

title: Marshalls Reported To Get New Head
description: Marshalls, the nation's biggest retailer of discounted apparel, will soon name Francis H. Arnone as its president to oversee a turnaround strategy that is expected to fully materialize this year, informed retailing executives said yesterday.

title: Setback for Borden
description: A high court blocked the American food conglomerate Borden Inc. from placing its plastic lemon juice container in British supermarkets. Judge Raymond Walton said a plan by Borden to market Realemon in Britain was an attempt to confuse shoppers because of the container's similarity in shape and size to a popular British product, Jif, made by Reckitt & Coleman. Both products use lemon-shaped plastic squeeze containers. The judge said Borden could market its lemon product if it were packaged differently.

title: Toast of Tokyo: Push-Button Bread
description: For those who have spent hours kneading dough, only to see it shrivel in the oven, Japanese companies are selling an automatic fresh bread machine.

title: PALL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 2
House Panel Hears Pleas to Improve Airlines
description: Support is growing in Congress for measures to correct deficiencies in airline safety and service standards that lawmakers believe declined under deregulation of the industry.

title: Rome Explosions Shake U.S. and British Embassies and Wreck Car
description: Two bombs exploded on the grounds of the American and British embassies here early today, and a third ripped apart a car in a side street next to the American Embassy compound, according to the police and witnesses.

title: SURPLUS TO PASS KOCH ESTIMATE, REGAN PREDICTS
description: New York City will have a $700 million surplus at the end of its fiscal year June 30, State Comptroller Edward V. Regan said yesterday.

title: Market Place; Many Bullish On Wal-Mart
description: ''WE continue to be enthusiastic about the outlook for Wal-Mart and recommend purchase of the stock for near-term and long-term appreciation.'' Those were Walter F. Loeb's opening words Monday morning when the retailing analyst briefed the sales force at his firm, Morgan Stanley & Company.

title: WASHINGTON TALK: Avocations; Networking at the Poker Table
description: Representative Buddy Roemer earned more at Harvard College than a degree in government and economics. He learned a love of poker that he has nurtured into an income-producing ''hobby,'' making him the House of Representative's only publicly declared card shark.

title: PACO PHARMACEUTICAL SERVCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 9
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $356,787 related to union multi-pension fund matters for the quarter and 9 months.

title: Haig Assesses Middle
description: Alexander M. Haig Jr., a contender for the Republican Presidential nomination, believes that a major Republican advantage for 1988 is that ''the Democratic Party remains in the grasp of the ultraliberal left,'' a category in which he includes all current contenders for the Democratic Presidential nomination.

title: ROCCO LANDESMAN NAMED JUJAMCYN THEATERS HEAD
description: Rocco Landesman, one of Broadway's so-called young Turk producers, will become president of Jujamcyn Theaters, the smallest of the three Broadway theater-owning groups, it was announced yesterday.

title: The Editorial Notebook; Borrowing Trouble for Raiders
description: You're the C.E.O. of a conglomerate whose latest acquisition, a fast food chain featuring Tex-Mex sushi, has given your balance sheet acute gastritis. You've redesigned the corporate logo and changed the name from Amalgamated Asphalt to Pacific Synergis but that hasn't distracted anyone from the prospect of poor earnings next quarter. As a result PacSyn stock is down to $50, half its worth.

title: Banking His Views
description: When Edward Kelley, a largely unknown former investment counselor from Texas, went before the Senate Banking Committee last month to be confirmed as a member of the Federal Reserve Board, he took with him a prepared statement expressing his views.

title: JAYS CRUSH SPUTTERING YANKS
description: Frustration. It seemed to build within Lou Piniella in the fifth inning last night, his team already losing by four runs and the game pointing decisively toward another forgettable defeat at the Stadium.

title: WOMAN CHARGED WITH BITING OFFICER
description: A woman arrested as a prostitute in Manhattan last week has been charged with attempted assault and reckless endangerment after she bit one of the arresting officers and then announced that she had AIDS, the authorities said.

title: THE STAGE: 'BIGFOOT STOLE MY WIFE'
description: CAN it be that there is reality behind the sensational come-ons of the supermarket tabloids? Ron Carlson's ''Bigfoot Stole My Wife'' answers that question in the affirmative, with six monologues by people who should know. In the title tale, for example, a car mechanic (to judge by his Ferrari T-shirt) tells how he returned one day from the racetrack, where he passes much of his time, to discover his Trudy gone, with her dog, her car and most of her clothes. What other explanation can there be than that Bigfoot, the fabled creature of the tabloids, has carried her off?

description: A group led by the New York brokerage firm Bear, Stearns & Company holds a 6.8 percent stake in Becor Western Inc. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Bear, Stearns said that it had no arrangements to provide investment banking services to any company involved in the battle for Becor, but added that it ''may do so in the future.'' Becor Western Inc. has received two bids: a $238.1 million offer from senior management and Goldman, Sachs & Company, and an offer from the Lynch Corporation, an affiliate of the New York financier Mario J. Gabelli, with an estimated value of $255.1 million.

title: HIGH COURT BACKS RIGHTS OF OWNERS IN LAND-USE SUITS
description: Handing a major victory to property owners, the Supreme Court ruled 6 to 3 today that they are entitled to compensation for government regulations that deprive them of reasonable use of their land, not merely to invalidation of the rules.

description: THE supermarket industry, seeking to cut costs, lure customers and promote items more effectively, is turning to new technology as never before.

title: U.S. Food Regulation: Tales From a Twilight Zone
description: WHATEVER happened to cyclamates, the artificial sweeteners we learned to love and then, with talk of cancer, leave? How about apples sprayed with Alar, candy dyed with Red No. 3 food coloring, irradiated foods and sodium nitrite in processed meats? Has the Federal Government decided whether these substances and treatments are hazardous to human health? If they are hazardous, why are they still in use?

title: So Seductive a Country and So Close to Vietnam
description: People here tell the story of Morgan Adams, an American diplomat who resigned ''for unexplained reasons'' and now lives in Thailand among opium warlords and beautiful women, rejecting what he calls the regimentation of life in the United States.

description: Governor Kean ended a tour today of the fire-gutted heart of the amusement district of this Jersey Shore city with a promise of disaster relief. Local officials promptly started giving him the bills.

title: USTINOV IN 'IMMORTAL BEETHOVEN'
description: ''THE IMMORTAL BEETHOVEN,'' on Channel 49 at 9 and Channel 13 at 10 this evening, provides the equivalent of an introductory course to the life and work of the composer. The narrator is Peter Ustinov, reading a script by Israela Margalit, a pianist. Biographical details and colorful anecdotes are combined with excerpts from the major musical works. The strong lineup of performing artists includes, in addition to Ms. Margalit, the cellist Mischa Meisky, the pianist Vladimir Ashkenazy, the conductors Leonard Bernstein, Neville Marriner and Hans Zender, plus the Cherubini Quartet and the Vienna Symphony and the Vienna Philharmonic orchestras.

title: JOHN M. LYDEN
description: John M. Lyden, a former vice chairman of Ted Bates and Company, the advertising concern, died at his home in New Canaan, Conn. yesterday after a long illness. He was 81 years old.

title: Mets' 5 Errors Honey for Cubs; Cubs 6, Mets 5
description: For an encore, this is what the wayward Mets did today in Wrigley Field: They made five errors, four of them in one inning, two of them by Keith Hernandez on one play. For the second straight day, they blew a tie in the late innings. And, for the second straight day, they lost a close one to the Chicago Cubs.

description: The Sovran Financial Corporation is offering $100 million of 9 3/4 percent subordinated capital notes due 1999, at a price of 99.582, to yield 9.81 percent, through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: AS I write this column, my mouth is throbbing with pain caused by the very thing I am writing about: canker sores, an ailment as mysterious as it is common. It is hard to imagine how a sore so tiny can cause so much discomfort for so long. No matter what I do it seems determined, like the common cold, to run its seven-day course.

Beginning tomorrow night in an exhibition game against the Tidewater farm team, Tom Seaver will be trying to convince the Mets that he can still pitch at age 42, just as Tommy John had to convince the Yankees that he can still pitch.

title: Justices, in a Child Custody Case, Uphold States' Right to Gain Extradition
description: The Supreme Court, in a case involving charges of parental kidnapping, held today that state courts must honor procedurally proper requests to extradite people accused of crimes in other states even if the accused seem clearly innocent.

title: DANCE: BALLET SCHOOL IN ITS FINAL WORKSHOP
description: THE School of American Ballet offered its final workshop concert Monday night at the Juilliard Theater. After seeing it, one could only marvel at the energy of youth.

title: Fight AIDS Now, With Methadone
description: AIDS tests for immigrants and Federal prisoners: that's the Reagan Administration's response to the epidemic so far. They are defensible steps but mainly symbolic. If the Administration is serious about fighting AIDS, it could do so far more effectively, starting now, with methadone.

description: The first phase of the Iran-Contra hearings is now drawing to a close, and from the Administration's viewpoint it has been a disaster.

And since the murder of Jennifer Dawn Levin in Central Park last August, the lawyer for the man who has admitted killing her -and who is in the midst of pretrial hearings - has made an issue of the young woman's sexual past.

title: 11 Injured in Bus Accident
description: Eleven children from an elementary school in Hartford were injured, one seriously, this afternoon when a school bus rolled over on Route 11 near the junction of Route 82, the state police said. Lieut. Edward Dailey, a state police spokesman, said the children, from the Kennelly School, were returning from a class trip to Ocean Beach Park in New London when the accident occurred. The name of the seriously injured pupil was not released.

description: Guinness P.L.C., the giant British brewing and distilling company, is reportedly negotiating to acquire Schenley Industries, a distributor of Guinness's Dewar's Scotch whisky and Gordon's gin in the United States. The Times of London said yesterday that Guinness may have reached an agreement in principle a month ago with the Rapid-American Corporation, which owns Schenley.

description: The share earnings reflect a 20 percent stock dividend paid in February 1987.

description: Brooklyn College of the City University of New York awarded 1,422 bachelor's degrees and 828 master's degrees at its 62d commencement yesterday.

title: LIFE IN THE 30'S
description: WHEN I was 10 years old I broke my nose. I fell face down on a gravel driveway during a chicken fight, and when I got up there was more blood than you can imagine. I suppose there was pain, although I don't remember it. I do remember my mother running across the lawn, large and plaid in a maternity smock and Bermuda shorts, screaming, ''I have three boys and the one girl ruins her face!''

title: MUSIC: MEHTA CONDUCTS NEW YORK PHILHARMONIC
description: ZUBIN MEHTA, who is in the midst of a yearlong sabbatical from the New York Philharmonic, interrupted his idyll to return and conduct last night's special concert consisting of Bruckner's Symphony No. 8 in C minor and the New York premiere of a short Elliott Carter piece entitled ''A Celebration of Some 100 x 150 Notes.'' Because the Philharmonic is playing host this week to the 42d convention of the American Symphony Orchestra League, Mr. Mehta apparently felt it was his duty as music director to shuttle back from Vienna, where he was scheduled to conduct a new production of ''Otello'' just two days after this concert.

title: U.S. Professor Convicted in West Bank Disorders
description: After a four-month trial, an Israeli military court today convicted an American professor in the West Bank of disturbing the peace by taking part in an unauthorized Arab demonstration.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET

title: Test of Teachers For Use of Drugs Is Ruled Illegal

description: India said today that it would resist moves by its smaller neighbors to discuss its recent supply drop in northern Sri Lanka, which may come up at a meeting of regional leaders this weekend.

title: WINE MARKET DROPS TO A LOW FOR 1980'S
description: THE United States wine market declined 5.5 percent in 1986 to its lowest level in the 1980's, with shipments of table wine dropping fastest, according to Impact, a trade publication.

title: Sampson Balks

''They agreed to give me the same thing as Akeem,'' Sampson told KRIV-TV. ''We went in and tried to do what was best for Ralph Sampson and the Houston Rockets. But they didn't come up to what they said they would, so we'll hit the market with free agency and see what we can get from there.''

title: Correction
description: A chart that appeared yesterday with articles about Fawn Hall's testimony at the Iran-contra hearings incompletely described the arrangement under which she was given immunity from prosecution. She received immunity from the special prosecutor as well as from the Congressional committees.

title: Mets Draft a Center
description: Terry Bross, the starting center for the St. John's basketball team, has been drafted by the Mets as a pitcher and is apparently close to signing, a school spokesman said. Bross, a 6-foot-9-inch junior, was drafted by the Mets in the 13th round last week. The right-hander, whose fastball has been clocked at more than 90 miles an hour, had an 0-1 record with 17 strikeouts in 21Y innings for the Redmen this year.

description: * Amax Inc., Greenwich, Conn., a mineral and energy concern, said its chief financial officer, Martin V. Alonzo, would resign to ''pursue challenges and opportunities'' outside the company.

description: The investor Paul A. Bilzerian, undaunted by the Pay 'N Pak Stores Inc. decision to accept a management buyout, said today that he would again sweeten his bid for the retailer of home improvement products, to $220 million, from $210 million.

title: AILEEN INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 2
FILM: A DOCUMENTARY, 'CHILE: HASTA CUANDO?'
description: IN 1985, under the pretext of covering a music festival, David Bradbury, an Australian documentary maker, led a camera team to Chile to report on the state of the opposition to the regime of Gen. Augusto Pinochet 12 years after the coup that brought him to power. Mr. Bradbury, alas, found nothing new. The scenes of the police breaking up political demonstrations with water cannons, tear gas and clubs have become only too familiar in Chile, as in much of the rest of the world. ''Chile: Hasta Cuando?'' (''Chile: Until When?'') offers a close-up view of the continuing resistance and repression in one of South America's enduring dictatorships.

title: FAST CARS, YOUNG RIDERS: CRACKDOWN ON DRAG RACING By ERIC SCHMITT
description: It is Friday night, and the parking lot outside the Channel Home Center here is filling up with cars and the rumble of turbocharged engines, the squeal of tires and the blare of stereos.

title: Ex-Leader of F.A.S.B. Joins Columbia Faculty
description: Donald J. Kirk got his first taste of accounting while serving as a jet pilot on an aircraft carrier. He then came home and practiced accounting for 14 years, was a leader of the industry's standard-setting board for another 14 and now, is settling into a third career as an accounting teacher.

title: 3 Haulers of Refuse Charged on Pricing In Los Angeles Area
description: A local subsidiary of the nation's largest waste management company and two smaller companies were indicted here today, charged with setting prices and conspiring to eliminate competition in the trash hauling business.

title: Rates Fall Slightly In Citicorp Sales
description: Interest rates fell slightly at Citicorp's weekly auction of 91-day and 182-day commercial paper. The bank holding company sold $50 million of 91-day paper at an average rate of 6.95 percent, down from 7.0485 percent last week.

title: Anchors Aweigh
description: David Robinson, the 7-foot-1-inch all-American from the Naval Academy who is expected to be a top choice in the National Basketball Association draft, will begin his two years of active duty three days before the college draft - on June 19 at the Kings Bay, Ga., submarine base, which is 240 miles from Atlanta, the nearest N.B.A. franchise. The San Antonio Spurs have the first crack at Robinson, but that Texas city is 1,000 miles from Kings Bay. ''It doesn't look like he'll be playing any pro ball while being stationed in Kings Bay,'' said David's father, Ambrose, who declined to speculate if his son would sign with the Spurs.

title: LEBANESE POUND FALLS
description: The Lebanese pound slipped to a record low against the dollar today, reflecting public anxiety after the murder of Prime Minister Rashid Karami last week, dealers said. The pound closed at 126.60, down more than 2 pounds from the previous close of 124.45. The Prime Minister was killed in a midair bomb blast aboard an army helicopter June 1. The once-resilient pound, under pressure from Lebanon's continuing civil strife, has lost more than 34 percent of its international value this year.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Tennis Becker Trounces Doohan: Boris Becker of West Germany started his preparation for Wimbledon yesterday with a 6-2, 6-4 victory over Peter Doohan of Australia in the opening round of the $300,000 Stella Artois tournament at Queen's Club in London. Winning in just one hour on the grass courts, the top-seeded Becker lost only 11 points on serve and pulled out nine aces, including three in the last game. Two seeded players were eliminated: Yannick Noah, of France, seeded No. 4, lost by 3-6, 7-6, 6-3 to Andreas Maurer of West Germany, and 12th-seeded Slobodan Zivojinovic of Yugoslavia lost by 6-4, 7-6 to Nduka Odizor of Nigeria.(AP) Yachting Constitution's Anniversary Race: Luxembourg won the Constitution race, a trans-Atlantic yachting competition, yesterday. The race marked the 30th anniversary of the European Economic Community and the 200th anniversary of the signing of the United States Constitution. The winning yacht, sponsored by Luxembourg and skippered by Paul Van Tongerloo of Belgium, crossed the finish line in Cape May, N.J., at 11:45 A.M., organizers said. The lone United States yacht to enter the race, Philadelphia, skippered by John Kalish, lost 12 hours at the start when it had to make repairs after a collision with a spectator craft. Philadelphia and Portugal were vying for third place, about 400 miles behind the winner.(AP) Golf 20 Qualify for Open: Mike Smith of Selma, Ala., shot an 11-under-par 130 yesterday on 65, 65 at the par-71 Century Country Club and the par-70 Old Oaks Country Club in Purchase, N.Y., to lead 20 qualifiers into the 87th United States Open scheduled for June 18-21 at the Olympic Club in San Francisco. Barry Jaeckel of Palm Desert, Calif., had a 70 at Century and a 63 at Old Oaks to finish second at 133. A field of 107 - 97 pros - competed in the sectional qualifying conducted by the Metropolitan Golf Association. School Baseball Titles to Tottenville, Molloy: Tottenville of Staten Island defeated Cardozo of Queens, 7-2, at Shea Stadium yesterday to win the Public Schools Athletic League title. In the first game of a doubleheader, Archbishop Molloy won the Catholic High Schools Athletic Association title by defeating Fordham Prep, 11-4. Tottenville (25-1) will play Molloy (23-9) today at Shea in the Metro Bowl to decide the overall city champion.

title: Real Estate; Renovation Of 5th Ave. Tower
description: SINCE the early 1930's, 745 Fifth Avenue, the pale brick office tower at the corner of 58th Street, has been known not only for its distinctive wedding-cake silhouette but also as the home of the F.A.O. Schwarz toy store. But when the toy store left last year for new space in the General Motors Building across 58th Street, the 56-year-old building lost not only its main retail tenant but a good deal of its identity as well. It long ago had lost E. R. Squibb & Sons, the original major office tenant that had given the building its name.

title: FANCY DISHES AND GRACEFUL GLASSWARE
description: 1.Classic Plastic Your guests will think these Italian plates are ceramic, until they pick them up. They are heavy plastic, safe for the dishwasher and ideal for outdoor summer entertaining. A set of six, with a different floral pattern on each plate, costs $60 at Hubert des Forges, 1193 Lexington Avenue (81st Street). 2.Dressed to Go With this versatile cotton knit dress by Christian de Castelnau, women will never have someplace to go and nothing to wear this summmer. Long and simple, with shoulder pads and two hip pockets, it can be worn for daytime as well as evening. The dress comes in white, blue or cherry, and is $80 at T.Edwards, 805 Third Avenue, between 49th and 50th Streets. 3.Waisting Time Watches are everywhere these days, even on this soft black leather belt by Morgan Taylor. It features images of two quartz watches, large and small. For $68 in belts on the main floor at Macy's Herald Square. 4.Elegant Glass English pressed glass has evolved from a 19th-century decoration to a 20th-century collectible. This graceful celery vase, circa 1885, cost $125 and is just one in a large selection. Many pieces - including mugs, bowls, creamers and commemorative plates - are from private collections. The glass can be found in Connoisseur Collections on the ninth floor at Lord & Taylor, 424 Fifth Avenue (39th Street).

description: A former Ku Klux Klan member, David Duke, announced today that he was a candidate for the Democratic Presidential nomination and said he saw his chief opponent as the Rev. Jesse Jackson. Mr. Duke, a New Orleans resident who now heads the National Association for the Advancement of White People, said the confrontation would provoke intense interest in the political process and stimulate a heavy vote in the primaries.

title: ELIJAH MASINDE
description: Elijah Masinde, the leader of western Kenya's Dini ya Musambwa sect and an opponent of colonial and independent Kenyan governments, died Monday. He was 75 years old.

title: JULE STYNE, AT 81, JUST WON'T STAY PUT
description: I know a place where dreams are born And time is never planned It's not on any chart You must find it with your heart Never Never Land . . . But it is perceived as an undeserved defeat by DFS Dorland of New York, Royal Crown's agency for the last four years.

title: MANY BANKERS UPSET BY TALK OF 'SUPERBANKS'
description: Bankers across the nation are upset by reports that top Treasury officials favor the creation of ''superbanks'' - conglomerates that would be made up of big commercial banks and huge industrial companies.

title: ACCUSATIONS STIR PROTESTS IN PANAMA

description: Revillon Inc., the internationally known furrier, was ordered yesterday to pay more than $2 million in sales taxes and penalties to New York City and State.

description: Israel has agreed in principle to let American investigators question a senior Israeli official about the country's role in the Iran arms affair, a newspaper reported today.

title: Abrams Is Backed by Shultz
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz vigorously defended his assistant, Elliott Abrams, today, saying that he had violated no laws and had Administration support from ''top to bottom.''

title: Advertising Age Publisher Retires
description: Louis F. DeMarco, 62 years old, has retired as publisher of Advertising Age and has been replaced by David D. Persson, 44, who is returning to the trade publication from the publisher's slot at Electronics Media. Both are publications of Crain Communications.

description: Federal prosecutors in Brooklyn disclosed yesterday that the Government had obtained secret tape recordings of John Gotti, the reputed boss of the Gambino organized crime family, discussing how he would reorganize the family shortly after he obtained control of the Mafia group.

title: Intelligence Budget Vote
description: The House, approved a bill today by voice vote setting the spending ceiling for intelligence gathering next year after adding a requirement for a report on the espionage capacities of the new Soviet Embassy complex in Washington. The amount of the appropriation, a classified secret, is to pay for intelligence activities in the fiscal year starting Oct. 1.

description: Kevin O'Brien, an assistant United States attorney who has prosecuted political corruption cases, has been appointed chief counsel of the State Commission on Integrity in Government.

Dating to 2,500 B.C., they document the concept of unity between nutrition and function, and reinforce the precept of Indian herbal medicine: that food and health are inseparable.

But when it came time for one team to take the boldest step toward controlling the series, it was as if no one was on the court except Earvin (Magic) Johnson and Larry Bird.

description: In a sweeping reversal of its strategy, the Allegis Corporation announced last night that it had replaced its chairman and intended to sell the company's rental car and hotel subsidiaries.

title: Economic Scene; Photos, Futility And Fatuities
description: VENICE could be the summit to end all economic summits. The congresses of the heads of the major industrial democracies that began at Rambouillet, outside Paris, in 1975 and continued in successive years through Puerto Rico, London, Bonn, Tokyo, Venice, Ottawa, Versailles, Williamsburg, London again, Bonn again and now Venice again have degenerated into opportunities for photos and fatuities.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: SUZANNE LOEBL, half daydreaming, was walking along Riverside Drive, gazing at the shimmering Hudson River and the George Washington Bridge. All at once a station wagon pulled up. Peering in the rear window, she saw an assemblage of wedding cakes -five wedding cakes, by swift count. One, a gazebo with latticework, had french doors and a roof decorated with little flower pots. Another was in the shape of a basket decorated with yellow and white flowers. A third consisted of three layers, each one supported by fluted columns. A fourth . . . . But by then Ms. Loebl's mind was spinning in wonderment. Who was getting married? Why so many cakes? Where was the wagon heading? ''We're lost,'' the driver said before she had a chance to ask. ''How do we get to Tiffany?'' the other passenger inquired.

description: Senator John B. Breaux, chairman of a Senate subcommittee with direct legislative authority over the Nuclear Regulatory Commission, today became the seventh member of Congress to demand the resignation of Commissioner Thomas M. Roberts.

title: BLUE JAYS SINGING DIFFERENT TUNE THIS YEAR
description: A clubhouse scene: It is the middle of the afternoon, still several hours before their work day will begin, but the room already has started to fill with players. Some are sitting near a television set watching a taped replay of a Yankee game; others are slowly dressing at their lockers. Many are engaged in quiet conversation, their voices almost inaudible, like a bad connection on a long-distance call.

title: Three Are Sentenced Over the Terrorizing Of Teachers in West
description: A case in which the owners of a chain of private elementary schools in Southern California hired a man to terrorize dismissed teachers has been concluded with the sentencing of three people One of the owners of the schools, Charlotte Wyckoff, 53 years old, was sentenced Monday to two years in prison by Federal District Judge Alicemarie Stotler. Mrs. Wyckoff is to be given credit for time served, which is likely to result in probation. She was ordered to pay about $3,000 restitution.

title:

Virtuous Gazpacho

This Andalusian fresh vegetable soup can do virtually no wrong, especially if you refrain from salt (or go lightly), and add only enough olive oil to fill it with that distinctive flavor and give it a little unctuousness.

title: Scrubbing Statues
description: New York City's Comptroller, Harrison Goldin, points out that of the city's 800 statues, only a handful pay tribute to women. He wants the Parks Department to rectify the imbalance by commissioning a statue of Eleanor Roosevelt. The motive is good. But the request seems off target given the far more urgent need to care for the city's existing treasury of public art.

title: Soviet Grain Outlook
description: The Soviet Union still appears to be headed for a bumper grain harvest this year despite a late spring that delayed planting of some key grain crops, the Agriculture Department said Tuesday. Grain production over all was estimated at 195 million metric tons, unchanged from the department's initial forecast made a month ago. Although that would be down from last year's bumper harvest of 210.1 million tons, the 1987 harvest would still be one of the largest on record. However, the report said the lateness of spring this year reduced total grain plantings to 115 million hectares, down from 116.5 million last year and the smallest area for Soviet grain since 1959.

title: ALLEGATIONS IN MYERSON CASE 'SHOCK' JUDGE'S DAUGHTER
description: A former aide to Bess Myerson said yesterday that she was shocked by allegations that she had been hired to influence her mother improperly. The aide's mother, a judge, had been handling a divorce case involving Ms. Myerson's longtime companion, Carl A. Capasso.

title: LAMPLIGHT FOR OVERHEAD
description: STANLEY COREN, owner of the Beige Gallery, has two collections of hanging lamps. One consists of more than 100 milk-glass lamps that were fixtures in a store in Albany. They are usually called American schoolhouse lamps, Mr. Coren said, because they were used in classrooms all over the United States after 1900. They are $100 each. The second group comprises lamps of Swedish case glass, in which glass is encased or covered by a second layer, usually of a different color. The white inner layers in Mr. Coren's are covered with glass in orange, turquoise, olive green, gray, pale blue or white. Designed in the late 50's, the lamps came from a store in Poughkeepsie, N.Y., that closed in 1960. ''The lamps were leftovers from the store's inventory and were never used,'' he said. They are also $100 each. From left to right: A Swedish inverted champagne flute-shaped lamp in pale aqua, an orange flared horn-shaped lamp, a white schoolhouse lamp and a white Swedish lamp. The Beige Gallery is at 119 Greenwich Avenue, near Jane Street.

title: BENNETT, IN SHIFT, URGES END TO DRIVE FOR EDUCATION CUTS

description: Completions of new homes rose 7.4 percent in April to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1.82 million units, the Commerce Department said today.

description: Shirley Lord Anderson, a senior editor at Vogue magazine, was married yesterday to A.M. Rosenthal, columnist, associate editor and former executive editor of The New York Times.

title: Driesell Clarifies
description: Lefty Driesell, the former basketball coach of the University of Maryland, says his remarks that cocaine can enhance the performance of an athlete have been misinterpreted.

title: NEW JERSEY GAMBLES ON BOUTS
description: Boxing's biggest fights in this country have traditionally landed in Las Vegas, Nev.

title: House Rejects Measure to Allow Tenants to Buy Units at Discount
description: As the House of Representatives today moved toward passage of a major housing bill, it defeated a key provision that would have given tenants of public housing the right to buy their apartments at 25 percent of market value.

title: WALSH WIDENS HIS INQUIRY AT STATE DEPT.
description: The special prosecutor in the Iran-contra affair has broadened his criminal investigation of senior State Department officials involved in raising money for Nicaraguan rebel groups, according to Reagan Administration officials.

title: JWT STOCK SOARS ON $ 45 BID
description: A leading British marketing services concern yesterday offered to buy the JWT Group, the parent of the J. Walter Thompson advertising agency, for $45 a share in cash, or about $420 million. JWT's stock surged on the news.

title: Disorder in Indian Country
description: LEAD: In Window Rock, on the Navajo Indian reservation in northeastern Arizona, Mrs. Aliene Lee wonders why the man who shot her in the head twice and raped and murdered her daughter, Priscilla Lee Yazza, three years ago hasn't been caught yet.

title: John Astley Gray Dies at 87; Won Britain's Cheapest War
description: Air Vice Marshal John Astley Gray, who as a pilot was instrumental in the defeat in 1920 of an African rebel known as the Mad Mullah in what was Britain's cheapest war, has died at the age of 87, his family announced today.

title: Comex to Open Earlier For Gold, Silver Trades
description: The Commodity Exchange Inc. announced yesterday that it would expand its gold and silver trading hours by opening the markets earlier, beginning Monday.

title: Events
description: Crafts Fair and Historic Houses Rhinebeck Crafts Fair in Rockland County, field house at Rockland Community College, College Road (exit 14B, New York State Thruway), Suffern; 914-268-3093 or 914-356-4650.

title: KEY RATES
30% Increase Seen In Apple's '87 Sales
description: Apple Computer Inc., the second-largest American computer maker, said sales in the 1987 fiscal year are expected to rise 30 percent from the $1.9 billion recorded in the previous year. Robert Saltmarsh, the company's treasurer, and Roger Kermisch, the European general manager, said in an interview that sales by Apple's European unit would probably grow 50 percent this year from the $300 million recorded in the 1986 fiscal year.

title: A SPACIOUS SUNKEN GARDEN WILL BLOOM IN SAN ANTONIO
description: EMILIO AMBASZ'S designs are primal, yet rich -as basic as a child's set of blocks, yet as complex and multilayered as a sonnet. He is a designer who probes architecture's fundamentals, struggling to release the emotion and intensity that lie beneath the surface of everyday experience. His work does not look like the work of any other designer actively practicing today, but it is neither mysterious nor bizarre; indeed, it has a strangely natural quality to it, a startling appropriateness.

title: Drug Testing Is Questioned
description: As drug testing in the workplace becomes more prevalent nationwide, employers must decide whether it is worth the ''ill will'' and expense to test the entire work force to find a few drug users, Government and business officials said today.

title: NICKLAUS AND SON IN WESTCHESTER FIELD
description: He has won more major golf tournaments than anyone in the history of the game, but he plays infrequently now and he is 96th on the money list this year, a rather unfamiliar position for Jack Nicklaus, .

title: Toyota Studies Europe Production
description: The Toyota Motor Corporation, Japan's largest auto maker, said it was studying the possibility of producing vehicles in Europe. Asahi Shimbun, a nationally circulated newspaper, had reported that Toyota and Volkswagenwerk A.G. of West Germany planned to produce about 5,000 commercial vehicles a month next year at an idle VW plant in Germany.

title: Adoptive Parents Keep A Navajo Boy for Now
description: A Navajo tribal judge today granted temporary custody of a 10-year-old Navajo boy to his white adoptive parents pending a custody trial that is expected to begin in about two months, lawyers in the case said.

title: AUDIT CRITICIZES TRANSIT AUTHORITY
description: The New York City Transit Authority's procedures for responding to emergencies have inconvenienced and possibly endangered subway riders, according to an audit by State Comptroller Edward V. Regan.

title: WHEREHOUSE ENTERTAINMENT reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: The year-ago results have been restated to reflect the 5-for-4 stock split paid Aug. 15, 1986, to shareholders of record July 25, 1986.

title: First Chicago, S.E.C. Settle
description: The First Chicago Corporation agreed today to revise its 1983 and 1984 financial statements in response to charges by the Securities and Exchange Commission that the company failed to provide adequate reserves for loan losses in 1983.

title: Dispute Over Military Stalemates '88 Budget
description: Senate Democrats this evening rejected a compromise offer from House Democrats on the 1988 budget and left the outlook for an agreement uncertain.

title: A PLANT FOR MOST SEASONS
description: A FRIEND who is not a gardener says that he might take up the hobby if someone could point out just one plant truly worthy of his attention.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Tennis Jelen Upsets Wilander: Mats Wilander, the No. 3 seeded player, was upset, 6-3, 6-7, 6-4, by Eric Jelen of West Germany yesterday in the first round of the Stella Artois championships at Queens Club in London. Wilander, the loser in Sunday's French Open final, was the third seeded player to be eliminated in the pre-Wimbledon grass-court event. Tuesday's losers included Yannick Noah and Slobodan Zivojinovic. But Jimmy Connors, a three-time winner of this event, beat Danie Visser of South Africa, 6-3, 6-4, and Sweden's Stefan Edberg, seeded second, became the first player to reach the third round with a 7-6, 6-4 victory over Kelly Evernden of New Zealand. Edberg saved four set points in the first-set tiebreaker.(AP) Shriver Defeats Reinach: Top-seeded Pam Shriver came back for a 6-4, 6-2 victory over Elna Reinach of South Africa in the second round of the Edgbaston Cup women's tournament in Birmingham, England, while two beaten seeded players complained about playing conditions. Bettina Bunge of West Germany, seeded third, said the grass courts were slippery and dangerous in her 1-6, 7-5, 6-2 loss to Svetlana Parkhomenko of the Soviet Union. Jo Durie of Britain, seeded 12th, lost to Akito Tijimuta of Japan, 4-6, 7-5, 7-5, in a match moved indoors as organizers tried to make up rain-postponed matches. Another seeded player eliminated outdoors yesterday was Catarina Lindqvist of Sweden, seeded fourth, who lost to Anne White, 6-3, 6-4. In the completion of a first-round match stopped by rain Tuesday, Elise Burgin beat Britain's Annabel Croft, 7-6, 7-6. (AP) High School Baseball Tottenville Beats Molloy: Tottenville of Staten Island capitalized on a four-run first inning and the complete- game pitching of Jason Donnelly to defeat Archbishop Molloy of Queens, 6-2, yesterday at Shea Stadium to win the Metro Bowl. It was the second straight year that Tottenville had won the game, which matches the Catholic league and public school league baseball champions for the city title.

title: ISCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 1
Firefighters Lose Jobs In Refusing AIDS Duty
description: A longtime firefighter was dismissed today and another has resigned after they refused to handle an AIDS patient.

title: A Presbyterian Leader Selected in Close Vote
description: Isabel Rogers, a Christian educator from Virginia, was narrowly elected today to lead the nation's largest Presbyterian denomination, the Presbyterian Church (U.S.A.).

title: On the Road
description: Is a winning road record essential for pennant contention? So far this season, there is no clear answer. In the National League, the four teams with the best road records are battling for division leads. On the other hand, Baltimore and Seattle have the best road records in the American League but are in the middle of the pack over all because of a puzzling inability to win before home fans. The 11 major league teams with winning records away from home: NATIONAL LEAGUE
