description: Following are excerpts from the Summary of Conclusions of the report by Harold R. Tyler Jr. on his investigation of Bess Myerson.:

title: BALLET: RENVALL IN 'SYLPHIDE'
description: ''LA SYLPHIDE,'' known as the first Romantic ballet when it was created in France in 1832 and then rechoreographed in Denmark in 1836, tells an anguished tale of a human life destroyed. And yet August Bournonville's Danish version, for years the only staging of the ballet extant, can send the viewer smiling into the street.

title: BRAZIL WANTS DELAY ON I.M.F. DEBT
description: Brazil wants to postpone the payment of $1.1 billion due this year to the International Monetary Fund, according to a report today by the official Brazilian news agency.

title: VENICE TALKS CONCLUDE IN A MOOD OF SATISFACTION, BUT LITTLE PROGRESS
description: The 13th conference of the major non-Communist industrial nations ended today with a sober appraisal of the world economy and a series of generalized proposals to deal with persistent problems like unemployment and protectionism.

title: NATIONAL LOTTERY: NEITHER DESIRABLE NOR INEVITABLE
description: To the Editor:

title: A DESIGNER LOOK FOR CABBIES?
description: New York cabbies may not always know where they are going, but some may soon look as though they have arrived.

title: Payton Accepts Terms
description: Walter Payton, the National Football League's career rushing leader, said yesterday he has reached terms on a one-year contract with the Chicago Bears. Payton, who will turn 33 next month, said he is still considering retiring after next season. Financial details of the new agreement were not disclosed, and Ken Valdiserri, a spokesman for the Bears, said club policy was to announce contracts ''only after they've been signed, and Walter has not actually signed his.''

title: Less for Lunch
description: The North Servery in the Dirksen Senate Office Building is pushing a new line of low-salt, low-cholesterol and low-calorie lunches.

title: ACCORD SETTLES BIAS DAMAGES AT DAILY NEWS
description: The Daily News reached an out-of-court settlement yesterday with four black journalists who had charged the newspaper with race discrimination, ending a long Federal trial in Manhattan.

title: TWO RECEIVE AWARDS
description: Frank Gehry and Patrick Naggar have been named winners of the first annual House and Garden Design Awards for outstanding achievement in residential design in the United States. Each will receive $25,000.

title: U.S. OPPOSES BID TO SHIFT SOIL TAINTED BY RADIUM IN JERSEY
description: The Secretary of the Interior has told Governor Kean that he will oppose a plan to move 15,000 barrels of radium-contaminated soil from the northern part of New Jersey to a wildlife refuge within a protected area of the Pine Barrens.

title: CONCERT: VILLAGE ORCHESTRA
description: WITH so many fine musical outfits around the city presenting the standard repertory, many lesser groups realize they contribute most by digging up unusual pieces that the others are not presenting. This was the value of the program that the Village Chamber Orchestra tackled Tuesday evening in Merkin Concert Hall. It opened with Weber's martial ''Turandot: Overture and March'' and included Prokofiev's ''Overture on Hebrew Themes,'' Faure's Ballade for Piano and Orchestra and concluded with the sassy ''Charleston Rhapsody'' of Robert Russell Bennett.

title: A 'No-Nonsense' Chief Is Chosen
description: Frank A. Olson's promotion to head of the Allegis Corporation makes sense to people familiar with his long career with Hertz, the car-rental company that Allegis owns.

title: TRINITY INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $3,046,000 for early extinguishment of debt and a tax credit of $1,401,000, both for the quarter and year. c-Net income

title: The Pilots Are Pleased And Eager for Next Step
description: F. C. Dubinsky, the head of the United Airlines pilots' union, emerged today as something of a lion tamer as he waited for the Allegis Corporation to discuss the purchase of United Airlines by the carrier's employees.

title: PHONE COMPANY FINDS SHARKS CUTTING IN
description: Sharks have shown an inexplicable taste for the new fiber-optic cables that are being strung along the ocean floor linking the United States, Europe and Japan, telephone company officials say.

title: Found in Franklin's House: Franklin's Stove?
description: Preservationists looking beyond the cobwebs and firebomb scars of a neglected outpost of American history - Benjamin Franklin's now-dingy lodgings on Craven Street - have uncovered what they say is a treasure, a prototype Franklin stove.

title: IN DIVORCE WARS THE APARTMENT CAN BE A BATTLEFIELD
description: ''WHEN you're talking divorce in New York City, you are talking real estate,'' said Joseph Hamer, a New York actor who for three years slept on the couch in the living room of his downtown apartment as he and his wife went through divorce proceedings.

title: Notes, Bonds Little Changed
description: After a day of nervous and erratic trading following the end of the economic summit meeting in Venice, Treasury note and bond prices were little changed.

title: ESTABLISHMENT DECORATORS: A NEW BREED
description: YOUNG, chic and energetic, they can be glimpsed running past doormen from their Upper East Side lobbies at 7:30 A.M. to meet contractors, or spotted commuting into the city several times a week from their summer homes.

title: SINGING THE PRAISES AND PLEASURES OF LIFE IN THE SLOW LANE
description: LEAD: REMEMBER the 1960's?

title: RESTORATION VICTORY: SAVING THE TILES
description: WHEN Mayor Koch acted Sunday to resolve a bureaucratic tiff over the tileless ceiling in the restored Bethesda Terrace in Central Park, he scored points with curators, conservationists and architects. They had protested the absence of the vibrant Gothic Revival tiles when the terrace reopened last month.

title: Q&A
description: Q.Our house has cedar siding that has weathered to gray at the bottom, where snow piles up. Can the house be restored to a single stained color? How can we keep the wood looking good? A.I assume from your question that the siding has already been stained. You can clean the weathered gray areas by washing with a special wood cleaner or ''brightener'' sold for this purpose in many paint stores.

title: Davis Mining Bids For Becor Western
description: Becor Western Inc. said it had received a buyout bid, worth about $173.3 million in cash and notes, from Davis Mining and Manufacturing Inc. of Coeburn, Va. Becor said Davis had proposed to buy its common shares outstanding for $10.45 in cash plus $3 principal amount of a 12.5 percent debenture. In addition, Becor shareholders would receive 60 percent of the common stock of the surviving company after the merger.

title: Palestine Occupation With a Difference
description: To the Editor:

title: Over Goal Line
description: The Mustang Club, which set out to raise $1.3 million for athletic scholarships at Southern Methodist University this year, has easily surpassed its goal, collecting $1,528,165 during its seven-week fund-raising drive. The fund, which consists of cash, endowments and gifts of goods and services, is used to support almost 200 scholarships for the school's 16 varsity athletic programs.

title: Chrysler Capital Picks A New Chief Executive
description: The Chrysler Capital Corporation, a fast-growing credit unit of Chrysler, has named a new president and chief executive, John M. Bowes.

title: Ex-Burlington Official Denies He Violated Pacts
description: James J. Ammeen, the central figure in a complaint brought by Burlington Industries in Federal court, denied yesterday that he violated the confidentiality agreements he had signed with the company.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Richard Petty, who suffered two broken ribs in a crash at Dover Del., May 31, will miss the next two races on the stock-car circuit. He is expected to be ready to drive again in time for the June 28 race at Brooklyn, Mich. . . . Arnold Palmer missed qualifying for the United States Open golf championship for the fourth straight year, this time by shooting 71-72-143 Tuesday at Disney World in Lake Buena Vista, Fla. Palmer, 57 years old, needed a 138.

title: BUDGET TIME AT CITY HALL AND LOBBYISTS DESCEND
description: In the last week of negotiations over the New York City budget, City Hall, with its French Renaissance decor, has come to look more like a Middle Eastern bazaar.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: ALLEGIS GOES UNDER THE KNIFE
description: The Allegis Corporation's stunning announcement late Tuesday that it would break up the company and sell off the pieces could bring investors about $3 billion in profits, investment bankers estimated yesterday.

title: Talking Deals; Builder Goes Back to Banks
description: THE birth of mortgage-backed securities four years ago was widely regarded in the real estate industry as the beginning of the end for traditional institutional financing of large commercial developments. The projects had grown so large that developers sometimes needed $500 million or more to construct them, and only a few banks, pension funds and insurance companies would participate in these projects, even at a premium interest rate.

title: Pavarotti Will Give Benefit for Carnegie Hall
description: Luciano Pavarotti will give his first Carnegie Hall recital in 12 years on Nov. 1, in a benefit for the hall. With John Wustman as accompanist, the tenor will sing works by Rossini, Scarlatti, Gounod, Verdi, Liszt, Donizetti, Mascagni and others.

title: Citing Unrest, Botha Renews Nationwide Emergency Rule
description: Prime Minister P. W. Botha told Parliament today that he had renewed the nationwide state of emergency declared one year ago, saying ''the security of the state is at stake.''

title: Newspaper Editors Ask Veto of Fairness Bill
description: The American Society of Newspaper Editors urged President Reagan today to veto a bill that would give the force of law to a policy requiring broadcasters to cover controversial issues and present opposing views.

title: The Better Way to Help U.S. Banks
description: The financial supermarket chains are coming, if the Reagan Administration has its way. Big commercial banks have long pushed to expand across state lines and into related financial markets. Now the Treasury Under Secretary, George Gould, would go further to encourage mergers between banks and industrial corporations, creating megabanks with enough capital to compete with huge banking conglomerates in Japan and Europe.

NEWS SUMMARY: THURSDAY, JUNE 11, 1987
description: International A3-17

title: WEDTECH OWNER GIVES CHARITIES 300,000 shares
description: John Mariotta, the founder and former chairman of the Wedtech Corporation, has donated more than 300,000 shares of the company's stock to charity since it became the center of a political corruption investigation last year.

title: S.E. COPPLE
description: S. E. Copple, who made and lost a fortune in real estate and the Commonweath Saving Company of Lincoln, Neb., died Tuesday. He was 90 years old.

title: ITT to Cut Rates For Long Distance
description: The ITT Corporation, the international telecommunications conglomerate, said it plans to reduce its long-distance telephone rates an average of 4.9 percent in July. The company said the reductions, if permitted by the Federal Communications Commission, would affect all of ITT's long-distance interstate calls.

title: Old Ways in Queens
description: The departure of Donald Manes from Queens politics raised hopes for reform of old patronage practices, especially when the acting Queens Democratic Party leader, John Sabini, set up a new system for selecting judges. Now, however, it's back to judicial politics as usual.

description: The White House announced today that President Reagan, who is in Venice for the economic summit meeting, had awarded the National Medal of Arts to seven artists and four patrons of the arts.

title: Venice Was a Bust; Here's What to Do
description: True to expectations, there was no progress at the Venice economic summit conference. Despite an intellectual consensus on the grave dangers of standing still, and even on the solutions, nothing happened.

description: At a time when many orchestras across the country have reported financial distress, fiscal issues dominated much of the conversation at the 42d national conference of the American Symphony Orchestra League, which opened yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

description: Helmut Kohl, alone among the seven heads of state visiting Venice, took time to visit the city's cafes and stroll among the pigeons of St. Mark's Square, proving himself the symbol of a modest summit conference.

title: Texas Air Stake
description: George Soros, a New York investor, has reduced his stake in the Texas Air Corporation to 2.6 percent, from 5.3 percent. According to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Mr. Soros sold just over one million Texas Air shares on the open market between June 4 and June 8 for prices ranging from $33.75 to $35.54 a share, well below the average price of $38.81 a share that he said he had paid for the stock. The S.E.C. filing gave no reason for the sale of the shares. Mr. Soros still holds slightly more than one million shares of the Houston-based airline holding company.

title: BIOTECHNOLOGY PARK FOR WASHINGTON HTS. IS CLOSE TO APPROVAL
description: An agreement with Columbia University clearing the way for a $200 million biotechnology research park in Upper Manhattan is expected to be signed today by New York City and state officials, the university said yesterday.

title: Milwaukee Mayor, 28 Years In Office, Planning to Retire
description: Henry Maier, who has been in office longer than any other big-city mayor in the country, said today he would retire when his seventh term expires next April.

title: AN AIDE TO MOYNIHAN RESIGNS AFTER DISPUTE
description: Five days after a confrontation with Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Lee Rainie resigned yesterday as the Senator's administrative assistant. He had held the post for three months.

title: OUTSIDERS' PRESSURE COST FERRIS HIS JOB
description: Richard J. Ferris lost his job as chairman and chief executive of the Allegis Corporation and his battle to preserve his travel company at a wrenching, seven-hour meeting on Tuesday.

title: DR. CHARLES C. WOLCOTT
description: Dr. Charles C. Wolcott, a retired ear, nose and throat specialist and a pioneer in the field of bronchoscopy - the use of a tubular instrument to examine and treat the inside of the windpipe -died Monday at Lawrence Hospital in Bronxville, N.Y. He was 94 years old and lived in Bronxville.

title: Threat by Strawberry
description: The feud between Darryl Strawberry and Dave Johnson deepened today when Strawberry was benched for the second straight day and then said he would refuse to play in the Mets' exhibition game Thursday night against their Tidewater farm club.

title: Phone Cards Are Restricted
description: The seven regional Bell telephone companies have been ordered to stop promoting their credit cards for charging long-distance phone calls, the Justice Department said today.

description: In his second appearance since leaving drug therapy, and his first on the road, Dwight Gooden responded with a blazing performance today at Wrigley Field.

title: DEBATE OVER ASBESTOS CONTINUES, AS DOES DANGER
description: Asbestos, slathered on years ago like dirty gray icing, insulates the beams in the ceiling of St. Patrick's elementary school here. There is asbestos in the classrooms, the cafeteria, the halls. There is asbestos on the basement pipes.

title: WORLD AIDS FIGHT IS URGED IN VENICE
description: Leaders at a seven-nation economic summit meeting today declared AIDS ''one of the biggest potential health problems in the world,'' and they called for international cooperation against it through the World Health Organization.

title: A REPORT TO KOCH FINDS MYERSON USED IMPROPER INFLUENCE ON JUDGE
description: Bess Myerson, the former New York City Commissioner of Cultural Affairs, improperly influenced a judge who was presiding over the divorce case of Ms. Myerson's companion, according to a report commissioned by Mayor Koch.

title: House Committee, Sharply Split, Clears Bill Overhauling Welfare
description: A deeply divided House Ways and Means Committee today approved a major welfare overhaul that would require many mothers who receive public assistance to work.

title: Three Blind Mice
description: While lips were smacking at the incipient appearance of Fawn Hall, another Administration witness came before the Iran-contra panel to testify about a legal opinion he had written: Bretton Sciaroni had held in the summer of 1985 that the National Security Council was not ''involved in intelligence activities'' that the Boland Amendment restricted.

title: NIMRODI GIVES A PARTY AND ALL THE BIG GUNS COME
description: For Israel, it was the wedding of the century. If you were not invited you were either nobody or in jail.

title: JAZZ BADEN POWELL AND JOE PASS
description: TWO guitarists who play unaccompanied solos - Joe Pass and Baden Powell - are sharing the stage at the Blue Note, 131 West Third Street through Sunday in what amounts to a minimalist guitar festival. Mr. Powell, a Brazilian whose father was so impressed by the founder of the Boy Scouts that he named his son after him, is making what is declared to be his first club appearance in the United States, while Mr. Pass is a veteran of both clubs and concerts.

title: Congresswoman Sworn In
description: Nancy Pelosi, a Democratic fund-raiser who never before held elected office, was sworn in Tuesday to represent San Francisco in the House of Representatives. Mrs. Pelosi, 47 years old, won a special election last week to fill the Fifth District seat of the late Sala Burton, also a Democrat.

description: The Real Deal

description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Padres Pick Feeney
description: At an age when most people would begin to think about retirement, Chub Feeney, the former National League president, has decided to go to work again, this time for the San Diego Padres.

title: CRIME PANEL BACKS BROAD EXPANSION OF COMPUTER FILE
description: A Federal advisory committee has tentatively endorsed a major expansion of a national computer file that would permit Federal, state and local law-enforcement agencies to exchange information on people who are suspected of a crime but have not been charged.

title: CONCERT: THE CATSKILL WOODWINDS
description: THE Catskill Woodwind Quintet is a faculty ensemble of the Catskill Conservatory, a quixotic 12-year-old institution in Oneonta, N.Y., where lively contact is maintained with living art. Sunday evening at Weill Recital Hall, the quintet offered a program that comprised three new pieces and one old, all in or related to the mainstream 20th-century tradition of expressive dissonance and each a delight in its way.

title: Mexican Inflation Up
description: Fueled by transportation fare rises, consumer prices in Mexico rose by 7.5 percent in May, bringing the nation's inflation rate for the first five months of the year to 44.5 percent, the central bank said Tuesday. The monthly pace in May 1986 was 5.6 percent. Mexico's inflation hit a record 105.7 percent for all of 1986. Increases in the costs of transportation - including public transit, airline fares, automobiles and maintenance - averaged 11.2 percent over April. The Government had hoped to reduce inflation by 20 to 30 percentage points from last year, but some private analysts have predicted inflation will total as much as 120 percent in 1987.

title: Plain Candor, Urgently
description: There is a peculiar quality about the way our Government talks to the American people about foreign policy problems involving life and death issues. It is an old-fashioned, musty quality, as if it came from another period and way of thinking.

title: VIOLENT PROTESTS ROCK SOUTH KOREA
description: Thousands of well-organized protesters, using bold hit-and-run tactics, fought with riot policemen in street battles that lasted through the night and into today. It was the worst street violence Seoul has seen in years.

title: LIFE OF ANDRE MALRAUX EXPLORED ON CHANNEL 13
description: ''ANDRE MALRAUX'' reaches the high points of an extraordinary life. Made in France in 1986 to commemorate the 10th anniversary of the death of a man who moved between art and action, philosophy and politics, contemplation and combat, the 90-minute documentary uses Malraux's own brilliant prose and well-selected photographs and artworks to tell his story. The impressive result can be seen tonight at 11 on Channel 13, part of WNET's ''Vive la France!'' series.

title: Takeovers Bill Is Opposed
description: The imposition of restrictions on foreign takeovers of American companies would have a chilling effect on foreign investment in the United States, Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige said today.

title: GENE TRANSPLANT OFFERS HOPE FOR A MULTI-DISEASE VACCINE
description: Scientists have transplanted foreign genes into the bacteria that make up tuberculosis vaccine, an important preliminary step in adapting that vaccine for use against other diseases.

title: Jefferies Executives Continue Venture
description: When Boyd L. Jefferies ran afoul of securities laws and resigned in March as chairman of Jefferies & Company, questions were raised about the future of the West Coast brokerage firm he founded. The issue was crucial to three executives -Herbert L. Denton; his brother, Robert L. Denton, and Michael Katz -who were forming a mergers and acquisitions department for Jefferies in New York.

title: YANKEES MAKE MOVES BUT ARE SWEPT
description: The clubhouse doors were closed tightly when the game was over, and they remained shut for several minutes as Lou Piniella delivered a brief but direct speech to his team.

title: Jury Convicts Officer In Protection Scheme
description: A police officer who had been assigned to the 77th Precinct in Brooklyn has been convicted of trying to arrange protection for a drug dealer so he would not be bothered by police narcotics officers.

title: Gretzky Is Honored
description: Wayne Gretzky has been in the National Hockey League for eight seasons, and he has been voted the Hart Memorial Trophy as best player after each. He was honored last night in Toronto at the league's annual awards ceremony.

title: A Restaurant Woos a Co-op's Residents
description: John R. Valenti is determined to have everything go smoothly at Crane's, his new seafood restaurant at Broadway and 105th Street. So just before 6 P.M. on Sunday, he gave last-minute instructions to the hostess, had a busboy dispose of the empty liquor cartons near the bar, dimmed the lights and lowered the music. Then, with the doors closed to regular customers, he served dinner, free of charge, to 225 residents of the cooperative building that houses his restaurant.

title: National Lottery: Neither Desirable Nor Inevitable
description: To the Editor:

title: CAMPAIGN OVER, BRITAIN VOTES FOR A NEW PARLIAMENT TODAY
description: Britain today reached the end of a general election battle in which Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher was tested by predictable attacks on her vision of the nation's future and by a surprisingly erratic performance by her own troubled campaign organization.

title: REPORT ON HATE GROUPS SAYS THEY'RE WEAKER
description: The Ku Klux Klan, neo-Nazis and similar groups have been seriously weakened by Government prosecutions in recent years, according to a report by the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith.

title: Market Place; Hard Times At Subaru
description: SUBARU OF AMERICA INC., a former high-flying stock, has lost friends in the Wall Street community for the simple reason that its earnings - and share price - have plummeted during the past year. The company, which imports and distributes Japanese-made vehicles for sale in the United States, has been a victim of the yen's appreciation against the dollar.

title: GIANTS CUT RED LEAD TO GAME
description: Candy Maldonado hit three doubles today, including one that drove in the go-ahead run in the eighth inning, as the San Francisco Giants beat the Cincinnati Reds, 9-4.

title: U.S. SEEKS CONTROL OF TEAMSTER UNION
description: The Justice Department is preparing a lawsuit aimed at removing the executive board of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters and putting the union under Federal control on the ground that is under the influence of organized crime, department officials said today.

title: AFTER INJURY AND DOUBT, A DIRECTOR COMES BACK
description: Legs propped on a chair, a legal pad in his lap, Jack Hofsiss, the Tony Award-winning director of ''The Elephant Man,'' sat in a front row of the Hudson Guild Theater on West 26th Street. On stage, a wounded murderer pleaded in song for his mother's approval.

title: WILSON FOODS reports earnings for Qtr to May 2
description: b-After tax credits of $213,000 for the quarter and $1,935,000 for the 9 months. c-Net loss and includes a charge of $21.4 million from plant closings, restructuring and workforce reductions.

title: Report on Orange Crop
description: The nation's orange harvest for the 1986-87 crop season is estimated at 183 million boxes, down 4 percent from the May forecast but still 4 percent more than last season, the Agriculture Department said.

title: COMARCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 3
REPORT ABOUT MYERSON PUTS MAYOR ON DEFENSIVE AGAIN
description: Fresh disclosures yesterday about two of Mayor Koch's longtime friends and government associates placed him on the political defensive in a new chapter of the municipal corruption scandals that have preoccupied City Hall for nearly a year and a half.

title: MAGNA INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Foreign Currency Used For Los Angeles Notes
description: In a marketing battle to earn kudos for handling the first local government note issue denominated in a foreign currency, Los Angeles County and the First Boston Corporation scored a coup yesterday.

title: 'Cop II' Is First Again In Box Office Sales
description: ''Beverly Hills Cop II'' and ''The Untouchables'' claimed the top two spots at the box office for Paramount Pictures last weekend, earning a total of $22 million.

title: General Re Corp.
description: The General Re Corporation, one of the nation's largest reinsurance companies, said its board had authorized the repurchase of common stock worth as much as $300 million. General Re said the repurchase, of about 5.3 million of its 102.8 million shares, was part of its efforts to enhance the company's value to stockholders. Its stock rose $1.625, to $55.375, in trading today on the New York Stock Exchange. The company said the purchases would be made from time to time, depending on market conditions.

title: MCCLOSKEY ENDS KNICK TALKS
description: The saga of the Knicks' search for a coach and general manager has taken another embarrassing twist.

title: Selling Drugs: The Role of Doctors
description: An issue that most members of Congress never heard of until a few months ago has blossomed into a major lobbying battle.

title: Rev. Jackson Sees Gains
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson, leader of a group pushing baseball to hire members of minorities for front-office jobs, met with major league club owners today and said ''the movement that has begun to take place is impressive.''

title: SUPER FOOD SERVICES reports earnings for Qtr to May 9
OFFICE FURNITURE WITH A BIT OF HUMOR SOFTENS HIGH TECH
description: To paraphrase the futurist John Naisbitt, who is constantly quoted as a design guru here, ''high tech'' has given way to ''high touch'' - a predilection for more material, soft fabrics and a touch of humor - at the World Congress of Environmental Planning and Design, the four-day debut of new commercial furniture styles at the Chicago Merchandise Mart.

title: APA OPTICS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: U.S. AIMS TO WIDEN AWACS PATROL OVER GULF BEFORE STARTING ESCORTS
description: The Pentagon hopes to expand patrols by Awacs surveillance aircraft over the entire length of the Persian Gulf before United States warships start escorting Kuwaiti oil tankers next month, Reagan Administration officials said today.

title: STAGE: 'BAR MITZVAH BOY,' WITH MUSIC BY JULE STYNE
description: WITH the playing of the overture, we are reminded of Jule Styne's invaluable contribution to the American musical. One difference between this and other Styne overtures is that there is, occasionally, a gentle Hebraic strain to the music. Then the show, ''Bar Mitzvah Boy,'' begins and, within minutes, it is evident that a major American songwriter has once again been diminished by those twin demons, book and lyrics. As a musical, ''Bar Mitzvah Boy'' is a hopeless melange of stereotype and sentimentality.

title: GOETZ'S TAPED ACCOUNT IS WRONG, LAWYER SAYSA
description: The defense attorney for Bernhard H. Goetz, making his final appeal in the six-week trial, asked the jurors yesterday not to believe the words of his own client.

title: Carson Is Selected
description: Harry Carson, the Giants' linebacker, and Brian Sipe, the former Cleveland Browns' quarterback, have been selected by the National Football League Players Association and the United States Information Agency to represent the United States as ambassadors of good will at the French equivalent of the Super Bowl.

title: 3 FEDERAL AGENCIES OPEN CRIMINAL INQUIRIES ON PTL MINISTRY
description: The Internal Revenue Service, the Postal Service and the Justice Department formally opened criminal investigations of the PTL ministry on Tuesday, the Rev. Jerry Falwell said today.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: THURSDAY, JUNE 11, 1987
description: Companies

title: Facing the Legends
description: They hide the celebrities in the Boston Garden, stick them in upper boxes, high above the screaming mob. Up there, the bald guy, that's Marvelous Marvin Hagler. Over there, making vaguely mocking gestures, is Jack Nicholson.

title: COOPER DEVELOPMENT reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $4,711,000.

title: AFTER 3 CENTURIES, A STUDENT FIGURES THAT NEWTON ERRED
description: A 23-year-old physics student has discovered an error in Sir Isaac Newton's ''Principia'' that had gone undetected since the work laid out the laws of motion and gravity 300 years ago.

title: Turtle Boats Were First

title: NEW, UNORTHODOX STRATEGY ON AIDS PROPOSED BY SALK
description: Dr. Jonas Salk, the polio vaccine pioneer, has proposed a research strategy to determine whether an unusual type of immunization could be developed to protect people already infected with the AIDS virus from developing the fatal disease.

title: PICO PRODUCTS reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net loss and is after an extraordinary gain of $43,185 for the 9 months.

title: NEW PRINTS TO BENEFIT WILDFLOWER RESEARCH
description: SHE was dressed in a cornflower blue outfit that matched the centerpiece of fresh cornflowers and garden moss and the cornflower-pattern tablecloth. She - Lady Bird Johnson - was the guest of honor at a luncheon yesterday to introduce a collection of 14 fabrics and wall coverings, Wildflowers of America, designed for the Hinson Collections to celebrate native American blooms.

title: F.C.C. Widens Access Charge
description: The Federal Communications Commission proposed today to eliminate an exemption from certain telephone access charges for computer-based services and information retrieval systems.

title: Westinghouse Cuts Interest in Robots
description: The Westinghouse Corporation, which spent $107 million to acquire the industrial robotics company Unimation in 1983, took a step back from that commitment today, after three rough years in the market. Prab Robots Inc. of Kalamazoo, Mich., said it had licensed from Westinghouse the right to make, sell and service the Unimate line of heavy-duty robots.

title: SPAIN'S SOCIALISTS LOSE SOME GROUND
description: Spain's governing Socialist Party lost ground in local and regional elections Wednesday, and as a result will have to share power with centrist and leftist parties in some cities.

title: MATTINGLY EAGER TO GET IN SWING AGAIN
description: He was back home yesterday, recuperating from a back injury and still firmly denying that there had been any horseplay with a teammate last week that led to the mishap. Then the voice sounded like the real Don Mattingly.

title: E I L INSTRUMENTS reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
YANKS LOSING GRIP, PINIELLA HOLDING ON
description: After he had been asked to leave, the manager of the New York Yankees had one more public point to make. Lou Piniella's behavior had already earned the manager something that most of the fans at Yankee Stadium soon grew to find appealing - an early exit from another one-sided Yankee loss to the Toronto Blue Jays.

title: Miller & Rhoads
description: The Allied Stores Corporation said it had agreed to sell its Miller & Rhoads division to an investor group led by the division's managers and by Kevin F. Donohoe, a Philadelphia real estate investor. Miller & Rhoads operates 21 stores in North Carolina and its home state of Virginia. The price was not disclosed.

title: BILL FIXING TAX FLAWS INTRODUCED
description: House and Senate tax writers introduced legislation today that would make hundreds of ''technical'' corrections to the Tax Reform Act of 1986 as well as provide relief to certain homeowners and several industries.

title: OF SHAKESPEARE, BRECHT, AND CANADA'S STRATFORD
description: During the 35-year history of the Stratford Festival, this town has turned Shakespeare into a Canadian institution and a thriving local industry. In Stratford, Shakespeare's presentment appears on coffee mugs and T-shirts; there is an As You Like It Motel, and a grassy lawn with several trees on it is officially designated the Birnam Wood Arboretum.

title: BOESKY'S COOPERATION STARTED IN SEPTEMBER
description: Ivan F. Boesky began his formal cooperation with Government investigators in September, two months before his plea agreement on insider-trading charges was made public, according to a copy of his plea agreement released yesterday.

title: DESIGNS INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 2
description: b-Net loss

title: FARMING OUT SOME INMATES
description: Although he was not able to attend the ceremony, Governor Cuomo was honored Monday at the Wallkill Correctional Facility in Ulster County as the first recipient of the Thoroughbred Retirement Foundation's Distinguished Service Award.

title: LIGHTNING STRIKES AND ROCKETS FLY, UNTENDED
description: As officials huddled in a blockhouse at Wallops Island, Va., to escape a storm Tuesday night, the space agency inadvertently conducted one of its busiest rounds of rocket launchings of the last year.

title: Power, Not Law, Still Appears to Rule Brazil
description: Upon taking office two years ago, Brazil's new civilian Government pledged both to punish those involved in past corruption and to put an end to kickbacks, conflicts of interest, nepotism and influence-peddling.

title: AEC INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net income
