description: To the Editor:

title: WASHINGTON TALK: Arms Control; For (and Against) Limiting Missiles
description: Jack F. Kemp is not known for mincing words. And arms control is no exception.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: EMPIRE. By Gore Vidal. 486 pages. Random House. $22.50.

title: Delta Raises Fares
description: Delta Air Lines said it would match the fare increases announced earlier by other airlines to offset rising fuel costs. The increases, ranging from $3 to $7 for one-way domestic trips, would be effective on tickets bought after June 19, a Delta spokesman, Jim Ewing, said. Similar increases have been announced by Trans World, Continental, United, American and Northwest airlines.

title: Freedom Suit Is Dismissed
description: A countersuit alleging that Harry Hoiles filed a groundless civil case against Freedom Newspapers Inc. has been dismissed in a conciliatory gesture intended to end a bitter feud within the Hoiles family.

title: REGAN'S OFFICE SAYS NEW YORK CITY MAY UNDERCOUNT ITS DROPOUTS
description: The dropout rate in New York City may be much higher than the Board of Education says, according to a draft report by the New York State Comptroller.

title: AFTER A SLOW START, AIDS BOOKS ARE COMING OUT IN A RUSH
description: Book publishers were slow to sign up books on AIDS after the disease came to public notice in 1981, but now they are making up for lost time.

title: MATRIX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
BONN TO TRY HIJACKING SUSPECT
description: West Germany will not extradite Mohammed Ali Hamadei to the United States for trial in the June 1985 hijacking of a T.W.A. airliner and the murder of an American passenger, White House officials said late today.

title: KRON CHOCOLATIER reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Hogan Undergoes an Appendectomy
description: Ben Hogan, formerly one of professional golf's top players, was listed in fair condition at Harris Hospital today, recovering from surgery to remove his appendix.

title: Getty Plans to Buy Clark Oil's Assets
description: The Getty Petroleum Corporation, the Long Island-based gasoline marketer, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy nearly all the assets of the Clark Oil and Refinery Corporation in a transaction valued at $447 million.

title: Grand Jury Date For Crown Unit
description: Crown Brands Inc. said that representatives of its I. Rokeach & Sons subsidiary were scheduled to appear next Monday before a grand jury in Federal District Court in New Jersey as part of ''an ongoing investigation by the U.S. Department of Justice into possible unfair competition practices relating to the kosher food industry.'' Crown, which is based in Englewood Cliffs, N.J., made the disclosure in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The company said the unit had been subpoenaed last month.

title: 'GENTEEL' TAKEOVER: NEW TWIST TO CORPORATE RESTRUCTURING
description: The about-face that will lead to the virtual breakup of the Allegis Corporation marks a new twist in the saga of corporate restructurings. In what is already being tagged a ''genteel takeover,'' the Allegis board caved in to demands of dissident shareholders.

title: Indictment of Co-defendant In Donovan Case Is Voided
description: Citing insufficent evidence, a Bronx judge yesterday voided an indictment against the last of 10 defendants in the larceny and fraud case involving former Labor Secretary Raymond J. Donovan.

title: BURLINGTON BID RAISED BY MORGAN
description: A leveraged-buyout group led by Morgan Stanley Group raised its bid for Burlington Industries yesterday by $2 a share, to $78.

title: GROUNDWATER TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to May 2
London Fox Emerges
description: The London Commodity Exchange today renamed itself London Fox, which stands for London Futures and Options Exchange, and adopted a russet red fox as its logotype in an effort to spiff up its image amid strong international competition. The exchange's chairman, Saxon Tate, said the company needed ''a distinctive name and an easily recognizable symbol to reflect our new sense of purpose and direction.'' He said the London Fox was embarking on a promotional campaign intended to increase its market share in Europe and the United States.

title: TEXT OF ECONOMIC DECLARATION BY 7 LEADING INDUSTRIAL NATIONS
description: Following is the official text of the economic declaration issued today at the end of the summit conference of the seven leading industrialized democracies: Introduction

title: Trouble for Tourists
description: The Rotunda of the Capitol, a stop on many Washington tours, will be closed for the next two weeks, and the fresco on the dome will be obscured for more than a year.

title: RESTORE RURAL SOLIDARITY, POPE SAYS
description: Pope John Paul II called today for the restoration of an outlawed Solidarity union of private farmers.

title: Yields Post Broad Rise
description: Yields on certificates of deposit, bank money market accounts and money market mutual funds rose for the week ended yesterday, even as upward pressure on rates continues to diminish.

title: CITY BALLET: 'LIEBESLIEDER WALZER'
description: IN one of the Brahms songs to which George Balanchine's ''Liebeslieder Walzer'' is set, an analogy is drawn between the stirring of branches brushed by a bird and the trembling of the human heart. The ballet itself, presented by the New York City Ballet on Tuesday at the New York State Theater, alludes to the world of the Brahms songs, created for the kind of elegant home musical entertainments put on by amateur musicians and singers in the late 19th century.

title: Toys for Contras
description: The Iran-contra situation continues to produce the unpredictable. Paul K. Vickery, a Chicago lawyer, read in the paper that the National Endowment for the Preservation of Liberty, a conservative group, had raised over $2 million to buy toys for children of Nicaraguan rebels but spent the money instead on weapons. To correct this situation, he organized a June 1 benefit called ''Bowling for Contras'' in Chicago, asking each participant to bring a toy.

title: MAJOR DEALS CITED IN CHINA-IRAN ARMS
description: European and Asian diplomats here have provided new evidence that China, despite its denials, has sold substantial numbers of weapons to Iran, including missiles, jet fighters and field artillery.

title: DOW UP 0.91 AS BIG GAINS EVAPORATE
description: The stock market fell back late yesterday after being strongly ahead almost all day. Trading was heavy.

title: Wheeling Steel Post Created
description: The Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corporation said its directors had approved a plan to create an unusually powerful chief executive position to speed the company's reorganization in bankruptcy court.

title: KOCH SAYS HE WAS SATISFIED BY MYERSON'S '83 ACCOUNT
description: Mayor Koch said yesterday that he was initially satisfied with Bess Myerson's explanation when questions were first raised in 1983 about her giving a city job to the daughter of a judge.

title: BOSWORTH'S FUTURE MAY LIE IN CHIPS
description: A zany numbers game, involving the outlandish Brian Bosworth, will occupy National Football League coaches today at a time they would rather be off on their annual one-week vacations.

title: COURT UPHOLDS L.I. TOWN'S ZONING LAWS
description: In a long-awaited decision, New York State's highest court today upheld the zoning ordinances of the Town of Brookhaven, L. I., rejecting the assertion that they had been used to exclude low-income housing.

title: Reggie Workman
description: Reggie Workman, a bassist, is leading a trio tonight through Sunday at Carlos 1, 432 Avenue of the Americas, at Ninth Street (982-3260). Sets begin at 9 and 11 P.M., with a 12:30 A.M. set tonight and tomorrow; there is a $10 cover and a $7 minimum.

title: CELTICS ROUT LAKERS AND TRAIL, 3-2
description: For the third time since they began the playoffs with a sweep of the Chicago Bulls, the Boston Celtics faced elimination tonight and met the challenge.

title: AMERICAN SOFTWARE reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: Share earnings and shares outstanding are adjusted for a 3-for-2 stock split.

title: Let's Play Two: 'Boys' of Summer Take the Field
description: At 72, after a decade in the Long Island Senior Softball Association, Mike Gurro knows how things are. ''The young guys come in, they push you out,'' he said. ''You know, they play the guys 62, 63. All us old guys know that. We understand guys in their 60's are faster.''

title: G.E. TELLS NBC CHIEFS TO CHANGE OR GO HOME
description: Just as NBC was completing its best-ever competitive performance this spring, the chairman of the General Electric Company, the network's corporate parent, told a closed meeting of NBC executives that they were rooted in the past and would have to change.

title: CELTICS ARE SUDDENLY FRISKY
description: It wasn't long ago that the primary topic of discussion concerning this latest renewal for basketball supremacy between the Lakers and Celtics had nothing to do with the strategies or matchups.

title: Long Island
description: The Nassau County Center for the Fine Arts, Roslyn - A collection of enormous pieces of outdoor sculpture serves as a silent greeting for visitors to the museum, once the home of Childs Frick.

title: NEW YORK LEADERS PUSH TO COMPLETE THE BUDGET
description: Leaders of the New York City Council and the Board of Estimate negotiated all day yesterday and into the early morning today, missing the legal deadline of midnight for passage of a new city budget. Missing the deadline, however, would have no effect on city operations because the new fiscal year does not start until July 1.

title: YANKS TURN A WEEK INTO EPIC
description: When the Yankees arrived in Milwaukee last Thursday, they were nestled neatly in first place, riding a modest winning streak and a wave of momentum that began when they took over the lead in the American League East on May 14.

title: A BIZARRE DEAL DIVERTS VITAL TOOLS TO RUSSIANS
description: Early in 1983 a team of Japanese engineers from the Toshiba Machine Company arrived in Leningrad, the center of Russian shipbuilding since Peter the Great, and was whisked through the back gate of the heavily guarded Baltic Shipyard. There they painstakingly assembled more than $17 million worth of computer-controlled machine tools used to make ship propellers.

title: McEnroe in the Clear
description: Marshall Happer, the administrator for the Men's International Professional Tennis Council, said yesterday that he had concluded an investigation of John McEnroe's behavior during a match against Miloslav Mecir of Czechoslovakia in World Team Cup play May 24 and would not recommend a suspension for the Amercan player. McEnroe walked off the court before completion of the match, which was played in Dusseldorf, West Germany. McEnroe complained at the time that his back hurt and that he could not continue. The council's code of conduct says a player must tell the chair umpire and receive permission from the tournament supervisor before he can leave the court. In a statement released in Paris, Happer said that Dr. Hartmut Krahl had examined McEnroe after the match and found that he had severely aggravated a back injury. The doctor concluded that McEnroe could not have continued playing.

title: KEY RATES
WIDENING OF TURNPIKE TO START IN NEW JERSEY
description: After two years of negotiations involving opponents of the project, a $2 billion plan to widen the New Jersey Turnpike along much of its congested northern corridor is getting under way this month.

title: REAGAN OPTIMISTIC ON SOVIET SUMMIT
description: President Reagan, speaking in highly optimistic tones about American-Soviet relations, said today that the seven-nation economic meeting here had led to an ''increased opportunity'' for a summit meeting with Mikhail S. Gorbachev.

title: T H E FITNESS CENTERS reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
RETAIL SALES FELL 0.6% IN MAY
description: Retail sales fell six-tenths of 1 percent in May, the biggest decline in four months, the Commerce Department said today.

title: Chemical Lifts Loss Reserve
description: The Chemical New York Corporation yesterday became the latest big banking company to acknowledge that many of its third world loans are all but uncollectible.

title: G.M. Sets 4,800 Layoffs
description: The General Motors Corporation said today that it will lay off 4,800 workers for one week, beginning Monday, at its Willow Run assembly plant for the Buick-Oldsmobile-Cadillac Group. The plant, near Ypsilanti, Mich., will be shut down for inventory adjustment.

title: CDI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: Share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split payable Aug. 10.

title: Simmons Beautyrest Goes With Bates Unit
description: An $8 million budget for advertising a mattress is nothing to snore at, especially at Simmons U.S.A. in Atlanta.

title: LABATT, JOHN reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: The company is listed on the Toronto Stock Exchange.

title: Westchester
description: The Neuberger Museum - Harrison, N.Y. A national exhibition organized by the Phillips Collection in Washington is to open on June 25. The 84 works in the exhibition, entitled ''John Graham: Artist and Avatar,'' document the career of the Russian-born artist and include eight pieces by several of the avant-garde contemporaries he influenced, including Jackson Pollock, Willem de Kooning, Stuart Davis, Lee Krasner and Alexander Calder.

title: FLUOR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $2.1 million and $2.8 million for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. The company said the major factors which lowered its second quarter results were Fluor Constructors' pretax operating losses and additional reserves totaling $18.9 million and a corporate tax expense of $9.7 million.

title: ART: PRE-MODERN VIENNA
description: ''VIENNA, 1900'' in all its ramifications is by now a road show that has been run right into the ground. But there is still room for an exhibition that shows us what came before Vienna, 1900 - and, for that matter, why Vienna in 1900 had to be unlike any earlier Vienna. ''Pre-Modern Art of Vienna: 1848-1898'' at the I.B.M. Gallery of Science and Art is intended to fill that gap. Organized by institutions that by the standards of the Metropolitan Museum, or of the National Gallery of Art, are neither rich nor powerful, it does a very good job. The galleries look well. The paintings, drawings and prints are bulked out with apt specimens of the decorative arts.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: FRIDAY, JUNE 12, 1987
description: International A3-15

title: FIRST PROVIDENT GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net income

title: U.S. Helicopters for Manila
description: The United States delivered 10 helicopters to the Philippines today, saying they reflected support for the President Corazon Aquino's Government in its drive against Communist insurgents.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE COMPLETE YES MINISTER. The Diaries of a Cabinet Minister. By the Right Hon. James Hacker M.P. Edited by Jonathan Lynn and Antony Jay. Illustrated. 514 pages. Salem House. $19.95.

title: Daniels Pleads Guilty
description: Lloyd Daniels, the former schoolboy basketball star from New York City who was recruited then spurned by the University of Nevada-Las Vegas, pleaded guilty yesterday to a misdemeanor charge of attempting to buy rock cocaine at a crack house this year. Daniels must enter a three-month drug rehabilitation program and undergo urinalysis twice a week under terms of a plea bargain. After Daniels's arrest in February, Coach Jerry Tarkanian of Nevada-Las Vegas said he would never play for him.

title: THEATRICAL AVANT-GARDE GOES FORWARD TO THE PAST
description: ''I WANT to sing in opera,'' Crystal Field warbled, clearly far from her goal. ''Signor Caruso told me I should do so.''

title: COMMUNICATIONS GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $152,730 for the latest quarter and $156,650 for the year-earlier period.

title: TOWN HOUSES FLOURISHING IN SOUTHEASTERN PUTNAM
description: In much the manner that the potato fields of Long Island gave way to a surge of suburban tract development in the 1950's, so the farms and rolling woodlands of Putnam County are now providing starter homes for hundreds of young New York families in the 1980's.

title: MUSIC: 'SONG FOR HOPE'
description: WHEN the 92d Street Y chose Elie Wiesel and the composer David Diamond to write a piece commemorating the 50th anniversary of the performing arts at the Y, they knew the result would not be one of the fanfares that such commissions typically spawn. ''A Song for Hope,'' which was given its premiere at a gala concert Wednesday evening, is concerned with issues that have occupied Mr. Wiesel's attention for many years - the Holocaust, the questions of faith it posed for Jews, the value of memory as a buttress against moral laxity, the notion of hope as redemptive.

title: Prices Rise in Light Trading
description: Treasury note and bond prices rose modestly yesterday, although market participants said the gains were based on light volume and accompanied by a great deal of uncertainty.

title: Edsel Ford 2d Gets Sales Post
description: Edsel B. Ford 2d was promoted to general sales manager of the Lincoln-Mercury division of the Ford Motor Company, the company said today.

title: FOR NEW YORK AIDS PATIENTS, FEW PLACES TO EASE THE DYING
description: As their days dwindle, these are things AIDS patients say they want most: cool sheets; a hand to hold; a promise that they will not have to bear too great a suffering, and that they will not have to die alone.

title: PLUSH SEATS, REAL BUTTER: NEW TIMES SQ. THEATER
description: To many movie lovers, the Times Square cinematic experience leaves something to be desired. Restrooms are often filthy, seat cushions non-existent and the popcorn not unlike little chunks of cardboard. The air frequently smells of marijuana and crack, and the sound is often scratchy.

title: After Venice, Still No Unity
description: ''VENICE speaks to us,'' Jean-Paul Sartre wrote two decades ago. ''Her voice is that of a perjured witness, now shrill, now whispering, always marked by periods of silence.''

title: 'The Saint,' on CBS, With a New Hero
description: Simon Templar, the character created by Leslie Charteris, has been around since the 1930's, first in print, and then in movies, radio and television. Louis Hayward, George Sanders, Roger Moore and others have played him, usually as the last word in elegance and style. Now Andrew Clarke takes a turn. Templar is still elegant, but in ''The Saint,'' on CBS at 8 o'clock tonight, he is also a hunk.

title: POLYMER INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $750,000 for the quarter and $1,350,573 for the year, and extraordinary tax credits of $10,000 and $330,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: MASSACHUSETTS GETTING AIDS EDUCATION PLAN
description: Gov. Michael Dukakis of Massachusetts today announced the most comprehensive statewide AIDS education program in the nation, including the mass mailing of a brochure on the disease to every household in the state.

title: Quartet in Yonkers
description: The Laurentian String Quartet and the violist Paul Doktor will perform works by Mozart Sunday at 8 P.M. at Reisinger Auditorium on the campus of Sarah Lawrence College in Yonkers. Tickets are $9, $7 for students and the elderly. Information: (914) 337-0700, ext. 412.

title: TRAK AUTO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: The sales for the year-ago quarter have been revised to reflect the consolidation of Trak Auto West Inc.

title: 1,000-Mile Goal
description: When Stu Mittleman of New York set a world record of 11 days 20 hours 36 minutes 50 seconds for 1,000 miles last year in the Sri Chinmoy race in Flushing Meadows-Corona Park, Queens, the 34-year-old fitness consultant covered 503 miles in the first six days. Yesterday, after six days in this year's Sri Chinmoy competition, the leader, Marty Sprengelmeyer of Davenport, Iowa, had run 500 miles, 60 more than Dan Coffey of London. In the women's competition, Arlette Touchard of France had covered 376 miles, one more than Izumi Yamamoto of Japan and 13 more than Pippa Davis of Westford, Mass. Each is hoping to become the first woman to reach 1,000 miles in a competitive organized race. Last year's winner, Suluchana Kallai, covered 631 miles in 16 days. This year's race will last 18 days, ending June 23.

title: INDIA STRIVING TO CHECK SECRET SWISS ACCOUNTS
description: The Indian Government, moving to limit political damage from allegations of military kickbacks, sought Swiss assistance today in investigating secret bank accounts held illegally by Indians.

title: SEAVER CAN'T STEM THE TIDE
description: Tom Seaver pitched in a game for the first time in nine months tonight, and endured two-plus very labored innings in an exhibition for the Mets against their Tidewater farm club. He faced 16 batters and gave up eight hits and seven runs, and then conceded that his return to the big leagues might take longer than he had expected.

title: THE PRESIDENT IN VENICE: ECONOMICS, CONTRA AID AND THE GULF
description: Following is a transcript of President Reagan's news conference in Venice today, as recorded by The Associated Press: OPENING STATEMENT

title: Dollar Little Changed; Reagan Flurry Fades
description: The dollar closed little changed in light trading yesterday, although remarks by President Reagan created a momentary stir.

title: NEWMARK & LEWIS INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
FILM: 'PUPPETOON MOVIE'
description: IT'S hard to resist a movie that lists a Gumby maker and a Gumby adviser in the credits.

title: EMPLOYEES ASSAIL NUCLEAR PANEL, CHARGING A BIAS TOWARD INDUSTRY
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission came under renewed attack today as some of its own employees, as well as two Congressmen, accused it of favoring the nuclear power industry at the cost of public safety.

title: U.S. REJECTS AN INCREASE IN POWER AT TWO TROUBLED NUCLEAR PLANTS
description: The Government turned down requests today to increase power at nuclear power plants on Long Island and in New Hampshire.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a dispatch from Colombo on Tuesday about Sri Lankan Army gains misattributed a statement about the dispute over India's airlift to Tamil strongholds. The comment - that the dispute must be resolved before a political settlement of Tamil grievances can be discussed - was made by Foreign Minister A. C. S. Hameed, not by the Tamil moderate leader Neelan Tiruchelvam.

title: AUCTIONS
description: A RARE Frank Lloyd Wright dining room ensemble -eight tall spindle-backed chairs and a squarish table - is to be auctioned June 20 at 2 P.M. at Christie's, Park Avenue at 59th Street, in what is described by the house as the largest and most important sale ever held of the architect's early furniture. The sale of 11 offerings of Wright material, all of which were completed before World War I, also includes a chest of drawers, five leaded and stained-glass windows, and four chairs, all but one of which were made for one of the architect's early houses.

title: Alexander Iolas, Ex-Dancer And Surrealist-Art Champion
description: Alexander Iolas, known internationally first as a ballet dancer and later as a leading art dealer who specialized in the Surrealists, died on Monday at New York Hospital. He was 80 years old.

title: Edwards Advising Ueberroth
description: Dr. Harry Edwards, an outspoken black sports sociologist, has had discussions with Peter Ueberroth, the baseball commissioner, on how baseball could be ''responsive and responsible on racial issues.''

title: New Brunswick's Top Officer And Two Lawyers Are Guilty
description: NEWARK, June 11 -

title: JAPAN'S TRADE SURPLUS FALLS, BUT NOT WITH U.S.
description: Japan's overall trade surplus declined in May by nearly 15 percent, but its trade surplus with the United States rose by nearly 10 percent.

title: H. KENNETH WANGELIN
description: H. Kenneth Wangelin, a Federal judge who recently retired, died here Wednesday. He was 74 years old.

title: PANAMA CALLS STATE OF EMERGENCY AFTER 4TH DAY OF VIOLENT PROTESTS
description: After the fourth consecutive day of protests and political violence, the Panamanian Government today imposed a ''state of urgency'' under which many civil and political rights were suspended.

title: Allegis Hopes to Recruiit A Top Labor Negotiator
description: In a move to get some semblance of agreement among its 61,000 employees on a $6 billion breakup of the company, the Allegis Corporation has begun looking for a top labor negotiator, insiders said yesterday.

title: Holders Approve Fleet-Norstar Deal
description: Shareholders of the Fleet Financial Group Inc. and Norstar Bancorp of Albany, in separate meetings, approved a $1.3 billion merger. At the Fleet meeting in Providence, 38.5 million shareholders voted with about 98.3 percent favoring the combination, said Bruce P. Crooks, a Fleet spokesman. At the Norstar meeting in Albany, about 29 million shareholders voted, which was 79.2 percent of the 35.4 million eligible votes, and the result was about 96 percent in favor, according to Barry Brandt, a spokesman for Norstar.

title: Aloha Cruise Line Picks A Baltimore Agency
description: Aloha Pacific Cruises has selected Smith Burke & Azzam, Baltimore, as its agency of record after a two-month competition that included two California-based agencies. The account is in the $1.5 million range.

title: PUBLIC HOUSING BILL APPROVED BY HOUSE
description: In a major step toward breaking a seven-year deadlock over the Government's role in housing, the House of Representatives today overwhelmingly approved a public housing bill costing up to $15.8 billion. The action set the stage for a confrontation with the White House.

title: The Art of Newslettering
description: It is deadline.

title: FOODARAMA SUPERMARKETS reports earnings for 13wks to May 2
First Jersey Given Penalty
description: First Jersey Securities Inc. and its Atlanta branch manager have agreed to pay $97,500 in penalties and cost reimbursements, concluding a state investigation into purported securities violations. Georgia's Secretary of State, Max Cleland, said Wednesday that the consent order signed by the branch manager, Matthew Wochele, and the New York-based stock brokerage firm also placed the company under probation for two years in Georgia.

title: Ex-Nazi Faces Ouster
description: Johann Leprich, a former Nazi soldier who admitted lying about his past to gain entry to the United States after World War II, will be stripped of his citizenship, a Federal district judge has ruled. Mr. Leprich, 61 years old, will be denaturalized, the judge, Barbara Hackett, ruled Monday in granting a request by the Justice Department. Mr. Leprich admitted last year that he he had served in the Death's Head Battalion, an SS unit that guarded the concentration camp Mauthausen.

title: When Hospital Doctors Labor to Exhaustion
description: To the Editor:

title: Impaired Care
description: To the Editor:

title: VETERANS AGENCY IS PENALIZED OVER DATE ORDERED BY COURT
description: The Veterans Administration was ordered to pay thousands of dollars in new penalties today because a judge ruled it had illegally withheld internal documents sought by a veterans' group in an increasingly bitter lawsuit.

title: Bridge: A Game in Florida Involved Dreaming and Daydreaming
description: Bridge performance may depend on whether a player is fully awake, half awake or totally asleep. All three states were involved in the diagramed deal, played recently in Florida.

title: LIPS UNSEALED, THE REGULARS SHARE THEIR COUNTRY JOYS
description: ACCORDING to a good many residents of Manhattan who have second homes within weekend commuting distance, they will be ostracized, lynched or maybe tried for treason if they so much as breathe the name of interesting places in their areas. In fact, a lot of them don't even want the areas mentioned. They'll be overrun with tourists, they say, and they want to stay rustic and unpublicized.

title: JUDGE UNDER A CLOUD: HORTENSE WITTSTEIN GABEL
description: Hortense W. Gabel first gained wide notice more than 30 years ago as a feisty antagonist of politicians whom she accused of abusing their offices to enrich themselves and real-estate developers.

title: Musical Mobiles Recalled
description: Musical crib mobiles made by Woodcrafter Kits Inc. are being recalled because of excess lead in the paint, the Consumer Product Safety Commission announced today. The paint on the mobiles contains more lead than is permitted in Federal rules, and paint that flaked off could pose a hazard, the agency said. No poisoning incidents involving the toy have been reported. The recall involves the model LP-205 musical mobile toy, which has two smiling satellites orbiting to music. It is designed to be attached to a crib rod.

title: RESTAURANTS
description: IT took about 30 seconds for word to spread on the Upper West Side that a serious new fish house called Coastal had opened on Amsterdam Avenue. The tidal wave of urbanites that rushed in nearly drowned the staff before it had time to develop sea legs.

title: German G.N.P. Drops by 0.5%
description: West Germany's gross national product fell five-tenths of 1 percent in the first quarter from the fourth quarter of 1986, the Government statistics office said.

title: Closing In
description: Last season, Don Baylor of the Boston Red Sox was hit by a pitch 35 times and became the American League career leader at ''taking one for the team.'' On Wednesday night in Baltimore, he was plunked for the 239th time (12th this season) and moved to within four of tying Ron Hunt, the major league career leader. The top 12 in the category:

title: Five Straight Birdies Put Lyle Ahead
description: Sandy Lyle and Seve Ballesteros, the leading Europeans in the Manufacturers Hanover Westchester Classic, played together in the opening round here today and inspired each other.

title: FILM: 'BURKE AND WILLS,' A TREK ACROSS AUSTRALIA
description: TWO hours and 20 minutes may not seem excessive for a 3,700-mile trek across an untracked Australia, yet you may find yourself fidgeting in the course of the new Australian movie based on that adventure. Despite Russell Boyd's stunning photography and a big, burly, bushy-bearded performance by Jack Thompson as Burke, leader of the 19th-century expedition, ''Burke and Wills,'' which opens today at Cinema 1, runs short of plot even before the explorers run short of water.

title: Becor Western
description: Becor Western Inc. said it had adjourned its annual shareholders meeting to evaluate a possible takeover offer from a new unidentified bidder. The company said it was also examining a bid from Davis Mining and Manufacturing Inc. and a merger proposal from BCW Acquisition, a buyout group formed by members of Becor Management and Goldman, Sachs & Company. Becor said the meeting would be reconvened next Thursday.

title: POPE CALLS SOLIDARITY A RIGHTS MODEL
description: Pope John Paul II today proclaimed the outlawed Solidarity labor movement a model for all human rights struggles, declaring that the world must remember Poland's brief, now dormant experiment with freedom.

title: Reagan's 'Weak, Coercive' AIDS Plan
description: LEAD: After months of growing public demand for the Federal Government to take more aggressive action against AIDS, we now have the Reagan plan. By an accident of history, this Administration had the opportunity to lead the American people through the most difficult health crisis that we may ever see. Instead, its policy is both abjectly weak and gratuitously coercive - too little, too late and tragically beside the point.

title: Goodyear's Threat on JWT Bid
description: THE Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company said yesterday that it would desert the J. Walter Thompson Company, its agency since 1978, if the London-based WPP Group P.L.C. takes over the agency's parent, JWT Group Inc.

title: A Softball Date Before the Prom
description: The Westhill High School girls' varsity softball team from Stamford, Conn., faced a dilemma while playing Fairfield in the semifinals of the Fairfield County Interscholastic Athletic Conference tournament.

title: New Jersey
description: Princeton University - Princeton. There are guided tours of Princeton University every day at 10 and 11 A.M and at 1:30 and 3:30 P.M., except Sundays, when there are no morning tours. Orange Key, which conducts the free hourlong tours, also has self-guided tours of the campus trees, sculpture, architecture and, a favorite of many, the dozens of gargoyles.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Golf Richard Leads Mayflower by a Shot: Deb Richard, who has never finished in the top 15 in her two years on the L.P.G.A. tour, shot a six-under-par 66 yesterday to take a one-stroke lead after one round of the Mayflower Classic in Indianapolis. Lenore Muraoka, who hasn't finished higher than 37th this year, shot a career-best 67 to share second with Colleen Walker and Cathy Gerring.(AP) Track and Field Ashford Upset in Dash: Angela Issajenko Taylor of Canada upset the world record-holder, Evelyn Ashford of the United States, in the women's 100-meter dash in a track and field meet last night in Verona, Italy. The Jamaican-born sprinter was timed in 11 minutes 19 seconds while Ashford, who holds the world mark of 10.76 seconds, finished second in 11.28. Another Canadian, Ben Johnson, won the men's 100-meters in 10.15 seconds. Calvin Smith of the United States won the 200-meter dash in 20.63 seconds.(AP) Tennis Becker Gains Quarterfinals: Boris Becker continued his preparation for Wimbledon by beating John Sadri, 6-4, 6-4, yesterday and reaching the quarterfinals of the Stella Artois grass-court tennis championships at the Queens Club in London. Becker, a two-time defending Wimbledon champion from West Germany, and the top-seeded player in this tournament, slammed 10 aces and lost only 7 points on serve in overpowering his American opponent. Becker's opponent in the quarterfinals will be David Pate of the United States, who defeated Bill Scanlon. (AP) Hanika Is Upset: Elise Burgin of Baltimore upset sixth-seeded Sylvia Hanika of West Germany, 6-7, 6-2, 6-3, in the Edgbaston Cup women's grass-court tennis championship in Birmingham, England. (AP) Bowling U.S. Women Take Gold: The United States women's team rolled a record final game of 1,063 yesterday and won its third straight gold medal in the World Bowling Championships in Helsinki, Finland. The American women finished with a record six-game total of 6,011. Sweden was second with 5,946. Sweden won the men's gold medal with a six-game total of 6,272. The United States, with 5,924, was eighth.(AP)

title: Effort Is Disclosed to Rescue Jet Flown by Dean Martin Jr.
description: An air traffic controller frantically tried to guide Dean Paul Martin's Air National Guard jet through a blizzard just before it crashed, but heavy air traffic hampered communications, according to an Air Force investigation.

title: REAGAN MENTION OF LOWER DOLLAR BRINGS A CLARIFICATION FROM AIDES
description: President Reagan told a news conference today that the dollar ''should remain stable'' but that ''there could still be some lowering.''

title: Species Loyalty
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 ACQUITTED OF RACKETEERING CHARGES AT GAMBINO TRIAL IN BROOKLYN
description: Two men described by the authorities as captains in the Gambino organized-crime family were acquitted yesterday of Federal racketeering conspiracy charges.

title: JOHN DAVENPORT
description: John Davenport, an author and freelance writer who was a former assistant managing editor of Fortune magazine, died Monday at Riverview Hospital in Red Bank, N.J. He was 82 years old and lived in Middletown, N.J.

title: U.S. MOVE IN THE GULF: MORE FIRMLY ON IRAQ'S SIDE
description: Diplomats in the Persian Gulf region say the United States appears more firmly on Iraq's side in the war against Iran because of President Reagan's decision to place half of Kuwait's tanker fleet under the protection of the American flag. They say the United

title: Just Raising Benefits Is Not Welfare Reform
description: To the Editor:

title: Former Morgan Officer Indicted for Conspiracy
description: A former vice president at the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company was indicted yesterday on charges of conspiracy and aiding and abetting the illegal activities of Antonio Gebauer, the former Morgan executive who pleaded guilty to defrauding the bank.

title: 'Strong on Music'
description: Although a lawyer by profession, George Templeton Strong was also a 19th-century patron of the arts who kept a journal of his cultural activities. The music scene of that period, as illustrated in his writing, is the subject of the exhibition ''Strong on Music: The New York Music Scene, 1836-1850,'' on view through Sept. 20 at the New-York Historical Society, 170 Central Park West, at 76th Street. The exhibition features paintings, prints, sheet music, newspapers and, the journal itself. Hours are 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. Tuesday through Saturday and 1 to 5 P.M. Sunday. Admission, $2 ($1.50 for the elderly; $1 for those under 12.) Information: 873-3400.

title: PARTIES SAY TO ITALIANS: PLEASE VOTE
description: Four days before national parliamentary elections, Italy's political parties are all growing fearful of what is being called the country's third biggest grouping: those who do not vote.

title: FILM: 'THE WITCHES OF EASTWICK'
description: JOHN UPDIKE performed his own bit of deviltry when he concocted ''The Witches of Eastwick,'' a novel filled with such delicious mischief that it seems made for the movies. With its three small-town New England witches, all divorced or conveniently widowed (one has ''permanized'' her husband ''in plastic and used him as a place mat'') and its latter-day devil, an extremely eligible bachelor who adores synthetics and Pop Art, Mr. Updike's story has great comic possibilities. It also has enormous visual appeal, since the witches are apt to do things like unstring pearl necklaces or conjure up thunderstorms to express their pique.

title: Ms. Myerson, the Judge and the Mayor
description: Two public offices were grossly abused when Bess Myerson, then New York City's Cultural Affairs Commissioner, hired the daughter of the judge presiding over the divorce of Carl Capasso, the Commissioner's companion. This transaction demands more public answers and appropriate prosecution.

title: Money Fund Assets Fall
description: Assets of the nation's 383 money market mutual funds decreased $2.46 billion, to $236.45 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Assets of the 94 institutional funds were down $992.5 million, to $63.44 billion. Assets of the 199 general-purpose funds decreased $921.0 million, to $68.19 billion. The 90 broker-dealer funds decreased $544.3 million, to $104.82 billion.

title: Redman Rotation
description: Two alumni of St. John's University, Frank Viola of the Minnesota Twins and John Franco of the Cincinnati Reds, are pitching in the major leagues, and a third Redman pitcher is trying to join them. Terry Bross, the starting center on the St. John's basketball team, signed yesterday with the Mets. He will report June 20 to the Mets' Little Falls club in the Class A New York-Penn League. The league season will end Sept. 1, in time for Bross to be back at college when his senior-year classes begin Sept. 9. He will continue to play basketball for St. John's, and the school says his contract with the Mets will allow him to report late for spring training if the St John's basketball season lasts longer than expected. The Mets chose the 6-foot-9-inch Bross in the 13th round of the recent amateur draft. After an outstanding season as a high school junior in Somerville, N.J., he gave up baseball to concentrate on basketball. He did not play baseball again until this season. The right-hander pitched 21Y innings in 7 games with 17 walks, 15 strikeouts, a record of 0-1 and a 2.95 earned run average. His fastball has been measured at 90 miles per hour.

title: Diner's Journal
description: LITTLE ITALY is one of the more challenging gastronomic labyrinths in the city, a neighborhood replete with deceptively homey-looking restaurants that are little more than tourist cafeterias. Occasionally, though, I stumble upon one that turns out an extraordinary dish or two. Positano, a remarkably inexpensive, simply appointed stucco-and-brick dining room on Mulberry Street, is notable for its fine light touch with pastas - and bargain prices.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday 'THE MOTHER OF US ALL'

title: AFGHANS SAY REBELS SHOT DOWN AIRLINER WITH A U.S. MISSILE
description: The Kabul radio said today that Afghan guerrillas firing American-made Stinger missiles shot down an Afghan passenger plane, killing 53 of the 55 people on board.

title: BAKKER VOWS TO RETURN TO MINISTRY
description: Jim and Tammy Bakker returned to their home here late Wednesday night, promising to return to television evangelism within 30 days.

title: Computer Phone Fee Might Soar
description: Millions of computer users, both individuals and businesses, would pay substantially higher fees for telephone hookups to information services under a new Government proposal, industry officials said today.

title: ETHNIC VIOLENCE IN SRI LANKA KILLS MORE THAN 30
description: More than 30 people were killed today in renewed ethnic violence in Sri Lanka's north and east, less that a week after the army had completed a campaign against Tamil guerrilla strongholds on Jaffna Peninsula.

title: Twist for Knicks
description: The unexpected rejection of the Knicks' general-manager job by Jack McCloskey of the Detroit Pistons this week could have other ramifications for the Knicks in their search for a new general manager. David Checketts of the Utah Jazz, who is also under consideration for the position, said yesterday that Richard Evans, the Knicks president, had promised him that if the job were offered to anyone else besides Checketts, he would be called. Checketts said that he wasn't called, and as a result, he said he told Evans on Wednesday that he would like the matter to be resolved - one way or the other - soon. . . . Richie Adubato, the Dallas Mavericks assistant coach, says that he will remain with the team. Adubato, the only assistant coach last season under Dick Motta, had hinted he would look for another job after John MacLeod was hired as the Mavericks' head coach last week.

title: FILM: SCHWARZENEGGER IN 'PREDATOR'
description: ''PREDATOR'' starts out as a second cousin to ''Rambo'' and ''Missing in Action,'' with Arnold Schwarzenegger (as Maj. Dutch Schaefer) leading a covert mission to find military operatives missing in Latin America. After 45 long minutes, he and his cohorts (among them Carl Weathers) find an enemy camp and conduct a raid. ''Knock, knock,'' says Mr. Schwarzenegger, kicking down the door to a hut. ''Stick around,'' he says, running somebody through with a sword.

title: Rhody's Partner
description: As reported, Ronald E. Rhody, 55 years old, will be opening his own public relations firm as soon as a successor is named for him at BankAmerica, where he has served as senior vice president for corporate communications and external affairs since 1983. Joining him will be William Shepard, a former vice president of public relations and advertising at Alcoa and head of his own counseling firm in North Carolina. The San Francisco-based firm will also have offices in Los Angeles, Washington and New York.

title: F.A.A. REDUCING FLOW OF AIR TRAFFIC
description: The Federal Aviation Administration said today that it was reducing the flow of air traffic through the nation's busiest airspace sectors when they faced saturation. It said that the program had been adopted to increase safety margins but acknowledged that it was causing added delays.

title: IN THE AMAZON, AMAZING DOINGS AT RABBI'S TOMB
description: Rabbi Salom Moyal of Jerusalem never intended to stay along the Amazon and perform miracles, but that is what people in this jungle city insist he has been doing for many years.

title: Broken Continuity
description: To the Editor:

title: CHARLES GARSIDE Jr.
description: Charles Garside Jr., a history professor at Rice University, died yesterday at St. Luke's Episcopal Hospital in Houston of complications after a stroke. He was 59 years old.

title: UGI-Cal Gas Deal
description: The UGI Corporation said its AP Propoane joint venture completed the purchase of the Cal Gas Corporation, a retail marketer of propane, from the Dillingham Corporation for about $295 million. UGI said AP Propane was owned by its Amerigas unit and the Prudential Insurance Company of America. UGI said the acquisition was a move to gain national presence in the propane industry. UGI is a diversified utility with interests in propane and industrial gases and is based in Valley Forge, Pa.

title: Tribute to C.I.A.
description: Representative Stephen J. Solarz, a Brooklyn Democrat who is on the House Foreign Affairs Committee, tells this story about a recent fact-finding trip to Honduras: At a camp for the Nicaraguan insurgents, a United States intelligence agent introduced the Congressman to a contra officer. The officer was wearing a baseball cap with a pyramid design in front. On each side of the pyramid was a legend: ''Admit Nothing -Deny Everything - Make Counter-Accusations.'' ''I asked him where he got the hat,'' Mr. Solarz said, ''and he answered that it had been run off at the special effects shop in Langley,'' the Virginia district where the Central Intelligence Agency is based.

title: France Approves Genentech's T.P.A.
description: Genentech Inc., a leading biotechnology company based in South San Francisco, said that its foreign licensee, Boehringer Ingelheim International G.m.b.H., had received approval to market tissue plasminogen activator, a blood-clot-dissolving drug, in France. The drug, which will be used in treating heart attack patients, has been approved in the Philippines and New Zealand.

title: Luce Tells of Shift By Allegis Board
description: Charles F. Luce, the senior director of the Allegis Corporation who had a pivotal role in the decision to break up the company and force the resignation of Richard J. Ferris as chairman, described yesterday why the board switched its stand this week.

title: BROWN-FORMAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Dow Gains 6.52 on Reduced Volume
description: The stock market continued its leisurely rally yesterday, with the Dow Jones industrial average gaining 6.52 points, to 2,360.13. But the pace of stock trading, which had picked up in the previous two sessions, settled down. Still, the Dow is now only about 45 points below its record high.

title: S.E.C. Acts On Unequal Stock Votes
description: In a step that could remove a key defense against hostile takeovers, the Securities and Exchange Commission today proposed a rule that would forbid corporate managements from diluting the voting rights of their existing shareholders by issuing new classes of stock with multiple voting powers.

title: Thompson Big Band
description: The 21-piece Walter Thompson Big Band is to perform new compositions for big band tonight at 8 P.M. at Greenwich House, 27 Barrow Street (242-4770). Tickets are $6.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A report in the Company News column of Business Day yesterday about the ITT Corporation gave an incorrect date for the plan to cut long-distance rates. It is scheduled for August or September.

title: FILM: SCHWARZENEGGER IN 'PREDATOR'
description: ''PREDATOR'' starts out as a second cousin to ''Rambo'' and ''Missing in Action,'' with Arnold Schwarzenegger (as Maj. Dutch Schaefer) leading a covert mission to find military operatives missing in Latin America. After 45 long minutes, he and his cohorts (among them Carl Weathers) find an enemy camp and conduct a raid. ''Knock, knock,'' says Mr. Schwarzenegger, kicking down the door to a hut. ''Stick around,'' he says, running somebody through with a sword.

title: CITING 'STATE OF EMERGENCY,' NEW YORK STARTS DRUG-CLINIC PROGRAM TO FIGHT AIDS
description: Warning that the spreading AIDS epidemic among intravenous drug users in New York City had reached a ''state of emergency,'' state and city officials disclosed a new program yesterday that would provide treatment for 3,000 drug addicts.

title: COUNTRYWIDE CREDIT INDUSRIES reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
FILM: 'MILLION DOLLARY MYSTERY'
description: LEGEND has it that Dino De Laurentiis was walking down the street one day when he saw a line of people buying lottery tickets. If a movie could capture the excitement of this experience, he reasoned, it might be a big hit. We are fortunate that he was not passing a bank robbery or a natural disaster when inspiration struck.

title: AIR CONTROLLERS VOTE NEW UNION OVER ISSUES THAT LED TO '81 STRIKE
description: The nation's air traffic controllers, successors to the thousands who lost their jobs when President Reagan broke an illegal strike in 1981, selected a new union today.

title: STAGE: 'NO WAY TO TREAT A LADY'
description: RARELY has a musical comedy boasted a villain with the elegantly nefarious charisma of Stephen Bogardus's Kit Gill in ''No Way to Treat a Lady.'' The show, adapted by Douglas J. Cohen from the movie, which was in turn adapted from the William Goldman novel, tells the story of a Manhattan serial murderer whose victims remind him of his monstrous actress-mother. In its subject matter, high musical tone, and gallows humor, it aspires to be a boutique-sized ''Sweeney Todd'' with more than a dash of ''Psycho.''

title: When We Could Believe
description: At the Harvard commencement 40 years ago Secretary of State George Marshall made his proposal for American aid to the devastated nations of Europe. In a few spare paragraphs, without oratorical flourish, he opened the way for the West's great postwar economic and political achievements.

title: Roosevelt's Ex-Wife Dies
description: Gladys Irene Roosevelt, 70 years old, a former wife of Franklin D. Roosevelt's son James, has died in a fire in her desert home. Mrs. Roosevelt was identified Wednesday as the victim of the fire on Friday, according to the Riverside County Cororner. The former Gladys Irene Owens married Mr. Roosevelt in 1956. She was his third wife. The couple divorced in 1969.

title: At the Movies
description: A Look at Vice

title: Allegheny Sales
description: The Allegheny Beverage Corporation said it had signed separate definitive purchase agreements, contingent upon financing, covering the sales of its laundry services and office furniture divisions. The laundry services division is being sold for $72.5 million in cash, and the office furniture unit is being sold for $12 million, with $6.5 million to be received in cash and the remainder to be financed by Allegheny.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Barnett Banks of Florida Inc., Jacksonville, Fla., said it had received approval from the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. to merge with Home Federal Bank of Florida.

title: 'UNCLE TOM'S CABIN'
description: IN what is called a ''contemporary adaptation,'' Showtime is presenting, this Sunday at 8 P.M., a film version of Harriet Beecher Stowe's ''Uncle Tom's Cabin.'' First published in 1852, the novel was an immediate success, selling 300,000 copies within a year. And from the outset, its unflattering depiction of slavery was controversial. Some attacked Mrs. Stowe for keeping the nation's blood at a boiling point. In this century, of course, Uncle Tom became a symbol among some civil-rights activists of shuffling acquiescence.

title: Pratt & Whitney
description: The United Technologies Corporation said its Pratt & Whitney unit's PW4000 jet engine had received Federal Aviation Administration approval for use on the Airbus Industrie A310. The company said the engine, which takes Pratt & Whitney into the large turbofan market, could represent more than half of the company's commercial engine sales in an estimated $70 billion market in the next 10 years. The company said Airbus Industries' A310-300 twin jet aircraft powered by the new engine was due to start passenger service this month.

title: GORBACHEV AND LIGACHEV, HIS DEPUTY, DIFFER IN WAYS BOTH SUBTLE AND BLUNT
description: Almost from the moment they assumed power more than two years ago, the two Soviet leaders have seemed slightly out of step.

title: CONVICT HAD SLAIN 2
description: Louisiana early today executed a high school dropout who in 1982 helped bind and gag a couple and then shot them dead.

title: ALLISON'S PLACE reports earnings for 13wks to May 2
UTAH POWER & LIGHT reports earnings for 12mo May 31
description: The net in the latest 12 months reflects a charge of $43,741,076 resulting from the December 1986 provision for a refund related to coal mining operations.

title: URS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: The net income and share earnings are from continuing operations.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I hesitate to make optimistic statements, always have, but at the same time, I can't deny that I believe there is an increased opportunity for a summit conference and an increased opportunity for actual reductions of armaments, particularly in - of the nuclear kind.'' - President Reagan. [ A13:1. ]

title: FIRST-TIME AND PUNK PIONEERS
description: AMONG the locals and regular visitors who perform on any weekend in New York City, there are also a few prodigies and apparitions. This weekend brings a discovery - Michelle Shocked, a songwriter, makes her Town Hall debut tomorrow, opening for Loudon Wainwright 3d - and a rediscovery, Wire, the British group, which reunited last year and will perform tomorrow night at the Ritz.

title: FILM: 'MOST BEAUTIFUL'
description: THOUGH it was only Akira Kurosawa's second feature, ''The Most Beautiful'' (1944), a propaganda film meant to boost Japan's industries at the height of the war, is an interesting footnote to the Japanese master's later career. The star is Yoko Yaguchi, who later married Mr. Kurosawa and remained his wife until her death during the production of the recent ''Ran.''

title: Makers Of Policy On AIDS
description: Who makes Federal policy on AIDS? Sometimes it is difficult to tell. Education Secretary William J. Bennett, for example, who has urged young people to refrain from sexual activity as a way to avoid the disease, has been more outspoken than have many Government health officials who, with decades of professional training, would ordinarily be expected to make the major policy decisions on such an epidemic.

title: Comings and Goings
description: When Sachio Kinugasa of the Hiroshima Toyo Carp ran out to third base for last night's game against the Yokohama Taiyo Whales, he matched Lou Gehrig's endurance feat of playing in 2,130 consecutive games. Gehrig took 15 years. Kinugasa needed 17. . . . Will Grimsley, who has covered 35 World Series and 25 Kentucky Derbys for the Associated Press, was given the Red Smith Award for sportswriting last night. Grimsley is 73 years old and has been with the wire service for 44 years.

title: BUCKS COUNTY'S LONG WATER WAR: DECISION TIME
description: For 20 years or more, officials in this area have planned to draw water from the Delaware River at the foot of this village on the river's west bank in Bucks County, then pump it up the lush valley hillside to a holding pond. From there it would be channeled to a nuclear power plant about 30 miles away and to growing suburban communities north of Philadelphia.

title: SCHWARZENEGGER IN 'PREDATOR'
description: ''PREDATOR'' starts out as a second cousin to ''Rambo'' and ''Missing in Action,'' with Arnold Schwarzenegger (as Maj. Dutch Schaefer) leading a covert mission to find military operatives missing in Latin America. After 45 long minutes, he and his cohorts (among them Carl Weathers) find an enemy camp and conduct a raid. ''Knock, knock,'' says Mr. Schwarzenegger, kicking down the door to a hut. ''Stick around,'' he says, running somebody through with a sword.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Tracy Nelson, Lone Star Cafe, Fifth Avenue and 13th Street (242-1664). The superb folk-blues singer Tracy Nelson, who is from Madison, Wis., possesses a penetrating contralto suffused with sorrow and resilience. Inevitably, she has been compared with Janis Joplin, who enjoyed far more commercial success but lacked Ms. Nelson's solidity and discipline. Ms. Nelson has recorded for many different labels over the years, with only marginal success. Her repertory is large, and her signature song, her own bluesy ''Down So Low,'' is classic. Shows are today and tomorrow at 9:30 and 11:30 P.M., and tickets are $12.

title: Narcotics for Cancer Patients
description: LEAD: Cancer pain creates a vicious circle: Uncontrolled pain demoralizes a patient, magnifying the severity of his physical and mental discomfort. With careful, supervised use of narcotics, this pain can be eased and the circle broken.

description: The International Business Machines Corporation said yesterday that it had sold much of its holding in the Intel Corporation, a key supplier of microprocessors for I.B.M. computers, after concluding that the chip maker no longer needed its financial support.

title: Dining Out Guide; Steaks and Chops
description: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. THE COACH HOUSE, #110 Waverly Place (777-0303) - **(Sept. 20, 1985) Brick and paneled walls, red leather banquettes and colorful artwork contribute to the Early American charm of this Greenwich Village restaurant. One of the best black pepper steaks in town comes out of this kitchen - a well-aged slab of tender beef embedded with black peppercorns and blanketed in a dark, intensely favorful veal-stock sauce. Other good options are the prime ribs of beef and rack of lamb. Entrees $18.50 to $25; complete dinners from $30 to $37. Fridays through Sundays, 5:30 to 10:30 P.M. FRANK'S, #431 West 14th Street (243-1349) - (Feb. 3, 1984) A homey, unpretentious Italian steakhouse, comfortable as an old flannel shirt, Frank's has a pressed-tin ceiling, languid overhead fan, sawdust-strewn tile floor and a long, elbow-worn mahogany bar. The best of the food is zesty, and the portions are large. Lamb chops are tender, cooked to a delicious crusty crisp outside, with a rosy pink interior; other selections include the pound-and-a-quarter veal chop, shell steak and skirt steak. Entrees $12.50 to $22. Fridays, 10 A.M. to 3 P.M. and 5 to 11 P.M.; Saturdays, 5 to 11 P.M.; closed Sundays. JAKE'S, #801 Second Avenue, at 43d Street (687-5320) - **(Aug. 31, 1984) A sleek, sophisticated restaurant with black-and-gray interior and red accents, Jake's is a good place to go for some old-fashioned beef: juicy, tender and prime. The prime ribs of beef, two inches thick, fat free and glowingly pink, are enough for two, and the same is true of the rack of lamb - four rosy-hued double chops with crusty coatings are almost fork tender. Also recommended are the thick minute steak and the filet mignon. Entrees $15 to $25. Fridays, noon to 3 P.M. and 5 P.M. to 1 A.M.; Saturdays, 5 P.M. to 2 A.M.; closed Sundays. KEEN'S CHOP HOUSE, #72 West 36th Street (947-3636) - *(March 22, 1985) The century-old landmark building has been renovated, but the four main dining rooms and gleaming old bar still have the look and aroma of a clubby masculine haunt. The star of the menu is the mutton chop, a large section of double-cut loin, charred outside and succulently pink in the center. Broiled filet mignon, rack of lamb and a thick, crusty veal chop smothered in wild mushrooms are all skillfully grilled. Entrees $14.50 to $22.50. Fridays, 11:45 A.M. to 3 P.M. and 5:30 to 11 P.M.; Saturdays, 5 to 11 P.M.; closed Sundays. PALM, #837 Second Avenue, near 45th Street (687-2953) - *(May 30, 1986) This archetypal New York steakhouse, with its sawdust-strewn floors and walls festooned with celebrity caricatures, still plays to clamorous, standing-room-only crowds. The 17-ounce sirloin steak that made the restaurant famous is still a winner -seared under a superhot broiler to impart a blackened crust while remaining juicy and succulent within. Other reliable options are veal chops and double-cut lamb chops. Entrees $17.50 to $22. Fridays, noon to 11:30 P.M.; Saturdays, 5 to 11:30 P.M.; closed Sundays. PETER LUGER, #178 Broadway, Williamsburg, Brooklyn (718-387-7400) -

description: The Hilliard Ensemble of London - David James, countertenor, Rogers Covey-Crump and John Potter, tenors, Paul Hillier, baritone, and Michael George, bass - wil present a concert of English sacred music from the 15th and 16th centuries on Sunday at 4 P.M. in Corpus Christi Church (529 West 121st Street). Tickets are $9, $6 for students and the elderly. Information: 666-0675.

title: THATCHER CLAIMS HER THIRD VICTORY, BUT MARGIN DROPS
description: After a bruising campaign, Margaret Thatcher claimed victory this morning in the British general election and a place in history as the first Prime Minister in this century to win three consecutive terms.

description: M. Richard Robinson Jr. followed in his father's footsteps at Scholastic Inc., but had some rough going when he tried to bring the publishing company into the computer age.

title: MAN KILLS SICK WIFE AND HIMSELF
description: A despondent 70-year-old man walked into a nursing home in Brentwood, L.I., yesterday afternoon, shot and killed his ailing wife and then killed himself, the police said.

title: USE LOGIC, GOETZ JURORS ARE URGED
description: The prosecutor in the trial of Bernhard H. Goetz urged the jurors yesterday to discard any sympathy they might feel for Mr. Goetz or antipathy toward the youths he shot on a subway train in December 1984. Instead, he urged them to submit the trial's evidence ''to the acid test of logic.''

description: Martin S. Sorrell, the 42-year-old chief executive of the WPP Group P.L.C., the British marketing-services company seeking to acquire the JWT Group Inc., may be unknown on Madison Avenue, but he is experienced in media acquisitions.

title: Jordan and Syria Hold Talks
description: King Hussein of Jordan held talks today with the Syrian Prime Minister, Abdel-Raouf al-Kassem, on issues affecting the region and relations between the two countries.

title: Tribute to Casey
description: About 1,000 guests are expected to attend a $250-a-ticket memorial dinner to William J. Casey June 22 at the Sheraton Washington Hotel.

title: British Trade In the Night
description: British dealers stayed open all night to handle what one called a ''phenomenal'' burst of buying following the news of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's election victory.

title: THE SOCIALISTS IN SPAIN LOSE 21 OF THE NATION'S BIG CITIES
description: Spaniards have sent a message of discontent in local elections in which the Socialists of Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez lost outright control of municipal governments in 21 of the country's 27 biggest cities, including Madrid, Valencia, Salamanca and Seville, Mr. Gonzalez's hometown.

title: HARVARD VOTE GIVES VICTORY TO DISSIDENTS
description: Two of six dissident alumni of Harvard University who ran for the Board of Overseers on a platform urging Harvard to divest itself of South Africa-related stocks have been elected, along with three others sympathetic to divestment. The sixth person elected has not taken a public stand on the issue.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: The Black Swan Quartet and the Muhal Richard Abrams Quartet, Merkin Concert Hall, 129 West 67th Street (206-1050.) Over the next two weeks, the World Music Institute's ''Improvisations'' series will present double bills of New York's most important jazz composers and group leaders, a good way to catch up with jazz on its way into the 1990's. As pianist and idea man, Muhal Richard Abrams has been a vital force in modern jazz since the late 1960's, demanding of himself and his cohorts that they explore jazz history while extending the music's reach; he'll be leading a quartet that includes John Purcell on saxophones and clarinet, Lindsey Horner on bass and Andrew Cyrille on drums. The Black Swan Quartet is a string quartet whose muscular ensemble arrangements launch gutsy solos; led by Akbar Ali on violin, it also includes Abdul Wadud and Eileen Folson on cello and Reggie Workman on bass. The quartet will play compositions by Mr. Ali and a Lee Morgan piece, ''Double-Up.'' Tomorrow at 9:30 P.M.; tickets are $12 and $15.

title: KLEINERT'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 30
Jackson and Impac '88
description: The Rev. Jesse L. Jackson has apparently patched up his relationship with Impac '88, a group of prominent Democratic fund-raisers that in the past year has met with most top Democratic Presidential contenders to assess their potential. Mr. Jackson had complained that he had not been invited to speak, but on Wednesday he had his chance, as did a new entry in the race, Senator Paul Simon.

title: REGAN CRITICIZES REPUBLICANS FOR NOT CHALLENGING KOCH ON SCANDALS
description: State Comptroller Edward V. Regan, who has been chided by Republican leaders for what they contend is an overly friendly relationship with Governor Cuomo, yesterday criticized New York City Republican leaders for failing to challenge Mayor Koch and his administration's scandals.

title: 24,000 DEMONSTRATE IN BERLIN AGAINST REAGAN'S VISIT TODAY
description: As the police imposed a security cordon in preparation for President Reagan's visit here, 24,000 leftists marched through the streets today to protest American policies.

title: Ward Will Review Fracas at Hospital
description: Police Commissioner Benjamin Ward will meet Monday with the head of the City Health and Hospitals Corporation to discuss the charges of a Harlem Hospital staff physician that he was the victim of police brutality, a police spokesman said yesterday.

description: b-Includes a gain of $18 million on the sale of mortgages resulting from certain special selling arrangements outside Freddie Mac's regular mortgage participation certificate sales programs. The company said the latest net represents $3.81 a share for about 15 million shares of outstanding participating preferred stock; year-ago first quarter net represents $3.27 for preferred stock.

title: WITNESSES CLASH ON ANIMAL PATENTS
description: Supporters and critics of the patenting of new forms of animal life created by genetic manipulation clashed sharply today as Congressional hearings opened on the issue. One of the few areas of agreement between the two sides was that Congress's decision on whether to uphold the patents would be crucial to the shape and stability of the livestock and dairy industries.

title: A Gunfight in Soweto Marks an Anniversary
description: A black was killed and two white policemen were wounded today in a gun battle in the township of Soweto, the police said. The gunfire brought to a violent start a second year of emergency rule in South Africa.

title: 2 Jersey Lawyers Disbarred
description: The New Jersey Supreme Court has disbarred two noted lawyers, one a former state bar association president, Donald R. Conway, for what it said was their involvement in a plan to bribe a state police officer into dropping charges against someone with ties to organized crime. In separate 4-to-1 decisions Wednesday, the court disbarred Mr. Conway, and Vincent P. Rigolosi, a former Mayor of Garfield who has served as a Bergen County counsel and as a Bergen County Bar Association president.

title: Soybeans, Pork Bellies Soar as Demand Rises
description: Soybean prices at the Chicago Board of Trade and pork belly prices at the neighboring Mercantile Exchange soared today on the strength of bullish fundamentals for both commodities.

description: A former Assistant Secretary of Commerce has told investigators that he was ousted from his job by Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d because he opposed efforts by the Wedtech Corporation to get special treatment from the Government.

title: Blue Jays Streak to 9th in Row
description: George Bell hit two home runs in a game for the sixth time this season and drove in six runs as the Toronto Blue Jays held on tonight to defeat the Baltimore Orioles, 8-6, for their ninth consecutive victory.

title: STAGE: 'THE BALD SOPRANO'
description: THE revival of ''The Bald Soprano'' at the Cubiculo is a doubly significant event. It represents one of Joseph Chaikin's most extensive involvements in theater since his stroke, and it is a rare opportunity to see a first-quality Eugene Ionesco production in New York. Though there was a period when his work was readily available, Ionesco productions have become increasingly sparse, at least in this city.

title: IRAN-CONTRA DOCUMENTS BLOCKED
description: A Geneva court has blocked the release of bank documents sought by United States officials investigating the Iran-contra affair pending the outcome of several legal appeals, officials said today.

title: VISITING CHEFS DO THE TOWN
description: ''My mom told me I'd get run over walking around with my head up in the air, but I'll take my chances,'' said Bill Collins, who doesn't want to miss any of the tall buildings on his second trip to New York. Mr. Collins, the owner of the Texas Pit B-B-Q on the Waterfront in St. Thomas, V.I., was one of the 18 chefs chosen in a competition to cook for the Citymeals-on-Wheels benefit dinner last night at Rockefeller Center.

title: Farmer Wins Bank Battle
description: A Monterey County Superior Court jury has awarded $60 million to a farmer who sued Wells Fargo & Company, contending that the bank forced him into bankruptcy.

title: Volcano Warning in Colombia
description: The Colombian Government has warned of an unusual increase in seismic activity at the Nevado de Ruiz volcano, whose eruption in November 1985 killed more than 23,000 people.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: FRIDAY, JUNE 12, 1987
description: Markets New stock issues with multiple voting rights would be limited by a proposed S.E.C. rule. The plan, which would bar shares carrying more than one vote each, effectively removes one defense against takeovers; it is aimed at preventing managements from diluting existing shareholders' voting power. The New York Stock Exchange is likely to relax its rules against multiple classes of stock. [ Page D1. ] The stock market continued its leisurely rally, but trading slowed to 138.9 million shares. The Dow Jones industrial average gained 6.52, to 2,360.13. [ D6. ] Treasury note and bond prices rose modestly in light trading. [ D13. ] Soybean and pork belly futures soared, helped by increased demand. [ D14. ] President Reagan seemed to shift his position on the dollar at a news conference at the end of the Venice summit meeting. He said that ''there could still be some lowering'' in the dollar. But White House aides quickly sought to discourage such interpretations. [ A13. ] The dollar closed little changed in trading that was light except for a brief stir caused by the President's remarks. Gold and other precious metals posted solid increases. [ D14. ] The Economy Millions of computer users would pay much higher fees for telephone hookups to information services under a new Government proposal. Various officials estimate that the fee would raise charges by $4.50 to $5.40 an hour. [ D1. ] The nation's air traffic controllers selected a new union. The controllers are successors of those dismissed by President Reagan over an illegal strike in 1981. [ A1. ] Retail sales fell 0.6 percent in May, largely because of weak automobile sales. But the drop still concerned economists. [ D4. ] Companies I.B.M. has sold much of its Intel stake after deciding that the chip maker no longer needed its financial support. Intel has bought back $361.6 million of its stock, leaving I.B.M.'s stake at about 11 percent, down from 20 percent. I.B.M.'s cash infusion, made in 1982, had resulted from its fear that Intel might not have enough capital to develop chips used in personal computers. [ D1. ] Procter & Gamble will restructure some product lines and close several factories, resulting in an $800 million pretax charge against earnings. A sizable portion of the write-off stems from the company's costly battle in the ready-to-eat cookie business. The moves also reflect the growth of liquid detergents at the expense of powders. [ D1. ] Allegis is seeking a top labor negotiator, with the goal of getting some consensus among its 61,000 employees on the company's breakup, according to insiders. The search is being handled by Frank A. Olson, the company's chief executive. [ D1. ] Charles F. Luce, a senior director of Allegis, said the board reversed its stance because the market ''would not wait'' for the company's diversification to prove itself. [ D2. ] Chemical will increase its reserve for possible loan losses by $1.1 billion. It said the move would result in a $1.1 billion second-quarter loss and a $710 million full-year loss. [ D1. ] JWT gained some client support. Goodyear said it would desert J. Walter Thompson if a British company's bid for the agency's parent is successful. Meanwhile, an industry expert said that WPP Group would begin a tender offer for JWT today. [ D5. ] Pay 'N Pak rejected a sweetened bid from Paul A. Bilzerian that the Florida raider had valued at $220 million. [ D4. ] A former official at Morgan Guaranty was indicted on charges of conspiracy and abetting the illegal activities of a former Morgan executive who had pleaded guilty to defrauding the bank. [ D4. ] International Japan's overall trade surplus declined in May by nearly 15 percent but rose by nearly 10 percent with the U.S. [ D2. ] Today's Columns The Venice summit showed that no agreement exists for achieving a stable exchange-rate structure, more balanced trade and stronger growth. Leonard Silk. Economic Scene. [ D2. ] Secondary stocks are being promoted by some investment advisers. These ''special situations'' include an Ohio bank, an operator of day-care centers and a casino manager. Market Place. [ D6. ]

title: HENRY M. STORHOFF
description: Henry M. Storhoff, one of a few people who could play the psalmodicon, died Wednesday at the age of 81.

title: Rail History Tour
description: The days of Brooklyn as a maze of trolley tracks and rail lines are to be explored on a bus tour Sunday sponsored by the Prospect Park Environmental Center. The history of rail travel, both street level and below, is to be illustrated with stops in Brooklyn Heights, Bay Ridge and Coney Island, where a subway facility is located. The daylong tour begins at 10 A.M. at Grand Army Plaza, off Flatbush Avenue. Reservations are necessary: (718) 788-8500.

description: LEAD: The Viennese ball had just ended, and the exhausted couples waltzed off the floor. They ran to their dressing rooms, discarded the glamorous gowns and handsome dark suits and made off into the night. title: People
description: * Jayne Eastman has been promoted to executive vice president and director of marketing and strategic planning at Wells, Rich, Greene/Worldwide.

description: A piece by Russ Wilson in the May 28 issue of the Long Island edition of The Fisherman does a nice job of explaining how to rig a whole eel - often an enormously successful night bait for striped bass -on a metal squid or jig.

description: The Procter & Gamble Company said yesterday that it would take an $800 million pretax charge against earnings to cover the cost of closing factories and restructuring several key product lines. The write-off will reduce Procter's projected earnings for the year ending June 30 by $435 million.
