title: CIVILIAN COMPLAINTS OF BRUTALITY BY POLICE SAID TO DECREASE IN '86
description: Civilian complaints of brutality by New York City police officers decreased slightly last year, reversing a trend, according to a Police Department report issued yesterday.

title: VW May Make Claims on Bank
description: Volkswagen A.G. said today that it had not ruled out the possibility that it might make claims on the National Bank of Hungary arising out of the multimillion-dollar currency fraud against it.

title: FLORIDA JUDGE ORDERS HOSPITAL QUARANTINE FOR YOUTH IN AIDS CASE
description: A Florida court has ordered a 14-year-old Pensacola youth quarantined in a hospital psychiatric ward after state health officials said the youth had been exposed to AIDS, was sexually active and represented a danger to public health.

title: Sensible Answers to Death and Deceit
description: Not long ago, death was a private affair. Most people died at home, nature deciding the moment of departure. Today most people die in institutions, and often it is man, not nature, who decides when.

title: U.S. AND FRANCE IN ARMS TALKS ACCORD
description: The United States and France have reached a tentative agreement on ways for the West to negotiate with the Soviet Union on conventional arms, a senior State Department official said today.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: NO VISION IN VENICE
description: The seven leaders left the economic summit conference proclaiming how pleased they were with themselves, and in a way it was true. They had come with thunderous warnings of tough talk, especially from the United States. But no one's arm was twisted, no one's toes were trodden on. They came up with banalities and ambiguities to address the issues before them with the least possible friction, and with the least possible content.

title: THE ALGONQUIN IN SOLD TO JAPANESE HOTELIER
description: The Algonquin Hotel, fabled haunt of writers and artists, has been sold for $29 million to a Brazilian subsidiary of a Tokyo corporation, it was announced yesterday.

title: New Clashes Keep Central Seoul Under Siege
description: After a night of fierce clashes, central Seoul lay under police siege today as student radicals pressed anti-Government protests.

title: MORTGAGE GROWTH INVESTORS reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
THE EVENING HOURS
description: ''TELL me, do you stay out late in New York?'' Jane Ikard asked her friend Roz Jacobs. Mrs. Ikard had just arrived from Washington for a party at the United Nations. ''We don't know your quaint local customs.''

title: Hudson Valley
description: Storm King Art Center - Mountainville, N.Y., on the west bank of the Hudson River, near Cornwall. The center displays hundreds of big works by such renowned sculptors as David Smith, Anthony Caro, Alexander Calder, Louise Nevelson, Isamu Noguchi, Alexander Liberman, Mark di Suvero, Henry Moore, Kenneth Snelson and Isaac Witkin, daily except Tuesday, from noon until 5:30 P.M.

title: The U.N. Today: June 12, 1987
description: SECURITY COUNCIL

title: Catnapping on the Grand Canal
description: Cameras caught more than one Western leader with drooping eyelids in the closing moments of their summit conference in Venice. Sadly, there wasn't much reason to stay awake. To avoid embarrassing each other, or exposing their own political weaknesses, none of the seven leaders had pressed for tough decisions on any of the world's burning issues. As a result, the meeting itself was an embarrassment.

title: Elizabeth Hartman, 'Patch of Blue' Star, Is Suspected Suicide
description: Elizabeth Hartman, who was nominated for an Academy Award for best actress in 1966 for her role in ''A Patch of Blue,'' died in a fall from her fifth-floor apartment in Pittsburgh on Wednesday.

title: Plapler Closes
description: When People Express was absorbed by Continental Airlines, 90 percent of the business of Plapler & Associates went down the drain. The agency was closed this week, and its founder, Larry Plapler, once a creative light also at Levine, Huntley, Schmidt, Plapler & Beaver, has joined Young & Rubicam as a senior vice president and creative group head.

title: Museum Seeks Broadcast Ads
description: New York is going to have a museum of broadcast advertising, thanks to a $375,000 grant from the Advertising Educational Foundation. But to make it a success, it must receive copies of advertising as donations.

title: Open Scoring Sought
description: Dennis Rappaport, the co-manager of Gerry Cooney, has called for a round-by-round breakdown of the official scoring during Cooney's 15-round heavyweight match Monday in Atlantic City against Michael Spinks. Rappaport said that he is seeking the change ''so the millions of viewers in closed-circuit seats and those live at the Convention Center will know how the officials are scoring.'' Rappaport has expressed uneasiness about what he has called closeness between Larry Hazzard, the chairman of the New Jersey State Athletic Control Board, and Butch Lewis, Spinks's promoter. Hazzard and his commission are choosing the bout's officials. ''Any official licensed in the state of New Jersey has our confidence,'' Hazzard said.

title: ART: TWO KINDS OF POP, FAKERY AND MASCULINITY
description: IN making the United States No. 1 on the global art charts, Abstract Expressionism also sowed the seeds of a vast art education system. Which is funny, considering the disdain that most of the primary Abstract Expressionists had for the academy. In replacing the movement, Pop aimed as much at the philosophy as the product, yet left intact the network of university art departments that by then was an industry capable of retooling at a moment's notice.

title: Problems at Brooklyn College
description: A month after Brooklyn College was cited by the National Collegiate Athletic Association for rules infractions, the former officials who first reported the improprieties are locked in a dispute with the school over who was responsible for the problems.

title: His Name Doesn't Hit Shots
description: Almost as slender as the shaft of his putter, the tall blond golfer in a light blue shirt and navy blue slacks was lining up a 3-footer that he would hole for a par. In the shade near the first green at the Manufacturers Hanover Westchester Classic, three gray-haired men were talking quietly about the 25-year-old pro from West Palm Beach, Fla.

title: REAGAN PUTS OFF A SALE TO SAUDIS OF 1,600 MISSILES
description: The Reagan Administration bowed today to fierce Congressional opposition and withdrew a proposal to sell 1,600 Maverick air-to-ground missiles to Saudi Arabia.

title: Finnish Regime Wins a Test
description: Finland's six-week-old coalition Government survived a no-confidence motion today by a 121-20 vote in Parliament. The Communist-run People's Democratic League accused the Cabinet of Prime Minister Harri Holkeri of indifference to layoffs in industry and also of neglecting trade with the Soviet Union.

title: U.S. AIDES FAULTED IN THE DEAVER CASE
description: The special prosecutor in the Michael K. Deaver perjury case has accused the State Department of raising ''serious questions about its own impartiality'' by defending the diplomatic immunity of the Canadian Ambassador to the United States.

title: JUDGE LINKED TO MYERSON NOW FACES CHARGES
description: Judicial misconduct charges have been brought by a state panel against the judge whom Bess Myerson, the former New York City Cultural Affairs Commissioner, is accused of having improperly influenced, law-enforcement officials disclosed yesterday.

title: Navy Boat Plan Wasted $10 Million, Study Finds
description: The Defense Deprtment's inspector general has concluded that the Navy, through gross mismanagement, wasted $10.7 million trying to build the first of a new class of attack boats for its Seal commandos.

title: SCORES ARRESTED IN MONEY-LAUNDERING
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation today announced scores of arrests of people accused of running major narcotics money-laundering rings, among them seven Colombians. Undercover agents processed sums totaling $175 million in the three-year operation.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Tennis Becker Downs Pate: Boris Becker, not quite scaling the heights of his previous matches, downed David Pate of the United States, 6-4, 7-6 yesterday to advance to the semifinals of the $300,000 Stella Artois grass-court tennis tournament at Queens Club in London. But Stefan Edberg, of Sweden, the No. 2 seeded player, was upset, 7-6, 7-6 by Pat Cash of Australia, who reached the last four after a match dominated by serve and decided by two tiebreakers, 9-7 and 7-3. One round behind, Jimmy Connors reached the quarterfinals in his bid to win this title for the fourth time. He led Nigeria's Nduka Odizor 7-5, 2-3 when play resumed after being suspended Thursday night. Connors got the vital break in the 11th game and served out the match with an ace for a 7-5, 7-5 victory.(AP) 3 Top Players in Semifinals: The three top-seeded players in the $107,000 Bologna tennis tournament - Sweden's Kent Carlsson, Martin Jaite of Argentina, and Emilio Sanchez of Spain - all won straight-set matches yesterday and qualified for the semifinals. Carlsson, the No. 1 seeded player, routed Argentina's Franco Davin, 6-0, 6-0. The second-seeded Jaite ousted Jimmy Brown of the United States, 6-1, 6-1, and the third-seeded Sanchez eliminated another American, Blaine Willenborg, 6-3, 6-3 at the tournament in Bologna, Italy.(AP) Shriver Beats Van Rensburg: Top-seeded Pam Shriver beat Dinky Van Rensburg of South Africa, 6-2, 6-3 in the Edgbaston Cup women's grass-court tennis championships yesterday in Birmingham, England. Canada's Carling Bassett rallied to defeat Sharon Walsh Peete, an American, 6-7, 7-6, 6-1 and make the quarterfinals. Bassett forced a second-set tiebreaker which she won 7-5, then easily topped her opponent in the deciding set. (AP) Jarryd Tops Tyson: Anders Jarryd of Sweden, dropped a set but beat Des Tyson, an Australian, 6-4, 3-6, 6-3, to advance to the semifinals against Ivan Lendl at the Scottish Grasscourt tennis championships in Edinburgh yesterday. Johan Kriek also was extended to three sets by Jonathan Canter before prevailing 7-5, 2-6, 6-4. In the semifinals he will meet Andres Gomez of Ecuador.(AP) Golf Walker and Rizzo Tied for Lead: Colleen Walker and Patti Rizzo birdied their final holes yesterday to move into a tie for the lead after two rounds of the L.P.G.A. Mayflower Classic in Indianapolis. Walker shot a two-under-par 70 and Rizzo had a 68 for 36-hole totals of seven-under-par 137. They were one stroke ahead of the first-day leader, Deb Richard, and Cathy Gerring. Penny Hammel shot a 67 and was tied at 139 with Spain's Marta Dotti-Figueras, Shelley Hamlin, Lenore Muraoka and Muffin Spencer-Devlin. (AP) Rodriguez Up by 1: Chi Chi Rodriguez, trying for his fifth consecutive victory, shot an even-par 72 yesterday to maintain a one-shot lead after the two rounds of the $400,000 Mazda Senior Tournament Players Championship in Ponte Vedra, Fla. His 36-hole score of 137 left him a shot ahead of Billy Casper, who had the day's lowest score, a 68. Butch Baird, Bruce Crampton and Charles Owens were three strokes behind at 140. (AP) Bowling Six Gold Medals for U.S.: Rick Steelsmith of Wichita, Kan., and Sandra Jo Shiery of Bronson, Mich., captured the all-events titles to give the United States team its fifth and sixth gold medals in the 11th World Bowling championships in Helsinki, Finland. Steelsmith, 23 years old, a senior at Wichita State University, piled up a record 24-game total of 4,860 to take the men's crown. Shiery, 22, piled up a record 4,895 points in 24 games. (AP)

title: Change at Oral Roberts
description: Ted Owens, who had a 21-36 record in two seasons as basketball coach at Oral Roberts University, resigned Thursday night after three months of pressure from the university. In March, Owens was removed from his post as athletic director, and Ken Trickey, a former head coach at Oral Roberts, was hired as his assistant. In addition, Owens was permitted no voice in decisions to withdraw from the Midwestern Collegiate Conference and to drop Tulsa University from the schedule.

title: 5 ARE INJURED IN RACIAL FIGHT AT A SCHOOL
description: Five students were beaten with baseball bats and 13 youths were arrested yesterday as a roving band of beer-drinking toughs snatched gold chains and attacked victims at random outside a high school in Brooklyn in what the police called an outbreak of racial violence.

title: Prenuptial Agreements
description: MARVIN TOMPKINS, a retired food company sales manager now living in Clearwater, Fla., signed a prenuptial agreement before remarrying 18 months ago.

title: Journalism Behind Bars Is Alive and Well
description: To the Editor:

title: Less Domestic Competitiveness, Please
description: LEAD: The national competitiveness issue seems destined for big play in the upcoming election year. There will be a lot of rhetoric until November 1988 about trade wars, industrial policy, worker retraining, investment incentives and more. Regaining our lost national edge, however, might require steps other than modernizing the means of production and making the rules of the marketplace more fair.

title: DAILY NEWS BIAS TRIAL VIEWED AS AID TO BLACKS
description: Leading black journalists have hailed the plaintiffs' success in a long and bitter racial discrimination trial against The Daily News as a significant development that will encourage the promotion and hiring of blacks in the nation's newsrooms.

title: Daniel Mandell, Won 3 Film Editing Oscars
description: Daniel Mandell, a film editor who won three Oscars and was nominated for five others during a lengthy Hollywood career, died Monday in Huntington Beach, Calif., at the age of 92.

title: INSIDE
description: Presbyterians and Judaism A sweeping document on Christian-Jewish relations appeared headed for defeat at a meeting of the largest Presbyterian denomination. Page 6.

title: NEW OFFICES CHANGING THE THEATER DISTRICT
description: The midtown office district is spilling west across Seventh Avenue and Broadway, transforming a neighborhood of theaters, movie houses and related businesses into a workplace for investment bankers, lawyers and accountants.

title: Saberhagen Gets 11th Victory
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., June 12 (AP) - Bret Saberhagen of the Kansas City Royals pitched a three-hitter, matching the performance of Mike Witt, and raised his record to 11-1 tonight with a 1-0 victory over the California Angels.

title: Japan Bankruptcies Flat
description: The number of Japanese corporate bankruptcies was little changed in May, standing at 1,107, compared with 1,108 in April, the Tokyo Commerce and Industry Research Company said today. Bankruptcies in May were down 32.2 percent from a year earlier, and the amount of debt involved in the bankruptcies was down 62.8 percent from the previous year's level, the private research company said.

title: BOARD AND COUNCIL IN BUDGET ACCORD
description: After almost a week of all-day and all-night negotiations, the City Council and the Board of Estimate reached an agreement last night to add $156.9 million to the $22.8 billion budget proposed by Mayor Koch.

title: AFTERTASTE OF A SCANDAL IS BITTER FOR JESSICA HAHN
description: Nearly three months after the PTL scandal broke, Jessica Hahn, the Pentecostal church secretary who was briefly at the center of it, says she spends her days in her Long Island apartment, bewildered, anguished and alone.

title: DEMOCRATS SEEKS ABRAMS'S OUSTER
description: More than 125 House Democrats called today for the resignation of Elliott Abrams as Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American Affairs, saying he had deceived Congress over his involvement in aid to the Nicaraguan rebels.

title:
Patents;
Plant Proteins Are Used In Treatment of Herpes
description: LEAD: A method of treating herpes simplex virus type 2 was patented this week by Dr. Tom G. Obrig, who is associate professor in the department of microbiology and immunology at the Albany Medical College of Union University. Herpes simplex is a disease marked by groups of blisters on the skin or mucous membranes.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 50

title: The Certain and Ominous Effects of Ozone Loss; Suntans Are Out
description: To the Editor:

title: GUILTY PLEA IN CLINIC BOMBING
description: A 37-year-old fireworks expert pleaded guilty yesterday to charges that he bombed an abortion clinic in Manhattan and tried to bomb another one in Queens.

title: CHAMBERS, ON A TAPE, SAYS LEVIN BEGAN A VIOLENT SCENE
description: Robert E. Chambers Jr., in a videotaped statement to the police last year, asserted that Jennifer Levin died inadvertently during a violent sexual encounter that she instigated after he told her he was interested in other women.

title: Researcher Resigns U.S. Post After Performing Fake Tests
description: A Federal researcher who pleaded guilty in Federal court last month to falsifying chemical analysis reports in accident investigations has resigned from the Federal Aviation Administration.

title: STEINBRENNER ASKS TOP EFFORT
description: George Steinbrenner, the Yankees' demanding owner, is unhappy with the failure of his left-handed hitters, with the sudden lack of dependable pitching, and with the sudden slide into second place this week. He called Monday night's nationally televised 11-0 loss to the Toronto Blue Jays ''embarrassing.''

title: Madge Kennedy Dies; A Film and Stage Star
description: Madge Kennedy, a stage and silent film star in the early part of the century, died of respiratory failure Monday at the Motion Picture and Television Country Hospital in Woodland Hills, Calif. She was 96 years old and lived in Hollywood.

title: Ski Races Cut
description: The Alpine Ski World Cup Committee announced today that the men's calendar will be cut from 30 to 28 races next season while the women's schedule will go from 28 to 27.

title: ERROR ADMITTED ON QUARANTINE OVER AIDS CASE
description: A top health official admitted today that the state had erred by having a 14-year-old boy locked up in a mental ward in an effort to keep him from spreading AIDS. The official said he would ask a judge to lift the quarantine order.

title: MCA-JWT RUMORS
description: Shares in JWT Group Inc. climbed $1.625 in heavy trading on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, to $50.625, amid widespread rumors that MCA Inc. might rescue the big advertising and public relations organization from an unwanted $45-a-share British takeover bid.

title: Paul D. O'Brien, 82, Is Dead; Lawyer for Many Celebrities
description: Paul D. O'Brien, a New York lawyer who had many famous clients from the entertainment industry, died after a long illness on May 29 at his home in Longboat Key, Fla. He was 82 years old.

title: Mets 10, Pirates 2
description: When all else fails for the Mets, when Darryl Strawberry stops talking to Davey Johnson, when Tom Seaver struggles and Bob Ojeda ails and Wally Backman hurts, there are always the bats and Sid Fernandez. And the combination exploded again tonight.

title: Waterbed as Weapon
description: Every once in a while a crime comes along that couldn't have occurred even 50 years ago - simply because the weapon didn't exist. Such is the alleged crime of Karl W. Hall, who lives in Brookville, Va. He is charged with trying to kill his wife with their waterbed.

title: AIDS TEST TO BE OFFERED FOR FOSTER BABIES
description: Mayor Koch has ordered the city to offer AIDS-antibody tests for babies being placed in foster or adoptive care, if prospective parents request the test.

title: RASMUSSEN AND YANKEES END SLUMPS
description: When the game was over, Dennis Rasmussen slumped into a chair in front of his locker and insisted once, twice, three times that he was not aware he might have been pitching last night to save his job with the Yankees.

title: When Lease of New York Waterfront Property Amounts to Sale; Don't Walk
description: To the Editor:

title: Inventories Up in April; Sales Off
description: Business sales fell three-tenths of 1 percent in April while inventories of unsold goods were rising, the Commerce Department reported today. Analysts said this was a bad sign for factory operating rates in the months ahead.

title: Miss Whitlock Marries Marcus Forsell
description: Valantana Welch Whitlock, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Emmet Whitlock of Christiansted, V.I., was married yesterday in Oyster Bay, L.I., to Marcus Albert Ante Forsell, the son of Goran Forsell of Lono, Sweden, and Charlotte Bonnier of New York and Stockholm. The Rev. Mario Costa performed the ceremony at St. Dominic's Roman Catholic Church.

title: ORTHODONTICS FOR ADULTS: A HELP AT ANY AGE
description: Adults with braces, a rarity 10 years ago, are almost commonplace nowadays, and orthodontists say that while their adult patients are more cooperative and responsible than younger ones, the adults complain more about discomfort and are more self-conscious about their appearance.

title: Poor Time to Impede World Health Efforts
description: To the Editor:

title: Ruland Retires
description: The Philadelphia 76ers' center, Jeff Ruland, the key in one of the franchise's most controversial trades, has retired from professional basketball because of a chronic knee injury. ''We have concluded that Jeff can no longer pass physical requirements to play professional basketball,'' said John Nash, the Sixers' general manager.

title: Marine Deserter Held in Jail
description: Pvt. Douglas G. Beane, who spent the last 17 years living in Australia after deserting from the Marine Corps in Vietnam, has been ordered held in jail until his case was settled, the Corps announced today. The 39-year-old marine, who returned to the United States voluntarily to visit his ill father, will be confined to the brig at the Quantico, Va., Marine Base pending a possible court-martial, a Marine Corps statement said.

title: HBO Board Wins
description: HBO & Company, a hospital information services company, said its board had been re-elected with more than 11.9 million votes after a proxy contest begun in March by the Andover Group. HBO said 5.7 million votes had been cast for nominees proposed by Andover, which is an investment group based in suburban Washington, D.C. Last September, Andover had made a $300 million takeover offer for HBO. HBO said it was continuing to work with its advisers, Goldman, Sachs & Company, on efforts to maximize its value to shareholders.

title: FILM: 'DANCES SACRED'
description: Charles Gatewood is a photographer and anthropologist who specializes in ''subcultures.'' On the evidence of ''Dances Sacred and Profane,'' Mark and Dan Jury's documentary about Mr. Gatewood, he is drawn particularly to Mardi Gras revels, gatherings of nudists and sex clubs. Bare breasts, elaborately tattooed bodies and bizarre behavior are featured in his work, and in the movie.

title: Judge Bars Questions Linking Biaggi and a Female Friend
description: The Federal judge in the fraud and bribery trial of Representative Mario Biaggi told lawyers yesterday that a woman who accompanied the Congressman on two vacation trips to Florida should not be asked about their relationship when she testifies.

title: ELUSIVE WEDDING PICTURES
description: IT has been a year and four months since Bill and Joyce Chadwick were married. So far, they have paid $950 of the $1,271.39 that they owe for their wedding pictures, but they have yet to receive them.

title: NICKLAUS MISSES THE CUT AT WESTCHESTER
description: The galleries swelled around Jack Nicklaus as the intermittent rain fell, but he could not satisfy his fans, who have been spoiled by his remarkable success in the past.

title: THE BATTLE OVER BLUEBERRY MUFFINS
description: The subject of blueberry muffins has come up periodically ever since this column carried a recipe two years ago for the blueberry muffins served at the Ritz-Carlton in Boston. The hotel had adapted the muffin recipe used by Gilchrist's, once one of Boston's best-known department stores.

title: TO ANOTHER LEVEL
description: Maybe, after these eight years, mine were lying eyes after all.

title: HUMBERTO COSTANTINI
description: Humberto Costantini, an Argentine writer, died of cancer Sunday in Buenos Aires, according to Janet Brof, his agent here. He was 63 years old.

title: A REALTY CONCERN WITH A BIG APPETITE
description: Neil Bluhm and Judd Malkin first went into business together in the 1950's, when the two teen-agers persuaded a distributor of Hires Root Beer to allow them to split one job, helping to deliver soda. As part of the deal, the driver had to buy breakfast and lunch. After two days the driver said enough, according to Mr. Malkin, ''because I ate too much.''

title: Ueberroth Confirms Hiring of Edwards
description: Peter Ueberroth, the baseball commissioner, confirmed yesterday that Dr. Harry Edwards would be hired by baseball as a part-time consultant to help find jobs in the sport for black and Hispanic former players.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''General Secretary Gorbachev, if you seek peace - if you seek prosperity for the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe - if you seek liberalization: Come here, to this gate. Mr. Gorbachev, open this gate. Mr. Gorbachev, tear down this wall.''

title: Standing Guard At the Tap: A Fine Palate
description: In a hurry as always, Jeanette Best did not bother to use a glass yesterday, but swigged straight from the bottle.

title: AT THE HEIGHT OF FASHION, BLACK MODELS
description: Louise Vyent smiled from the cover of the February issue of Vogue. Two months earlier, Karen Alexander, another black model, appeared in profile on the cover of Elle magazine.

title: Marianne Savare, Teacher, Marries Ronald A. Walter
description: Marianne Savare, the daughter of Mrs. Leo Dugar Savare of Memphis and the late Mr. Savare, was married there yesterday to Ronald Anderson Walter, a son of Norris Walter of Memphis and the late Estelle Anderson Walter. The Rev. Donald Mowery, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the Orpheum, a restored landmark theater.

title: BABBIT TV CAMPAIGN SEEKING TO END ANONYMITY
description: Bruce Babbitt, a Democratic Presidential hopeful, began his campaign in Iowa nearly a year ago with what he describes as ''a terrible anonymity.''

title: U.S. DROPS ITS CASE AGAINST A MARINE IN EMBASSY SPYING
description: Charges were dropped today against a second Marine guard accused of spying at the United States Embassy in Moscow. The move amounted to an acknowledgment that the Government could not prove that a crippling security breach occurred at the embassy.

title: Comings and Goings
description: John Niekro of Lilburn, Ga., whose father, Phil, and uncle Joe are both veteran major league pitchers, has been drafted by the Atlanta Braves, with whom Phil pitched 18 seasons and Joe part of two seasons. At Shiloh High School, Niekro was mainly an outfielder, but won his first six pitching decisions. . . . The trial on charges of fraud and tax evasion involving Dana Kirk, a former Memphis State basketball coach, which was originally scheduled to begin on June 22, will be delayed several months while Judge Odell Horton reviews transcripts of grand jury proceedings that led to Kirk's indictment. . . . Willie Banks, an 18-year-old Jersey City pitcher who was chosen third in the baseball draft by the Minnesota Twins, was named the high school boys player of the year by Scholastic Coach magazine. . . . Apryl McCray, the 5-year-old daughter of Rodney McCray, the forward for the Houston Rockets, died of a brain tumor on Thursday in Houston.

title: IN LAND OF CRICKET, THE GRAND SLAM RESOUNDS
description: Bloke here claims he can throw the knuckleball.

title: T>oo Little Housing
description: When the marble floors of railroad stations become beds . . . when 6-year-olds play games like snatch-the-purse in welfare hotel lobbies . . . when lack of housing for middle-income executives threatens business expansion . . . when old people cannot afford to heat the houses from which they cannot afford to move, America's urban housing problems send alarms that cannot be tuned out. Behind these problems lie three hard truths.

title: PTL Asks Court For Protection From Creditors
description: The PTL ministry, struggling to survive in the face of a mountain of debt, filed for court protection from its creditors today under Federal bankruptcy laws.

title: The Certain and Ominous Effects of Ozone Loss; Trouble in Antarctica
description: To the Editor:

title: 4 NONWHITES IN PARLIAMENT
description: The new Parliament that sits on June 25 will include the first nonwhites elected to the House of Commons since the 1920's, but it will be missing some veteran politicians from past Parliaments.

title: Puzzling Puzzler
description: WHO KILLED PALOMINO MOLERO? By Mario Vargas Llosa. 151 pages. Farrar, Straus, Giroux. $14.95.

title: A More Perfect Union Prescribed With Clarity
description: To the Editor:

title: The Certain and Ominous Effects of Ozone Loss
description: To the Editor:

title: FOSTER BABIES' HOSPITAL STAYS LIMITED
description: New York City must stop leaving babies in hospitals for months at a time while foster homes are sought for them, according to a court agreement announced yesterday.

title: Group in Study On Zondervan Bid
description: A Minneapolis-based investment group said that it was considering reviving an attempt at a takeover of the beleaguered Zondervan Corporation. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, a Minneapolis broker, Jeffrey P. Wendel, and an investment partnership, DVC-JPW Investors, said that they ''are seeking to enter into arrangements with other persons who may be interested in acquiring control'' of the Bible publisher. Zondervan, based in Grand Rapids, Mich., has been a takeover target since early last year.

title: Taiwanese Ordered to Trial In Writer's California Killing
description: An alleged gang member should stand trial in the 1984 slaying of a Chinese-American writer who was a critic of the Taiwanese government, a judge has ruled.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: SATURDAY, JUNE 13, 1987
description: International 2-5 Espionage charges against a marine were dropped. The Marine Corps said it had been unable to corroborate Cpl. Arnold Bracy's confession of spying at the United States Embassy in Moscow. Page 1 South Korean students fought police throughout the heart of Seoul, hurling bricks and gasoline bombs and chanting, ''Down with the military dictatorship.'' 1 News analysis: In Britain's elections held Thursday, a political message was delivered with unmistakable clarity. An unshakable bloc of voters supported Margaret Thatcher on pocketbook and defense issues. 1 Britain's interest in baseball has raised the spirits of Americans there. But they discovered a hard truth: there is no total conversion of the English to baseball. 1 Polish police and workers clashed briefly in Gdansk in an incident that marred Pope John Paul II's visit to the birthplace of the Solidarity labor movement. The clash occurred after a mass celebrated by the Pope. 1 News analysis: U.S. credibility in the Persian Gulf has been hurt by Adminsitration efforts to sell Maverick air-to-ground missiles to Saudi Arabia and then the abrupt decision Thursday to withdraw the proposal. 2 The President challenged Moscow to tear down the Berlin wall. In West Berlin, Mr. Reagan sought to undercut Europe's perception of Mikhail S. Gorbachev as a leader of peace. 3 In Italy, an American may be elected to Parliament. title: Strawberry Is Still Upset
description: An uneasy truce settled over the Mets today, but the bitter feelings continued between Manager Dave Johnson and Darryl Strawberry, who said: ''I don't know why Davey is always trying to bury me.''

title: Pretoria Frees 1,000; Strict Rules Extended
description: The Government said today that it had released 1,000 detainees held under the state of emergency.

title: Foreman's Next Step
description: After being retired for 10 years, George Foreman, the former heavyweight champion, returned to the ring March 8 in Sacramento, Calif., with a fourth-round knockout victory over Steve Zouski. Now Foreman, 39 years old, is taking the next step in his comeback. He has signed for a 10-round bout July 9 at the Oakland Coliseum Arena against Charlie Hostetter of Odessa, Tex., a former champion of his home state.

title: RAZE BERLIN WALL, REAGAN URGES SOVIET
description: President Reagan sought today to undercut Europe's perception of Mikhail S. Gorbachev as a leader of peace, bluntly challenging the Soviet leader to tear down the Berlin wall.

title: When Lease of New York Waterfront Property Amounts to Sale
description: To the Editor:

title: DOW RISES 17.60 TO CAP GOOD WEEK
description: The stock market moved ahead smartly yesterday, capping a week when its blue-chip indicator, the Dow Jones industrial average, never had a down session. Indeed, it has now moved higher in seven of the last eight trading days.

title: Three Years Later, Jackson Is Haunted by Anti-Semitism of Farrakhan
description: Although the Rev. Jesse Jackson severed political ties with Louis Farrakhan three years ago, the anti-Semitic views of the Black Muslim leader continue to haunt Mr. Jackson's Presidential campaign.

title: Yields on U.S. Bonds Decline
description: Yields on Treasury bonds fell to around 8 1/2 percent yesterday for the first time since late April, in response to a slight decline in the trade deficit and slower than expected inflation.

title: Workers and Police Clash Briefly As Pope Visits a Solidarity Center
description: Workers and security forces clashed briefly tonight in an incident that marred Pope John Paul II's visit to the birthplace of the Solidarity labor movement.

title: NEW ECONOMIC PLAN SET BY BRAZIL
description: President Jose Sarney ordered drastic measures today to give what he called a ''shock to the economy'' in order to ''pull Brazil from its crisis.''

title: BUCOLIC DUTCHESS COUNTY FIGHTS A 354-MILE-LONG ENEMY
description: Here among the wooded hills and green fields of Dutchess County some very angry people are mounting an assault against an enemy 354 miles long.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A picture caption on the Style page yesterday with an article about the costumes of the New York City Ballet misidentified a man inspecting an Edwardian jacket. He was Leslie Copeland.

title: Timing of U.S. Effort to Sell Missiles Said to Have Hurt Influence in Gulf
description: By seeking to sell Maverick air-to-ground missiles to Saudi Arabia and then abruptly withdrawing the proposal Thursday, the Reagan Administration appears to have erected a new hurdle in its efforts to restore American credibility in the Persian Gulf.

title: Babcock & Wilcox
description: A union local of the United Steelworkers said it was ready to begin a feasibility study for an employee buyout of three Babcock & Wilcox steel mills in Beaver County, Pa., if the company is willing to sell. Babcock & Wilcox is owned by McDermott International Inc. A union spokesman said that the company had announced in late May that it would make a decision on shutting the plants within 90 days.

title: Burlington Bid Rise Hinted by Edelman
description: Asher B. Edelman and Dominion Textile Inc. hinted yesterday in a letter written to Burlington Industries that they might raise their joint bid for the company from $77 a share.

title: 7 THEOLOGICAL AFFIRMATIONS
description: Following is an excerpt from a paper, ''A Theological Understanding of the Relationship Between Christians and Jews,'' being considered by the Presbyterian Church (U.S.A.):

title: Celtics' Luck Hasn't Run Out
description: During the warmup before Thursday night's game, several Boston Celtic players were distracted by the huge, glittering National Basketball Association championship trophy that was on a table in Boston Garden. The trophy was ready for presentation to the Los Angeles Lakers if they won the game, because their three-games-to-one advantage had put them on the brink of winning the N.B.A. finals.

title:
Patents;
Holder of Many Patents Is Recipient of 2 More
description: LEAD: Jerome H. Lemelson of Princeton, N.J., who has many patents and operates a licensing management corporation in New York, got two more patents this week. No. 4,671,111 covers a performance monitor system for such vehicles as cars, aircraft or boats, with electronic computer analysis of the acceleration and deceleration of the vehicle.

title: MILTON F. TINGLING
description: Milton F. Tingling, a New York City Civil Court judge, died of respiratory failure Tuesday in St. Clare's Hospital and Health Center. He lived in Manhattan and was 66 years old.

title: No Way to Attract Businesses to New York
description: The Koch administration has responded to the rash of corporate departures by announcing new tax incentive programs to attract and retain business. The administration may give the impression that it is ''doing something,'' but its program, awaiting approval by the City Council and State Legislature, seems hastily drawn and suffers from basic flaws.

title: Rep. Schroeder Visits Iowa
description: Representative Patricia Schroeder of Colorado met with top Democrats in her former home state today, testing the waters for a potential run for the party's Presidential nomination. She said her one-day swing in Iowa, where the Democrats' first caucuses will be held next Feb. 6, would be followed by a trip to New Hampshire.

title: Chrysler Unit Seeks Stadium
description: The Chrysler Capital Corporation said today that it was negotiating to buy the Three Rivers Stadium in Pittsburgh and then lease it back to the city.

title: OBSERVER
description: When I arrived in New York indictment had been widespread for months. All over town lawyers were standing outside courthouses and jails telling television crews that though their clients may have taken the money they had done nothing illegal.

title: Murderer of a Couple Executed in Louisiana
description: A swaggering inmate who said he would ''rather be fishing'' was executed in the electric chair early today for the shooting deaths of a bound and gagged couple in 1982.

title: EXCERPTS FROM REAGAN'S TALK AT THE BERLIN WALL
description: Following are excerpts from President Reagan's speech today at the Berlin wall, as recorded by The Associated Press:

title: KEY RATES
Why Libels Suits Are 'Sand in the Gears'
description: The settlement of a suit by former Senator Paul Laxalt against the McClatchy newspaper chain leaves in its wake serious questions about the good sense and propriety of libel suits by Presidential candidates and high public officials. In Mr. Laxalt's case, both sides proclaimed victory after an ambiguous settlement.

title: Raya Dunayevskaya Is Dead; Author Was Aide to Trotsky
description: Raya Dunayevskaya, an author who was secretary to Leon Trotsky, died Tuesday in Sheridan Road Hospital, Chicago. A resident of Evanston, Ill., she was 77 years old.

title: THE RIDICULOUS THEATER, AFTER LUDLAM
description: The flowers covering the front of the Sheridan Square Playhouse, bleached from two weeks of late spring sun, have begun to wither; the notes from the bereaved - some hastily scrawled on cards, others printed out by computer on yellow telegram paper - are fading; the impromptu crowds of mourners have slowly dwindled to a trickle of passersby, curious about this funny-sad street shrine.

title: Reform Redux in Russia
description: The world watches Mikhail Gorbachev's reforms with hope and wonder. President Reagan challenges him to go further with glasnost and tear down the Berlin Wall. East German youths trying to hear a rock concert in West Berlin chant his name. How fast and radically can the Soviet system be changed without bringing on reaction?

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A Washington dispatch yesterday about testimony critical of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission before a House Interior subcommittee misidentified a subcommittee member who questioned the commission's believability. He was Representative George Miller, Democrat of California.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 10.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in some editions of Sports Pages yesterday incompletely described the new position for Harry Edwards at the baseball commisioner's office. He will act as a part-time consultant to the commissioner and will not have a formal title with major league baseball. Further developments are reported today on page 45.

title: 173 Illegal Aliens Arrested
description: Immigration officials stopped a tractor-trailer Thursday and arrested its passengers, 173 illegal aliens who were to pay up to $300 for the trip across the border. ''Some already had jobs lined up,'' said Harold Ezell, Western regional commissioner of the Immigration and Naturalization Service. The driver, identified as Eduardo Cardenas-Ventura, faced alien-smuggling charges. He is also an illegal alien.

title: Homage to Catalonia and Madrid, Too
description: The historical antagonism between this city by the sea and its longtime rival, Madrid, is on the decline. In recent years, the two have found less that divides them and more that binds them, and reasons to pull together rather than continue to fight.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, JUNE 13, 1987
description: The Economy

title: Kodak Sets Deal
description: The Eastman Kodak Company said it had agreed to acquire International Biotechnologies Inc., a maker of systems for molecular biology research, for about $15.2 million. Kodak said it would pay $6.30 a share for all outstanding shares of International, which is based in New Haven. The deal must be approved by International shareholders, the companies said.

title: Hearing on Radium Delayed
description: A three-judge Appellate Court panel today delayed a court hearing scheduled for Monday in Toms River on the suitability of a site in Ocean County as a temporary repository for 15,000 barrels of radium-contaminated soil. The panel made its ruling pending a decision, expected next week, on a request by the State Department of Environmental Protection that the case be heard directly by the Appellate Division rather than by lower courts.

title: CARTER INDICATES HE'D FAVOR NUNN IF GEORGIAN RAN IN '88
description: Former President Jimmy Carter said today that ''it would be hard'' not to endorse Senator Sam Nunn for the Democratic Presidential nomination if Mr. Nunn, a fellow Georgian, decided to enter the race.

title: CHURCH IN DALLAS WILL REPLACE PASTOR AFTER SUICIDE ATTEMPT
description: Leaders of the First United Methodist Church here said today that they would seek a replacement for the senior pastor who tried to commit suicide last month, eight days after his wife was nearly choked to death by an unidentified assailant.

title: BOKASSA DOOMED BY BANGUI COURT
description: Jean-Bedel Bokassa, who once proclaimed himself Emperor Bokassa I, was convicted and sentenced to death today for at least 20 murders of real or imagined opponents in his 14-year reign.

title: JAZZ: 'DIZZY GOES BROADWAY'
description: Dizzy Gillespie's current engagement at Michael's Pub, his first appearance at the club at 211 East 55th Street, is titled ''Dizzy Goes Broadway.'' But not to worry. As he approaches his 70th birthday in October, the celebrated jazz trumpeter still goes no way except his own.

title: CONTINENTAL AIRLINES TO PAY FINE FOR VIOLATIONS OF CONSUMER RULES
description: The Transportation Department today announced a civil penalty of $250,000 against Continental Airlines for various consumer protection violations.

title: N.F.L. Strike Talk
description: Gene Upshaw, the National Football League Players Association's executive director, said yesterday that 92 percent of the members have approved a possible players strike as early as Sept. 1.

title: Hilton Ruiz
description: Hilton Ruiz, a pianist, will lead his Latin-jazz quintet - featuring Lew Soloff on trumpet and Daniel Ponce on congas - tonight and tomorrow at the Village Vanguard, 178 Seventh Avenue South, below 11th Street (255-4037). Sets begin at 10 and 11:30 P.M. and 1 A.M.; there is a $12 cover and a $6 minimum.

title: NATO BACKS A BAN ON SOME MISSILES
description: Western foreign ministers formally endorsed today a proposal to ban American and Soviet short-range missiles, a move that helps pave the way for a possible arms treaty.

title: 3 PANAMA PAPERS WON'T PUBLISH WITH CENSORSHIP
description: Three of Panama's six morning newspapers failed to appear today after editors refused to submit articles for censorship.

title:
Patents;
Nuclear Survival Structures
description: LEAD: SURVIVAL structures and campsites to provide safety for city populations in case of a nuclear war were patented this week by a California inventor. The buildings are designed to resist blasts, to provide equipment for clearing dust containing radioactive fallout and to offer means for keeping the sheltered people physically and mentally healthy.

title: PHILHARMONIC: REGIONAL CONDUCTORS
description: The New York Philharmonic has presented three concerts this week at Avery Fisher Hall intended primarily for the visiting delegates of the American Symphony Orchestra League's annual convocation. On Tuesday, Zubin Mehta broke his year-long sabbatical to lead a snippet by Elliott Carter and Bruckner's massive Eighth Symphony. On Wednesday, there was a ''reading'' of new scores by four regional conductors. And Thursday, those same four conductors returned for a four-item program (one piece per conductor) that had been properly rehearsed.

title: CABLE SERVICE DUSTS OFF 'UNCLE TOM'S CABIN' FOR TV
description: ''You hear about a lot of projects that have made the rounds for years before they finally get filmed,'' said the executive vice president in charge of programming for Showtime/The Movie Channel Inc., Fred Schneier. ''But this may be the ultimate example of a project that has been around town for years. It may have broken the industry record.''

title: SAFETY PANEL WIDENS INQUIRY AT LARGEST U.S. MEATPACKER
description: The Occupational Safety and Health Administration is expanding its investigation into allegations of unreported job injuries among workers at the nation's largest meatpacking company, according to Labor Department officials.

title: JUDGE IS DEPICTED AS WILLING TO JOIN CABLE TV PLOT
description: The prosecution in the trial of Justice Francis X. Smith of Queens described him yesterday as a willing participant in a scheme to bribe a cable television operator seeking a franchise in the borough.

title: Churchill Downs Likely for '88 Cup
description: A selection committee has made Churchill Downs - the home of the Kentucky Derby - its unanimous choice as the site for the fifth annual Breeders' Cup Day next year.

title: THE BOEING 737 IS NOW NO. 1
description: At the Paris Air Show today, Boeing announced new orders that made its 737 aircraft the best-selling plane in aviation history.

title: BUILDER WANTS GREEN IN GREAT WHITE WAY
description: David S. Solomon, a 35-year-old developer who resembles Groucho Marx (he is taller and does not wear glasses), hates the lights of Broadway. He wants to replace them with trees.

title: ITALY'S COMMUNIST PARTY RUNS AMERICAN CANDIDATE
description: In the soft Roman night, Carole Beebe Tarantelli sat on a metal chair under an abundantly leafy plane tree in the Piazza San Cosimato explaining to about 60 citizens why they should vote for the Italian Communist Party on Sunday.

title: REPORTS PROMPT INVESTIGTION OF '83 MYERSON TRANSACTIONS
description: Investigators looking into mysterious reports that Bess Myerson sent large amounts of cash to a Third Avenue address have subpoenaed financial records from at least three companies in the building.

title: MARK OLF
description: Mark Olf, a composer and singer of Yiddish and Hebrew songs, died of leukemia Sunday at Booth Memorial Hospital in Queens. He was 82 years old and lived in Queens.

title: BOSWORTH BALKS AT CHOICE BY SEAHAWKS
description: The Seattle Seahawks defied 37-1 odds yesterday by gaining the right to pick Brian Bosworth, the University of Oklahoma all-America linebacker, first in the National Football League's supplemental draft. Then they defied Bosworth's ''Dear John'' letter by taking him.

title: Rise in Producer Prices Eases
description: Easing fears of a resurgence in inflation, the Government reported today that prices at the producer level rose a modest three-tenths of 1 percent in May, or an annual rate of 3.7 percent.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: Home Grown

title:
Patents;
Controlled Regeneration Of Tissue From Plants
description: LEAD: Controlled regeneration of whole plants from plant tissue was patented this week after research at Pennsylvania State University's pesticide research laboratory. Patent 4,672,035 was granted to Gayle H. Davidonis, a research assistant, and Professors Ralph O. Mumma and Robert H. Hamilton.

title:
Patents;
Spelling Verification For Compound Words
description: LEAD: An efficient method of verifying the spelling of compound words for computer use has been invented for the International Business Machines Corporation by staff members in Austin, Tex. Vance B. Bass and six co-inventors were awarded patent 4,672,571 this week. The process is being used in Displaywrite programs, which are run on personal computers.

title: PENZOIL IS WEIGHING SPINOFF OF SUBSIDIARY
description: The Pennzoil Company said it was considering spinning off one or more subsidiaries if its protracted $10.3 billion legal dispute with Texaco Inc. was not resolved in the coming months.

title: GORBACHEV BACKING ONLY SOME CHANGE
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev has called for a methodical loosening of central controls over the Soviet economy, but he stopped short of endorsing more far-reaching measures urged by some economists and party officials, according to party documents published today.

title: Cedar Walton
description: Cedar Walton on piano, Ron Carter on bass and Billy Higgins on drums will play trios tonight and tomorrow at Sweet Basil, 88 Seventh Avenue South, above Bleecker Street (242-1785). Sets are at 10 and 11:45 P.M. and 1:30 A.M; there is a $12 cover and a $6 minimum.

title: The Terrorist and Mr. Kohl
description: Good for West Germany's Chancellor, Helmut Kohl, for not yielding on a case of concern to all Western democracies. The case involves murder charges against Mohammed Ali Hamadei, a Lebanese accused of killing a U.S. Navy diver in the 1985 hijacking of a T.W.A. airliner. The unanswered question is whether West Germany will extradite Mr. Hamadei to the United States, where he is under indictment, or try him in German courts. The case has been clouded by rumors that Bonn was willing to try the captive on lesser charges and swap him for two Germans since taken hostage in Beirut. President Reagan brought up the case with Chancellor Kohl at the Venice economic conference. He reported Mr. Kohl's assurance that the suspect would go on trial for murder, though no decision has been taken on extradition.

title: ROCK: ROYAL CRESCENT MOB
description: For stomping, chattering, guitar-driven funk, it's hard to beat the Royal Crescent Mob, the four-man band from Columbus, Ohio, that played CBGB on Wednesday. The band is steeped in James Brown and the Ohio Players, with a dash of George Clinton's P-Funk; now and then, it moves toward heavy-metal. And while the band kicks along, David Ellison sings, grunts, plays harmonica or flaps his arms like a blond scarecrow.

title: Muriel V. Hutton Is Married
description: The marriage of Muriel Vanderbilt Hutton, a daughter of Mrs. Edwin Marston Burke of New York and Palm Beach, Fla., and William Langdon Hutton of East Hampton, L.I., to Michel Louis Francois de Chabert-Ostland took place yesterday in New York. Msgr. George F. Bardes performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More. The bridegroom is a son of Dr. and Mrs. Jean G. de Chabert-Ostland of West Hartford, Conn.

title: TUVIA BIELSKY, WHO FOUGHT NAZIS IN BYELORUSSIA, IS DEAD
description: Tuvia Bielsky, the leader of an armed band of Jewish partisans in Nazi-occupied Byelorussia that was known as Bielsky's Brigade, died yesterday in Brookdale Hospital in Brooklyn. A resident of Brooklyn, where he used the surname Bell, he was 81 years old.

title: TRADE GAP SHRANK A BIT IN APRIL
description: The nation's trade deficit narrowed modestly, to $13.3 billion, in April, the second consecutive monthly improvement, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: STADIUM PARACHUTIST RELEASED FROM JAIL AFTER F.A.A. RELENTS
description: Michael Sergio, the parachutist who landed afoul of the law when he jumped into Shea Stadium during the sixth game of the World Series last fall, was released yesterday from the Metropolitan Correctional Center in Manhattan, three weeks after he began a six-month term for civil contempt of court.

title: ALVARADO HIRED BY LOCAL BOARD TO HEAD DISTRICT
description: Anthony J. Alvarado, who resigned as New York City's Schools Chancellor three years ago just days before he was to face misconduct charges, was hired yesterday as superintendent of School District 2 in Manhattan.

title: Japan Suspension
description: Warren Cromartie, a former outfielder with the Montreal Expos, was suspended for five days and fined $2,143 by the Yomiuri Giants of Japan's Central League for punching an opposing pitcher in a game Thursday. Cromartie, after being hit by a pitch, punched Masami Miyashita of the Chunichi Dragons, who is expected to miss about 10 days while recovering from a cut in his mouth.

title: GOETZ JURY HEARS CHARGE BY JUDGE AND DELIBERATES
description: After two and a half years of public passion, the case of Bernhard H. Goetz went to the jury yesterday.

title: Thatcher Victory Shows a Changed Britain, As Voters Support Own Economic Interest
description: The unevenness of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's campaign clouded a political message that was delivered with unmistakable clarity by Britain's voters once the ballots were tallied this morning. Come thick or thin, an unshakable bloc of voters support Mrs. Thatcher on pocketbook and military issues.

title: Michael Michalovic, 67, Dies; Performer in Yiddish Theater
description: Michael Michalovic, a performer in Yiddish theater and a prominent figure in organizations active in its propagation, died of heart failure after a long illness Tuesday in St. Vincent's Hospital. He was 67 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: CITY BALLET: A LONGER 'ECSTATIC ORANGE'
description: Second thoughts are best. Who would have thought that ''Ecstatic Orange,'' Peter Martins's unimpressive little ballet of last January, would grow into the longer and stunning premiere of the same title that the New York City Ballet presented on Thursday night?

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A brief article in Weekend yesterday about a concert tomorrow by the Laurentian String Quartet at Sarah Lawrence College gave an incorrect time supplied in the college's announcement. The concert is at 4 P.M.

title: Bridge; Telling the Same Story Twice Made for a Difficult Contract
description: Telling the same story twice may be profitable for a panhandler or a stand-up comedian but it is a great mistake for a bridge player. North made this error on the diagramed deal played recently in California.

title: SNOW CHIEF SUFFERS LEG INJURY
description: Snow Chief, the fourth-leading money-winner in thoroughbred racing history, has an injured tendon in his left front leg that will probably cause him to be retired to stud, his trainer, Mel Stute, said today.

title: CLASHES CONTINUE IN CENTER OF SEOUL
description: Several thousand anti-Government student radicals fought with the police in the heart of the capital Friday and early today, hurling bricks and gasoline bombs and chanting, ''Down with the military dictatorship!''

title: Sheila Hultkrans Wed To William Feick Jr.
description: At St. James's Episcopal Church in New York yesterday, Sheila Driggs Hultkrans and William Feick Jr. were married by Bishop Robert C. Witcher of the Episcopal Diocese of Long Island, who was assisted by the Rev. Susan C. Harris.

title: PRESBYTERIANS BALK AT PROPOSAL ON JEWS
description: A landmark document on Christian-Jewish relations ran into sharp, unexpected opposition today at the annual meeting of the nation's largest Presbyterian denomination and appeared headed for defeat.

title: Boston Bank Loses Appeal
description: A Federal appeals court has upheld the March 1986 conviction and $1.2 million fine imposed against the Bank of New England for violating a Federal law requiring banks to report large cash transactions to the Internal Revenue Service.

title: The Heart of Lake Wobegon
description: Like the Grover's Corners of Thornton Wilder's ''Our Town,'' Lake Wobegon, Minn., is situated on a stretch of the imagination, at the crossroads of what we are and what we wanted to be. Millions acquired the habit of tuning in to that mythical place Garrison Keillor created wherever public radio might be received.

title: Madrid
description: To the Editor: ''Madrid's Other Museums'' gave welcome information on Madrid's art treasures beyond the Prado. However, your readers should also know about the Cerralbo Museum, which is a fine 19th-century house that gives an excellent idea of the way a wealthy Spanish family lived and the art they collected. Its ground-floor chapel has a painting of St. Francis of Assisi by El Greco, and its long gallery has paintings by Titian, Tintoretto and the late Baroque Spanish painter Francisco Herrera. Upstairs is a collection of armor, a dining room filled with still lifes and a billiard room that is now a portrait gallery of Dutch, Flemish, French, Italian and Spanish works, including Louis XIV by Rigaud. DAVID LAWRENCE MORTON White Plains The writer is author of ''Traveler's Guide to the Great Art Treasures of Europe'' to be published in October.

title: WINFIELD INJURY CLOUDS VICTORY
description: Dave Winfield stepped into the batting cage last night, took a half-swing at the first pitch and felt a sudden twinge. Moments later, he was lying face down in the trainer's room as heat packs were applied to the left side of his neck.

title: JOHANN HUMMEL GETS A NEW DAY IN THE SUN
description: IT IS PERIODICALLY INTERESTING to step behind the mighty threesome of Mozart, Haydn and Beethoven and see what other music is lurking in the shadows of their time. Johann Nepomuk Hummel (1778-1837) was one of the greatest pianists of his age; as a child prodigy he studied the instrument under none other than Mozart. He befriended Beethoven when both were studying composition with Albrechtsberger and, later, with Salieri, and eventually composed well over 100 works: operas, ballets, masses, concertos and an immense number of piano pieces, including six sonatas, all of which received favorable attention during his lifetime.

title: Carnegie Hill
description: To the Editor:

title: Smaller - and Smarter - Hearing Aids
description: FIVE years ago most hearing aids were bulky collections of conspicuous wires bunched behind the ear. But the industry is benefiting from long years of research, and hearing aids have been getting a lot smaller and far less obvious.

title: MUSIC: BOSTON FESTIVAL OFFERS HAYDN 'SEASONS'
description: BOSTON, June 13 - The Boston Early Music Festival and Exhibition, which takes place every two years about this time, has established itself as this country's principal forum for the early-music movement. Each festival has a climactic, large-scale event, and this year it was Haydn's 1803 revision of his oratorio ''The Seasons,'' conducted by Roger Norrington, the new darling of the movement worldwide. The first of the two scheduled performances in Jordan Hall took place Friday night, with the second scheduled for tonight.

title: 2 Months Without Pay Sparks Yugoslav Strike
description: About 1,000 construction workers have gone on strike in Skoplje, in the southern republic of Macedonia, to protest a lack of wages for two months, the Belgrade daily Politika said today.

title: Recent Sales
description: Eastchester, N.Y. $232,000 89 Joyce Road 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 38-year-old Cape Cod; in-law apartment; taxes $2,896. North Salem, N.Y. $208,500 21 Alice Road 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 22-year-old shingle/ stone ranch; family room, office-workshop, 0.7 acre; taxes $2,725. Shrub Oak, N.Y. $65,000 1228 Main Street 4-bedroom, 3-bath, 138-year-old clapboard; no plumbing, no power, 1,000 square feet, barn, .343 acre; taxes $1,545. Stratford, Conn. $450,000 Beaver Forest 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, new colonial; whirlpool, screened porch, 5 acres; taxes $4,000. Trumbull, Conn. $395,000 15 Tudor Lane 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 6-year-old colonial; private setting on pond, large deck, 1.7 acres; taxes $3,935. Weston, Conn. $875,000 1 Nimrod Farm 5-bedroom, 3 1/2-baths, new colonial; fine moldings, 5 fireplaces, 2 acres; taxes not yet available. OTHER AREAS Livingston, N.J. $160,000 41 Elmwood Drive 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 43-year-old Cape Cod; enclosed porch, corner lot, 1-car garage; taxes $2,289. Rockaway, N.J. $135,000 11 Lindbergh Trail 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 40-year-old ranch; central A/ C, fireplace, patio, 1-car garage; taxes $2,062. Setauket, L.I. $317,000 5 Setalcott Place North 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 6-year-old contemporary; 2 fireplaces, skylights; taxes $5,000.

title: TRANSIT BRIEFS
description: LEAD: THE IDEA of a new Route 92 connecting the Princeton area with the New Jersey Turnpike near Hightstown has been around for years, and the explosive growth along the Route 1 corridor between Trenton and New Brunswick has generated new interest in the four-lane, limited-access proposal.

title: COLLEGE PRESIDENTS' HOW DO THEY STAND?
description: In Dallas on June 29, four college presidents will open a special National Collegiate Athletic Association convention with speeches on the future of college athletics. They will be starting what the N.C.A.A. Presidents' Commission calls a ''national dialogue'' that's meant to produce major change over the next 18 months.

title: Post Retirement
description: To the Editor:

title: CORRECTION
description: An article last Sunday about the resignation of the White House's executive chef, Henry Haller, misidentified his wife. She is Carole Itjen.

title: CHARADE AT MALACANANG PALACE
description: THE FOUR DAYS OF COURAGE The Untold Story of the People Who Brought Marcos Down. By Bryan Johnson. Illustrated. 290 pp. New York: The Free Press. $19.95.

title: KEAN AND LEGISLATURE IN THEIR ANNUAL BUDGET-SURPLUS BATTLE
description: Although the New Jersey Legislature considers thousands of bills each year, and passes hundreds, there is only one bill it is required to act on - the state budget.

title: SOVIET STUDIES SATELLITES TO CONVERT SOLAR ENERGY FOR RELAY TO EARTH
description: The Soviet Union is drawing up plans to build huge satellites in orbit that would convert sunlight into electricity for cities and industry on Earth, senior Soviet scientists and American experts say.

title: CHAUCER'S PACKAGED PILGRIMAGE
description: Every age has its heresy and our own might be the questioning of the holiday cult and all that it involves.

title: THE OTHER WOMAN IS A SLEEK SAILBOAT
description: THERE is another woman in my husband's life now. She's only 21 - and before you (ahem) start calculating my age - that's feet, not years. I haven't compiled the statistics yet, but my intuition tells me that most marriages break up not over mundane things like sex and money, but over boats.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: 'BOHEME' IN SNUG HARBOR The Metropolitan Opera Company will present a free performance of Puccini's ''La Boheme'' Saturday evening on the South Meadow at Snug Harbor, S.I. Elizabeth Knighton will sing Mimi and Vinson Cole, Rodolfo.

title: THE BLOODIEST BATTLE OF ALL
description: ON OKINAWA TODAY, Flag Day will be observed with an extraordinary ceremony: two groups of elderly men, one Japanese, the other American, will gather for a solemn rite. They could scarcely have less in common.

title: POSTINGS: Turning a New Page; Library Condo
description: Avid readers in Jersey City's Hamilton Park neighborhood have visited the Pavonia branch of the Jersey City Free Public Library for nearly two decades at its humble quarters, comprised of four attached trailer homes, at 206-210 Pavonia Avenue. Now, however, the same hot real-estate market that is forcing the branch to leave its current site -so that new brick town houses can rise there - has also prompted a most unusual solution to the library's search for a new home.

title: Ann H. Lumbard Marries a Banker
description: Ann Howland Lumbard, a daughter of Eliot Howland Lumbard and Jean Ashmore Lumbard, both of New York, was married yesterday to Robert Carter Alexander Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Alexander of Smyrna Beach, Fla. The Rev. Judy Baumer performed the ceremony at St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church in New York.

title: A COURSE IN COOKING FOR THE MELTING POT
description: LEAD: FOREIGN residents of Westchester will have an opportunity to learn English and at the same time develop some practical daily survival skills in a new course, ''American Cooking With the Accent on English.'' The eight-session course at Marymount College in Tarrytown will be held Tuesday and Thursday mornings starting June 23.

title: LESSONS LEARNED AT THE KNEE OF A GOLDFISH
description: IT is not as if my daughter Jessica, who is 5 1/2 years old, has nothing to do with her free time.

title: Venice Meeting Ends With Modest Results
description: The Venice summit meeting ended with the leading non-Communist industrial nations providing a somber assessment of the world economy and a series of generalized proposals to deal with persistent problems. While participants from all seven nations said they were satisfied with the results, no breakthroughs were claimed, and the United States settled for less than it had sought. Of President Reagan, one European senior official was quoted as saying, ''He was a pussycat here.'' The President yielded, for instance, on the matter of getting a binding commitment that the nations would eliminate agricultural subsidies by the year 2000.

title: Fair or Scare?
description: To the Editor:

title: Hanoi Vows a Cambodia Exit Despite Effect on Guerrillas
description: Vietnam will honor a promise to pull its 140,000 troops out of Cambodia by 1990 even though that is likely to lead to a stepped-up guerrilla war against the Phnom Penh Government, officials here say.

title: POSTINGS: Factory Into Offices; Norwalk Comeback
description: Once a decaying industrial town by the water, South Norwalk, Conn., has staged a major comeback in this decade, turning old factories into smart residences and boutiques and luring young professionals. Now, businesses are the latest newcomers.

title: AGRICULTURE AIDES HELPING TO SET UP BEE BARRIER
description: LEAD: THE Mexican state of Chiapas, just north of Guatemala, is a long way from New Jersey, but Federal and state agriculture officials agree that it holds the key to whether ''killer bees'' will infest the Northeast - and the rest of the country - in this decade.

title: CHILDREN WITHOUT PARENTS
description: LEAD: COMFORT 204 pp. New York: Viking. $16.95.

title: Widening the Electronic Net
description: For 20 years the Federal Bureau of Investigation has kept a computer file - a kind of electronic bulletin board for police agencies - on people with criminal records or outstanding arrest warrants. Now a Federal advisory committee has tentatively recommended that the system be expanded.

title: Headliners; Coming Home
description: Years after the United States ceased to prosecute a war in Vietnam, it continues to ponder the prosecution of errant warriors of that era. Last week, there arose the question of what to do about Douglas Beane, who deserted the Marine Corps 17 years ago while serving in Vietnam. Mr. Beane, who was at the time facing charges of dealing in the black market and threatening to kill another marine, took off for Australia, where he married, had two sons and worked as a cook. He was arrested by military policemen after he flew from Sydney to Los Angeles with the intention, he said, of visiting his ailing father in Vermont. A Marine Corps spokesman said the disposition of charges against Mr. Beane could range from a discharge to a court-martial. If officials decide to discharge him, the spokesman said, Mr. Beane could be free in three or four weeks.

title: What We Must Know About Our Leaders
description: To the Editor:

title: LITTLE BITS OF HEAVEN
description: OTHERWORLD JOURNEYS Accounts of Near-Death Experience in Medieval and Modern Times. By Carol Zaleski. 275 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $18.95. I USED to think, somewhat innocently, that seeing is believing. That was before someone showed me a certified photograph of a leprechaun, looking very much like the little Irish elf of my imagination. Now I have become sophisticated. I have learned, through much schooling, that seeing is believing only if I am already prepared to believe; and that there is a lot more to our conceptions of ultimate reality, and a lot less to the visionary experience of it, than meets the eye.

title: FOR DAVID ROBINSON: ACTIVE DUTY OR N.B.A.?
description: David Robinson should fulfill his active duty obligations without any stipulation. As an officer in the Navy, Ensign Robinson must draw the line between service to the nation and personal gain through professional sports. SETH M. BECKHARDT New York

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: LEAD: ON NATURE: Nature, Landscape, and Natural History. Edited by Daniel Halpern. (North Point, Cloth, $22.50; Paper, $9.95.) Last year Daniel Halpern asked six distinguished nature writers to help edit a special issue of the magazine Antaeus. The result confirms that today's most exciting work is not being done in fiction but in essays, memoirs and travel writings.

title: NEW CAUSE FOR LINCOLN BRIGADE VETERAN
description: LAST year, William S. Susman of Great Neck was in demand as a speaker. His 30 or 40 appearances took him to Yale, Harvard, Dartmouth and Cornell, among other institutions, and the 71-year-old Mr. Susman figures he'll be speaking again at seminars and symposiums when autumn rolls around.

title: FOR DAVID ROBINSON: ACTIVE DUTY OR N.B.A.?
description: Ensign Robinson is a credit to his parents, heritage, academy and country. Likewise, the 3,000-plus service academy graduates who incur active duty obligations every year. The oath administered on day one means that if an academy program is successfully completed, active duty is a commitment.

title: PARKLAND PLANNING
description: A recent study shows that the state does not have enough parkland to accommodate present and future visitors. In a report earlier this month, the 21-member Governor's Council on New Jersey Outdoors urged state officials to act quickly to buy some 400,000 acres for recreational use before such land - most of it farmland - fell into developers' hands. It also recommended that some $800 million be raised through bonds to pay for the purchases.

ART;
EARLY MASTERS OF THE LONG VIEW AND CLOSE-UP

But the old photographs on view at the Metropolitan Museum of Art through Aug. 16 are meant to be more than nostalgic. The exhibition is entitled ''Masterpieces of 19th-Century French Photography by Gustave Le Gray and Henri Le

title: RENTAL CARS
description: To the Editor: Be alert for the unexpected when renting a car abroad (Travel Advisory, April 5). We arranged our rental with our American travel agent for a diesel-fueled car. The contract we signed here was for a diesel. The contract we signed in Luxembourg was for a diesel. The clerk who handed us the keys said it was a diesel. And the driver who presented us the car reminded us, one last time, to remember to use diesel fuel. The car was not a diesel. A Paris gas station attendant questioned our claim that the car was a diesel but nonetheless managed to fill it with diesel fuel. Not only were we unable to leave his underground station near the Pantheon, but we also nearly asphixiated workers and customers alike in our attempt.

title:
INVESTING;
Big Payout From Home Builders?
description: LEAD: With interest rates up and housing construction down, the stocks of some home builders have sagged to near their 52-week lows. The slump has created yields of almost 13 percent on the units of two builders' master limited partnerships - Emerald Homes and Standard-Pacific, both operating in growth markets on the West Coast.

title: THE 17-YEAR CICADA RETURNS NOISILY TO L.I.
description: LEAD: UPON completion of its 17-year life cycle, the mysterious brood 10 cicada is returning to Long Island backyards this summer for what local officials predict will be an uncommonly noisy summer.

title: BLOWING UP PROJECTS DOESN'T SOLVE PROBLEMS OF HOUSING
description: THE Edward W. Scudder Homes in the Central Ward of Newark were completed in 1963 during the Kennedy Administration's ''New Frontier,'' when abolishing poverty seemed both desirable and attainable.

title: Lawsuit Dropped
description: THE St. Louis Blues have dropped the litigation over Jacques Demers, the National Hockey League coach who left the Blues for the Detroit Red Wings last season. The Blues filed suit against Detroit in August 1986, claiming that St. Louis should be compensated. The Blues later filed an amended suit, asking that Demers be prohibited from coaching for three years, the length of a verbal deal Demers reportedly had agreed to with Harry Ornest, the former Blues owner.

title: A Labor Fight Looms Over The COLA Concession
description: IN the last 15 months, cost-of-living clauses have been disappearing en masse from union contracts, negotiated away in exchange for the job security provisions that were the unions' central concern.

title: JOLLY AMBIANCE IN NORWALK
description: ''FINE Italian hand'' may have a negative connotation, politically speaking, implying Machiavellian intrigue, but when it comes to cooking, that's the kind of hand required - fine, as in dextrous, keen, sharp, precise, skillful. In Italian cooking, that mother of all European culinary finesse, it is essential.

title: IN THE BOGS OF WESTERN IRELAND
description: My friends were incredulous.

Page 7. POPE'S TALKS UPSET WARSAW Senoir Polish officials told Pope John Paul II's entourage that they were distressed by pro-Solidarity speeches he has made in his visit to Poland. JOYOUS WELCOME FOR BRACY Cpl. Arnold Bracy was welcomed home by his neighbors in Woodside, Queens, after espionage charges against him were dropped. Page 44.

title: Q and A
description: The Alien Homeowner Question: I am a foreigner working in New York who expects to be in the country for about two or three years and I am considering buying a home. Before I buy I would like to know if, as a foreigner, I would be subject to capital gains tax on the profit when I sell the home? If so, would it make a difference if I sold the residence while still living in the United States or if I sold the property after leaving the country? Are there any other factors which I should take into account in the decision to purchase a house in this country? G. R., Manhattan Answer: You would be required to pay tax on any capital gains you realize. According to Robert Kobel, a spokesman for the Internal Revenue Service's New York division, for tax purposes you would be classified as a resident alien. As such would be subject to the same tax rules and regulations and be entitled to the same tax credits that applied to any other United State resident.

title: BEST FRIEND: LOVE AND LOSS FOREVER
description: A RECENT excursion to Shea Stadium with the family brought an unexpected reaction. As I sat in the stands rooting for the home team, I was overwhelmed by a feeling of melancholy. Analyzing it afterward, I realized it was brought on by the release of a flood of memories about a person whose departure left a tremendous void in my life - my best friend, Kathy.

title: FOR DAVID ROBINSON: ACTIVE DUTY OR N.B.A.?
description: Why not the best of both worlds? Let him play in the N.B.A. and also let him do military recruitment and public relations in the cities to which he travels. He could address high school assembly programs, Y's, Boys Clubs, go on local talk TV and radio shows extolling the virtues of the military, of the clean (drug-free) life, of hard work, of study, of stick-to-it-tiveness. He can be an example of the military letting you be all you can be. JOAN MARY MACEY Binghamton, N.Y.

description: The Pentagon said today that a 25-year-old American soldier was found shot to death Thursday in downtown Panamam, but that the killing was unrelated to civil disturbances there.

title: FOOD
description: CHARLES PALMER HAS HUNTED AND FISHED all his life, playing hooky on more than one occasion just to catch bullfrogs. ''My mother used to go crazy over frogs' legs,'' he says. ''She still does.''

description: LEAD: THE state's Agent Orange Commission is acting on a proposal calling for the establishment of a dioxin testing center for Vietnam veterans.

title: FROM THE ASHES, BRONX FACES UNCERTAIN FUTURE
description: The Bronx, where years of arson and abandonment in the 1970's created a national symbol of urban decay and despair, is showing the first, flickering signs of recovery. It is a difficult and unsure convalescence, however, and one that is far more apparent to portions of its business community than to its still desperate poor.
