title: AT BRAWL SITE, TALES OF RECENT RISE IN RACIAL TENSION
description: City officials yesterday ordered strengthened security at a Brooklyn high school hit by an outbreak of racial violence as students and residents of the area told of rising tensions between blacks and whites marked by slurs, fights and the kind of territoriality associated with gangs.

title: FOR DAVID ROBINSON: ACTIVE DUTY OR N.B.A.?
description: Now let's see . . . On one hand, David Robinson could put up bombs, and on the other hand he could launch them. He could overthrow a pass or a government. He could shoot hoops or people. He could follow the rules of the basketball court, or ignore the rules of the World Court. Hmmm . . . tough call. Scoring or warring? C'mon, let the big kid play. ALAN B. WEBER Brooklyn

title: Symbols of Austerity: 16 Flagless Flagpoles
description: Some of the 20 new flagpoles put up by the City of Hamtramck will be bare on Flag Day because there is not enough money to buy flags for them.

title: CASTOFF PENS: A GOOD OMEN
description: ONE of Connecticut's largest collections of castoff pens lies in the center drawer of the teacher's desk in the computer room at Westport's Coleytown Middle School. There must be about 200 there now, most in good working order. Since Westport is an affluent town, some of the pens cost $2.79 at the local stationery store. Few students ask for them back. The pens are discarded by children who are at an age when losing a shoe is not all that unusual. But I choose to think there is something symbolic, even epic, about those forgotten pens. They mark the era in which computers replace the more traditional methods of learning how to write.

title: COURT BACKS DETROIT LAYOFFS
description: The City of Detroit can legally lay off 1,100 police officers, most of them black, in accordance with a seniority system, a Federal appeals court ruled Friday.

description: FOR years, government attempts to train welfare recipients for jobs have snagged on such persistent problems as no jobs, or jobs that paid less than welfare benefits; no day-care facilities, no transportation.

description: ON a February evening 10 years ago, Eddie Antar walked out of an East Side discotheque where he had been inspecting a sound system and two men attacked him. He was knifed so badly that for days doctors questioned whether he would survive.

title: A Straw to Stir George Steinbrenner
description: IN checking the seismographs of the latest Mets and Yankees rumblings, as provoked by Darryl Strawberry and George Steinbrenner, the shame is that their squawks are separated by the Triborough Bridge toll booths. These two were meant for each other. And each deserves the other.

title: Looking Homeward
description: A FUNNY THING HAPPENED to me on the way to Indonesia several years ago. And then again on the way to Vienna. And to Budapest. And to Jamaica. And recently, even, on the way to New York. Something strange seized me, something ''unmanly'' - downright embarrassing at first - but now, slowly, ever so slowly, comprehensible to me. It might, at first blush, be called by some common, diagnostic and pejorative name -something like what the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of the American Psychiatric Association labels ''panic disorders.'' But I think, as I reflect on it, it is something deeper, more common, less pathological . . . perhaps even less interesting. I think it's homesickness.

title: AGNES GUND BECOMES THE BRIDE OF DANIEL SHAPIRO
description: Agnes Gund and Daniel Shapiro were married yesterday at the bride's home in New York by Bishop Paul Moore Jr. of the Episcopal Diocese of New York. David, Catherine, Jessica and Anna Saalfield attended their mother, and Anthony M. Solomon was the best man.

title: WETLANDS: MEETING SET ON NEW BILL
description: LEAD: SUPPORTERS of a broad state wetlands-protection program believe that Governor Kean's decision last week to impose a moratorium on building in freshwater wetlands should give them the initiative in the ongoing legislative debate on the issue. They are not ready to proclaim victory, however. Nor are representatives of the state's builders and developers about to concede.

title: TWO SHOWS AT THE BRONX MUSEUM OF ARTS
description: SALVADOR DALI once insisted that he was the first to pop his eyes at the camera and that Picasso picked up the trick from him. The comedian, Eddie Cantor, was probably the real pioneer in this area, but Dali and Picasso were almost certainly the first ''serious'' artists to gear their personal images to the media - only to be topped by Andy Warhol, who made showmanship itself an art form.

title: FOR SEOUL, LINGERING FUMES TOUCH OFF TEARS AND ANGER
description: Nothing is more inescapable these days than the lung-searing, eye-burning tear gas that saturates the streets of the entire downtown area. The gas, a particularly virulent brand, is said to be used nowhere else so unsparingly.

title: FOR ALCOHOLIC WOMEN, A PLACE TO GO
description: Massachusetts has opened a new clinic for alcoholic women in an effort to correct a glaring deficiency in services that had resulted in the state housing such women in a prison without treatment.

title: SETTING THE STAGE WITH A TEXAS VICTORY
description: IT could well be argued that Friday, May 15, 1987, was the most exciting day in American bridge history. Few people, however, were able to savor it, for it occurred in four small rooms at the Hyatt Hotel in Memphis. The occasion was the second day of semi-final play in the International Team Trials with four top-ranked teams battling for the right to represent the United States in the world championship, scheduled in Jamaica in October.

title: Reagan Renews Attack On Protectionist Bills
description: President Reagan, just back from the economic summit meeting in Venice, renewed his battle today against trade restriction bills that he said would ''damage our own prosperity and that of virtually the entire world.''

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LEAD: TAKING LEAVE. By Janet Shaw. (Viking, $17.95.) This first novel is a carefully observed portrait of a family coming unraveled in upper-crust Chicago. Each character - rational Will Brenner, a dedicated Highland Park doctor; Laura, his pretty, brittle wife who is fighting boredom and anorexia; and her innocent, self-possessed younger sister, Jo - suffers from painful, nearly debilitating longings for transformation, for more passionate and coherent lives.

title: SARATOGA
description: Like most resorts that had a heyday, Saratoga is long on nostalgia. Saratoga's was the late Victorian era, and the remnants are clustered among parking lots and fast-food places along Broadway. But beyond those facades, visitors know they can recapture a bit of the past, for the diversions of an 1870's holiday - morning promenades, afternoons at the races and evenings at concerts -now have an 80's spin, with minimalls, quinellas and avant-garde music. Men and women continue to dress in linen and straw hats on summer days, the Thoroughbreds delight and confound, and the music and dance are among the country's best.

title: LEIGH F. WATKINS BECOMES A BRIDE

Taylor of Wellington and Otaki, New Zealand. The Rev. Donald Etherton performed the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church in St. Michaels, Md.

title: CONNER LAUNCHES NEW CUP DRIVE
description: On his way to an interview in a Seventh Avenue high-rise last week, Dennis Conner got the high-five salute from one of the building's janitors. The goodwill gesture could have been taken for just that. But as far as Conner was concerned, it was one of many signals that ''the people in America care about the America's Cup.''

description: LEAD: HEIRESS. By Janet Dailey. (Little, Brown, $17.95.) To satirize this novel is very easy. All you have to do is quote from the steamy sex scenes that occur with regularity. You can do the same with the sentimental hearts-and-flowers death scene with which it ends. Still, with more than 126 million copies of her 12 previous novels in print, Janet Dailey should know what her readers want and how to serve it up.

title: Charter Falls Through Cracks Of Boston's Record-Keeping
description: Boston's original City Charter and its 350-year-old deed to the Common are among scores of historic records that have been lost, stolen or given away because of a century of shoddy record-keeping, the city's archivist says.

title: On Target on AIDS
description: Credit New york state and city officials for focusing on the most meaningful way to fight AIDS: helping heroin abusers kick their habits. Such addicts pass the disease among themselves by sharing needles, then pass it along to sexual partners and children.

title: Headliners; Going to Bat
description: After 20 years of studying and criticizing the treatment of black athletes, Harry Edwards is getting a chance to actually do something about it. Mr. Edwards, who was associated with protests by black athletes at San Jose State University in 1967 and during the 1968 Olympics, has been invited to help increase minority employment in baseball. Peter Ueberroth, the baseball commissioner, said last week that Mr. Edwards, now a professor of sociology at the University of California at Berkeley, would be involved in a project aimed at bringing more nonwhites into front office and coaching jobs. Details had not been worked out, but Mr. Edwards said Mr. Ueberroth seemed sincere about changing baseball employment practices that have recently been criticized by blacks. ''If he had his druthers, I'm sure the problem would have been worked out within two weeks after he became commissioner,'' Mr. Edwards said.

title: U.S. Schoolchildren Found to Master Some Language Skills
description: American schoolchildren are mastering the mechanics of grammar, punctuation and spelling, a testing agency says.

title: Lindley Boegehold, Editor, Married to John M. Milkey
description: Lindley Boegehold, an editor at the Macmillan Publishing Company in New York, and John Marshall Milkey, a painting contractor in New York, were married yesterday at the home of Harry Boyd Marshall, a grandfather of the bride, in Cornwall-on-Hudson, N.Y. The Rev. Craig D. Townsend performed the Episcopal ceremony.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: LEAD: NEVER BEFORE NOON: An Autobiography. By Afdera Fonda with Clifford Thurlow. (Weidenfeld & Nicolson, $16.95.) They met in Rome during the filming of ''War and Peace'' (1956), in which Henry Fonda played Pierre. Afdera Franchetti, the daughter of an Italian baron, was tacitly engaged to one of her own class and age and, in fact, when it came to the crunch, had a great deal of trouble making up her mind.

title: LUNCHING AT WORK
description: WHEN he was an accountant, Budd Goldman said, eating at his desk meant spreading out his sandwich on a brown paper bag. So he was receptive when Michelle Horwitz, a designer, came up with a more stylish way to lunch at work: on a series of laminated mats called Lunch-In Mats. Mr. Goldman's company, Banning Enterprises in Bellmore, L.I., manufactures them. They are 9 by 11 3/4 inches, and one suggests lunch at a fancy resaurant, with its roses, gleaming flatware and cloth napkin in a silver holder. The mats, $4.99, are at Plastic Works, 1407 Third Avenue (80th Street) and 2107 Broadway (74th Street).

title: GOLFER DOMINATED TOUR, THEN QUIT
description: Ralph Guldahl, the tall self-taught Texan who dominated professional golf in the late 1930's only to give up the tour for lack of interest, died in his sleep early Thursday at his home in the Los Angeles suburb of Sherman Oaks. He was 75 years old and was the professional at the Braemar Country Club in Tarzana, Calif.

title: LOUISE BERLINER Weds JOHN SAI-CHEONG LAM
description: Louise Berliner, a daughter of William F. Berliner of Armonk, N.Y., and the late Patricia Lopin Berliner, was married at Lyndhurst in Tarrytown, N.Y., yesterday to John Sai-Cheong Lam, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William Lam of Cambridge, Mass. Justice Theodore Dachenhausen Jr. of New York State Supreme Court performed the ceremony.

title:
ART VIEW;
AT LAST, A 'MUSEUM WITHOUT WALLS' ...
description: LEAD: NOTHING COULD BE MORE DE-ceptive than the cool, distanced impact of the new Menil Collection in Houston. In its installation - owed above all to Dominique de Menil, the museum's prime mover, with the collaboration of her director, Walter Hopps - it is a model of clarity. Yet it is a museum of discreet passions and audacious pairings.

title: DRAWING CARD FOR DEMOCRATS: POWER OF A TOP FUND-RAISER
description: No Democrat could remember anything quite like what happened here this weekend. But then, there are not many Democrats who have raised as much money for the party as Walter H. Shorenstein.

title: SUMMER TOUCHES
description: ON THOSE DAYS OF SUMMER WHEN THE AIR SHIMMERS with heat, the idea of piling on makeup seems unthinkable. Fortunately, a lighter touch is both more appealing and more attractive.

title: Marines Drop Spy Charge in Moscow Embassy Case
description: Many Americans were stunned earlier this year by stories of young Marine guards at the United States Embassy in Moscow who confessed to fraternizing with women who were spies and ended up letting Soviet agents into some of the most sensitive parts of the compound. But last week the Marine Corps issued a confession of its own. The corps said it could not prove its espionage case against Cpl. Arnold Bracy, a 21-year-old former Marine guard at the American Embassy in Moscow and was dropping the charges against him. Corporal Bracy said he had been coerced into confessing that he had let Soviet agents into the embassy last year.

title: BEACHES RE-EMERGE AS SWOLLEN LAKES SUBSIDE
description: Beaches not seen in years are emerging along parts of the Great Lakes because of a drop in water levels from the record highs of last fall.

title:
ANTIQUES;
YESTERYEAR'S FASHIONS AND FABRICS TODAY
description: LEAD: WHEN Erika Bevis began selling vintage clothing here seven years ago, she said, ''Antique textiles were looked down on as sort of the black sheep of the business.''

NEW JERSEY Journal;
OPEN-HOUSE GARDENS
description: LEAD: This year's open house at the display gardens of Rutgers University's Cook College will celebrate the 200th anniversary of the Constitution with a showing of modern varieties of Colonial herbs and flowers. title: Ethiopians to Vote Today
description: Millions of Ethiopians are expected to vote on Sunday in elections for the country's first national Parliament. The elections, for 835 seats, will be the first since the overthrow of Emperor Haile Selassie and the creation of a Marxist state in 1974. Three candidates are running in each district, with the exception of the central district in the capital where Ethiopia's leader, Lieut. Col. Mengistu Haile Mariam, is unopposed. The Parliament is to replace the ruling military council.

title: A New Push for Public Housing
description: Almost no new public housing has been built during the Reagan Administration and many existing programs have suffered cutbacks. But pressure is rising in Congress to reverse that trend.

title: CARDS ROUT CUBS, 9-2, AND LEAD BY 5
description: Lee Tunnell pitched six-hit ball over six and one-third innings in 97-degree heat today as the St. Louis Cardinals beat Chicago, 9-2, and increased their lead in the National League East to five games over the second-place Cubs.

description: Governor Mario Cuomo is not running for the Presidency.

title: A SUPERHERO FOR CARTOONISTS?
description: RICHARD NEWCOMBE is fond of saying that he is ''like Lincoln, freeing the slaves.'' Six months ago, Mr. Newcombe founded Creators Syndicate, which claims to offer its cartoonists and artists emancipation from what he calls ''indentured servitude'' - the 10- to 20-year contracts and the signing over of ownership rights that have characterized the syndication business for years.

description: MARTIN WILLIAMS, THE Smithsonian Institution's jazz guru, has revised his 1973 Smithsonian Collection of Classic Jazz, which is now a seven-LP (rather than six) or a five-cassette overview of the entire jazz tradition.

title: Portugal
description: To the Editor: I was amused to learn from Marvine Howe's article ''Lisbon's New Tavares'' (Travel, March 15) that the late dictator Antonio de Olivira Salazar had urged the restaurant to present American tourists with scrupulous accounts instead of exploiting them. Alas, that good advice is no longer followed. When we ate at Tavares in 1985, my wife asked for a copy of the menu to take home. The waiter inadvertently gave her a Portuguese menu instead of the English one from which we had ordered. When we later compared our bill with the menu, the prices were 50 to 75 percent higher on the bill than on the Portuguese menu. HERMAN HARMELINK 3d Poughkeepsie, N.Y. Fernando Lopes, owner of Restaurante Tavares, replies: At any time of the year the prices on the Portuguese, French and English menus are exactly the same. What happened in this case is that we always give an old menu - sometimes a year or more old - when we offer one to a client because we need the menu of the day for other customers. Of course, the old menu is likely to have different prices. We regret that Mr. Harmelink did not understand that.

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''Anything that recognizes that the U.S. banking system is at a disadvantage is positive. But there may be an exaggerated emphasis on size.''

title: ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT IS OVERPROTECTIVE, CRITICS CONTEND
description: LEAD: WILDLIFE officials in Montana had enough of a job with the state's grizzly bears when, two years ago, after half a century's absence, a pack of gray wolves wandered down from Canada. The wolves are thriving, and last month two of them crippled and killed a 900-pound cow, the first confirmed livestock kill since the wolf returned to the state.

title: BBC SITCOM PROVES POLITICS HAS ITS LAUGHS
description: THE AMERICAN SITUATION comedy is wide enough to encompass adolescent capers, romantic flings and even tips on how best to raise a family. But the native form has had problems getting a handle on political comedy. The few more notable attempts to poke fun at our politics and politicians have been decidedly off target. A couple of years ago, ''Hail to the Chief'' gave us Patty Duke as the first female President of the United States, a promising concept that was then buried in frantic efforts to be irreverent. The result was merely sour. Currently, on Fox Broadcasting's new Sunday lineup, ''Mr. President'' is offering George C. Scott as the nation's chief executive, complete with patient wife and adorable family. While the comedy is meant to be light, the always formidable Mr. Scott leaves the impression of an elephant stampeding through marshmallow.

title: Public or Special Interests on Insurance?
description: Thousands of New Yorkers know the life insurance sold by savings banks is an excellent buy. Fewer know that the chance to purchase certain kinds of savings bank life insurance is now under attack by the insurance agents' lobby. Voters ought to let legislators know they are watching.

title: POMPADOUR'S PALACE
description: It's not often there's a new travel story to be written about the chateaus of the Loire. But then it's not often there's a new chateau to be visited there.

title: IN NORTH NICARAGUA VILLAGE, THE WAR IS BRUTAL FACT
description: This small, fire-scarred huddle of wood shacks, parasite-laden children and nervous militiamen is one of the places where the eight-year-old Nicaraguan revolution is on the defensive.

title: WILDLIFE APPEARS ON NEW ISSUES
description: THE United States Postal Service utilized the opening day of Capex '87, the international stamp show being held in Toronto, Canada, to release its spectacular sheet of wildlife stamps. The new sheet of 50 stamps of animals reflects the geographic and biological diversity of wildlife native to the North American continent. All states are represented. Unlike the state birds and flowers sheet of 1982, stamps on the new sheet do not include state names.

title: A FAT AND HUNGRY NATION
description: LEAD: EMPIRE By Gore Vidal. 486 pp. New York: Random House. $22.50.

title: Where Are The Black Fans?
description: To me, the phrase ''gifted athlete'' always carried the connotation of having the ability to think quickly and accurately as well as having the physical attributes necessary to perform great deeds on the field. Should I now no longer use such language when referring to black athletes? Is it O.K., one wonders, to use alternative phraseology, such as talented athlete, exceptional athlete? OWEN McNAMARA Herkimer, N.Y.

title:
ABOUT WESTCHESTER;
A YEAR IN THE LIFE
description: LEAD: CAPTION under the 1987 yearbook photograph of Laura J. Ghiron, graduating senior at Horace Greeley High School:

title: What's Up in the Park? Ceiling Tiles!
description: RARE 19th-century tiles that once rewarded an upward glance in Central Park will be restored even if the work does cost the city an extra $1 million, Mayor Koch decided last week.

title: Presbyterian Unit Adopts Paper on Jews and Israel
description: A compromise was reached here tonight at the annual meeting of the nation's largest Presbyterian church that was expected to clear the way for adoption of a landmark document on Christian-Jewish relations.

title: Misery on the Meatpacking Line
description: MARY TVEDT had learned to live with the dirt and the danger of a meatpacking house. So she did not think much of it when the huge blade jammed in the bacon slicer where she was working. She turned off the power, opened the machine and began clearing out chunks of bacon the way she had a hundred times before in her years at John Morrell & Company's plant here.

title: BECK LEE, WRITER, AND CARY BROWN WED IN KENTUCKY
description: At the Calvary Episcopal Church in Louisville, Ky., Alice Cary Brown, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Lee Lyons Brown Jr. of Louisville and Fishers Island, N.Y., was married yesterday to Warren Beckwith Lee Jr., the son of Frances Parillo Lee of New York and the late Mr. Lee. The Rev. Alfred R. Shands 3d performed the ceremony. He was assisted by the Rev. Fleming Parker Rutledge, godmother of the bride.

title: THE EXECUTIVE COMPUTER
description: In a world of many standards, the ability to convert information from one format to another reigns.

title: SPINKS-COONEY BOUT: NO SALE
description: In April, at the news conference in New York at which his match against Michael Spinks was formally announced, Gerry Cooney emerged from a cloud of smoke when he was introduced.

title: FEWER YOUTHS SEEK JOBS PROGRAM
description: FEDERALLY funded summer jobs, which have traditionally given many disadvantaged teen-agers their only chance for employment, are going unfilled in Connecticut as more youths are finding jobs at supermarkets and fast-food restaurants.

title: SUMMITE DOES NO HARM AND VERY LITTLE BUSINESS
description: PERHAPS it was the unlucky number, but the 13th meeting of leaders of the seven major industrial democracies last week will probably go down in history as one of the least consequential since Valery Giscard d'Estaing and Helmut Schmidt first came up with the idea of the annual get-togethers. The world economy is not quite in the parlous state it was in 1975, when the French President and West German Chancellor urged concerted action to deal with the dramatic rise in Middle East oil prices. But it is shaky enough, and the generalities and palliatives proffered in Venice, officials privately concurred, will probably change little.

title: RIZZO GAINS LEAD BY SHOT ON EAGLE
description: Patty Rizzo made a 75-foot eagle putt on the final hole today to take a one-stroke lead over Betsy King after three rounds of the $350,000 L.P.G.A. Mayflower Classic.

title: DAVID EDWARD LEVIN AND ELLIE PADELL WED
description: The marriage of Ellie Padell, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bert Padell of New York and Westhampton Beach, L.I., to David Edward Levin took place last evening at the Metropolitan Club in New York. Rabbi Charles Lipman performed the ceremony. The bridegroom is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Levin of Long Beach, L.I., and West Palm Beach, Fla.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: LEAD: BACK TO THE PAST Although knighthood actually wasn't in flower in these parts, the towering presence of copies of Renaissance castles on the Sands Point Preserve gives the people who run the former Gould and Guggenheim estate for Nassau County a perfect excuse to stage a Medieval Festival.

title: ALIEN AMNESTY OFF TO SLOW START
description: LEAD: THEY came to the United States from places like Thailand, Poland, Nigeria, Korea and Argentina. They came because the United States is still considered the land of opportunity, and many have settled and found work on Long Island.

title: WHAT COMES AFTER HAPPILY EVER AFTER
description: LOVE UNKNOWN By A. N. Wilson. 202 pp. New York: Viking. $16.95.

title: HEATHER C. NUTT MARRIES D. A. CRIMMINS IN JERSEY
description: Heather C. Nutt, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gordon Nutt of Ridgewood, N.J., was married at the West Side Presbyterian Church there yesterday to Douglas A. Crimmins, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Crimmins of Ridgewood. The Rev. Ralph Wagner performed the ceremony.

title: BETWEEN BISTRO AND NOUVELLE
description: RESTAURANTS can be located and identified in at least two ways. Geographically, Le Troquet is in Huntington Village.

title: LAUTENBERG SEEKS TO CURB A JAPANESE CANDY MAKER
description: NEW JERSEY'S junior Senator has come to the defense of an American product being threatened by a Japanese imitation. However, this time the focus is not on electronics, but on a familiar candy: M & M's.

title: BERGENFIELD BAND HELPS IMAGE
description: THE 25,500 residents of this Bergen County community have a reason to celebrate: the performance of the Bergenfield High School marching band on the annual Tony Awards program last Sunday night.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: NEW NATURE CENTER A new nature center will open at 2 P.M. today on the grounds of the Lenoir Nature Preserve in Yonkers. The former two-story, brick carriage house of an estate that once belonged to John Stillwell, a vice president of Con Edison and brother of ''Vinegar'' Joe Stillwell, an Army general in World War II, has been renovated in the last year into an educational environmental facility by the County Parks Department.

title: JAPANESE STAR PASSES GEHRIG MARK
description: Lou Gehrig's consecutive-game record in baseball, achieved from 1925-39, was surpassed today when Sachio Kinugasa stepped onto the playing field for the 2,131st straight time.

title: TWO FEET AND A LONG SEARCH
description: I'VE put it off for as long as I can, but I simply must buy a new pair of shoes. Other women look forward to such an excursion with anticipation. I approach it with dread.

title: BATTLES FOR SEATS IN SUFFOLK
description: LEAD: ALONG with choosing a County Executive in November, voters in Suffolk County will also decide between keenly competing candidates for the 18 seats of the County Legislature.

title: Joanne Lipman, Reporter, Weds Thomas Distler
description: Joanne Beth Lipman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Burton E. Lipman of East Brunswick, N.J., and Thomas Richard Distler, a son of Donald J. Distler of West Orange, N.J., and the late Bette Feitelson Distler, were married yesterday. Rabbi A. Bruce Goldman performed the ceremony at the National Arts Club in Manhattan.

title: ONE NEW YORKER'S CURE FOR HYPERTENSION: WIN A MILLION-DOLLAR LOTTERY
description: Vincent Coda - millionaire, world traveler and No. 1 celebrity in Sparrow Bush, N.Y. - was taking advantage of the freedom that wealth gave him, freedom to do what he wanted.

title: 'A Truly Bad Rabbit'
description: To the editor:

title: DRUGS AND GRAFT MAIN ISSUE IN BAHAMAS VOTE
description: With the most important national elections in the recent history of the Bahamas scheduled for next Friday, only one issue dominates the campaign: drug trafficking and the official Government corruption it has spawned.

title: Soprano Supreme
description: MARIA CALLAS: HAMBURG CONCERT 1959 With the Sinfonieorchester des NDR, Nicola Rescigno, conductor. Kultur. 68 minutes. $39.95.

title: MUSIC
description: Barry Harris: Passing It On Directed by David Chan and Ken Freundlich. Rhapsody Films. P.O. 179, New York, N.Y. 10014. 23 minutes. $29.95.

title: FREEDOM TO FAIL INSPIRES SUCCESS
description: THERE was something about the way he slammed the door as he climbed into the car that day. He kept staring straight ahead, but repeated over and over that he hated that school and wasn't going back.

title: CALLS FOR GENERAL'S OUSTER PERSIST AS VIOLENCE IN PANAMA SUBSIDES
description: Political violence began to subside in Panama today, but many stores remained closed and policemen in riot gear were prepared for new outbreaks of protest.

title: FLIBERTY VS. GREATNESS FOR ALL
description: IDEOLOGY AND U.S. FOREIGN POLICY By Michael H. Hunt. Illustrated. 237 pp. New Haven: Yale University Press. $22.50. ENTANGLING ALLIANCES WITH NONE American Foreign Policy in the Age of Jefferson. By Lawrence S. Kaplan. 230 pp. Ohio: The Kent State University Press. Cloth, $24. Paper, $14.50.

title: TOBACCO TURNS AN ARTY LEAF
description: FOR THE FIRST TIME, TO bacco - a symbol of America for more than 400 years, a subject of national debate and a source of inspiration to folk artists for most of that time - is the subject of a major museum exhibition. Titled ''Tobacco Roads: The Popular Art of an American Pastime'' and organized by the Museum of American Folk Art, the show - on display through June 24 at City Gallery, 2 Columbus Circle - includes 75 works, produced mostly between the Civil War and World War II. All relate to the manufacturing and merchandising of tobacco products - or the recycling of materials used in its packaging.

title: Terror Chief Sentenced In Paris Police Slayings
description: A special anti-terrorist court today sentenced a leader of the Direct Action terrorist group to life imprisonment for his role in the 1983 slayings of two Paris policemen.

title: THEY DON'T BITE OR KICK, THEY'RE CUTER THAN COWS, BUT...
description: ''MARY had a little lamb; its fleece was white as snow. . . .'' How easily that rolled off my child's tongue. And how picturesque it was. But how unreal! This grown-up suburban matron-turned-shepherd has found out that Mary must have washed her lamb in Woolite every day for it to have that ''white-as-snow'' look.

title: Hold Rodman Responsible
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Madrid
description: To the Editor: I was surprised that Edward J. Sullivan didn't mention the Museum of the Royal Academy of Fine Arts of San Fernando in ''Madrid's Other Museums'' (Travel, March 22). I visited this outstanding collection before it closed in the mid-1970's for major renovations. According to The New York Times of Dec. 21, 1986, it has now been reopened. JOHN S. PERKINS Boston Mr. Sullivan replies: Mr. Perkins is indeed correct that the academy's collection of paintings is one of the most outstanding in Madrid. At the time I wrote my article it was still closed for repairs. This museum, on the Calle de Alcala, not far from the Puerta del Sol, is definitely worth a visit.

title: SEPT 12 WEDDING FOR TRACY SCHACH
description: Mr. and Mrs. William O. Schach of Pittsburgh and Christiansted, V.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter Ann Tracy Sawtelle Schach to Bruce Brian Simpson, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Hugh Simpson of Glasgow and Kincraig, Scotland. A Sept. 12 wedding is planned.

title: The Need to Seek Oil in Alaska's Arctic Refuge
description: Nearly two months have passed since the Administration proposed exploring for oil in the coastal plain of Alaska's Arctic National Wildlife Refuge. The plan is now before Congress, which must decide -presumably on the basis of a dispassionate reading of the evidence -whether to kill it or move it forward. Regrettably, however, critics have engaged in nonstop misrepresentation of the facts.

title: CAN YOU TOP THIS?
description: THERE'S A CLASS of malicious bore whose chief delight is in disproving things we've known all our lives, thereby scuttling the fragile buoys of fact to which we cling in a sea of uncertainty. ''Attila the Hun was really a mild collector of snuff boxes,'' he'll say with a knowing sneer, or ''Mozart's best stuff was stolen from Francis Bacon.''

title: THE METRO TO APOCALYPSE
description: LANDSCAPES AFTER THE BATTLE By Juan Goytisolo. Translated by Helen Lane. 159 pp. New York: Seaver Books. $17.95.

title: Photography
description: James Casebere's photographs have as much to do with sculpture as with photography, which is not to their disadvantage. Depicting rudely shaped scenes fashioned by the artist in his studio, and evoking a nether world filled with half-remembered, stereotypical forms, they put their collective finger on a critical juncture of representation and reality.

title: HOW BAKKER WIDENED THE EYE OF THE NEEDLE
description: JUST inside the entrance to Heritage USA, the 2,300-acre theme park and headquarters of the PTL ministry, stands the Rev. Billy Graham's childhood home. Some years ago, Jim Bakker, PTL's recently deposed founder, purchased the building and moved it 15 miles from Charlotte, N.C., where Mr. Graham was born. While Mr. Bakker intended the gesture as homage to the dean of American television evangelists, it now serves as a reminder of how far Mr. Bakker has drifted from the evangelical movement's mainstream.

title: DRINKING AND BOATING: A DEADLY COMBINATION
description: ON May 18, a 14-foot boat carrying three fishermen capsized on the Quinnebaug River in Killingly, resulting in the drowning of a 52-year-old man. Two weeks later, a 22-year-old man drowned when a boat half that size carrying five people flipped over on Lake Desek in Middlefield.

title: Expanding on the Whitney
description: To the Editor:

title: Minor Quake Jolts Missouri, But No Damage Is Reported
description: A light earthquake rattled pictures on walls in southeast Missouri today, but no damage was immediately reported.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: LIGHT, BUT NO BRIGHT COLORS FIRE ISLAND may be a trend-setter, but an artistic new color scheme is not in the future for the lighthouse there.

title: UTILITIES SEE THREAT OF POWER SHORTAGE
description: FOR the first time since the Arab oil embargo of 1973, residents of Connecticut may experience brownouts, or even blackouts, across the state in July and August because of an electricity shortage shaping up throughout New England.

title: ELLEN OPPENHEIM IS MARRIED TO DR. NEIL FELDMAN
description: At Temple Hesed in Scranton, Pa., last evening, Ellen Oppenheim, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Oppenheim of Scranton, and Dr. Neil Feldman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Maurice Feldman of Willow Grove, Pa., were married by Rabbi Milton Richman.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I don't know what's around that bend, but when I do, I'll be sure to let you know. And that's all the news from Lake Wobegon, a little town where all the women are strong, all the men are good looking, and all the children are above average.'' - Garrison Keillor [ 26:6. ]

title: NEW STATE RULES DISMAY LAKE HOMEOWNERS
description: HOMEOWNERS on the 600 private lakes in New Jersey are in an uproar over new laws that regulate bathing in their waters. Many face large, unanticipated expenses to comply with the new state standards, and several lake communities are even considering banning swimming altogether because of the cost.

title: CHIEF OF POLICE STANDS APART IN S. CAROLINA
description: That Reuben M. Greenberg is black, that he practices the Orthodox Jewish faith of his grandfather and that he is the Chief of Police in this quintessential Southern city are reasons enough to call him unusual. It is Chief Greenberg's successful, hard-nosed approach to law enforcement, however, that makes him stand out in his field.

title: DIFFICULT CHOICE: MAINER OR MANOR
description: The new Earl of Wharncliffe says he would rather remain the old construction foreman of Cumberland, thank you just the same.

title: Parliament Acts To Bar Kahane
description: Rabbi Meir Kahane, the militant Israeli conservative who was born in the United States, has fought to keep his American citizenship while serving as a member of the Israeli Parliament. In 1985, the State Department deprived him of his American citizenship because of his membership in a foreign parliament, but a Federal Court gave him back his passport.

title: Virginia Daly Is Married
description: Virginia Adkins Daly, the daughter of Mrs. William Patrick Daly of Brooklyn and the late Mr. Daly, was married yesterday to Martin Patrick Cusack, the son of Mrs. Martin Cusack, also of Brooklyn, and the late Mr. Cusack. The Rev. James F. Keenan performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of Our Lady Help of Christians in Brooklyn. The bride is an editor in the special projects division of Adweek magazine in New York. Mr. Cusack is a senior rating analyst for Insurance Services Office Inc. in New York.

title: AS AGIED INCREASE, STUDY INTENSIFIES
description: LEAD: WITH an unprecedented growth in the elderly population on Long Island comes an urgent need for geriatric research and high-quality care. To better serve the medical and psychosocial needs of people with chronic problems and illnesses who are now living to advanced ages, Long Island institutions are conducting major scientific research, much of it related to

title: One Man's Mousetrap
description: Jacob Rabinow is right, ''You gotta make things,'' but to get from the invention to the successful manufacturing and use of products, you've gotta have innovation (''One Man's Mousetraps,'' by Robert Kanigel, May 17). Invention is often the solution to a technical problem. To take an invention and translate it into a commercially successful product requires the fusion of marketing requirements, manufacturing and assembly, and ergonomics, all translated by design into useful ''things'' that meet user needs and arrive on the market ahead of the competition. COLIN CLIPSON Professor of Architecture University of Michigan Ann Arbor, Mich.

title: DON'T COUNT OUT CONSERVATISM
description: THE OBITUARIES FOR THE ''REAGAN revolution'' are already being published. A Time magazine cover story reports that ''there are signs of a fundamental change in the nation's political weather . . .'' Even Mikhail Gorbachev has casually referred to Ronald Reagan as a lame-duck President, though why the Soviet leader should be so eager to make unprecedented concessions in order to negotiate an arms-control agreement with such a President is left unclear. Perhaps Mr. Gorbachev sees something that American news magazines do not - namely, that whatever the follies of ''Irangate,'' or the vagaries of the electoral cycle, the basic conservative trend will persist, and that this is as good a time as any to strike a bargain.

title: A Mother's Memory Book
description: By publicizing her mother's Memory Book, Joan Gage does a disservice to her mother's memory. The reader, with all due respect to piety, will find this woman neither mysterious nor interesting, despite the many pretty photographs. If she is memorable, then it is for her apparent inability, all her life, to cease being a spoiled little girl. Her bitterness cannot be ascribed to the rigidity of the times she grew up in. We all know women of her generation who coped with broken hearts, shattered hopes, illness and sorrow, and yet lived lives full of caring. HANA DEMETZ Bethlehem, Pa.

title: SEGOVIA'S ONLY AIM: PERFECTION
description: WHEN THE WORD OF ANDRES Segovia's death came the other day, the thoughts of many of his admirers must have gone back to the first time they heard him play in person. I was surprised to realize that I could not pinpoint that signal event of some 40 years ago in my own memory, but that must be because my first face-to-face meeting with the grandee of the classic guitar several years later still stands out as a more vivid experience. As a conscientious young interviewer, I had prepared a page of probing questions for the venerable artist - he was then only in his early 60's, I must remind myself - but, hoping to oil the wheels of conversation, I mentioned that I not only owned all of the Segovia recordings available but had recently been inspired by them to become a student of the guitar. Big mistake. Segovia immediately took his instrument from its black case, unwrapped the shroudlike cloth that protected it, and pushed it into my hands. In an almost paralytic state, I began an easy etude by Sor, noting with interest that while the fingers seemed to be moving, no human will - certainly not mine - seemed to be impelling them.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: AFTER THE HOLIDAYS. By Yehoshua Kenaz. Translated by Dalya Bilu. (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $16.95.) First published in Israel 23 years ago, this powerful novel is an ironic, biting portrayal of pioneer life in pre-World War I Palestine. What some early Zionists called a paradise on earth, a land without people for a people without a land, the Israeli writer and critic Yehoshua Kenaz describes as inhospitable, threatening and heavily populated by Arabs. He mocks the Socialists for their rhetoric on the moral righteousness of manual labor and dismisses the religious as madmen, fools and ''Talmudic scholars who had abandoned the articles of their faith but had remained as idle as ever.'' Written in a tone of quiet detachment, and gracefully translated, ''After the Holidays'' presents a cast of highly individualized characters, a number of whom are raped, murdered or otherwise die badly. At the center of the story is the deracinated family of Haim Weiss, his chronically depressed wife, Bracha, and his two mad daughters, Batsheva and Riva, who wreak havoc on the lives of anyone near them. The most memorable character is Baruch (which means blessed in Hebrew), a dimwitted, strong-backed laborer whom Weiss employs to oversee his orange groves. In a series of tragic mishaps, Baruch becomes the counterpart to Lennie in John Steinbeck's ''Of Mice and Men.'' Also portrayed in sharp detail are Borochov, an intellectual without ideas who longs to express a hopeless, sticky Romanticism in poetry but cannot write a word; the drunken cart driver Friedman, who turns his daughter's wedding into a hilariously chaotic scene reminiscent of Bunuel's ''Viridiana''; and Langfuss, the unctuous real estate broker who makes money on everyone's misfortune. While no one in this book has any lasting pleasure in life or is exempt from disaster, ''After the Holidays'' (the first of Mr. Kenaz's novels to be translated into English) is not bleak or gloomy; its oblique, dark humor turns tragedy into absurdist comedy, milk and honey into acid and vinegar.

Miss Shields, one of the 1,050 members of the class of '87, was graduated from Princeton with honors last week. ''I did it in four years and I worked hard,'' the actress said. ''I didn't set out to prove anything to anyone except myself.'' Miss Shields, who was accompanied by a bodyguard on graduation day, said being a celebrity on campus was a problem only during her first year. ''Everybody knew me but I didn't know anybody, so I was at a disadvantage,'' she said. ''People were trying to be very polite and in doing so almost avoided me because they didn't want to come on too strong.''

title: Q and A
description: Vienna Question:We plan on visiting Vienna in September but have been told that performances of the Vienna Boys' Choir are sold out. Is there any way we can go about getting tickets? - J. J., Broomfield, Colo. Answer:Though there is always a strong demand, you should try writing directly to the Castle Chapel where the performances are given. Visitors should write asking for tickets on preferred dates at least eight weeks ahead of time to Hofmusikkapelle, Hofburg, A-1010, Vienna. Do not send checks, money orders or cash. The chapel office will respond, in German, to say whether or not tickets have been put aside for you. (Performances this year are being given on Sundays and religious holidays until June 28 and from Sept. 20 to Dec. 27, except the religious holidays on Dec. 8 and 26.) If tickets have been reserved for you, they can be picked up and paid for at the box office at the chapel, the Burgkapelle, between 11 A.M. and noon on the Friday preceding a performance or on Sunday by 9 A.M. at the latest. Seats cost from about $4 to $9.50; standing room is free.

title: REVOLUTIONARY WITH A HUMAN FACE
description: ROSA LUXEMBURG A Life. By Elzbieta Ettinger. Illustrated. 286 pp. Boston: Beacon Press. $24.95.

title: CYNTHIA E. WEISS IS MARRIED TO PETER A. ANTONUCCI
description: Cynthia Elizabeth Weiss, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Weiss of Farmingdale, L.I., and Peter Anthony Antonucci, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony Antonucci of New York, were married yesterday. The Rev. Brendan Riordan performed the ceremony at St. Kilian's Roman Catholic Church in Farmingdale.

title: AT LAST, A 'MUSEUM WITHOUT WALLS' ... GETS WALLS WORTHY OF IT
description: IN AN AGE IN WHICH MUSEUMS HAVE become grandiose, expressionistic, highly personal works of architecture, the first impulse is to say that the new Menil Collection in Houston represents an opposite trend: it is matter of fact, understated, utterly deferential to the art it contains. Yet in its way, this 402-foot-long, two-story-high box of steel, wood and glass, which seems so plain, is as expressive of personal style as any museum in America. Indeed, there may be no museum building anywhere that tells us as much as this one does about the person who created it. It is a built expression of the character of Dominique de Menil, the remarkable patron who, with her late husband, John, assembled the extraordinary collection that is displayed within. Like Mrs. de Menil herself, this new building is reserved and unpretentious on the surface -but it is no shrinking violet. The Menil Collection is absolutely sure of itself, completely unself-conscious and not a little bit stern.

title: SUZANNE DURRELL WEDS IAN S. MCISAAC
description: Suzanne Elizabeth Durrell, an assistant Attorney General for the Commonwealth of Massachusetts in Boston, and Ian Scott McIsaac, a Boston real-estate executive, were married yesterday at the Cochran Chapel on the campus of the Phillips Academy in Andover, Mass.

title: FRENCH VISAS
description: To the Editor: The writer has sometimes been accused of being a francophile, with some reason. One must admire French verve, style, culture and ambiance. One must also admire the French knack for making a good thing out of a bad situation.

title: Greenery Sprouts Sales
description: THE brilliance of azaleas in blossom, the contours of a shade tree and the lush green of a well-tended lawn are among the outdoor amenities that can add significantly to the market appeal of a suburban condominium development.

title: LISA DIMASI IS BRIDE OF DAVID E. HOWE JR.
description: At the Houghton Memorial Chapel at Wellesley College yesterday, Lisa DiMasi, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry DiMasi of Bayside, Queens, and David Endicott Howe Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Howe of Marlborough, N.H., were married by the Rev. John P. Culloty, a Roman Catholic priest. Donna Marie Farrell was maid of honor, and Nelson Bartlett Howe was his brother's best man.

title: BLAME IT ON THE BARRACUDA
description: TO THE SARGASSO SEA By William McPherson. 461 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $18.95.

title: Justice Dept. Is Held in Contempt in a Bankruptcy
description: A Federal bankruptcy judge held the Justice Department in contempt of court Friday, ruling that it unlawfully tried to put a financially troubled computer company out of business in 1985.

title: NUREYEV RETELS A FAIRY TALE
description: RUDOLF NUREYEV GRINS MIS-chievously as he describes his extravagantly untraditional retelling of ''Cinderella'': the wicked stepmother has become an ambitious stage mother, the ugly sisters aspiring starlets, the Prince a matinee idol and the fairy godmother that unequaled purveyor of modern American magic, a Hollywood producer.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
ISRAELI MEDAL MARKS HADASSAH'S ANNIVERSARY
description: LEAD: A medal from Israel marks the 75th anniversary of Hadassah, the women's Zionist organization of America. The obverse features a stylized number ''75'' along with the inscription ''75 Years - Hadassah -1912-1987'' in English and Hebrew. The reverse depicts the Star of David along with the motto, ''The healing of the daughter of my people.

title: Where Are The Black Fans?
description: In his article ''Where Are the Black Fans?'' (May 17), the ultimate logic behind Brent Staples's argument seems to be that because racism is an inextricable part of America's past, and thus America's identity, then anything that embodies the American identity is by definition racist. But isn't a strain of tolerance and egalitarianism also an inextricable part of the American identity? Mr. Staples treats the democratic aspect of baseball as a form of fraud. Mightn't that aspect also be part of the dynamic that integrated baseball, even though that integration is only partial? That would account for the newsworthiness of the current controversy over black management in the game.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.C.A.A. Golf Watts Takes Medalist Honors: Brian Watts shot a final-round 66 to match the course record and earn medalist honors, leading Oklahoma State to the team title at the 90th N.C.A.A. championships at Ohio State's Scarlet Course yesterday in Columbus, Ohio. Watts finished at eight-under-par 280 for a six-shot margin of victory. Oklahoma State scored a final-round even-par 288 to finish at eight-over-par 1,160 shots. Wake Forest was second with 1,176 strokes.(AP)

title: An Airport To Land Business
description: TWO communities in the fast-growing suburbs northwest of Chicago are hoping for a pick-up in real-estate activity in the aftermath of a significant investment of their own: With a big lift from Federal and state funds, they bought an airport.

title: A Mother's Memory Book
description: ''My Mother's Mystery'' reveals that its author has painful childhood memories of her mother and that she has not yet come to terms with them. She tells us that her mother was a hypochondriacal ice queen, a perfectionist who could never be satisfied and who was, therefore, never happy. Mrs. Gage's rage bubbles to the surface with such intensity that what purports to be a revelation is really a cathartic exercise that is painful to read. SYLVIA B. BELKIN Swampscott, Mass.

title: A LA CARTE
description: WHAT does the Grumman Corporation, Long Island's largest employer, have to do with food and restaurants? Grumman operates the Linden Tree Restaurant in Hicksville. When people learn of that, they're confused. Is it open to the public? Do you have to be affiliated with Grumman to go there?

title: Modern Inflatables Are Rugged Boats
description: PERHAPS because I was raised on the seacoast in an era when wood was the basic building material for small craft, I have been slow in realizing that the best of today's inflatable boats - whether dinghies, rafts, kayaks or big water craft driven by outboard or inboard engines - are tough, safe and seaworthy and sometimes better suited for a specific role than their conventional counterparts.

title: AMANDA CLARKE BECOMES A BRIDE
description: The marriage of Amanda Clarke, marketing services manager at Manhattan,inc. magazine in New York, to N.Louis Shipley, an associate at Paine Webber in New York, took place yesterday at the Ethel Walker School Chapel in Simsbury, Conn. The Rev. Thomas Furrer performed the Episcopal ceremony.

title: '42D STREET' PUTS ON A STRAW HAT
description: Come and meet those dancing feet on the avenue I'm takin' you to Winnacunnet Road.

title: GROWING UP WITH PRIVILEGE AND PREJUDICE
description: To our children . . . in the hope that they will grow up as we could not . . . equal . . . and understanding.

title: 400 ALIENS ASK FOR NEW STATUS
description: ''I'LL go get the Mexicans,'' the young father said cheerfully, gesturing toward his toddler sons as the immigration counselor summoned him for his interview.

title:
DINING OUT;
OLDEST PLACE IN WHITE PLAINS
description: LEAD: FEW county dwellers passing through White Plains have failed to note the charming and misspelled sign of Le Gai Pinguin.

title: PROFESSIONALS RIDE FOR LOW STAKES
description: Raise your son (or daughter) to be an athlete and the dollars may start flowing. But make sure you have the right sport.

title: HOUSE PANEL IS TOLD OF DEATHS ON COMMERCIAL FISHING BOATS
description: A House committee that is working on legislation to regulate the American fishing industry has taken testimony from people who have lost relatives in accidents at sea.

title: THE SHORT STORIES OF THE STAGE
description: DURING ANTON CHEKHOV'S lifetime, the one-act play ''The Bear'' was one of his most popular and financially rewarding works. As he acknowledged, ''I live off the labors of my bear.'' With a few exceptions, dramatists today have had no such comparable experience with one-acts. Short plays are generally regarded as curtain raisers or afterthoughts, perhaps stageworthy but not commercially viable. They can be seen in the annual marathon at the Ensemble Studio Theater, or in special festivals at other institutional theaters, such as the Actors Theater of Louisville. After a brief run, they disappear (unless they are taped for television). If a playwright is fortunate, the play may be published, and then there is a chance that it may have a life in community or university theater.

title: TO CUT BIRTHS, KENYA TURNS TO TV SHOW
description: A character in the melodramatic world of television soap operas marries an elderly polygamist in her rural village and, at 15, becomes pregnant. The girl has a miscarriage, but, six months later, becomes pregnant again.

title: SUNDAY OBSERVER
description: ONCE UPON A TIME, or in 1942 if you prefer, high schools graduated their sweaty produce in June. Now the car-crash roundups in the press suggest they favor May, and why not? It's a whole new world out there at Hudson High and oodles more fun, I gather, than it was when Jack Armstrong and I were reading Ovid when the Latin teacher was looking and ''Spicy Detective'' when he wasn't.

title: DEMONS BEGONE IS FIFTH IN OHIO DERBY
description: Lost Code, winner of his previous four races, led all the way today to capture the $250,000 Ohio Derby by 3 1/2 lengths at Thistledown.

title: An Erratic March to Mid-Rise Production
description: People who live in the Jackson Heights section of Queens probably remember the block on 35th Avenue, between 70th and 71st Street, as the place where Roosevelt Chevrolet once operated its car dealership. But in 1981, one of the city's larger sheet-metal and air-conditioning contractors, the B.S.M. Mechanical Corporation, bought the 30,000-square-foot property and moved in.

title: REDISTRICTING PLAN OFFERED IN LEGISLATURE
description: SOME of the bitterest, and most colorful, fights in the State Legislature occur after each Federal census, when the state must realign its Congressional districts to reflect shifts in population.

title: Where Are The Black Fans?
description: Brent Staples mentioned, as a racist ''slight,'' the occasion when Commissioner Bowie Kuhn was not present at the game in which Hank Aaron broke Babe Ruth's home-run record. The rebuttal is so obvious that it makes the whole issue appear silly.

title: MOVIES
description: Georgy Girl Starring Lynn Redgrave, James Mason, Alan Bates, Charlotte Rampling. Directed by Silvio Narizzano. 1966. RCA/Columbia Pictures Home Video. 100 minutes. $69.95.

title: FRANCE'S LEADING MAN
description: LEAD: AT BOUGIVAL, THE SEINE swells, greening the Ile-de-France, as the region surrounding Paris is known. In that serpentine village, Gerard Depardieu owns a cluster of three houses, above the road running east to Paris and northwest to his farm on the Norman coast. The actor bought the first house 12 years ago, and, with his success, the two next door for the overspill of family life.

title: AUTO MAKERS SOUP UP HI-FI
description: IT USED TO BE AXIOMATIC that a car radio that comes with the car can't be very good. Too often that's still true, but lately there have been notable exceptions.

description: To the Editor:

In fact, they seem to be trying to outdo each other in their quest not to reach the World Series, together or alone.

A truck bike it was called, big and heavy, not like the 10- and 12-speed racers of today with their lightweight chromium frames and astronomical price tags.

McGrath of Washington. Msgr. John D. Benson performed the ceremony at Our Lady Star of the Sea Roman Catholic Church.

title: Boca Raton

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, a dispatch from Colombo, Sri Lanka, in some copies last Sunday about an Indian offer to discuss aid for Sri Lankan Tamils described the Colombo Government's response to the overture incorrectly. The Government was reconsidering whether to attend a ministerial meeting of the South Asian Association for Regional Coop eration because of an Indian airdrop of supplies to Tamils in Sri Lanka, not because of the Indian offer to hold talks.

description: It was 2 A.M. when Cpl. Arnold Bracy came home to Queens yesterday, but a huge crowd of friends and neighbors was there to greet him.

title:
IN SHORT: NONFICTION;
ARTISTS BENEATH ARARAT

Though high and remote, Armenia, the biblical land of Ararat, was always contested by empires: Rome and Persia, the Arabs and Byzantium. The Armenians were good horse breeders and soldiers, and on occasion they ruled the states that sought to subdue them.

title: SOMETIMES A SERIOUS BOOK WINS THE BEST-SELLER GAME
description: WHEN the recession was battering the book business a few years ago, a publisher lamented, ''More people seem to be writing books than buying them.'' The industry has since fallen on better times. But it is still difficult, after last month's semiannual convention of the American Booksellers Association, not to be struck by the possibility that too many books are being loosed upon the world.

title: A JOB PROGRAM SWAMPS ITS FOUNDER
description: For 13 years now, the Rev. James Harvey has taken juvenile offenders and homeless teen-agers - more than 3,000 in all - and tried to change their lives with flowers.

title: INTELLECT ON STAGE
description: THE BOTTOM TRANSLATION Marlowe and Shakespeare and the Carnival Tradition. By Jan Kott. Translated by Daniela Miedzyrzecka and Lillian Vallee. Illustrated. 165 pp. Evanston, Ill.: Northwestern University Press. Cloth, $32.95. Paper, $14.95.

title: STILL ON THE SCENE, THE LONG SKIRT
description: SHORTER skirts might be making a heralded comeback, but they have a long way to go before they dominate the fashion scene. Evidence of this can be found in the long skirts that still seem to be almost everywhere you look. A lot of women are reluctant to let them go, even on warmer days.

description: To the Editor:

title: Accounts of Guns, Money and Promises
description: Testimony before the Congressional Iran-contra panels over the last six weeks has produced a picture of an American foreign policy initiative largely in private hands. Here are some excerpts. May 7 Representative Louis Stokes: ''. . . aren't we, in effect, accepting the fact that the United States Government contracted out its foreign policy to you, subject to you carrying out their best wishes?'' Maj. Gen. Richard V. Secord, the retired Air Force officer who organized arms sales to Iran and the contra supply operation: ''I don't think they viewed it that way, sir. I think that they viewed me as a . . . logistics operator and commercial go-between. . . .'' May 18 Robert W. Owen, a former aide to Senator Dan Quayle, Republican of Indiana, and a courier for Colonel North whose business card was found in the wreckage of a downed contra supply plane in Nicaragua: ''I was a private citizen who believed in what I was doing. I thought I was doing it, certainly, under the auspices of the United States Government, but I was still a private citizen.'' May 21 Joseph Coors, vice chairman and director of the Adolph Coors Co. brewery, telling why he deposited $65,000 in a Swiss bank account set up by Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North to aid the contras: Colonel North ''. . . was very anxious to provide me with an area where he thought I could be of most help. . . . That was in the area of providing a small Maule airplane.'' May 28 Lewis A. Tambs, former Ambassador to Costa Rica, describing his reaction to the news that John K. Singlaub, a retired major general, had promised a contra leader that the United States would provide food, arms and advisers: ''. . . I said, 'You cannot negotiate for the United States Government.' He said, 'That does not mean the United States Government.' He said, 'That means we private United Statesians.'' June 4 Arthur L. Liman, chief Senate counsel, referring to an arms-for-hostages deal with Iran: ''When you were told that this agreement that you had negotiated had been approved by the President of the United States, you must have felt very proud.'' Albert Hakim, General Secord's business partner: ''I felt proud throughout, sir. I felt proud being part of the team.'' Mr. Liman: ''Did you feel like you had been the Secretary of State for a day?'' Mr. Hakim: ''I would not accept that position for any money in the world, sir.'' Mr. Liman: ''Well, you had it better than the Secretary of State in some sense. You didn't have to get confirmed, correct?'' Mr. Hakim: ''I still believe that I have it better than the Secretary. I can achieve more, too.'' Mr. Liman: ''And if this, if this initiative had succeeded, did you ever make any calculation as to how much you and General Secord would make?'' Mr. Hakim: ''In what period of time, sir?'' Mr. Liman: ''People tend to think in terms of three- or five-year plans.'' Mr. Hakim: ''Many millions.'' June 5 Senator Daniel K. Inouye, Democrat of Hawaii and chairman of the Senate panel: ''. . . It just saddens me to be told that as a United States Senator, I may not be privy to certain information, but . . . Mr. Hakim can be made privy to all our secrets.'' June 9 Fawn Hall, Colonel North's secretary, describing her feelings about being asked to alter documents: '' . . . I felt uneasy, but . . . I believed in Colonel North, and there was a very solid and very valid reason that he must have been doing this. And sometimes you have to go above the written law, I believe.''

description: A 99-cent weapon to foil electronic bugging?

title: Sophisticated Silliness
description: THE GODS MUST BE CRAZY Written and directed by Jamie Uys. With Marius Weyers, Sandra Prinsloo and Xao. 1984. Playhouse Video. 109 minutes. $79.98.

Spears here offers us an anthology of reviews and essays written, for the most part, over the last 15 years.

description: To the Editor:

title: DECISION ON RADON DELAYED
description: A COURT-ORDERED deadline to remove 5,000 barrels of radium-contaminated soil from the lawns of four Montclair homes by tomorrow will not be met and may be delayed for as much as 10 days, if not longer.

title: GOD AND MAN IN LATIN AMERICA
description: FIDEL AND RELIGION Castro Talks on Revolution and Religion With Frei Betto. Translated by The Cuban Center for Translation and Interpretation. Introduction by Harvey Cox. 314 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $19.95. LIBERATION THEOLOGY Essential Facts About the Revolutionary Movement in Latin America - and Beyond. By Phillip Berryman. 231 pp. Philadelphia: Temple University Press. Cloth, $24.95. Paper, $6.95.

title: WITHIN GARDEN BORDER, THE SEXES BATTLE ON
description: IN the beds and borders of a garden, men and women meet as equals. Eager for blooms and merciless on bugs, both appreciate the efforts of the other. But a few aspects of the art appear to be rooted to gender.

title: In Poland, Pope Praises Solidarity
description: Pope John Paul II surprised the authorities and delighted many of his countrymen last week by extolling pluralism, free association and human rights in Poland. On his third visit to his homeland as Pope, he mixed Gospel citations with references to the outlawed Solidarity movement, met privately with Lech Walesa, the movement's founder, and visited a Solidarity monument to 40 shipyard workers killed by soldiers in the 1970 food riots.

title: INTERFAITH CHAPELS IN DEMAND
description: WHERE shall the wedding be held? When the bride and bridegroom are of differing faiths, that can be a difficult question to answer.

title: BLACKS IN THE ARTS: EVALUATING RECENT SUCCESS
description: Blacks have scored a number of notable successes in the performing and dramatic arts in recent weeks and months, prompting discussion in artistic, academic and other circles of a question: Do those triumphs reflect real advances for blacks in American culture and society as a whole?

title: IRANIAN DENIES CHINA IS A SOURCE OF WEAPONS
description: Iran's Foreign Minister forcefully denied today that his country had received any weapons from China, including antiship missiles, and he warned both the United States and the Soviet Union to stay out of the Persian Gulf.

title: CONNORS ADVANCES
description: Jimmy Connors, who has won 105 Grand Prix tournaments but none since October 1984, swept into the final of the $300,000 Stella Artois grass-court championships today. He beat Pat Cash, 7-6, 6-4, with a scintillating display of counter-attacking tennis on one of his favorite courts.

title: POSTINGS: Royalton Renaissance; Joining the Elite
description: The old Royalton Hotel, with its dingy facade, had never commanded much attention on 44th Street between Fifth Avenue and Avenue of the Americas, a block noted for its illustrious institutions. But with a $40 million renovation under the tutelage of some of Manhattan's more up-to-date practitioners of design, the new Royalton, when it is finished next year, might just show up its important neighbors.

title: Comings and Goings
description: WARREN CROMARTIE, the former Montreal Expo star who has been playing for the Yomiuri Giants in Japan, was suspended by the league for seven games after he charged out to the mound and punched a pitcher who had hit him with a ball in a game on Thursday. . .. Tatu, the Brazilian-born Dallas Sidekick forward who tosses his shirt into the stands every time he scores a goal, was named the Major Indoor Soccer League's most valuable player for the 1986-87 season after he led the league with 111 points on 38 assists and 73 lost shirts. . . . Kevin Williams and Dale Ellis, the Seattle Supersonics players who were arrested after a scuffle in a Houston nightclub in May, were scheduled for arraignment July 1. The proceedings, originally set for tomorrow, were postponed without explanation. . . . The Green Bay Packers said they are trying to sign Ron Jaworski, and a team official says the former Philadelphia Eagles quarterback has responded to the team's initial offer with his own proposal.

title: STATE ACTS TO EASE BURDENS OF AGING
description: LEAD: FACING a growing elderly population, Connecticut officials have begun to act to ease the burden on both the state and private citizens of paying for nursing home care.

title: MARC TABAH, MIMI DALBEY ARE MARRIED
description: The marriage of Marie Overton Dalbey, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. R. Thomas Dalbey of Denver, to Marc Tabah, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Tabah of Demarest, N.J., and Cabris, France, took place yesterday at the Prince of Peace Chapel in Aspen, Colo. The Rev. Hays H. Rockwell, rector of St. James' Episcopal Church in New York, performed the ceremony.

title: A Building Long Past Its Prime On a Choice Site for Offices
description: A slaughterhouse does not exactly fit in with the contemporary image of New York as a center of finance and communication. Thus it is no surprise that the vacant New York Butchers' Dressed Meat Company building, on the west side of Eleventh Avenue, from 39th to 40th Streets, is scheduled for demolition by the city, eager to capitalize on the growing building boom in midtown west.

title: FOR MANHATTAN COURIERS, BRAKELESS BIKES ARE THE WAY TO GO
description: Bicycle messengers, the speeding bane of New York's pedestrians and motorists, have a new weapon - the brakeless bicycle.

title: DRAWING ROOM COMEDY WITH A 1930'S LOOK
description: THE Penguin Repertory Company, which can be counted on for presenting offbeat or strictly new plays, is putting on, of all things, a 1930's-style drawing-room comedy.

title: CARLA MCDONALD MARRIES
description: At the Holy Trinity Roman Catholic Church in Washington yesterday, Carla Maria McDonald, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Daniel F. McDonald of McLean, Va., was married to Gregory Thomas Everts, a son of Dr. and Mrs. James A. Everts of Madison, Wis. The Rev. Maurice Monette performed the cermony.

title: WHAT BECOMES A LANDMARK? FOUNDATION TO GIVE PLAQUES
description: New York City landmarks have everything from neo-classical acanthus leaves to Art Deco zigzags. What most of them are missing is any sign that they are, indeed, landmarks.

title: RETAILERS RUSH TO THE MINISKIRT
description: RETAILERS' memories might be called ''longuette.'' That term was coined to describe the mid-calf (and longer) skirts that designers and retailers banked on almost exclusively in the fall of 1970. At the time, the fashion was described as the most heavily promoted in history; it was hard to find anything else.

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: LEAD: THE Legislature is considering amendments to the Environmental Cleanup Responsibility Act (ECRA) that would either make it more effective or merely tinker with a hopelessly failed program, depending on one's view of that controversial statute.

title: U.S. Seeks Control Of the Teamsters
description: The International Brotherhood of Teamsters is so corrupt that the Government is preparing a lawsuit aimed at taking control of the union, the Justice Department said last week.

title: WHO SPEAKES FOR TENNANTS AND OWNERS?
description: IN just over a week, the annual showdown between New York City landlords and tenants will reach its rowdy and often rancourous climax.

title: Park Slope
description: To the Editor:

title: One Man's Mousetrap
description: If only one in 100 patented inventions makes its inventor any money and he must then split the royalties with his lawyer, this explains why so few bright young Americans want to be inventors - and why so many are lawyers. MICHAEL TAGLIERI Brooklyn

title: A Mother's Memory Book

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: A SHADOW IN THE WEAVE. By Michael Humfrey. (Overlook, $15.95.) It wouldn't be a surprise to find this novel on the shelf of some Caribbean great house transformed into an inn, perhaps written in the 1960's when the islands were waking from the long colonial nightmare. Though the book is about miscegenation, it is also an allegory of the struggle between good and evil and the choice human beings have between the two. A young, white, convent-educated woman of planter stock and a black engineer hired to work on the family estate fall in love on the fictional island of San Sebastian at a time, shortly after World War I, when the outcome is bound to be harrowing. Michael Humfrey, who was born in Grenada and now lives in England, is slow to start his story; the device of discovered diaries and the elegiac tone of the narrator, the heroine's nephew, don't help. But the mood is a foil for the book's extensive descriptions of nature. (The author, an authority on marine mollusks, has written a standard guide to seashells of the West Indies.) This paradise, with the idealized couple a kind of Adam and Eve Crusoe in exile on a pristine islet that could be one of the Grenadines, is subtly contrasted with the hellish racism of the colonials on the main island and later, during World War II, with the cynicism of German submarine crews who, sometimes fatally, disrupt the lives of the poor fishermen. That Victoria at last ignores her convent teachings - ''We must forgive them'' - and fights actively against the evil around her seems also to be a message the author somewhat didactically is trying to convey.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: BREAD AND CIRCUS. By Morris Renek. (Weidenfeld & Nicolson, $18.95.) This historical novel is like New York City itself. So many characters do so much so fast that one is seldom entirely sure of what is going on. Historic fact suggests that the hero, William M. (Boss) Tweed, must come a cropper at the end, but in the meantime one is carried along by the energy of this tale of 19th-century power and lust and by the enchantment of the author's gift for the metaphor juste. We meet the behemoth Tweed at table over a plate of empty oyster shells as he wipes his lips with ''a small flag of a Delmonico's linen napkin'' while savoring thoughts of the battle ahead. The Fifth Avenue crowd, led by the fastidious white-clad Samuel Tilden, whom Tweed has served, now plans to dump the popular patronage-wielding Tweed so as to push reform and beat back the menace of the growing Republican Party. Once joined, their battle lasts a decade, encompassing the carnage of the 1863 Draft Riots, Tweed's affair with the fictive Augusta Cordell and cartoons drawn by that relentless crusader Thomas Nast. Augusta expresses her needs in the language of ''The Playboy Advisor,'' and other characters speak in maxims such as, ''Innocence is useless . . . yet to live without it is to live without the sun.'' In sketching Nast, Mr. Renek, the author of ''The Big Hello'' and other novels, manifests his gift for verbal portraiture, but his best character is New York City itself, so young that 42d Street is lined with desirable mansions and Throgs Neck is a vista of fertile wetlands and aquatic birds. In the top hat and spittoon world of ''Bread and Circus,'' the city is, as ever, corrupt, chaotic and paradoxical.

description: If blacks used to go to the ball park but no longer do, it would be well to document when the drop-off began and attempt to correlate that with some other feature. My intuition recommends that the urbanization of blacks might have a hand in this. Basketball is a game that can be played one-on-one. Touch football can be played in the street two-on-two. But it is difficult ever to play baseball with less than five-on-five. Basketball starts its talent in the schoolyard, an urban environment. Baseball starts its talent in Little League, an organized suburban and small-town endeavor. Might these things have something to do with who gets caught up in the mythos of what game? AVRAM I. REISNER Teaneck, N.J.

title: PRESSURE IS ON TO MASS MAIL AIDS REPORT
description: LEAD: MANY Connecticut households might soon be getting the Surgeon General's report on AIDS, whether they want the report or not. It has already been mailed out to all of Greenwich, several members of Congress are considering sending it to all of their constituents, and the General Assembly has passed a measure to cover the costs of local mass mailings of the report.

title: DUKAKIS TAKING A COOL AND PRAGMATIC APPROACH TO DEMOCRATIC NOMINATION
description: He once climbed the Acropolis in wing-tip shoes. He switched from Thomas's English muffins to Wonder Bread English muffins, gleefully explaining to friends that ''they taste better because they cost less.''

title: WITH VAN HAMEL AND MCKENZIE
description: ''LA SYLPHIDE'' possessed the proper mystery and gentle melancholy when it was danced by American Ballet Theater Thursday night at the Metropolitan Opera House. The performance, headed by Martine van Hamel and Kevin McKenzie, made clear why this work is considered one of the masterpieces of the Romantic era of ballet.

title: Bakkers Are Reported Ready To Relinquish PTL Residence
description: A spokesman for the fallen television evangelist Jim Bakker said today that Mr. Bakker and his family will move out of a home owned by the PTL ministry.

title: ELIZABETH STRAUSS, AN ARTIST, IS WED
description: Elizabeth Lois Strauss and Richard Mark Grossi were married yesterday at the home of the bride's father, Dr. Julian Max Strauss, in Amenia, N.Y. The Rev. Terrence W. Ryan, a Congregational minister, performed the ceremony.

title: CONSERVTIVES SEEK INQUIRY ON LEFTIST FUNDS
description: Two conservative groups are urging Congress to investigate left-wing fund raising as vigorously as the private conservative organizations under investigation in the Iran-contra affair.

title:
SPORTS OF THE TIMES;
THE ODD COUPLE
description: LEAD: IT was February 1968, and Martin Luther King and Robert Kennedy had not been shot yet and the Chicago convention and the Nixon election had not happened yet.

title: A Mother's Memory Book
description: When I finished reading Joan Gage's article ''My Mother's Mystery'' (May 17), I had tears on my cheeks. I was moved and intrigued by this intimate journey through one woman's scrapbook, and I wish to thank Joan Gage for sharing it with me on a Sunday morning. ELIZABETH HESS CHARDIET New Haven

title: HEALTH AIDES IN SHORT SUPPLY
description: LEAD: ON weekends, Ted La Rocque of Greenlawn takes care of all daily needs for himself and Grace, his wife of 54 years. Weekdays, two home health aides attend to Mrs. La Rocque, who lost the use of her left leg and arm after two strokes in the last five years. The aides provide six hours of care a day.

title:
BUSINESS FORUM: THREAT TO THE FINANCIAL MARKETS;
Shaking Off a 1930's Habit of Thought
description: LEAD: SHAKEN by recent breakdowns in outdated trading systems and challenged by relentless technological advances, the nation's financial markets are considering steps needed to keep them competitive in global finance into the next century. The danger, though, is that the exchanges will settle for Band-aids when major changes are needed.

title: BONN OPPOSITION LEADER BACKS A MISSLE BAN
description: The designated leader of West Germany's opposition Social Democratic Party, Hans-Jochen Vogel, called today for the removal of West Germany's 72 Pershing 1A missiles and the creation of a nuclear-free corridor in central Europe. His call came a day after the Western allies had approved a plan to ban short-range nuclear missiles in Europe.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Westerly, R.I.;
A Schoolhouse Goes Condo
description: LEAD: FOR more than six years the High Street Elementary School here was vacant, a target for vandals and an eyesore for this community of 20,000 people on the Connecticut border.

title: Uncertainty on Horizon as Italians Vote Today
description: Italians will vote Sunday in a parliamentary election that many people predict will open a period of uncertainty and shifting coalitions after almost four years of stability under the Socialist-led Government of Bettino Craxi.

description: To the Editor:
