title: Reagan Officials To Extend Reach Of AIDS Testing
description: To the dismay of those who fear that any mandatory testing might be a precedent for civil-rights abuses, the Reagan Administration described last week the details of its plan to screen Federal prisoners and aspiring immigrants for evidence of infection with the AIDS virus. While the announcement had been expected, Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d alarmed some civil libertarians by suggesting that a positive AIDS test might be considered a possible ground for the denial of parole.

title: The Tanning Confusion
description: The article on the dangers of tanning delivers a contradictory message (''A Place in the Sun,'' by Linda Wells, May 17). The text warns against the dangers of exposure to the sun and recommends appropriate precautions. However, the pictures accompanying the article display well-tanned models in stylish swimsuits. What are we to conclude? PHYLLIS SNYDER Merion, Pa.

description: Some old friends are back on the home screen this week after a long absence.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: CONTINUO: A Life in Music. By Robert Starer. (Random House, $16.95.) The composer Robert Starer has written an autobiography of a remarkable sort. He reveals himself almost entirely through stories about people who have passed through his life, among them the dancer Martha Graham, the conductor William Steinberg and the composer Joseph Tal. The stories, graced by a writer's skill for finding the telling detail, are fleshed out with perceptive thoughts about the business of composition. But at heart, the book is much more interesting for what it says about people than about music. The author emerges as a person one would very much want to meet - modest, honest, self-critical. Born in Vienna, Mr. Starer was forced to leave at the age of 14 when the Nazis moved into Austria. He was sent unaccompanied by his parents to Jerusalem and did not see his mother again. On his own in Palestine, he came under the influence of the imposing Mr. Tal, and also met the stately tenor Hermann Jadlowker, the man whom years earlier Kaiser Wilhelm had called ''my Lohengrin.'' The author's American career began with a stint as a Juilliard student and has included work for Broadway, television and dance, in addition to his compositions for the concert and opera stages. Throughout ''Continuo,'' Mr. Starer writes in lean, graceful prose, buoyed by an evident optimism. ''I have moved from an old, decaying civilization to a young, powerful one, having touched others in between,'' he concludes. His wanderings make for an amusing and engaging book.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of a transcription error, a story last week on earth sciences weekends for Pleasantville High School students incorrectly quoted Dorna Schroeter, director of the Madden Outdoor Education Center in Kent Cliffs, Putnam County. Miss Schroeter said: ''The reason we may not have as much of a problem with acid rain here as compared to the Adironacks is because we have a lot of limestone deposits in the Taconic region, and limestone acts as a neutralizer, bringing down the level of acidity.''

description: WHEN the Board of Education in Paterson, N.J., adopted a dress code for 1,800 public school teachers, it hoped to instill discipline in the ranks and enhance the teachers' influence as role models. The immediate effect was dissension.

description: Ninety days into an investigation that is supposed to last a year, Governor Cuomo's Task Force on Bias-Related Violence has issued two modest but useful recommendations.

description: In percent

title: WHATS NEW IN THE HEARING BUSINESS
description: EVERY year, about two million people join the ranks of the hearing-impaired, a group that now totals about 20 million adults. Yet only 3.9 million use hearing aids. ''That's an awful lot of people asking 'What's that you said?' and 'Pardon me,' '' said Cynthia Compton, an audiologist at Gallaudet University in Washington, D.C.

title: SHULTZ ARRIVES IN THE PHILIPPINES BEARING PRAISE BUT NO ADDED AID
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz arrived here today bearing expressions of good will but no financial aid bonuses for the Government of President Corazon C. Aquino.

title: Where Are The Black Fans?
description: Part of Brent Staples's evidence that black ballplayers are discriminated against is the fact that they are disproportionately found in outfield positions.

title: FREE SUMMER RACES HELP STATE'S HORSE-BREEDING DRIVE
description: LEAD: NEW JERSEY'S drive to increase its role as a breeding center for standardbred horses has created a boon for those who want to watch trotters and pacers race, but without the lure of $2 windows and other parimutuel machines.

title: TIBET'S BUDDHIST MONKS ENDURE TO REBUILD A PART OF THE PAST
description: THE brick shells of scores of buildings cling to the steep mountain slopes here, 30 miles east of Lhasa, the Tibetan capital. Once the holiest monastery of the Gelukpa sect of Tibetan Buddhism, the temples were dynamited by the Chinese in the 1960's to extirpate religion from Tibet, both in retaliation for an armed uprising in 1959 and as part of the leftist hysteria of the Cultural Revolution. Today 300 monks are slowly rebuilding, determined to recreate the grandeur of the 15th-century monastery. In doing this, they are also erecting a monument to Tibetan resistance to Chinese rule.

title: Ethics Don't Start in Business Schools
description: As dean of a leading business school, I am barraged with questions about what I am going to do to improve business ethics. The questions are usually accompanied by a strong undercurrent of accusation that business schools are responsible for the bad ethics of corporate America.

title: COMMENTS BY POPE IRK POLISH PARTY
description: A delegation of senior Communist Party officials sped to Poland's holiest shrine early this morning to tell Vatican officials they were distressed by the Pope's speeches praising Solidarity, according to a member of the Pope's entourage.

title: Panel Issues a Report On Teen-Age Suicide
description: A New York State task force studying teen-age suicide has made a number of recommendations to Governor Cuomo on ways to prevent teen-age suicides, including the creation of a statewide clearinghouse to maintain data on teen-age suicides and information on suicide prevention.

title: Melissa Jo Pruyn Becomes a Bride

The Rev. Frederick Boswell performed the ceremony at St. James Episcopal Church in Montclair.

description: ONCE considered a premier commercial location in Stamford, Summer Street lost its cachet as the city matured and large buildings rose closer to Interstate 95. As a result its vacancy rate is high.

description: POURING your own concrete walk or patio is a lot of work, but it is one project that an economy-minded do-it-yourselfer can safely tackle. It requires no unusual skills or expensive equipment (a mixer can be rented if need be), and by doing the work himself the homeowner can save more than half the cost of a professional contractor.

For the smart seller, this may mean an opportunity to get the best price.

title: NUISANCE INSECTS AND THEIR CONTROLS
description: COOL, moist weather has been a mixed blessing for gardeners. While many report that this has been one of the loveliest seasons in remembrance, others say they never seen so many bugs. Both are right. Blossoms have flourished, but so have the bugs. Pests multiply easily in this sort of favorable weather. Here are some of the most active insect pests that gardeners are likely to encounter and practical measures to control them.

description: A drive north from San Francisco, past the apple orchards of Sebastopol and the spindly resort homes along the Russian River, suddenly brings you out to the Sonoma coast, where rounded hills drop with striking severity to the sea. On sunny days, which alternate with spells of storm and fog in the summer, the sky maintains a blue stillness, and on the hills sheep graze almost without moving.

description: DURING months of comparison shopping for a company that intends to transfer 2,000 back-office employees from Manhattan, Philip R. Sprayregen has seen New Jersey office developers beat their competitors in Brooklyn.

Biden Jr. of Delaware last week formally announced his candidacy for the Democratic Presidential nomination. ''We must rekindle the fire of idealism,'' he said, emphasizing that ''this generation of Americans'' -meaning those who barely remember or were born after World War II - has special responsibility for this mission.

Morse of New York, were married yesterday at the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club in Oyster Bay, L.I. Village Justice John F. Johnston 2d of Matinecock, L.I., officiated.

title:
TELEVISION;
ROAMING AMERICA'S BYWAYS: A QUIET JOY

title: POINTS OF VIEW
description: WOODED PROPERTY IS A RARE COMMODITY ON the eastern end of Long Island, where life tends to center around the dunes, beaches and water. In this extremely overbuilt area, available land is usually a sliver amounting to far less than an acre sneaked between two existing houses on an already densely populated street. Determined to scour the area for an undiscovered place on which to build her dream house, Ronne Fisher, an architect who until recently headed the interior-design department at Robert A. M. Stern's office, happened on four untouched acres in East Hampton. Working with her former boss, the two architects surveyed the site to see what views they would have were they to build. Much to their delight, a sweeping expanse of ocean and beach was visible on the horizon. ''Helping to choose a site is a rare privilege,'' says Stern. ''It immediately helps formulate ideas.''

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: A DISPLAY OF WYETHS A. N. Wyeth, the 38-year-old nephew of the painter Andrew Wyeth, will attend the opening reception for his exhibition of watercolors from 2 to 5 P.M. today at the Lyman Allyn Museum in New London. Mr. Wyeth's work will be on display until July 12, accompanied by one painting from each of his artist-relatives.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LEAD: STANDING ORDERS. By John Hooker. (Sifton/Viking, $17.95.) Like many ambitious novels, ''Standing Orders'' suffers from trying to say too much. At its most compelling, John Hooker's story is about the price one pays for trespassing, told through the eyes of David Andersen, an Australian who fights for the United Nations forces during the Korean War.

title: THE EVOLVING NEIGHBORHOODS OF PARK HILL
description: LEAD: FROM the Old World cafes at the foot of the hill to the turreted, Victorian homes on the crest, the Park Hill section of Yonkers encompasses two distinct and changing neighborhoods.

title: ON THE WAY TO THE DEDICATION OF A GARDEN - LITTER AND GRAFITI
description: SPRING is always too rushed for the plain dirt gardener, and this spring seemed somehow more hectic than most. The unusually warm March, followed by a cold, rainy April, had rushed the spring bulbs so that their display was nice but over far too quickly, and most of nature seemed somehow out of synch. How good it was then to finally have some truly glorious May weather, as I wended my way south toward the Botanical Garden in the Bronx, to attend the dedication of the Memorial Rock Garden to its creator, the late T. H. Everett.

title: Britain Fashions a Virtual Coronet for Thatcher
description: IT turned out the voters, if not the gods, must have heard her the first time when, in a moment of what one commentator called ''casually megalomaniacal'' candor, Margaret Thatcher confessed she hoped to go ''on and on'' toward a fourth and fifth term as Prime Minister, rounding the century with the momentum of Queen Victoria.

title: ESTIMATE BOARD AVOIDS A PARLEY
description: Negotiations over the city budget virtually ground to a halt yesterday when most of the members of the Board of Estimate decided to stay away from City Hall.

title: TARTS AND MORE TARTS, MAKE USE OF SUMMER'S FIRST STONE FRUITS
description: SUMMER has definitely begun now that the first stone fruits have arrived. Apricots, plumbs, nectarines and peaches make wonderful cooked desserts. Best of all, in my opinion, are tarts in which the fruit is served lightly cooked, attractively arranged on the shell and coated with a light glaze.

title: Americans Get Education on Soviet Students
description: Soviet high school students are more serious, do more homework and have a stronger national pride than their American counterparts, according to members of the first group of American high school students to study in Soviet secondary schools.

title: STRANGERS BECOME FRIENDS IN TRAVEL
description: LEAD: ON July 9, 22 Hartford-area residents are to become ''ambassadors'' for America, flying to Bristol, England, to stay in the homes of strangers. A week later, another group from the area will become guests in Ipswich, Australia.

title: Bond Yields Lowest in Weeks
description: Bond yields have fallen to the lowest levels since late April, helping revive hopes that the recent jump in rates was an aberration.

Isaac of Flushing, Queens. Rabbi Elazar Cohen, a great-uncle of the bridegroom, performed the ceremony at the Sheraton Stamford Hotel and Towers.

Grant, rallying support for the troubled President Andrew Johnson after peace came at Appomattox, and Victoria Woodhull, feminist and free-love advocate, giving her lecture a selling title - ''The Naked Truth.''

description: In the trial of Bernhard H. Goetz, the prosecution and defense lawyers have battled for the last seven weeks over some of the most intricate and misunderstood laws covering how and when a citizen may shoot another in self-defense.

title: A STAR OF STAGE AND FILM
description: Geraldine Page, dedicated to acting for more than four decades and long identified with the work of Tennessee Williams, died of a heart attack Saturday at her home in the Chelsea section of Manhattan. Both a Broadway star and an Academy Award winner, she was 62 years old.

title: MARRIAGE IS STILL POPULAR
description: A statistical portrait of the attitudes of American families shows that Americans have an enduring preference for marriage despite the nation's high divorce rate. A majority of couples also said they believe in sharing home and child-care responsibilities, and an unprecedented number are doing so in marriages where both spouses work.

title: CITY BALLET: 'SWAN LAKE,' WITH MARIA CALEGARI
description: THE New York City Ballet took off in a blaze of scorching passion and ended on a cool, sweet note in a performance Wednesday at the New York State Theater. The passion was provided by Maria Calegari, dancing the role of Odette in George Balanchine's ''Swan Lake.''

Wurzburger, assisted by Rabbi Maurice Schwartz, the bridegroom's father.

title: Carter-Wallace to Vote
description: Carter-Wallace Inc., a maker of personal consumer products and drugs, said that it would ask shareholders to approve an increase in shares and a new issue at its annual stockholders meeting next month. The company, whose stock trades on the New York Stock Exchange, said the new series of common stock would be ''subject to significant restrictions on transferability.'' If approved, one share of the new stock will be provided as a dividend for each share of common stock outstanding. Carter-Wallace is also seeking to increase its existing common shares from 10 million to 30 million.

description: New York State is proposing to remove all state barriers restricting the movement and sale of milk throughout the Northeastern states in a move it says will help dairy farmers, milk dealers and the public.

description: It wasn't the time for humor, but remembering the obstacles they faced and nearly overcame this season made it easier for the Celtics to smile today.

title: G.E.'s $250 Million Pact
description: Alitalia, the Italian airline, has placed a $250 million order with the General Electric Company to make engines for its new jets, the company said today. Jack Batty, a G.E. spokesman, said that Alitalia ordered six engines and had taken options on four more. If it buys all 10 engines, the order will be valued at more than $250 million, he said. Mr. Batty said that the engines would be used for Alitalia's new MD-11 jets made by the McDonnell Douglas Corporation. He said the engines would be made at G.E.'s plant in Evandale, Ohio.

title: COLORADO IS SPLIT ON NEW AIDS LAW
description: A controversy has developed over a new state law requiring doctors and some other health professionals to disclose the names of patients with the AIDS virus to the Colorado Department of Health.

description: b-Includes tax credits of $99,000 and $222,500 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Includes tax credits of $286,000 for the quarter and $465,000 for the 6 months.

title: In Favor of Naps
description: Is there room in the Senate schedule for nap time? Senator Christopher J. Dodd, Democrat of Connecticut, presiding last week over a committee hearing on child care, listened to a teacher describe a typical day's routine for her preschool-age charges.

title: CONGRESS DEBATES LAW LIMITING LIABILITY IN NUCLEAR ACCIDENTS
description: A law that limits the amount the nuclear industry would have to pay after a reactor accident, no matter how great the damage to public health or property, is under sharp debate here as it comes up for renewal in the shadow of the Soviet nuclear disaster last year at Chernobyl.

title: Contra Chief Explains Checks
description: Adolfo Calero, the Nicaraguan rebel leader, has said that he provided $2,500 in traveler's checks directly to a rebel supporter who has represented himself to Congress as a Roman Catholic priest.

title: MORE AND MORE, HOUSE RACES AREN'T RACES BUT RUNAWAYS
description: Competition for seats in the House of Representatives, once a spirited feature of American politics, has declined so much that in the last two elections, seven out of eight House races were won by majorities that approached or surpassed landslides.

title: Private Talks Cited
description: Ford confirmed today reports that it is planning to cut back its already reduced investment in South Africa but that it was not prepared to sever all links with the country.

description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

description: To the Editor:

title: Reagan and the Democrats Redux
description: Politicians, like generals, tend to fight the last war over again. So President Reagan's themes and arguments in the weeks ahead - and the Democrats' responses to him - are likely to sound very familiar.

title: STARK VILLAGE JUSTICE: MUST THE LOVERS BE FLOGGED?
description: Disgraced and threatened with public whipping, the lovers have turned against each other, and their stories, told in sullen monotones, are now at odds.

title: More Straight Talk for NATO
description: Listen to NATO officials for five minutes and hear the phrase: ''The slippery slope to denuclearization.'' It signals a case of European jitters about nuclear weapons and arms control. The West has finally reached agreement on banning medium- and short-range missiles from Europe. But European jitters remain. They demand an honest response from Washington, and from Western European leaders themselves.

title: NUCLEAR PLANT SHUTS DOWN
description: The Millstone 3 nuclear power plant automatically shut down early today after a routine test of its steam turbine, Northeast Utilities said. ''We were going the steam turbine weekly check and when operators tried to go back from manual operation into automatic operation, the plant shut down,'' a spokesman, Anthony E. Nericcio, said. He said no radioactivity was released in the incident at about 3:45 A.M.. The cause is being investigated.

title: THE STAGE 'CLAPTRAP'
description: INTENDED as a spoof of ''Deathtrap,'' ''Claptrap'' succeeds in living up to - or, rather, down to - its title. Opening last night, the play concludes the season at the Manhattan Theater Club on a note of ineptitude and desperation. The ineptitude belongs to the author, Ken Friedman, the desperation to the director, David Trainer, and to his actors, especially Nathan Lane, who has the unenviable assignment of trying to pump air into a flat tire.

title: Advertising; People
description: * K. Jane Brite has been promoted to executive vice president, and Geraldine M. Donini to senior vice president at Young & Rubicam, New York.

title: College of Staten Island
description: The Soviet Union should immediately withdraw from Afghanistan and reach agreement with the United States to cut strategic nuclear weapons by 50 percent, Andrei Sakharov said in a message broadcast yesterday to graduates of the College of Staten Island.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article on Wednesday about antitrust charges against three waste haulers in Los Angeles incorrectly characterized the filing of the charges. They were made in a criminal complaint by the Los Angeles County District Attorney, not in an indictment.

title: AIR QUALITY WON'T MEET STANDARDS
description: Instead of meeting national standards for air quality by year's end or facing tough sanctions, New York City may spend several more years - perhaps the rest of the century -with ozone and carbon monoxide levels above Federal levels, according to government officials.

title: Investors Look to Auctions of Notes
description: Today's regular weekly auctions of three- and six-month bills are the only Treasury sales scheduled for this week. Traders and investors are looking ahead to next week, when the Treasury is expected to auction notes with maturities in two, four and seven years.

title: Columbia Gas May Buy Unit
description: The Columbia Gas System Inc. has disclosed that it is negotiating to acquire an unidentified natural gas company, believed to be a small gas-distribution concern, for an estimated $200 million. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Columbia said that the negotiations ''were recently reinstituted, but no agreement has been reached.''

title: PRESYTERIAN PAPER HIGHLIGHTS MERGER
description: The complexity of Christian-Jewish relations and the difficulty of reconciling tensions within a reunited Protestant denomination have been underscored here at the annual convention of the nation's largest Presbyterian church.

title: IN U.S., COURTING AFFLUENT CUSTOMERS

Its manufacturing plants in Asia, Europe and the United States have been turning out high-quality products and selling them at attractive prices. Its cars have won praise for their design and its dealerships have been hailed for the service they provide.

title: Dr. Radomisli Weds
description: Dr. Aylin Radomisli, a psychiatrist and an assistant clinical professor at the Cornell University Medical College, was married yesterday to Joseph Cates, a television producer and director. Rabbi Jack Stern performed the ceremony at the Carlyle Hotel in New York. The bride is a daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Cemal de Vrimel of Istanbul, Turkey. Her three previous marriages ended in divorce, as did the bridegroom's two previous marriages. He is a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Nathan Cates of New York.

description: The Chilean Government has indicated that it will reject a United States demand to turn over two former top intelligence officials accused in the Letelier murder case.

title: Valid Logic, Sun Sign Deal

title: Tire Fire Is Finally Out
description: A spectacular fire amid two million cast-off tires was finally extinguished Saturday when bulldozers finished burying them in about three feet of dirt. The fire broke out Tuesday night when lightning struck a private salvage yard known as Tire Mountain, south of Platteville and about 40 miles north of Denver.

description: Freeman McNeil, perspiring after a recent Jets' off-season workout program, took a soda someone offered him and said, ''Grazie.''

title: Robin Roger Marries Roger Goodspeed
description: Robin Roger, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ronald Roger of Beachwood, Ohio, and Ashville, N.Y., and Roger Campbell Goodspeed, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Norwick Royall Givens Goodspeed of Fairfield, Conn., were married yesterday. Judge John F. Keenan of the Federal District Court for the Southern District of New York performed the ceremony in Manhattan at the penthouse and roof garden of Douglas Watts Catering.

title: BEING DEAN OF THE DIPLOMATS
description: It was a small but delicate problem, one befitting the attention of a diplomat.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The Pope did more than any of us could expect. He made every gesture count.'' - Maciej Jankowski, an organizer in Warsawfor Solidarity. A6:6.

title: Pit Bull Kills California Boy
description: A 2 1/2-year-old boy died today of injuries suffered when he was mauled by a pit bull Saturday night, and the dog's owner was booked for investigation of murder. The youngster, James Soto, suffered deep wounds on the head and the shoulders. Michael Patrick Berry, 37, was arrested as the owner of the dog, which the police said appeared ''to have been trained as a fighting dog and also to protect Berry's 200 marijuana plants.''

title: GARY PLAYER TAKES SENIORS
description: Gary Player birdied the last hole today for a final-round 69 and a one-stroke victory over Chi Chi Rodriguez and Bruce Crampton in the Senior Tournament Players Championship.

title: At Home, Cooking
description: THEY could have played this one the way some bicoastal friends play chess, putting each move on postcards.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Horse Racing Peggy's Dream Wins: After two unsuccessful forays into open company, Peggy's Dream returned to state-bred competition and raced to a 2 1/4-length victory yesterday in the $73,100 Hyde Park Handicap for New York-bred fillies and mares 3 years old and up at Belmont Park. With 114 pounds and carrying Richard Migliore, Peggy's Dream lagged early, as usual, and then circled her nine rivals on the turn and into the stretch to win in hand. Lady Be Regal was runner-up, 2 3/4 lengths ahead of Chase the Dream. The victory was the fifth in 11 starts this year for the 3-year-old daughter of Sir Wimborne-Cousins Three. She went one mile on the fast track in a moderate 1:38 2/5 to earn $43,860 for Margaret Smyth and returned $5.40 for $2 to win as the favorite. Harness Racing Go Get Lost Finds Success: Before the $100,000 Statue of Liberty Trot got under way, John Hogan was worried that Go Get Lost may not have belonged in the star-studded international field. But halfway down the stretch, Hogan was suddenly thinking about winning. And once he hit the wire, Hogan not only knew the 3-year-old Go Get Lost belonged in the race, he also knew he was driving a favorite for the Hambletonian this summer. ''This is a real handy colt,'' said Hogan after Go Get Lost put on a strong stretch run to capture the Statue of Liberty Trot by a nose at the Meadowlands Saturday night. ''He can pretty much do anything, go to the front, come from behind.''

title: ROLE REVERSAL: ORIOLES END JAY'S STREAK
description: Ray Knight, Cal Ripken Jr. and Jim Dwyer hit home runs today as the Baltimore Orioles ended their 10-game losing streak and Toronto's club-record 11-game winning streak by beating the Blue Jays, 8-5.

title: Words and Rockets
description: ''What we have here is a failure to communicate.'' That line from the movie ''Cool Hand Luke'' could have been the theme of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration in the wake of a freak launching of three small rockets at a facility at Wallops Island, Va., last Tuesday.

title: VALUE OF COLLEGE ENDOWMENTS RISES
description: The market value of college endowments has risen dramatically in the last few years because of the robust performance of the stock market, partially offsetting the effects of cuts in Federal aid.

title: POPE SETS TERMS FOR ESTABLISHING DIPLOMATIC TIES WITH POLISH STATE
description: Pope John Paul II declared today that the Holy See could not establish diplomatic relations with the Polish Government until his local bishops were willing to pursue the struggle for political freedom and the Government did not interfere.

title: HUFFMAN KOOS reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Bridge: 'Encrypted Signal' Has Been An Advance for the Defense
description: One of the most ingenious thoughts in the area of defense in recent years was the ''encrypted signal.'' The defenders vary their signaling procedure according to a formula that is revealed to the declarer, but he cannot decode the signal because a key variable depends on some spot cards in the defenders' hands.

title: Business and the Law; U.S. Lawyers Head for Japan
description: AFTER more than 30 years, the United States has resumed exporting lawyers to Japan.

title: Williamsburgh Bank's Head
description: Martin F. Mertz has been named president and chief executive officer of the Williamsburgh Savings Bank. Mr. Mertz succeeds George Ulich, who will retire on June 30 after almost 46 years at the bank.

title: CHILDREN AND 2D WEDDINGS
description: HE had a teen-age son; she had two daughters in grade school.

title: INDEPENDENCE FOR UNITED WILL NOT END PROBLEMS
description: United Airlines will almost certainly emerge from the current takeover battle for the Allegis Corporation as an independent company. The odds are just as great that the airline will emerge much weakened.

title: Rebecca Moses, Designer, Is Bride of Louis Perlman
description: Rebecca Moses and Louis Perlman were married yesterday afternoon at the bridegroom's home in Sag Harbor, L.I., by Rabbis Arthur Schneier and Abraham I. Ziegelman. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Howard Moses of North Bergen, N.J. Mr. Perlman is a son of Susan Perlman of London and the late Henri Perlman.

title: Edelman Cuts Morse Stake
description: An investment group led by Asher B. Edelman has reduced its stake in Morse Shoe Inc., from 8.6 percent to just under 5 percent.

title: MAYORS, AT CONFERENCE, SEEK TO REASSERT INFLUENCE
description: Eager to reassert their influence in the post-Reagan era, more than 200 mayors are meeting here for the 55th Annual Conference of Mayors to talk about urban policy and scrutinze eight candidates in the 1988 Presidential race.

title: BRANDT ENDS LEADERSHIP OF SOCIALISTS
description: Willy Brandt, the former West German Chancellor and a Nobel laureate, formally stepped aside today after more than 20 years as chairman of the Social Democratic Party.

title: VICTORY ESCAPES YANKEES AS RIGHETTI GETS ROCKED
description: When he walked to the mound to begin the ninth inning yesterday afternoon, Dave Righetti heard the familiar sounds that come with five seasons of productive pitching in the Bronx.

title: The Editorial Notebook; Would Women Govern Differently?: Norway's Answer: Probably, If Enough Came to Power
description: If Margaret Thatcher completes the new term she just won, she will have governed for 13 years; it's a notable win for any British prime minister, let alone a woman. Otherwise she follows a typical pattern. The few women who have become national leaders have done so in a world of men. Cory Aquino could ask ''What on earth do I know about being president?'' before taking over leadership of the Philippines. But for the most part, women have behaved no differently in office from men.

title: GIACOMIN MODESTY ENTERING HOCKEY HALL OF FAME
description: ''WHY am I going in the Hall of Fame?'' Eddie Giacomin wondered the other day.

title: Fourth Hit for Missile
description: A Trident 2 missile hit its target in the Atlantic Ocean several hundred miles south of here, in the fourth consecutive success for the test program, the Navy has reported. Officials said the 44-foot, three-stage missile hurled an instrumented dummy warhead to a floating target Friday afternoon. It was the fourth of 20 scheduled Trident 2 launchings from land. Five to 10 launchings from submarines will follow.

title: JOHNSON LEADS LAKERS TO 4th TITLE SINCE '80
description: One year after they were embarrassed, criticized and labeled as a team whose time had passed, the Los Angeles Lakers are once again champions of the National Basketball Association.

title: AMCOLE ENERGY CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income and after extraordinary gains from debt restructuring of $908,000 for the quarter and $1,181,701 for the 9 months.

title: New Era, No New Ideas
description: As prospects for a major Soviet-American agreement improve to the point of likelihood, it is evident that a new stage in East-West relations is already beginning. It probably won't be a repetition of detente.

title: LIMITS ON SUBSIDIES TO BIG FARMS GO AWRY, SENDING COSTS CLIMBING
description: Stringent new farm law provisions aimed at reducing Government subsidies to big farmers have backfired, officials say, by creating a new level of entrepreneurs whose techniques are driving the costs of the subsidies even higher.

title: LARGE CROWDS ANGER SEAPORT'S NEIGHBORS
description: Ten years ago, it was a serene slip of land in lower Manhattan where fish outnumbered people, warehouses crumbled quietly and visitors watched the sun rise over the abandoned piers.

title: ART: 'DOCUMENTA 8,' EXHIBITION IN WEST GERMANY
description: A provocative, polemical, sometimes oppressive art exhibition, the most important in Europe this year, opened here Friday. The exhibition, ''Documenta 8'' rejects such recent artistic developments as Neo-Expressionism, Neo-Geo and ''appropriation,'' and presents itself as an answer to the pluralism and irresolution of Post-Modernism. The show makes a case for art that is socially and politically engaged, but it is so rambling and uneven that it also makes a case against it.

title: GLOOMIER ECONOMIC OUTLOOK
description: The West's central bankers, in a gloomy economic report, say that the industrial countries would have a hard time reducing trade imbalances without disrupting financial markets, causing inflation in the United States or pushing the United States or other countries into recession.

title: Networks Will Carry Address by President
description: President Reagan's speech on the economic summit meeting, arms control and the Federal budget will be broadcast live at 8 P.M. tonight on the ABC, CBS and NBC television networks and on the Cable News Network. Some local affiliates of PBS and SIN, the Spanish International Network, will carry the address, either live or later on tape. In New York, Channel 13 will show a tape-delayed broadcast at midnight.

title: Waiting for the Docudrama
description: In a film docudrama to be shown years from now, a tall, beautiful woman granted total invulnerability will take her place at the witness table and defiantly face the grim-visaged Congressmen.

title: Market Place; Dayton Hudson Stock Run-Up
description: THE stock of the Dayton Hudson Corporation proved alive and kicking last week, providing fuel for the entire big-store retail group. But the Minneapolis-based Dayton Hudson paced the others, enjoying a run-up of $5 a share in the week.

title: PHOTRONIC LABORATORIES reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Includes pre-tax gains of $275,000 for the latest second quarter and $380,000 for the year-ago period from equipment sales.

title: THE POPE IN POLAND: A LIFT FOR SOLIDARITY'S SPIRIT
description: During his week in Poland, Pope John Paul II grew steadily bolder as he challenged the Government to prove its assertions of reform, pressed priests to identify with the aspirations of Solidarity, and urged society to persist in patient pursuit of liberty.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: Has a major-leaguer ever hit 50 or more home runs in a season and failed to drive in 100 runs that season?

title: MUSIC: CHARLES AZNAVOUR
description: CHARLES AZNAVOUR tackles disturbing subjects for a pop singer: mortality, divorce, infidelity, couples locked in battle. He's been perfecting an air of autumnal reflection at least since 1964, the year he wrote ''Yesterday.'' And Wednesday at Radio City Music Hall, the silver-haired, 63-year-old songwriter played his self-created roles - rueful observer, wronged party, victimizer, romantic - with artful casualness, sounding intimate even in the vast hall.

title: 'SCARED STRAIGHT!' ON 9, FOLLOWED BY A SEQUAL
description: ''SCARED STRAIGHT!'' was shown first in 1978; it returns on Channel 9 at 9 o'clock tonight. It will be followed at 10 P.M. by ''Scared Straight! 10 Years Later.'' Although it is only nine years later, the original one-hour documentary is still compelling, and the 30-minute follow-up is fascinating. Can youthful offenders be frightened into not breaking the law? ''Scared Straight!'' and its sequel suggest they can.

title: BECKER TOPS MAYOTTE TO GAIN LONDON FINAL AGAINST CONNORS
description: Boris Becker, finding his touch in a high-quality final set, beat Tim Mayotte of the United States by 4-6, 7-6, 6-4 today and reached the final of the Stella Artois grass-court championships at Queens Club. The match began Saturday, but the finish was postponed because of rain.

description: b-Net loss The company is listed on the Toronto and Vancouver stock exchanges. The results are in U.S. dollars.

title: Tennessee Educator to Quit
description: Edward J. Boling, president of the University of Tennessee, has announced that he will resign July 1, 1988, after almost 18 years as head of the university. Dr. Boling, who is 65 years old, will become president emeritus of the university and will serve as a professor, a spokesman for the university said Friday. The state university system has 40,000 students on campuses in Knoxville, Chattanooga and Martin, the Center for Health Sciences in Memphis and the Space Institute in Tullahoma.

title: Light Earthquakes Are Felt In Missouri and California
description: A light earthquake measuring 4.1 on the Richter scale rattled pictures on walls in southeast Missouri on Saturday, but no damage was immediately reported, the National Weather Service said.

title: REAGAN REPORT TO CONGRESS WILL ASSESS GULF PERIL
description: The Reagan Adminstration is expected to submit a report to Congress this week asserting that it can manage military threats to American naval forces assigned to protect Kuwaiti oil tankers in the Persian Gulf, Administration officials said today.

title: Bakkers Given Time to Move
description: PTL ministry officials said today that they would give the organization's former leader, Jim Bakker, a ''reasonable'' amount of time to vacate the $1.3 million waterfront home near here where they have remained largely secluded since last week.

description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $1,205,000 from tax loss carryforwards and prepayment of debt. c-After an extraordinary tax credit of $2,731,000. d-Net income e-Net loss Preferred dividends exceeded net income for the year-ago quarter. The year-earlier revenue includes $40,250,000 for the quarter and $93,445,000 for the 6 months from a divested subsidiary.

title: Fleck Reflects
description: When it happened, 32 years ago at The Olympic Club in San Francisco, it was as if a fog had rolled in off the ocean and obstructed everyone's vision: So strong was the image of Ben Hogan achieving his fifth United States Open victory that when Hogan was beaten, people couldn't see the winner through Olympic's thousands of trees.

description: * Boston Co., Boston, a financial services holding company, appointed Hans P. Ziegler executive vice president and head of the company's Individual Client Group.

description: The Ford Motor Company and a group headed by William E. Simon, the former Treasury Secretary, are among five bidders for the troubled Financial Corporation of America, an industry publication reported Friday.

description: In a move that has rocked France's prestigious jewelry trade, the French Government has accused two brothers, Jacques and Pierre Chaumet, of defrauding their customers and their bankers.

title: Joan K. Ballard Is Wed To Dr. Jonas Goldstone
description: The marriage of Joan Kaweske Ballard and Dr. Jonas M. Goldstone took place yesterday at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. John V. Kaweske, in Sussex, N.J. Rabbi Joel S. Goor officiated. The bride, a graduate of Fairleigh Dickinson University, is a nurse and the program manager of home-care services for the Suffolk County Social Services Department in Hauppauge, L.I. Her father and her mother, Madeline Kaweske, raise beef cattle in Sussex.

description: The Mitel Corporation, a major Canadian maker of telecommunications equipment, is looking for a new president and chief executive.

title: OUSTER IS SOUGHT AT U.N. FARM UNIT
description: The United States, Britain and several other nations, most of them Western, plan to open a campaign here this week to replace the head of the United Nations Food and Agricultural Organization, whom they accuse of mismanaging the organization and pursuing anti-Western policies, according to Western diplomats.

title: A BOEING OVERHAUL IN CANADA 888>
description: It takes a practiced eye to spot the changes under way at the de Havilland Aircraft Company of Canada, the commuter aircraft manufacturer whose sale to the Boeing Commercial Airplane Company provoked a political storm in Canada 18 months ago.

title: DARTMOUTH COLLEGE
description: Dartmouth College held its 217th commencement yesterday on Baker Library lawn of the campus in Hanover, N.H. Senator Bill Bradely, Democrat of New Jersey, delivered the commencement adress and received an honorary doctor of laws degree.

title: Inflation Dips in Britain
description: Britain's annual inflation rate declined by a tenth of a percentage point in May, to 4.1 percent, the Government said Friday. The slight fall from April to May was largely a result of cheaper mortgage rates, which offset increases in the prices of seasonal foods and motor vehicles, the Department of Employment said. The annual inflation rate reflects the percentage rise in the Government's retail price index over the previous 12 months. The index is a measure of the cost of consumer goods and services.

title: SIT-IN AT CHURCH IN SEOUL IS ENDED AMID NEW CLASHES
description: About 200 South Korean students ended their occupation of a Roman Catholic cathedral in central Seoul today in return for a guarantee that they could return to their campuses.

title: G.E. Seeks Japan Listing
description: The General Electric Company will apply soon to list its common stock on the Tokyo Stock Exchange, a company spokesman said Friday. The Nomura Securities Company and the Daiwa Securities Company have been chosen as G.E.'s sponsors, the spokesman said.

MAGNACARD INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net loss

title: COMPROMISE REACHED ON $22.8 BILLION CITY BUDGET
description: A compromise was reached early today on the city's $22.8 billion budget, ending a week of negotiations over whether the City Council and the Board of Estimate could add more than $150 million in new or enhanced programs.

title: Ex-I.B.M. 'Police Chief' A 'Wall St. Private Eye'
description: Joseph R. Rosetti, who was director of security for the International Business Machines Corporation, has signed on with Kroll Associates, a security concern that has been called ''Wall Street's private eye.''

title: DANCE: SIN CHA HONG
description: IN ''Matter of Fact,'' Sin Cha Hong has created a small, sometimes almost claustrophobic world. The dark and cavernous recess of La Mama Annex has been transformed into a room of sorts. Rain beats against screens at the back wall that serve as windows. But there is no furniture to speak of in this room, no doors to enter through. For Ms. Hong is once more involved in making myth or fable.

title: CAVENHAM, USA INC reports earnings for 12wks to March 28
description: b-Includes an extraordinary tax credit related to the utilization of a net operating loss carryforward of $2,903,000 for both the 12 weeks and 52 weeks.

title: Schmidt Smacks 3 Homers
description: Mike Schmidt, who enjoyed one of his greatest thrills ever at Olympic Stadium, produced one of his greatest games here today.

title: THE OPERA: ALBAN BERG'S 'WOZZECK,' IN VIENNA
description: The first and perhaps the more powerful of Alban Berg's two operas took on a new face at the Vienna Staatsoper tonight. This new production of ''Wozzeck'' - conducted by Claudio Abbado, sung by Hildegard Behrens and Franz Grundheber, and with the direction and staging by Adolf Dresen and Herbert Kapplmuller - has been awaited with interest and perhaps a touch of malicious apprehension by the city's opera lovers. Its scene changes and machinery are reportedly complicated enough to have thrown the house's performance and rehearsal schedules into some confusion, even to the point of a two-day public closure to shake out unresolved problems. Some here have been wondering if the effort is worth it, given the Staatsoper's existing and eminently respectable ''Wozzeck'' production by Oscar Fritz Schuh and Caspar Neher that will evidently now be retired.

title: A VERSATILE ACTRESS WITH FEW CHALLENGES
description: When Geraldine Page played Alma Winemiller in Jose Quintero's revival of ''Summer and Smoke'' in 1952, it seemed an exact meeting of actress, character and sensibility. Those who were fortunate enough to see her emerge in that play at Circle in the Square might have assumed that the loneliness and suppressed passion came directly from life. Yet seven years later, by creating the role of Alexandra del Lago in ''Sweet Bird of Youth,'' that of a formidable, sensual and ravaged movie star, she was playing the opposite end of the Tennessee Williams spectrum. The two Williams dramas certified the breadth of Miss Page's versatility as well as the depth of her emotional identification.

title: PARKS CHIEF SAYS FOES IMPERIL PAVILION PLANS
description: Plans to replace the old tennis house in Central Park with a neo-Victorian pavilion may be abandoned if public opposition runs strong enough, Parks Commissioner Henry J. Stern said yesterday.

title: METS WIN BATTLE, 7-3
description: The great beanball war was resumed along the Monongahela today, and the Mets lost it to the Pittsburgh Pirates on a technicality. They also lost their rookie starting pitcher, John Mitchell, and their manager, Dave Johnson, who were banished by the umpires after the war had flared again.

title: Richardson Is Released
description: Micheal Ray Richardson was released today by the Long Island Knights of the United States Basketball League. A club spokesman said Richardson was cut because he did not follow the team's game plan and was taking too many shots.

title: EX-C.I.A. MAN, CENSURED IN '79, RETURNS TO U.S.
description: Philip Agee, the former Central Intelligence Agency agent whose passport was revoked in 1979 while he was abroad, has returned to the United States for the first time in 16 years.

title: Purging College Athletics
description: LEAD: George Gipp, Dink Stover, Frank Merriwell - legendary names that conjure up the image of the college athlete as moral hero. That image is on its deathbed. Its last best hope could come later this month in Dallas when a special convention of the National Collegiate Athletic Association will review the fundamental principles governing intercollegiate athletics, including the specific question of containing costs.

title: CREW BEGINS QUEST FOR SUNKEN VESSEL'S TREASURE
description: On Jan. 23, 1909, at 5:30 A.M., a 600-foot luxury liner, the Republic, collided with the smaller Florida in the fog-hidden waters south of Nantucket, Mass. Until three years later, when the Titanic sank near Newfoundland, the Republic would retain the distinction as the largest ship to capsize and sink.

title: AT OPEN, COURSE IS THE ENEMY
description: THE Olympic Club's Lake Course is, to some, a green tunnel of horrors where the mighty fall and where any golfer can cry, ''Help!'' The 6,700-yard site of the 87th United States Open championship this week will be the longest ''short course'' used for the most prestigious tournament in golf.

title: Dispute on Deductions
description: It was described as a routine move to make some ''technical corrections'' to last year's tax legislation, but the bills introduced simultaneously in the House and Senate last week could have more than a techincal impact on collegiate athletics, especially in Texas and Louisiana.

title: IN BRONX POLITICS, SIGNS OF CITY'S FUTURE
description: The Bronx is at a racial and ethnic crossroads that is likely to determine its future politically for many years.

title: Forced AIDS Tests Might Slow Quest for a Cure
description: To the Editor:

title: STAGE: 'GIVE MY REGARDS'
description: ''GIVE My Regards to Broadway,'' the Light Opera of Manhattan's free and easy adaptation of George M. Cohan's 1904 show, ''Little Johnny Jones,'' deals with greed, corruption, star worship, Anglophilia and other promisingly pertinent themes. But rather than using the past to strike an ironic contemporary chord, the show's adapters and directors, Raymond Allen, Todd Ellison and Jerry Gotham, have created a flat, all-purpose period piece perfunctorily performed.

title: SUPREME EQUIPMENT & SYSEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After a loss of $95,000 from the reversal of a tax credit for the quarter and a gain of $336,000 from tax loss carryforwards for the 9 months. c-Net income The year-earlier third quarter and 9 months' earnings include a loss of $75,000 from disposal of the company's auto systems division.

title: Cocaine Seizure Called Largest at Land Border
description: Federal agents seized 1,660 pounds of cocaine that they said they saw float across the Rio Grande from Mexico on a raft Thursday night, and arrested two men who loaded the drug into trucks, the United States Customs Service reported Saturday.

title: Tanker Flew Too Low, Inquiry on Crash Finds
description: The KC-135 tanker that crashed at Fairchild Air Force Base in March was flying lower and slower than planned before it hit air from the jet exhaust of its companion B-52, an Air Force investigation board concluded in a report made public Friday.

title: COMPETITION IN BUSINESS PITS TOWN VERSUS GOWN
description: Colleges and universities across the country are increasingly clashing with the owners of small businesses who accuse them of using their tax-exempt status to engage in unfair competition.

title: SUBURB'S ROLE IS RESHAPED AFTER 40 YEARS
description: As the post-World War II suburb marks its 40th birthday, experts who study it agree that the suburbia of long ago has shed its role as only a bedroom community.

description: b-Net loss

title: Jewelry Store a Target For 2d Time in Month
description: A Fifth Avenue jewelry store was burglarized last night for the second time this month by thieves who broke through a wall from a vacant store next door, the police said.

title: Metro Matters; Racial Barriers: Private Schools Confront Reality
description: More than 145,000 students attend public schools in Manhattan. Fewer than 10 percent of them are non-Hispanic whites.

title: A Manila Paper Says Ramos Has Offered His Resignation
description: The armed forces Chief of Staff, Gen. Fidel V. Ramos, who is credited with blocking at least six coup attempts against President Corazon C. Aquino's Government, has offered to resign, a Manila newspaper reported today.

title: SOUTH AFRICA SALE BY FORD WILL GIVE BLACKS BIG STAKE
description: The Ford Motor Company is poised to sell its South African interests in a complex deal that would give its predominantly black work force a major share of the business, but leave its products still available there.

title: Claire Schiffman Becomes a Bride
description: Claire Schiffman, director of marketing for the Phillips Janson Group, an architectural firm in New York, and Andrew Butterfield, a doctoral candidate at the New York University Institute of Fine Arts, were married yesterday in East Hampton, L.I. Rabbi David Greenberg performed the ceremony at the home of Alex and Doris Weber, friends of the bride's family.

title: EAST SIDE RESIDENT HELPS LOTUS TEAM
description: Ken Szymanski is an avid auto racing fan, and he has turned his enthusiasm for motor sports into a part-time job that would be the envy of others of his ilk. Most days when Szymanski leaves his Upper East Side apartment, it is to go off to his job as a flight attendant. But Tuesday he will go to the airport and board a plane bound for Detroit and his second job: race mechanic for the Lotus Formula One team.

title: Bennett Would Detain Some Carriers of AIDS
description: Secretary of Education William J. Bennett said today that prisoners with AIDS who make threats to spread the disease may have to be kept in prison after serving their sentences.

title: SUSPECT KILLED, TOO
description: One New York State trooper was shot and killed and another was seriously wounded by a man with a rifle who was also killed last night when the troopers attempted to resolve a dispute between neighbors in Pleasant Valley, N.Y., officials said.

title: BRAZIL'S ECONOMIC PLAN: AUSTERE AND ORTHODOX
description: President Jose Sarney's tough economic austerity program marks the end of Brazil's effort to change the way that foreign governments and banks handle Latin American debt crises, according to foreign and Brazilian financial experts.

description: Casey Layne Hammer, the daughter of Julian Armand Hammer of Bel Air, Calif., and Sue Kane of San Marcos, Calif., and Victor Jeffrey Swab, a son of Mrs. Martin A. Vaughn of Tulsa, Okla., and the late John T. Swab, were married yesterday. The Rev. Dr. James Lockwood-Stewart performed the ceremony at the Westwood United Methodist Church in Los Angeles.

title: Amy Fern Sklar Is Bride Of Ronald B. Kremnitzer
description: Amy Fern Sklar, the daughter of Evelyn Sklar of Fort Lee, N.J., and the late Barnett Sklar, was married yesterday to Ronald Bruce Kremnitzer, the son of Mr. and Mrs. John Kremnitzer of New York. Rabbi Bernard N. Cohn performed the ceremony, assisted by Cantor Bruce Halev, at the Harmonie Club in New York.

title: 'WITCHING' FOCUS ON THURSDAY
description: With new rules governing the expiration of certain stock-index futures and options contracts, the focus for potentially sharp moves in stock prices has shifted from this Friday's ''triple witching hour'' to the day before, traders and investment professionals say.

title: SAYS WAR IS FAR FROM OVER
description: The twin-engine Gulfstream Commander airplane sat on the small landing strip with its front window smashed by one bullet, and its fuselage perforated by 40 more. Neatly stacked on the ground were packets of cocaine.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Wednesday about genetic engineering misidentified the university linked to Embryogen, a biotechnology company. It is Ohio University. The article also described the company's contract with Upjohn incorrectly.

title: TRANSIT POLICEMAN IS HELD IN STABBING DEATH OF FRIEND
description: A young transit police officer was charged with murder yesterday in the stabbing death of a friend.

description: Danny Cox pitched five-hit ball for eight and one-third innings as the St. Louis Cardinals beat the Chicago Cubs, 3-2, today to sweep the three-game series.

description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $974,000 for the quarter and an extraordinary credit of $905,000 for the 9 months. c-Net loss The year-ago periods' results include real estate tax refunds of $40,976 for the quarter and $136,964 for the 9 months. The latest 9 months' net includes a pre-tax gain of $4,307,180 on the sale of the company's leasehold on the Glen Oaks store in Queens, N.Y.

title: SIKH TERRORISTS SAID TO KILL AT LEAST 26
description: The police set up roadblocks and fanned out through the capital today looking for terrorists after at least 26 people were killed here and in the Punjab Saturday night in attacks that were ascribed to Sikh militants.

title: IN TOKYO, GIVING DISSENTERS A FORUM
description: Aggressive and innovative, the Honda Motor Company has emerged as a superstar among the world's multinational corporations. Its manufacturing plants in Asia, Europe and the United States have been turning out high-quality products and selling them at attractive prices. Its cars have won praise for their design and its dealerships have been hailed for the service they provide.

title: 2 WORKS ON GERTRUDE STEIN AND ALICE B. TOKLAS
description: THE temptation is to say that Gertrude Stein, like her famous rose, is Gertrude Stein is Gertrude Stein. But capturing the essence of this extraordinary exile can be a tricky exercise, depending on the eye of the beholder as much as on the known facts. Two dramas based on her life are currently available for illustration.

title: Lynn A. Stein Is the Bride of Richard P. Melnick
description: Lynn Andrea Stein, a daughter of Dr. H.David Stein and Dr. Ruth E.K. Stein of Larchmont, N.Y., and West Dover, Vt., was married yesterday to Richard Phillip Melnick, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Robert N. Melnick of Larchmont. Rabbi H.Leonard Poller performed the ceremony at the Beach Point Club in Mamaroneck, N.Y.

title: JETRONIC INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net income

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: PRESUMED INNOCENT. By Scott Turow. 431 pages. Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $18.95.

title: SCHULER CHARGES TO TITLE AND RECORD
description: Last winter, Tom Schuler of Wauwatosa, Wis., considered retiring as an athlete. He decided against it, but started spending almost as much time working on team administrative duties as on training.

title: AIDS: Good News and Bad News
description: Is the AIDS epidemic scything indiscriminately through the population like a medieval plague? Or is it still largely confined to high-risk groups like drug addicts, homosexuals and their sexual partners? The answer is critical because it determines which of two quite different strategies society pursues. The Reagan Administration, almost certainly, has picked the wrong answer and the wrong policy.

title: SPORTING LIFE INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After an extraordinary tax credit of $46,000.

title: Advertising; Some Thompson Clients Wary of Taking a Stand
description: A spot-check Friday of major J. Walter Thompson Company clients found not one that was willing to so stoutly stand behind the present management of its parent, the JWT Group, as did the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company last week. As a matter of fact they did not even use language as strong as did the Eastman Kodak Company, which said it would find any management change ''negative and disruptive.''

title: No, Inflation Isn't the Fed's Top Priority
description: Fight inflation, fight inflation and fight inflation! That's the advice Alan Greenspan, chairman-designate of the Federal Reserve Board, is getting from many of his fellow economists. It's bad advice.

title: CARDIS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
HONORS FOR OLDEST OLYMPIAN
description: In his day, Abel Kiviat was one of the world's most celebrated athletes. But his day was three-quarters of a century ago, and from the time he was 30 years old until the time he was almost 90, he faded from the public eye and memory. Few people remembered his 1912 Olympic silver medal in the 1,500-meter run or his world indoor bests or his two national indoor titles in one night.

title: LAW FIRM SPEARHEADS CAMPAIGN TO WIDEN VOTING RIGHTS IN ILLINOIS
description: Voting-rights lawsuits are sprouting across Illinois, and the lawyer responsible for them says he has initiated them because he believes members of minority groups must have fair chances of winning elections.

title: Schwab Is Said To Plan Offering
description: Charles Schwab & Company, the discount brokerage firm, is planning a public stock offering, less than three months after it was purchased in March from the BankAmerica Corporation for $230 million, according to The Los Angeles Times. Schwab hoped to file a stock registration statement for about 20 percent of the company's value with the Securities and Exchange Comission before Aug. 1, the newspaper reported.

title: AN ERA OPENS AS SCIENTISTS REPRODUCE DRUGS MADE IN THE BODY
description: FOR thousands of years, people have used herbs, microbes or other substances for drugs that somehow either helped the body or poisoned its foes: aspirin was derived from willow bark; digitalis, a potent heart drug, comes from the foxglove plant; penicillin is made from a common mold. In recent years many of these ancient healing substances have been improved synthetically and new sources have been found.

title: JUSTICES, 5-4, DEAL BLOW TO BACKERS OF VICTIM RIGHTS
description: The Supreme Court ruled 5 to 4 today that the Constitution bars the use at death sentencing hearings of evidence about the victim's personal characteristics, the impact of a murder on the victim's family members and their feelings.

title: Origin of Quasar Jets
description: A major puzzle to astronomers has been the origin of jets, thousands of light years long, that radiate in opposite directions from some quasars. The latter are widely thought to be galaxies in an early stage of formation and are most abundant at distances so great their light has taken billions of years to reach the earth. They are therefore seen as they were when the universe was young.

title: New Look at Drug Fever
description: The first systematic analysis of fevers that are brought on by drugs has produced findings that challenge long-held beliefs that have been espoused in medical textbooks and journals. For example, the study found nothing to support the belief that these fevers occur more often among people who have certain medical conditions and allergies.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A report last Thursday in the Finance/New Issues column of Business Day, about ''currency exchange warrants,'' misstated the approval process for the new security. Only the Securities and Exchange Commission was involved; the Commodities Futures Trading Commission did not have jurisdiction.

title: Texaco in Plea On Judgment
description: Texaco Inc. asked the Supreme Court of Texas yesterday to overturn the $10.53 billion judgment by a Texas lower court for Texaco's unlawful interference with the Pennzoil Company's plan to merge with the Getty Oil Company in 1984.

title: WONDER WHEEL, HUMBUGGERY AND FREUD'S FASCINATION
description: Denos D. Vourderis confesses that when he took Lula Lolas to the Coney Island beach in 1946, his motivation was to get a peek at her legs. He liked what he saw enough to propose matrimony.

title: ASA LTD reports earnings for As of March 31
description: Assets represent net assets. Net investment income for the latest period totaled $17,629,361, or $1.84 a share, compared with $16,578,189, or $1.73 a share, for the year-ago period.

title: MACARTHUR AWARDS OF $150,000 TO $375,000 GO TO 'OUTSTANDINGLY TALENTED' 32
description: The MacArthur Foundation of Chicago announced yesterday the selection of 32 ''outstandingly talented and promising individuals'' to receive awards over five years ranging from $150,000 to $375,000.

title: Q&A
description: Q. Are there any environmental ramifications of underground nuclear testing in the near and the far future? A. The Department of Energy says that all underground nuclear testing by the United States is conducted at the Nevada Test Site, an area of 1,350 square miles - a little bigger than Rhode Island. An underground detonation contaminates the immediate underground area, but there have been no leaks into the atmosphere since 1970, according to Chris West, a spokesman for the Nevada Test Site. In time, however, underground water will be contaminated by radiation from a test. There is little rainfall in the Nevada desert and the water table is more than 2,000 feet below the surface. Still, water under the test site will not be fit to drink. Mr. West said the Environmental Protection Agency and the United States Geological Survey have concluded that the contaminated water moves so slowly underground that by the time it leaves the site the radiation level would be within Federal standards for drinking water.

title: U.S. WILL NOT PRESS KOREAN INITIATIVE
description: As violent demonstrations in South Korea continued, senior Reagan Administration officials said today that the United States had no plan for a major diplomatic initiative that would press South Korea to move toward democracy.

title: CONTRAS' KILLING OF AMERICAN: DOUBT CAST ON REBEL ACCOUNT
description: Nicaraguan rebels who killed an armed American in Nicaragua six weeks ago say they selected their victim because they thought he was a Cuban adviser to the Nicaraguan Government.

title: Chess: New High School Champion Shows Deft Positional Touch
description: Vivek Rao, a junior at Gateway Senior High in Monroeville, Pa., has won the National High School Championship in Pulaski, Va.

title: SCOTT STRIKES OUT 14 AS ASTROS WIN, 4-0
description: Mike Scott struck out 14, equaling his career high, and pitched a seven-hitter over more than eight innings tonight, leading the Houston Astros over the Cincinnati Reds, 4-0.

title: Car Sales Fall 15%; Light Trucks Up
description: Sales of American-made cars fell 15 percent in early June, the eight domestic manufacturers reported today.

title: Report on Sandberg
description: The ankle injury suffered by Ryne Sandberg of the Chicago Cubs is more serious than previously believed and could keep the second baseman out of action for three to five weeks. Sandberg, who leads the National League second basemen in the All-Star Game balloting, sprained his right ankle trying to avoid a collision with the Cardinals' first baseman, Jack Clark, while coming down on the first-base bag during the third inning of Saturday's game. Sandberg was immediately placed on the 15-day disabled list, but the Cub trainer, John Fierro, said additional X-rays yesterday showed ligament damage in the ankle.

title: ATCO LTD reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars. The company said the latest year's results include a $58.1 million gain from real estate sales and the sale of certain stock, offset by a $20.7 million writedown of drilling rigs and the relocation of rental assets.

title: A New Vaccine for Chicken Pox Is Tested
description: Chicken pox vaccine has been tested in thousands of children, and researchers are optimistic that routine inoculations against the common, rash-causing childhood disease will be available within a few years.

title: JURY GETS JUDGE'S CLARIFICATION FAVORING GOETZ
description: For the second time in three days of deliberations at the trial of Bernhard H. Goetz, a request by the jurors for information resulted in a clarification -in Mr. Goetz's favor - of the legal instructions given by the judge.

title: FRETTER INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net income

title: Burlington Bond Waived
description: The investors seeking to take over Burlington Industries, the nation's largest textile producer, agreed to a waiver yesterday of a requirement for Burlington to post a $500 million bond, and then appealed the injunction linked to the bond. Asher B. Edelman, the New

title: ONE DAY AS A TRADE LOBBYIST
description: She walks the halls of Congress with 60 percent of the gross national product in her Louis Vuitton attache case.

title: LINDENAUER OPENS TESTIMONY IN NEW PARKING BUREAU TRIAL
description: The second trial stemming from thecorruption scandal that enveloped New York City's Parking Violations Bureau last year opened in Federal District Court in Manhattan yesterday with Geoffrey G. Lindenauer, chief government witness at the first trial last fall, back on the witness stand.

title: Corrections
description: A map yesterday with an article about the search for treasure aboard the sunken ship Republic off the New England coast mislabeled two islands near the wreck. The names, Nantucket and Martha's Vineyard, were reversed.

title: Words in Berlin
description: Speaking of Mr. Wright, on April 20 he was in Berlin, on his way back from a trip to the Soviet Union with a Congressional delegation. In a speech celebrating the 750th anniversary of the city, he said: ''And I shall tell you how we may know when real peace, real trust and true good will have returned to Europe: We shall know it when the wall comes down!''

title: DALLAS NO. 1 IN DEADLY FORCE
description: Dallas's police department ranked No. 1 among the nation's 11 largest cities in the use of deadly force in 1986, according to a survey of police departments by a Dallas newspaper. Police officers in Dallas killed 1.03 people per 100,000 population, the Dallas Times Herald reported Sunday. San Diego was second with 0.83 people killed per 100,000 and Los Angeles third with 0.71 deaths, the newspaper said. Per capita, Dallas police last year killed about four times as many people as police in Philadelphia, Baltimore, Phoenix and New York and twice as many as police in Chicago, Houston, San Antonio and Detroit, according to the survey.

title: INVESTING IN CHINA: STILL HARD
description: When China opened its doors to capitalism several years ago, Western businessmen and financiers seized the opportunity as the opening of a vast new frontier. But they have found that the reality is not living up to the promise.

title: REAGAN DEFENDS PERSIAN GULF ROLE BY SAYING SOVIET WOULD MOVE IN
description: President Reagan said tonight that if the United States did not take an active military role to protect shipping in the Persian Gulf, the Soviet Union would step in.

title: FROM TREASRUY SECRETARY TO GUILT IN A FRAUD
description: Ethel Gabriel, for decades one of the RCA Corporation's most illustrious record producers, left the company three years ago to start one of her own. Mrs. Gabriel, a widow who was prudent by nature, had long taken care of her own finances.

title: Minnesota Is Warned On Early Caucus Date
description: National Democratic Party officals are warning that they might not seat Minnesota's delegates to the 1988 national convention because Minnesota has moved its delegate selection process forward.

title: Spinks Was Here, There, Everywhere
description: To be there and not be there. And to stay off the ropes. That was the strategy Michael Spinks used tonight before his swarming punches knocked down Gerry Cooney twice in the fifth round, and Referee Frank Cappuccino stopped the bout at 2:51.

title: TREE-GUARD TEMPEST: TWO AGENCIES TANGLE
description: A dispute over some of the most cherished real estate in New York City has caused tension between two city agencies and prompted a debate about a section of the city administrative code. That most of the parcels of land in question are less than three feet across hardly seems to matter.

title: WOMEN IN U.S. PRISONS: FAST-RISING POPULATION By PETER APPLEBOME
description: As a criminal court judge well known here for stiff sentences and tough views on law and order, Ted Poe is a keen observer of crime and punishment. Lately, he has been noticing something.

description: b-After a loss of $87,449 from discontinued operations.
