description: b-Includes a $474,000 after-tax gain from the sale of land during the second quarter. Share earnings and shares outstanding are adjusted to reflect a 3-for-2 stock split in August 1986.

title: EDWARD W. SCRIPS 2d
description: Edward Willis Scripps 2d, a trustee of the Scripps Howard news organization founded by his grandfather and namesake, died yesterday on a flight from Honolulu to Sydney, Australia. He was 57 years old and lived in Honolulu.

title: Supermarkets General Elects Its New Leader
description: The Supermarkets General Corporation said yesterday that Kenneth Peskin had been elected chairman and chief executive by the board.

title: EXPLOSION AT ATHLETIC CLUB DISRUPTS LOWER MANHATTAN
description: An explosion and fire erupted in an electrical transformer at the Downtown Athletic Club overlooking Battery Park yesterday afternoon, touching off evacuations, power problems, concern over toxic fumes and a rush-hour traffic jam in lower Manhattan.

title: Keeping Report on Myerson Secret Was Not the Mayor's Idea
description: To the Editor:

title: STAGE: MANY FACES OF SHAKESPEARE
description: There was a time when Americans visited the London theater to savor the sheer poetry of Shakespeare. But fashions in English stagecraft have long since gone the way of the rest of the world. For every Royal Shakespeare Company or National Theater production that asks Shakespeare's text to carry the burden of the work, there is another (or two) that demands we visualize - or, if you will, conceptualize - the plays first and worry about the words later. In England no less than the United States, the pressing question of our theatrical day remains: Can we have our modern directors' visions and preserve Shakespeare's too?

title: Louis Menk, Architect, And Consultant, Dies
description: Louis Menk, an architectural consultant and a former assistant dean of the New York University School of Architecture, died in his sleep Friday at his home in Southfield, Mich. He was 78 years old.

title: Article 665787 -- No Title
description: The authorities have seized $15 million in cocaine and arrested two Colombians, one of them the reputed leader of a New Jersey drug ring, the Somerset County prosecutor said today.

title: LACKING FUNDS, RESEARCH CENTER STANDS IDLE
description: Moved by the starving children he saw on travels around the world, C. B. Pennington decided to create a nutrition research center. In 1980, he committed $125 million to the project.

title: POLITICAL AND CIVIC GROUP CALLS FOR SECONDS PANEL ON CHARTER
description: A group of politicians and civic leaders, dissatisfied with the makeup of the panel named by Mayor Koch to revise the City Charter, is planning a referendum to create a second charter revision commission.

title: Landmarks 'Moving' On Charts
description: The Washington Monument, the Empire State Building and the Space Needle in Seattle are no longer where they used to be, at least according to the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration.

title: PANAMANIAN, VOWING TO TOPPLE CHIEF, FLEES TO EXILE
description: A leading Panamanian businessman who was once Ambassador to the United States has fled into exile and vowed to wage a worldwide campaign to oust Panama's military leader, Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega.

title: G.&W. Unit's Offering
description: The Associates Corporation of America, a unit of Gulf and Western Inc., is offering $150 million of 8 1/4 percent subordinated notes due in 1992 at a price of 99.668, to yield 8.33 percent, through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

title: A SRI LANKAN MINORITY THAT DOESN'T DO BATTLE
description: By day they pluck the tea, climbing the steep, green hills of plantations that give the mountainous heart of Sri Lanka a landscape of ordered beauty.

title: ADOLFO FOR FALL: SHORT BUT SEDATE
description: The first style down the runway yesterday at what turned out to be one of Adolfo's best fashion collections was a dark-green wool coat with a black Persian lamb collar and cuffs. Worn over a matching wool shift, the double-breasted coat heralded the return of the coat and dress ensemble for fall.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: TUESDAY, JUNE 16, 1987
description: Companies

title: NORTHROP SEES LOSS ON BOMBER
description: The Northrop Corporation said today that it would report a second-quarter loss because of a $124 million write-down that analysts said was caused by higher-than-expected costs on the classified Stealth bomber project.

title: On That Filibuster
description: Several citizen groups, including Public Citizen and the U.S. Public Interest Research Group, plan to demonstrate today for an end to the filibuster of the Senate Election Campaign Act.

title: Dow Gains 13.81 as It Nears 2,400
description: Stock prices rose yesterday as the Dow Jones industrial average and some other market indexes continued to flirt with historic highs.

title: SRI LANKA AGREES TO AID FOR TAMILS
description: Sri Lanka, whose navy turned back an Indian relief flotilla earlier this month, agreed today to let unarmed Indian vessels bring supplies to ethnic Tamils in the Jaffna Peninsula.

title: FOLK: 2 SINGERS AT TOWN HALL
description: IT is difficult to imagine a more refreshing contrast of folk-music talents than Loudon Wainwright 3d and Michelle Shocked, the aging preppie and the young punk feminist who shared the bill at Town Hall on Saturday evening.

title: KOCH WANTS WELFARE CONTRACTORS TO GIVE JOBS TO WELFARE CLIENTS
description: New York City plans to create jobs for people on welfare by requiring contractors who do business with the Human Resources Administration to hire about 3,000 recipients over the next year, Mayor Koch said yesterday.

title: STREET PROTESTS BY SOUTH KOREANS RESUME AND GROW
description: Anti-Government protests spread Monday and early today as tens of thousands of South Koreans in major cities took to the streets in bursts of violence and choruses of prayer.

title: LOUISIANA EXECUTES 2D MAN IN SLAYING OF COUPLE
description: Jimmy Wingo, a former Boy Scout convicted of killing a married couple during a robbery was executed today in Lousiana's electric chair. He was the fourth man to be executed here in in nine days.

title: Harold Strauss Teams With Rosenfeld Agency
description: In early April the principals of Rosenfeld, Sirowitz & Humphrey read a report in The New York Times of a speech by Harold L. Strauss on how he built the old Creamer agency to $380 million in billings, from $22 million, through 17 agency acquisitions. It interested them because they had been discussing such a modus operandi to make R.S.&H. into an empire.

title: G.O.P. to Ask Trump About Mayoral Bid
description: The developer Donald J. Trump is ''at the top of the list'' as New York City Republican leaders search for a candidate to head a ''fusion'' ticket to defeat Mayor Koch in the 1989 election, the State Republican Party Chairman, Anthony Colavita, said today.

title: ROLEY IS SPREADING THE CREDIT AROUND
description: Pat Riley, a former journeyman player in the National Basketball Association, proved himself long ago to be a capable coach.

title: A Potemkin President
description: In private meetings at the Venice summit conference President Reagan spoke from note cards prepared for him. He was the only one of the Western leaders unable or unwilling to exchange ideas - to talk about the issues - without a script. When the others tried to start a discussion about Mikhail Gorbachev, the President read them lines from one of his recent speeches.

title: DUARTE ASKS DELAY IN MEETING OF LATIN CHIEFS
description: A politically charged meeting of Central American presidents scheduled for later this month has been put in doubt by a request from El Salvador that it be postponed.

title: Refined Equipment Is Helping Golfers
description: Ben Hogan was beaten in the 1955 United States Open playoff by Jack Fleck at The Olympic Club when his foot slipped on the 18th tee and he hooked his ball into the deep left rough.

title: Tax Watch; The Key Issues In PTL Case
description: AMONG the many problems facing the PTL ministry, its tax dispute with the Internal Revenue Service ranks high on the list.

title: Six Witnesses Take the Stand in Barbie's Defense
description: The defense in the Klaus Barbie trial presented six witnesses today to dispute the case against him and compare the former Gestapo chief's actions to those carried out in France's colonial wars.

title: WTD INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Congress's Pay
description: A Ralph Nader group, Repeal the Salary Grab, has issued income figures suggesting that members of Congress, at least the leaders, need a salary increase far less than their constituents do.

title: FUROR OVER SALE CASTS A SPOTLIGHT ON RACE FOR SILENCE IN SEAS By MALCOLM W. BROWNE
description: AS the Soviet Union and the United States race to build the quietest submarines possible, the recent disclosure that a Japanese company sold robot propeller-manufacturing machinery to Moscow has underscored the growing importance of computer control to the weapons industry.

title: AARON SPELLING PRODUCTIONS reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Includes a non-recurring charge of $750,000 for expenses related to the company's reorganization in August 1986. Year-ago third quarter and 9-month results are pro forma.

title: Made in Japan
description: Senator Bob Kasten, Republican of Wisconsin, was sorting through some postcards at the Senate gift shop the other day when one caught his eye. Part of a series of patriotic images of America, it depicted the flag raising at Iwo Jima. Mr. Kasten flipped it over and discovered that, down in the corner, in small print, it said, ''Made in Japan.''

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A report in the Business People column on Friday about Scholastic Inc. misstated the circulation of its Family Computing magazine. It is 435,000.

title: A COMPROMISE ON KOCH PLAN YIELDS BUDGET
description: A compromise was reached early yesterday on New York City's $22.8 billion budget that allowed the City Council and the Board of Estimate to add about two-thirds of the $156 million in programs they had sought.

title: Creditor Opposes Bid for Dome
description: The Bank of Montreal, the third-largest creditor of Dome Petroleum Ltd. in Calgary, Alberta, will not accept Amoco's $3.86 billion bid for Dome, according to its . executive vice president, Carson Stratton. He said the bank, which is owed $638 million by Dome, was prepared to force the oil company into bankruptcy. The bank would then receive all of its money because it is a secured creditor, he said.

title: IN NEW JERSEY, AN EARLY ENTRY FOR GOVERNOR
description: John F. Russo, already in the thick of maneuvering for the Democratic nomination for Governor, is working full time just to make sure he survives as a potential candidate past next November.

title: Steel Union's Election Goal
description: The United Steelworkers of America opened its annual legislative conference today with a pledge by the union's president to help elect a Democratic president in 1988. ''We're going to get a Democratic president elected,'' Lynn Williams, the union president, told 700 local union leaders. We're a long way from gone.''

title: NEW JERSEY METALS FIRM INVESTIGATED ON FUTURES
description: Officials from the Federal Government and the states of Florida and New Jersey are investigating the American Metals Exchange Inc., a New Jersey-based commodities firm, to find out whether it is selling futures contracts illegally to small investors around the country and whether it has been misrepresenting its product to customers.

title: Off Base on Yankee TV
description: Organized baseball's exemption from antitrust laws allows unusual freedom but also makes it vulnerable to legislative dyspepsia with home-team problems. The latest case is that of Representative Charles Schumer of Brooklyn, normally a sensible fellow.

title: CABLE TV INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Includes income from discontinued operations of $4,000 and an extraordinary tax credit of $68,000. c-Net loss and after income from discontinued operations of $13,000.

title: A 2d Pond's Unit Is Sold in a Month
description: Chesebrough-Pond's Inc. will sell its Prince Manufacturing Inc. subsidiary to a group that includes top Prince managers. The buying group, Brentwood Associates, is a Los Angeles-based leveraged buyout firm with about $300 million in capital. Terms were not disclosed, but the sale should be completed by July.

title: INNOVATIVE AMEX FIGHTS BACK
description: Smack in the middle of the trading pits of the American Stock Exchange is a real pit - a hole in the ground where, soon, yet another high-tech trading post will emerge. This construction - along with some 6,500 square feet of trading space being carved from an adjoining building -represents a triumph of prosperity for an exchange whose imminent demise had been predicted for more than a decade.

title: MOBIL SETS YIELDS
description: The Mobil Corporation is offering $200 million of 8 1/4 percent notes due in 1992 at a price of 99.70, to yield 8.32 percent, through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company. Noncallable for the life, the notes yield about 43-hundredths of a percentage point more than Treasury securities with a similar maturity. They are rated A-1 by Moody's and AA- by S.&P.

title: Placid Seeks to Lessen Banks' Role
description: Attorneys for the Hunt brothers' Placid Oil Company filed the outline of a bankruptcy reorganization plan today that attempts to lessen the role of its bank lenders in shaping the final repayment plan.

title: Ft. Shafter Issues Call For High-Tech Bugle
description: The soldiers at Fort Shafter, just outside Honolulu, stopped wondering years ago whether the bugle calls they heard were live or recorded.

title: Dynamics Sets Rocket Plans
description: The General Dynamics Corporation, the defense and aerospace company, announced at the Paris Air Show today that its space systems division would go ahead immediately with the construction of 18 Atlas Centaur rockets for commercial satellite launches.

title: Scott Cable Bid
description: Scott Cable Communications Inc., an operator of 29 cable systems in the Southwest, has agreed to be acquired for about $186 million by a company formed by Steve Simmon, the president of the Simmons Corporation. Scott Cable said its shareholders would receive $27.25 a share in cash under the agreement. The Simmons company would also assume about $69 million in debt. Scott Cable's stock closed yesterday at $26.50, unchanged, in over-the-counter trading.

title: Market Place; Quiet Rebound In Stock Prices
description: PERHAPS it was the heat wave. Or the lingering caution of the Wall Street community, which vividly remembers the plunging prices of April and May. For whatever reason, the equity market yesterday was knocking on the door of new highs without fanfare.

title: DANCE: ROBERT SMALL
description: ROBERT SMALL is a long, lean and limber dancer with an often quirky choreographic imagination who delights in giving the members of his Robert Small Dance Company lots of goofy things to do. At times, he gives them too much.

title: Guatemalan Volcano Erupts
description: The Pacaya volcano, 18 miles from here, began spewing lava and ash and caused a nearby town to be evacuated, a spokesman for the national observatory said today. The volcano, which has been sporadically active since January, erupted early Sunday. No injuries were reported but National Emergency Committee officials ordered the evacuation of the town of Caracol, which has a population of about 600.

title: TRANSCRIPT OF REAGAN'S SPEECH ON MEETING IN VENICE AND ECONOMIC ISSUES
description: Following is a transcript of President Reagan's address tonight on the economic summit meeting in Venice and budget issues, as recorded by The New York Times.

title: B-1B Bomber Breaks Down
description: The United States supersonic nuclear B-1B bomber, the most advanced ever built for the Strategic Air Command, broke down at the air show at Le Bourget today, a spokesman for Rockwell International said. The plane was due to leave for Dyess Air Force Base in Texas this afternoon but the crew was unable to start it because of a problem with an on-board power plant, he said.

title: CLABIR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Includes a pretax loss of $712,000 from the sale of a subsidiary. c-Includes a $958,000 gain from the sale of stock of an associated company. The company said it incurred $672,000 of expenses in the recently terminated merger of Clabir with Ambrit Inc.

description: b-After tax credits of $111,000 for the quarter and $601,000 for the 9 months. c-After income from discontinued operations of $145,000 for the quarter and $41,000 for the 9 months. d-Net loss The year-ago results do not include Action Drug Co., acquired as of Aug. 29, 1986.

title: WESTERN STAR BUSINESS SYSEMS reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After extraordinary tax benefits of $46,000 for the quarter and $92,000 for the 6 months. c-Net loss

title: Trade View Of U.S., Japan
description: The United States must ''check its tendency toward overconsumption'' while Japan must consume more in order to diminish trade imbalances between the two countries, the Japanese Government said today.

title: Politics, Pushed Into Korea's Streets
description: An important element has been added to the perennial confrontation between radical students and the police in South Korea. In clashes that have now spread from Seoul to other cities, students are being cheered on by a middle class that has so far shown scant sympathy for their demands.

title: SURGE OF SUPPORT IS SEEN FOR DENVER MAYOR ON EVE OF ELECTION By THOMAS J. KNUDSON
description: After trailing through much of the race, Denver's Democratic Mayor, Federico Pena, led the Republican challenger Don Bain on the eve of Tuesday's mayoral runoff election, according to a recent poll.

title: The U.N. Today: June 16, 1987
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: JOHN WINS SEVENTH
description: He wore peach-colored slacks, white shoes and a short-sleeved shirt, and if Tommy John were standing on the first tee instead of in the Yankee clubouse last night, he would have been appropriately dressed for a round of golf.

title: LEO SULLIVAN
description: Leo Sullivan, a theater consultant and former public relations director for the Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts, died of cancer Wednesday at George Washington University Hospital. He was 66 years old.

title: Careers; Required Course in Job Plans By Elizabeth M. Fowler
description: SUSQUEHANNA University, with just 1,500 students, is small as universities go. But it may have been the first with a big idea: requiring every undergraduate to take a course in career planning.

title: Baker Stands By Debt Plan
description: Despite criticism from some Latin American leaders, Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d today reaffirmed the plan to aid debtor countries that he proposed nearly two years ago.

title: 'URGE TO INVESTIGATE AND BELIEVE' SPARKS NEW INTEREST IN U.F.O.'S
description: THE ALIENS are here again, at least in terms of popular culture, if not fact.

title: SAN ANTONIO AND SANTA FE GET AWARDS AS MOST LIVABLE CITIES
description: San Antonio and Santa Fe, N.M., were honored today by the United States Conference of Mayors as the nation's most livable cities.

title: WITH AN OPEN MIND, CLAUDE BESSY MOLDS PARIS BALLET SCHOOL'S FUTURE
description: When two young French ballet stars, Sylvie Guillem and Patrick Dupond, brought 4,000 cheering viewers to their feet at last year's gala opening of the Paris Opera Ballet in New York, those in the know credited their triumph to Claude Bessy as well.

title: Gooden Loses First
description: The beginning of Dwight Gooden's delayed season has been completed. But the persistent scrutiny that followed him through the end of the 1986 season continued tonight.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Tennis Becker Wins Final in London: Boris Becker wore down Jimmy Connors, 6-7, 6-3, 6-4, to win the Stella Artois grass-court championship yesterday at the Queens Club in London for the second time in three years. In his final match before starting defense of the Wimbledon title he has won twice in a row, Becker had to call on all his reserves to prevent Connors from winning a Grand Prix tournament for the first time in more than two and a half years.(AP) Navratilova Advances: Martina Navratilova won 12 consecutive games to begin her defense of the Pilkington Glass women's grass-court championship in Eastbourne, England, with a 6-1, 6-0 victory yesterday over Marianne Werdel of the United States. Chris Evert, who is seeded second to Navratilova, also breezed into the second round with a 6-2, 6-1 victory over another American, Sharon Walsh-Peete.(AP) Basketball Greece Takes European Final: Greece edged the Soviet Union, 103-101, yesterday in Piraeus, Greece, to win the European Basketball Championship for the first time. Greece's victory prevented the defending champion Soviet team from capturing a record 14th European championship.(AP) Horse Racing Landing Plot Wins by a Neck: Landing Plot, ridden by Chris Antley, closed with a rush to overtake Mr. Classic inside the sixteenth pole yesterday for a neck victory in the $40,000 Shutout Purse for 3-year-olds and older at Belmont.(AP)

title: APPEALS COURT ORDERS DEAVER TO STAND TRIAL
description: A Federal appeals court ruled today that Michael K. Deaver, the lobbyist and former top aide to President Reagan, must stand trial on perjury charges.

title: ALASKA PIPELINE AT 10: OIL AND QUESTIONS FLOW
description: What is 800 miles long, four feet thick, cost about $10 billion, has been worth $130 billion to the nation and gave every Alaskan an annuity?

title: Report Sees Slower Growth
description: Top officials at the Bank for International Settlements, which represents the views of the West's central banks, said today that growth in the industrialized nations had slowed to less than 2 percent in the first quarter and needed to be speeded up to help debt-plagued developing nations.

title: DAY INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $1,592,000. c-Net income The company said the latest second quarter results include a pre-tax charge of $8 million to establish a reserve to cover future operating losses of a unit until it is sold and to offset employee severance costs related to a restructuring.

title: Large Families Need Health Care, Too
description: New York is a good example of a state where Medicaid eligibility forces the cruel choice of work or health on poor families. If a family is poor, according to the defined poverty level, it may receive Medicaid - but only if it contains one or two people.

title: Minority Businesses Still Struggle
description: LEAD: At times, it is very difficult to explain to a young person how this system of ours works. Now is one of these embarrassing times.

title: THEATER: 'COPPERHEAD' AT THE WPA
description: An underground anthracite fire in the fictional town of Fertile, Pa., has been smoldering for 19 years, spreading noxious fumes throughout this former coal-mining area. Stubbornly, some citizens have stayed on, and tourists stop by to stare at the ghostly community as if it were a way station on the road to the end of the world. Fertile has joined Love Canal and Three Mile Island on the ''disaster circuit.''

title: A.M.C. INCENTIVES
description: The American Motors Corporation said it was offering new cost-cutting incentives on selected Renault cars and Jeep models beginning today and with no expiration date. The company said its Renault models would carry $500 rebate or various discount financing rates ranging from zero percent for two-year loans on subcompacts to 9.9 percent for five-year loans. It said Jeep models would carry rebates of $500 to $1000, with similar financing rates depending on models.

title: Chile's Right-Wing President Welcomes a Chinese Official
description: Gen. Augusto Pinochet, who often speaks out on his role in fighting to defeat Communism in Chile, warmly received the Chinese Foreign Minister today and gave a lunch in his honor.

title: LONDON STOCKS SURGE
description: Prices on the London Stock exchange set new highs today amid optimism over last week's Conservative Party victory at the polls. The Financial Times index of 30 stocks closed at a record 1,786.6, up 18.7 points.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We want the Government leaders to realize what the people want. This is a time when the people unanimously want a democratic Government.'' - Im Jin Chang, a college professor, at rally inSeoul, South Korea [ A1:6. ]

title: JUSTICES REJECT 2 LAWS RESTRICTING FREE SPEECH
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that the First Amendment protects the rights of individuals ''verbally to oppose or challenge police action'' as long as their conduct does not amount to ''physical obstruction.''

title: Our Towns; The Anxiety Of Cream Cheese: A Singles' Tale
description: Stan and Roz Togut have two grown, unmarried daughters, one a businesswoman, the other an artist. Al and Marilyn Ross have three unmarried. Jerry and Janet Kroll have an unmarried accountant for a daughter.

title: Reports Disclose Biaggi Used Campaign Funds for Lawyers
description: Representative Mario Biaggi, who has been indicted in two New York corruption investigations, has been using campaign funds for his personal legal expenses since July 1986, according to his reports to the Federal Election Commission.

title: TO BEAT HEAT, SEERSUCKERS AND BEACHES
description: Across the New York region, people sweltered and sweated yesterday, and then many of them got soaked in a late-afternoon downpour. But all day long the big thermometer hanging outside 280 Broadway read a cool 48.

description: To the Editor:

title: People
description: * Diana Kramer has been appointed senior vice president, creative director, at Saatchi & Saatchi Compton.

title: Bonds Rise in Erratic Trading
description: Treasury note and bond prices rose modestly yesterday after a day of erratic trading.

title: GREAT AMERICAN MANAGEENT & INVESTMENT INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
THREE DEMOCRATIC HOPEFULS PROFESS FAITH IN CITIES
description: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts made a profession of urban faith today. ''I'm a guy who believes in UDAG's,'' he told some of the mayors assembled here for the 55th annual Conference of Mayors. ''I believe in C.D.B.G.'s. And I'm sorry about revenue sharing.''

title: Dodd Rules Abrams Isn't Credible Witness
description: Senator Christopher J. Dodd, the chairman of a Senate Foreign Relations subcommittee that handles Latin American affairs, today barred Assistant Secretary of State Elliott Abrams from testifying on the ground that he was not a credible witness.

title: MOHAWK DATA SCIENCES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After extraordinary tax credits of $1,526,000 for the quarter and $3,896,000 for the year. c-Net loss The company said the decline in fiscal 1987 revenue reflects its restructuring program which was completed April 30, 1986.

title: AMBRIT INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: The company said because of prefered dividend requirements, there were no share earnings in either quarter.

title: SPINKS BATTERS COONEY FOR 5TH-ROUND KNOCKOUT
description: Michael Spinks is the real thing.

title: Lay Off the Teamsters
description: LEAD: The Justice Department's plan to take over the 1.7 million member International Brotherhood of Teamsters is unconstitutional and impractical and should be scrapped before it goes any further.

description: To the Editor:

title: Bitter Choice: Work or Health; The Medicaid Precipice
description: For many poor families, the desire to move from dependency to self-sufficiency founders on the problem of health insurance. A person leaving welfare for a job may earn too much to qualify for Medicaid, Federal health insurance for the poor. Yet many employers offering low-wage, entry level jobs don't provide health coverage. The search in Congress for a Federal response deserves support.

title: FALWELL ASKING PTL'S DONORS TO SEND IN AN EXTRA $50 EACH
description: The Rev. Jerry Falwell urged ''PTL Club'' viewers today to include an extra $50 donation when they mail in their monthly pledges for June.

description: To the Editor:

title: HOSPITAL CITED FOR VIOLATING PATIENTS' RIGHTS
description: About 20 patients at Creedmoor State Psychiatric Center in Queens were unlawfully subjected to research experiments last year without their required informed consent, a New York State commission and a legislative leader charged yesterday.

title: Gold Demand Higher in 1986
description: The price of gold rose about 15 percent last year despite a bigger supply and only a modest increase in amounts of the metal held by monetary authorities, the Bank for International Settlements said today in its annual report.

title: Efficiency Gains by U.S.
description: The United States led the industrialized world in improving its manufacturing efficiency last year and was the only major country to reduce effective labor costs, the Labor Department said tdoay.

description: To the Editor:

title: ITALIAN ELECTION DEALS A SETBACK TO COMMUNISTS
description: The Italian Communist Party suffered a clear defeat Monday in parliamentary elections that crushed the party's hopes of forming a leftist coalition.

title: BILL ON ETHICS EXCLUDES LAW CLIENTS
description: Leaders of the State Legislature said today that a stricter Government ethics code being negotiated would not require legislators to disclose their law clients.

title: William Esty Promotes Itself in Newspaper Ads
description: Nothing like a bit of adversity and some new management to change an ad agency's modus operandi.

title: PUEBLO INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 23
description: b-After tax credits of $81,000 for the latest first quarter and $398,000 for the year-ago period. The year-ago figures are restated to include the early adoption of Financial Accounting Standards Board No. 87, ''employers' accounting fro pensions'', adopted in the 1987 fourth quarter.

title: Round-About Comeback
description: Bert Yancey says he believes his contribution to national mental health is to give ''high visibility'' to his recovery from manic-depressive illness, and that the medium is his comeback in professional golf. When he missed the cut in the Manufacturers Hanover Westchester Classic by two strokes last week, he said just playing well was an achievement; a few years ago it would have been impossible.

title: Michael Borus, an Economist And Human Relations Leader
description: Michael Borus, a New York economist who was senior vice president of the Manpower Demonstration Research Corporation, died of a heart attack last Friday in his office at 3 Park Avenue. He was 49 years old and lived in South Orange, N.J.

title: HOME LOAN BANKS
description: The Federal Home Loan Banks announced plans to offer two debt issues totaling $2.6 billion. Interest rates for $1.85 billion of two-year securities and $755 million of five-year securities will be announced today.

title: Carbide Seeks Adjournment
description: The Union Carbide Corporation applied to the Bhopal district court today to adjourn legal proceedings until October, the United News of India reported.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: Serious Jazz

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: STOP & SHOP COMPANIES reports earnings for 16wks to May 23
description: The year-ago first quarter's results are restated to include a loss of $2,042,000 from discontinued operations. The share earnings for both periods are restated to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split effective in July 1987.

title: Backer & Spielvogel Wins Wendy's Account
description: Where's the beef?

title: ELATED BY SUPERNOVA, ASTRONOMERS WATCH THEIR THEORIES COME TO LIFE
description: The cataclysmic explosion of a nearby star four months ago has dramatically strengthened major theories of how such explosions occur, and astrophysicists say the supernova has given them a new sense of confidence in their ability to interpret stellar events.

title: Sound Split for Spofford
description: New York City's Department of Juvenile Justice wants to shut down the Spofford Detention Center, in a far-off corner of the southeast Bronx, and build two smaller facilities in that borough and Brooklyn. The Board of Estimate ought to grant the plan environmental approvals.

title: ZACCARO WAS SOUGHT AS INTERMEDIARY, JURY IS TOLD
description: A former New York State Assembly Speaker testified yesterday that John A. Zaccaro received a crash course in cable television so he could become an intermediary between Queens officials and a cable company seeking a Queens franchise.

title: POPE IN POLAND
description: Many Polish television viewers who watched Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski bid farewell to Pope John Paul II on Sunday have been trying to identify the emotions reflected in the faces and postures of the two men as they stood together at the airport.

title: BRAZIL SEEKS LOANS, A NEW $7.3 BILLION
description: Brazil's Finance Minister estimates that his country will need $7.3 billion in new credits over the next 18 months as part of any agreement enabling it to resume interest payments on its foreign commercial debt.

title: LAKELAND INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Miwok Capital Files With S.E.C.
description: An investment group led by the Miwok Capital Corporation, which controls a 10.6 percent stake in the Zondervan Corporation, said it was seeking ''other persons interested in acquiring control'' of the Bible publisher, based in Grand Rapids, Mich.

title: PICTURES SPOKE BEST IN N.B.A. FINALS
description: ''Compelling'' is the best way to describe the National Basketball Association Finals. Even for those of us who believe that basketball has no right intruding on our airwaves in mid-June, the bicoastal grudge match between the Celtics and Lakers was impossible to ignore. And, unlike the regular season, when the last five minutes are the only part of a game worth watching, the six final games generally rewarded those who stayed from start to finish.

title: CLIMATE STUDY TESTS SATELLITE DATA
description: IN one of the first undertakings of an international climate study, more than 100 scientists are gathering on a prairie in Kansas this summer to conduct experiments comparing ground measurements of temperature, soil moisture and vegetation condition with those made by orbiting spacecraft.

title: Chase Manhattan
description: The Chase Manhattan Corporation plans to issue $100 million of three-year subordinated notes, which pay no interest until maturity. At the end of three years, the interest payment is tied to the performance of the stock market, according to a formula to be announced when the notes are offered. Louis Margolis, managing director of Salomon Brothers, an underwriter for the issue, said these might be attractive to investors wanting to hedge large equity portfolios.

title: West German Who Landed In Moscow Is to See Parents
description: The parents of Mathias Rust arrived here today to meet with their son for the first time since he landed a light plane near Red Square.

title: Diary of a Weirdo
description: Flew to New York, Dulles to La Guardia. Cost $78. Exactly twice what it cost last year. Another benefit of airline deregulation: 100 percent price boost gives customer chance to feel like big spender.

title: FINAL GRADE: MODEST GAINS
description: THE school year that is about to end was widely acclaimed as the year of reform, but how much has actually changed? An honest answer must be that progress has been modest.

title: MEDICAL NEGLIGENCE: A PROBLEM UNDER ATTACK
description: To the Editor:

title: ACTOR'S MEMORABILIA LEFT TO THE PLAYERS
description: An extensive collection of theatrical memorabilia of Maurice Evans, whose American career as an actor and manager spanned more than 30 years, has been left to the Hampden-Booth Library of the Players club on Gramercy Park.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: TUESDAY, JUNE 16, 1987
description: International A3-14

title: INTERNATIONAL EFFORT AIMS TO SAFEGUARD WILDLIFE TREASURES OF MADAGASCAR
description: MADAGASCAR, a biological wonderland in jeopardy, is now seen by many experts as the world's top priority for nature conservation.

title: American Brands Names Chairman
description: American Brands Inc. said yesterday that it had named William J. Alley chairman and chief executive to succeed Edward W. Whittemore, 64 years old, who suffered an illness this month and is convalescing. Mr. Alley, 57, has been vice chairman and chief operating officer.

title: Limit on AIDS Booklet Lifted
description: The Secretary of Health and Human Services, Dr. Otis R. Bowen, has responded to Congressional demands by removing a limit on the number of AIDS education booklets that members of Congress may obtain to send to constituents, officials said today.

title: INSIDE
description: Creedmoor Accused

title: WHITE HOUSE OPPOSES PLAN REAGAN URGED TO HOUSE HOMELESS
description: The Reagan Administration said today that it opposed a bill that would let cities use Federal welfare funds to build low-cost housing for the homeless, a concept President Reagan publicly endorsed last year.

title: MELLON, NAMING CHIEF, PREDICTS LOSS
description: The Mellon Bank Corporation yesterday named its new chairman and chief executive and at the same time it forecast a $500 million second-quarter loss.

title: ERRANT SHELLS HIT A GERMAN SHIP
description: A West German military supply ship observing Warsaw Pact maneuvers in the Baltic Sea was hit by naval artillery fire today, probably by a Polish vessel, the Defense Ministry said. Three crew members were slightly wounded.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: The Metropolitan Museum of Art has announced that its Costume Institute will no longer present the annual blockbuster shows of historical fashion that have been a fixture in New York for 14 years.

title: Farm Talks In Europe
description: Agricultural ministers of the European Community began new talks today on the 1987-88 farm price package, but officials doubt that an agreement can be reached soon.

title: OTTERS THRIVE IN PARK AFTER 60-YEAR ABSENCE
description: Otters reintroduced into Great Smoky Mountains National Park after a six-decade absence are showing all the signs of settling in, biologists say.

title: AN OFFER TO LIFT BID FOR JWT
description: Martin S. Sorrell raised the ante for JWT Group Inc. yesterday.

title: Secret Talks
description: At a secret location to avoid the confrontational atmosphere and large number of reporters that marked the contract negotiations five years ago, the National Football League Players Association and N.F.L. Management Council yesterday began a key series of contract talks. The site is so secret that even some members of the union did not know where the talks were being held. The current contract expires before the 1987 season starts. The union says it has eight major points to resolve, including free agency, guaranteed contracts and a share of N.F.L. licensing profits. Five years ago, the union's head was Ed Garvey. He clashed often with Jack Donlan, who was in his first negotiations for management.

title: CAMPAIGN LOANS OFTEN RISKY
description: When four Ohio banks lent $2 million to keep alive Senator John Glenn's bid for President in 1984, it was not because of the campaign's financial stability.

title: HIJACKING SUSPECT SHOWN TO VICTIMS
description: A suspect in the hijacking of a T.W.A. jetliner, who is being held in a West German prison, was brought today before Americans who had been aboard the plane.

title: Reagan Appointments
description: The White House announced today that President Reagan plans to appoint Bill Blass, one of Nancy Reagan's favorite dress designers, and Betsy Bloomingdale, a close friend whom the Reagans often visit in California, to new positions on the President's Committee on the Arts and Humanities.

title: French Police Said to Arrest 2 Italian Terrorist Suspects
description: The Paris police arrested Maurizio Locusta, reputed leader of a Red Brigades terrorist unit wanted in the killing of an Italian general, and a companion, official sources said today.

title: TRIAL CHANGES ARE SOUGHT BY REVOLUTIONARIES
description: A Federal district judge began hearing more than 100 motions today in the trial of eight avowed revolutionaries accused of plotting the violent overthrow of the United States Government.

title: RIFLEMAN SHOOTS 2 STATE TROOPERS, ONE FATALLY, AND TAKES HISOWN LIFE
description: A New York State trooper was killed and a second was seriously wounded Sunday night when a man opened fire with a rifle as they investigated a neighbor's complaint in a Dutchess County town. The gunman then took his own life with a shotgun, the police said.

title: MACGREGOR SPORTING GOODS INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net income and after extraordinary tax credits of $44,000 for the quarter and $105,000 for the 9 months. Both latest periods include the operations of Sports Specialties acquired as of Aug. 1, 1986, for financial reporting purposes.

title: TUNING UP FOR 'TOSCA' IN THE PARK
description: For Sherrill Milnes, the big problem is bugs, he said. After all, it is tough enough to sing an aria in front of 200,000 people without worrying about a mosquito sizing up your tongue. There are also car horns to contend with, as well as airplanes, sweltering temperatures and picnickers who've perhaps drunk a little too much sparkling wine.

title: Bosworth Softens
description: While insisting he still will not negotiate with the Seattle Seahawks, Brian Bosworth said yesterday he is now willing to listen to the club's best offer. Bosworth said on ABC-TV's ''Monday Sportsnite'' that his agent, Gary Wichard, would ''listen to only one offer so it's going to have to be their best offer and after that I guess we're going to have to negotiate . . . to get a trade worked out.'' This is a softening of the stance taken last Friday, when the Seahawks got the first pick in the National Football League's supplemental draft and chose Bosworth, the University of Oklahoma all-America linebacker. The Seahawks were not on the player's preferred list of teams, which included the Jets, the Tampa Bay Buccaneers and the Philadelphia Eagles.

title: Pro Basketball Notebook; Celtics Must Face Tough Questions
description: The road that led to the Celtics' 16 National Basketball Association championships began with the 1956 trade that brought Bill Russell to Boston. In the years that followed, the legend continued with the timely drafting of John Havlicek, Dave Cowens and Larry Bird and then the 1980 deal that put Kevin McHale and Robert Parish in Celtic uniforms.

title: Bridge: A Husband Risked Discord In Analysis of Wife's Game
description: Many wives no doubt consider that their husbands should tell them everything, and vice versa, but a case can be made for some exceptions. A candidate for a bridge exception arose on the diagramed deal, played recently in the Northern California semifinal of the Grand National Teams.

title: MCCORMICK & CO reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $3.6 million, or 31 cents a share, from the sale of property for the quarter and 6 months.

title: A DEFICIT HAUNTS ROYAL SHAKESPEARE
description: While the Royal Shakespeare Company is riding high abroad, at home it is facing what some see as the gravest financial crisis in its 27-year history.

title: AMCAST INDUSTRIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Net loss and includes a pretax charge of $22,500,000 for restructuring.

title: U.S. JUDGE REFUSES TO DISMISS CHARGES IN LAROUCHE CASE
description: A Federal district judge has refused to dismiss charges against 18 aides and organizations of Lyndon H. LaRouche Jr., rejecting arguments that the defendants were being prosecuted because of the Presidential candidate's extremist political views.

title: FIGHTING RAZZLE-DAZZLE
description: I RECENTLY attended a planning meeting for software developers and educators on computer software for home use, and I suspect that I was invited to play the devil's advocate. In fact, one participant dubbed me ''the curmudgeon'' because of my dubious attitude toward home computer applications and educational software.

title: NEW CHANCE FOR 'SPENSER: FOR HIRE'
description: ALTHOUGH far from a blockbuster hit, ''Spenser: For Hire'' has been renewed for a third season on ABC. Using the private-investigator character created by the novelist Robert B. Parker and developed for television by John Wilder, the series got off to a solid start, then took a tumble into confusion and hack writing. Now the beleaguered network has at least one good opportunity to get back to the basics of entertainment.

title: India Is Said to Detain Former Defense Chief
description: A former Defense Minister who has become a bitter critic of Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi was reportedly detained today by the police in the northern state of Uttar Pradesh and prevented from addressing a rally.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: ORPHANS. Real and Imaginary. By Eileen Simpson. 249 pages. Weidenfeld & Nicolson. $16.95.

title: TRACKING THE ELEVATION OF A FRIEND OF MEESE
description: The awarding of titles, jobs and offices based on whom one knows rather than what one knows is hardly a new or shocking practice in this city.

title: BLOOMSDAY OBSERVANCE
description: Joyceans all over the world today will observe Bloomsday, the day named after the wanderings in Dublin of Leopold Bloom, the central personality in James Joyce's novel ''Ulysses.'' In this country, the centerpiece of the celebration will be a dramatic reading tonight from ''Ulysses'' and a portion of Joyce's ''Finnegans Wake'' at Symphony Space, Broadway at 95th Street.

title: KNICKS HAVE DRAFTY FEELING
description: Now that the professional basketball season is over, let's talk about the Knicks. When last we heard, they were still looking for that magic combination of general manager-coach-personnel director, but were getting turned down by potential candidates who want no part of New York.

title: DART GROUP CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $303,000 from a loss on the repurchase of debentures. Year-ago revenue for the first quarter is adjusted to reflect the consolidation of Crown Books Corp. and Trak Auto West Inc.

title: KEY RATES
U.S. CITIZENS CLAIM ABUSE BY SAUDIS
description: A half-dozen Americans, contending they were victims of human rights abuses in Saudi Arabia, told a Congressional panel today of experiences of imprisonment and torture. They also accused the United States Government of ignoring their plight.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Chemical Bank named Stephen J. McWhir president of its subsidiary Chemical International Securities Corp., a licensed Eurosecurities broker-dealer.

title: SURVIVAL TECHNOLOGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net income and is after an extraordinary tax benefit of $180,000.

title: KEEPING REPORT ON MYERSON SECRET WAS NOT THE MAYOR'S IDEA
description: To the Editor:

title: De Wit Bout Doubtful
description: In the aftermath of the death of his father and brother in a weekend plane crash, the title defense of the Canadian heavyweight champion, Willie de Wit, against Ken Lakusta on Aug. 4 in Edmonton is in question. De Wit's father, Len, and younger brother, Theo, were killed in the crash of a small plane Sunday moments after taking off in Grande Prairie, Alberta.

title: US HEALTH INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
U.S. KNEW OF IRAN ARMS, OFFICIALS SAY
description: Kuwaiti officials and Western diplomats here say the United States has known since last summer that Iran was preparing Chinese-made Silkworm missiles near the Strait of Hormuz, where they could threaten shipping in the Persian Gulf.

title: SOSNOFF GIVES UP BID FOR CAESARS WORLD
description: Martin T. Sosnoff, the first-time corporate raider who put Caesars World Inc. into play in mid-March, dropped his $35-a-share bid for the Los Angeles-based casino operator yesterday.

title: BENEFIT'S 4 YOUNG ORGANIZERS
description: Success and money. They are, stereotypically anyway, what drive today's youth. But a handful of men and women, all in their 20's and most the offspring of rich and successful New Yorkers, are pulling every string and using every contact to remind their peers of other priorities, such as social action and the performing arts.

title: Goodyear Layoffs
description: The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company said it would lay off 140 salaried and hourly workers at its general products plant in New Bedford, Mass., by July 13 in an efficiency move. Ned Kendall, a Goodyear vice president and general manager, said that the plant, which employs about 400 people, try to maintain the company's rapid growth in roofing products, selected graphic products and internal use items.

title: A LOOK AT AFGHAN STRUGGLE
description: AS many as one million people may have died in Afghanistan since the Soviet military intervention in 1979; some five million people have fled. Afghanistan, however, is not much in our consciousness. Western journalists, with only a few exceptions, have been kept out. ''Afghanistan: The Fight for a Way of Life,'' on Channel 13 at 11 o'clock tonight, fills in some vacant spaces. It is a somber and clear-eyed examination of what the war is about.

title: AN EAST HARLEM LEARNING CITADEL WHERE OPENNESS RULES
description: A faculty meeting was in progress at Central Park East Secondary School in East Harlem last Thursday when a telephone call came for Deborah Meier, its director. ''This had better be important,'' she said, grumbling.

title: COMMUNICATION'S COST
description: THE Federal Communications Commission made a proposal last week that would sharply increase the fees paid by people who use computers to communicate over telephone lines. The surprise proposal, which is now open for public comment, would take effect Jan. 1.

title: RESTITUTION TO BLACKS UNLIKELY IN GEORGIA COUNTY
description: Descendants of black property owners who were forced out of Forsyth County, Ga., in 1912 are unlikely to to have their ancestors' land restored to them in Georgia courts, according to the state Attorney General.

title: NAVY ALLOWS FEMALE TECHNICIANS ON BOARD FOR TESTS OF SUBMARINES
description: Navy Secretary James H. Webb today ordered today that female civilian technicians be allowed aboard submarines for sea trials to test new equipment.

title: JUDGE LINKED TO MYERSON SEEKS RELEASE OF EVIDENCE
description: The judge who was accused of having been improperly influenced by New York City's former Cultural Affairs Commissioner, Bess Myerson, demanded yesterday that Mayor Koch make public the evidence compiled in the special inquiry he ordered.

title: McEnroe Is Out Of Wimbledon Play
description: In London, the news will probably comfort the very proper members of the All-England Lawn Tennis Club, although many fans and the British tabloids may be disappointed. In New York, executives of HBO, the cable network that televises the weekday matches from Wimbledon, will be frowning, too. HBO had built its promotional campaign around the return of John McEnroe to Centre Court. Now, the question arises whether he will play there again.

title: Monkeys as Helpers To Quadriplegics At Home
description: IT has been 10 years since an innovative behavioral psychologist set out to make life more bearable for a quadriplegic friend. With a grant of $2,000 from the Tufts New England Medical Center, Mary Jane Willard began training capuchins - organ-grinder monkeys - to become the arms and legs of quadriplegics, disabled people who have lost significant use of all four limbs. The monkeys help them eat, drink, read, listen to music or watch television - in short, to live more independently.

title: Investigators Find No PCB's After Blaze at Athletic Club
description: Fire Department investigators said yesterday that there were no appreciable levels of hazardous toxic chemicals in the transformers involved in an explosion and fire Monday at the Downtown Athletic Club at 19 West Street.

title: FILM: BENJI
description: WHO but Benji would dare to work with co-stars like these? In ''Benji the Hunted,'' which opens today at the Guild, he appears with four adorable blue-eyed cougar cubs, who become his charges when their mother is killed by a hunter. Benji feeds them, carries them about in his teeth and protects them from such other cast members as a timber wolf and a Kodiak bear. Also in the film are ferrets, raccoons and one extremely brave frog, whose job is to be played with by the cougars. It took 23 cougar cubs (because they grow so quickly) to fill the four cougar roles.

title: BRONX SEASCAPE: SEALS ARE TAUGHT TO DIVE FOR GUNS
description: ''Welcome to the Undersea World of the Bronx.'' That's what the man said, and the people went inside, a few of them half expecting to see aquariums filled with rusty oil drums, assorted garbage and muggers wearing snorkels, masks and swim fins.

title: 12 Leftist Guerrilla Suspects Are Killed by Chilean Police
description: Security agents killed 12 suspected leftist guerrillas during a series of gun battles in Santiago, the authorities reported today.

title: KOCH ADMINISTRATION WEIGHS TAKEOVER OF BUS STOP SHELTERS
description: The Koch administration is preparing to take over the bus stop shelter system, which is still incomplete after years of scandal, delay and failure by private operators.

title: Real Estate; Midblock Tower Due Near Saks
description: AFTER nearly three decades of aborted efforts, an office tower is finally ready to rise behind Saks Fifth Avenue's flagship store.

title: BILLS WOULD AID NEW YORK WINE COLLECTORS
description: THE New York State Legislature is considering competing bills that would legalize the sale of private wine collections. At present, only licensed retailers, distributors and importers can legally sell wine.

title: Shultz Endorses Philippine Paramilitary Groups
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz, who has been unreserved in his praise of the Philippine Government's strategy in battling the Communist insurgency, offered a cautious endorsement today of anti-Communist paramilitary groups here.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: WEDNESDAY, JUNE 17, 1987
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Gifts for Father On His Day
description: 1. Neat and Trimmed

title: WALTER HELLER, 71, ECONOMIC ADVISER IN 60'S, DEAD
description: Walter W. Heller, the chief economic adviser of Presidents Kennedy and Johnson, died Monday of a heart attack at his second home, near Seattle, his office in Minneapolis reported today. He was 71 years old.

title: Enough U. S.-Japan Poison
description: LEAD: United States-Japan trade tensions are taking their toll on the nerves of the Japanese people. Resentment and fear that Japan is being forced to pay the price of the Reagan Administration's economic policy failures and American industries' declining competitiveness have reinforced the Japanese people's image of their country as a punching bag, a scapegoat, a victim - and of the United States as a bully all too ready to hit below the belt.

title: VERA CASPARY, SCREENWRITER AND NOVELIST
description: Vera Caspary, a novelist, playwright and screenwriter best known for her films ''Laura,'' ''Letter to Three Wives'' and ''Les Girls,'' died of a stroke Saturday at St. Vincent's Hospital. She was 87 years old and lived in Greenwich Village.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: COUPLE'S SLAYER IS PUT TO DEATH
description: Jimmy Wingo, a double murderer, was put to death in the electric chair early today, the fourth man executed by Louisiana in 10 days.

title: 1986 CHEMEICAL ACCIDENTS LEFT 5 DEAD IN NEW YORK
description: At least 5 people were killed and 133 injured last year in New York State as a result of toxic chemical accidents, according to data compiled by the office of the state's Attorney General.

title: PIANO: DAVID HOLLANDER
description: DAVID HOLLANDER was full of surprises at his piano recital Sunday afternoon in Weill Recital Hall. He walked out shyly, took an awkwardly deep bow, and then sat down and played like a daredevil.

title: POLITICAL GOALS SPUR BOTH U.S. AND SOVIET
description: The United States and the Soviet Union seem to be inching toward a summit meeting in Washington this autumn, provided they can resolve their final disagreements over a treaty eliminating short-range and medium-range nuclear weapons from Europe.

title: Once Again, Blindly Into the Breach
description: President Reagan's pledge to ''protect the free world's oil flow'' by expanding our naval presence in the Persian Gulf suggests a powerful itch to plunge us into military action. It is also the latest manifestation of fallacious thinking to which all superpowers succumb - the notion that we know the interests of other countries better than they know their own interests.

title: DEBATE OVER BROADWAY: DUDGEON, PIQUE AND IRE
description: Henry Denker didn't waste any time on pleasantries. ''The American play is being pushed off the scene by certain elements of the theater,'' said the playwright, novelist and screenwriter, his eyes beaming killer darts across the stage, ''one of whom is sitting here.''

title: Not New York
description: New Yorkers tend not to expect much from taxi drivers. So United States Attorney Rudolph Giuliani sounded a bit startled when he described his arrival yesterday at National Airport on his way to the National Press Club to give a speech. Mr. Giuliani tore his trousers on a ''protruding wire.'' The driver immeditately took him to a tailor, waited with him while repairs were made and then, unasked, offered to pay the bill. ''I'm going to take him back to New York with me and ask the Mayor to make him cab driver of the year,'' Mr. Giuliani said.

title: Abdul-Jabbar: 2 More Years
description: Kareem Abdul-Jabbar, who at 40 years of age, played a key role in the Los Angeles Lakers' championship season, has signed a contract that will keep him playing another two seasons, the team announced tonight.

title: TWO G.O.P. HOPEFULLS REJECT MORE U.S. SPENDING ON CITIES
description: Two Republican Presidential hopefuls urged the nation's mayors today to reject the notion that an increase in Federal assistance is the solution to urban problems.

title: Gold Futures Back at Merc
description: The Chicago Mercantile Exchange began trading gold futures contracts again yesterday, ending a two-year hiatus. Gov. James R. Thompson of Illinois rang the ceremonial opening bell to start trading in the new, 100-ounce contract.

title: SANDINISTAS UPROOT VILLAGERS TO LIMIT SUPPORT FOR CONTRAS
description: The Nicaraguan soldiers arrived without warning last month and were not in the mood to give explanations.

title: Burlington Rail Warns of Job Loss
description: Apparently positioning itself for upcoming labor negotiations, the Burlington Northern Railroad warned its 33,70O union members that 12,000 jobs could be lost if the rail carrier was not able to improve its return on investment.

title: FOR GREATER SAFETY, THE AIRLESS SPARE
description: FOR a motorist with a flat tire, there are few experiences as dismaying as the discovery of a deflated spare.

title: Out of the Cold
description: Maybe you thought the indoor ''winter'' sports season ended on Sunday, June 14, when the Lakers finally eliminated the Boston Celtics as palm trees wilted in Los Angeles. Well, the Major Indoor Soccer League championship final grinds on tomorrow with Tacoma visiting steamy Dallas for Game 6. And guess what's coming up on Aug. 3? Teams Canada and U.S.A. open training camps in Montreal and Bloomington, Minn., to prepare for their game in Ottawa that opens the Canada Cup round-robin competition on Aug. 13. That's a hockey tournament. Ice hockey.

title: SPINKS'S FORMULA: WAIT, THEN WALLOP
description: With Michael Spinks, one night in the ring never seems quite like the one before. He is a ring chameleon, altering his style to suit whatever fight his opponent brings him.

title: O.E.C.D. Inflation Up
description: Rising oil prices sent inflation in O.E.C.D. countries up to a 3.5 percent rate in April from 2.9 percent in March, the group said today. In its monthly report, the Organization of Economic Cooperation and Development said consumer prices in its 24 member countries rose an average six-tenths of 1 percent in April, against five-tenths of 1 percent in March.

title: Drug Use at Nuclear Plant
description: Ten employees at the Three Mile Island nuclear station, none of them involved in the plant's operation, have tested positive for drug use, officials said Monday. The workers were among 33 tested in a three-week investigation into drug use at the site, said the GPU Nuclear Corporation, which operates the plant. Eight were suspended for 30 days without pay, one resigned and one was dismissed.

title: The U.N. Today: June 17, 1987
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Greece Seeks Investors
description: Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou of Greece urged foreign businessmen today to invest in Greece. He spoke to about 1,000 members of the American, British, French, West German and Italian chambers of commerce.

title: LAST OF DUSKY SPARROWS DIES
description: The last pure dusky seaside sparrow died today, ending a steady drift toward extinction of the little bird that refused to yield to man's intrusion.

title: HANOVER LIFTS RESERVE BY $1.7 BILLION
description: Three more global financial institutions - Manufacturers Hanover, Bankers Trust and National Westminster of Britain - said yesterday that they would set aside additional reserves for loan losses.

title: House Votes to Delay Soviet Use of New Embassy
description: The House of Representatives voted today to prohibit the Soviet Union from occupying its new embassy complex here until President Reagan has certified that the new United States Embassy in Moscow is secure and that the Russians are not using their site on a Washington hilltop for electronic espionage.

title: Bomb Wounds 4 in Lima
description: A car bomb believed to have been left by guerrillas exploded in front of two banks in a Lima neighborhood of expensive houses early today, wounding four people, the police said. They said leftist rebels of the Tupac Amaru Revolutionary Movement had planted a bomb that used 110 pounds of dynamite in a stolen taxi cab.

title: 25 Die as Korea Ferry Sinks
description: A fire started in the engine room of an excursion boat packed with tourists and it sank off the western coast Tuesday, killing at least 25 people, navy officials said. The 25-ton boat went down off Koje, a city 170 miles south of Seoul.

title: JUSTICE DEPT. SAYS PROSECUTOR LAW SHOULD BE VETOED
description: The Justice Department, with White House approval, said today that it regarded the law on special prosecutors as unconstitutional and asserted that it would advise President Reagan to veto any Congressional extension of it as now drafted.

title: A WRITER ACTIVE IN CIVIL RIGHTS
description: Eunice Clark Jessup, a writer who was active in the civil-rights movement, died of complications from pneumonia Monday at Norwalk (Conn.) Hospital. She was 76 years old and lived in Wilton, Conn.

title: OPERA: A 'TOSCA' IN THE PARK
description: THE Metropolitan Opera began its 21st season of parks concerts yesterday evening under what could hardly have been better circumstances. There were clear blue skies and warm temperatures as a pleasant breeze blew across the Great Lawn of Central Park, where the company presented Puccini's ''Tosca'' before a crowd of picknickers, opera fans and curious passers-by that was estimated by the police to number 70,000. The tenor Placido Domingo and the baritone Sherrill Milnes headed the cast, conducted by Garcia Navarro and featuring Marilyn Zschau as Tosca. Their performance drew rousing applause that brought Mr. Domingo back for an encore of ''E lucevan le stelle.''

title: Reagan Insists He Never Saw Contra Fund Memo
description: President Reagan insisted today that he had not received a memorandum last year outlining the diversion to the Nicaraguan rebels of proceeds from the Iran arms sales.

title: GANDHI IS CHALLENGED IN HINDU STATE NEAR PUNJAB
description: Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi's forces face a formidable challenge in an election campaign in the politically sensitive northern state of Haryana.

title: CUBS WIN, BUT LOSE DUNSTON
description: Steve Trout, backed by home runs from Jerry Mumphrey and Dave Martinez, came off the disabled list today and pitched the Chicago Cubs to a 7-2 victory over the Philadelphia Phillies.

title: Gift-Giving Check Planned
description: The American Express Company announced yesterday that it would be introducing a new product during the Christmas gift season - a traveler's check gift certificate.

title: A Wedtech Defendant Enters a Not Guilty Plea
description: The former law partner of Representative Mario Biaggi pleaded not guilty at his arraignment on Federal racketeering and extortion charges yesterday after answering questions in court exploring his competancy to stand trial The former partner, Bernard G. Ehrlich, was indicted on June 3, along with Mr. Biaggi, Democrat of the Bronx, Mr. Biaggi's son, and four other defendants on Federal charges of turning the Wedtech Corporation, a Bronx military contractor, into a criminal racketeering conspiracy.

title: DOWNTOWN SEOUL IS CALMER, BUT A CRISIS MOOD PREVAILS
description: A measure of calm returned to downtown Seoul today, but tension remained high as battles between radical students and riot policemen spread elsewhere in the capital and other cities.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: WEDNESDAY, JUNE 17, 1987
description: International A3-18

title: Song and Dance and Politics: The Capitol Steps
description: ''Some Washingtonians reach for the newspaper each morning and worry about the fate of the Western world,'' said Elaina Newport, ''but we worry about what rhymes.''

title: JUDGE HAS WIDE DISCRETION IN SENTENCING
description: Although Bernhard H. Goetz, in theory, faces a minimum sentence of one year in prison for his conviction yesterday on a gun-possession charge, the law gives the judge wide discretion in imposing sentence.

title: Trade Deficit Down 2.3%
description: The deficit in the broadest measure of United States foreign trade showed a slight improvement in the first three months of this year, but it was not enough to keep the country from plunging further as the world's largest debtor, the Government said today, The Commerce Department said the imbalance in the nation's current account narrowed to $37.12 billion in the January-March quarter, down 2.3 percent, from a record deficit of $38 billion in the final period of 1986.

title: TAKEOVER LAW LAGS
description: Facing opposition from lawyers and business people, an influential group of the Delaware Bar Association has decided not to introduce corporate takeover legislation.

title: KEY RATES
Stores Reopen in Panama as the Crisis Eases
description: At one of the busiest corners in the uptown shopping and banking section, McDonald's opened today and many passers-by took it as a sign that the political crisis was coming to an end.

title: TEXAS MILLIONAIRE GAINS IN TAX CASE
description: The tangled financial affairs of Cullen Davis, the millionaire Texas industrialist, and his former wife, Priscilla, have been slightly clarified at the expense of the Internal Revenue Service.

title: WINE TALK
description: ON June 4 - 105 years, 5 months and 29 days after Giuseppe and Pietro Simi paid $2,250 in gold coins for a winery on Front Street in Healdsburg, Calif. - their successors spent $10,185 on a retrospective tasting of 23 premium Simi wines held in a hotel ballroom overlooking Madison Avenue in New York City.

title: Ex-Bank Official in Shift
description: Thomas A. Cooper, who resigned as president of the BankAmerica Corporation last month, is expected to be named the chief executive of the ISFA Corporation, a Tampa, Fla., company that operates stock brokerage and insurance sales programs for banks and thrift institutions, according to a banking industry source. Mr. Cooper, who said he had resigned to pursue other business interests, could not be reached for comment. A spokesman for the Florida company said that a statement on a new chief could come as early as Wednesday.

title: On Trade With Korea
description: The wave of anti-Government protests in South Korea has given new impetus to the campaign by a group of Democrats in Congress for trade sanctions against Seoul. The hope is that sanctions, or the threat of them, will press President Chun Doo Hwan to make political reforms.

title: Blast Kills Arab in Israel
description: An Arab man was killed today in Petah Tikva, a suburb of Tel Aviv, when a bomb exploded in his hands, apparently as he was trying to plant it in an abandoned car, the police said. Another explosive device was discovered and safely dismantled in the crowded central bus station in Tel Aviv, the Israeli radio said.

title: Cartoons' Voices on Strike
description: The actors who supply the voices for the three networks' Saturday morning cartoon shows have struck over a year-old contract dispute. The walkout Monday, affecting about 40 cartoon shows, was the first ever against Hollywood's top five animation studios - Disney Studios, Filmation, DIC, Hanna-Barbera and Marvel.

title: JAZZ: TWO QUARTETS
description: MUSICIANS whose attitudes toward improvisation were shaped by jazz experience in the 50's and 60's, and musicians influenced by the broader range of musical sources available in the 70's and 80's, collaborate in the Black Swan Quartet and the Muhal Richard Abrams Quartet. The two groups shared a program in the World Music Institute's Improvisations concert series on Saturday at Merkin Concert Hall, 129 West 67th Street.

title: 3-Part Offering By First Boston
description: The First Boston Corporation is offering $270 million of fixed-rate and floating-rate collateralized mortgage obligations that are divided into three issues.

title: Does Indian Museum Fit Into Old Custom House?
description: To the Editor:

title: IN THE JUNGLE OF FOOD REGULATIONS, CONGRESS AND STATES CLEAR A PATH
description: WHEN President Reagan took office, high on his agenda was reducing the Government's deficit and its regulatory powers. To that end, budgets for most Federal agencies were cut and regulatory activities reduced. The Food and Drug Administration and the Agriculture Department have issued fewer regulations on health and nutrition than in previous Administrations. The Federal Trade Commission, charged with regulating advertising, has brought few cases involving nutrition claims in advertisements.

title: JWT BOARD WAS GIVEN A TROUBLING REPORT
description: In an appearance before JWT Group Inc.'s board in January, Joseph W. O'Donnell, then the recently appointed chairman of JWT's J. Walter Thompson Company, presented a letter with a list of 10 suspected financial irregularities he had found in the operation.

title: U.S. Filling Trade Post
description: President Reagan plans to nominate Charles Cobb to be Assistant Secretary of Commerce for Trade Development, succeeding Harold Goldfield, the White House said today. Mr. Cobb, 51 years old, is chairman and chief executive officer of the Arvida Disney Corporation in Miami.

title: FOODNOTES
description: Tips on Poultry

title: 11 STATES SEEK RIGHT TO RESTRICT GUARD'S TRAINING
description: Eleven states have come to Federal District Court here seeking to overturn a law that denies them the right to prevent foreign training for National Guard troops.

title: LANNY WADKINS IS READY TO ATTACK
description: Walking quickly from shot to shot and pausing only a few seconds before taking each of his fast swings, Lanny Wadkins is the most exciting player on the PGA Tour when he is in the hunt. The 37-year-old Texan is up there often enough to make golf a lot more fun to watch than it is when another player takes forever to play a shot.

title: Interest Rates Little Changed
description: Interest rates were stable yesterday as the credit markets were beset with uncertainty about the future of the dollar and the American economy.

title: 'Predator' Places First In Weekly Ticket Sales
description: ''Predator,'' the latest action film by Arnold Schwarzenegger, earned $12 million in ticket sales in its debut weekend to take over first place at the box office.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: IN SEARCH OF MELANCHOLY BABY. By Vassily Aksyonov. Translated by

title: Reagan's Greatest Hits
description: It was one of the stranger speeches of the Reagan Presidency. With a good script in his hands, Ronald Reagan is still the Music Man. Like the hero of Meredith Willson's musical, he can still inspire River City to buy band instruments for the kids, and uniforms too. But Tuesday's was an old script. What the nation heard sounded like one of those $9.95 albums, one familiar tune modulating into another, recapping an artist's career.

title:
FOOD AND FITNESS;
Vichyssoise, Nearly
description: LEAD: WHEN gazpacho, one of summer's leading soups, is made in the classic fashion, it is a solid nutritional citizen. Vichyssoise, sorry to say, is not in the same boat: this famous cold potato and leek soup contains large amounts of cream - and therefore fat.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: On the Waterfront

title: QUARANTINE LIFTED IN AIDS CASE, BUT THE BOY INVOLVED IS CONFINED
description: A judge today lifted a quarantine that had confined a 14-year-old boy to a mental ward to prevent him from spreading AIDS, but the judge refused to let the youth go home.

title: THEATER: 'SELF-DEFENSE' STARTS REGIONAL SERIES
description: IN Joe Cacaci's ''Self Defense,'' America's system of justice stands accused of favoritism, inequity and human fallibility. The play, which opened the American Theater Exchange season at the Joyce Theater last night, is as topical as today's headlines.

title: 9 Venezuelan Guards Killed In a Battle With Colombians
description: Nine Venezuelan national guardsmen and as many as 30 Colombians died in a recent battle near the Colombian border when the guardsmen were ambushed during an anti-drug patrol, Government officials said today.

title: FACTORY PRODUCTION RISES 0.5%
description: Output at the nation's factories, mines and utility companies rose a healthy five-tenths of 1 percent in May - its largest increase in three months, the Federal Reserve Board said today.

title: STAGE: 'TALKING DRUM,' HONORING BLACK WOMEN
description: IN ''Her Talking Drum,'' Vinie Burrows's theatrical collage evoking the universal experience of black women, the human voice emerges mystically out of the chaos of nature. As the piece opens, the stage lights dawn on the show's four performers - Ms. Burrows, Kim Staunton, Hattie Winston, and the percussionist Madeleine Yayodele Nelson - humming against a soundtrack of tropical night noises. The hums quickly turn into chants and the chants into poems, prayers, and stories narrated and sung by the three speakers.

title: Henry D. Baer Is Dead; Ran Cutlery Company
description: Henry D. Baer, a retired president of the Schrade Cutlery Corporation, a manufacturer of pocket and hunting knives, died Sunday in his Manhattan apartment. He was 88 years old.

title: LEACH'S VICTORY BRINGS HIS RECORD TO 5-0
description: It was opening day at Shea Stadium and the 1986 world championship pennant had been sent up the flagpole for the first time. One by one, most of Terry Leach's Met teammates had accepted their rings, and tried them on, and held them in the air. Leach's eyes wandered around the clubhouse.

title: SMITHSONIAN GIVES LIFE TO OLD DINER
description: A New Jersey greasy spoon is about to slide into the Smithsonian Institution.

title: THE FRENCH MEET THE CHOCOLATE CHIP
description: LEAD: PARIS, June 16 -

title: Girls, Babies and Schools
description: New York City's Board of Education has a chance today to act with calm and sense on an issue of widespread interest that is charged with inflaming emotion: birth control counseling in the schools.

title: Electronics Gap Shrinks
description: The United States electronics products trade deficit with both Japan and the rest of the world declined significantly in 1987's first quarter, the American Electronics Association said today. The trade group said the United States' first-quarter trade deficit in electronics with Japan dropped to $4.6 billion, from $5.2 billion in the first quarter of 1986. It said the nation's electronics deficit with the rest of the world fell by more than 19 percent, to $2.5 billion, from $3.1 billion.

title: Redskins' Owner Gets TV Systems
description: Jack Kent Cooke, the owner of the Washington Redskins football team, said that he would buy First Carolina Communications Inc.'s 21 cable television systems. First Carolina's systems serve about 156,000 customers in Tennessee, Georgia, North Carolina, South Carolina, Kentucky and Arizona.

title: Hearns Threatened
description: Thomas Hearns will lose his ranking as the No. 1 middleweight contender by the International Boxing Federation, an I.B.F. spokesman said yesterday after a United States District Court judge in Detroit dismissed Hearns's restraining order. Judge Robert E. DeMascio made the ruling Monday.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: ONE day in May, Myra Burroughs was among those jammed into a room of State Supreme Court on Centre Street in lower Manhattan. Ms. Burroughs, along with the others, was waiting for her name to be called for jury empanelment. It was not the liveliest of occupations.

title: Moody's Keeps 3 Bank Ratings
description: The debt ratings for the Mellon Bank Corporation, the Bankers Trust New York Corporation and the National Westminster Bank were reaffirmed yesterday by Moody's Investors Service.

title: The Lure of Pork Rind
description: In case you haven't noticed, the venerable pork rind bait, a consistent fish catcher for more than half a century, is now being offered in many new sizes, shapes and colors.

title: Bridge: Many Declarers Fail to Take A Good Look at the Dummy
description: Most players know in theory that as declarer it is wise to take a good look at the dummy before making a move. In practice they often charge ahead after insufficient thought, discovering too late that they have planned poorly.

title: 'COUCH PEOPLE': HIDDEN HOMELESS GROW
description: It was almost 11 P.M. The streets in the Brownsville section of Brooklyn were dark and quiet as Jackie, who had recently been evicted, moved her belongings into her sister's apartment in a public-housing project.

title: I.B.M. Offers Software In Computer Networks
description: In its latest step to connect disparate computers, the International Business Machines Corporation yesterday introduced a host of communications software products that it said would make it a much fiercer competitor in telecommunications.

title: TAKING THE MEASURE OF THE REAGAN MANTLE
description: Where will all the Reaganauts go next year?

title: COLLECTIONS AIDE TELLS OF PAYING MANES PARTNER
