description: A partner of a collection agency that worked for the New York City Parking Violations Bureau testified yesterday that he paid more than $150,000 to the law firm of a former partner of the late Donald R. Manes.

title: Playing From Weakness
description: President Reagan has chosen an odd time to pick a fight with Congress. At no time in his long and now waning Presidency has he been in a weaker position, and everything he wants to achieve in his remaining months depends on the cooperation of the House and Senate.

title: INVESTOR EAGERNESS IN SUPERCONDUCTORS
description: IN venture capital circles, where major scientific advances pump up investment activity the way adrenalin sets the human pulse racing, recent breakthroughs in the esoteric field of superconductivity are sparking visions of new riches.

title: The Best of the Crop
description: WITH at least 250 specialty foods produced in Oregon, it is hard to keep track of the delicacies without a scorecard. Following are some catalogues and products that can bring some of Oregon's best to anyone's doorstep. CATALOGUES Harry and David, 2518 Pacific Highway, Medford, Ore. 97501; 503-776-2121.

title: 1,200 Maine Workers Strike International Paper Co. Plant
description: Twelve hundred union members went on strike today against the International Paper Company's Androscoggin mill. Gov. John R. McKernan Jr. urged both sides to continue negotiations.

title: Phone Rate Cut Is Approved
description: An agreement that will provide customers of Southern New England Telecommunications Corporation with credits and rate decreases valued at $54.5 million through 1988 was approved today by the State Department of Public Utility Control. Under the agreement, monthly billing credits for each local exchange telephone line will be distributed starting next month. A $3.20 one-time credit will be issued in July, followed by a $2 one-time credit in December, and a credit of 50 cents per month from July 1987 to December 1988. The credits will total $14.20 per line, or $23 million overall.

title: SENATOR ASSAILS AGENCY ON LAG IN MINE SAFETY
description: The Mine Safety and Health Administration today faced renewed bipartisan charges of lax safety enforcement and of delays in making promised changes in regulations.

title: Regret From Rodman
description: For the first time since he started the controversy on May 30, Dennis Rodman, a Detroit Pistons' rookie, has said he was sorry for calling Larry Bird of the Boston Celtics ''way overrated'' because he is white. But that doesn't necessarily mean Rodman's changed his opinion.

title: U.S. NAVY DEFENSE IS ON HAIR TRIGGER ON ESCORT IN GULF
description: American naval forces escorting merchant ships in the Persian Gulf are operating under hair-trigger rules of engagement, with the crews often manning battle stations and prepared to shoot before they come under fire, the Pentagon said in a report to Congress that was made public today.

title: Brazil Stocks Soar
description: Brazil's stock markets soared today in a show of enthusiasm for a price freeze plan announced by the Government last Friday evening. The Sao Paulo stock market, the country's biggest, stood 21.5 percent above Friday's closing, with the Bovespa index at 8,995 against 7,134 at the end of last week. The stock market in Rio de Janeiro rose 14 percent. The plan includes authorizing steep price rises for bread, milk, electricity and other items.

title: JUDGE LINKED TO MYERSON STEPS ASIDE
description: The judge who is under investigation for her ruling in a divorce case in which Bess Myerson had an interest is suffering from a heart ailment and has stepped down from the bench temporarily, the judge's lawyer said yesterday.

title: THE DANCE: NUREYEV'S 'CINDERELLA'
description: IN Rudolf Nureyev's ''Cinderella,'' a new ballet set in Hollywood, the fairy godmother is transformed into a movie producer and his name, according to the program, is Pygmalion Diaghilev.

title: GOVERNOR SIGNS A BILL ALLOWING FOR COURT CAMERAS
description: Governor Cuomo signed legislation today to allow news cameras in many New York courtrooms for the first time.

title: OREGONIANS MARKET THE FRUITS OF THEIR AGRICULTURAL EDEN
description: One day recently, John Ullman perched on a rock near the mouth of the mighty Columbia River in Oregon and ate a small mountain of sturgeon caviar. ''It was, literally, that day's catch,'' he said happily later. ''Where else could I be doing this?''

title: Air Traffic Computers Falter, Causing Delay of 131 Flights
description: Computers that control air traffic in the Chicago area broke down over the weekend, delaying 131 flights for periods ranging from 27 minutes to more than an hour and a half, the Federal Aviation Administration says.

title: The Pop Life
description: Waters's Dark Side

title: Market Place; Pinning Down Insider Trading
description: DETERMINED to help police Wall Street, Congress is about to propose clearer guidelines to the investment community on just what constitutes illegal trading activity.

title: REAGAN ASKS SHIFT IN BUDGET PROCESS
description: President Reagan sought to give his weakened Administration a political lift today by starting a personal campaign to change Congressional budget procedures.

title: INQUIRY ON CLEVELAND PAPER ENDS WITHOUT CHARGE
description: The Justice Department said yesterday that a grand jury investigation into whether antitrust law was violated in the closing of The Cleveland Press in 1982 has been concluded with no charges being filed.

title: Massachusetts Utility Offers High Bond Yields
description: The Massachusetts Municipal Wholesale Electric Company is offering an unusual package of high-yielding tax-exempt and taxable bonds through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

title: The Zero Factor
description: Bert Blyleven's shutout against the Milwaukee Brewers on Monday night was the 55th of his career and lifted him into a tie with Steve Carlton for third place in shutouts by active pitches. The top 10: Tom Seaver 61 Don Sutton 58 Bert Blyleven 55 Steve Carlton 55 Nolan Ryan 54 Tommy John 45 Phil Niekro 45 Jerry Reuss 37 Joe Niekro 29 Frank Tanana 28

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: WITHIN the past few months, I offered a recipe for preparing and cooking sweetbreads in less than an hour. It surprised many readers that sweetbreads can cook in such a short time. It is done, however, by eliminating a refinement: the overnight soaking that makes the flesh whiter.

title: Inside
description: Stocks Rally to a Record

title: Maxwell Plea On Harcourt
description: Robert Maxwell, apparently still interested in acquiring Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, the book publishing company, yesterday asked stockholders in his British Publishing and Communications Corporation to put up $1 billion to finance his bid for the United States publisher.

title: USA Today Posts Its First Profit
description: USA Today, the Gannett Company's flagship national newspaper, posted its first monthly profit ever in May, six months ahead of schedule, Gannett's president, John Curley, said. USA Today, the colorful newspaper that had been losing money since it was founded in September 1982, had a $1.1 million operating profit in May, compared with a loss of nearly $900,000 the previous month, Mr. Curley said. The breakthrough to profitability ''confirms that USA Today is here to stay,'' he said at a news conference.

title: Divorce for Gov. Blanchard
description: Gov. James J. Blanchard said today that he and his wife of more than 20 years were getting a divorce because of long-standing irreconcilable differences. Mr. Blanchard's wife filed the action today in Ingham County Circuit Court. Mr. Blanchard, 44 years old, a Democrat, was elected to his second term last November. The couple asked the court for joint custody of their 16-year-old son, Jay.

title: A Rainbow Of Produce: Pots of Gold
description: WHEN Andrew D'Amico cooked for a party of Mobil Corporation executives, he served purple potatoes. ''There were a lot of weird comments,'' said Mr. D'Amico, the executive chef at the Sign of the Dove in Manhattan. ''The first thing people think is that the potatoes have been shot full of chemicals.''

title: MEANWHILE, THE PROTESTS RIPPLE ACROSS KOREA
description: The student protests that have gripped Seoul for the last week have been echoed in this southeastern port city and in other major cities around the country.

title: Joe Pytka and B.B.D.O. Big Winners at Clios
description: Joe Pytka of Pytka Productions, Venice, Calif., who was described in Madison Avenue magazine as ''the most sought-after director'' for commercials, was rewarded this week Monday night with nine statuettes at the Clio TV Awards. The event was held at the New York State Theater at Lincoln Center.

title: BECKER FACES EARLY CHALLENGE
description: Top-seeded Boris Becker, seeking a third consecutive men's championship at Wimbledon, drew a tough first-round opponent today, while Ivan Lendl, seeded second, got a bit of a break.

title: FLORENCE E. MATTSON
description: Florence Evelyn Mattson, the mother of Walter E. Mattson, president of The New York Times Company, died yesterday at the Forbes Regional Health Center in Monroeville, Pa. She was 85 years old and lived in Pittsburgh.

title: Plan of Action
description: Because he wants to ''rewrite the laws and change the ills of society,'' the Jets' Harry Hamilton, a safety known for his intense willingness to hit others on the field, has started law school.

title: For Chemcapital Head, New Role, New Risks
description: Suresh Bhirud, the former chief investment strategist at the First Boston Corporation, is ready to practice what he has preached. ''Instead of just giving advice to other people,'' he said yesterday, ''I will be putting my neck on the line and managing other people's money.''

title: For Asian Bloc, Old Issues and More Refugees
description: For more than half its 20 years, the Association of Southeast Asian Nations has been preoccupied with Indochina, first over Hanoi's conquest of South Vietnam and then over its invasion and occupation of Cambodia.

title: Light Drill for Mattingly
description: Don Mattingly returned to the Yankee clubhouse yesterday and began light workouts, but he said the back injury that put him on the 15-day disabled list nearly two weeks ago would force him to take a precautionary approach to his comeback.

title: WALL ST. WATCHES SOUTHLAND
description: The Southland Corporation, the operator of the 7-Eleven convenience stores, told the New York Stock Exchange yesterday that it was studying various strategic alternatives typical of ''many other companies whose stock is the subject of rumors.'' The company's stock soared on the disclosure.

title: Allegis to Rename Card
description: When the Allegis Corporation, owner of United Airlines, sells its hotel and auto rental businesses, the company will rename its credit card, which was introduced last month as the Allegis First Card. The new name will be Mileage Plus First Card.

title: YANKESS GET ORIOLE GIFT
description: Officially, it will go down as an infield single. But the play that helped the Yankees beat the Baltimore Orioles last night was simply a mental error. Even Alan Wiggins conceded that point.

title: 2 ARE CHARGED WITH STEALING UNION FUNDS
description: A money broker and a financial consultant were arrested on Long Island yesterday and charged with stealing about $16 million from two union pension and welfare funds. Federal authorities called it the ''largest criminal union fraud scheme'' ever prosecuted by the Justice Department.

title: PROBATION OFFICERS' CASELOADS TO BE CUT
description: The New York City Probation Department will cut the caseloads of probation officers to 150, from 210, as part of a broad program announced yesterday to revitalize the long beleaguered agency.

title: LOSS SEEN AT FIRST BOSTON
description: The First Boston Corporation, one of Wall Street's largest securities houses, said yesterday that it expected to report a second-quarter loss because of the steep trading losses it suffered when bond prices plunged in April.

title: Senator Helms and the Guilty Victims
description: In the faraway land of Erewhon, where Samuel Butler derided the hypocrisy of Victorian England, crime was treated as a regrettable malady and health was promoted by vigorously punishing the sick. Imagine the satirist's despair if he could see the Reagan Administration's reaction to the AIDS epidemic.

title: Home Loan Banks' $2.6 Billion Issue
description: Two-year and five-year bonds totaling $2.6 billion are being offered by the Federal Home Loan Banks through various securities dealers.

title: Commings and Goings
description: Two football players will be declared ineligible for intercollegiate athletics because they signed contracts with the sports agents, Norby Walters and Lloyd Bloom, The Atlanta Constitution reported. The newspaper said, however, its sources would not disclose the names of the athletes, who are teammates, or their schools. . . . Larry Bowa, manager of the team with the worst record in the majors, likely won't receive the early contract extension he had wanted, Chub Feeney, the new San Diego Padres president, said yesterday.

title: Bristol-Myers Ends Scimed Bid
description: The Bristol-Myers Company, a leading drug and toiletries company, called off a plan to acquire Scimed Life Systems Inc. because of a patent infringement lawsuit against the medical products company, Scimed's president, Dale Spencer, said. The news sent Scimed shares down $9.75, to $13.25, in over-the-counter trading. Mr. Spencer said the lawsuit charging Scimed was guilty of patent infringement was without merit. Bristol-Myers shares on the New York Stock Exchange rose 62.5 cents, to $51.25. Officials of Bristol-Myers were not available for comment.

title: White UMass Students Plead No Contest in Racial Brawl
description: Three white students at the University of Massachusetts pleaded no contest today to reduced charges stemming from a campus fight between whites and blacks after the final game of the World Series last year.

title: Chrysler Picks Lockhart For Minority Campaign
description: For the first time, the Chrysler Corporation has appointed an agency specializing in advertising to minority markets. It is Lockhart & Pettus.

title: DENVER MAYOR RE-ELECTED IN CLOSE RUNOFF CONTEST
description: Federico Pena, the city's first Hispanic Mayor, narrowly won re-election today over his Republican challenger, Don Bain, in a runoff marked by bitter clashes over both candidates' advertisements.

title: SLOVENES OF YUGOSLAVIA SPEAK FREELY AND THRIVE FINANCIALLY
description: In this most open of Communist countries, the capital of the Slovenian Republic is the most open city and the most prosperous.

title: World's Safest Air Traffic System Is Getting Safer
description: To the Editor:

title: Gencorp Gets Offer For Its Tire Unit
description: Gencorp Inc. said yesterday that it had received an offer from the management of its General Tire and Rubber Company unit to purchase the subsidiary in a leveraged buyout. The price was not disclosed.

title: Economic Scene; A New Battle Of the Budget
description: DESPITE his satisfaction with the overall achievements of the Venice summit parley, President Reagan informed his television audience, ''Honesty compels me to tell you about one disturbing topic in our discussions there, and that was the continuing threat of deficit spending.''

title: 15.81 RISE PUTS DOW AT A HIGH
description: The stock market, which until a few days ago had been consigned by many on Wall Street to a lethargic ''trading range,'' broke through to new highs yesterday.

title: KNICKS IN NO HURRY TO HIRE
description: Time, apparently, is not of the essence for the Knicks.

title: Death of Key Witness
description: In the wake of the death of Johnny High, a former Phoenix Suns' player, in an automobile accident over the weekend, an Arizona judge has dismissed one count each against three defendants in a case involving drugs. James Keppel, a deputy Maricopa County Attorney, sought the dismissal of counts against James Jordan, manager of a nightclub in Phoenix; Terry Kelly, a waiter at a Phoenix restaurant, and Mike Bratz, a former Suns' player. Keppel said that High was an essential witness against the three, but even with the dismissal of the conspiracy counts, each still faces additional counts.

title: ANOTHER SMALL STEP TAKEN BY SEAVER
description: Pitchers were playing the outfield. For a while, Dave Johnson played first base. There were five outs in one inning of a simulated baseball game that would help determine how soon - or if -Tom Seaver can conclude his career with the Mets.

title: LIFE IN THE 30'S
description: LIKE many American women, I know a good bit more than I'd like about birth control, much of it garnered from books, magazines, telephone calls to friends and raunchy conversations at bridal showers.

title: A Fearful Dilemma for Alien Families
description: To the Editor:

title: Battle for a Cool Penn Station Is in Full Swing
description: To the Editor:

title: The Other Goetz Jury
description: By acquitting Bernhard Goetz of all but a gun possession charge, a Manhattan jury settled a narrow debate over his justification for shooting down four teen-agers on a New York City subway train. But this case also puts broader questions to a larger jury, composed of everyone concerned about crime, anger and fear. Those questions endure.

title: LAUGHTER AS A BALM FOR PAIN
description: FOR all its merriment, laughter has taken its knocks over the years. Plato maintained that laughter was improper for dignified men.

title: That F.B.I. Vacancy
description: Senior Republicans on Capitol Hill are seething over the Administration's delay in nominating a new director for the Federal Bureau of Investigation. And, according to Republican staff members, they have told the White House in no uncertain terms that if a nomination is not made within a month, President Reagan can look forward to a bitter and protracted partisan wrangle over the next F.B.I. chief that may drag into next year.

title: U.N. MIGHT STAVE OFF TROUBLE IN BURUNDI
description: To the Editor:

title: Water Main Break Causes West Side Disruptions
description: Traffic on Columbus Avenue at 79th Street waiting to detour around a three-block section of the avenue closed because of a water main break. The fracture in the 48-inch, low-pressure pipeline flooded basements, knocked out some telephone service and disrupted morning rush-hour traffic. (NYT/Chester Higgins Jr.)

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: SUMMERTIME can be hard on the ears. Warm-weather activities and travels place the nonauditory parts - the middle ear and external ear canal -especially at risk.

title: GUN COUNT UPHELD; GOETZ JURORS FOUND BOTH SIDES' EVIDENCE DIFFICULT TO ACCEPT
description: In the end, after all the 10,000-odd pages of testimony over seven weeks, the four-woman, eight-man jury in the trial of Bernhard H. Goetz was never convinced that he was guilty of anything more serious than illegal possession of a gun, jurors said last night.

title: KOCH SEEKS HELP TO PAY AIDS COSTS
description: Mayor Koch proposed today that the Federal Government divide the country into health-care districts so cities can share the costs of treating AIDS patients with surrounding areas.

title: Glory That Was Copper Lets Zambia Down
description: Between this central Zambian city and Kitwe, another copper-mining center about 30 miles west, lies a rarity in Africa: a four-lane divided highway.

title: New Deal for Gretzky
description: Wayne Gretzky, the 26-year-old Edmonton Oilers' captain who hinted last week that he might retire, has signed a five-year playing contract extension with the team.

title: FOES OF APARTHEID SEE MAJOR GAIN
description: Citibank, long a vocal opponent of corporate withdrawal from South Africa, gave in to the trend yesterday and said it would sell its subsidiary there.

title: HART AIMING TO KEEP HIS IDEAS ALIVE
description: Gary Hart is planning a return to public life as a man of ideas, but not as a candidate, he has told aides.

title: A 'GET RICH QUICK' STAR FALLS
description: Albert J. Lowry, the best known and most successful of the get-rich-quick artists who flourished from the late 1970's well into the 1980's, apparently never absorbed the lessons of financial discipline and security that he preached.

title: There's a New Wrinkle at the Zoo
description: No, this is not I.B.M.'s secret new computer memory device.

title: Boland, in Print
description: It is not exactly light summer reading. But the price is right, and the topic could hardly be hotter.

title: HONG KONG PROGRAM: ADDICTS WITHOUT AIDS
description: Lee Ping is a wizened 72-year-old heroin addict, a gaunt man who still speaks a smattering of English he learned from working with Americans in pre-Communist China.

title: G.M. Quality Accord Adds to Workers' Role
description: The General Motors Corporation and the United Automobile Workers signed an agreement last week aimed at improving the quality of cars produced at G.M. plants throughout the United States.

title: Pansophic's Leader Is Retiring at Age 42
description: The rewards of starting a successful company are many - such as retirement at age 42 with a great deal of money and a goal of playing better golf.

title: Changing of the Guard At Long, Haymes & Carr
description: Five years ago the founding triumvirate at Long, Haymes & Carr, Winston-Salem, N.C., created a plan for its succession. As a result, four executive vice presidents will be moving up at the 38-year-old agency on Sept. 1. Donald N. Adams, 50 years old, will be promoted to chairman and chief executive; Robert F. Graham, 41, to vice chairman and chief creative officer; Loren L. Chamberlain, 43, to vice chairman and chief marketing officer, and Robert E. Fly, 40, to president and chief operating officer.

title: SHOCK IN SOUTH AFRICA
description: The decision by Citibank to quit South Africa has sent shock waves through the financial community and is likely to speed the withdrawal of remaining American companies from South Africa, business people said today.

title: FRIEDMAN, SEEKING APPEAL, FAULTS HIS LAWYER'S ACTIONS
description: Attempting to reverse his conviction on racketeering and other charges, Stanley M. Friedman has argued that his trial lawyer, Thomas P. Puccio, failed to provide a full defense because of conflicts of interest.

title: HARE KRISHNA LEADER REPORTED LINKED TO SLAYING
description: Aides to the leader of the largest Hare Krishna community in North America have told investigators that he approved a plan to kill his most outspoken critic, according to the Federal and state law-enforcement authorities.

title: CARLY SIMON TRIUMPHS OVER HER OWN PANIC
description: Carly Simon, one of pop music's most notoriously stage-shy performers, gave her first public concert in seven years last week, at Gay Head, a remote community at the southwestern tip of Martha's Vineyard.

title: Soviet Seeks to Resolve Property Issues in Israel
description: Soviet officials have applied for visas to travel to Israel this summer to deal with consular issues, including Soviet-owned property, the Foreign Ministry spokesman, Gennadi I. Gerasimov, said today.

title: Eisenreich Returning
description: The Kansas City Royals last night purchased the minor league contract of Jim Eisenreich, who was forced out of the major leagues in 1984 because of a nervous disorder.

title: British Aerospace
description: British Aerospace said it had won a $32.6 million contract to build 10 commuter airplanes for Washington-based Presidential Airways. Presidential Airways has already received one of the Jetstream 31 19-seat turboprop planes and two more will be delivered this month, British Aerospace said. Four more will be delivered later this year and the remaining three next summer, the company said.

title: A PARTNER IN LAW FIRM
description: John E. F. Wood, a senior partner in the Manhattan law firm of Dewey, Ballentine, Bushby, Palmer & Wood, died Monday at his home in Scarsdale, N.Y., after a long illness. He was 83 years old.

title: Revlon Adding Fragrance Line
description: Revlon Group Inc. will acquire a number of popular Charles of the Ritz fragrances from France's Yves Saint-Laurent for about $150 million, a Saint-Laurent spokesman said today. Company sources said Saint-

title: Baltimore Newspaper Pact
description: The Newspaper Guild voted early today to accept a contract with The Sun and The Evening Sun that included a pay increase averaging 4 percent a year for the next three years. Members of the union, which represents reporters and advertising and circulation workers, will still have to pay premiums for medical benefits and workers in suburban bureaus will still be paid less, the issues that largely prompted the strike last week.

title: Red Square Interloper Visited by His Parents
description: The parents of a West German teen-ager jailed for landing a plane at the foot of Red Square spent three hours at Lefortovo Prison today, visiting their son for the first time since his May 28 arrest and talking with Soviet investigators.

title: Warwick Gets Account For BVD Underwear
description: Warwick Advertising has picked up its third new account in two weeks, BVD men's and boys' underwear from Union Underwear. Billings should be around $4 million to $5 million.

title: O'CONNOR AIDE PICKED TO HEAD SYRACUSE REGION
description: Bishop Joseph T. O'Keefe, who runs the day-to-day activities of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York as the second in command to John Cardinal O'Connor, was named yesterday by Pope John Paul II as Bishop of the Diocese of Syracuse.

title: A Special Kind Of Olympian
description: Loretta Claiborne, the fourth of seven children born to Rita Claiborne of York, Pa., was judged ''retarded'' at age 2 and six years later her mother was advised to place her daughter in an institution for mentally handicapped children.

title: WRANGLING OVER HOMELESS SHELTERS DELAYS BUDGET
description: Last-minute negotiations over Mayor Koch's plan to spend $172 million on shelters for the homeless delayed adoption last night of a $3.1 billion capital budget for public works.

title: 14-Day Detoxification Does Little or Nothing for a Drug Addict
description: To the Editor:

title: POSNER, 'NOT YOUR AVERAGE RUSSIAN'
description: WHO is Vladimir Posner?

title: A Modern Life In the House Of Medici
description: SHE is the epitome of a certain, unmistakably Italian chic. Tall, slender, handsome and quiet-spoken, on a recent visit to New York she wore a discreet string of pearls and an elegantly draped silk shirt, in sage green, selected perhaps to match the gray-green of her eyes. She carries one of the most eminent names in Italian history and is the doyenne of Badia a Coltibuono, a Tuscan wine estate that traces back its heritage a thousand years or more.

title: SOUTHERN BAPTISTS RE-ELECT CONSERVATIVE PRESIDENT
description: The Rev. Dr. Adrian P. Rogers, a conservative, was elected to a second one-year term as president of the Southern Baptist Convention today, defeating a moderate after a committee warned that the two sides must end their years of hostilities.

title: GUN COUNT UPHELD; ACQUITTAL WON IN SHOOTING OF 4 YOUTHS - PRISON TERM POSSIBLE ON WEAPON CHARGE
description: Bernhard H. Goetz was acquitted by a jury yesterday of the attempted murder of four teen-agers on a Manhattan subway train in December 1984. But the jury convicted him of illegal weapons possession for the gun used in the shootings.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Tennis Evert Advances: Chris Evert, who is trying to prevent Martina Navratilova from winning the Pilkington Glass women's grass-court tournament for the sixth consecutive year, routed Lisa Bonder, 6-1, 6-1, in the second round in Eastbourne, England, yesterday.

title: PRESBYTERIANS APPROVE PAPER ON JEWS
description: Presbyterians adopted a study paper today for establishing guidelines for Christian-Jewish relations at their annual convention here.

title: HOUSING STARTS FELL 2.7% IN MAY
description: Housing construction fell for the third straight month in May, a 2.7 percent decline that put residential building at its lowest level in 29 months, the Commerce Department said today.

title: AFTERMATH OF ITALIAN VOTE: NEW ROUND OF POLITICKING
description: Italian party leaders and commentators today emphasized the potential for the unexpected in the formation of a new government - a period of political jockeying that could last longer than the just-concluded electoral campaign.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''This has been the most difficult case of our time. There will be criticism and there will be support. But whatever is thought about your verdict, you have the confidence of the court.'' - Acting Justice Stephen G. Crane, to the Goetz trial jurors. [ A1:6. ]

title: 20 YEARS OF KURALT EXCERPTED
description: IF Charles Kuralt did not exist, it is clear he would have to be invented. He is so nice he makes Walter Cronkite look like a grouch; he is also zesty. It is hard to imagine a better traveling companion than Mr. Kuralt, and in his ''On the Road'' series the man and the moment have always met nicely. ''Twenty Years on the Road With Charles Kuralt,'' on CBS at 8 o'clock tonight, gives us the flavor. Watching it is a treat.

title: S.E.C. Inquiry on Crazy Eddie Bid
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission is investigating a recent filing made in connection with a bid to take Crazy Eddie Inc. private, according to the company's annual 10-K statement, which was filed yesterday with the S.E.C.

title: TYSON-SPINKS A YEAR AWAY
description: During the introductions before Michael Spinks chopped down Gerry Cooney the way a woodsman fells a tree, another heavyweight was identified as if he were a comma separating the Rev. Jesse Jackson and Donald Trump. ''From New York City,'' the ring announcer blared, ''Mike Tyson.''

title: FROM THE MAYOR, IN ANY LANGUAGE: A REVOLUTION
description: When he took office as Mayor in November, Jean Dore ordered the City Hall staff to open the great bronze doors that guard the front entrance to the 18th-century building in this city's Old Port district. It was a symbolic gesture, signifying the end of of the vest-pocket approach to civic administration under the departing Mayor, Jean Drapeau.

title: TUCKER DRILLING reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a $365,000 writedown of oil and gas reserves for the year, and the writedown for the quarter, the company said, is not available. c-Includes a $2,151,000 writedown of oil and gas reserves.

title: MAYORS' GROUP URGES MAJOR U.S. EFFORT ON AIDS
description: The United States Conference of Mayors today called for a heightened Federal effort to fight AIDS, arguing that the disease had become the nation's top public health problem, with its burden especially heavy on the cities.

title: PENRIL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $6,286,000 for the quarter and $6,252,000 for the 9 months.

title: VERTIPILE INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 30
description: b-Includes an extraordinary tax credit of $171,000. c-Net loss and includes income of $59,600 from early compliance with new pension accounting standards.

title: Sunday Night Trading Due
description: The Chicago Board of Trade, which initiated night futures trading in April, will begin trading certain futures and options on Sunday nights beginning in September.

title: BEAMAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 3
description: b-Net income

title: ARCHITECTURE SHOW AT THE COOPER UNION
description: Each June an exhibition of student work transforms the Cooper Union for the Advancement of Science and Art, at Seventh Street, near Third Avenue, into an eight-story, building-wide gallery. Architecture, sculpture, painting and photography projects occupy the lobbies, corridors and classrooms of the entire school. Asked just where the show was, the guard in the downstairs lobby pointed to the elevator and said, ''All over.''

title: Mariners Explain
description: Seattle Mariners officials said yesterday that they believe their director of player development, Bill Haywood, remains committed to promoting minorities within the team's front office despite a comment he made. Chuck Armstrong, the club president, and General Manager Dick Balderson met with Haywood to discuss the remark he made to a weekend meeting of the Northwest chapter of the Society for American Baseball Research. When asked about baseball's pledge to promote blacks in front-office jobs, Haywood replied: ''I told my wife to get the burnt cork, because I'm probably going to have to wear blackface from here on out.'' Armstrong said in a statement: ''Dick and I met this morning with Bill and, after a lengthy discussion, remain convinced that Bill's true convictions coincide with those of our organization.'' Haywood, contacted Tuesday night in Bellingham, site of Seattle's Northwest League club, said: ''If I screwed up, I screwed up. But it does make me angry. I'm all in favor of minorities. All minorities. But when they talk about minorities now, it all comes down to one color.''

title: JERSEY BISHOPS URGE FULL SUPPORT FOR AIDS VICTIMS
description: People with AIDS are entitled to the full range of support, services and employment opportunities the Roman Catholic Church provides, New Jersey's Catholic Bishops declared yesterday.

title: An Indian Leader
description: To The Home Section:

title: STANDARD COMMERCIAL TOACCO CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $771,000 and $1,042,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, and a loss from discontinued operations of $613,000 for both periods. c-Includes tax credits of $469,000 and $1,902,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: Merc's Gold Contract Up in 2d Day of Trading
description: Trading in the Chicago Mercantile Exchange's new gold futures contract rose markedly yesterday from its inaugural session on Tuesday.

title: 2D JAPAN OVERTURE BY BANK AMERICA
description: The BankAmerica Corporation, apparently stepping up its efforts to obtain new capital from Japan, has sent its chief financial officer there this week to meet with potential investors.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * AMC Entertainment Inc., Kansas City, Mo., a motion-picture exhibitor, said it and a private investor had agreed to buy almost 6.3 million common shares of TPI Enterprises Inc. that are held by Rank America Inc. at $6 a share. The name of the investor was not disclosed.

title: BACK-TO-BASICS PLAN SAVES STORAGE TECH
description: If all goes as expected in Bankruptcy Court on Thursday, Ryal R. Poppa, the corporate turnaround artist, can add another notch to his gun.

title: A Briton Is to Head William M. Mercer
description: William M. Mercer Inc., the largest of the concerns specializing in advising companies on employee benefits, announced yesterday that it had named Peter Coster, a Briton, to come to New York as its new president.

title:
Talking Deals;
Utilities' Gains In a Leaseback
description: LEAD: THE sale and leaseback of plants and equipment has long been a convenient way for corporations to free up capital for a plethora of better uses.

title: Jerking Us Around
description: Emir Jaber al-Ahmad al-Sabah, absolute ruler of Kuwait, must be quite a fellow. In the last year, the Emir closed the National Assembly and shut down the free press; arrested Kuwaiti Shiites suspected of supporting Iran; sent $3 billion to Iraq, and showed the Arab world how to manipulate the U.S.

title: WALDHEIM TO PAY OFFICIAL VISIT TO POPE
description: President Kurt Waldheim will pay an official visit to Pope John Paul II in the Vatican next week, the Vatican and the Austrian Government announced today.

title: Successor for Top Marine
description: President Reagan announced Tuesday that he had selected Lieut. Gen. Alfred M. Gray Jr. to succeed Gen. P. X. Kelley as Commandant of the Marine Corps. General Gray, who will be 59 years old next Monday, is a combat veteran of Korea and Vietnam who now commands the Marines' Atlantic Fleet forces.

title: U.S. IN GULF: THE INITIATIVE IS LEFT TO IRAN
description: Early next month eight American warships are to enter the Persian Gulf to protect ships flying the American flag. The flotilla will include two cruisers plus guided missile frigates and destroyers.

title: Fighting for Space
description: Newer is not necessarily better in the Senate, where the 80-year-old Russell Senate Office Building is preferred by at least some senators to the new $138-million marble and glass building named for the late Senator Philip Hart.

title: REVISED GROWTH IN G.N.P. SHOWS DOLLAR'S THRUST
description: The nation's economy grew at a rate of 4.8 percent in this year's first quarter, somewhat faster than reported previously, the Commerce Department said today.

title: STENDIG INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After extraordinary tax credits of $75,000 for the quarter and $527,000 for the 9 months; the 9 months also is after a gain of $129,000 from the reduction of estimated loss on disposal of discontinued operations. c-Net loss d-After losses from discontinued operations of $88,000 for the quarter and $212,000 for the 9 months.

title: A DRESS CODE FOR CABBIES: NO T-SHIRTS
description: New York cabbies will soon have to wear collars they can get hot under.

title: Thomson to Buy British Publisher
description: Associated Book Publishers P.L.C., the British publishing house, agreed to be acquired by the International Thomson Organization for about $:210 million, or $342 million. The successful cash offer of 730 pence, or $11.89, a share from the Canadian media concern, ends two weeks of speculation about the future of Associated Book.

title: Stocks at High in Tokyo
description: Stock prices rose to a record close on the Tokyo Stock Exchange in active trading today, spurred by Tuesday's report of a 1.2 percent growth in Japan's gross national product in the January-March quarter, brokers said. The market index rose 190.56 points, to a record closing 25,929.42.

title: Baseball Notebook; CLUBS ARE DODGING RACIAL CHALLENGE

title: Nets Sign Dawkins
description: Darryl Dawkins, the free-agent center whose back injuries over the last three seasons have limited him to 96 of the 246 regular-season games, signed a two-year contract with the Nets yesterday. The first year is not guaranteed, but the second will be guaranteed if the 6-foot-11-inch Dawkins meets certain incentives for minutes played and rebounds next season. ''If he obtains the goals outlined for him, Darryl can earn as much as $1.3 million and as little as $750,000'' each season, said Harvey Lakind, Dawkins's agent. Lakind said that Dawkins's salary would be based in part on how many games the Nets won. Dawkins played in only six games last season. He re-injured his back Nov. 13 when he slipped in the shower of his home. He underwent back surgery for a second time in his career toward the end of last season. . . . Kareem Abdul-Jabbar, the 40-year-old Los Angeles Laker center who has played a record 18 seasons, has signed a contract to play two more years for a total of $5 million. Magic Johnson, Abdul-Jabbar's teammate who was the most valuable player in both the regular season and the championship series this year, said yesterday he deserved a raise but would not demand more money. Asked about Abdul-Jabbar's contract, Johnson said: ''I just have to get paid with the best people. I don't know if $1 million a year does that . . . I'll let you know.''

title: Eisenreich Returns
description: Jim Eisenreich, who left the major leagues three years ago with a neurological disorder, joined the Kansas City Royals yesterday. Eisenreich, an outfielder, was called up from the Royals' Class AA team in Memphis, where he was leading the Southern League in hitting (.382), hits (105) and runs (60). Eisenreich has been diagnosed as having Tourette's syndrome, a neurological problem that can be treated with medication. The syndrome is characterized by involuntary facial tics and twitches of the arms and shoulders. Eisenreich takes a drug called Haldol to control his symptoms, and he said he had experienced no serious side effects.

title: Q&A
description: Q. When my forced-air heating system is turned on after being off even a few days, a dank odor comes through the ducts. Dampness is the likely source of the odor, and I would first suspect the humidifier, where algae often grow. Have yours cleaned and replace any filter elements. title: Analysis; GOETZ CASE: COMMENTARY ON NATURE OF URBAN LIFE
description: The jury's decision in the Bernard Goetz case seemed to be a verdict on the nature of contemporary urban life, churning up issues of vulnerability, rage and racial tensions that lie just beneath the surface. The acquittal of Mr. Goetz on charges of attempted murder broke no dramatic new legal ground, in the opinion of legal experts. But in the context of the national debate on the balance between self-defense and social order, it appeared to widen the circumstances that justify the use of deadly force The New York State standard governing the use of deadly force in self-defense - what a reasonable man might do if he felt similarly threatened - has not changed because Mr. Goetz was found not guilty of attempted murder. But what the verdict suggests is that juries have a more expansive concept of what is reasonable, a concept that has grown because of the impact of crime on the lives of city dwellers.
