title: TENT CITY OFFSETS PART OF EXPENSES
description: Three dozen snow white tents shine brightly alongside The Olympic Club's Lake Course as a glaring example of the commercialism that has apparently become a part of the United States Open championship.

title: THEATER: THREE MUSICALS LIVEN STAGES IN LONDON By FRANK RICH
description: In the days after ''Les Miserables'' and Robert Lindsay won their Tony Awards, the London press rejoiced nonstop over the ascendancy of the British musical on Broadway. Perhaps even the English are becoming a bit skeptical about this line of hype by now. When people talk about the ''new'' English musical, they are really talking about the output of only two people, the composer Andrew Lloyd Webber and the director Trevor Nunn. Without them, the hottest shows in town might well be ''Nunsense'' and ''Drood.''

title: Arab Emirate's Ruler Is Reported to Abdicate
description: Sharja's state radio said today that Sheik Sultan bin Mohammed al-Qasimi had abdicated as the emirate's ruler because of ''financial difficulties,'' but the Government in neighboring Dubai indicated he had been forced to step down.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE GREAT DEPRESSION OF 1990. By Dr. Ravi Batra. Illustrated. 235 pages. Simon & Schuster. $17.95.

title: DEMOCRATIC CHIEFS IN CONGRESS REACH ACCORD ON BUDGET
description: House and Senate Democratic leaders, after six weeks of frustrating negotiations, today agreed on a $1 trillion compromise budget for 1988 that puts them on a collision course with the White House over taxes and Pentagon spending.

title: Site in West Is Chosen For New Space Shuttle
description: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration said today that it would cost too much in time and money to build the replacement for the space shuttle Challenger at Vandenberg Air Force Base and that it will be assembled, as all previous shuttles have been, in Palmdale, Calif.

title: ACADEMY'S GRADUATES SHIFT GAZE TO SHORE
description: Keith Gillette, a burly 24-year-old midshipman at the Merchant Marine Academy, has spent much of the last four years training at sea.

title: BERGEN BRUNSWIG CO reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
DAIRY QUEENS FILL BIG VOID IN SMALL-TOWN TEXAS
description: The judge was stern when a young man went on trial here recently for the murder of his mother, sister and niece: Spectators were not to discuss the case at the Dairy Queen.

title: Maryland Bonds
description: Maryland is offering $144.8 million of general obligation bonds with yields ranging from 4.90 percent for those maturing in 1990 to 6.30 percent in 1997 and 6.80 percent in 2002. The underwriters are led by the Chase Manhattan Capital Markets Corporation. The issue is rated triple A by Moody's and Standard & Poor's.

title: THE STAGE: 'ROTARY NOTARY AND HIS HOT PLATE'
description: PART magic show, part mixed-media collage, part art-history meditation, Susan Mosakowski's ''Rotary Notary and His Hot Plate'' is a delightful, spinning contraption of a play chock full of wittily surreal images and propelled by Vito Ricci's elegant, snappy electronic score.

title: INVENTION, DESIGN, ENGINEERNG ASSOCIATES reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net loss

title: CUSTOMS INQUIRY FINDS DRUG BRIBES
description: A yearlong inquiry into corruption in the United States Customs Service has uncovered bribes to some inspectors who closed their eyes to drug smuggling.

title: Reagan Meets Costa Rican to Fault Peace Plan
description: President Reagan told the President of Costa Rica today that he had serious reservations about a Costa Rican peace plan for Central America, officials of both countries said today.

title: DEDUCTIONS THAT APPLY
description: WHILE the bill for setting up a home office can be steep, one consolation is that the tax code allows deduction of such costs as a business expense. Although tax reform has abolished the investment tax credit for business property, it has doubled the amount of capital costs that business owners can claim in a year.

title: Douglas Considers Stretching MD-11
description: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation is holding talks with airlines on the possibility of building a stretched version of its MD-11 advanced long-range passenger jet airplane, according to Louis Harrington, a senior executive. If the company goes ahead with construction, it hopes to have the stretched version in service by 1993, three years after the standard 276-seat MD-11 becomes operational, he said. The stretched plane would be designed to carry 430 passengers in two classes, or up to 450 in a single class, over 5,000 miles, a much shorter range than the standard MD-11.

title: ALEXANDER'S INC reports earnings for 12wks to May 2
description: b-Reflects a net charge of $1,280,000; the charge takes into account expenses from an abandoned conversion to a master limited partnership, additional real estate tax refunds and lower interest expense resulting from conversion of a debenture issue. c-Net loss d-Includes a gain of $1,408,000 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change for investment tax credits and also reflects a loss of $729,000 resulting from the closing of the company's Mohegan Lake, N.Y., store. Net sales include leased departments.

title: Group Buys 6.9% Of Cottrell Stock
description: A group led by a New York investor, Alan B. Slifka, has purchased a 6.9 percent stake in Research-Cottrell Inc. The Somerville, N.J., construction and engineering company has received a bid of $43 a share, or $293 million, from a group that includes its chairman, Peter J. Gianacakes; Allen & Company and Odyssey Partners. But two lawsuits have been filed in New Jersey seeking to block the buyout, arguing that the $43 price is not fair.

title: UNIVERSITY PATENTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $123,626 for the quarter and $829,872 for the 9 months.

title: Baltimore Utility Marketing Bonds
description: The Baltimore Gas and Electric Company is offering $100 million of 8 1/2 percent bonds due in 1997 at a price of 98.419 to yield 8.74 percent through underwriters led by Shearson Lehman Brothers.

title: FERNANDEZ AND METS FLOUNDER
description: The fans back home - the ones who not so many years ago were asked to believe in Met magic - have faithfully looked upward in the standing of the National League East. They have waited for the Mets to overcome their medical miseries and begin the inevitable comeback of a determined defending champion.

title: INSIDE
description: Who Calls Shots in the Gulf?

title: SCHWARTZ BROTHERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
EUGENE L. FUTTERMAN, ARCHITECT AND TEACHER
description: Eugene L. Futterman, an architect and teacher noted for a wide range of houses in the Hamptons, died of liver cancer Monday in Southampton (L.I.) Hospital. He was 51 years old.

title: Fletcher Challenge Sells Notes in U.S.
description: Fletcher Challenge U.S.A. Inc., a subsidiary of a diversified New Zealand industrial company, is offering $190 million of 9 1/4 percent notes due in 1997 at a price of 99.80 to yield 9.28 percent through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation.

title: RCM TECHNOLOGIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
JG INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to May 2
PHOENIX AIRPORT RANKED LOWEST ON F.A.A. TEST
description: Phoenix Sky Harbor International Airport in Arizona was identified today as the airport with the worst record of detecting mock weapons in tests of airport security by the Federal Aviation Administration.

title: Cuomo Faults Plan to Allow Larger Rises in Rent
description: Governor Cuomo, in an unusual direct appeal to the public, called tonight for the defeat of a proposal before the New York City Rent Guidelines Board that he said would lead to ''skyrocketing'' rents.

title: Accounting for Power
description: One principle pervades our constitutional system. It is the principle of accountability. Everyone who exercises power in American government must account for what he does: explain, justify, take responsibility. Accountability prevents tyranny. So the Framers believed. The principle is centrally at stake in the Iran-contra affair. For the conspiratorial adventures in Nicaragua and Iran and Washington were all designed to avoid accountability. And the same intention is evident now in the attempts to frustrate the investigations by Congressional committees and the independent counsel.

title: BARDOT SELLS HER MEMORIES TO AID ANIMALS
description: There was a poster of her in a bikini romping around the beach in St.-Tropez. There was a fiery-red Spanish dress that she wore in the movie ''A Woman Like Satan.'' And there was the 8.36-carat diamond her third husband gave her 10 years after they were divorced.

title: Advertising; Geer, DuBois Rewarded With B. Dalton Account
description: Geer, DuBois has been rewarded for its good work on the relatively small Barnes & Noble bookstores account, billing in the $1 million class. It has been given the $9 million account of the B. Dalton chain of bookstores.

title: REVLON IN NEW BID FOR GILLETTE
description: Revlon Inc. yesterday made its second takeover bid for the Gillette Company in less than a year, and both sides immediately engaged in battle.

title: Ride Victim Wasn't Secured
description: A 19-year-old woman who fell to her death from a roller coaster at the Six Flags Great Adventure amusement park was not properly strapped in, Ocean County officials said today. Michael Murray, a spokesman for County Prosecutor Edward J. Turnbach, said the woman, Karen Anne Marie Brown of Chester, Pa., was not secured under a shoulder safety harness when the Lightnin' Loops ride began. Ms. Brown fell Wednesday at 3:45 P.M.

title: Certificate Offering By BankAmerica
description: The BankAmerica Corporation is selling $300 million of certificates backed by credit-card loan receivables through a special purpose subsidiary, California Credit Card Trust.

title: EX-BANKER AND MANUFACTURER
description: Samuel Y. Gibbon, a former investment banker and medical equipment manufacturer, died of a heart attack Monday while aboard the Royal Viking Sea on a trans-Atlantic voyage to Southampton, England. A resident of Longboat Key, Fla., he was 82 years old.

title: BRUCE, ROBERT INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to March 28
Canada Mail Strike Goes On
description: Letter carriers stayed off the job today across the four Atlantic provinces, in parts of Quebec and in Vancouver as Canada's first major postal strike in six years entered its third day. Workers continued to strike in Edmonton and Victoria for the second day, but letter carriers in Montreal and Calgary, where the strike began Tuesday, returned to work. The main issue in the strike is job security.

title: Bonds Drop in Light Trading
description: Treasury bond prices fell about a point yesterday, after six consecutive days of stable or rising prices.

title: STUDENT PROTESTS GAIN IN INTENSITY IN CENTER OF SEOUL
description: All of central Seoul was turned into a battle zone tonight as the police lost control of the streets to tens of thousands of students in the worst disorders yet in South Korea's political crisis.

title: Benny Carter
description: Benny Carter, who plays alto saxophone and trumpet, is leading a quintet tonight through Sunday at Carlos 1, 432 Avenue of the Americas, at Ninth Street (982-3260). Sets begin at 9 and 11 P.M., with a 12:30 A.M. set tonight and tomorrow; there is a $10 cover with a $7 minimum at tables and a one-drink minimum at the bar.

title: FOUR CARS LEAD DETROIT PACK
description: The ''Big Four'' drivers who dominated Formula One racing in 1986, Alain Prost, Nigel Mansell, Nelson Piquet and Ayrton Senna, are again the ones to beat in the Detroit Grand Prix Sunday.

title: FILM: WERTMULLER 'NIGHT'
description: LINA WERTMULLER'S newest comedy, ''Summer Night With Greek Profile, Almond Eyes and Scent of Basil,'' isn't as bad as her ''End of the World in Our Usual Bed on a Night Full of Rain'' (1978), but it's not even in the same universe with her ''Swept Away by an Unusual Destiny in the Blue Sea of August'' (1975). The once galvanizingly funny Italian director has run out of ideas, though not words.

title: MICRODYNE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 3
description: b-Net loss c-After losses from discontinued operations of $171,000 for the quarter and $358,000 for the 6 months. The 1986 figures restated to account for the sale of a unit.

title: HONORING 7 WHO 'DO AND DO'
description: Seven outstanding black women -including Coretta Scott King, a newspaper publisher, an automobile dealer and an aerospace engineer with the National Aeronautics and Space Administration - were honored Wednesday night at a celebration at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. They were presented with the fifth annual Candace Awards, sponsored by the National Coalition of 100 Black Women.

title: TNR TECHNICAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Coffee Crop Surge Seen
description: The world coffee crop for 1987-88 is expected to reach a six-year high of 97.8 million bags, up 27 percent from last season's revised production of 77.1 million bags, the Agriculture Department said Wednesday.

title: From BankAmerica To Head of ISFA Corp.
description: Thomas A. Cooper, a former president of the BankAmerica Corporation, was named as expected to be chairman and chief executive of the ISFA Corporation, a Tampa, Fla., company that operates stock brokerage and insurance sales programs for savings and loans and banks.

title: PENWEST INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $280,000 from the sale of equipment.

title: I.R.S. Arrests Hutton Broker
description: A broker at E. F. Hutton & Company was arrested yesterday by agents of the Internal Revenue Service on charges that he helped to launder $450,000 in drug money.

title: LAWYER AND BALLET CHAIRMAN
description: Orville H. Schell Jr., a former president of the City Bar Association and chairman of the New York City Ballet, died of cancer Wednesday in Danbury (Conn.) Hospital. He was 78 years old and a resident of Redding Ridge, Conn., and Manhattan.

title: BUYOUT PIONEER QUITTING FRAY
description: Jerome Kohlberg Jr., whose name has become synonymous with one of the most important financial developments of the last decade, the leveraged buyout, has withdrawn from active participation in the firm he helped found and build into the industry's leader, Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company.

title: Allegis picks Labor Counsel
description: The Allegis Corporation, the parent company of United Airlines, announced today that it had named Stephen E. Tallent as a special labor counsel for the airline. Allegis had been seeking a new labor adviser who could help to improve relations between United's management and its labor unions, who have proposed two separate plans to take control of the airline.

title: Money Fund Assets Fall
description: Assets of the nation's 384 money market mutual funds decreased $702.4 million, to $235.75 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Assets of the 95 institutional funds increased $337 million, to $63.78 billion. Assets of the 199 general-purpose funds decreased $728.7 million, to $67.46 billion. The 90 broker-dealer funds decreased $310.7 million, to $104.51 billion. ''Continued improvements in securities market during the past week may have prompted some investors to shift dollars from general-purpose and broker-dealer funds into stocks or bond and income funds,'' said Ann Anderson, assistant vice president for research at the institute.

title: JOHN LEE HOOKER
description: John Lee Hooker will sing the blues with the Nighthawks tonight at the Bottom Line, 15 West Fourth Street (228-6300). Shows are at 8:30 and 11:30 P.M.; tickets are $12.50.

title: VISIONTECH INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 1
description: b-After tax credits of $46,000 for the quarter and $89,000 for the 6 months. c-Net loss

title: U.S. AND SOVIET PLAN STUDY OF OZONE HOLE IN ANTARCTICA'S SKIES
description: A cooperative effort to study ozone and other gases that could affect the earth's climate is being started by scientists from the United States and Soviet Union.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: Tribute to Scorsese

title: Broadway
description: Two From Cy Coleman

title: PETER STAMPFEL
description: Peter Stampfel will sing his songs with the Bottlecaps tomorrow at Speakeasy, 107 Macdougal Street (598-9670), with Suzie Unger opening. Sets are at 8:30 and 11:00 P.M.; admission is $7 with a two-drink minimum.

title: Warning on AIDS
description: On the theory that it is never too soon to learn about the potential danger of AIDS, the Department of Education is preparing a booklet on the disease. The pamphlet is intended for use by parents and teachers to inform children about AIDS. A department spokeswoman said that the pamphlet would present relevent information about acquired immune deficiency syndrome and would give advice on how the information should be presented to school-age children.

title: Willis-Drummond Duo
description: The duo of Larry Willis on piano and Ray Drummond on bass will perform tonight and tomorrow at Bradley's, 70 University Place (228-6440); on Sunday, George Coleman, a tenor saxophonist, will lead a trio with Kirk Lightsey on piano and Santi DeBriano on bass. Music begins at 9:45; there is no cover charge or minimum.

title: FILM: 'VIRUS,' A CAUSTIC AIDS SATIRE
description: SPEAKING of AIDS, as does everyone in Rosa von Praunheim's brave and vicious ''A Virus Knows No Morals,'' a sadistic research doctor (a woman) says, ''The best defense is shame.'' Someone else says that acquired immune deficiency syndrome is psychosomatic. A Marxist declares that AIDS victims ''are the proletariat of tomorrow.'' The owner of a gay bathhouse, who himself has AIDS, suppresses the distribution of so-called safe sex literature.

title: Diner's Journal
description: ALLORA, a splashy six-week-old Italian restaurant on Amsterdam Avenue, got off to a rousing but rocky start. My several visits there this month found the multilevel, pastel-dappled dining room shatteringly loud and hopelessly disorganized. The food was equally chaotic: fatuous fancy pastas, risotto with strawberries and brandy, overcooked seafood and more. The prospects were dim to say the least. Even the owner, Sal Guzay, a fashion industry executive, evidently realized the ship was listing, so he hired a consultant, Gerald Gliber, a teacher at the New York Restaurant School, to straighten things out.

title: Insurance Anachronism
description: State law requires a New York driver to carry only $10,000 in insurance for personal injury damage done by an automobile - the same level set by the Legislature nearly 30 years ago. Given the mushrooming inflation of medical costs since then, that leaves many innocent victims of driver negligence vastly undercompensated. Yet the state Senate still blocks reform.

title: SUMMIT ENERGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Includes a $10 million writedown of oil and gas properties.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Our party will work out measures to cope with the present situation, respecting as much as possible public opinion and the people's aspirations as demonstrated in recent developments.'' - Roh Tae Woo, president-designate of South Korea. [ A1:6. ]

title: CONVERGENT SOLUTIONS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss c-Includes a gain of $1,849 from a tax loss carryforward. The share earnings do not reflect shares issued in the company's initial public offering concluded in May 1987.

title: Tammy Bakker's Accusations Are 'Ludicrous,' Falwell Says
description: Tammy Bakker's tearful accusations Wednesday that officials of the PTL ministry had searched her home and sent her dogs to the pound are ''embarrassing and ludicrous'' and detract from the ministry's fight for survival, the Rev. Jerry Falwell said today.

title: Tax Revision Plan Is Set by Canada
description: Canada today announced a tax revision plan intended to end a ''crazy quilt'' of loopholes and to move some of the income tax burden to business from individuals.

title: CRENSHAW ON TARGET AT OPEN
description: Ben Crenshaw, the Texan who sinks putts from everywhere, took advantage of near-perfect golfing weather today to gain a one-stroke lead over three of the world's best golfers, including the defending champion Ray Floyd, in the first round of the 87th United States Open.

title: COMMUNICATIONS CABLE INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net loss

title: The Rift Within Canada's Constitutional Lute
description: To the Editor:

title: ART: FRENCH ACADEMICS AT THE SHEPERD GALLERY
description: IF the house occupied by the Shepherd Gallery, at 21 East 84th Street, has changed little since it was built in the late 1880's, it is only because no extraordinary measures have been taken to preserve it. The same goes for the 19th-century European art in which the gallery specializes: it comes unassisted by either 20th-century hindsight or educational officiousness. And, because of the interior's design and furnishings, the exhibitions look like the personal salons that were maintained by 19th-century collectors.

title: PENTAGON DISCOUNTS RISKS TO U.S. ESCORT SHIPS IN GULF
description: Pentagon officials and leading members of Congress said today that the risk of Iranian attack should not deter the United States from escorting Kuwaiti tankers through the Persian Gulf.

title: LED NATIONAL BANK OF DETROIT
description: Henry T. Bodman, a former chairman of the National Bank of Detroit who was a supporter of conservative research organizations, died Tuesday at the Henry Ford Hospital in Detroit after suffering a stroke. He was 81 years old.

title: 'Solstice '87'
description: ''Solstice '87,'' a performance to celebrate the summer solstice, will take place Sunday at 4 P.M. at City Hall Park. There will be music by Charlie Morrow, dance by Pooh Kaye and Gloria McLean and cameo appearances by Philip Glass, John Cage and others; it will be broadcast, along with simultaneous celebrations from Sweden, Taiwan, Italy and the South Pole, on Channel 31 and WNYC-FM, 93.9.

title: DIVI DIVI HOTELS CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Includes an extraordinary credit of $538,000.

title: Turning the Persian Gulf Into a Bridge
description: The doctrinaire view of foreign policy demonstrated by the President's reaction to recent events in the Middle East reflects his strange compulsion to express all regional quarrels in the bellicose idiom of the East-West struggle. That practice is anything but useful. Not only does it obstruct progress toward a settlement of the Middle East's complex problems, but it denies us the opportunity to explore some potentially productive approaches to the Soviet Union that evolving realities now make possible.

title: SECORD DENIES LINK TO DISLOYAL AGENT
description: Maj. Gen. Richard V. Secord denied today that he had had any financial connection with Edwin P. Wilson, the renegade C.I.A. operative convicted of smuggling arms to Libya, and charged that Congressional committees were conducting a ''continuing campaign'' to discredit him.

title: Nun Who Pioneered the Use Of Electronic Teaching Dies
description: Sister Mary Theresa Brentano, a Benedictine nun who was a pioneer in the use of electronics in the classroom, died of a stroke Sunday at the Mount St. Scholastica Convent, Atchison, Kan. She was 84 years old. In 1957, while she was principal of St. Scholastica Academy in Covington, La., she designed and put to use an electronic system for teaching children through tape recordings.

title: CSX CUTS 480 JOBS
description: CSX Transportation Inc., the railroad operator, said it expects to eliminate 480 management jobs by the end of 1987, about 10 percent of its 4,871 non-union jobs, most of which are in Baltimore and Jacksonville, Fla. The cuts are part of an effort by the parent, the CSX Corporation in Richmond, to cut costs in the face of flat freight volume, a spokeswoman said.

title: HANOI'S PRESIDENT AND PREMIER OUT
description: Prime Minister Pham Van Dong and President Truong Chinh, the last founders of the Vietnamese Communist Party still in power in Hanoi, were removed today by a vote of the National Assembly.

title: President and Chief Named by Ann Taylor
description: Michele Fortune, senior vice president and a general merchandise manager of apparel at Lord & Taylor, will become president and chief executive officer of Ann Taylor, the fashion chain operated by the Allied Stores Corporation, on July 6.

title: FILM: 'LUGGAGE OF THE GODS'
description: ''LUGGAGE OF THE GODS'' is an extremely modest comedy about the effects on the members of a North American Stone-Age tribe when, by chance, a jet airplane dumps cargo in its vicinity. It's full of fairly predictable culture-clash jokes involving such things as transistor radios, spear guns, canned food and hats decorated with plastic fruit.

title: FROM 1984, SUMMER OLYMPICS, A GOLDEN FALLOUT
description: Young people in inner-city neighborhoods here are being introduced to tennis, surfing and fencing. Disabled teen-agers are learning to play tennis and other sports on wheelchairs. And at playgrounds around the city, the 1984 Summer Olympic Games, three years after they ended, are financing recreational activities for thousands of the young.

title: Fibrous Facts
description: Eating more fiber is said to reduce the risk of heart disease, colon cancer and diabetes. But consumers seeking to follow that advice are hampered by the failure of food packagers to list fiber contents. Congress could enhance the nation's health by requiring such listings.

title: BALLET: 'CINDERELLA' NEW CASTS
description: RUDOLF NUREYEV'S ballet version of ''Cinderella'' for the Paris Opera Ballet could still use the equivalent of a play doctor - but a second and third viewing with new casts Wednesday at the Metropolitan Opera House suggest his ideas are more persuasive than first apparent.

title: MONUMENTS, PRESIDENTS AND BARBERS
description: The capital, as glimpsed through the prism of its tourist guides, is a different city from the one inhabited by the President, Congress and legions of civil servants. The familiar buildings and monuments are all there, but the history and politics dispensed aboard the buses that crisscross Washington this time of year are something else again.

title: ACCOUNTING FIRM PLANS TO LEAVE MANHATTAN
description: Deloitte, Haskins & Sells, one of the nation's largest accounting firms, said yesterday that it was moving its national headquarters out of Manhattan because of the shortage of affordable housing for its staff.

title: RESTAURANTS
description: THE refurbishing of the legendary ''21''

title: O.E.C.D. GLOOMY ON GROWTH
description: In one of its most pessimistic forecasts in years, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development predicted today that economic growth among the Western industrial nations would be a sluggish 2.25 percent over the next 18 months.

title: 'TURTLE ON THE BEACH!' CRY FADES AS COAST CHANGES
description: Under the full moon, the tracks stood out sharply in the smooth wet sand, like the tread marks of a tank that had rolled out of the surf. In excited whispers, the word spread quickly along the shore: turtle on the beach!

title: FAILURE OF BRAIN IS LEGAL 'DEATH,' NEW YORK SAYS
description: Embracing a landmark 1984 court decision, New York State yesterday adopted a new regulation expanding the definition of death to include the total and irreversible cessation of brain function.

title: PRICE CO LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 7
Don't Blink
description: Herschel Walker has been seeded first in the Subaru National Football League's Fastest Man dash competition today at the College of the Desert in Palm Desert, Calif. But in what may have been a psychological ploy common among elite sprinters, he complained yesterday of being ''overtrained'' and ''sapped of strength'' by a recent heat spell in Texas.

title: IN YONKERS ERA OF SCHOOL INTEGRATION, YEAR 1 ENDS WITH GRADUATION CHEERS
description: In a flourish of purple and white, to the electric strains of ''Pomp and Circumstance'' and frequent whoops, 422 young men and women from Yonkers today became the first seniors to graduate from Lincoln High School under court-ordered integration.

title: ALPHA 1 BIOMEDICALS reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $305,000. c-Net loss The company went public Dec. 23, 1986.

title: ENERGY OPTICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Word Is Embargoed
description: Those who closely follow trade legislation noticed recently that the word ''adversarial'' had disappeared from a trade bill being prepared by the Senate Finance Committee. The word had been used to describe trade practices by nations that were piling up huge surpluses in their trade with the United States, particularly Japan.

title: Court Backs Plan For Storage Tech
description: The Storage Technology Corporation, a leading maker of I.B.M.-compatible data storage devices and printers, said its plan for reorganization and emergence from Chapter 11 protection had been approved by the United States Bankruptcy Court in Denver. Storage Tech, which is based in Louisville, Colo., filed for protection from its creditors in October 1984 after costly diversification programs and reliability problems in its core disk drive business had driven the once-successful company deeply into the red.

title: Guilty Plea In Kickbacks
description: Keith McDermott, a former officer of the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company, pleaded guilty in Federal court in Manhattan yesterday on charges that he conspired to receive $212,000 in kickbacks while employed at Morgan and that after he left the bank he arranged for another Morgan officer, Antonio Gebauer, to receive kickbacks.

title: MARGARET SETON IJAMS
description: Margaret Seton Ijams, a former vice president of the Community Service Society, New York's oldest family welfare organization, died Tuesday in her Manhattan apartment. She was 92 years old and also lived in Lawrence, L.I.

title: Howser's Last Smile
description: About a month ago, Dick Howser was munching apple slices in the kitchen of his Kansas City home when he suddenly brightened. Three friends had arrived in a surprise visit. One was George Brett, the Royals' third baseman, then hobbling on a damaged right knee. Another was Dean Vogelaar, a Royals vice president.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Boxing Obelmejias Defeats Reid: Fighting as a light heavyweight, Fulgencio Obelmejias (49-4, 41 knockouts) handed Chris Reid (17-1-1, 16 knockouts) his first defeat when he stopped him at 1:01 of the final round of a 10-round bout last night in Felt Forum. Obelmejias knocked Reid down six times during the bout. The 34-year-old Obelmejias of Venezuela put Reid on the canvas once in the first round, twice in the third, twice in the eighth and the final time in the 10th. Earlier, Ricky Stackhouse (17-4, 9 knockouts) won the Continental Americas middleweight championship when he stopped Kevin Moley (28-3, 24 knockouts) at 47 seconds of the 10th round of a scheduled 12-round bout. Tennis Shriver Wins: Pam Shriver won her ninth match in nine days yesterday and set up a semifinal against her doubles partner, Martina Navratilova, in the Pilkington Glass grass-court tournament in Eastbourne, England. The other semifinal will be between second-seeded Chris Evert of the United States and Helena Sukova of Czechoslovakia, seeded third. The top players were in two matches because rain washed out Wednesday's play, and Shriver, seeded fourth, posted impressive victories over two seeded players, Elizabeth Smylie of Australia and Gabriela Sabatini of Argentina. Navratilova, the No. 1-seeded player beat 12th-seeded Robin White of the United States 6-4, 6-3, then defeated unseeded Isabelle Demongeot of France, 7-5, 6-3. Evert beat Wendy White, 6-3, 6-4, and Larissa Savchenko of the Soviet Union, seeded No. 13, 6-3, 6-1. Sukova beat an Australian, Elizabeth Minter, 7-5, 6-2, and Rosalyn Fairbank of South Africa, 6-7, 6-3, 8-6.(AP) Leconte Advances: Henri Leconte of France, the No. 1-seeded player, made it to the third round of the rain-plagued Bristol Trophy grass-court tournament in Bristol, England. Leconte, preparing for next week's Wimbledon championships, beat Chris Bailey of England, 7-5, 6-1, Wednesday. Another player who lost was second-seeded Ramesh Krishnan of India, a 3-6, 6-2, 9-7 loser to Wolfgang Popp of West Germany. Swimming Evans Beats Defending Champion: Janet Evans of Fullerton, Calif. overtook the defending champion, Debbie Babashoff of Mission Viejo, Calif., and finished first in the 800-meter women's freestyle event at the Mission Viejo Swim Meet of Champions yesterday. Evans swam the race in 8 minutes 40.05 seconds. In the men's 800-meter freestyle, Daniel Jorgensen of San Diego defended his title, finishing with 8:14.59. (AP)

title: COSTA RICA CRITICIZES CONTRA AID
description: The President of Costa Rica renewed his criticism today of American aid to the Nicaraguan rebels, saying it had given the Sandinista Government an excuse to be repressive and to dismiss its economic failures.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: ''FOOD!'' was the unanimous cry of dozens of children who arrived with their parents at a gala at Tavern on the Green after a performance of ''The Comedy of Errors'' at the Vivian Beaumont. The party Wednesday night, a benefit to inagurate the Friends Program at the Lincoln Center Theater, was seen by parents as a rare opportunity for a little family togetherness and by children as a chance to be part of New York's night life.

title: MEDCHEM PRODUCTS reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Memorial Service Held for Howser
description: About 1,300 people crammed into a suburban church this evening for a memorial service for Dick Howser, the former manager of the Kansas City Royals who died at 51 Wednesday after an 11-month battle with brain cancer.

title: IRISH MUSIC
description: Tony DeMarco, a fiddler,and Linda Hickman, a flutist, will play Irish music tomorrow at the Eagle Tavern, 355 West 14th Street (924-0275). Sets are at 9 and 10:30 P.M.; tickets are $5.

title: Job Displacement Study
description: The Federal Government should expand and improve job training programs and services for displaced workers and provide more income support to the workers while they are being retrained, a panel of 20 business and labor leaders, economists and educators said in a report Wednesday.

title: HORIZON GOLD SHARES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes gains from extinguishment of debt of $82,859 and $81,356 for the quarter and year, respectively; tax credits of $34,264 for the quarter and $412,264 for the year. c-Net loss and includes charges from extinguishment of debt of $4,199 and $37,578 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: FOR FIRST TIME, CUT IN CHOLESTEROL IS SHOWN TO DETER ARTERY CLOGGING
description: A team of scientists reported today the first ''clear evidence'' that a large reduction in blood cholesterol will slow and in some cases even reverse the formation and growth of fatty deposits that clog the arteries and cause heart attacks.

title: PANEL IN HOUSE BARS DISCIPLINING MEMBER WHO VIOLATED RULES
description: The House ethics committee has decided not to discipline one member for improperly keeping an aide on her Congressional payroll and has decided to investigate allegations of financial irregularities against another member.

title: MONOLITHIC MEMORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 7
description: b-Includes a pre-tax gain of $10.4 million from the sale of about 1 million shares of Cypress Semiconductor.

title: Cetus and Squibb Try Joint Venture
description: The Cetus Corporation, a leading biotechnology company based in Emeryville, Calif., said it had agreed to form a joint venture with the Squibb Corporation to develop new drugs for the cardiovascular, anti-infective and anti-inflammatory markets.

title: GENERAL INSTRUMENT CORP reports earnings for 13wks to May 31
description: b-Includes net from discontinued operations of $2,461,000.

title: Rangers Pull a Surprise: Bergeron Becomes Coach
description: The Rangers surprised the hockey world, and themselves, yesterday by naming Michel Bergeron, the longtime successful coach of the Quebec Nordiques, as their new coach.

title: ON 107TH ST., A MIXTURE OF CELEBRATION AND ANGER
description: Just 10 minutes after the wave of police officers in flak jackets poured out of buses along West 107th Street, neighbors realized they had gained a respite, an hour, a day or possibly a week, when the sidewalks might be free of the milling crowds of drug buyers and the corridor of fading tenements would not echo with chants of ''Crack,'' ''Jumbo,'' and ''Come 'ere - I got the best in the West!''

title: CENTENARIANS PRESENT NEW CHALLENGE FOR U.S.
description: The number of Americans who live to be 100 years old or more could quadruple by the turn of the century, presenting the nation with a new set of challenges, a Government study shows.

title: G.M. Extends Incentive Offer
description: The General Motors Corporation today extended most of its automobile buyer incentive programs, retroactive to Tuesday, when they were to have expired. The terms are largely unchanged, and resemble those offered by the Ford Motor Company on Monday.

title: JWT Bidder Set to Hire Ousted Thompson Head
description: John E. Peters, who was dismissed from the presidency of the J. Walter Thompson Company in January, would return as the president and chief operating officer of its parent company, JWT Group Inc., if WPP Group P.L.C.'s acquisition bid were successful.

title: Fire Check on Houston Hall
description: An inspection of Houston's City Hall, which Fire Chief Robert Clayton has said is the most dangerous building downtown, turned up 30 violations Wednesday on all 11 floors of the 48-year-old building. Even the Mayor's office, the inspectors said, had halls filled with bookcases, refrigerators and files. In the inspection, the 11th floor, the scene of a recent fire, was found jammed with old furniture and stacks of boxes.

title: Tugboat Goes Home; Garbage Barge Stays
description: After 88 days with the garbage barge Mobro, the tug Break of Dawn has left the barge in New York Harbor and headed home to New Orleans.

title: Rachel E. Fishman, 55, Dies; A Novelist and an Educator
description: Rachel Eytan Fishman, a novelist and professor of Israeli and Yiddish literature at Hofstra University, died of a stroke Wednesday at Lenox Hill Hospital in Manhattan. She was 55 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: ILLEGAL ASBESTOS WORK CITED AT MIDTOWN HOTEL
description: Workers at the Martinique Hotel in midtown Manhattan illegally ripped asbestos-coated pipes out of the basement boiler room and placed the refuse on the sidewalk, city officials said yesterday.

title: APPLIED SOLAR ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 2
description: b-Includes tax credits of $28,000 and $118,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Net loss Year-ago periods ended April 26.

title: ENZO BIOCHEM CO reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
MCDERMOTT INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $195,937,000 for the quarter and $220,568,000 for the year; a tax credit of $4,991,000 for the quarter and year and an extraordinary gain of $25,711,000 from the cumulative effect of accounting change for the year. c-Net income and after losses from discontinued operations of $5,736,000 for the quarter and $26,393,000 for the year and an extraordinary tax credit of $2,789,000 for both periods. The latest year includes an after- tax charge of $223.7 million taken in the fourth quarter related to the planned closing of the seemless tubular products division.

title: Blacks Resist Racial 'Balance' At 5 L.I. Schools
description: Jamaica Square is a small, black neighborhood in the midst of the mainly white, suburban Sewanhaka school district. In its 25 years, the Jamaica Square homeowners association has never had a visit from a Sewanhaka school superintendent. But Monday night a little before 8, the first arrived. Dr. George Goldstein needs black children.

title: DAVID NEWMAN
description: David (Fathead) Newman, a saxophonist, will lead his dance band, featuring Michele Hendricks, a singer, tomorrow at 8 P.M. and midnight at Jazztrack, 27 Barrow Street (645-2387). Admission is $12.

title: KUWAIT'S RICH, STABLE SOCIETY IS TORN BY IRAQ-IRAN CONFLICT
description: Seven years of war between Iran and Iraq have begun to tear the social fabric of this rich, oil-producing emirate in the Persian Gulf, stirring ancient animosities between Sunni and Shiite Moslems.

title: FOR KOREAN MIDDLE CLASS, A PROCESS OF POLITICIZATION
description: Kang Jung Ja, 58 years old and demure in a flowered dress and pink shoes, sat facing rows of black-helmeted riot police. Her eyebrows finely plucked and her graying hair neatly combed, she chanted slogans denouncing her Government.

title: MOTHER SENTENCED IN DEATHS
description: A woman accused of throwing six of her seven children into a bayou, where two of them drowned, was sentenced to probation today after pleading no contest to murder and attempted capital murder.

title: METS JUST HIT; Yankees 6, Orioles 3
description: Powered by the utility corps of Cotto and Kittle, the Yankees returned to the brink of first place last night. Scott McGregor, meanwhile, was shoved closer to the brink of retirement.

title: TERRANO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Ousted Fijian Premier Suspects U.S. on Coup
description: The ousted Prime Minister of Fiji said today that he had ''strong suspicions'' of American involvement in the coup last month in his Pacific island nation and called for a Congressional inquiry.

title: TELECALC INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
CULP INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 2
description: The company said in the fourth quarter of fiscal 1986 certain adjustments were made to previous quarterly estimates which increased net income in the final period by $900,000, or 20 cents a share. These adjustments related to estimates of LIFO reserves, compensation-related accruals and a revision of the effective income tax rate.

title: Chas. Young Ends Offer for Sorg
description: The Chas. P. Young Company, a subsidiary of the Service Resources Corporation, said it was terminating its $23 million merger proposal to Sorg Inc. because Sorg had failed to respond. Young and Sorg are both printing companies.

title: AIDS TESTING SEEN IN SURGERY CASES
description: Everett Koop, the Surgeon General of the United States, predicted today that testing of surgery patients for the AIDS virus would soon become routine.

title: SILENCE IS HEARTENING TO DEMOCRATS
description: Democratic senators and representatives used to cringe when President Reagan made one of his televised appeals for public support on a budget or tax issue before Congress. They knew that the telephone calls and letters would pour in and that they would have to explain over and over again why they were not giving a popular President their wholehearted support.

title: Irate Over Iran
description: Demonstrations against and, occasionally for, the regime of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini by Iranian residents in Washington are so frequent that passers-by barely bother to look up when processions wind through downtown Washington with their banners and chants. Journalists basically ignore them.

title: NEW RULES ON ZONING BACK LOWER BUILDINGS
description: New zoning rules that are meant to encourage lower and bulkier apartment buildings - the very type that proliferated before the city was rezoned in 1961 - have been approved unanimously by the City Planning Commission.

title: CONGRESSMAN ASKS REAGAN TO OUST MEMBER OF NUCLEAR PANEL
description: One of half a dozen Congressional critics who demanded that Thomas M. Roberts resign from the Nuclear Regulatory Commission appealed to President Reagan today to ''swiftly remove'' the commissioner for malfeasance.

title: DATA MED CLINICAL SUPPORT SERVICES reports earnings for Qtr to May 3
description: The company said the year-ago sales are from inception on Feb. 5, 1986 to May 31, 1986.

title: INTEGRATED BUSINESS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net loss

title: SANFORD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
2d Moscow Embassy Guard to Be Court-Martialed
description: The Pentagon announced today that a second Marine guard would be court-martialed on charges related to his assignment to the United States Embassy in Moscow.

title: Auctions
description: Tiffany Candelabra

title: THE BEARS
description: The Bears, featuring Adrian Belew on guitar, and Tirez Tirez, led by Mikel Rouse, a composer, will play a double bill tomorrow at the Ritz, with Tirez Tirez opening at 11 P.M. Tickets are $13.50 in advance, $15 tomorrow.

title: REAGAN CAUTIONS KOREAN PRESIDENT ON UNREST
description: President Reagan has sent a letter to President Chun Doo Hwan of South Korea urging him not to overreact to street demonstrations and calling for a resumption of discussions with the political opposition, a senior Administration official said today.

title: ADDITIONAL PAYMENTS TO FOMAN
description: Robert Fomon, who recently resigned as chairman of the E. F. Hutton Group, will receive $465,000 a year for life in additional pension benefits and $500,000 annually in consulting fees for up to seven years.

title: Dance Festival Tribute
description: The Wendy Osserman Dance Company is to present a tribute to the Riverside Dance Festival on Sunday at 8 P.M. at the Theater of the Riverside Church, 120th Street and Riverside Drive. The tribute is to include appearances by the Mary Anthony Dance Company, the Osserman dancers and Evelyn Shepard, all of whom have appeared at the theater, whose dance program ends Sunday after 22 years. Tickets are $7.50; $5.50 for students and the elderly. Theater Development Fund Vouchers accepted. Reservations: 864-2929.

title: SHORTER COURSE BRINGS SMILES TO SENIORS
description: A number of the players in the Northville Invitational this week had expressed fears that the length of the course would result in high scores.

title: JAZZ: BENNY CARTER
description: LOGIC says that it cannot be true that Benny Carter is still getting better and better. After all, he was one of the most influential alto saxophonists in jazz over 50 years ago and in less than a month he will reach his 80th birthday.

title: Kid Thomas Valentine, Jazz Band Trumpeter
description: Kid Thomas Valentine, the last of the ''roughhouse'' trumpet players and longtime leader of the Preservation Hall jazz band, died Tuesday night. He was believed to be 91 years old.

title: Robinson Selects Agent
description: He hasn't donned a professional uniform yet and he may not do so for perhaps another two years. But David Robinson, the 7-foot Navy graduate, is making waves in the financial sectors of basketball.

title: Whitney Proposal Wins Backing of Local Board
description: Community Board 8 voted on Wednesday night to approve two key historical landmark issues that ultimately favor the proposal of the Whitney Museum of American Art to build an addition to its building at Madison Avenue and 75th Street.

title: Bias Suit Filed
description: The news was not all good for Fentress, though, yesterday. On the eve of the anniversary of Len Bias's death, his father, James Bias, filed a suit in Superior Court in Washington seeking a total of $6.6 million from Fentress, his son's agent; an insurance company and Reebok International, the shoe company that had concluded a $1.6 million endorsement agreement with the former Maryland basketball star the day before his death from a cocaine-induced heart attack on June 19, 1986.

title: Art Works That Shouldn't Be Compromised
description: To the Editor:

description: Friday THIRD WORLD VIDEOS

title: Fair Housing Begins With Fair Advertising
description: To the Editor:

title: G.M. to Lay Off 850
description: The General Motors Corporation said today that it would lay off 850 workers for an indefinite period at two assembly plants in August as it adjusts production schedules. About 500 workers at G.M.'s Buick-Oldsmobile-Canada Group plant in Lordstown, Ohio, will be laid off on Aug. 24, and 350 workers at the Buick-Oldsmobile-Canada Group plant in Janesville, Wis., will be laid off beginning Aug. 11.

title: Major Shifts Made At Nabisco Brands
description: H. John Greeniaus, an energetic 42-year-old executive vice president at Nabisco Brands Inc., was named yesterday as president and chief executive of the big foods company, which is a unit of RJR Nabisco Inc. The appointment was one of several executive and organizational changes announced by RJR Nabisco.

title: Muller Named Captain
description: The Devils' time has finally come, said Kirk Muller yesterday, in discussing the significance of being named the team's new captain and the youngest one in the National Hockey League. ''We've been improving each year, and the last two years we started off strongly,'' Muller said. ''Now we have to do it.'' According to the 21-year-old center, it is also significant that two other former Devils draft picks, Aaron Broten and Joe Cirella, have been named associate captains. In fact, Broten, the Devils' top scorer, has signed a new three-year contract.

title: British Joblessness Off
description: Britain's unemployment total last month fell below the 3 million barrier for the first time in four years, the Department of Employment announced today. The total out of work fell from 3.10 million in April to 2.98 million in May, the biggest single monthly fall on record.

title: ART WORKS THAT SHOULDN'T BE COMPROMISED
description: To the Editor:

title: Anderson Sentence Put Off
description: Sentencing of Robert B. Anderson, a former Secretary of the Treasury and Deputy Secretary of Defense who was found guilty of bank fraud and tax evasion, was postponed until next Thursday in Federal District Court, Manhattan. Mr. Anderson, 77 years old, was to have been sentenced yesterday.

title: Conducting for Cultists: Beethoven From Kleiber
description: Tonight at 9, Channel 13 beckons cult worshipers of the conductorial art to draw a little closer. Seated at this particular shrine is Carlos Kleiber - famed for his demanding standards and rare availability for public viewing. Here he conducts the Amsterdam Concertgebouw Orchestra in Beethoven's Fourth and Seventh Symphonies.

title: INDICTMENT SAYS ATTORNEY TRIED TO OFFER BRIBES
description: A Manhattan lawyer who specializes in personal-injury cases was indicted yesterday on charges that he sought to bribe potential trial witnesses in a $7 million wrongful-death suit against New York City.

title: TRI-STAR PICTURES reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: Tri-Star changed in the latest period its fiscal year-end from Dec. 31 to the last day in February. Results of operations for the comparable prior period have been restated to reflect this change. The latest quarter includes the results of operations for Loews Theatre Management Corp., which was acquired by Tri-Star, effective Dec. 31, 1986.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Mayor Tom Bradley said he had spoken informally with International Olympic Committee officials about using Los Angeles as an alternate site for the 1988 Summer Games if the Seoul, South Korea, site must be abandoned because of political strife in that country. ''They know we have the capability of hosting the Games if that becomes a need,'' said the mayor, whose city staged the 1984 Games.

title: 2 DOZEN HELD ON DRUG CHARGES ON WEST SIDE
description: With a force of more than 200 officers, the New York City police sealed off a two-block area of the Upper West Side of Manhattan yesterday and charged two dozen people with buying or selling drugs at 16 suspected crack houses.

title: U.S. Gymnasts Compete
description: The United States Gymnastics championships began here today with 70 men and 33 women in competition that will help determine the teams in the Pan American Games in Indianapolis in August and the World Championships in Rotterdam, the Netherlands, two months later.

title: Options Rule Set for Review
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission voted today to review its restriction against the trading of options of exchange-listed securities by more than one exchange.

title: MORE TOSHIBA TOOLS SAID TO REACH SOVIET
description: Federal officials said yesterday that they now believe that the Toshiba Machine Company sent a second illegal shipment of four giant propeller milling machines to the Soviet Union in April and May 1984.

title: ART: BEVERLY PEPPER, SCULPTOR, IN 3 SHOWS
description: BEVERLY PEPPER is an American sculptor who for nearly 40 years has lived primarily in or near Rome. Rome is a charismatic place, and by all accounts Ms. Pepper is a charismatic person. She and her work have a large constituency among Americans who have fond memories of their time in Rome.

title: Jewish Festival of Arts
description: An appearance by the comedy duo of Marty Allen and Steve Rossi will highlight the 15th Jewish Festival of the Arts, to be held Sunday at the Garden State Arts Center, in Holmdel, N.J. The festival begins with a crafts and food sale at noon, followed at 3 P.M. with a three-hour show featuring Mr. Allen and Mr. Rossi. Also appearing will be Geula Gill, an Israeli singer, and Norman Atkins, a baritone. Tickets to the performance range from $5 to $14. Proceeds from the festival are to benefit various community groups and the Garden State Arts Center Cultural Fund. To reach the festival, take the New Jersey Turnpike to exit 11, then the Garden State Parkway to exit 116. Information: (201) 367-0645 or (201) 442-9200.

title: METS JUST HIT; Mets 10, Expos 7
description: Dave Johnson and Darryl Strawberry are shaking hands again, and frequently at that. At the end of a trip that began in icy silence, they shook hands at the edge of the visitor's dugout in Olympic Stadium after Strawberry's two home runs - two of the five the Mets hit in a 10-7 victory over the Expos.

title: FILM: STEVE MARTIN IN 'ROXANNE'
description: BEHIND the clownish makeup, Steve Martin gives a sweet and serious performance as a latter-day Cyrano de Bergerac in ''Roxanne.'' It's easy to see why Mr. Martin, who wrote the film and served as its executive producer, was moved to re-invent this role. The turnabout of identities must have intrigued him, with one man writing love letters in the name of another; stories about confused identities have attracted Mr. Martin a number of times before. The star-crossed romance must have been appealing, too, since Mr. Martin conveys hopeless longing very well. And the nose itself is a perfect prop for a man who began his career with a fake arrow through his head, a man who has since evolved from a coolly absurdist stand-up comic to a fully formed, amazingly nimble comic actor.

title: HE'D 'ALWAYS GO TO SCENE'
description: Two years ago today, an ABC News Middle East correspondent, Charles Glass, stood on the tarmac at the Beirut airport, shouting questions to the captain in the cockpit of a hijacked Trans World Airlines jet.

title: O'GRADY HAS A SPECIAL FAN
description: Jack Fleck, gaunt, gray-haired and wearing a light pink blazer, was virtually unnoticed as he hurried alongside the fairways at The Olympic Club today. But Mac O'Grady knew he was there. Thirty-two years ago, Fleck, almost as unknown then as he is today, pulled off one of golf's greatest upsets when he caught and beat Ben Hogan here to win the United States Open. Fleck is back at Olympic for the 87th Open this week, and the man he wants to watch is O'Grady.

title: TRADE BILL PROVISINS CHALLENGED
description: Administration officials said today that they had drawn up a 30-page list of ''objectionable'' provisions in the trade bill, which is scheduled to come to the Senate floor next week.

title: NEW EDELMAN PLEA ON BURLINGTON BID
description: A spokesman for Asher B. Edelman and Dominion Textile Inc. said yesterday that were they free to participate in the bidding for Burlington Industries, they would be prepared to make a better offer.

description: International A3-11

title: The U.N. Today: June 19, 1987
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: ROCK: BANGLES AND HOODOO OPEN PIER 84 SEASON
description: SOME years back, amidst much wailing and gnashing of teeth, Ron Delsener, the rock promoter, moved his summer outdoor music series from Wollman Rink in Central Park to Pier 84, which juts out into the Hudson River between 43d and 44th Streets. To this taste, the pier is preferable to the park, especially when the night is lovely and the sun sets scenically over New Jersey.

title: LANGER BIOMECHANICS GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
IN THE COUNTRY OF THE OCCULT, POWER TO THE SPIRITS
description: The man who nearly brought down the Panamanian Government last week, Colonel Roberto Diaz Herrera, is depending on the spiritual power of a holy man from India to ward off what he describes as ''strong negative impulses'' beamed at him by enemies.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Aca Joe Inc., San Francisco, said its accountant, Touche, Ross & Co., intended to qualify its report on Aca Joe's year ended Jan. 31 because of uncertainty about the company's ability to continue as a going concern.

title: Gulf Canada Corp. To Split 3 Ways
description: The Gulf Canada Corporation, a diversified company whose assets total $6.66 billion (Canadian), or about $5 billion (United States), will be split into three publicly traded companies, its chairman said at its annual meeting.

title: TRANSFORM LOGIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net income

title: Dow Climbs 0.78 Point, to 2,408.13
description: The stock market moved tentatively higher yesterday in trading enlivened by Wall Street's apprehension over today's ''triple-witching hour'' and by real or rumored takeover action.

title: A Way Out of the Budget Impasse
description: With a prod from President Reagan, Congressional Democrats have finally agreed to a plan for next year's budget. It makes a sensible cut in the Federal deficit. It courageously seeks to establish the principle that increases in military spending be covered by tax increases. Its one major drawback derives from its very boldness; if Congress and President Reagan can't agree on taxes, the total deficit reduction will be small.

title: Top Rate
description: The N.B.A. game on Sunday afternoon in which the Los Angeles Lakers drubbed the Boston Celtics on their way to the league championship was the highest-rated daytime basketball game ever, according to figures announced yesterday by the A. C. Nielsen Company.

title: Lazy Talk
description: To the Editor:

title: Market Place; Japan, the Land Of Lofty P/E's
description: THE lofty - some would say stratospheric -price/earnings ratios of many Japanese stocks have convinced some American investors and analysts that the Tokyo stock market is a bubble about to burst.

title: Dining Out Guide; With Out-of-Town Guests
description: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. AMERICAN FESTIVAL CAFE, 20 West 50th Street (246-6699) - *(July 27, 984) Occupying one of New York's most popular tourist haunts is this glittering restaurant that spills out in warm weather into what is the winter home of the Rockefeller Center skating rink under the golden statue of Prometheus. Inside, American antiques are featured against a background of gleaming light woods, sparkling glass, shiny brass and a tiled floor. The summer menu has starters of chilled crab and sweet corn chowder, backfin crab cake, and angel hair pasta with pesto and roasted pignoli nuts. Main course options include pan-fried catfish Louisiana-style; swordfish and salmon brochette with tropical herbs and fried rice; New York sirloin steak with grilled zucchini, tomato and fries. Dinner entrees $11.75 to $19.50. Fridays and Saturdays, 7:30 A.M. to 12:30 A.M.; Sundays, 9 A.M. to 10 P.M. CAFE DES ARTISTES, 1 West 67th Street (877-3500) - *(May 30, 1986) Housed in a historic turn-of-the-century building, this quintessential New York restaurant has dark, burnished-wood walls, lead-paned windows and bucolic murals by Howard Chandler Christy. The kitchen's strength lies in certain French bistro dishes, and you might start with cold duck liver terrine in black pepper crust; home-cured bresaola with melon, Parmesan shavings and olive oil, or salmon four ways, smoked, poached, dill-marinated and tartar. Entree options include rare-roasted rack of lamb encrusted with basil; swordfish paillard; gnocchi parisienne, made with Parmesan cheese, cream and asparagas, and soft-shell crabs with almond butter. Dinner entrees $13.50 to $30. Fridays and Saturdays, noon to 3 P.M. and 5:30 P.M. to 12:30 A.M.; Sundays, 10 A.M. to 4 P.M. and 5 to 11 P.M.. CELLAR IN THE SKY, 1 World Trade Center, 107th floor (938-1111) -

title: Musicians' Union Head Ousted by Dissident
description: Marty Emerson, the 74-year-old former secretary-treasurer of the American Federation of Musicians, was elected president of the union late Wednesday night at the federation's 1987 national convention in Las Vegas, Nev. He defeated Victor Fuentealba, the incumbent, by 58 votes out of more than 700 cast.

title: INSIDE
description: Rangers Name Coach

title: MAJOR VIDEO reports earnings for Year to April 30
description: b-After a tax credit of $215,000. The share earnings have been adjusted to reflect a 1-for-25 reverse stock split in March 1987.

title: SAFETY OFFICIALS WARN OF FIREWORKS' DANGER
description: Each year more than 10,000 Americans are treated in emergency rooms for injuries from fireworks, and, as usual, many of this year's accidents are expected to occur between now and the Fourth of July.

title: The Republicans' Big-Bucks Filibuster
description: They don't filibuster in the Senate the way they used to in the days when Wayne Morse or Sam Ervin would strap on a tube and bag called The Motorman's Friend and then go out on the floor and orate for 22 hours without a break. Still, even lacking such individual heroics, Senate Republicans seem determined to prove their filibustering skills. For two weeks, they've blocked a bill that would clean up the present system of campaign finance. The filibuster will go on, unless some sensible Republicans recognize how obstructionist their party looks on this issue, and is.

title: JAZZ FESTIVAL PLAYS IT HOT AS WELL AS COOL
description: ORNETTE COLEMAN, back in the forefront of jazz with his trailblazing Prime Time Band and a reunion of his original late 50's quartet, is feeding a sheaf of his distinctive compositions through the very different improvisational processes of both ensembles. The Modern Jazz Quartet is introducing new compositions and arrangements by its pianist, John Lewis, accompanied by the New York Chamber Symphony. The World Saxophone Quartet, fresh from a triumphant album of Ellington interpretations, is sharing a concert at Town Hall with the young saxophone star Branford Marsalis. Dizzy Gillespie has assembled a diverse and potentially adventurous big band for his 70th birthday, and the pianists Hank Jones and George Shearing are the centerpieces of elaborate retrospective concerts. Charlie Watts, drummer for the Rolling Stones, will lead an orchestra of British jazz stars through a program of swing-era standards.

title: STAGE: 'LATE GREAT LADIES,' A ONE-WOMAN SHOW
description: IN her one-woman show, opening last night at the John Houseman Theater, Sandra Reaves-Phillips tries to delineate six ''Late Great Ladies of Blues and Jazz'' - Ma Rainey, Bessie Smith, Ethel Waters, Billie Holiday, Dinah Washington and Mahalia Jackson. However, through her choice of songs and biographical material and her style of delivery, she largely succeeds in accentuating similarities.

title: News Organizations Got Advance Notice
description: Plans for the drug sweep yesterday on the Upper West Side were carried out in secrecy, although in the hours before the raid the Police Department notified news organizations of its intentions and invited coverage.

description: b-Net income

description: * Sims & Associates, a public relations firm, has been established by Idan Sims.

title: 6 Die in Philippine Fighting
description: Six people were killed and seven soldiers were wounded in clashes with guerrillas in the last two days, military and news reports said today. The military said guerrillas killed two policemen, two militiamen and two civilians in separate attacks Wednesday in Albay, Quezon and Negros Occidental provinces.

title: GANDHI'S PARTY ROUTED IN STATE ELECTION
description: An opposition coalition was headed for a landslide victory tonight over Prime Ministe Rajiv Gandhi's Congress Party in legislative elections in the northern state of Haryana.

title: The Pay as They Play
description: When Kareem Abdul-Jabbar signed to play for two more years with the Los Angeles Lakers, his minimum $2 million salary for next season breaks down to at least $24,390 for each of the 82 games, and his minimum $3 million the next season will give him at least $36,585 per game. Here is what baseball's 10 highest-paid nonpitchers will earn for this season, and for each of its 162 games.

title: GAIN IN CONDUCTIVITY IS SEEN AT 90 DEGREES, BUT EFFECT IS LIMITED
description: Researchers at a Michigan company reported yesterday that they had evidence of total loss of electrical resistance at a record high temperature of 90 degrees Fahrenheit.

title: Seoul Growth Forecast
description: South Korea's real gross national product will grow more than 10 percent this year, up from a target of 8 percent, Deputy Prime Minister Chong In Yong said today. He also said that the South Korean currency, the won, was expected to rise further. The nation's G.N.P. rose 15.6 percent in January-March 1987 from the comparable 1986 period, according to provisional Bank of Korea figures, making it the highest quarterly growth rate in eight years.

title: Advertising; Discover's Optimistic New Chief
description: THE July issue of Discover magazine, to be the last under the aegis of Time Inc., seems to have a mournful look: a jet-black cover, with the logotype in gray and, in small white letters, ''The End of the Universe. How and When.''

title: A NEW FAST LANE FOR BUSINESS
description: When the brightly colored Formula One Grand Prix cars blast through the streets of downtown Detroit this weekend, several of them will have the names of major American corporations on their flanks.

title: Gemayel Is Ready for Lebanese Power Sharing
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Blacks Are Fair Game'
description: It was a typical day. My calendar was filled with one appointment after another.

title: PAYMENTS FROM WEDTECH TO FRIEND OF MEESE ARE RECALLED IN INQUIRY
description: Former executives of the Wedtech Corporation have told investigators about a series of questionable payments they made to a close friend and personal lawyer of Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d and two associates, according to officials familiar with the investigation.

title: Devourers of the Earth
description: To the Editor:

FILM: 'WITHNAIL AND I,' A BRITISH 60'S COMEDY
description: ''Withnail and I'' was shown as part of this year's New Directors/New Films Series. Following are excerpts from Vincent Canby's review, which appeared in The New York Times March 27. The film opens today at the Carnegie Hall Cinema, Seventh Avenue between 56th and 57th Streets.

AMERICAN CYTOGENETICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
F.T.C. Charge On Kraft Ads
description: Advertising for Kraft Singles exaggerated the calcium content of the cheese product, the Federal Trade Commission said today. A spokesman for Kraft Inc. denied the charge.

title: COMPILER OF ANTI-WHITE GUIDE IS DISCHARGED FROM STATE JOB
description: The affirmative-action officer for the State Insurance Fund, who compiled a 38-page training manual that characterized all white Americans as racist, has been dismissed from her job because she falsified her credentials, the agency announced yesterday.

title: Bridge: Group of Leading Brazilians Stumbled at National Trials
description: A group that is capable of winning a world team title must surmount three hurdles, at national, zonal and world level, to bring home the grand prize. Stumbles at the first fence are not uncommon, and this happened in Brazil in April.

title: Defending Europe
description: There is a certain ferment just below the top in Western Europe as people begin to contemplate the uncertain prospects of strategic change once disarmament actually starts.

title: HOUSE AND SENATE NEGOTIATORS APPROVE '88 BUDGET
description: House and Senate negotiators formally approved a $1 trillion 1988 budget today amid predictions that the $19.3 billion in new taxes that it calls for will never become law.

title: CALSTRAR INC reports earnings for Year to April 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $565,000 for the latest year and $620,000 for the year-ago period.

description: Today INTERNATIONAL FOOD FESTIVAL, Washington Square Church, West Fourth Street, between Avenue of the Americas and Macdougal Street. Today, 6 to 9 P.M. Entertainment. Admission, $10 ($8 for the elderly; $6 for those 12 and under.) Information: 777-2528. CRAFT SHOW, #42d Street, between Fifth Avenue and Avenue of the Americas. Today, 10 A.M. to 6 P.M. Leather goods, jewelry, pottery. Through December. EIGHTH GREGORIAN FESTIVAL, Cross Island Parkway and 87th Avenue, Bellerose, Queens. Food, games, entertainment. Today and tomorrow, 7 P.M. to midnight; Sunday, 7 to 11 P.M. Information: (718) 347-3707. title: BUSINESS DIGEST: FRIDAY, JUNE 19, 1987
description: Companies

title: No Deals for the Beirut Nine
description: With the kidnapping of Charles Glass, a television journalist, nine Americans are now held hostage in Beirut. His situation is cruel and his abduction an outrage, and the State Department speaks for America in demanding the unconditional release of Mr. Glass and all other foreigners now held captive by Lebanese zealots.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Charlie Haden Quartet, Village Vanguard, 178 Seventh Avenue South, between 11th and Perry Streets (255-4037). Since Charlie Haden came to prominence as a member of the quartet with which Ornette Coleman astonished or puzzled New York in 1959, he has continued to be one of the most thoughtful and provocative bassists in jazz. His recently organized quartet is made up of musicians living in Los Angeles, where Mr. Haden settled after leaving New York in 1979. The group, which includes Ernie Watts on tenor saxophone, Alan Broadbent on piano and Billy Higgins on drums, is making its New York debut this week at the Village Vanguard, coinciding with the release of its first album, ''Quartet West,'' on the Verve label. Sets tonight, tomorrow and Sunday are at 10 and 11:30 P.M. and 1 A.M. There is a $6 drink minimum and a $12 cover charge.

title: A WANDERER, DION RETURNS TO HIS ROOTS
description: By the end of Dion DiMucci's visit to his old neighborhood in the Bronx, there were laughs and hugs and pleas that he take free mozzarella. But at the beginning, nobody could quite believe he had come home.

title: KEY RATES
Advertising; Arby's Looks to Replace Backer & Spielvogel
description: The telephones in the marketing department at Arby's headquarters in Atlanta have been ringing off the hook since Backer & Spielvogel won the Wendy's International account this week.

title: SUMMERSTAGE BRINGS DOWNTOWN UPTOWN
description: FOR organizers of this year's Summerstage - the second annual series of free performances at the Central Park Band Shell - the mission was simple, if formidable. Bring the downtown arts scene uptown.

title: Phillies Lose, 9-7, In Debut of Elia
description: Lee Elia, dropped as manager of the Cubs here four years ago, was promoted from coach to manager by the Philadelphia Phillies today, replacing John Felske.

title: Chicagoan to Head New York Hospital
description: A leading Chicago surgeon, Dr. David B. Skinner, has been named president and chief executive officer of New York Hospital, effective next Oct. 1, the hospital's board announced yesterday.

title: THE CLASSICS, FROM 'BOHEME' TO BARBER
description: TIME was, when the musical season ended in New York, concert halls went dark and listeners had to wait till midsummer for the gates of Tanglewood and other outdoor festivals to open up for business. Nowadays, the schedule of concerts is a nearly unbroken series of events. Air-conditioning of halls, a growing population of concertgoers who stay in the city during the summer and what is presumably a larger body of classical-music followers has provided ambitious cultural organizers with both the means and the motivation to fill in what used to be seasonal gaps.

title: Consumers Power
description: The Consumers Power Company is offering two bond issues totaling $250 million, through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley & Company.

title: CRIMINAL AND CIVIL LITIGATION ON SPREAD OF AIDS APPEARS
description: LEAD: Legal cases focusing on people ac-cused of knowingly exposing others to the AIDS virus are cropping up around the country, raising troubling issues for the courts, public health officials and the law-enforcement authorities.

title: SOUTH NORWALK TRIES NONPROFIT PROJECT
description: Nonprofit corporations are becoming more active in efforts to increase the supply of affordable housing in Connecticut, where high prices have narrowed the opportunities for moderate-income households.

title: More Woes For S.M.U.
description: Southern Methodist University officials are expected to announce Friday that, as of May 31, contributions to the school were more than 15 percent below their goal, newspaper reports here said today.

title: 'THE SECRET DIARY OF ADRIAN MOLE,' ON CHANNEL 13
description: GETTING under way on Channel 13 tomorrow at 8 P.M., ''The Secret Diary of Adrian Mole'' is a seven-episode British production being offered as a series for young viewers. It is not, be assured, your ordinary fare for youngsters. A clue to the tone and style can be detected when Adrian, age 13 3/4, tells us his mother is ''not like the moms on TV.''

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: TROUBLE. By Michael Gilbert. 254 pages.

title: U.S. ARTS MEDALS PRESENTED
description: Winners of the National Medal of Arts - a painter, a singer, two poets, a choreographer, a sculptor and a composer - were honored at the White House today by President and Mrs. Reagan.

title: SETTLEMENT IN LINCOLN'S HOMETOWN
description: The City Council voted today to settle a two-year battle over political discrimination against blacks, approving an agreement that would scrap the current city government by 1991.

title: A Tall Order For a Prospect
description: Tyrone (Muggsy) Bogues - at 5 feet 3 3/4 inches - is a bit more than 15 inches under the National Basketball Association's average height, but he may gain stature Monday when the league holds its 1987 draft at the Felt Forum. Although there are skeptics who say the player from Wake Forest cannot compete professionally, Bogues has some strong supporters.

title: DATARAM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After gains from the sale of securities of $500,000 for the quarter and $1,251,000 for the year.

title: Ban in AIDS Case Is Affirmed
description: A state panel has reaffirmed a ban on job discrimination against AIDS victims but has refused to award $92,000 in legal fees to civil rights lawyers who won the ruling.

title: C&R CLOTHIERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 2
Lester Eisner Jr. Dies at 73; Former U.S. Housing Official
description: Lester Eisner Jr., a lawyer who was a former regional administrator of the Federal Department of Housing and Urban Development, died Tuesday at his Manhattan apartment after a long illness. He was 73 years old and also had a home in Saxtons River, Vt.

title: U.S. JOURNALIST ABDUCTED IN LEBANON
description: An American journalist has been kidnapped in a predominantly Shiite Moslem suburb along with the son of the country's Defense Minister, the police said today.

title: Bank Raises Loss Reserve
description: The American Express Company said yesterday that its banking subsidiary, the American Express Bank Ltd., would set aside $600 million in the second quarter for losses on loans to underdeveloped countries.

title: Cocaine Use by Washington Mayor Alleged
description: A former friend of Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. has told Federal prosecutors that she provided him with cocaine 20 to 30 times in the early 1980's and that she and Mr. Barry often used the drug and had sex together, a television news report said tonight.

title: SENATORS IN ALBANY FORECAST $1.5 BILLION SURPlUS
description: A report issued today by the State Senate Finance Committee estimated that the state's budget surplus this year would be $650 million greater than the Governor's budget office predicted last month.

title: Hagler Reportedly Still Bitter Over Loss to Leonard
description: Since Marvelous Marvin Hagler lost his World Boxing Council middleweight title to Sugar Ray Leonard on April 6, reports have persisted that the former champion was having trouble dealing with his defeat.

title: Consistent Trudeau
description: To the Editor:

title: Israel Says a Soviet Consular Team Will Visit
description: The on-again off-again detente between Israel and the Soviet Union appeared today to be on again, with the official announcement by Israel that a Soviet consular delegation would soon visit Jerusalem.

title: Plan to Break Impasse in North's Testimony
description: The Congressional committees investigating the Iran-contra affair developed a proposal today for breaking the impasse with Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North over his refusal to give a private deposition before his public testimony.

title: CABOT MEDICAL reports earnings for Qtr to May 2
description: The company said the 1986 periods ended April 3.

title: NITZE ASKS ABM PACT REVIEW
description: An Administration official said today that the United States must drop its opposition to new talks with the Soviet Union on interpreting the Antiballistic Missile Treaty if it wants an accord on defensive systems and long-range arms.

title: DSP TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $9,000 for the latest quarter and $24,000 for the year-earlier period.

title: BankAmerica Plea
description: The BankAmerica Corporation, which has been plagued with losses because of problem loans, asked Japanese commercial banks today to buy $350 million in notes and preferred stock as part of a $1 billion package to raise badly needed cash. Frank Newman, BankAmerica vice chairman, met with representatives of 20 banks at a hastily convened session. Japanese bank sources said the initial reaction was less than enthusiastic.

title: ROCHESTER COMMUNITY SAVNGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
