description: b-After tax credits of $2,288,000 for the quarter and $4,548,000 for the 6 months. c-After tax credits of $667,000 for the quarter and $3,043,000 for the 6 months. The bank converted to stock form April 29, 1986.

title: CULLINET SOFTWARE INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Includes a first quarter non-recurring charge of $7 million after taxes for the writeoff of certain assets. c-Net income The company results for the latest periods include the impact of the company's April 21, 1987, acquisition of Distribution Management Systems Inc. for 1.7 million common shares. Year-earlier results, which have been restated to reflect the acquisition, have been converted from a fiscal year ending Sept. 30 to a fiscal year ended April 30.

title: AMERICAN ELECTROMEDICS reports earnings for Qtr to May 2
description: The company is 80-percent owned by Technodyne Inc.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Chico and Von Freeman Quintet, Sweet Basil, 88 Seventh Avenue South, above Bleecker Street (242-1785). The Freemans are tenor saxophonists. Chico Freeman has recorded more widely and been heard in New York more frequently than his father, Von Freeman. But in Chicago, their hometown, Von Freeman is a legend, a musician's musician whose great gnarled sound and labyrinthine phrasing are singularly idiosyncratic. Chico Freeman's approach is rooted in the more familiar modern mainstream of John Coltrane and Sonny Rollins, but he is becoming an increasingly personal player, and when he's playing alongside his father, sparks fly. The Freemans are playing three sets nightly, at 10 and 11:45 P.M. and 1:30 A.M., through Sunday. There is a $12 cover charge and a $6 minimum.

title: BARRICINI FOODS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Economic Scene; Heller Legacy: Clarity for All
description: WALTER W. HELLER, who died this week at the age of 71, raised the role of the President's Council of Economic Advisers to the highest level it has attained since that body was established by the Employment Act of 1946.

title: NEW YORK TRANSIT CHIEF PRESSES TOWARD GOALS
description: Last year, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority published a slick brochure that proclaimed on its cover the coming of a new era. ''The year is 1992,'' it read. ''All the subway cars are new or rebuilt. All the buses are mechanically sound and air-conditioned. All the commuter trains are running swift and sure.''

title: Correction
description: The headline yesterday on an article about a decision by the New York City Board of Education to continue operating school health clinics misstated the clinics' function. They will provide a wide range of services, including prescriptions for contraceptives, but at present they are not permitted to distribute contraceptives.

title: AFTER-TAX INCOME UP 3.4% IN MAY
description: After-tax incomes increased a record 3.4 percent in May as Americans recovered from high tax bills in April, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: U.S. PLANS A RADIO SITE IN ISRAEL
description: The Voice of America and the Board for International Broadcasting, which oversees Radio Free Europe and Radio Liberty, signed an agreement with Israel today permitting them to build a relay transmitter in that country.

title: CIVIL LIBERTIES UNION TO DEBATE POLICIES ON AIDS TEST AND ALIEN LAW
description: As the American Civil Liberties Union opened its conference today in the birthplace of the Constitution, delegates began taking up issues they say are threatening individual rights and freedoms guaranteed in the Constitution. The topics being debated include AIDS testing, immigration laws and Presidential secrecy.

title: Japan Vehicle Exports
description: Japanese vehicle exports fell 9.3 percent in May from a year earlier, to 531,253, mainly because of lower exports to the United States, industry sources said today. Exports in April stood at 633,869 vehicles.

title: Feeling Left Out
description: William Penn Mott Jr., director of the National Park Service, is popular among conservationists, who believe he is doing his best to protect the park system in an Administration more interested in economic development of public lands and resources. But inside the Interior Department, it appears, Mr. Mott is sometimes left outside the room when decisions that affect the parks are made.

title: Recital: Jungwon Park, South Korean Soprano
description: Jungwon Park, a South Korean soprano trained at the Juilliard School, made a further step into her career with a recital at Merkin Concert Hall Wednesday night. Miss Park emerges from her education with a substantial set of attributes. The voice is full and secure in all its registers; decisions on phrasing, accents and tempo are good ones, and if Wednesday evening is an example, the repertory is tasteful and suitable to her strengths.

title: By ISADORE BARMASH
description: Come tomorrow morning, thousands of dear old dads will be beaming on the outside but grimacing on the inside as they open that all-too-familiar thin, rectangular box. Not another ugly tie!

title: President Signs Bill Lifting Fee at Statue
description: Lady Liberty is free again.

title: A Kidney Disease That Deserves More Attention
description: To the Editor:

title: New Coach in Albany
description: For Bill Musselman, the thrill, as well as the franchise, is gone. Musselman, who coached the Tampa Bay Thrillers to the Continental Basketball Association title the last three years, then saw the franchise shift to Rapid City, S.D., has signed a one-year contract to coach the Albany Patroons of the C.B.A. He succeeds Phil Jackson, a former Knick, who is pursuing a job in the National Basketball Association.

title: Better Home Health Care by Worker-Owners
description: To the Editor:

title: Oil at 17-Month Highs; July Contract Up by 14/
description: Oil futures today hit their highest prices in 17 months, buoyed by bullish factors ahead of next week's meeting of OPEC ministers.

title: JERSEY TRACES ILLEGAL DUMPING ALONG TURNPIKE
description: A tank-cleaning company in Jersey City was cited by state environmental officials today for illegally discharging chemicals into sewers near the New Jersey Turnpike Extension in Jersey City.

title:
Patents;
Obtaining Patents In Other Countries
description: LEAD: American inventors will get a better idea after July 1 of whether inventions can be patented in certain foreign countries. At that time they will be able to take advantage of the Patent Cooperation Treaty to which 40 countries have subscribed. New rules offering full benefits and providing additional time for applicants to file in foreign countries were published in this week's Official Gazette.

title: C. M. Brooks, Lawyer; Drafted Taft-Hartley
description: Charles Maynard Brooks, a labor attorney who helped draft the Taft-Hartley Act of 1947 and a former head of industrial relations for Texaco Inc., died of a heart attack Monday at Memorial City Hospital in Houston. He was 76 years old and lived in Houston.

title:
Your Money;
Pros and Cons Of Convertibles
description: LEAD: DEL GOEDEKER, a businessman in Beaver Falls, Pa., has been buying convertible bonds for the last few years. The reason, he says, is ''it's a matter of trying to have your cake and eat it, too.''

title: Time Inc. to Sell Cable Unit Stake
description: After months of disputes and failed negotiations, Gulf and Western Industries and MCA Inc. said they had agreed to buy out Time Inc.'s stake in USA Network, a cable television programming service, for $52 million. Disputes among the three owners have gone on for several years and have been particularly acrimonious between MCA and Time, according to an official who has long followed the companies.

title: THE BANDMASTER OF FOREST PARK RECOLLECTS ICE CREAM WITH SOUSA
description: He is a modern-day music man whose musical heritage is rooted in the era of John Philip Sousa, when families in their Sunday best traveled by trolley to picnic groves for band concerts on sun-dappled afternoons.

title: SALOMAN CITES STAKE BY HARCOURT
description: Salomon Brothers Inc. disclosed yesterday that it held Harcourt Brace Jovanovich debentures that it said are convertible into almost 22 million shares of the publishing company's common shares.

title: ALBERT BADAIN
description: Albert Badain, who coached varsity and junior varsity basketball at Erasmus Hall High School in Brooklyn for 40 years, died yesterday at Biscayne Hospital in Hallandale, Fla., after a heart attack. He was 80 years old.

title: Astros Trade Garner
description: Phil Garner, a third baseman who in 43 games was batting .223 with 3 home runs and 15 runs batted in, was traded by the Houston Astros to the Los Angeles Dodgers for a player to be named. Garner, 38 years old, had been with Houston since August 1981, when he arrived after a trade with the Pittsburgh Pirates.

title: WPP Extends Bid
description: WPP Group, the British marketing specialty company that is trying to acquire the JWT Group, parent of the J. Walter Thompson advertising agency, said it was extending until Monday at noon its $50.50-a-share offer originally made in a letter Wednesday and already extended once. According to a WPP spokesman, the two companies were in communication yesterday.

title: ISRAEL CAPTURES WEST BANK RING
description: Security agents have captured a group of Syrian-backed Palestinians suspected of six attacks in the occupied West Bank, including the assassination of an Israeli-appointed Arab mayor last year, the army said today.

title: Soviet Student Sentenced to Die in Kazakh Riots
description: A Soviet student has been sentenced to death by firing squad for killing a man during rioting last December in the streets of Alma-Ata, capital of the Central Asian republic of Kazakhstan.

title: A Twist on Shakespeare By a Twirling Champ
description: Sophie Hayden is letting Shakespeare's words trip off her tongue when suddenly the audience at the Vivian Beaumont Theater notices that something is happening to her elbow. In fact, a baton seems to be dancing and twinkling up along her forearm and back down again to her hand even as she speaks. Is it an illusion? No, it is simply Sophie Hayden, actress and World Baton Twirling Champion of 1971, doing what comes naturally.

title: HIGHWAY TIE-UP STRETCHES 2 YEARS AHEAD
description: For more than two years, drivers have suffered through snarled traffic along a 1.7-mile section of the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway that has been under repair. Officials say motorists can expect at least two more years of major tie-ups.

title: STATE PROPOSES AIDS EDUCATION FOR ALL STUDENTS
description: Proposed guidelines for a statewide AIDS education curriculum were presented to the Board of Regents yesterday by the State Education Department.

title: DONNA RICE AIMS TO RESUME LIFE AFTER HART
description: Seven weeks after she was catapulted into national prominence by her association with Gary Hart, Donna Rice is trying to pick up the pieces of her life and wants to resume her acting career, her adviser said today.

title: Saturday News Quiz
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times thi s week. Answers ap= pear on page 21.

title: INSIDE
description: Car Bomb Kills 15 in Spain A bomb exploded in a parking garage, killing 15 and wounding 39 in Barcelona, Spain. Basque separatists took responsibility. Page 3.

title: Room Tax Isn't Hurting New York City Hotels
description: To the Editor:

title: S.E.C. to Define Insider Trading
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission plans to develop its own definition of illegal insider trading. The acting S.E.C. chairman, Charles C. Cox, said today, in testimony before a Senate Banking subcommittee, that the agency had decided to draft its own legislation because it could not support a bill that was introduced earlier this week by two leading members of the Banking Committee:

title: BARCELONA BOMB KILLS 15 CIVILIANS
description: A car bomb exploded in a department store parking garage here today, killing 15 people and wounding 39, the authorities said.

title: Rhode Island Drops Charges
description: Charges were dropped today against a Roman Catholic priest accused of lying to help Claus von Bulow escape charges of attempted murder. The priest, the Rev. Philip A. Magaldi, had been accused of perjury and obstruction of justice in allegedly submitting a false affidavit on behalf of Mr. von Bulow, who was acquitted in 1985 of charges he tried to murder his wife with an insulin injection.

title: The Day My Daughter Discovered Baseball
description: LEAD: Because some of the happiest times of my boyhood were spent at a ballpark with my father, I used to dream of having such times with my own son. My first child, however, was named Jill and she somehow grew to like lacrosse, a sensible sport if her father had been an Iroquois and could have taken her out to the old stick game.

title: SHOP NEAR PHILADELPHIA FOR FASHIONABLE BRIDES
description: When a customer walks into Suky Rosan's bridal boutique in suburban Ardmore, Pa., the first question she's asked is not ''What's your size?'' but ''What's your sign?'' She is then assigned to an astrologically compatible saleswoman.

title: New French Cause Celebre: A Book Calling Nation Lazy
description: Are the French lazy?

title: CAPTAIN OF STARK AND TWO OTHERS RELIEVED OF DUTY
description: The captain of the frigate Stark and two other officers were relieved of duty today because of their performance during an attack on the ship last month by an Iraqi jet in the Persian Gulf.

title: Chairman and Trustees Elected at Rockefeller
description: The board of trustees of the Rockefeller Foundation yesterday elected Dr. John R. Evans, a prominent public health specialist in Canada, its ninth chairman. Dr. Evans, a former president of the University of Toronto, succeeds Dr. Clifton R. Wharton Jr., former Chancellor of the State University of New York, who is leaving the board after 17 years as a trustee.

title: Hoyt Move Challenged
description: The baseball players union is challenging the San Diego Padres' decision to ask waivers on the pitcher LaMarr Hoyt, a union official said yesterday. The union will seek to have Hoyt, the 1983 Cy Young Award winner in the National League, restored to the club's roster.

title: Court Rules on Child-Molesting Cases
description: The Supreme Court ruled 6 to 3 today that a person accused of molesting a child has no constitutional right to attend a hearing on the child's competence to testify.

title: Crane Drops Beams At Construction Site
description: A crane gave way at a construction site at the Mount Sinai Medical Center in Manhattan yesterday, sending several steel beams crashing onto an unfinished building and temporarily halting work at the site.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: SATURDAY, JUNE 20, 1987
description: International 2-4, 28 The captain of the frigate Stark and two other officers were relieved of duty because of their performance during the attack on the ship by an Iraqi jet. The action left open the possibility that they may be court-martialed. Page 1 A South Korean official warned that ''extraordinary measures'' were inevitable if civil unrest did not end, and that the country was plunging toward ''social chaos.'' The warning came from the Prime Minister. 1 The anti-Government protests have been an occasion for many Koreans to vent their anger at the United States. Many Koreans lament what they see as the United States Government's failure to exert more active pressure for change. 4 Are the French lazy? The country of sunbathers and cafe habitues is in an uproar over this question, prompted by a provocative new book that accuses the French of not working hard enough to compete. 1 A Soviet election with choices for various candidates will be held Sunday for the first time since the Soviet authorities began direct elections to government offices. Only selected districts will have such elections. 1 Shipments of oil to Nicaragua will be resumed by Mexico and Venezuela, according to Mexican Government officials and Latin American diplomats. The shipments were suspended two years ago. 3 In the Iran-contra investigation, Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North's lawyer rejected a Congressional proposal to break an impasse over the colonel's testimony before the committees investigating the affair. 3 Plans for a papal meeting with Jewish leaders could be disrupted by the Pope's willingness to grant an audience to President Kurt Waldheim of Austria, leaders of several major Jewish organizations warned. 2 Bahamian Premier re-elected 2 Saudi King agrees to wider U.S. air patrols 3 Barcelona car bombing kills 15 4 Pinnawela Journal 4 Abductions in Beirut laid to pro-Iranian radicals 28 Israel arrests West Bank ring 28 National 5-8, 33-34 The teaching of the creationist theory of man's origin or any other particular religious beliefs in public schools may not be required by states, the Supreme Court ruled in a 7-to-2 decision. 1 The Court's ruling ended a battle that is the latest in a long line of legal struggles by fundamentalist Christians to censor or counter teaching of the theory of evolution in science classes. 1 Mixed reactions in Louisiana 7 An accused child molester has no constitutional right to attend a hearing on the child's competency to testify, the Supreme Court ruled. The 6-to-3 decision did not question a defendant's right to confront a child accuser at his trial. 7 Charges against General Dynamics and four of its top executives were dismissed by a Federal judge late Friday. The criminal charges alleged the company mischarged the Defense Department $7.5 million. 1 The Trailways Corporation will sell many of its buses, terminals and garages to Greyhound Lines Inc., thus conceding the nation's roads to its much-larger rival. 37 The stock market climbed higher into record territory, with the Dow Jones industrial average closing up 12.72 points. In the process, Wall Street weathered another ''triple witching hour.'' 37 The prosecutor in the Deaver case ''mischaracterized facts'' and made use of ''irrelevant legal principles'' in issuing a subpoena for the Canadian Ambassador to the United States, the Justice Department charged. 5 Irrigation in the West is too costly, farmers said. As water from a dam on the Dolores River in Colorado starts to flow to farms, some farmers plan to sue the Bureau of Reclamation to try to stop the water's delivery. 5 Texas' Governor misled the National Collegiate Athletic Association, a report says. Bill Clements tried to cover up his involvement in the Southern Methodist University football scandal, it says. 5 Patricia Schroeder would run for the 1988 Democratic Presidential nomination beginning in September if she raises enough money by then for a pay-as-you-go campaign, the Colorado Congresswoman said. 8 Doctors judged as incompetant will still be barred from the Medicare program, an organization that monitors Texas doctors vowed. The assertion came following complaints that rural towns are being deprived of doctors by review panels. 33 California's Ambassador Hotel is in decline 5 5 ex-Puerto Rican officers sentenced 34 Washington Mayor assails prosecutor 8 Nuclear official vows to keep job 33 Polygraphs in workplace assailed 33 Rice wants to resume her life 34 Creditor will challenge PTL 34 Evidence indicates new planets 34 Regional 29-32 Repairs to a New York highway will continue for at least two more years, officials said. Traffic has been snarled along a section of the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway that has been under repair for more than two years already. 29 The day after raids on crack dens in a two-block stretch of West 107th Street by 200 police officers, neighborhood residents said that drug dealers had adopted a lower profile, but remained active. 31 Two Howard Beach trials will be held, the judge in the case ruled. The trial of four white teen-agers charged in the death of Michael Griffith will begin on Sept. 8. Seven other defendants will be tried afterward on other charges. 31 Bess Myerson was obsessive in her behavior during a romance, according to a police report prepared in 1980. The report was not included in a background check when Mayor Koch nominated her for a city post. 29 Reacting to the Goetz verdict, Benjamin L. Hooks Jr., executive director of the N.A.A.C.P., said that the United States Attorney in Manhattan will be asked to re-examine whether Mr. Goetz can be prosecuted under Federal civil-rights laws. 31 The passing of the concert band era is well recognized by George F. Seuffert, in his 59th year as conductor of the Seuffert Band. The 75-year-old conductor said his band may not continue if he cannot find a successor. 30 Harmony is strained in Radburn, the first suburb designed for the automobile age. Various disputes have led to the first formal challenge to the community's board of trustees in its 58 years. 29 One-way traffic plan for 42d St. 29 Judges add confusion to merger 29 Jersey traces illegal dumping 30 Inquiry in boy-stranger incident 30 State proposes AIDS courses 32

title: METS ROLL BY 8-1
description: In the 65th game of an otherwise grinding season, the Mets finally got their act together last night in Shea Stadium.

title: Winning, Italian Style
description: ''Very complex and confusing,'' declared former Prime Minister Bettino Craxi after the Italian election that his own Socialists came closest to winning. Winning, Italian style, means creeping up a few points in the popular vote, from 11.4 to 14.3 percent in the case of the Socialists. That only shifts the balance within the ruling center coalition; nothing much was changed by last Sunday's vote. So Italy faces months of the paralysis that the vote was meant to end.

title: Panel Accepts Changes In Holocaust Memorial
description: The Commission of Fine Arts today unanimously approved a revised design for the United States Holocaust Memorial Museum.

title:
Patents;
Copy Method for Xerox
description: LEAD: A vacuum device to turn and remove the pages of a book for copying in an electrophotographic machine has been invented for the Xerox Corporation, based in Rochester. Patent 4,673,286, granted this week to Troy Shinbrot, a former employee, described the device, which peels pages from a book with a vacuum roll, exposes them for copying, and returns them to the book.

title: SUBURB'S CALM SHAKEN BY DISPUTES ON LAND
description: When spinach fields here were carved up by builders in 1929, what arose was not just another subdivision, but Radburn, the first suburb designed for the automobile age.

title: London Stocks Decline
description: Stocks continued their selloff today because of disappointment that overseas buyers have yet to enter the British market in a big way after last week's Conservative Party general election victory, dealers said. The Financial Times index of 100 shares closed down 27.1 points, at 2,266.1.

title: COPING WITH FAILURE: ROADS TO RECOVERY
description: Who would have expected Linda Gottlieb to be fired from her job? Inducted into Phi Beta Kappa at Wellesley College, winner of three Emmy awards and a Peabody, author of a novel and a longtime film maker, she had gone from one professional achievement to another for all of her working life.

title: The Graying of School Decentralization
description: The time has come for a thorough review of the mechanisms and operations of school decentralization and the governance of the public school system in New York City.

title: Metals Dealer's Records Seized
description: The authorities seized records of a precious-metals sales operation today both in Florida and at its New Jersey headquarters to determine whether the concern violated securities laws, the Florida comptroller's office said.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL ATLANTA (NL) - Placed David Palmer, pitcher, and Albert Hall, outfielder, on the 15-day disabled list.

title: 9 Injured by Stray Gunfire
description: Nine people, including two children, were hit by gunfire Thursday as they watched a quarrel in a vacant lot, the police said. ''Somebody was shooting at someone and just hit the people standing on the street,'' said Capt. Greg Nicholson of the High Point police.

title: MUSIC: OPERA REPERTORY STAGES 'TRANSFORMATIONS'
description: Since its first performance in 1973 by the Minnesota Opera Company, Conrad Susa's ''Transformations'' has carved out a modest place for itself in the music-theater repertory. Although it is usually staged by small opera troupes, the 10-scene work is propelled more often by a conversational speech-song than by singing.

title: What a Rush to Spend City Dollars
description: Years of fiscal crisis showed that New York City legislators face adversity with calm; it's the prospect of a surplus that stirs them to a feeding frenzy. The city budget ''negotiations'' just concluded offer a model of the confusion prosperity creates.

title: Seoul Promises Strong Actions To Curb Unrest
description: South Korea's Prime Minister said tonight that the country was plunging toward ''social chaos'' and that extraordinary measures were inevitable if civil unrest did not end.

title: Colored Movies Ruled Eligible for Copyright
description: The Library of Congress, which has jurisdiction over copyrights, ruled today that colored versions of black-and-white movies are eligible for copyright protection as ''derivative work'' under many circumstances.

title: Third-Class Mail Is Alive, Well and Paying Its Way; First-Class First
description: To the Editor:

title: OBSERVER
description: The Goetz case is about a failure of government.

title: 5 IN PUERTO RICO RECEIVE SENTENCES
description: Five former police officers were sentenced Thursday to prison terms of up to 30 years for the 1978 murders of two young advocates of Puerto Rican independence from the United States.

title: SOVIET SUPPLY CUT, MANAGUA TO GET LATIN OIL
description: Mexico and Venezuela plan to resume oil shipments to Nicaragua that were suspended two years ago, according to Mexican Government officials and Latin American diplomats here.

title: Retailer Nips Takeover Bud
description: The Dayton Hudson Corporation, the Minneapolis-based retailer, which had declined comment for more than a week as takeover reports fueled a sharp rise in its stock, yesterday said that it has told an ''aggressive buyer'' of its shares that it does not want to be acquired.

title: America's Poorly Paid New Work Force
description: To the Editor:

title: Small Place Squeezes In for Elephant
description: The Asian elephant, hauler of teak and vehicle of monks and monarchs, is rapidly being driven from the Asian landscape as the last of the wild savannas and jungles feel the encroachment of people and progress.

title: Bishops' Panel Says Clements Led Cover-Up of S.M.U. Athletes' Pay
description: A report issued today by four Methodist bishops charged that Gov. Bill Clements, while chairman of Southern Methodist University, led a concerted effort to mislead the National Collegiate Athletic Association, cover up his and other officials' involvement in rules violations, and pay school officials for their cooperation in the cover-up.

title: Alumni Appointment
description: The first black athlete to play at the University of Tennessee, Lester McClain, has been named to an alumni position on the university's athletic board. Edward J. Boling, the president of the university, announced that McClain, who played football as a wide receiver from 1968 to 1970, had been appointed along with Alan Cates, a Chattanooga attorney, to three-year terms.

title: Times Buying Georgia Paper
description: The New York Times Company agreed yesterday to buy The Gwinnett Daily News, an evening newspaper published in Lawrenceville, Ga., which serves Gwinnett County in northeast suburban Atlanta.

title: KEY RATES
JUDGES ADD CONFUSION TO MERGER
description: Leaders of the state court system reversed themselves today and said they would accept a Senate Republican plan for merging trial courts despite reservations about its constitutionality. But the comments set off such a political outcry among Democrats that later in the day the court leaders contended that they neither supported nor opposed the bill.

title: Jays Win With 9 Runs in 7th
description: Tony Fernandez hit a two-run single and Lloyd Moseby had a two-run triple to highlight a nine-run seventh inning as Toronto topped the Milwaukee Brewers, 15-6, tonight.

title: Addresses Required for Bolshoi Tickets
description: For the first time in the history of the Metropolitan Opera, all ticket buyers for the June 30 through July 18 engagement of the Bolshoi Ballet at the Metropolitan Opera House are being required to provide personal identification and addresses.

title: Illinois Banking Bill
description: Gov. James Thompson of Illinois will probably sign a bill setting Dec. 1, 1990, as the date for opening the state to wider interstate banking, a gubernatorial spokesman said today. ''The only question is whether he will use his authority to change the trigger date,'' the spokesman said. The bill allows Illinois banks and bank holding companies to be acquired by similar institutions from any state with a reciprocal law.

title: UNTANGLING 42D STREET: TRAFFIC TO GO WEST (ONLY)
description: City officials are planning in October to convert 42d Street to a one-way street westbound for automobiles and trucks, with two lanes to be reserved in the opposite direction exclusively for buses.

title: Bond Prices Advance Slightly
description: Bond prices moved slightly higher yesterday in listless, pre-weekend trading, after being off a bit at the opening.

title: Elation, Relief and Sadness In Louisiana as Fight Ends
description: Louisiana's public schools, beset with budget problems and widely criticized as failing to provide adequate education, today faced one problem fewer because of the Supreme Court decision striking down a state law requiring the teaching of the divine theory of creation along with any teaching of evolution.

title: TEXAS PANEL REITERATES VOW TO BAR UNFIT DOCTORS
description: Citing five elderly Texans who died after receiving what was described as inferior medical care, the official peer organization that monitors Texas doctors vowed today to continue to bar incompetent ones from the Medicare program.

title: IF IT'S THORPE, IT'S THE OPEN
description: Six years ago Jim Thorpe, one of the few black golfers on the PGA Tour, returned to his Philadelphia motel as the first-round leader in his first United States Open after a 66 at Merion.

title: PROMOTING THE PRODUCE OF NEW YORK
description: Whether in competition for a football team or a company headquarters, New York and New Jersey are frequently rivals. But not when it comes to agricultural products. In that contest, New York State does not even play in the same league.

title: Ex-Police Chief and 3 Others Get Jail Terms in Exam Case
description: Four men, including a former police chief of Revere, Mass., and two former officers, were sentenced to prison today for participating in a scheme to steal, sell and alter police promotional examinations.

title: Senate Fails, for Fifth Time, To End Election Fund Debate
description: Senate Democrats failed today, for the fifth time since June 3, to break the Republican filibuster against Democratic legislation to revise the way Senate elections are financed.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Coach Dan Gable of Iowa has suspended Brad Penrith, his all-America wrestler, indefinitely after Penrith was arrested for the third time in 13 months. Penrith, who won the National Collegiate Athletic Association 126-pound title last year and was second this year, pleaded guilty to charges of disorderly conduct and public intoxication and was fined after a fight on Tuesday in front of a bar in Iowa City. . . . Billy Thompson, a rookie forward on the Los Angeles Lakers, will undergo arthroscopic surgery on Monday in Inglewood, Calif., for examination of an injury to his left knee. He suffered the injury in the final game of the Lakers' first round playoff series against the Denver Nuggets and did not play again. . . . Joe Dial, who broke his own American record in the pole vault for the second week in a row on Thursday, cleared 19 feet 6 1/2 inches in Norman, Okla. A week earlier in Albuquerque, N.M. he jumped 19-5 3/4. Dial, an assistant track coach at the University of Oklahoma, tried twice to clear 19-9 for a world record, but failed both times. . . . Sue Scheetz, who coached Penn State to the N.C.A.A. women's lacrosse championship last month, was named coach of the year by the Intercollegiate Women's Lacrosse Coaches Association. . . . Greg LeMond, who suffered gunshot wounds in a hunting accident two months ago, will compete in the Coors International Bicycle Classic in Hawaii Aug. 5-23, race officials announced.

title: POLICE REVIEW A POSSIBLE BID TO ABDUCT BOY
description: Detectives are investigating the possible attempted abduction of an 11-year-old boy by a man with a blue van outside a private school in Manhattan two weeks ago. The boy said he broke away and fled unharmed.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 10.

title: Ruling Foils Latest Strategy In Fighting Idea of Evolution
description: Ever since Charles Darwin published his seminal study ''On the Origin of Species by Means of Natural Selection'' in 1859, his theory of evolution has been anathema to some religious denominations, fueling a wider, continuing debate over religion and public education.

title: IN SOUTHERN RUSSIA, A GLIMPSE OF DEMOCRACY
description: As the ritual of a Soviet political campaign drew to a close this week, the citizens of this agricultural center on the Russian steppes faced an unfamiliar predicament in their local elections: a choice.

title:
Patents;
Phone Line Linkup for Computers
description: LEAD: A SYSTEM for connecting personal computers with existing telephone lines was patented this week for the American Telephone and Telegraph Company. Called the Starlan Local Area Network, the system is said to permit more than 100 personal computers to share their operations.

title: YANKEES WIN, 10-5, IN 13
description: Behind closed doors, decisions were being made. But while Lou Piniella and Woody Woodward conducted a lengthy meeting late tonight, Charles Hudson basked in a moment's glory.

title: WATSON'S PLAY AT OPEN REVIVES SOME MEMORIES
description: Tom Watson made his most impressive move in three years to recapture the glory days when he shot the lowest score in the first 36 holes of the 87th United States Open today, five-under-par 65 on The Olympic Club's Lake Course.

title: Fears That Are Tearing New York Apart
description: Although many people have argued that the acquittal of Bernhard H. Goetz for attempted murder is a single incident having unique circumstances, there can be no doubt that the verdict has larger implications for New York City, particularly in the wake of a racial attack in the Howard Beach section of Queens and other recent incidents involving rising racial tensions.

title: HIGH COURT VOIDS CURB ON TEACHING EVOLUTION THEORY
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that states may not require the teaching of the creationist theory of man's origin alongside evolution in public schools if such requirements are intended to promote religious belief.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Tennis Sukova Defeats Evert: Helena Sukova of Czechoslovakia rallied from 2-5 in the final set and beat Chris Evert, 4-6, 6-4, 8-6, yesterday in Eastbourne, England, to reach the final of the $200,000 Pilkington Glass women's grass-court tennis championships for the third consecutive year. Sukova, seeded third, will meet the winner of the other semifinal between the defending champion, Martina Navratilova, and Pam Shriver. Their match was suspended because of bad weather, with Navratilova leading, 4-3, in the first set. It will be resumed today, when the organizers also hope to stage the final. Sukova, who beat Evert in their last meeting, at the 1986 United States Open, won in 2 hours 25 minutes. Sukova combined some wild serving - 16 double faults - with stunningly effective volleying in defeating Evert, who was seeded second . (AP) Tournament Off Schedule: Rain postponed play in the Bristol Trophy men's grass-court tennis tournament in Bristol, England, leaving officials with a backup of matches on the final weekend before Wimbledon, which starts Monday. The tournament was to have ended today, giving the players a rest day before Wimbledon. Now, organizers said, the championship match will be held tomorrow, if the weather allows enough matches to be played today.(AP) Skoff Loses Tiebreaker: Horst Skoff of Austria, seeded second, was beaten by Pavel Vojtisek, an unseeded West German player, 7-6, 6-4, in a quarterfinal match of a Grand Prix tournament in Athens. Skoff served five aces in the first set of the two-hour match, and broke Vojtisek's service twice, but lost the tiebreaker on a double fault. Vojtisek will play fourth-seeded Guillermo Perez-Roldan of Argentina in the semifinals today. Perez-Roldan beat Marian Vadja of Czechoslovakia, 6-4, 6-4, in a one-hour match. In the other quarterfinals, Francisco Yunis of Argentina defeated Jaro Navratil of Czechoslovakia, 6-3, 7-5, and Tore Meinecke of West Germany beat Pedro Rebolledo of Chile, 6-1, 7-6, rallying from a 0-5 deficit in the second set.(AP) Golf South Korean Leads Keystone: Ok-Hee Ku of South Korea, who hasn't won in two seasons on the L.P.G.A. Tour, shot a five-under-par 67 yesterday to take the first-round lead at the $300,000 Lady Keystone Open in Hershey, Pa. She had six birdies and one bogey on the 6,438-yard West Course of the Hershey Country Club and held a one-stroke lead over Sally Little, who birdied three of the final four holes on her way to a 68. Muffin Spencer-Devlin, Cathy Gerring, Lenore Muraoka, Judy Sams and Marta Figueras Dotti were tied for third at 69. Ayako Okamoto of Japan was at 70 with Cathy Morse, Beth Solomon, Missie McGeorge and Kris Monaghan. Betsy King, the leading money-winner on the tour with $302,806, withdrew from the tournament with a sprained ankle.(AP)

title: Richard Drayne, 49, Counsel for CBS News
description: Richard Drayne, public affairs counsel for CBS News in Washington and a former press secretary and adviser to Senator Edward M. Kennedy, died of cancer yesterday at his home in Washington. He was 49 years old.

title:
Patents;
A Seat for Meditation
description: LEAD: A Los Angeles sculptor who believes in the benefits of meditation received a patent this week for what he has trademarked as the Lotus Seat. It is designed to offer long comfort to people using a cross-legged sitting position. Patent 4,673,216 was awarded to Jaroslaw G. Alfer.

title: Lloyds Ends Eurobond Tie
description: Lloyds Bank, a leading British bank, said today that it would stop dealing in the $3.5 trillion Eurobond market, one of the biggest international markets. The bank also said it would stop making a market in British Government bonds.

title: Trap Is More Likely to Work Against the Novice Defender
description: The ''right'' line of play may vary according to the caliber of the opposition. If your opponent is a high-ranked player, it is rarely right to deviate from the technically correct strategy. But against a defender of lesser experience, a trap can be tried in the reasonable hope that he will tumble into it.

title: Letter: On Politics; Reforming Campaigns, Constitutionally
description: To the Editor:

title: Sainsbury in Pact For 74% of Shaw's
description: J Sainsbury P.L.C. said it had an agreement that would allow it to increase its stake in Shaw's Supermarkets Inc. to 74 percent. The British supermarket chain also said it had already raised its stake in the New England company to 49.4 percent.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: Much

title: Iraq No. 1 Arms Importer, U.S. Discloses in a Study
description: Iraq has become the world's principal arms importer, according to a Government report made public today.

title: DOW ENDS AT 2,420.85, A RECORD
description: The stock market pushed further into record territory yesterday, led by the blue-chip Dow Jones industrial average, which closed at a record 2,420.85, up 12.72 points.

title: Excerpts From Supreme Court Opinions in Creationism Case
description: Following are excerpts from the opinions in the Supreme Court's decision today striking down a Louisiana law requiring public schools that teach the theory of evolution also to teach the theory of creation as a science. Justice William J. Brennan Jr. wrote the Court's opinion, joined by Justices Thurgood Marshall, Harry A. Blackmun, Lewis F. Powell Jr. and John Paul Stevens and in part by Justice Sandra Day O'Connor. Justice Powell wrote a concurring opinion joined by Justice O'Connor. Justice Byron R. White wrote an opinion concurring in the result. Justice Antonin Scalia dissented, joined by Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist. FROM THE OPINION By Justice Brennan

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A photograph in Weekend yesterday with a review of Beverly Pepper's art exhibition portrayed a work incorrectly. The work, ''Goliath Wedge,'' was printed upside down.

title: Article 797387 -- No Title
description: Shearson Lehman Brothers said yesterday that it was trying to recover about $19 million from Mark A. Stahl, a former senior vice president who has pleaded guilty to checking-account manipulations that allowed him to divert company funds into his own outside accounts and investments.

title: Washington's Mayor Assails U.S. Attorney on Drug Report
description: Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. today accused the United States Attorney here, Joseph E. diGenova, of trying ''to run me out of office'' after a television report was broadcast Thursday evening linking the Mayor with cocaine use.

title: Warning Preceded U.S. Reporter's Abduction
description: At least 24 hours before an American journalist was kidnapped near Beirut, Lebanon, the United States Embassy there received intelligence that an American had been marked for abduction, Administration officials said tonight.

title: Carnegie Hall Cinema Reopens, Gleaming and Elegant
description: New York's oldest auditorium for showing movies reopened yesterday with a new face. After months of architectural and technical renovation, the Carnegie Hall Cinema has been transformed into one of the most elegant cinematic settings in the city.

title: PHILS DEFEND HIRING OF ELIA AS MANAGER
description: Bill Giles, the Philadelphia Phillies' president, today defended his selection of Lee Elia as manager in the face of criticism from the Rev. Jesse Jackson and Dr. Harry Edwards.

title: Long Prose Poem
description: THE RED TRUCK. By Rudy Wilson. 178 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $15.95.

title: U.S. Tells Court Subpoena Errs In Deaver Case
description: The Justice Department charged today that the special prosecutor in the Michael K. Deaver perjury case had ''mischaracterized facts'' and was using ''irrelevant legal principles'' in pursuing a subpoena for the Canadian Ambassador to the United States.

title: U.S. Jews Say Waldheim Issue Imperils Meeting With Pope
description: Leaders of several major Jewish organizations said yesterday that Pope John Paul II's willingness to grant an audience to President Kurt Waldheim of Austria could disrupt plans for a meeting between the Pope and Jewish leaders in Miami in September.

title: Uncovered Short Sales Rise by 6.6% on Big Board
description: The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday that the number of shares sold short and not yet covered in the month ended June 15 rose by 28.9 million, or 6.6 percent, to 465.8 million shares. The record of 470.6 million shares was set in the month ended April 15. The period a year earlier totaled 349.8 million shares.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, JUNE 20, 1987
description: Companies

title: NORTH REJECTS DEAL ON TESTIMONY
description: Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North's lawyer has rejected a Congressional proposal to break an impasse over Colonel North's testimony before the committees investigating the Iran-contra affair, legislators said today.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The Weekender Guide in Weekend yesterday gave an incorrect telephone number for the Three Beauties film festival starting at the Regency Theater on Sunday. The correct number is 724-3700.

title: USE OF LIE DETECTORS IN THE WORKPLACE IS ASSAILED
description: Hundreds of thousands of honest employees are mistakenly branded as liars or thieves every year as a result of examinations by polygraph, or lie-detector, Attorney General Robert Abrams of New York told a Senate committee today.

title: Schroeder Will Run for President If Her Campaign Can Pay for Itself
description: Representative Patricia Schroeder of Colorado said today that she would become a candidate for the 1988 Democratic Presidential nomination in September if she raised enough money by then to run a debt-free campaign.

title: Argentine Plan Credited to Alfonsin
description: Argentina's ability to line up, in a matter of weeks, more than 90 percent of a $1.95 billion package of new financing is a vote of confidence in the economic policies of President Raul Alfonsin, experts on debt said yesterday.

title: About New York; Tired of Ties? One 'Perfect' Gift Is a Goetz Ballad
description: '' 'Subway Vigilante' is a lovely song with a nice melody and a real folksy quality,'' asserts Ronald Gold, whose group recorded the number, subtitled ''The Ballad of Bernhard Goetz.'' ''It is singable, hummable and danceable -the perfect Father's Day gift.''

title: New Charge for a Chief Of Philadelphia Mafia
description: Nicodemo (Little Nicky) Scarfo, a reputed leader of organized crime who has already been convicted of an extortion attempt and is facing murder charges, was accused Thursday of running a drug ring, along with 27 other people.

title: Women Join Optimist Club
description: Optimist International, a service organization, announced today that it had begun accepting women as members for the first time since it was founded in 1919. A spokesman for the 160,000-member organization said the group's board approved the move a week ago, but held off the announcement to permit time to inform the presidents of the nearly 4,000 Optimist Clubs in the United States, Canada and the Caribbean.

title: GREYHOUND IN DEAL FOR TRAILWAYS
description: The financially troubled Trailways Corporation, whose red-and-white buses once traveled to more than 40 states, is conceding the nation's roads to its much-larger rival, Greyhound Lines Inc.

title: SHULTZ WARNS ASIA NATIONS ON TRADE
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz warned six nations of Southeast Asia today that even if the Reagan Administration thwarted protectionist trade legislation, they should not expect to increase their markets in the United States.

title: HARLEM HOMECOMING: A READING OF HUGHES
description: The actor Danny Glover was at the Studio Museum in Harlem Thursday night to read the poems of Langston Hughes.

title: Chrysler Sets Deal For Electrospace
description: The Chrysler Corporation today announced an agreement to acquire Electrospace Systems Inc., a Texas-based producer of communications equipment, for $27 a share, or $367 million.

title: South Koreans' Anger at Rulers Is Also Turned Against U.S.
description: The anti-Government demonstrations over the last week have also been an occasion for many Koreans to vent their anger at the United States.

title: TULANE PLANS BUILDUP
description: The Tulane University board of administrators has approved a proposal calling for reinstatement of men's basketball and a $25 million, five-year fund-raising campaign for all sports.

title: Savard Joins Nordiques
description: Only one day after Michel Bergeron, their coach for the last seven years, had signed a multiyear contract with the Rangers in New York, the Quebec Nordiques replaced him yesterday with Andre Savard, a former National Hockey League center and coach in the minor leagues.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It is complicated, deciding how to give out our votes. We are now obliged to cross out names, and that is difficult.''

title: U.S. Drops Case Charging Fraud By Arms Maker
description: A Federal judge today dismissed a criminal indictment against the General Dynamics Corporation and four executives charged with illegally billing the Army for millions of dollars in cost overruns on a prototype of the Sergeant York antiaircraft gun.

title: Immunity for Diplomats, Not Officials
description: Two important mechanisms are bashed together in the Justice Department's strange new assault on the special prosecutor law. One is the idea that independent lawyers should investigate when high officials are charged with misconduct. The other is diplomatic immunity, which protects foreign representatives from prosecution for whatever charges are cooked up in other countries.

title: MOODY 2D AFTER BIRDIE SPREE
description: Orville Moody's putting got sizzling hot for six birdies in the last nine holes today and that put him in second place after two rounds of the Northville Invitational for seniors.

title: Colorado Farmers Threaten to Sue U.S. to Stop Water Delivery
description: Farmers who were thirsting for irrigation water here in southwest Colorado 10 years ago now say it is too costly, and they are threatening to sue the Federal Government to stop its delivery to their farms.

title: Angolan Official Says Release Of a U.S. Pilot Is Imminent
description: A visiting Angolan official told members of Congress and the Rev. Jesse Jackson this week that an American civilian pilot imprisoned in Angola would be released ''quite soon.''

title: Albert C. Wagner Dies at 76; Headed Jersey Prison System
description: Albert C. Wagner, former director of the New Jersey Division of Correction and Parole, died of a heart attack Monday in Portsmouth, England, where he was vacationing. He was 76 years old and lived in Ewing Township, N.J., near Trenton.

title: Jazz: Charlie Haden on Bass With His Quartet West
description: Charlie Haden's Quartet West, which has been playing its first New York engagement this week at the Village Vanguard, is one of three current projects for the bassist and composer. The others are a new edition of his Liberation Music Orchestra and a reunion of the original Ornette Coleman Quartet, which included Mr. Haden as a charter member. The latter two endeavors have an aura of significance about them; Mr. Haden's Quartet West seems to have more to do with relaxing, playing some jazz, having some fun.

title: It Takes Luck to Collect Social Security Checks
description: To the Editor:

title: NUCLEAR OFFICIAL VOWS TO KEEP JOB DESPITE CALLS FOR HIS RESIGNATION
description: Thomas M. Roberts, a member of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission who has been accused of showing favoratism to the nuclear power industry, vowed today to remain on the commission and called accusations against him ''ludicrous.''

title: Gleason Ends Hospital Stay
description: The entertainer Jackie Gleason has been released from the hospital where he spent nearly a month recuperating from complications he suffered after taking prescription drugs. ''Due to the family's wishes, that is all we can disclose,'' Debra Rand, a spokeswoman for the Imperial Point Medical Center, said today.

title: Case Against Ohioan Lost by U.S.
description: Marvin L. Warner was acquitted today of all Federal charges stemming from a 1985 savings and loan collapse that touched off a statewide financial crisis in Ohio.

title: U.S. Jews Say Waldheim Issue Imperils Meeting With Pope; Vatican Explains Decision
description: The Pope agreed to meet with President Waldheim only after Mr. Waldheim had repeatedly pressed his request, senior Vatican officials said today.

title: N.A.A.C.P. LEADER SEEKS FEDERAL CASE ON GOETZ
description: Benjamin L. Hooks Jr., the executive director of the N.A.A.C.P., said yesterday that he would ask the United States Attorney in Manhattan to re-examine whether Bernhard H. Goetz could be prosecuted under Federal civil-rights laws.

title: Brodsky Quits Arts Group Over Yevtushenko Induction
description: Joseph Brodsky, the Soviet-born poet, essayist and translator, has resigned from the American Academy and Institute of Arts and Letters in protest over its inducting Yevgeny Yevtushenko, the Soviet poet, as an honorary member.

title: Article 760287 -- No Title
description: After showing a rare surplus in April, the Federal budget was in deficit again in May, with a shortfall of $35.7 billion, the Treasury Department said today. In April, a surge in receipts from 1986 income tax payments that were due on the 15th brought a surplus of $38.7 billion.

title: 2 TRIALS ORDERED FOR DEFENDANTS IN RACIAL ATTACKS
description: A Queens judge ruled yesterday that there would be two trials on the Howard Beach racial-attack case.

title: BEHAVIOR OF MEYERSON CITED IN '80
description: In a romance with a financial investor seven years ago, Bess Myerson displayed obsessive behavior, making numerous anonymous telephone calls and sending abusive letters, according to a police report prepared at the time.

title: Johnson Is Top Gymnast
description: Scott Johnson, one of two gold medal winners from the 1984 Olympic gymnastic team still competing, won the men's United States Gymnastics Championships tonight and led a group of 19 who qualified for the American national team.

title: Bahamian Premier Is Re-Elected; Aide Says U.S. Meddled in Vote
description: The deputy leader of the political party that has ruled the Bahamas for 20 years and that has been widely accused of corruption, declared victory in national elections tonight, giving Prime Minister Lynden O. Pindling a sixth term in office.

title: Third-Class Mail Is Alive, Well and Paying Its Way
description: To the Editor:

title: CALIFORNIA SYMBOL OF AN ERA IS IN DECLINE
description: The Ambassador Hotel in Los Angeles, once the site of merrymaking by movie stars and pronouncements by politicians, faces an uncertain future.

title: FAHD AGREES TO WIDER U.S. AIR PATROL
description: King Fahd of Saudi Arabia has agreed to permit United States Awacs surveillance planes operating from Saudi bases to expand their patrol zones over the Persian Gulf, American officials said today.

title: Creditor Will Challenge PTL
description: The PTL ministry's largest creditor told a television network today that he would challenge in bankruptcy court plans to reorganize PTL and that only Jim Bakker ''can make this ministry work.''

title:
Patents;
Laser Surgery By Computer
description: LEAD: A method and apparatus for computer-controlled laser surgery were patented this week by Israel Barken of San Diego. Patent 4,672,963 explains that an ultrasonic probe provides signals to the computer, permitting creation of images of body tissues and enabling the physician to select tissues that should be removed.

title: Chip Makers Report Gains
description: After eight quarters of losses, the National Semiconductor Corporation returned to profitability in its fourth quarter, ended May 31. Separately, Micron Technology Inc., a semiconductor manufacturer based in Boise, Idaho, today reported sharply reduced losses in its third quarter ended June 4.

title: Brown Water in Jersey City
description: Residents here may have discolored tap water and low water pressure during the next 10 days because of a water loan to Newark, Tom Neilan, director of the city's Water Department, said today. Jersey City, which usually runs about 60 million gallons of water through its pipes each day, is loaning 20 million gallons a day to Newark, Mr. Neilan said.

title: JACOBS CALLS HOLDINGS IN GILLETTE 'SUBSTANTIAL'
description: Irwin L. Jacobs, the Minneapolis investor, disclosed yesterday that he owned ''a substantial'' block of stock in the Gillette Company.

title: TV: 'AMERICAN PROMISE,' ON 4, LOOKS AT SCHOOLS
description: What does a public school do? In New York, it may fill, or try to fill, the role of home and family. The figures are staggering: 936,000 students, attended by 104,000 employes in 1,000 buildings, spend up to 11 hours in school each day, while being fed 622,000 meals. ''The American Promise: No Place Like School,'' on Channel 4 at 9:30 tonight, doesn't say America's social structure has broken down, but it does say it has changed.

title: CAR LIGHTS IN DAYTIME PROPOSED
description: The Transportation Department is considering a proposal for a safety measure already in effect in some other countries: the use of running lights on cars during the day.

title: DAY AFTER CRACK RAID IT'S STILL CAT AND MOUSE
description: The day after 200 police officers raided crack dens in a two-block stretch of West 107th Street, neighborhood residents said that drug dealers had adopted a lower profile, but remained active.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Springfield, Mass.;
A Livable Downtown
description: LEAD: ENCOURAGED by this city's success in revitalizing its central business district, condominium developers have discovered that the community's downtown is now a marketable residential address.

title: AN UNLIKELY LAB FOR FREE MARKETS
description: ON a continent known for protectionism and government control over the economy, Chile's controversial effort to create a market economy is finally showing signs of success after a drastic collapse in 1982 and 1983.

title: VISITING THE ELDERLY: AN EXPERT'S ADVICE
description: ''I ONLY got one foot into her room when my mother said, 'My fingers don't sew, my eyes can't read and my ears are like stones. What do you mean I must keep occupied? You don't understand me.' Then I lost my cool and I yelled at her. Now I feel terrible.''

title: FIBER ARTS EXPLORED
description: ''IT COULD be thought of in terms of entering a new space, with all the joy, fear and trepidation of going beyond where you've comfortably settled.''

title: HOLLYWOOD HOPES FOR A LONG, HOT SUMMER
description: IN Hollywood, summer is a synonym for money.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It takes King Fahd about 10 seconds to sign a check. It takes Congress weeks to debate the smallest issue of this sort. If you can get somebody else to pay for it, it's nice and convenient.''

title:
THE ARTS;
INSTITUTE TAPS WELL OF CREATIVITY
description: LEAD: ALTHOUGH Edwin Romond considers himself primarily a teacher who writes - he teaches English at Warren Hills High School in the Warren County community of Washington -for 10 days a year he becomes a poet.

title: In East Harlem, Millionaire Nurtures Dreams
description: Six years ago Eugene Lang, a millionaire industrialist, offered 61 sixth-grade students in East Harlem a chance to reach an impossible dream. If they stuck to their school work, he said, he would guarantee them a college education.

title: First With Radical Chic
description: To the Editor:

title: BATTLE OVER PLAN FOR BALTIMORE STADIUMS TAKES ON EPIC TONE
description: Citing precedents from ancient Greece and Rome, Gov. William Donald Shaefer's administration is pressing a $200 million plan to build a pair of professional sports coliseums here that Baltimoreans apparently do not want and that the Governor himself concedes would probably be given the thumbs-down by other Marylanders.

title: SUMMER JOBS IN COUNTY OUTRUN LABOR POOL
description: WORKING for the minimum wage in Westchester is ''a thing of the past,'' a spokesman for the State Labor Department's Westchester region said last week, adding that summer-job opportunities for young adults in the county had never been better.

title: Q and A
description: Hardship Increase Question: I own several rent-controlled apartments in a co-op that was converted under a noneviction plan a few years ago. I have complied with all of the rent-regulation rules and have gotten the regular increases. But the rent my tenants pay does not even cover the maintenance on the units, let alone my return on the capital investment. Am I eligible for a hardship increase? T. B., Manhattan Answer: Regulations of the state's Division of Housing and Community Renewal, which supervises rent-regulated housing, allow owners of rent-controlled units to file with the agency for hardship rent increases. Whether a rent increase will be granted, however, will depend on the circumstances of your situation.

title: FOR A CHANGE, THE NORTH RIM
description: My family wasn't the traveling kind, and I grew up without seeing the Grand Canyon, although my parents did swing West on their own one summer and sent back a postcard of themselves perched on mules and angling around a steep cliff on their way down the canyon. Impressed as I was by the technology that put my mother and father on a postcard, that card was probably the start of my misapprehension of the Grand Canyon as a giant teacup-shaped hole in a dusty desert.

title: Bakker Ally Denies PTL Plan
description: The PTL ministry's biggest creditor, an ally of the ousted Jim Bakker, disputes a report that he and others owed money by the ailing ministry will challenge its bankruptcy reorganization plan with one of their own.

title: William Florence Weds Ms. Carter
description: The marriage of Anna Helm Carter and William David Florence, candidates for Master of Divinity degrees at the Princeton Theological Seminary, took place yesterday at the First Congregational Church in Guilford, Conn. The Rev. Suzanne P. M. Rudiselle, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony. She was assisted by the Rev. Kendrick Norris, senior pastor of the church, and Shira Lander, a student at the Hebrew Union Rabbinical School in Los Angeles.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: LEAD: FATHER'S DAY DOINGS Father's Day is upon us, so you might as well take advantage of whatever fate has to offer. For example, just as the complex does for everybody else's special day, the Museums at Stony Brook throw open their doors to Dad, who from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. can visit the site's various components, including its brand new Carriage Museum, free, while all around him others are paying $4, or $3 for senior citizens, $2.75 for students and $2 for children 6 through 12.

title:
INVESTING;
Buying Mutual Funds at the Bank
description: LEAD: AT least half of typical bank customers would consider switching their savings and checking accounts to another bank if that bank sold mutual funds, according to a recent survey by Market Facts Inc., a Chicago research firm.

title: TOXIC ASH: GARBAGE THAT WON'T GO AWAY
description: LEAD: AS municipalities on Long Island and across the country continue to move toward garbage-to-energy incineration as a solution to their mounting solid-waste problems, a debate is emerging over whether the ash produced by incinerators is toxic enough to be classified as hazardous waste.

title: WALL CRACKS AND OTHER PROBLEMS
description: TO catch up on mail from readers, the Home Clinic column this week is again devoted to questions about common maintenance and repair problems.

title: ALICE BELKNAP MEADE Weds in Washington
description: At St. Mark's Episcopal Church in Washington yesterday, Alice Belknap Meade, an application developer for the Lotus Development Corporation in New York, was married to Gard Landgrave Little, the manager of personal-computer operations at the Computer Consulting Center in New York. The Rev. James R. Adams, assisted by the Rev. Susan Gresinger, performed the ceremony.

title: Preakness Point
description: To the Sports Editor: Bet Twice won the Belmont Stakes by 14 lengths. But he had lost the Preakness though he was similarly situated throughout the race. The critics leveled their ire on Jose Santos riding Cryptoclearance and thought Craig Perret on Bet Twice gave the horse an exemplary race.

title: ISRAEL WAS EVERTHING
description: BEN-GURION The Burning Ground 1886-1948. By Shabtai Teveth. Illustrated. 967 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company. $35.

title: Blockwatcher Arrogance
description: To the Editor:

title: Doing More With Less in Crafting a Work Station
description: AS rents continue to rise, companies are breaking old rules - and discarding old furniture - to squeeze more people into less office space.

title: The Shape Of Ford's Success
description: Few doubt that Jack Telnack is among the better automobile designers today (''The Shape of Ford's Success,'' by Phil Patton, May 24). But I think it's proper to challenge the thesis of your story, with its stress on design as the reason for the enthusiastic response to the Ford Taurus line.

title: About Cars; HONDA HITS BULL'S-EYE IN LUXURY DRIVE
description: HONDA has long been thought of as the maker of Everyman's Mercedes. And the rumor that the Japanese company was indeed gunning for part of the European luxury market started so long ago that its most unbelievable facet was the projected price tag of $20,000.

title: BANKER IS ACCUSED OF SHOOTING YOUTH
description: A retired Salomon Brothers investment banker, who is a grandson of one of the firm's founders, shot and seriously wounded a Larchmont teen-ager during an apparent traffic dispute on the Hutchinson River Parkway, then fled in his car, the police said yesterday.

title: OF RACE, CRIME AND PUNISHMENT
description: THE United States Supreme Court has declared that it is unpersuaded by statistical evidence indicating that the capital-case processing system in Georgia may be significantly affected by race, in particular by whether or not the victim is white.

title:
ART;
'FIT FOR AMERICA,' FITNESS FROM 1830 TO 1940, IN YONKERS
description: LEAD: A WHITE soccer ball sent bounding across the lawn outside the Hudson River Museum in Yonkers by a band of children served as a lively visual overture for this visitor to ''Fit for America,'' a survey of fitness, sport and American society from 1830 to 1940. The theme is still very much with us.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: LEAD: THE ''IT'' GIRLS: Lucy, Lady Duff Gordon, the Couturiere ''Lucile,'' and Elinor Glyn, Romantic Novelist. By Meredith Etherington-Smith and Jeremy Pilcher. (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $17.95.) Elinor Glyn and her sister, Lucy, did very well for themselves. Daughters of a genteel but impoverished Isle of Jersey family, each managed to become an arbiter of style in a society closed to all but the properly rich and aristocratic.

title: PATRICIA CHU MARRIED TO LEE BAYLOR EWING
description: Patricia Pei-chang Chu and Lee Baylor Ewing were married yesterday at the West End Collegiate Church in New York. The Rev. Kenneth Gorsuch, pastor of the church, and the Very Rev. James Parks Morton, Dean of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, performed the ceremony.

title: Dance
description: ''Fresh Tracks'' is what Dance Theater Workshop calls its program by six young choreographers on Tuesday night at the Bessie Schonberg Theater. That title also describes other dance events this week, for works by many new choreographers will be on view. The ''Fresh Tracks'' choreographers are Carol Clements, Meg Eginton, Ruth Fuglistaller, Betsy Hulton, Carol Kueffer and Aspassia Yaga. Their dances include an evocation of a Cezanne landscape, a portrait of a Victorian couple torn between reserve and desire and a serio-comic solo said to depict the lighter side of depression.

title: THE KING LIVES
description: The grass courts in England are like a trampoline, propelling Boris Becker to new heights. It could be seen in the self-assured way the West German teen-ager carried himself at the Queens Club tournament in London, two weeks ago, that he won for the second time. It is evident in the way he looks forward to playing at Wimbledon, his tennis home, as he calls it.

title: Syphilis Held More Perilous If the AIDS Virus Is Present
description: Two new reports suggest that syphilis may be especially dangerous and hard to treat in people infected with the AIDS virus.

title: Pamela Dowling Becomes a Bride
description: The marriage of Pamela Jane Dowling, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Kevin V. Dowling of West Hartford and Madison, Conn., to James T. Healey Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Healey of West Hartford, took place yesterday in Farmington, Conn. The Rev. James Conefrey, assisted by Msgr. John Kennedy and the Rev. Francis Hale, performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Patrick.

title: No Headline
description: THE SPY WORE RED My Adventures as an Undercover Agent in World War II. By Aline, Countess of Romanones. 304 pp. New York: Random House. $18.95.

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: LEAD: A NEW report by the Morristown-based New Jersey Conservation Foundation warns that uncontrolled development is imposing unmanageable costs on the state.

title: THE CONSTITUTION CLOSEST TO HOME
description: WHEN New York's top court invalidated random drug testing for public employees earlier this month, it virtually insulated its ruling from reversal by the United States Supreme Court by citing the State Constitution as well as the Federal. More significantly, the ruling provided the latest evidence that the Court of Appeals has joined - and some would say is beginning to lead - other courts that have answered a clarion call first sounded by William J. Brennan Jr., the senior and most liberal member of the United States Supreme Court, 10 years ago.

title: A GUIDE TO LONDON'S RARE BOOKS
description: If, as some say, England is the world of English literature, then to spend a week or so immersed in London bookshops will put one in touch with a whole range of its culture and history - to say nothing of savoring the comfortable melange of rooms with densely packed bookshelves that has been the traditional domain of the London antiquarian bookseller. ''Generous, liberal-minded men'' and ''anxious for the encouragement of literature'' were two phrases Dr. Johnson used to describe the booksellers in the 18th century.

title: What the Questions Tell About the Questioners
description: AFTER six weeks of hearings into the Iran-contra affair, the members of the joint Congressional committees have begun to emerge as familiar personalities. Some have been eloquent, like Representative Lee H. Hamilton, the chairman of the House panel. Some have proved to be doughty defenders of the Reagan Administration, like Senator Orrin G. Hatch. A few, like Senator George J. Mitchell, have pursued a consistent thread of inquiry. And one, Representative Les Aspin, has been notable for his absence. In all, the questions, and sometimes the soliloquies, of certain legislators have given shape to the proceedings. What follows is a guide to some of the Senators and Representatives who have made important contributions so far and who are likely to remain in the spotlight when the hearings resume Tuesday. DANIEL K. INOUYE

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: Have Genes, Will Travel THE passenger seats came out and the Micropipets, spectrophotometers and electrophoresis apparatuses went in. The Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory has just created its second mobile DNA lab, a specially equipped van that makes a summer tour of high schools and universities around the country.

title: Democratic Cash Flows to Dukakis
description: The Presidential campaign of Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts said today that it had raised $3 million and expects the figure to reach $3.5 million by the end of the month.

title:
GARDENING;
WAYS TO BRING FLOWERING AND FRUITING
description: LEAD: AT one time or another, many gardeners have been disappointed when a recently planted tree or shrub fails to bloom the year after it was planted. Often, several years may go by without a floral display. This can be especially perplexing when the plant had flowers on it when it was purchased.

title:
GARDENING;
WAYS TO BRING FLOWERING AND FRUITING
description: LEAD: AT one time or another, many gardeners have been disappointed when a recently planted tree or shrub fails to bloom the year after it was planted. Often, several years may go by without a floral display. This can be especially perplexing when the plant had flowers on it when it was purchased.

title: Landslides Triggered By Electorate Apathy
description: To the Editor:

title: Joys of the Appetite and the Arts
description: In the 1700's, a successful sugar cane harvest was celebrated with dancing, singing and feasting on Antilles Island plantations. This summer, in Jamaica and Barbados, there will be festivals of local history, culture and food recalling the celebrations. The first ''Jamaica Bruckins'' will be held through Dec. 11 in Ochos Rios and at Montego Bay. The 14th annual ''Crop Over Festival'' in Bridgetown, Barbados - with calypso competitions, a fair and a costume show - runs from July 11 to Aug. 3.

title: A Bid to Seize Control From the States
description: CRITICS of the insurance industry are trying to capitalize on the recent ''crisis'' of higher premiums, as well as a general suspicion among the public of antitrust exemptions, to achieve their long-term goal of eliminating state control of insurance, and replacing it with Federal control. They would achieve this by drastically modifying, or even repealing, the McCarran-Ferguson Act of 1945, which exempts the insurance industry from certain provisions of our Federal antitrust laws. Congress should not be fooled.

title: READING THEIR SIGNALS
description: THE BOAT OF QUIET HOURS By Jane Kenyon. 85 pp. St. Paul: Graywolf Press. Paper, $8. TALKING TO STRANGERS By Patricia Dobler. 65 pp. Madison: The University of Wisconsin Press. Cloth, $12.50. Paper, $7.95. LOVE, DEATH, AND THE CHANGING OF THE SEASONS By Marilyn Hacker. 212 pp. New York: Arbor House. Cloth, $30. Paper, $7.95.

title: New York Is Seeking to End Conversions by 4 Landlords
description: The New York State Attorney General is seeking to put four landlords out of the cooperative conversion business because they filed fraudulent documents concealing an excessive warehousing of vacant apartments in two Manhattan buildings, according to separate court complaints.

title: POSTINGS: Long-Term Loan; Tokyo Takeout
description: To those major borrowers of mortgage money who think that interest rates will soon tumble, a new financing product called the Tokyo Takeout might be appealing.

title: More Than a Lawyer
description: Orville Schell Jr., who died last week at the age of 78, exemplified the kind of New York lawyer whose public spirit, and career, transcended the practice of law. His name and reputation rank with those of Whitney North Seymour Sr., Orison Marden, Francis Plimpton, Herbert Brownell and Cyrus Vance.

title: Manhattan's 'Fringes' Getting Voguish
description: MANY years and housing trends ago, well-off Manhattan families lived primarily in established residential areas and the less-well-off lived on the fringes.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: SUNDAY, JUNE 21, 1987
description: International 3-17 Tensions climbed in South Korea as thousands of students took to the streets, skirmishing with riot policemen. The students defied a Government warning to stop their protests or face extraordinary measures.
