title: Namibian's Story: Rebel to Jail to Union Chief
description: Benjamin C. Uulenga was fired with idealism for an independent Namibia when he crossed the Angolan border in 1974 en route to Zambia to join guerrillas fighting to liberate this mineral-rich territory.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LEAD: ROAD LINES. By Chris Ould. (Andre Deutsch/David & Charles, Box 57, North Pomfret, Vt. 05053, $18.95.) This first novel by a young Cornish writer belongs to a class of fiction that calls people's attention to the shortcomings of society. Chris Ould blends elements of the political, sociological and detective story into a work of considerable power.

title: STEPHEN FRANK AND JANE REMY MARRY IN BOSTON
description: Trinity Episcopal Church in Boston was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Jane Frances Reny, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lucien Guy Reny of Weston and Westport Harbor, Mass., to Stephen Hamilton Frank, the son of Brooke Baker Frank of Miami and Walter N. Frank Jr. of Locust Valley, L.I.

title: JUSTICES REJECT EQUAL TIME FOR 'CREATION SCIENCE'
description: Christian fundamentalists who have been testing the constitutional line between church and state met a defeat last week as the Supreme Court struck down one of their biggest hopes, a Louisiana statute forbidding the teaching of evolution in public schools unless equal time is given to ''creation science.''

title: CORRECTIONS
description: In a letter commenting on Paul Goldberger's essay ''Bringing Light and Space to a Tenement'' [ May 3 ] , one of the co-signer's names was omitted. The letter was signed by both the interior designer Richard Rosen and by Sharon Zukin, professor of sociology, Brooklyn College and the Graduate Center of the City University of New York.

title: JERSEY WONDERS WHERE ON EARTH TO PUT RADON-TAINTED SOIL
description: When a three-judge Appellate panel agreed last week to take up a temporary storage plan for 15,000 barrels of radon-contaminated soil, it raised the possibility of another prolonged delay in dealing with a not-in-my-backyard problem that has defied resolution for two years.

title: Dance: Jones and Zane
description: CENTRAL PARK'S SummerStage, which opened on Friday at the 72d Street Band Shell, is well on its way to becoming a New York tradition. And Bill T. Jones/Arnie Zane & Company charged the air with the punch and vigor of their dancing, in a program dedicated to the late Willi Smith.

title: Issue on Streak
description: To the Sports Editor: The New York Times on June 5 carried an article by The Associated Press from Madrid reporting that Edwin Moses' winning streak in the 400-meter hurdles ended at 122 victories.

title: HARD CHOICES SEEN FOR CLEAN SOUND
description: LEAD: SCIENTISTS say early indications of a study of pollution in Long Island Sound suggest that Connecticut and New York are likely to face difficult economic and environmental choices in the coming decade.

title:
THE REGION;
MYERSON REPORTED 'ERRATIC' IN 1980
description: LEAD: With the surfacing last week of a 1980 police report involving Bess Myerson, prepared three years before Mayor Koch named her his Cultural Affairs Commissioner, it appeared that the Mayor may have ignored early warning signals about his old friend.

title: AFFORDABLE HOUSING: ALL NEEDS MUST BE MET
description: Harry Katz and I agree [ Letters to the Long Island Editor, May 17 ] on the fact of the area's lack of affordable housing. What caused the problem is history and should not be so much the concern as remedying it.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Portsmouth, N.H.;
A Key Addition To a Cityscape
description: LEAD: AKEY component of the Portsmouth cityscape is falling into place as a $22 million mixed-use hotel, conference center and condominium complex nears completion on the Piscataqua River.

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''Sometimes people get bored in a stable market, and that's when you have problems. It's hard to outsmart the market all the time.''

title: Photo of Margaret Hofer (Burian-Moss); MISS KUGELMAN BECOMES BRIDE
description: Margaret Ann Kugelman, a summa cum laude graduate of Yale College, class of '87, and Andrew Paul Hofer, a cum laude graduate of Yale, class of '86, were married yesterday at the Asylum Hill Congregational Church in Hartford. The Rev. James L. Kidd, assisted by the Rev. David B. McIlhiney, performed the ceremony.

title: MISS WHIFFEN IS WED TO GORDON ERIK DYAL
description: Candace Ellen Whiffen, a vice president of Oppenheimer & Company in New York, was married yesterday to Gordon Erik Dyal, who received an M.B.A. degree this month from the Amos Tuck School of Business Administration at Dartmouth College. The Rev. Susan Alexander performed the Presbyterian ceremony at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Richard E. Whiffen, parents of the bride, in Doylestown, Pa.

title: FATHERS AND DAUGHTERS AT WORK
description: WHEN Cheryl Chase Freedman was growing up, she assumed her family thought she would not have a career, but would marry and raise a family. Her father, David T. Chase, vehemently denies that they did.

title: A Plea For the Chimps
description: I had the distressing opportunity late last year to view the same videotape as did Jane Goodall of chimpanzees in a biomedical laboratory (''A Plea for the Chimps,'' May 17). As a psychiatrist, I can attest to the bizarre and stereotypic behavior of the animals.

title: ELIZABETH A. PECK, A TEACHER, IS WED TO MARK P. SPERRY
description: The marriage of Elizabeth Alden Peck to Mark Porter Sperry took place yesterday at St. John's Episcopal Church on Fishers Island, N.Y. The Rev. Jack Silvey Miller performed the ceremony.

title:
HOME VIDEO;
HOW TO
description: LEAD: How to Have a Moneymaking Garage Sale With Phyllis Diller. J2 Communications. 24 minutes. $19.95.

title: MINIMAL MUSIC BRIDGES A CULTURAL DIVIDE
description: TO MANY ROCK MUSICIANS, classical music is stuffy and antiquated; to some classical types, rock is the sound of barbarians slavering at the gates of culture. But there's one area where cordial relations have prevailed, at least since the end of the 1960's: minimalism, a style both sides can understand.

title: Crum Gets Chance
description: WHEN the selection committee passed over Louisville for the 1987 National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball tournament, the Cardinals' coach, Denny Crum, was more than a little miffed. Louisville's 18-14 record may not have been among the best in college basketball, but the way Crum figured it, the Cardinals were the reigning champions and deserved a chance to defend their 1986 title.

title: Cashing In on the CD Rate War
description: FOR the first time in several years, banks are offering eye-catching interest rates on certificates of deposit. In New York, special promotional offers on short-term C.D.'s by some commercial banks and thrift institutions have increased rates by two percentage points or more since late April, to the 7 to 7.75 percent range.

title: MOVIES
description: Mayerling Starring Charles Boyer, Danielle Darrieux, Jean Dax, Suzy Prim. Directed by Anatole Litvak. 1936. Embassy Home Entertainment. 91 minutes. $29.95.

title: COLLARS FOR CABBIES
description: The same city administration that has been scrubbing the graffiti off its subway cars is now tackling the T-shirts and tank tops of its cab drivers. The New York City Taxi and Limousine Commission last week tentatively approved a dress code for the drivers of its 11,787 medallion cabs that would require shirts to have collars and sleeves, and trousers and skirts to reach at least midthigh. Holes, said the commission, would be out.

title: HARD CHOICES OUTLINED ON THE SOUND
description: SCIENTISTS say early indications of a study of pollution in Long Island Sound suggest that New York and Connecticutare likely to face difficult economic and environmental choices in the coming decade.

title: VOTE-GETTERS SNUB NAASSAU DEMOCRATS
description: ATTEMPTING to end 17 years of Republican domination of Nassau County, Democrats had such difficulty finding candidates that they were forced to select second choices for at least three of the five top election contests this November.

title: ARTS ANNUAL PHOTOGRAPHS AND PRINTS AT THE JERSEY CITY MUSEUM
description: THE joint brainchild of the State Council on the Arts and six museums, the New Jersey Arts Annual is a juried show that arrives twice a year.

title: THE THREE FCES OF CAMCORDERS
description: THE BEGINNING OF THE vacation season has sent sales of camcorders soaring. These handy camera/ recorder combinations have captured the imagination of Americans much as home movies did a few decades ago. Or, to draw earlier parallels, you might say that the camcorder is today what diary and sketchpad were to Victorian travelers.

title:
LONG ISLAND SOUND;
FATHER'S DAY, MOTHER'S LOT
description: LEAD: GOD couldn't be everywhere, the saying goes, so He created mothers. And He probably created fathers as the antidote to mothers.

title: NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: West Palm Beach, Fla.; A Town House Bubble Bursts
description: WHEN Marianne Rusche and Jane Reynolds, who work at the Quail Ridge Country Club in Boynton Beach, decided early last year to invest in a home together, they went to an agent for the Westbury Homes Corporation, one of the largest home builders in thriving Palm Beach County.

title: GLOBAL VIEW AT SETON HALL
description: THE political science department at Seton Hall University will be the host, beginning this week, of a conference on ''Global Level Political Thought.''

title: Prokofiev's Russia
description: To the Editor:

title: PITCHING TOO THIN TO STOCK EXPANSION
description: DURING a discussion about expansion following the recent owners' meeting, Commissioner Peter Ueberroth was asked if the owners have considered the question of available talent when pondering whether to add teams to the major leagues.

title: DIRECTING SITCOMS IS NO JOKE TO DAVID STEINBERG
description: IT IS WEDNESDAY AFTERNOON, first rehearsal, for the pilot episode of a new sitcom called ''Family Man.'' The show has been cast, the sets have been built, the jokes - more or less - have been written. As the actors, glancing furtively at their scripts, begin the run-through, one fact becomes startlingly apparent: Something funny has happened to David Steinberg's career.

title: MISS ROONEY HAS WEDDING
description: Frances Elizabeth Rooney, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Francis Charles Rooney Jr. of Greenwich, Conn., was married there yesterday to Michael Stephen Cifrino, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James P. Cifrino of Cohasset, Mass. The Rev. Robert Farrell, assisted by Msgr. Thomas P. Guinan and the Rev. Mark Connolly, performed the ceremony at St. Michael's the Archangel Roman Catholic Church.

title: THE GUIDE
description: SUPER GARAGE SALE For a third consecutive year, a group of Mamaroneck residents will hold a mammoth garage sale from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. Saturday and next Sunday at Mamaroneck High School. Proceeds, which amount to about $20,000 a year, benefit the Mamaroneck Free Library-Emelin Theater Center complex.

title: FALLING LOW
description: Robert B. Anderson used to run the United States Treasury; this week he is scheduled to be sentenced for cheating it. Mr. Anderson, who served as Secretary of the Treasury in the second Eisenhower Administration, pleaded guilty three months ago to charges that he failed to report $127,000 in income in 1984 and illegally operated an offshore bank in the British West Indies. Prosecutors said the bank's depositors lost a total of at least $4.4 million. Commenting on the case last week, Mr. Anderson said he went astray as a result of factors including his wife's 10-year battle with Alzheimer's disease - she died earlier this month - and his own struggle with alcoholism. Federal investigators saw things differently, painting the 77-year-old Texan as a sophisticated businessman who used his public reputation for personal gain.

title: PLAYER RAISES LEAD TO 3 SHOTS
description: The usual suspects on the Senior PGA Tour were rounded up again today after 54 holes of the $300,000 Northville Invitational.

title: Shultz Responds Tartly to NATO Chief's Criticism
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz delivered an unusually harsh rebuke today to the commander of NATO for having said that the Reagan Administration was pressing Europe to accept what he called a dangerous arms agreement with the Russians.

title: WOULD-BE KINGS AND RUNAWAY PODIATRISTS
description: LEAD: OUR WAR And How We Won It. By E. J. Cullen. 238 pp. New York: Elisabeth Sifton Books/ Viking. $17.95.

title: FAMILY FORTUNE: TANGLED TALE
description: WHEN Barbara Goldsmith, a writer with a keen interest in social issues, published ''Johnson v. Johnson'' last February, she brought out into the open the tangled family contretemps and high-stakes trial over the will of J. Seward Johnson, heir to the Johnson & Johnson pharmaceutical fortune.

title: Cable TV Executive Testifies On Seeking Manes's Support
description: A cable television executive told a court in Queens last week that his company, seeking a franchise in the borough, sought out politically influential people to ''get our story across'' to the decisive figure in the franchising process - Borough President Donald R. Manes.

title: SIXTH LOSS TESTS NAVRATILOVA'S CONFIDENCE
description: This is not the kind of streak that Martina Navratilova is accustomed to. For the last five years she has been the No. 1 player among the women, more often than not, winning as she pleased, building a record that will stand the test of any era.

title: Sound and Fury, and Now the First Death
description: On Friday in Taejon, southeast of the capital, anti-Government protesters commandeered a bus and drove it into a group of policemen, killing one of them.

title: Reflections on Reflagging
description: What should the United States do next in the Persian Gulf? American warships have been there for 40 years to protect American shipping and to give visible expression to extensive American interests. None of that is at issue.

title: New York Officials Cite 30 Food Outlets For Code Violations
description: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 30 food establishments cited for violating the health code.

title: JAZZ, OPERA ON AGENDA
description: LEAD: THE musical component of The Artist/Teacher Institute this summer comprises two elements: A jazz program and a ''Metropolitan Opera-in-the-Schools'' program.

title: Albert Collins on Board
description: BATHED in the flickering of photographers' flashbulbs, his fingers scrambling over the neck of his guitar and wrenching out quivering tremolos, Albert Collins seemed galvanized by more than mere electricity on Friday. He was performing on a Musicruise Dayliner, sailing around Manhattan on the opening night of the JVC Jazz Festival, with the saxophonist David (Fathead) Newman and the Uptown Horns as guests. The evening was hardly your typical jazz festival concert. It was more like a blues bacchanalia, with a boisterous crowd that seemed to have left its inhibitions, if not its sanity, behind at Pier 81.

title: ON THE ROAD IN A $350,000 HOME
description: THIS dusty speck of a town, 25 miles south of Macon, is a good place to find serenity. Only 9,000 people live here. It's a good place to buy pecans, being that it nestles in the heart of pecan country. And it's a good place to get your tires rotated free over at Peach Maximum Auto Care.

title: On Color
description: To the Editor: In ''Encounters of Another Color'' (Travel, April 12), Stephanie Griffith describes her experiences as a black American in Spain and other countries.

title: WARNINGS ARE ISSUED ON TICK BITES
description: LEAD: BECAUSE July is when most tick bites occur, Dr. Terry Schulze of the state Department of Health's Disease Control Center urges vacationers to be especially cautious in areas known to harbor Iodes dammini, the tick that transmits Lyme disease, and to recognize early signs of the disease.

title: Marshall Plan
description: To the Editor:

title: Roger II of Sicily
description: To the Editor: In his interesting and informative article ''Tracing the Norman Rulers of Sicily'' (Travel, April 26), Louis Inturrisi translates the inscription on the tomb of Roger II (1093-1154) as ''Leader and First King of Sicily.''

title: Clinton
description: THE Film Center Cafe on Ninth Avenue near 45th Street was for years a down-to-earth bar without a menu. But today, although it still uses its old handle, it serves soft-shelled crabs and steak tartare and the stereo plays Vivaldi and Billie Holiday.

title: Failure of General Dynamics Case Called Damaging to U.S. Efforts on Fraud
description: The Government's decision to abandon a criminal case against the General Dynamics Corporation could damage efforts to prosecute cases of fraud in military contracting, Federal law-enforcement officials said today.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
STEEL BAND
description: LEAD: At many schools the ''in'' thing to join is the football team, the basketball team or the cheerleading squad. At the Graham School in Hastings-on-Hudson, one of the sought-after memberships is in the Graham School All-Star Steel Band.

title: Shifting Out of Steel, Into Carbon Fiber
description: THE best bicycles have long been made of tubing carrying such proprietary labels as Reynolds 531 or Columbus SL, or generic names like chrome molybdenum - but these terms were all fancy names for alloys of steel. Most of the best bikes are still made of these alloys, but they have been joined by frames of aluminum and composite materials.

title: SUMMER THEATER AND SOME OF IT FREE
description: WHAT'S new and novel about the state's summer theater season? A so-called New Jersey Theater Jubilee, and the tickets are free!

title: ANOTHER DEFEAT FOR RAJIV GANDHI
description: Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi's Congress Party suffered an overwhelming local defeat last week, winning only four out of 87 seats in state legislative elections in Haryana, a small, prosperous state in northern India. Many of the issues were local - demands for more irrigation water, territory and other largesse. But Devi Lal, the veteran politician and onetime Congress stalwart who led the opposition coalition, said the voting was ''a referendum on Rajiv Gandhi.''

title: Doctor's Panel Recommends Limited AIDS Testing
description: Mandatory testing for infection with the AIDS virus should be extended to prison inmates and immigrants but not to everyone getting a marriage license or entering a hospital, trustees of the American Medical Association said today.

title: GOLF COURSES AND LAND USE
description: The article ''More Golfers Tee Off on Less Land'' [ May 24 ] was only partially accurate with regard to the ownership of the Commack Hills Country Club, and very inaccurate in describing our plans for the property. The Holiday Organization is Long Island's largest residential building firm and it does own the Commack Hills Country Club.

title: A Plea For the Chimps
description: Thank you for printing Jane Goodall's moving article on the treatment of chimpanzees used for research. I, for one, would not begrudge one cent of tax money or medical charges used to provide a humane environment for these animals. MEREDITH TROMBLE San Francisco

title:
INVESTING;
Manville: No Place but Down?
description: LEAD: Shares of the Manville Corporation, the asbestos-plagued building products manufacturer that is exected to emerge from bankruptcy early next year, shot above $5 last week. The stock sold at $3 in late May and less than $2 in February. Caught in the surge - and involuntarily helping it along - were bearish traders who had sold short Manville shares in recent months, expecting a decline.

title: LOGIC AND OTHER IMPERFECT THINGS
description: FOREVER UNDECIDED A Puzzle Guide to Godel. By Raymond Smullyan. 257 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $17.95.

title: MOVIES
description: The Lost Honor of Katharina Blum Embassy Home Entertainment. 1975. 97 minutes. $29.95.

title: THE PERFECT HAMBURGER
description: THEY ARE RELATIVELY HUMBLE, to be sure, and there are those haute cuisine purists who malign them. But in the real world, the people who are passionate about hamburgers far outnumber those who scorn them.

title: THE KING LIVES, BUT THE QUEEN'S CROWN TOTTERS
description: She emerged from her London hideaway for a photo opportunity, posing on Centre Court at Wimbledon, holding a bouquet of roses. Consider it a practice session for the day when Steffi Graf wins her first Wimbledon singles championship and establishes herself as the new queen of women's tennis. The only question appears to be whether that will occur in two weeks or will be delayed for another year or more.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LEAD: RENIFLEUR'S DAUGHTER. By Candida Fraze. (Holt, $16.95.) In modern psychiatry ''renifleur'' means a person erotically stirred or gratified by smells. Freud used the word, however, to indicate someone obsessed to the point of neurosis. Candida Fraze draws both definitions into her captivating first novel.

title: SWEET ARE THE USES OF BUREAUCRACY
description: THE COMPLETE YES MINISTER The Diaries of a Cabinet Minister. By the Right Hon. James Hacker MP. Edited by Jonathan Lynn and Antony Jay. Illustrated. 514 pp. Topsfield, Mass.: Salem House Publishers. $19.95.

title: SOMETHING ROTTEN IN NORWAY
description: THE HONEYMOON By Knut Faldbakken. Translated by Liv Myhre. 233 pp. New York: St. Martin's Press. $15.95.

title: Toshiba Affair: Deals That Run Silent And Deep
description: TECHNOLOGY-STARVED Soviet engineers have long looked to the West to help solve their most pressing military problems, and with the help of the K.G.B. they have grown increasingly adept at bypassing even the strictest export controls.

title: A Plea For the Chimps
description: Jane Goodall wants the public to believe that all scientific institutions house primates in small, cramped cages. This isn't so. For example, most of the chimpanzees at the Yerkes Regional Primate Research Center live in social groups. Play equipment, large indoor rooms, outdoor play yards and social companionship with peers are provided for the young animals. Even many of the chimpanzees involved in studies of AIDS live in pairs, in cage units much larger than the sizes quoted by Dr. Goodall.

title: FESTIVITIES INDOORS AND OUT
description: Dancing in the Country June 21 - The Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival will open its season in Becket, Mass., with an afternoon benefit indoors and out. The festivities will start at noon with a picnic on the Pillow Green, where Ann Reinking, the dancer, and Christopher Reeve, the actor, will be the hosts. Circus Oz, an Australian company, and the Les Miserables Brass Band will perform before a 3 P.M. show by Miss Reinking and members of the Boston Ballet. Tickets, $100 or $250, which includes a second picnic and performance on July 9; call 413-243-0745. Garden Party June 22 - The four-year old Lesbian and Gay Community Services Center, housed in the former high school building at 208 West 13th Street, serves the social, cultural, religious and health needs of 3,500 New Yorkers each week. To raise money for its operation, the center is holding its fourth annual garden party, which Martin Sheen and Anne Meara, the performers, and William Hoffman, the playwright, are expected to attend. The evening will start with cocktails at 6:30 P.M., followed by a buffet, entertainment and dancing until 11 P.M. Tickets, $35 at the door or by calling 212-620-7310. French Double Feature June 22 - Two recent French films, ''Jean de Florette'' and ''Manon of the Spring,'' both starring Yves Montand and Gerard Depardieu, depict French peasant life in the 1920's. At a benefit for the American Foundation for AIDS Research, the movies will have their American premieres at Alice Tully Hall at Lincoln Center, starting at 6:15 P.M. Mr. Montand and Claude Berri, the director of both productions, are expected to greet guests at a buffet during the intermission. Tickets, $50 and $100; call 212-874-4098. Honoring a Legend June 22 - The 100th birthday of the Broadway director George Abbott will be celebrated at 8 P.M. at a black-tie benefit for the Actors' Fund at the Palace Theater, on Broadway near 47th Street. A supper dance at Roseland will follow the performance by scores of Broadway figures, past and present. Tickets, $750 and $1,000 or $50, $100 and $250 for performance alone; call 212-977-4180. On the Waterfront June 22 - One of the city's newest and most striking parks, the Socrates Sculpture Park in Long Island City, Queens, will be the site for a party from 7 to 10 P.M., a benefit for the Municipal Art Society. The evening includes dinner, dancing and a tour of an adjacent pier, where Mark di Suvero works and also stores his cast-iron sculptures. Round-trip transportation will be provided; buses will leave the society's headquarters at 457 Madison Avenue (50th Street) at 6:30 P.M. Tickets, $125; call 212-935-3960. Party in Central Park June 23 - The Friends of the American Cancer Society will hold a Summer Solstice Celebration from 6 to 10 P.M. at the Loeb Boathouse in Central Park. There will be a picnic supper, dancing and boating, all a benefit for the society's research, education and patient-services programs. Requested dress: summer whites. Tickets, $50; call 212-586-8700, extension 390. Briefly Noted: June 22 - Lawyers for the Legal Aid Society will hold a 9 P.M. party at the Palladium to benefit the society's civil and volunteer divisions. Tickets, $50; call 212-577-3346. June 23 - A black-tie dinner dance at the Waldorf-Astoria, starting with cocktails at 7 P.M., will benefit the Mental Illness Foundation. Le Masquerade will entertain. Tickets, $200; call 212-629-0755. June 23 - The Roundabout Theater Company will hold a benefit at a performance of Tom Stoppard's ''Rosencrantz and Guildenstern Are Dead.'' Wine and hors d'oeuvres will be served at 7 P.M. before the play at 100 East 17th Street. Champagne and dancing at Stringfellow's will follow the show. Tickets, $45, from 212-420-1360, or $50 at the door. June 25 - The 15th annual Superstar Dinner to benefit the Police Athletic League will start with cocktails at 6 P.M. at the Pierre. Dinner, dancing and entertainment will follow the black-tie event, a fund-raiser for programs serving 50,000 boys and girls a year. Tickets, $1,000; call 212-477-9450, extension 16. June 25 - Representative Bill Green, Republican of New York, will be the guest of honor at a reception and dance from 6 to 9 P.M. aboard the Wavertree at the South Street Seaport. The evening will benefit Community Access, which is breaking ground for three apartment houses on the Lower East Side for the homeless and mentally ill. Tickets, $20, from 212-420-1700 or at the ship. June 25 - Hank Aaron and A. Bartlett Giamatti, president of the National League, will be honored by the American Friends of the Hebrew University at the annual Sports Torch of Learning Award Dinner at the Marriott Marquis, starting with cocktails at 6 P.M. Tickets, $350 or $175 for those under 16 years old; call 212-472-0040. June 26 - A Federalist Ball to celebrate the bicentennial of the Constitution and to raise money for the restoration of the family home in Rye, N.Y, of John Jay, the first Chief Justice of the United States, will be held at the Shenorock Shore Club in Rye. Cocktails at 8 P.M. will be followed by a dinner dance. Tickets, $150; call 914-424-3484. June 27 - Fountain House on West 47th Street, which serves the chronically mentally ill after they have been released from a hospital, will be the beneficiary of a black-tie dinner dance and auction at the Indian Harbor Yacht Club in Greenwich, Conn. Tickets, $85; call 212-582-0340.

title: AMERICA'S NEWEST NATIONAL PARK
description: Driving west from Delta, Utah, on U.S. Highway 50, one is almost lulled to sleep by the desert landscape and its infinity of sand, sun and sagebrush.

title: The Message of 'Best Intentions'
description: To the Editor:

title:
GARDENING;
WAYS TO BRING FLOWERING AND FRUITING
description: LEAD: AT one time or another, many gardeners have been disappointed when a recently planted tree or shrub fails to bloom the year after it was planted. Often, several years may go by without a floral display. This can be especially perplexing when the plant had flowers on it when it was purchased.

title: Confessions of Koch: Ice Cream and Curses
description: For Mayor Koch, the last two weeks surely was one of the most grueling periods this year. As negotiations over the city budget dragged on, eventually missing the legal deadline, a report was made public that accused Bess Myerson, the former Cultural Affairs Commissioner and a longtime friend of the Mayor, of improperly influencing a judge.

title: Sarah Vaughan At Carnegie
description: AN unofficial summit meeting of vocal pyrotechnicians was held on Friday evening, when Sarah Vaughan, whose burnished contralto remains lustrous after all these years, and Bobby McFerrin, who can simulate the sound of practically any instrument in a jazz band, shared the bill at Carnegie Hall. Both singers command a proficiency that can be daunting. Their timbral range and rhythmic inventiveness are so vast that the act of singing can sometimes become a demonstration of prowess rather than artistic expression. On Friday, however, both singers displayed ample heart and humor.

title: SUMMERFARE OFFERS A HOME FOR THE LEADING EDGE
description: AMERICANS, AND NEW YORK-ers in particular, like to imagine being at the center of the cultural world; yet for all the comings and goings across local stages, a great deal of the most important and influential work done abroad has little chance of being seen here. The predilection in this country for traditional grand opera has meant that few opportunities exist to view the experimental opera productions that have dominated European stages lately. Language barriers pose problems for the importation of foreign plays. There are in fact not many venues where major leading-edge peforming arts companies from both this country and abroad can feel at home.

title: Sharjah's Emir Regains Rule After Brief Ouster
description: The ruler of the Gulf emirate of Sharjah, Sheik Sultan bin Mohammed al-Qasimi, has been restored to power four days after his brother ousted him, the Emirates News Agency said today.

title: ANXIETY PERVADES WASHINGTON'S KOREA POLICY
description: IMPOSING American morality on other countries' political systems is a ticklish business, and the United States has rarely done it well, whether the Administration be Republican or Democratic. There is a peculiar interplay between Washington's regard for democracy and its anxiety over Communist expansion. Occasionally the two concerns line up together, as in the Philippines last year. But when one comes into conflict with the other, the anti-Communist reflex prevails, as in South Korea during the last two weeks.

title: REAGAN FINDS FLAW IN PEACE PLAN
description: President Oscar Arias Sanchez of Costa Rica was on a private visit to Indianapolis last week when he was told President Reagan wanted to see him at the White House.

title: Washington Mayor Sues Prosecutor Over Rumors
description: Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. has filed a suit in Federal District Court here accusing United States Attorney Joseph E. diGenova of ''prosecutorial abuse and vindictiveness.''

title:
FOCUS: WILLIAMSBURG;
Retiring Outside the Sun Belt
description: LEAD: HOWARD AND MARION BUTTERS retired to Fort Lauderdale, Fla., from Pittsburgh about 20 years ago. But when they started looking for a community in which to spend their later years - both are in their 80's - they looked north to Williamsburg, Va. ''It just wasn't the same place,'' Mrs. Butters said of

title: THE CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: LEAD: Just About Everything In the Larger Sizes He-Man Shops in Yonkers caters to big (1X to 5X in sport shirts) and tall men (long to XXXT); big jackets from 46 to 66 and in tall sizes 40 to 54 extra long. Ties are six inches longer, belts extend to size 70, all socks are king size (12 to 15) and shoe sizes are 10 1/2 EEE to 15 EEE.

title: U.S. Official Blames Farmers For Worker Shortage in West
description: California farmers must share the blame for a shortage of field workers as the peak harvest season approaches, the Western regional director of the Immigration and Naturalization Service says.

title: Controversy Continues in Arizona Over Honors for Dr. King
description: Gov. Evan Mecham has proposed to recognize the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. with a proclamation instead of a holiday, but his suggestion did not mollify backers of a full-fledged holiday honoring the civil rights leader.

title: Lebanese Judge Quits Assassination Inquiry
description: The judge heading the investigation into the assassination of Prime Minister Rashid Karami resigned today, saying he was doing so because press reports had cast doubts about his integrity.

title: TAKING THE STUGGLE BEYOND THE FIELD
description: IN 1968, Harry Edwards was a young activist who tried to persuade black American athletes to boycott the 1968 Olympics. Though that effort failed, it led to the black-power salute on the victory stand by Tommie Smith and John Carlos and helped dramatize Edwards's message: that black Americans were being denied equal opportunity in the land of opportunity.

title: MISS WARD WEDS TAYLOR BODMAN
description: April Atchison Ward, a daughter of Mrs. Henry F. Field of Chicago and David H. Ward of New York, was married yesterday to Taylor Stockwell Bodman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard S. Bodman of Washington. The Rev. George Hull performed the ceremony at St. Chrysostom's Episcopal Church in Chicago.

title: Jews Are Aghast at the Pope's Invitation to Waldheim
description: LEAD: In September 1971, in a synagogue in Paris, there was a new beginning in the often painful history of the relations between Jews and Roman Catholics. For the first time ever, the Vatican had sent an official delegation to the table to meet with an equally weighty group that spoke for the major Jewish organizations.

title: More Finishers
description: To the Sports Editor: I was disappointed with a part of the coverage of the L'Eggs Mini-Marathon in Central Park on May 30. You provided the name and times of all the first-place finishers in every age division except the Seniors and the Golden Age. Wasn't this a bit unfair? CHONGHYO SHIN Greenfield, Mass. The winner of the Seniors division was Joyce Rhines in 54 minutes 24 seconds; the Golden Age winner was Evelyn Havens in 1 hour 16 minutes 13 seconds.

title: LILCO TO RESUBMIT SHOREHAM REQUEST
description: LEAD: THE Long Island Lighting Company will pursue Federal permission to operate the Shoreham plant year-round at a quarter of its full power as an interim measure to meet electric demand, the company's chairman, William J. Catacosinos, said last week.

title: The Shape Of Ford's Success
description: My experience behind the steeply angled windshield of a modern sports car, in a South Dakota downpour last summer, indicates a problem with the aero design. The nearly horizontal wipers are ineffective and the eye has considerable difficulty focusing past the blade-smear tracks out there in middle distance. On the same trip, a short, near vertical, close-to-the-eye windshield on a companion vehicle modeled after a 1929 touring car afforded excellent visibility, with the eye easily focusing past whatever wiper streaks remained. JAMES P. BOHAN Southport, Conn.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: IRISH FESTIVAL The 1987 New Jersey Irish Festival will begin bright and early next Sunday with the rattle of drums and skirl of bagpipes, as 16 bands from the eastern United States vie for awards at the Garden State Arts Center in Holmdel.

title: IN PURSUIT OF THE LONGEST CAST
description: RON ARRA, the Cape Cod carpenter and cabinetmaker who has had little difficulty dominating the Stren Longcasting Tournaments for the past three years, cannot relax this time around.

title: Edith G. Brand Married to Lyman B. Townsend Jr.
description: Edith Gingrich Brand and Lyman Bass Townsend Jr. were married yesterday at St. Peter's Kierch in Middletown, Pa., by the Rev. Thomas Sanagorski, a United Methodist minister. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Abel Lineberger Brand of Middletown. The bridegroom is a son of Mrs. Louis Busch Hager of New York and Cooperstown, N.Y., and Mr. Townsend of Pittsford, N.Y.

title: Iraq Hits a Tanker in Gulf, First Since Attack on Stark
description: Iraq broke a monthlong lull in the Persian Gulf shipping war today, announcing that its jets had raided a ''large naval target,'' its usual reference for an oil tanker.

title: The Designers Who Lead
description: THERE ARE DESIGNERS, and then there are designers. Most consistently churn out collections of attractive, often beautiful clothes. But there are also the few whose output is so dramatic - or sensible - that it shifts fashion everywhere. On these pages are observations on some of the latter, based in Paris, Milan and Tokyo. (Next week, a look at the Americans.) CHRISTIAN LACROIX

title: Punishment for Crime, not Grief
description: Whether a convicted murderer lives or dies should not depend on the grief or eloquence of the victim's family. So ruling in a Maryland murder case, the Supreme Court strikes down the use of victim impact statements in the death sentencing process. The decision, by a bare 5-to-4 majority, honors important principles.

title: Booking Trips By Computer
description: The promise of computerized travel services may finally be catching up with the technology of home computers.

title: Ex-Police Chief Sought In 3 Murders in South
description: A nationwide search is under way for a former police chief who is suspected of attacks on motel guests in three states in which three people were killed.

title: JOHN LETS LEAD SLIP AWAY
description: The first player out of the clubhouse was Tommy John, who stalked past a cluster of reporters and artfully weaved his way through the hordes of spectators leaving Fenway Park.

title: WASTE FEES TRIPLE IN LANDFILL 'LOCKOUT'
description: LEAD: SINCE June 1, the 70 tons of garbage collected each day in the City of Long Beach have been hauled off the barrier island to Glen Cove, Hauppauge and even Pennsylvania because the city's contract with the Town of Hempstead to use the Oceanside landfill less than two miles away expired and the town has refused to renew the agreement.

title: Housing Funds Bolster Effort At Lower East Side Renewal
description: As residents of the Lower East Side celebrated the completion of two rehabilitated apartment buildings yesterday, they learned that $1.5 million more in Federal funds had been allocated to upgrade four more buildings in their neighborhood - one ravaged by drug dealers and abandonment.

title: CARAMOOR FESTIVAL BEGINS ITS SEASON
description: WHAT has been called ''the most stylish and civilized music festival in the nation'' is about to open to the public for the 42d summer. The Caramoor Music Festival in Katonah has an extraordinarily bountiful schedule of more than 30 concerts this year, ranging from Elizabethan madrigals to two world premieres and including a first for the festival: a jazz program by the Wynton Marsalis Quintet.

title: WHAT COMFORTS AIDS FAMILIES
description: ON THE OTHER side of the one-way mirror, Marie Cannell sits talking to a therapist. She's twisting a Kleenex, carrying on a normal conversation one minute, breaking into tears the next. Mrs. Cannell is trying to shed the paralyzing grief she feels for her daughter and 2-year-old grandson. Both have died in the last few months of AIDS.

title: Reagan Vetoes Measure to Affirm Fairness Policy for Broadcasters
description: President Reagan today vetoed a bill that would write into law the fairness doctrine requiring broadcasters to present divergent views on controversial topics.

title: Knife-Wielding Man Is Shot And Killed by Police Officer
description: A police officer shot and killed a knife-wielding man early today after the man assaulted his wife, attacked an officer with a kitchen knife and refused to drop the weapon, officials said.

title: JIRI KYLIAN'S SOURCES OF CHOREOGRAPHIC INSPIRATION
description: BALLETS CHOREOGRAPHED BY Jiri Kylian are passionate, rhapsodic, even tempestuous. The Czech-born artistic director of Netherlands Dance Theater likes to send dancers surging in great waves across the stage, and he is not afraid to make strong choreographic statements in the theater. He is also willing to talk about the unusual sources of inspiration for his works.

title: All Eyes On Her
description: Surely, there must be some man out there somewhere who has experienced love and, yes, excitement in a relationship with an older woman . . . and who is willing to write about it with as much pride and unabashed delight as Edward Harper does. VIVIAN GREENBERG Lawrenceville, N.J.

title: CHANGING THE RULES OF PUBLIC DISCUSSION
description: The British are complaining about the ''Americanization'' and ''televisionization'' of their elections. Margaret Thatcher hit Neil Kinnock with celebrity endorsements; Mr. Kinnock struck back with a film by the man who had directed the film ''Chariots of Fire.'' The British may be right to complain. Americans, after all, have been complaining for years, although nothing happens, except that we keep getting more of the same. It is the entertainment factor. Politics, journalism and public affairs have always had an entertainment factor, but in recent years it has grown more pronounced. We are witnessing the ascension of media. This is journalism with a tickle and a giggle.

title: BROKER, 17, DEALS BETWEEN CLASSES
description: FOR the last few weeks, seniors at Greenwich High School have spent much of their free periods and time between classes discussing final exams, the senior prom, tomorrow's graduation ceremonies and plans for the summer.

title: Cheap Shot?
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Seeks Long Terms This Week For 16 in 'Pizza Connection' Case
description: Sixteen defendants convicted last March in the ''pizza connection'' narcotics trial are to be sentenced beginning tomorrow morning in Federal District Court in Manhattan.

title: Easy-Riding Mountain Bikes Take Off
description: WHEN a self-described group of ''Marin County maniacs and lazy backpackers'' modified some old balloon-tired bikes and began attacking the trails north of San Francisco, no one knew they were starting the hottest two-wheeled trend since the 10-speed. Mountain bikes account for 21 percent of bicycle sales, and are expected to account for up to 40 percent by the early 1990's, according to Bicycle Dealer Showcase, a trade publication.

title: COLLEGE TUITION PLEDGED FOR A CLASS OF 6th GRADERS
description: LEAD: FOR the sixth graders at the Cecil H. Parker Elementary School in Mount Vernon, the graduation ceremony last week had all the usual ingredients. There were awards and speeches by city and school officials. Camera lights flashed and toddlers in the audience grew restless.

title: DESPITE LOSSES, NEWARK STILL ENJOYS AIR BOOM
description: LEAD: ALTHOUGH some of its tenants have been knocked down - and its biggest one knocked out - by fierce competition spawned by Federal deregulation of the airline industry, Newark International Airport continues to enjoy the air-traffic boom.

title: Refugee Gains Weight to Get Flier's Wings
description: A Vietnamese refugee who was originally rejected by the Navy as a security risk and who later began a pasta-rich diet to measure up to the size requirements earned his wings Friday as a naval aviator.

title: ACTOR REFLECTS ON FATHERHOOD
description: OSSIE DAVIS says he feels ''flattered'' by having been named a 1987 ''Father of the Year.'' And he didn't say no when the National Father's Day Committee selected him as one of eight prominent men who symbolize ''moral and ethical family leadership.''

title: Do We Want Big Business to Be Our Bankers?
description: To the Editor:

title: Abroad
description: To the Editor: Simon Winchester in ''Inside Every Tourist, a Traveler'' (Travel, May 10) credits Edward VII wtih the remark that ''abroad's bloody.''

title: New S.M.U. Charge
description: THE improper payments scandal at Southern Methodist may reach beyond the football program, The Dallas Times Herald reported yesterday. Sources who appeared before the Bishops' Committee investigating improper payments to football players told the newspaper that Henry Andrade, a two-time N.C.A.A. hurdles champion, had received monthly cash payments in violation of N.C.A.A. rules from the same slush fund that paid football players.

title: RUBEN BLADES: UP FROM SALSA
description: CROSSING THE STAGE OF WASHINGTON'S Kennedy Center dressed in a loose gray suit and dark tie, Ruben Blades looks more like a lawyer (which he is) than one of today's most popular Latin American singers (which he also is). Squinting into the spotlight, he looks out at the 2,000 people filling the elegant concert hall and asks to hear from those who do not speak Spanish. The clapping is measured, but substantial. Then he says: ''Y aquellos que hablan espanol, aplauden'' - ''And those who do speak Spanish, applaud.'' This time, the roar is thunderous.

title: Artist Found Shot to Death In Apartment in East Village
description: An artist was found shot to death in his East Village apartment Friday evening, the police said.

title: Law Professor Chosen To Be S.E.C.'s Chief
description: A former law school dean is the White House choice to head the S.E.C. David S. Ruder has spent the last 10 years at Northwestern University. His distance from Wall Street and its current scandals was said to be one reason he was picked to head the agency that is leading a crackdown on insider trading. A key question is whether his prosecutorial zeal will match that of John S. R. Shad, under whose stewardship the S.E.C. brought down Ivan F. Boesky with a $100 million fine. Mr. Ruder will be nominated for a four-year term but it is expected that whoever succeeds President Reagan in 1989 would probably name a new S.E.C. chief. * * *

title: KEEP YOUR COMPASSION, GIVE ME YOUR MADNESS
description: I'M always puzzled when I see an advertisement for a novel in which a reviewer, or several reviewers, are quoted as praising the novel's ''compassion'' and its ''integrity.'' What compassion? is my first reaction. Never in the history of the novel have authors given their characters such a hard time. Why, novelists seem positively gleeful in exposing their people's pettiness, their dishonesties, secret humiliations and ugly yearnings. And more often than not, at the end of the book the author just leaves his subjects mired in their imperfections, like somebody buried in sand.

title: U.S. to Let Poles Stay Longer
description: The United States has decided that 7,000 to 10,000 Polish citizens who fled martial law will be allowed to remain in the United States at least through the end of this year.

title: CLIPPERS HOLD THREE KEY CHOICES AND A $13,000 PRIZE
description: THE Los Angeles Clippers, the National Basketball Association's most troubled franchise, one that has missed the last 11 playoffs, are sponsoring a ''Read Elgin's Mind'' contest. The challenge is to name, in correct order, the three players General Manager Elgin Baylor will select when he exercises the Clippers' three first-round choices - Nos. 4 13 and 19 - in tomorrow's draft. The top prize is a $13,000 automobile and a pair of season tickets to Clipper home games.

title: PATRICIA A. LEAHY BECOMES A BRIDE
description: Patricia Ann Leahy, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas F. Leahy of Bronxville, N.Y., was married at St. Ignatius Loyola Roman Catholic Church in New York yesterday to George Jonathan Renner 3d, a son of Mr. Renner Jr. of Greenwich, Conn., and Stratton, Vt., and Cynthia Bjork of Greenwich.

title: Leslie Vosshall Is Wed to David Sulzer
description: At the Middle Collegiate Church in New York yesterday Leslie Birgit Vosshall, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gerhard Vosshall of Smoke Rise, N.J., was married to David Louis Sulzer, a son of Dr. Beth Sulzer-Azaroff of Storrs, Conn., and the late Edward Sulzer. Rabbi Roy Rosenberg performed the ceremony.

title: A FATHER REFLECTS ON THE ROLE OF A SON
description: A SON is many things to a father. A son is, at times, a mirror that reflects the father's strength and his shortcomings. A son is a reminder of a father's waning youth, a reminder that life is not forever. If a father is attentive to his duties, a son, as he matures, is a friend and companion who shares in the dreams and the memories of the father. Most of all, a son aids a father in fulfilling his humanity.

title: GOODEN GOES THE DISTANCE IN METS' VICTORY
description: Dwight Gooden, the missing man for the first two months of the season, showed up in Shea Stadium again last night with the missing ingredient, pitching, and the Mets glowed.

title: Nothing Exotic Is Alien to Them
description: Earth's first experimental space colony, City of the Second Chance, a low-density Babylon - Los Angeles has been called a lot of things, but historical is not often one of them. Sam Hall Kaplan, a transplanted New Yorker writing on design for The Los Angeles Times, wants to correct the pop image of L.A. as ''a city of weirdos on roller-skates in pursuit of deep tans and shallow relationships.'' Beginning with the year 1781, when the Indian village of Yangna was transformed into the Spanish settlement (44 people) of Pueblo de los Angeles, and moving swiftly to the boom times of the late 1950's, when 107 houses sold per hour, L.A. LOST & FOUND: An Architectural History of Los Angeles (Crown, $27.95) provides a lively, streamlined chronology of the events, industries and architects that ''shaped and styled L.A.'' The word ''styled'' sounds perfect in connection with the city's reputation for trying out exotic styles like so many interchangeable wigs, but Mr. Kaplan puts the accent on more-or-less indigenous building types, for example, the bungalow and the ranch house, and on serious architects, such as Richard Neutra, the Greene Brothers and Frank Lloyd Wright, who did some of their best work in Los Angeles. The final chapter offers a series of photographic epitaphs chronicling buildings lost (demolished) and found (restored). It is depressing to discover just how many have been torn down in the landmark-conscious 80's, but Mr. Kaplan, with the help of the volume's principal photographer, Julius Shulman, offers abundant evidence that, whatever happens, L.A.'s time is now, always has been and always will be.

title: CORRECTION
description: An item in the Westchester Guide on June 7 about the Scarsdale Historical Society's current exhibition misspelled the name of the building that is being restored by the society. It is the Cudner-Hyatt House.

title: DIANNE HAMLIN, BANKER, MARRIES
description: At St. Thomas More Roman Catholic Church in Darien, Conn., yesterday Dianne Marie Hamlin, a daughter of Helene Mayer Hamlin of Haddonfield, N.J., and Richard Thomas Hamlin of London, was married to William Kent Haydock Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Haydock of Darien. The Rev. Edward J. Howley, pastor of the church, performed the ceremony. He was assisted by the Rev. Walter Hamilton Taylor, rector of St. Luke's Episcopal Church in Darien.

title: FORSAKING THE ODDBALL LIFE
description: SOMEWHERE OFF THE COAST OF MAINE By Ann Hood. 225 pp. New York: Bantam Books. Paper, $6.95.

description: To the Editor:

title: Anti-U.S. Mood Was a Key Issue in Bahamas
description: In winning a sixth term as Prime Minister of the Bahamas on Friday, Lynden O. Pindling turned aside allegations of corruption and played heavily on nationalism and black pride and the specter of American domination.

title: ISRAEL WAS EVERTHING
description: LEAD: THE LIFE AND TIMES OF MENACHEM BEGIN By Amos Perlmutter. Illustrated. 444 pp. New York: Doubleday & Company. $21.95.

title: CREATING JOBS FOR AID RECIPIENTS
description: Mayor Koch put some muscle into the search for jobs for welfare recipients last week with a proposal to require contractors who do business with the Human Resources Administration to put some of the agency's clients on their payrolls.

title: A LITTLE MATTER OF SENSE
description: FEW things are more characteristic of the modern mind than to take complication for improvement. We have automatic windows on our cars, which is a convenience; but on a hot day, or in an accident, they cannot be opened unless the engine is running. The paradox of inconvenient convenience repeats in all domains. A literary example is the improved criticism of the arts, which has reached the point where it is so expert that it defies common understanding.

title: Cable TV
description: To the Editor:

title: A YOUNG COMPOSER ACHIEVES NOTICE
description: ALTHOUGH a new musical comedy about multiple murders, ''No Way to Treat a Lady,'' marks the official New York theater debut of Douglas J. Cohen - as composer, lyricist and librettist - it was ''Wonder Goose,'' a one-act show he composed while attending Edwin O. Smith High School in Storrs, that was his real initiation into the musical theater - as a composer and co-lyricist.

title:
ART;
FULL-FLEDGED TALENT IN FIVE SOLO FLIGHTS
description: LEAD: AMID a stream of feature articles highlighting young artists who have hit stardom quickly, it is nice to be reminded of those who have been producing serious, thoughtful work for several decades. There are substance and quality, as well as a few surprises, in the cluster of five solo exhibitions currently at the Benton Gallery in

title: Where Greed, Unofficially Blessed by Reagan, Has Led
description: There has been no end of anguish recently about the philosophy of greed that, armed with the unofficial blessing of the Reagan Administration, seems to have invaded a distressingly large number of our institutions, from Wall Street to the electronic ministry.

title: HOWSER REMEMBERED FONDLY: 'GOOD GUYS DO FINISH IN FIRST'
description: Dick Howser was remembered for his personal qualities as much as for his contributions to baseball at a funeral service attended by 400 people today.

title: New York's Inquiry on Bid Rigging In Road Construction Nears End
description: Federal prosecutors are in the final stages of a major investigation into purported bid-rigging and territory allocations by highway construction and supply companies in New York City and in suburbs to the north, law-enforcement officials say.

title: Fresh Air Fund Gives a Girl From Harlem a Maine Home
description: In about a month, Lawanda Duncan, 12 years old, is going to board a bus and leave her family, her friends, her neighborhood, everything she knows. She's already packed.

title: Salim Ali Dies in India; Authority on Wildlife
description: Salim Moizuddin Abdul Ali, India's foremost ornithologist and wildlife conservationist, died of a heart attack in Bombay today. He was 90 years old. Dr. Ali, known as Salim Ali, wrote a 10-volume series with an American, S. Dillon Ripley, on the birds of India and Pakistan.

title: WORK-WELFARE BILL WINDING THROUGH TRENTON
description: GOVERNOR KEAN'S bill to require all able-bodied welfare recipients, including women with children as young as 2 years old, to go to school or work is making its way through the Legislature with some minor changes, but its mandatory feature remains intact.

title: STEPHEN BLABER WEDS MARY ELIZABETH BACON
description: Mary Elizabeth Bacon, director of investor communications in the corporate finance department of Oppenheimer & Company in New York, and Stephen James Blaber, an institutional sales representative in the investment banking sector of Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company in New York, were married yesterday in Greenwich, Conn. Msgr. Thomas Patrick Guinan performed the ceremony at St. Michael the Archangel Roman Catholic Church.

title: Earl Muntz Is Dead; As Radio 'Madman,' He Sold Used Cars
description: Earl Muntz, better known as Madman Muntz, a zany advertiser who sold used cars, low-priced television sets and car stereo systems, died of lung cancer today at Eisenhower Medical Center. He was 73 years old.

title: Samuel Bergman Dies; Engineer and Musician
description: Samuel Bergman, an engineer who made and restored violins and cellos in his later years, died of cancer on June 14 at Calvary Hospital in the Bronx. He was 67 years old and lived in Syosset, L.I.

title: Russian Tells Shadowy Tale Of Spying Inside the Church
description: A former translator for the Russian Orthodox Church, who was long suspected by human rights campaigners of being a K.G.B. informer and provocateur, has acknowledged that he was recruited by the Soviet security police to spy on and entrap religious dissidents from inside the church.

title:
HOME VIDEO;
Sympathetic Portrait
description: LEAD: HOROWITZ, THE LAST ROMANTIC A film by David Maysles, Albert Maysles, Susan Froemke, Deborah Dickson and Patricia Jaffe. MGM/UA Home Video. 89 minutes. $39.95.

title: jANE BRESCHARD IS MARRIED
description: Jane Stapleton Breschard, the New York advertising director for Ms. magazine, was married at the Roman Catholic Church of Our Saviour in Manhattan yesterday to John Murray Wilson, an account executive at Execu-Flow Systems in Cranford, N.J. The Rev. Delos A. Humphrey, an uncle of the bridegroom, performed the ceremony. The parents of the couple are Mr. and Mrs. Elmer M. Breschard Jr. of Hicksville, L.I., and Mr. and Mrs. Murray Crowell Wilson of Rome, N.Y.

title: TRADE LEGISLATION: COUNTING WAYS TO OPEN -- AND TO CLOSE -- MARKETS
description: THE 100th Congress is considering legislation that would deeply affect both the future course of trade policy and two basic economic facts of life - jobs and the cost of living. The Senate is expected to take up a trade bill this week in what many consider the most protectionist climate since the 1930's - though few in Congress breathe the word, preferring to call for ''fair trade.'' Both that bill and the one the House passed in April are aimed at opening foreign markets to more chemicals, food, computers and other goods made in America. But some provisions in both would also close American markets to imports.

title: LOEW'S THEATER APPARENTLY DOOMED
description: MAYOR Anthony J. Cucci of Jersey City and Hartz Mountain Industries, owner of the old Loew's Theater, agreed last week that the city could not afford to save the theater, a Journal Square landmark since 1929.

title: ESCPAING THE CROWDS
description: Beyond the well-known national parks are also less-frequented parks that offer diverse scenery and activities - from canoeing on lakes in Minnesota to exploring pre-Columbian cliff houses in Colorado to snorkeling among coral reefs off Florida. Following is a guide to these parks. The 18 listed here were selected on the basis of three criteria: each park had fewer than 1 million visitors last year; each offers camping and, in some cases, lodging, and all are in the 48 contiguous states. Most of these parks, in fact, had fewer than 500,000 visitors last year; by comparison, Yellowstone National Park had 2.4 million and Great Smoky Mountains National Park had 9.8 million.

title: Seeing the Sky: Not a Limit but Infinity
description: Jack Borden has an idea for motivating inner-city schoolchildren, residents of nursing homes, even prisoners: Look up at the sky.

title: Reagan Assails Budget Proposed in Congress
description: President Reagan today derided a $1 trillion budget expected to be adopted next week by the Democratic-controlled Congress.

title:
FILM VIEW;
WANTED: SINGING, NOT ACTING
description: LEAD: SOMETHING HAS TO BE DONE ABOUT THE ACT-ing in opera. There is altogether too much of it.

title: A Serene Oasis Facing the Demands of the Jet Age
description: IN an age of post-modern architecture the three chapels at Kennedy International Airport are often ridiculed for their aggressively ''contemporary'' design. But take an extra half hour before your next flight, and give them a closer look, because the chapels may not be around much longer.

title: BOARD GAMES ARE SAFER THAN MARRIAGE
description: WITH OR WITHOUT And Other Stories. By Charles Dickinson. 159 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $15.95.

title: Dance: Keiko Fujii In New York Debut
description: EVERY two years or so, a new dance company arrives from Japan to perform at Lincoln Center. That company is usually headed by a woman with strong ideas and strong ambitions - moreover, she has studied dance in the West and her eclectic mix of idioms and styles proves both intriguing and baffling.

title: TIME TO WALK, TO THINK AND DREAM
description: ''Let's spend the last three days in London,'' my husband said, looking up from a table spread with well-worn tourist maps of Devon, Dorset, Somerset and Cornwall. I thought for a moment, images rapidly clicking through my mind. I saw us strolling down Birdcage Walk on a sunny Sunday afternoon, admiring extravagant clumps of searing-blue delphinium; sitting sedately in a black square taxi as it careened around Hyde Park Corner; panting down the escalators to catch the tube for a last-minute matinee at the Barbican. I heard the tapping of umbrellas along Knightsbridge, smelled the fresh sausage rolls in Justin de Blank's, watched the slow brown sweep of the Thames under the Hungerford footbridge. I examined delicate teacups in the Reject China Shop in Beauchamp Place and fingered the impossibly expensive cashmere sweaters in the Burlington Arcade. Then I reluctantly turned off my projector.

title: LISA ANN FIEDLER BECOMES A BRIDE
description: The marriage of Lisa Ann Fiedler, a daughter of Mrs. William Walter Gustafson of Pasadena, Calif., and the late Kern Arthur Fiedler, to Virgil Thomas Fryman Jr. took place yesterday at the Episcopal Church of the Nativity in Maysville, Ky. The Rev. Joseph Hammond performed the ceremony. The bridegroom is the son of Mr. Fryman of Mount Olivet, Ky., and the late Elizabeth Louis Marshall Fryman.

title: DR. MARTHA CORTES WEDS
description: Dr. Martha Cortes, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alejandro Cortes of Rego Park, Queens, was married yesterday to Dr. David Gaudino, a son of Dr. Mario Gaudino of Summit, N.J., and Ann Murray of New York. The Rev. Eugene G. Connolly performed the ceremony at St. Patrick's Cathedral. The bride, who will keep her name, is a dentist in New York and a clinical instructor in dentistry at the Mount Sinai School of Medicine. Dr. Gaudino is a surgical resident at the St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center.

title: CRIME
description: James Lee Burke has been writing procedurals set in New Orleans, and THE NEON RAIN (Holt, $16.95) is one of his best. The central character is Lieut. Dave Robicheaux, a tough, experienced, conscientious police officer. Also a former alcoholic. Also a jazz buff. Also a man you would not want to fool around with, as he demonstrates when his back is against the wall.

title: A WEDDING KEEPSAKE
description: THE latest wedding status symbol may be all-glass invitations, designed by a New York graphic designer, Gene Seidman, of Seidman/Questel Unlimited.

title: SANCTIONS POSSIBLE FOR ADELPHI SPORTS
description: LEAD: AS Adelphi University students sweated through their final exams, their school's basketball program underwent its own examination, which has so far resulted in the resignation of its head coach and may lead to disciplinary action by the National Collegiate Athletic Association.

description: JAZZ FETE IN JERSEY

title: 'You Bright and Risen Angels'
description: In his inventive first novel, William T. Vollmann has given us fiction for the electronic age: a social and political satire that critiques America in technological terms, a computer cartoon that is both a product of technology and a comment on it.

HOME VIDEO;
NATURE
description: LEAD: Return of the Great Whales Produced by Hardy Jones. Written by Julia Whitty. Color. Home Vision. 50 minutes. $39.95.

title: PHILLIPS ON SCHEDULE FOR OLYMPIC GOLD
description: With a perfect score of 10 on the vault and not much worse on her other three routines in the optional round of competition tonight, Kristie Phillips of Houston won the women's title in the McDonald's United States National Gymnastics Championships.

title: Leaving a Legacy Of Destruction
description: ETHEL TURNER'S will stipulated that when she died, her $300,000 house in Cranston, R.I., must perish with her.

title: A Cup Ruling
description: An arbitrator's order to reconsider the membership of the America's Cup site selection committee offers all the ports competing to hold the yacht race an even chance, officials of Sail America Foundation said today in San Diego.

title:
ABOUT WESTCHESTER;
'JUST STRAYS' BOOK OF CATS
description: LEAD: IT was a brilliant spring morning, but Nikki Manookian, president of Just Strays, a nonprofit, all-volunteer, organization dedicated to helping homeless cats, was not relaxing in the sunshine. She was crawling on her hands and knees through a cluttered warehouse, trying to coax four tiny, trembling, kittens into a metal cage.

FIRST FORMAL GRADUATION

Roth of West Haven, Conn. The Rev. Daniel Keefe, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at Grace Memorial Church in East Falmouth, Mass.

title: S.E.C. NOMINATION GOES TO ACADEMIC
description: When Administration officials began looking for someone to replace the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, John S.R. Shad, they wanted what one White House aide called a ''hanging judge'' to vigorously pursue the investigation of Wall Street's year-old insider trading scandal. After Rudolph W. Giuliani, the United States Attorney in Manhattan, declined the job, the White House decided to seek someone with a different kind of expertise, the same source said.

Swan of Rancho Palos Verdes, Calif., were married yesterday at the Loeb Boathouse in Central Park. The Rev. Stoddon G. N. King, a Congregational minister, performed the ceremony.

title: CITIBANK, FORD JOIN THE EXODUS FROM SOUTH AFRICA
description: South Africa has long been a good place to make money, but the pressures of prolonged civil strife and rising international condemnation of apartheid have taken a heavy toll on business. More than 100 American companies have left the country in the last 18 months rather than deal with the consequences of civil unrest, a war of black resistance and white crackdowns in which more than 2,500 people have been killed. Last week, two of the best-known remaining companies, Ford Motor Company and Citibank, prepared to sell out and leave.

title: photo of Mark Wiebe (AP) (page 9); WATSON BIRDIES 18th TO LEAD OPEN BY 1
description: Tom Watson, who won the 1982 Open but has not won any tournament in the last three years, sank a slippery 15-foot downhill putt on the last hole today to take a one-shot lead into Sunday's final round of the 87th United States Open.

title: ITALY'S COMMUNISTS ON SLIPPERY SLOPE
description: THE leaders of Italy's Communist Party spent long hours last week reading bad news. Computer analyses of parliamentary election results showed the party had lost more than a million votes to rivals across the spectrum, from the Christian Democrats on the right to the Proletarian Democrats on the left.

title: JILL STANLEY-BROWN, A NURSE, IS MARRIED
description: At St. Mary Our Lady of the Isle Roman Catholic Church in Nantucket, Mass., yesterday Jeanne Drake Stanley-Brown, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Edward Garfield Stanley-Brown of Ridgewood, N.J., and Nantucket, was married to Paul Robert Driscoll Jr., a son of Mr. Driscoll of Needham, Mass., and the late Genevieve Hatchfield Driscoll. description: ''POP! POP!'' I keep shouting between ringing the bell and knocking. ''Pop, are you in there?''

One of its goals was to support the Christian-dominated Government and to keep Soviet influence in the area in check by keeping Moscow's military client, Syria, removed from power in Beirut.

description: Two Soviet eye specialists have been given permission to examine an American Indian in the Federal prison at Leavenworth, Kan., where he is serving two life sentences for killing two Federal Bureau of Investigation agents in 1975.

The Rev. John T. Morrow performed the ceremony at St. Luke's Episcopal Church in Gladstone, N.J.

title: Question Of the Week; How Will Americans Fare at Wimbledon?
description: I think it's a good thing that John McEnroe has withdrawn from Wimbledon this year - both for his own sake (and sanity) and for the other American players in the draw who are inevitably overshadowed by and underappreciated in his presence. McEnroe would not have been at his best anyhow, and there is nothing sadder than to see this former three-time champion a shadow of his brilliant self, humiliated by an early-round defeat as he was in Paris last month.

title: IN THE NATURAL STATE
description: LEAD: CAPT. JOHN LARSON opened her up, and the twin props dug frothy furrows in an ocean that looked like it had just been paved. The Miss Barnegat Light, pride of the Long Beach Island-based fleet, lifted her nose and sped for home.

description: Dr. Irvin Balensweig, an orthopedic surgeon who practiced in Manhattan for about 50 years until his retirement in 1970, died Thursday at his home in Palm Beach, Fla. He was 92 years old.

description: ''Half a World Away,'' a musical comedy based on stories by Sholem Aleichem, has postponed its opening to July 2. The play, announced as opening Thursday, will continue in previews at the Jewish Repertory Theater, 344 East 14th Street.

description: Defying a Government warning to stop their protests or face extraordinary measures, thousands of students took to the streets today, skirmishing with riot policemen in the capital and other major cities.

description: St. Albans Episcopal Church is the latest to be struck by a gang that has stolen ceremonial silver from scores of churches since 1983, the authorities said.

title: SCHOOL'S CLOSING ANGERS PARENTS
description: A PRIVATE school in the county known for its foreign-language study, small classes and use of Montessori materials and methods has closed, leaving many of its 325 students wondering where they will attend school in the fall.

title: TUNING OUT THE INNER CRITIC
description: PEOPLE frequently express to me curiosity about the relation between criticism and creativity, and the apparent paradox of practicing both. Of course, it is not much of a paradox - a visitor from Mars would be hard pressed to distinguish between a person writing a book review and one writing a short story; the same fidgets and sighing, the same avoidance maneuvers in the direction of the bathroom and the kitchen, the same sudden swoops of fruitful concentration and forward motion are common to both. If one sets up to be a writer, one should be able to write anything, from a sonnet to a sermon, or at least be willing to try. I write not criticism but book reviews. A critic I understand to be someone who devotes a major part of his life and publication to the appreciation and analysis of an art; I, instead, am merely willing now and then to read a book and give my opinion of it in public.

description: The Con Man Michael Raymond has walked on both sides of the law: a key informer on municipal corruption in New York and Chicago, a dealer in stolen securities facing trial for murder. A profile appears in The Magazine, Section 8.

Closer to home, the Albany-based First Meridian Planning Corporation, in a widely publicized civil suit last fall, were accused of using the term financial planner as a means of selling investment vehicles such as condominiums in Florida, rare coins and paintings by largely unknown artists while obscuring the fact that they were receiving hefty commissions from the sale of the ''financial products.''

The effort would involve state officials, hospital and nursing home administrators, home-care agencies and insurance companies in an attempt to devise a plan similar to one adopted by the General

The explosion with a force of less than 20,000 tons of TNT was the eighth nuclear test in Nevada announced this year.

title: A Plea For the Chimps
description: Dr. Goodall doesn't dispute the contention that we need animal tests for the sake of progress. However, numerous drugs that were taken off the market after causing damage or even death in humans have shown that animal tests are not reliable. As an example, Thalidomide didn't seem to have any negative effects on animals; its only drawback was that it caused deformities in thousands of children whose mothers had taken the drug as a sedative during pregnancy. PETRA WEISHEIT East Norwalk, Conn.

title: EVOKING BOSCH'S HEAVEN AND HELL
description: IT IS THE PREROGATIVE OF great paintings that, as Vincent van Gogh once wrote, they ''keep their calm even in the midst of catastrophe.'' In our lives, they are the point of maximum stillness. We move. They don't.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article on June 7 about the Bedford-Stuyvesant Restoration Corporation incorrectly described its role in the founding of Empire State College. The corporation provided research help and office space to a branch of the college, which was established by New York State. The article also incorrectly described the corporation's role in attracting businesses to Bedford-Stuyvesant. The corporation played no direct role in bringing a Fayva shoe store to the area. The article also incorrectly reported the year when the International Business Machines Corporation opened a plant in Bedford-Stuyvesant. It was 1978.

title: CORRECTION
description: A short article about Tom Hayden in The Week in Review on June 7 misstated the circumstances surrounding the cancellation of a speech he was to have made at the San Jose City College commencement on June 5. The appearance by Mr. Hayden, a California Assemblyman who was an activist during the Vietnam War, was canceled by the college, because of fears that the ceremony would be disrupted by what it called ''outside groups.''

title:
NUMISMATICS;
FRANCE HONORS AN ECONOMIC GENIUS

The coins are dated 1986 and have been issued to commemorate the 100th anniversary of Mr. Schuman's birth. He died in 1963 at the age of 77.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: INSIDE THE PRIVATE OFFICE: Memoirs of the Secretary to British Foreign Ministers. By Nicholas Henderson. (Academy Chicago, $15.95.) In his brief and unrestrained memoir, Sir Nicholas Henderson commits that most unusual sin - he reveals the hidden world of Britain's Foreign Office, and brings to life several of the colorful men who served as its master. The author, Britain's ambassador to Washington from 1979 to 1982, spent his earlier career nursing a passion for anonymity as private secretary to five foreign ministers. In this high but shadowy post, he gained unrivaled access to both the intrigues of power and the quirks of the powerful. ''Private Secretaries [ are ] the keepers of private secrets,'' he writes, ''just as . . . the Secretaries of State . . . are the keepers of state secrets.'' He describes fondly his years in the entourage of Anthony Eden, the suave political insider whose gilded public career was eclipsed by an emotional breakdown suffered during the Suez crisis; Ernest Bevin, the folksy west country trade unionist whose taste for sherry was surpassed only by his success at statecraft; Richard Austen (Rab) Butler, whose short tenure at Whitehall was clouded by a reputation for indecision and a talent for avoiding political confrontation; and Michael Stewart, the most ''unsung'' of modern Foreign Ministers, loved for his bookish and quiet bearing and hated for his vocal support of United States policy in Vietnam. If Sir Nicholas's memoir is sentimental, he is to be forgiven: his was the last generation to serve the empire before it sank into obscurity.

title: A LITTLE NIGHT MUSIC IN MILFORD
description: LEAD: ON a recent spring night, the sound of music - Ravel, Beethoven and Dvorak -drifted from a small red clapboard building in rural northwestern Connecticut.

title: ADMIRING THE UNPREDICTABLE MR. KUBRICK
description: IT WAS ABOUT EIGHT MONTHS ago when I first heard that Stanley Kubrick was making a film dealing with Vietnam, called ''Full Metal Jacket.'' Holding Mr. Kubrick's work in the high esteem that I do - and having attempted to write about the war in a number of ways and from a number of angles - I was immediately intrigued. The fact that Michael Herr, who had written ''Dispatches,'' an amazing book about the war, was involved only increased my interest. The person to whom I was speaking said the movie was based on a novel, ''The Short-Timers,'' by Gustav Hasford, and that it contained one of the scariest scenes my friend had ever read. It sounded like this material was right up Mr. Kubrick's alley. Certainly he had shaken me up a number of times.

description: To the Sports Editor: A man can resist the call to service only so long.

Walsh of Amenia, N.Y. The Rev. Donald J. Moore performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at the Fordham University Church on the Rose Hill campus in the Bronx.

description: In the end, everyone blinked.

description: EXACTLY half a century ago the first world team championship ended in Budapest. Nineteen teams from 18 countries battled for a week and Austria triumphed in both the open and women's divisions.

title:
IN THE REGION: LONG ISLAND;
Marketing a Rare Tract of Shoreline Land
description: LEAD: IT is rare to find a major waterfront parcel on the East End that is still available for development, but that is the case with a 396-acre forested tract in the Village of North Haven, where lots have been available for purchase since April.

description: Africa, still recovering from the famine of 1983-85, is now grappling with an equally damaging ''financial famine,'' African economists warned here this week.

description: Tom Seaver pitched four dull innings yesterday in a simulated game in the third workout of his comeback at the age of 42, then implied strongly that he might abandon the experiment and retire.
