description: The World Cup of golf, featuring two-man teams from 32 nations, will be renewed this fall, Howard Clark, chairman of the International Golf Association, announced today.

title: WONDERS FROM THE TIME OF DUNCAN PHYFE
description: DUNCAN PHYFE'S NAME is better known to Americans than the furniture he crafted in 19th-century New York, an oversight that the Museum of the City of New York is trying to correct in ''An Elegant Assortment: The Furniture of Duncan Phyfe and his Contemporaries, 1800-1840.'' The exhibition remains through Aug. 23.

title: Giants Fall Short
description: CONTRIBUTIONS for the Giants' Super Bowl victory celebration fell short of the cost by $68,163, so the state sports authority will chalk up the deficit as its contribution, officials say. The Jan. 27 bash at Giants Stadium cost $719,180 and most expenses were covered by $651,017 in public and corporate donations, according to an audit released Friday by the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority.

title: Gathering of Mississippians Revels in Down-Home Style
description: ''It's the damnedest thing,'' said Greg Harkins of Vaughan, Miss., who was in Central Park yesterday selling rocking chairs from back home, ''but in New York there aren't any front porches.''

title: FRANCE'S SAVORY TALE OF FATE
description: IT'S PERHAPS A MINOR RITE, one of the lesser pilgrimages in this country, but, if you go to the old town of Aubagne, just a few miles from Marseilles, you'll find maps and guidebooks showing how to visit the very spots where Marcel Pagnol, the novelist, playwright and director who was born there, filmed some of his most famous scenes.

title: PAYING FOR PRESERVATION
description: FOR ALL THE URGENCY THAT the threat of overdevelopment poses in New York and so many other downtowns today, there is another side to this coin, and I do not mean the hurt feelings of real-estate developers. Those who would shoehorn towers everywhere can take care of themselves, thank you. But less self-sufficient, often, are the owners of landmark buildings whose properties have been turned by the current real-estate madness into potential gold mines. In an age that sees virtually every landmark more as a potential base for a skyscraper than as an object in itself, who can blame the owners of these landmarks if their eyes glimmer with the prospect quick riches?

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of a production error, an article in the Westchester Weekly today about the Jay property in Rye is incomplete and includes passages from an unrelated article. A corrected version will appear next Sunday.

title: HOLOCAUST AND MORAL IMPLICATIONS
description: FORTY-TWO years after World War II, we know the Holocaust's outline and many of its critical details. Of almost equal interest is its aftermath. In West Germany, the overwhelming majority of war criminals, never tried, die peacefully in bed after long and propsperous careers in government, industry and the professions. In Austria, political campaigns once again take as their theme the machinations of an International Jewish Conspiracy based somewhere in Jerusalem. From California, revisionist historians issue broadsides ''proving'' that the Holocaust never occurred.

title: AIDS ON STAGE: COMFORT, SORROW, ANGER
description: WHEN WILLIAM HOFFMAN sat down to revise his award-winning 1985 drama ''As Is'' for its recent revival at the Circle Repertory Theater, he ended up making only one major change. The original script contained a scene in which the six members of the play's informal Greek chorus recalled the first time they had heard about AIDS - from a doctor, from a friend, from a newspaper. In the new version, the playwright extended the scene with a speech in which one character reminisces about the first memorial service he had attended for someone who had died of AIDS.

title: MARTHA BERETTA BECOMES BRIDE
description: The marriage of Martha Savoy Beretta, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David Beretta Jr. of Jamestown, R.I., to Douglas Henry Mainiero took place yesterday in Newport, R.I. The Rev. description: GORBACHEV'S CHALLENGE Economic Reform in the Age of High Technology. By Marshall I. Goldman. Illustrated. 296 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company. $16.95.

description: ''What the schools have to do is develop in children a deep thirst for knowledge and learning and discovering,'' said Franklyn M. Branley of Sag Harbor. ''I think we haven't done thatsuccessfully.''

title: CAR BOMB KILLS 15 IN BARCELONA
description: Most of the 600 people killed in Spain in 19 years of attacks by E.T.A., the Basque separatist group, have been police officers, paramilitary civil guards and military men. But last week, a car bomb set fire to a parking garage under a Barcelona department store, killing at least 15 shoppers, including five women and several children. At least 30 people were injured.

description: When Bernard Cardinal Law issues his annual blessing forthe Boston Harbor lobster boat fleet on Sunday, he will celebrate the end of an era of uncertainty for the lobstermen.

title: AIRPORT SECURITY LAPSES FOUND

Since the system was implemented in 1973, hijackings in the United States have been virtually eliminated. So it would seem that the airline industry, which is responsible for the screening, has erected a very tight net.

title: In Boston, A Traffic Debate

title: STANLEY KUBRICK'S VIETNAM

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
WRITERS' WEEK

Writers' Week, which begins today and runs through Friday, started in 1983 as a weekend event. Since then writers of distinction have come to the college to lecture and conduct workshops each June and the program has grown into a full week of events.

title:
DINING OUT;
AND SO WHY NOT A STATE CUISINE?

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: GENERAL A. P. HILL: The Story of a Confederate Warrior. By James I. Robertson Jr. (Random House, $24.95.) ''A. P. Hill came up'' is a phrase often found in the stories of Civil War battles told from the Confederate side. General Hill's Light Division always seemed to be on the spot in the major engagements fought by the Army of Northern Virginia. He was one of Gen. Robert E. Lee's favorite combat generals - and one of his most troublesome. Hill reached the level of his incompetence when he was promoted to lead a corps and proved he couldn't work with other generals. To the credit of his biographer, James I. Robinson Jr., a professor of history at Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University, Blacksburg, he is both praised and damned for his valor and his foolhardiness in this book. This is a battle biography, and it disproves the romantic legend that the Confederate generals were brilliant tacticians who were outnumbered but never outfought. Hill does not emerge as a man of thought or vision; there is hardly anything in the book about the aims of the war or what he believed he was fighting for. The judgment of Douglas Southall Freeman, in the foreword to his three-volume study, ''Lee's Lieutenants,'' still stands: ''Hill was full of contradictions, able and negligent, cooperative with his subordinates and both punctilious and contentious in his dealings with his corps chief.'' Mr. Robertson's book confirms that judgment in detail.

description: Researchers have strong evidence for the first time that reducing cholesterol can reverse the progression of arterial disease, a major cause of heart attacks. A group from the University of Southern California Medical School said last week that a regimen of diet and drugs had reduced fatty deposits in the arteries of 16.2 percent of the patients who received the treatment. It was clear before that such treatment reduced illness and death rates, but researchers had not been able to confirm that it acted directly on the deposits.

Use mulches to cover the ground, keep it cool, prevent weed growth and preserve moisture; pine needles, where naturally available, are good around acid-loving plants such as rhododendrons, azaleas, mountain laurels, leucothoes, heaths and heathers; use wood chips or buckwheat hulls for roses and perennials; for vegetables try thin layers of grass clippings, rough compost or chopped leaves. title: THE RESPONSIBILITIES OF CAT OWNERS
description: I am somewhat dismayed at Susan Spehar's essay, ''Kittens: Cute, Clean and $1,141.50'' [ Opinion page, May 24 ] . Keeping a companion animal healthy is a responsibility and it costs money. She made the latter point quite clear and then did a turn-around in her article and promoted irresponsible cat ownership. Cats that have been declawed should not be allowed out to roam free because they are defenseless. However, they can still kill birds and other small creatures, as can cats with their claws. So free-roaming cats are more likely to contract diseases, some of which, like Lyme disease, can be passed on to humans.

title: AIMING HIGH
description: Donald Trump, who has made a lot of money investing in plots of earth, apparently has cast his eye to the heavens. Word had it last week that the 41-year-old real estate developer had recently begun accumulating shares of Pan American World Airways and would soon control 17 percent of the company's stock. Sources familiar with Mr. Trump's Pan Am investments said he might be planning to acquire the airline, which lost $463 million last year, with a couple of goals in mind: one, to make a profit on a stock he considers undervalued and, two, to bring scheduled airline service to Atlantic City, where Mr. Trump owns two hugely profitable casinos and is planning a third. Mr. Trump himself had ''no comment whatsoever'' on the matter.

title: THE NEW JAZZ ERA CLIMS ITS AUDIENCE
description: JAZZ IS BACK, THEY SAY. NOT SO LONG AGO, jazz musicians were rarely seen on television or in national magazines, jazz records were either small-label affairs or imports from Europe and Japan, jazz radio was something of a contradiction in terms, and even watered-down jazz-pop hybrids were hiding behind the rubric ''fusion.'' Now they - the trend-spotters, the arbiters of au courant - have declared that jazz is back. But the music hasn't simply become stylish; it has been integrating itself into the larger culture. Jazz is showing signs of an unprecedented resilience, a determination to hold onto hard-won gains.

title: Lendl U.S. Citizen?
description: HE was born in Czechoslovakia, but he lives in Greenwich, Conn., and now Ivan Lendl, the tennis star who recently obtained permanent resident status, wants to become a full-fledged United States citizen, and as quickly as possible. To help him, Senator Lowell Weicker, Republican of Connecticut, has introduced a bill that would allow Lendl to bypass the usual five-year waiting period and gain citizenship in time to represent the United States on the 1988 Davis Cup team, in the World Team Cup competition and maybe the Olympics. Those would appear to be compelling arguments for special treatment, but perhaps not compelling enough for Rep. Romano L. Mazzoli, the Kentucky Democrat who heads the House immigration committee. He and Senator Edward M. Kennedy, his Senate counterpart, are known to frown on special citizenship exemptions, especially for athletes, and last month Mazzoli said private immigration bills should be available only to help aliens facing ''extreme hardship.''

title: SHOES FOR WARM WEATHER
description: I WAS EVERYTHING THE WELL-DRESSED PRIVATE detective should be,'' Philip Marlowe boasted in ''The Big Sleep.'' Indeed, the sleuth's self-assurance extended to his shoes - sturdy black brogues that he didn't hesitate to wear with a pale-blue summer suit. These days, Mr. Marlowe's shoes would surely be made of lighter stuff, from pliant glove leather to kid, or fine-grained calf. For, according to the experts, the primary difference between a winter shoe and one made for summer is weight. Hefty English brogues (some weigh as much as eight pounds) remain acceptable year-round, but they tend to seem rigid and even somewhat clumsy when the weather turns. Accordingly, they have lately given way to more flexible footwear with a distinctly European flavor.

title: A County Named Bullfrog

Most Nevadans do not want the dump in their state but feel that, if they are overruled, the Federal Government should be heavily taxed for it. Current law sets the state's property tax limit at $3.64 per $100. Under the new law, sent to Gov. Richard H. Bryan for his signature, the tax would be $5 per $100 in Bullfrog County.

The violence and strikes that have shaken Panama this month have not interfered with operations at the canal, but they have raised renewed concern about its future. According to treaties signed during the Carter Administration, Panama will take control of the canal in the year 2000. As challenges to Gen.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: USURPERS. By Francisco Ayala. Translated by Carolyn Richmond. (Schocken, $15.95.) Like many of the best Spanish writers of the post-civil war period, Francisco Ayala, one of Spain's modern masters, came to artistic maturity in exile -much of it spent in the United States. But until now his work has been largely unavailable in English. The eight stories of ''Usurpers'' (1949), here translated to convey the rhetorical weight of the original, serve to illustrate the author's belief that every exercise of power is by nature a usurpation. In ''The Impostors,'' set in 16th-century Portugal, a pastry chef tries to pass himself off as royalty; when he is exposed, we are given to understand that he is a reflection of the fraud already inherent in the idea of monarchy. (Not surprisingly, Mr. Ayala's works were banned in Spain for most of the Franco era.) In ''The Invalid,'' Enrique III of Castile leaves his sickbed to arrest a band of rebellious noblemen; months later, drowsily questioning his retainers, he learns that the prisoners have gone free - and that he himself gave the order to release them. ''The Bewitched'' is a quietly terrifying story reminiscent of Kafka's ''Trial.'' When a man is finally granted an audience with Carlos II, the monarch is distracted by a pet monkey, and the petitioner leaves without ever making his request. Nothing of substance is uttered, because there is no substance; late 17th-century Spanish society is revealed as a sham, an elaborate appearance of power whose center is a drooling idiot. Of course Mr. Ayala's j'accuse is not directed just at the distant past. The volume ends with the striking ''Dialogue of the Dead: A Spanish Elegy,'' in which cadavers muse about the Spanish civil war that took their lives. The tragic modern conflict is everywhere present.

title:
GARDENING;
WAYS TO BRING FLOWERING AND FRUITING
description: LEAD: AT one time or another, many gardeners have been disappointed when a recently planted tree or shrub fails to bloom the year after it was planted. Often, several years may go by without a floral display. This can be especially perplexing when the plant had flowers on it when it was purchased.

title: Banking on the Yuppie Fitness Boom
description: WHETHER they are aging joggers looking for a sport that's easier on the knees, or hard-core endorphin junkies turning to triathlon competitions for the ultimate high, runners are rediscovering bicycles. Industry experts differ only on their numbers, not their significance.

title: Meeting of North and Casey With Top Contras Reported
description: Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North, the former White House aide, and William Casey, the former Director of Central Intelligence, met secretly with Nicaraguan contra leaders in a Washington town house in 1984 and 1985, apparently to avoid leaving any record of the talks, The Los Angeles Times said today.

title: PLANNERS ACT ON JAY PROPERTY
description: THE future of the Jay property in Rye remained uncertain last week as the Rye City Planning Commission gave conditional approval to a developer's plan and the developer immediately rejected and denounced the conditions.

title: Swill and Spill
description: The beer slobs are those grinning rowdies who get sloshed in the stadium and slosh beer on others. To its credit, the New York Legislature is determined to keep them in check. Threatened with legislation to require alcohol-free ''family sections,'' stadium operators promise tougher controls on drinking in the stands. The Legislature ought to keep up the pressure.

title: 100,000 Condoms Called Back
description: Manufacturers are recalling 100,000 condoms as a result of increased Federal inspection stemming from their promotion as a way to prevent AIDS and other sexually transmitted diseases.

title: WHEN BERLIN WAS AN ARTISTIC CAULDRON
description: THE CITY, OR, MORE accurately, cities, of Berlin are celebrating their 750th anniversary this year, and the record companies have not been remiss in observing that milestone. Perhaps the most interesting Berlin album thus far is titled ''Musik Zwischen den Kriegen: Eine Berliner Dokumentation'' (Thorofon Capella ETHK 341/4, four LP's), which translates as ''Music Between the Wars: A Berlin Documentation.''

title: SUMMER: SO WHAT? (A CONTRARY VIEW)
description: I HATE summer.

title: FRANCES JAMIESON WED TO DAVID UNGER
description: At the Unitarian Church of All Souls in New York yesterday, Frances Eder Jamieson, a daughter of Mrs. James J. Storrow Jr. of New York and the late Francis A. Jamieson, was married to David Alan Unger, a son of Joseph K. Unger of Morristown, N.J., and the late Bertha Dalrymple Unger. The Rev. John Buehrens performed the ceremony.

title: WALTER HELLER: PRESIDENTIAL PERSUADER
description: WALTER W. Heller, chief economic adviser to Presidents Kennedy and Johnson, came of age in the postwar era when many of the most creative economic thinkers were drawn to the theories of John Maynard Keynes. But Mr. Heller, who died last week at the age of 71, was unusual in that he was in a position to apply those precepts. Moreover, he was an enormously personable man with a soothing manner that served him well in convincing Presidents to follow his prescriptions, even when they clashed with political expediency.

title:
ART;
PHOTOGRAPHIC VIEW OF PALLADIO'S VILLAS
description: LEAD: IT'S a widespread dream to want to return to one's alma mater in triumph. At Wesleyan University in Middletown, Philip Trager has realized it. Since his graduation from Wesleyan in 1956, he has become a noted photographer. His current exhibition at the Zilkha Gallery features 60 photographs of Palladian villas, and it often touches the sublime.

title: GRAPPLING WITH THE MYSTERIES OF THE 'BLACK BOX'
description: TO MANY AUDIO FANS -even those informed about technical matters - an FM tuner is what is called a ''black box'' in engineering parlance, meaning an enigmatic device with mysterious innards. Such listeners may be knowledgeable about power ratings, distortion and frequency response in amplifiers. But when it comes to assessing the performance of tuners - the component that pulls in radio programs - even otherwise savvy audio fans are often at a loss, feeling intimidated by what they perceive as technical arcana.

title: CAUSE OF DYSLEXIA STILL AT ISSUE
description: In the May 17 article entitled ''Dyslexic Student Seeking New Grade,'' a statement was made to the effect that dyslexia is an inner ear disorder. This has never been proven and as far as experts in the field know, the etiology for dyslexia is still unknown.

title: CAN TRADITIONAL CANTONESE OPERA COMPETE WITH WESTERN-STYLE POP MUSIC?
description: A LITHE 72-YEAR-OLD WHO still exults in his back flips, Sun Martsai is the lord of Cantonese opera.

title: PROJECT BATTLING SEX BIAS IN COURSES
description: THE names Charlotte Perkins Gilman, Alice Paul and Zorah Neal Hurston may not be household words yet. Nor, for that matter, is the phrase ''gender integration,'' even though New Jerseyans are in the midst of that integration, according to a recent proclamation by Governor Kean.

title: ELIZABETH STEPHENS WEDS
description: Elizabeth Wade Stephens, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Wade Carroll Stephens of Lawrenceville, N.J., was married there yesterday to James Stephen Hebb 4th, the son of Mrs. John Stephen Slorp of Memphis and Mr. Hebb 3d of Alexandria, Va. The Rev. Dr. H.Dana Fearon 3d, a Presbyterian minister, and the Rev. Donald Stuart Dunnan, an Episcopal priest, officiated at the Edith Memorial Chapel of the Lawrenceville School, where the bride's father is director of studies.

title: MAYORS LOOK PAST THE REAGAN YEARS
description: After years of fighting Federal cutbacks, the nation's mayors are hoping that the end of the Reagan Administration will bring more money from Washington. But even so, the mayors say they learned two lasting lessons from Ronald Reagan's Presidency: to narrow their list of demands, and even then not to expect too much.

title: Music Festivals
description: To the Editor: Depicted in a cartoon, Snoopy, while sauntering through the countryside, utters, ''The secret of staying young is to find an age you really like and sticking with it.'' In search of finding good music abroad, I decided to follow Snoopy's advice.

title: All Eyes On Her
description: In his article ''All Eyes on Her'' (About Men, May 24), Edward Harper proclaims with too-coy modesty that, despite the fact that he is ''nondescript,'' he has been able to win a beautiful wife half his age.

title: BREWERS TOP JAYS
description: Bill Wegman allowed seven hits in seven and one-third innings today, and Milwaukee scored two unearned runs in the seventh as the Brewers beat the Toronto Blue Jays, 3-2.

title: Liza Phillips Is Married to Arthur Platt
description: Elizabeth Laughlin Phillips and Arthur van der Gracht Platt were married yesterday at the Siasconset (Mass.) Union Chapel on Nantucket Island by the Rev. John Wing, an Episcopal priest. The bride is the daughter of Laughlin Phillips and Mrs. Hood Phillips of Washington. Mr. Platt is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Cheney Platt of Palisades, N.Y., and Cornish, N.H.

title: ANIMATION ART IS FEATURED
description: A NUMBER of postal administrations issued stamps to commemorate Capex '87, the international stamp show that concludes today in Toronto. Among the popular topics for collectors are Disney characters. The latest come from Redonda and Sierra Leone.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Horse Racing Massachusetts Handicap: Waquoit, ridden by Chris McCarron, held off a late stretch drive by Broad Brush, the favorite, for an upset victory yesterday in the 53d running of the Massachusetts Handicap at Suffolk Downs in Boston. Waquoit, the top horse in New England last year, broke out immediately to lead the six-horse field and stayed in front until the sixteenth pole. Broad Brush, ridden by Angel Cordero, put a head in front, but McCarron urged Waquoit on and won by a nose. Broad Brush carried topweight of 126 pounds, conceding from 4 to 17 pounds to the rest of the field. Waquoit, who carried 117 pounds, was timed in 1:49 for a mile and an eighth and returned $10.60 for $2 to win. He earned $124,560 for his owner, Joseph Federico, from the total purse of $207,600. Finishing third was Tour d'Or, ridden by Tammi Campbell. (AP) Forest Fair First at Belmont: Forest Fair slipped through along the inside entering the stretch to gain the lead and then drew away to a three-length victory in the $121,200 Hill Prince Stakes for 3-year-olds at Belmont Park. It was the third winning ride of the day for Jose Santos. Kindly Court closed well while racing wide to be runner-up, a length ahead of First Patriot. Forest Fair, a Kentucky-bred son of Naskra-Fairest Forest, went the mile and a sixteenth on the firm Widener Turf Course in 1:42 4/5 to register his fifth victory in eight starts this year. He returned $3.40 for $2 to win. Auto Racing Mansell on the Pole: Nigell Mansell earned his fourth pole position in five races this season, winning the top spot for the Detroit Grand Prix today. Mansell, a Briton who drives a Honda-powered Williams, started the qualifying yesterday on the provisional pole. He led easily on the 2.5-mile 20-turn circuit, which winds through the streets of downtown Detroit. His fast lap in the final 60 minutes of qualifications was timed at 1 minute 39.264 seconds, which averages out to 90.667 miles an hour. The top four for today's 63-lap 157.49-mile race are Ayrton Senna of Brazil, the defending champion, who held on to second place with a time of 1:40.607; Nelson Piquet of Brazil, the 1984 Detroit winner and Mansell's Williams teammate, who earned a second-row starting berth with a lap of 1:40.942, and Thierry Boutsen of Belgium, who drives a Benetton-Ford and was fourth at 1:42.050.(AP) Rugby New Zealand Rallies for Title: Led by Grant Fox, New Zealand rallied from a 9-0 halftime deficit to crush France, 29-9, and win the inaugural 16-nation World Cup Rugby Union tournament in Auckland, New Zealand. Fox kicked four penalties, a drop goal and a conversion for 17 points.(AP) Cycling Mayor's Cup: About 18,000 spectators jammed the streets around the South Street Seaport yesterday afternoon to cheer cyclists riding in the third annual Nabisco Mayor's Cup Race series. Yesterday's race was the first series stop in New York and the 13th on a 14-city cycling tour that began in April. The course went south on Front Street, then to Wall Street, South Street, John Street and back to Front Street for the finish. Male cyclists raced 75 laps and female bikers 45. Each lap measured one-half mile. Thomas Prehn of Boulder, Colo., sprinted out of a nine-bike pack in the final turn of the 50-kilometer criterium race to capture the men's race with a time of 1 hour 12 minutes 32 seconds. The top woman in the 30-kilometer criterium was Carol Addy of Greensboro, N.C., who was timed in 47:19. Golf Long Island Amateur Championship: P. J. Cowan, a member of the St. John's University golf team, won the 66th Long Island amateur championship by defeating Jonathan Jame, three up, in the 36-hole final at Garden City Golf Club.

title: SUNDAY OBSERVER
description: I HAVE THESE FEELINGS. Some are about insurance. I have a feeling that when I need the insurance it will turn out that the policy doesn't cover what I need it for.

title: JUNE SWOON: SMALL BRIDAL, BIG HEADACHE
description: IT was the late-night phone call that every parent of a daughter fears - won't come. ''I'm engaged,'' she shrieked over the long-distance wires.'' We were thrilled, relieved, ecstatic.

title:
BUSINESS FORUM: ENDING AN ANTITRUST EXEMPTION;
Insurance Needs a Dose of Competition
description: LEAD: INSURANCE companies have been legally allowed to fix prices since 1945, when Congress passed the McCarran-Ferguson Act, which exempts the insurance industry from the antitrust laws. As a result, Americans have paid more than they should for coverage and business has been forced to suffer through periodic ''crises'' of soaring premiums.

title: Sports of The Times; USING LEN BIAS AS A DIFFERENT KIND OF ROLE MODEL
description: THIS is prom season, graduation season, wedding season. The traditional two words a parent says to a young person rushing out the door to a joyous celebration are ''Be careful,'' but anybody with an interest in sports might change those two words to ''Len Bias.''

title: A BOAT RIDE, A VIEW, AND THEN...
description: THE quintessence of summer on Long Island is a cooling ferryboat ride, a view of ospreys on their highly perched nests and a lovely inn offering water views and good meals at the end of the journey. Our destination was the Ram's Head Inn on Shelter Island.

title: GOING BACK TO DISTINCTIVE BASICS
description: ROOTS WILL TELL, AS THE RE-spective seasons of New York City Ballet and American Ballet Theater suggest. At a time when the differences between them were believed to be diminishing, the two troupes now appear again distinct, with each seeming closer to its traditional artistic profile.

title: LIFE ON STRUGGLE MOUNTAIN
description: AND A VOICE TO SING WITH A Memoir. By Joan Baez. Illustrated. 378 pp. New York: Summit Books. $19.95.

title: ON LANGUAGE
description: FAWN HALL, SECRETARY to Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North at the National Security Council until last November, appeared before the Iran-contra panel and boosted its ratings overnight. Linguists were immediately struck by her pronunciation.

title: THE SORRY SUCCESS OF A PART-TIME TEACHER
description: SUCCESS at last. One week before spring term of '86 I was asked to teach a course at Quinebaug Valley Community College in Danielson. I had just earned my master's degree in English and for eight months I'd been searching for a job. The course was called Business, Technical and Report Writing.

title: THE WOMEN THEY FEARED
description: MALE FANTASIES Volume One: Women, Floods, Bodies, History. By Klaus Theweleit. Translated by Stephen Conway in collaboration with Erica Carter and Chris Turner. Foreword by Barbara Ehrenreich. Illustrated. 517 pp. Minneapolis: University of Minnesota Press. Cloth, $25. Paper, $14.95.

title: Valley Rail
description: To the Editor: I enjoyed reading ''All Aboard for a Ride Back to the 1920's'' by Karl Zimmermann (Travel, May 17). I should like to tell you of a spur of the Valley Railroad in Connecticut that existed many years ago.

title: PART OF THE SOLUTION, PART OF THE PROBLEM
description: ''DEMOCRACY IS IN THE STREETS'' From Port Huron to the Siege of Chicago. By James Miller. Illustrated. 431 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $19.95.

title: No, the Goetz Verdict Was Not a Landmark Precedent
description: LEAD: The jury of his peers that has spent most of the spring with Bernhard H. Goetz has rendered a mixed verdict: guilty of one felony gun charge, innocent of 12 more serious offenses, including assault and attempted murder. Now comes the open season for pundits identifying the deeper significance of the Goetz trial and the jury's verdict.

title: Fathers, Young and Old
description: A father we know, a man in his early 40's, was thinking out loud about Father's Day. ''It was shortly after I had kids that people began postponing parenthood,'' he said. ''As a result, I have a lot of friends my age who are just now starting families.

title: POSTINGS: Stamford Development; A Pricey Elegance
description: When BEC Development Corporation looked into the Stamford, Conn., area, it found plenty of condominiums and cookie-cutter houses. ''We wanted to pick up a niche in the marketplace that few people had gone into,'' said Donna J. Crandley, president of BEC in Stamford.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: LEAD: ON POETS AND OTHERS. By Octavio Paz. Translated by Michael Schmidt. (Seaver, $18.95.) Seven of these 16 essays by the Mexican poet and philosopher Octavio Paz focus on poets such as Robert Frost, Walt Whitman, Andre Breton and Luis Cernuda. However, Mr. Paz is not only concerned with literary criticism, and considers topics as diverse as the art criticism of Charles Baudelaire, the graphic art of Charles Tomlinson and the films of Luis Bunuel.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: LEAD: THE CBS MURDERS. By Richard Hammer. (Morrow, $16.95.) This book is fun. Perhaps it shouldn't be. It explains the rat's nest of circumstance that led to the 1982 murders of three CBS technicians who ran to aid Margaret Barbera as she was gunned down on Manhattan's Pier 92. Their deaths, as every reporter said at the time, were senseless and tragic.

title: RAIL LINE FACES NEW LEGAL TEST
description: LEAD: THE joint state and Federal effort to restore railroad passenger service between Philadelpia and Atlantic City appears headed for further legal challenges.

title: ELIZABETH H. COLE BECOMES A BRIDE
description: At St. John's Episcopal Church in West Hartford, Conn., yesterday, Elizabeth Huntington Cole, assistant to the headmistress of the Winsor School, and Jonathan Albert Horton, a candidate for an M.B.A. degree at Georgetown University, were married by the Rev. Allan H. O'Neil, rector of the church. He was assisted by the Rev. Albert Bartlett, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: MIDLIFE MUSIC
description: IT IS 1967 AND I'M 20 YEARS OLD. I am in college visiting my friend Scott, who owns the best stereo on campus. We have dragged his speakers across the room so they are just a foot apart, facing each other. My head is in between. Country Joe and the Fish, Jimi Hendrix and Janis Joplin are all helping me to forget that my draft deferment and my boyhood are about to expire.

title: IMMIGRATION REFORM
description: The Westchester Personnel Council of the County Chamber of Commerce is sponsoring a half-day conference tomorrow that will address employer compliance with recent immigration reform legislation, at the Stouffer Westchester Hotel in White Plains. The special half-day conference, to be held from noon to 5 P.M., is designed to familiarize area employers with the new employment verification and hiring procedures as mandated by the Immigration Reform and Control Act of 1986.

title: Credit Cards
description: To the Editor:

title: GLASNOST TRIED IN CHERRY HILL
description: ALENE S. AMMOND, the Cherry Hill housewife who became known as ''The Terror of Trenton'' as a State Senator from 1973 through 1977, has been pursuing ''glasnost'' lately.

title: Cable TV
description: To the Editor:

title: JURY SEES JUSTIFICATION, SOME SEE INJUSTICE
description: On a New York City subway train one afternoon two winters ago, Bernhard H. Goetz, an unprepossessing 37-year-old electronics expert, whipped out a pistol and shot four teen-agers who were, Mr. Goetz has said he believed, about to rob him. They are black, he is white, and what passed between them on the IRT loosed a storm of national debate over issues of crime and racism.

title: Affirming Rights of Owners in 'Takings'
description: WHAT Frank and Mary Bisigmano would like to hear unequivocally from the State of New York - in writing - is that they will not be permitted to build on their land.

title: FOR YOUNG ARCHITECTS, PRACTICAL TRAINING AND CIVIC SERVICE
description: ON a recent cool and drizzly morning at Bridgeport's Seaside Park, a dozen architecture students were finding out what happens to well-thought-out designs after they leave the drawing board.

title: Discovering a Common Language
description: THE ability to transfer data from 5 1/4-inch to 3 1/2-inch disks and vice versa is becoming an important consideration as sales of laptops and I.B.M. PS/2 computers increase. There are various ways to perform this time-consuming nuisance task. One software package specially designed for the purpose, The Brooklyn Bridge from White Crane Systems of Norcross, Ga., was covered in last week's column.

title: MISSING
description: Charles Glass, a 36-year-old American journalist, was known in the Middle East for reporting from places that most outsiders thought prudent to avoid. He also knew a lot of people. Last week, Lebanon's Defense Minister, Adel Osseiran, said radicals within the Party of God, Lebanese Shiite followers of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini of Iran, had abducted Mr. Glass, Mr. Osseiran's son, Ali, and their driver, from a limousine in southern Beirut. Mr. Glass, who was on leave from ABC News to write a book, was the first foreigner known to have been abducted since Syria sent 7,000 soldiers into Beirut in January. Nine Americans and 15 other foreigners are missing.

description: BIKES aren't just kid stuff anymore.

The letters had lain in a locked trunk for 40 years and in a bank safe-deposit box for 30 more, and all Mr. Ewing knew was that they had been written by William Tecumseh Sherman.

title:
DINING OUT;
NEW ENTRY FROM ACROSS THE RIVER
description: LEAD: THERE is good news for county diners who have been loath to sacrifice themselves to the chaotic traffic of the Tappen Zee Bridge in order to dine at Theresa's in Piermont. Theresa and Frank Miraglia have packed kitchen knives and tasting spoons and reopened in a renovated church rectory in Ossining.

title:
CRITICS' CHOICES;
Photography
description: LEAD: Deborah Turbeville is the last romantic fashion photographer. Her langorous ladies, dressed to the nines but faint to the point of exhaustion, live in an imaginary world remote from ours. The recent photographs on view at Staley Wise Gallery, 177 Prince Street, through July 11, seem to have been taken in the aftermath of a violent revolution in which all the men of the ruling class were killed; only their women survive, desolate, abandoned, immobilized by shock.

title: THE VARIED PALETTE OF HISPANIC ART IN AMERICA
description: MARTIN RAMIREZ IS AN UN-likely artistic icon. A poor Mexican who drifted across the border around the time of the Mexican Revolution, he did odd jobs for a while before gradually lapsing into what was diagnosed as a form of paranoid schizophrenia. He suffered from delusions and hallucinations, stopped speaking and spent the last 30 years of his life in a mental institution until his death in 1960.

title: THE STUGGLE FOR A DEMOCRATIC HAITI
description: THREE HOURS OUT OF NEW York, I start awake to find myself floating over a grotesque landscape - the sickly, reddish-brown hills of Haiti, wave upon wave of blood-dark corrugations, thickly marbled with white sand. Haitian peasants have long since uprooted the once-dense covering of trees and underbrush, selling the wood for charcoal and leaving bare white canyons through which, month after month, year after year, the rainwater flows, carrying tons of precious topsoil to the bottom of the Caribbean.

title: WALDHEIM TO VISIT POPE THIS WEEK
description: The Austrian Government said last week that Presdent Kurt Waldheim had received, and would accept, an invitation to pay an official visit to Pope John Paul II this Thursday in the Vatican. In Rome, the Pope's spokesman said the Pope had postponed the meeting several times and agreed to it only after Mr. Waldheim pressed his request.

title: NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Popham Beach, Me.; Environmental Laws at Issue
description: THE State Supreme Court will shortly rule on an appeal of a lower court's decision that Maine must pay for denying a beachfront homeowner the use of his local residence. The State Attorney General's office says that if the ruling is affirmed, Maine's zoning and environmental laws could be threatened.

title: THE RESPONSIBILITIES OF CAT OWNERS

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LEAD: THE DAMNATION GAME. By Clive Barker (Ace/Putnam, $18.95.) The Liverpudlian writer Clive Barker, who has established a reputation as a writer of short horror fiction, has now written his first novel, set on a vast estate outside London. In fairness, those who like this genre will, no doubt, enjoy the book for its unremitting devotion to the most sickening imagery.

title: DE PALMA BREAKS THE MOLD
description: WE HAVE ALL SEEN OUR SHARE OF heartless remakes, films made in a spirit of cannibalism and apparently for no better reason. They're part of the recycling blight that afflicts all aspects of popular culture in a period, like this one, that has no distinct identity of its own. So it's possible for a new record that sounds almost precisely like a 20-year-old record to be a Top-40 hit all over again. At the movies, this can mean knockoffs as mindless and random as the recent ''Wanted: Dead or Alive,'' which had absolutely nothing to do with the television series from which it took its title.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: FAITHFUL REBECCA. By Janice Eidus. (Fiction Collective, Cloth, $15.95; Paper, $7.95.) Rebecca is true to her friend Sagana, but by the end of this curious first novel she is most loyal to herself. The women grew up together playing fantasy games with dolls, and in their mid-20's they share an apartment in New York City. Both unwed, they have given birth to girls, when Sagana, disgusted with Rebecca's relentless pursuit of men and lackadaisical approach to motherhood, absconds with the babies to a virtually all-female upstate mountaintop commune she has founded without Rebecca's knowledge. As the book opens, Rebecca is recovering from a fever at the commune, where she has come to seek her baby and Sagana, who are deliberately hidden from her. She is aided in her quest by a teen-aged boy who has answered a classified advertisement calling for ''Adams'' to come ''meet your Eves!'' Rebecca all but falls for him. Sagana, meanwhile waits in her hut, ready to consider Rebecca's apologies. Janice Eidus, who has also published short stories, possesses a fierce imagination; she also adroitly orchestrates intrigues. Rebecca is convincing - a woman determined to grow by her own convictions. Sagana is more eccentric, a caustic, stereotyped feminist who believes most men are ''bland . . . like cottage cheese.'' Questions in the book nag: How did the women in the commune create such an idyll? How do they survive financially? Fantasies and symbolism (a voodoo enactment with dolls) are either carried too far or left ambiguous. It is not clear if the author meant to impart an otherworldliness to accentuate the characters' idealistic side. Nonetheless, the book's surrealistic edge is inventive and darkly amusing, even if Ms. Eidus's technique is not yet quite equal to her vision.

title: Uruguayan Clears Up 'State of Siege' Killing
description: One day almost 17 years ago, Dan Mitrione, an American police adviser, was kidnapped by Tupamaro guerrillas as he left his house in suburban Carrasco. Ten days later, his body was found in an abandoned car.

description: TRENDY has become something of a negative word, but trendy can be fun, as Tucson in Greenwich proves. This newest, possibly noisiest of the trendies, proves that being on the crest of a fad isn't all bad.

An uncertain student, she struggled in my Introduction to Literature class at Suffolk Community College two years back, struggled with Sophocles and Shakespeare, with Hawthorne and Chekhov and Joyce.

title: GERALDINE PAGE: A SELF-PORTRAIT IN WORDS
description: LEAD: In a recent series of interviews with Sandra Hochman, a poet who is at work on a book about the Circle in the Square theater, Geraldine Page, who died on June 13, discussed some of her ideas about acting, teaching and life. Excerpts from those interviews follow.

NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Portsmouth, N.H.;

title: Q and A
description: Soviet Union Question:Is it legal and/or advisable to take candy, chewing gum and blue jeans to the Soviet Union to trade with citizens for such things as fur hats? Also, what is the likelihood of touring Lenin's Tomb on my own if it is not on my Intourist itinerary? -B. B. R., Cleveland Heights, Ohio. Answer:Tour company people who make many visits to the Soviet Union frown on the idea of bartering with Soviet citizens. While such trading is not strictly illegal, says E. Wallace Lawrence 3d, of the Russian Travel Bureau, an American company that has specialized for many years in tours to the Soviet Union, it borders on the black market because it can easily lead to buying rubles for dollars. And unofficial currency trading is illegal, he says. However, Mr. Lawrence adds that he thinks it a good idea to take along bubble gum to give to children. Another tour official says that handing out little knicknacks as gifts is acceptable but anyone who indulges in trading or unofficial currency transactions is risking trouble.

title:
GARDENING;
FOR LAWNS, TRY A FEW WILDFLOWERS
description: LEAD: COUNTLESS hours and dollars are spent by many homeowners each year to keep their lawns weed-free. But a case can be made for encouraging wildflowers to mix with the grass. The result is a garden you can not only walk in, but walk on, one that requires little work and no expense and yet is colorful, attractive and even rich in folklore and history.

title: CYPRESS SENTRY AT 18th
description: At the Masters each year the golfers warn that the tournament at Augusta National doesn't really begin until the back nine in Sunday's final round. But the 87th United States Open might not really begin until the last three holes of today's final round - the 609-yard 16th that Seve Ballesteros considers a par 6, the uphill 428-yard l7th with what Tom Watson calls a ''goofy'' fairway, and the 343-yard 18th where Tommy Nakajima's 9-iron shot yesterday is still up in the cypress tree that serves as a sentry at the final green.

title: CHART FEVER: WATCHING THE HIT PARADES
description: THESE ARE HEADY times for chart fanatics, those of us for whom the weekly fluctuations of the pop music charts exert an irrational fascination and excitement. Today, not only reams of charts but encyclopedic tomes of pop statistics exist to fuel the competitive spirit of a world that seems increasingly obsessed with giving everything a numerical rating. Like baseball statistics, a record's weekly chart positions presume to offer an absolute ranking of performance over a given period of time. At least that is what those of us who follow the pop charts week after week, year after year, like to fool ourselves into believing.

The program - serious and engaging - included works by Schwantner, Xenakis and William Douglas, and premieres of pieces by David Krakauer and Dean Drummond.

description: The investigation into how Wedtech, a small South Bronx machine shop, grew into a $100-million-a-year military contractor has moved westward in recent weeks.

title: Cocaine Seized in London
description: Customs officers seized 110 pounds of cocaine today. It was the largest such haul ever made in Britain. A Customs spokesman said several people had been arrested in a raid on a house in Harley Street, London center of the private medical profession, but he gave no other details.

title: IN SHREVEPORT, A PRIVATE PERSON GOES PUBLIC
description: On Thursday, the arts critic of The Shreveport (La.) Journal declared that he was homosexual in a column on AIDS that appeared on the newspaper's editorial page.

title: UNEASY CALM AT THE COMEX
description: The dust has begun to settle at New York's Commodity Exchange from its latest calamity.

title: HERMAN OUT OF HOSPITAL
description: Woody Herman has been released from a hospital here where he spent almost three months being treated for a heart ailment and congested lungs, according to his manager, Tom Cassidy. The 74-year-old big-band leader has ''gone home to Los Angeles to get some rest, and hopefully he'll be able to rejoin the band soon,'' Mr. Cassidy said. Mr. Herman's band continued to tour during his illness.

title: Jazz Festival; CITY BALLET: MCBRIDE IN 'COPPELIA'
description: THE New York City Ballet production of ''Coppelia'' skipped into the New York State Theater on Wednesday, just in time for the hot weather. Derived from Marius Petipa's version of the ballet, this production's choreography and staging by George Balanchine and Alexandra Danilova, performed to the traditional score by Delibes, catches some of the dark tones of the Hoffman tale that inspired the ballet. But the production was actually created for the company's 1974 season in the outdoor amphitheater of the Saratoga Performing Arts Center in Saratoga Springs, N.Y., the company's summer home. And it is a frothy, amusing delight that is a perfect hot weather treat for children and adults.

title: PASSPORT TRAVEL INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Net loss

title: POKER, QUALITY TIME AND AN END TO THE GRAY FLANNEL MYTH
description: When the 5:32 bores out of Manhattan each weekday evening and starts making its way through the Westchester and Connecticut suburbs, it might not seem to need a conductor as much as a croupier.

title: NO OPEC PRICE RISE FORESEEN
description: At its meeting beginning this Thursday in Vienna, the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries is likely to vote to keep its official price at $18 a barrel and to approve modest increases in production quotas, Western energy analysts say.

title: U.S. OFFICIALS CALLED BITTERLY SPLIT OVER CONTINUING TRADE WITH IRAN
description: The Pentagon is locked in a bitter struggle with the State and Commerce Departments over whether the United States should continue to trade with Iran, according to Administration officials.

title: AD AGENCIES' BATTLE OF BRITAIN
description: Britain's general election campaign ended on June 11 with a solid victory for the Conservative Party and Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher. But that was just the beginning of a battle among the advertising agencies that wanted to take credit for the win.

title: FARRAKHAN SAYS HE WILL NOT BACK JACKSON BID
description: The Rev. Louis Farrakhan, the black Muslim leader, has said he will not publicly support the Rev. Jesse Jackson's campaign for President because it would hurt the black Democrat's chances among white voters.

title: Belgian Tax-Cut Plan
description: Belgium's Finance Minister, Mark Eyskens, will propose a package of income tax cuts worth $2.7 billion, a ministry spokesman said Friday. The package would cut the top tax rate to 50 percent, from 71.4 percent now, and considerably simplify the system. Belgian income taxes are the second highest in the European Community, after Denmark. Other key changes include taxing spouses' incomes separately. Joint taxation is widely seen as discouraging marriage.

title: AEL INDUSTRIES reports earnings for 13wks May 29
Quotation of the Day
description: ''I want to go home.'' - Omar Navas, conscripted by the contras in Nicaragua. [ A1:3. ]

title: RIGHTS GROUP HAILS NATIONAL SHIFT TOWARD EMBRACING CIVIL LIBERTIES
description: Civil-libertarians necessarily spend a lot of their time ''screaming about the imperfections of society'' and ''bemoaning the things that need to be fixed'' and warning ''that the sky is falling,'' says Ira Glasser, executive director of the American Civil Liberties Union.

description: It took awhile for the sad news to get around, but when it did last week, it brought back memories of a famous, long-ago Olympic showdown.

title: BEJART PLANS TO QUIT BRUSSELS
description: Maurice Bejart, the renowned French-born choreographer and opera director, is to move his 70-member Ballet of the 20th Century to Lausanne, Switzerland, in August, ending a 27-year stay in Brussels that had soured, and rejecting pleas from France that he return to his homeland.

title: ENVOY UNSURE HE'LL SEE OPPOSITION ON SEOUL TRIP
description: A high-level State Department official who will assess the civil unrest in South Korea said today that he is unsure whether he will meet with opposition leaders there.

description: Nancy Anne Kase, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Nathan G. Kase of New York and Katonah, N.Y., and James Henry O'Brasky, a son of Elizabeth Hahn Barnston of New Haven and Harris O'Brasky of Medway, Mass., were married yesterday. Rabbi Robert Goldberg performed the ceremony at the Kase home in Katonah.

description: Wearing a black suit and clerical collar, James Wright stands daily near an escalator at Los Angeles International Airport, and on a good day he collects $150 or more in the cigar box he extends to passengers.

description: It's summertime, and the living is fiercely competitive for New York's pop-concert promoters.

description: For teams that endured similarly horrid seasons, the Knicks and the Nets go into today's National Basketball Association draft in strikingly different circumstances.

description: LEAD: In 1970, when James R. Lightner and three fellow employees left Collins Radio, now a division of the Rockwell International Corporation, to set up Electrospace Systems Inc., they had to be flexible and a bit humble.

description: At the Park Avenue Synagogue in New York yesterday Shari Z. Teitelbaum, a business analyst for Philip Morris Inc. in New York, was married to Mark Lewis Bibi, an associate in the New York law firm of Sullivan & Cromwell. Rabbis Judah Nadich and Ezra M. description: They didn't exactly scale Mount Everest, but the Mets did reach some significant heights yesterday after two months of significant lows when they completed a three-game sweep and beat the Philadelphia Phillies, 8-3.

description: Rachel Harris Wilder, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Otis Wilder of New York and Chautauqua, N.Y., was married yesterday to Daniel Francis Smeragliuolo, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Alfonso Smeragliuolo of Jamestown, N.Y. The Rev. Charles A. Baldwin, a United Church of Christ chaplain at Brown University, performed the ceremony at the Athenaeum Hotel in Chautauqua.

5 Arrested in a Weapon Case After Death of Teen-Age Girl
description: Five men were charged Friday with possession of an unregistered machine gun in connection with the death of a teen-ager and the wounding of a 6-year-old girl at a crowded swimming pool earlier this month.

title: PHILLIPS, JOHNSON TAKE 2 TITLES EACH
description: The United States Gymnastics championships ended today with Kristie Phillips and Scott Johnson each adding two individual titles to the all-round championships they won earlier in the meet.

title: AMERICAN GREETINGS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 30
Baxter Travenol Officer Will Head IC Industries
description: IC Industries, a conglomerate with interests in commercial and consumer products and railroads, has elected Karl D. Bays chairman and chief executive officer. Mr. Bays, who has been chairman of Baxter Travenol Laboratories Inc., will assume the positions on July 1.

title: PLAYER IS WINNER ON 2D EXTRA HOLE
description: Perhaps it was fitting that Gary Player captured the Northville Invitational on the second playoff hole against Bruce Crampton today: He was the leader after each of the first three rounds of this $300,000 tournament.

title: PANHANDLERS SILLY, SAD AND HARD TO REGULATE
description: One man wears a clown costume, complete with a bulbous red nose. Another has balls attached to his head by springs; He says he is from another planet, raising money to go home. And, of course, there are sad stories. ''One guy appears to have no legs,'' said Jared Lebow, a spokesman for the New York City Transit Authority. ''And another guy I've seen, his pitch is, 'I am homeless. I don't want to commit any crimes. So please give me some money.' ''

title: TV, Sex and Birth Control
description: Starting this month, television watchers in New York City and Buffalo can see yet another commercial featuring a handsome man, a pretty woman and music to go to bed by. But this commercial isn't selling detergent, jeans or diet soda. It's selling birth control, ''from saying 'no' to taking the pill.''

title: Jazz Festival; WORLD SAXOPHONE QUARTET, AT TOWN HALL
description: THE World Saxophone Quartet's jazz festival performance at Town Hall on Saturday included a revelatory interpretation of Duke Ellington's ''Come Sunday.'' David Murray's tenor stretched and pummeled the melody while Hamiet Bluiett's baritone provided a rumbling, percussive counterpoint. That left Julius Hemphill and Oliver Lake, whose cannily voiced altos created the illusion that an entire reed section was harmonizing. With four horns, a commitment to teamwork and a brilliantly incisive arrangement, the quartet created music as richly detailed as that of an orchestra, but with a small band's mobility and punch.

title: SIMPSON WINS OPEN BY ONE SHOT AS WATSON JUST MISSES LONG PUTT
description: Scott Simpson, faced with the pressures of a head-to-head struggle with Tom Watson over the treacherous final holes of The Olympic Club Lake Course today, birdied three holes in a row and saved par from a bunker at No. 17 to win the 87th United States Open championship by one stroke over Watson.

title: By Walter Goodman
description: CLOSE QUARTERS by William Golding. 281 pages. Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $16.95.

title: RISE TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said the latest quarter's loss reflects expanding marketing, sales and customer support activities in connection with its recently developed computer-aided publishing system, as well as $99,000 of interest expense. The company completed its initial public offering in April 1987.

title: MOTIVES OF JUDAISM'S CONVERTS
description: A strong desire to please a spouse is a major motivating factor in conversions from Christianity to Judaism, according to a recent study sponsored by the American Jewish Committee in New York.

title: Turning a Phrase
description: Today, James Earl Jones, winner of this year's Tony Award for best actor in a play for his work in ''Fences,'' will read poetry by August Wilson. Mr. Wilson also won a Tony for writing ''Fences,'' the story of how one father sternly nurtures his son. Reading her own poetry will be the poet and playwright who wrote ''For Colored Girls Who Have Considered Suicide/When the Rainbow Is Enuf,'' Ntozake Shange. Esther Rolle is to be the host in Theater Four at 424 West 55th Street at 7:30 P.M.

title: KENNETH B. WEINER MARRIES ELIZABETH RAPOPORT, EDITOR
description: Elizabeth Rapoport, an editor at Charles Scribner's Sons, and Kenneth Benson Weiner, the vice president of the Beacon Press, were married yesterday at the Wainwright House in Rye, N.Y., by Cantor Raymond Smolover.

title: STREET STUDY CITES NEED FOR VAST REPAIRS
description: There are 68,000 blocks in the bumpy city and half of them are candidates for repaving or rebuilding, according to the first comprehensive survey of the state of New York City's streets.

description: Japanese semiconductor companies are expected to increase their output of computer memory chips by 10 percent in the next quarter to head off a potential shortage, according to industry analysts.

title: Approaches on Angola
description: Angola and the United States are exploring the prospects for improved relations, although no breakthrough is expected on the American demand for the withdrawal of the nearly 30,000 Cuban troops from Angola. Nor does it seem likely that the United States will extend diplomatic recognition to the Angolan Government; the Reagan Administration reportedly plans to continue covert aid to Unita, the rebel group trying to overthrow the Luanda Government.

title: Tough Korean Dilemma
description: The violent crisis in South Korea goes on. It will leave more bitter scars in a country that has many resentments to cherish, and whatever the U.S. does now, anti-American feelings are stoked.

title: KOREANS FIND A DAILY RITUAL IN THE PROTEST
description: A father hoists his little girl on his shoulder, after carefully affixing a surgical mask to her face. People line the sidewalks as if waiting for a parade. From far away sound the first faint choruses of protest songs. The riot policemen straighten up from their afternoon rest and put on their Darth Vader helmets. Soon, the protest will begin. For all the spontaneous turmoil on the streets of this and other cities in the last 12 days, the anti-Government protests have assumed something of a ritual air. They have come to seem so commonplace that people have built their days around them. Opposition Stronghold

Coffin of Princeton, N.J., to Hershel Yellin Allerhand, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Allerhand of Brooklyn. Rabbi Emanuel Rackman officiated.

description: Twenty-five black men began patrolling the New York City subway system yesterday in an effort to curtail crime that they believe disproportionately affects the black community.

description: Of the many sailing regattas held in the United States each year, few have the correct proportions of work and play. Either there are too many hotshots, or too many part-time sailors; too many protests, or too much frivolity. A notable exception has been Block Island Race Week.

description: The Coast Guard said yesterday that it has abandoned its search for the body of a Manhattan man missing from a boating accident in Long Island Sound Saturday afternoon. A second man who was on the boat when the accident occurred was recovering in a Long Island hospital last night.

description: The average earnings of retail and institutional stockbrokers soared last year, according to a survey by the Securities Industry Association, a trade group.

title: MORE QUESTIONS THAN ANSWERS FOR NAVRATILOVA
description: DOUBTS have replaced the confidence that made Martina Navratilova appear arrogant at times, a trait typical of a champion. Shots that were stroked with an air of finality now inexplicably stray into the net or land at points unknown. There are angry swipes at the ground with her racquet - an effort, perhaps, to exorcise the gremlins in her game, and an occasional plaintive look in the direction of the stands, where the members of her entourage sit like mannequins, equally puzzled by her unforeseen decline.

description: Tom Seaver, convinced that he cannot pitch with the old command at the age of 42 after a nine-month layoff, will appear in Shea Stadium at noon today to announce the end of his three-week comeback and his 20-year career.

title: Advertising; National Geographic, Conde Nast Go to Court
description: The National Geographic Society went into Federal Court here last week to try to prevent Conde Nast from publishing a magazine named Conde Nast Traveler, since a National Geographic Traveler began publication in March as a quarterly.

title: SUSAN FISHER IS BRIDE OF JUDAH LEE PLOTNER
description: Susan Abby Fisher, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Everett Fisher of Westport, Conn., and Judah Lee Plotner, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome Plotner of Jamaica, Queens, were married yesterday. Rabbi Paul Joseph performed the ceremony at Le Chateau in South Salem, N.Y.

title: Catching Up
description: * It took almost a week of round-the-clock negotiations to do it, but when Mayor Koch, the City Council and the Board of Estimate completed their annual financial negotiations last week, among the items in New York City's $3.1 billion capital budget for the next fiscal year was $5.5 million for construction of a 25-meter swimming pool at Fort Hamilton High School in Brooklyn. The pool, a brainchild of the Fort Hamilton swimming coach, Tom Greene, who waged a 12-year lobbying effort to get it, will be the first metric-measure pool in the city's school system.

title: DEMOCRATS IN RACE FOR '88 ARE FORCING ACCORD ON ISSUES

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: If the Dodgers were to turn things around and go on to win the World Series this fall, following the Lakers' winning the National Basketball Association title this spring, would Los Angeles become the first city to have the champions in baseball and basketball in the same calendar year?

title: Submarined by Japan and Norway
description: Western security has been undercut by the avarice of two companies, Toshiba of Japan and Kongsberg Vaapenfabrikk of Norway, and by their Governments' lackadaisical supervision of militarily sensitive exports. Under false pretenses, the companies shipped machinery to the Soviet Union that will enable the Russians to fabricate quieter submarine propellers. Soviet submarines will now become much harder to detect, all so that Toshiba and Kongsberg could turn some extra profit.

title: SIMPSON SEIZES SPOTLIGHT
description: For the last several years, Scott Simpson has labored quietly on the fringe of pro golf's upper echelon. He is often in contention, and he rarely stumbles out of it. He says he would like to achieve many great victories, but his top priority is making a living.

title: FOR CITY CAMBODIANS, IT'S WEDDING TIME
description: Dressed in a traditional Cambodian robe, Meas Lim sat cross-legged on a straw mat as dawn crept into an apartment in the East Bronx on Saturday. Having just been blessed by a Buddhist priest, Mr. Meas waited to go downstairs to be married.

title: HOPE, TOO, IS TRANSIENT IN A CAMP FOR HOMELESS
description: A desolate and dusty field near downtown Los Angeles, transformed into a city-run campground for those with nowhere else to go, is a symbol of the problem that gave Los Angeles County the title of homeless capital of the nation.

title: BURKS'S HOMER OFF TEWKSBURY LIFTS RED SOX, 4-2

title: KATHLEEN STREETT BECOMES A BRIDE

Streett Jr. of Ithaca, was married to Eric Joseph Werblow, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick M. Werblow of Scarsdale, N.Y. Rabbi Philip Aronson performed the ceremony.

title: COLEMAN'S HITTING LIFTS THE CARDINALS
description: Vince Coleman said it was no accident that his batting average is 46 points higher this season than it was at the same time last year.

title: 'I Thought It Was In'
description: OUT in the long shadows of Olympic's 17th fairway, Tom Watson peered up at the green. Scott Simpson was hunched over an 8-foot putt for the par 4 to retain his one-stroke lead that would be the difference in the 87th United States Open golf championship. And now, as the gallery around the green cheered Simpson's par, Watson turned to his caddie, Bruce Edwards.

title: CHARLES M. DAVIS AND JAN PHILLIPS ARE WED ON L.I.
description: The marriage of Jan Leslie Phillips, the daughter of Mrs. Donald H. Kallman and Howard W. Phillips, both of New York and East Hampton, L.I., to Charles Michael Davis, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joel Davis of Westport, Conn., took place yesterday at Mulford Farm on the grounds of the East Hampton Historical Society. Rabbi Daniel Wolk performed the ceremony.

title: Europe After NATO
description: The George M. Cohan phase of American foreign policy is ending. ''Send the word, send the word over there,'' went his World War I lyric, concluding ''and we won't come back till it's over, over there.''

title: Advocate Cites Housing Needs Of AIDS Victims
description: A leading advocate for the homeless is appealing to New York City and state officials to create thousands of units of housing for people with AIDS and to enact legislation barring hospitals from discharging AIDS patients without a suitable place to live.

description: To the Editor:

title: Barcelona Toll Rises to 17
description: The death toll in the bomb blast Friday at a Barcelona supermarket rose to 17 today, and tens of thousands of people demonstrated in the Catalan city against Basque separatist guerrillas, who were blamed for the explosion.

title: Jazz Festival; OSCAR PETERSON AND FRIENDS
description: OSCAR PETERSON, who was to perform solo at Carnegie Hall on Saturday evening, surprised everyone by arriving onstage with three other musicians, including the guitarist Joe Pass, the bassist David Young and the drummer Martin Drew.

description: Lebanon's Minister of Justice said today that he would join the search for a kidnapped American journalist and his Lebanese host.

description: SAATCHI & SAATCHI'S long-awaited merger of its Saatchi & Saatchi Compton and its DFS Dorland Worldwide, which will create the largest agency in New York, will be formally announced today by the British holding company.

title: 3 Note Auctions Planned for Week
description: The Treasury's three-part note financing totaling $24.25 billion will dominate the credit markets this week.

title: German Economy Recovers
description: West Germany's normally buoyant economy has begun to pick up after a rare sluggish period at the start of the year, the Bundesbank said.

title: EASTERN HIGH'S DAILY ASSAULT ON FAILURE
description: At Eastern District High School in Brooklyn, failure is common. The dropout rate, by some measures, is as high as 80 percent, among the worst in New York City. Each day, teachers, administrators and students struggle with inadequate resources and the legacies of urban poverty: drugs, crime, teen-age pregnancy, broken homes, alienation, despair.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Rowing Harvard Prevails: In fierce crosswinds, Harvard's varsity eight skimmed an 1,800-meter course in 5 minutes 34 seconds yesterday to take the Royal Victoria Boat Race in Victoria, British Columbia. Harvard finished three seconds ahead of the University of London. Yale was third in 5:39.20, followed by Vancouver Rowing Club (5:39.54), University of Victoria (5:39.70) and Wisconsin (5:44.66). Vancouver Rowing Club's women's eight finished first in a four-team field in 6:13.6 for 1,800 meters. Victoria was second in 6:16.4 and Wisconsin third in 6:24.1. (AP) Tennis Evernden Takes Title: Kelly Evernden of New Zealand won his first Grand Prix title, beating Tim Wilkison, 6-4, 7-6, in the rain-delayed final of the Bristol Trophy grass-court championships in Bristol, England. The unseeded Evernden, 25, won in 1 hour 37 minutes.(AP) Running Smith Wins: Anthony Smith of Rye, N.Y., won the four-mile Father's Day run sponsored by the New York Road Runners Club in Central Park yesterday. His time was 19 minutes 22 seconds. Ted Sinclair of Walden, N.Y., was the runner-up in 19:47, followed by Kevin Sullivan of Super Runners in 20:12. Candace Meighan of the Central Park Track Club won the women's event in 28:55. (AP) Cycling Clark Is First: Danny Clark of Australia, a former Olympic cyclist, nipped Gary Coltman of England, to win the 15th annual Skyscraper Harlem Cycling Classic feature professional Category 1 race. Clark set a Classic record, finishing the 35-mile race in 54 minutes 48.9 seconds to win the $2,500 first prize. Roberto Gaggioli of Italy placed third. Barbara Gradley of Westwood, N.J., was first in the women's division. Linda Shutt of East Chester, N.Y., placed second and Jessica Grieco of Emerson, N.J., was third. Dog Show Keeshond Is Best: Vandy's Malik, a keeshond who will be a year old in two weeks, was named as best of 1,277 dogs in the 49th annual show of the Staten Island Kennel Club at Fort Wadsworth. The pup, owned by Cynthia Turnbull and Carole Henry of Old Chatham, N.Y., defeated Carl and Hilary Tunick's mastiff, Ch. Deer Run William The Conqueror, which has won several best-in-show awards.

title: Election Necessitates Runoff For Cherokee Nation Post
description: Wilma Mankiller, the first woman chief of the Cherokee Indian tribe, has been forced into a runoff in her attempt to win a four-year term as head of the 72,000-member Cherokee Nation in Oklahoma.

title: WERNER ENTERPRISES reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
What Tennis Players Want
description: New York City's Parks Department wants to replace Central Park's old tennis house with a new structure that includes lockers, showers, a verandah and a computer to assure equity in court assignments. ''We don't want the new house,'' say some increasingly excited park players. They demand protection for three wild cherry trees that would be chopped down to make room for it, and insist the present house is more suitably located, farther from the 96th Street transverse. Their complaints are disingenuous.

title: IN EUROPE, IT'S SUPER BOWL FRENCH STYLE
description: Le quarterback backpedaled, turned and tried to hand off le ballon to un running, unaware that le cornerback was coming fast. ''Attention au blitz,'' part of the crowd screamed, but it was too late and le quarterback was flat on the ground, sacke.

title: Suns Deal Bedford And Ed Pinckney
description: The Phoenix Suns gave up their 1985 and 1986 first-round draft choices last night, a few hours before the National Basketball Association trading deadline. They swapped 7-foot William Bedford, their top 1986 pick, for the Detroit Pistons' 1989 first-round choice. Then, the Suns dealt Ed Pinckney and their second pick in 1988 to Sacramento for 6-8 Eddie Johnson.

description: International A2-11, B10

title:
WHO WILL PAY FOR AIDS, AND HOW?;
NOT JUST THE INSURANCE COMPANIES
description: LEAD: The debate about who will pay for AIDS presupposes that the proper answer is somehow different from the answer to the questions ''Who will pay for cancer?'' or ''Who will pay for heart disease?'' But nothing about AIDS significantly alters the terms of our nation's long-running debate over the financing of health care.

description: Gov. Bill Clements of Texas signed into law Saturday a bill making it a civil offense to violate rules of the National Collegiate Athletic Association and holding those found in violation to be liable for monetary damages suffered by a school as a result of sanctions.

description: The five permanent members of the United Nations Security Council have agreed on a resolution calling for a cease-fire in the Iran-Iraq war, the Under Secretary of State for Political Affairs, Michael H. Armacost, said today.

description: AN idea once characterized by a Reagan Administration official as ''the looniest idea since Looney Tunes came on the screen'' is beginning to take hold in state legislatures.

title: Judge Closes Court for Case Of Woman With AIDS Virus
description: A local judge ordered his courtroom closed on Friday for the arraignment of a woman, charged with prostitution, who was diagnosed as having AIDS-related complex, a less severe form of the deadly disease.
