description: Debt

title: Revlon Officer Retiring
description: Robert W. Armstrong, the chairman of a Revlon subsidiary responsible for establishing Revlon in developing markets such as the Soviet Union, China and India, will retire after more than 25 years at the company, Revlon officials said. Mr. Armstrong, who heads the Revlon Development Corporation, will step down at the end of June and open a consulting firm specializing in international trade and marketing.

title: 18,000 Take Part in Protest Around U.S. Base in Okinawa
description: More than 18,000 demonstrators formed a human chain 10.4 miles long around the Kadena United States Air Base on Okinawa to protest the presence of American military bases in Japan, the police said.

title: BECKER'S FIRST STEP MAY BE HARDEST
description: The first day of Wimbledon revolves around the defending men's champion, but Boris Becker most likely will not be able to spend Monday afternoon basking in the glory of last year's victory.

title: BAD TIMES ARE BOON TO RIO GRANDE WILDLIFE PLAN
description: Once this was the heart of one of the most diverse wildlife areas in the nation, a teeming subtropical landscape of tidal flats, thorn and palm forests, brush land and river woodlands that supported an extraordinary variety of plant and animal life.

title: WHEN A CHILL BRINGS A SMILE
description: New York and Los Angeles have a reputation for hucksterism. Washington, by contrast, is supposed to be the city of solemnity.

title: MUSIC: OPENING NIGHT AT WATERLOO FESTIVAL
description: The Waterloo Festival -which lies at the end of a short drive into the New Jersey countryside - looks more attractive than ever. With its first full orchestra concert of the season tonight, there were added amenities. Indeed, one returns every June to this 10-year-old venture at Waterloo Village pleased by the improvements. Flowers have been planted along walkways. An attractive brick patio surrounds an equally attractive buffet and dining room. Picnickers are being looked after more assiduously, and there is even even a spacious new access road. Surrounding all is a soft greenery that frames and accents this combination park, historic site and performing space.

title: Bonn Decision to Try T.W.A. Suspect Is Seen
description: The West German Government is expected to announce this week that it will try a man suspected of hijacking a Trans World Airlines jetliner and not extradite him to the United States, according to reports in West German newspapers.

title: CROWS AND THE SENSORS WATCH OVER DEAD CITY
description: Silence and sand cover the abandoned acres of Pripyat.

title: Ford Record Set in Europe
description: The Ford Motor Company said Friday that it had sold a record 643,000 cars in Europe in the first five months of the year, up 8.6 percent from the corresponding period last year. Philip E. Benton Jr., executive vice president for international automotive operations, said Ford captured a larger slice of a larger market, with a 12 percent market share, up three-tenths of a percentage point from last year. He said the European industry was selling at an annual rate of 11.6 million, compared with a rate of 10.9 million a year in the 1986 period.

title: Jazz Festival; CHICK COREA AND CRUSADERS
description: THE Chick Corea Electric Band's Jazz Festival performance at Avery Fisher Hall on Saturday suggested that technology, which is supposed to be making a broader range of sounds available to the plugged-in musician, is actually circumscribing the music's sonic boundaries. The sounds coming from Mr. Corea's quintet were superficially diverse, but fundamentally there were only two - the brisk, busy percussive textures of Dave Weckl's drum kit, and the glitzy, detergent-scrubbed sheen of the electronics. Mr. Corea's massed keyboards, the guitar, even the electric bass all tinkled tinnily, making a sound without richness, without depth, a sound only a microchip could truly love.

title: Bond Prices Regain Stability
description: The bond markets stabilized last week, but the shock from the sharp rise in interest rates during April and May still lingers, keeping long-term bond yields about a percentage point above first-quarter levels.

title:
WHO WILL PAY FOR AIDS, AND HOW?;
ALL OF SOCIETY
description: LEAD: It's obvious that AIDS is going to cost our society a lot of money. Who will pay, and how? Two things seem clear. First, we must put the true costs in perspective. Second, we must begin to think about new kinds of public-private partnerships to spread the financial risk - partnerships that will inevitably involve a creative response from the insurance industry.

title: Burton Sells Big Shoe Chain
description: Wylycollection Inc., a retail holding company, has acquired Delman/I. Miller, the largest, high-fashion chain of shoe stores in the United States, from the Burton Group P.L.C., a British company that has owned the American shoe retailer for a number of years. Terms were not disclosed. Delman/I. Miller operates a total of 49 shoe stores and leased shoe departments, including the flagship store on 57th Street and Fifth Avenue in Manhattan and six Rayne-Delman/I. Miller salons. The chain's annual sales are more than $50 million. Under the new ownership, Delman/I. Miller will continue to be headquartered in New York. It will be headed by Lawrence Gore, who has been associated with the Wylycollection in acquisition activity, as president and chief executive officer. Mr. Gore is a former vice president and general manager of Neiman-Marcus in Chicago. Edward Rayne remains chairman of Delman/I. Miller. Wylycollection is headed by Sam Wyly, a Dallas computer entrepreneur who in 1981 founded Sterling Software, one of the nation's largest software makers. Mr. Wyly is chairman and controlling shareholder of Michael's stores and USACafes, two public companies.

title: Jazz Festival; BRACKEEN, PIANIST
description: JOANNE BRACKEEN brings a well-developed sense of compositional form to the normally opened-ended field of solo jazz piano improvisation. In her performance at Weill Recital Hall on Saturday evening, the pianist took pop standards like ''Emily'' and ''Darn That Dream'' and framed their original melodies in structured inventions that hewed to the songs' harmonic formats, yet also had an independent life of their own.

title: Brooklyn Woman Is Wounded While Waiting at Traffic Light
description: A 21-year-old woman was seriously wounded when she was struck in the neck by a bullet while sitting in a car waiting for a traffic light to change at Linden Boulevard and Kings Highway in the East New York section of Brooklyn, the police said.

title: ADVERTISER BOYCOTT OF FLORIDA GROWS
description: National advertising agencies, manufacturers and publishers are canceling sales conventions and meetings in Florida to protest the state's new 5 percent sales tax on professional sales and services. The tax goes into effect July 1.

title: TUNISIA, ACCUSING IRAN, CRACKS DOWN ON DISSENT
description: Faced with a surge of fundamentalist dissent, the Tunisian Government has been charging that ''Khomeini-ist'' insurgents, backed by Iran, are plotting its violent overthrow in pursuit of Teheran's threats to export Islamic revolution.

title: John Magee, 86, Dies; Stock Market Analyst
description: John Magee, a leading practitioner and popularizer of technical analysis of stock prices, died of heart failure last Monday at Mercy Hospital in Springfield, Mass. He was 86 years old and lived in Springfield.

title: SPURS WAIT FOR THEIR ENSIGN TO COME IN
description: In the normal scenario, the lines of success-starved basketball fans that circled San Antonio's HemisFair Arena on the day after the National Basketball Association's draft lottery in May would have dissipated by now. But telephones in the offices of the San Antonio Spurs would still be ringing, at a slower but still steady pace. And Bruce Guthrie would not have a care in the world.

title: MOZAMBIQUE REBELS SAID TO RAID A ZIMBABWE VILLAGE, KILLING 11
description: Rebels of the Mozambique National Resistance attacked a small village in far northeastern Zimbabwe Saturday night, killing 11 villagers and leaving pamphlets warning that there would be further attacks, witnesses said today.

title: WALDEN SCHOOL, AT 73, FILES FOR BANKRUPTCY
description: The Walden School, for 73 years an innovator in progressive unconventional education, said yesterday that it had sought permission to reorganize under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code.

title: LEAD-TAINTED SOIL TO BE REMOVED IN BOSTON
description: A major attack on lead poisoning of children will begin here this summer with the removal of topsoil from around houses that were once covered with leaded paint, city and Federal officials announced today.

title: NETS PICK HOPSON; BIG PLANS FOR OHIO STAR
description: It was only two seasons ago that the Nets possessed one of the league's most admired backcourts. Micheal Ray Richardson was at his peak. Otis Birdsong was healthy. And Kelvin Ransey and Darwin Cook were capable reserves with the talent to play more prominent roles on other teams. But that was before troubles - including Richardson's drug use, contract disputes and injuries - created a revolving door of mediocre guards that was among the reasons for the team's recent woes.

title: U.N. AIDES DUBIOUS ON A GULF ACCORD
description: A draft Security Council resolution calling for an Iran-Iraq cease-fire, which was praised Sunday by a State Department official, basically repeats earlier Council statements and would lack impact without sanctions, United Nations officials said today.

description: There is an old saying at the Bureau of the Census: ''Change the method, change the count.''

description: Researchers at the University of Georgia have obtained the remains of the last pure dusky sparrow and intend to use them for a genetics study, according to Professor John Avise of the school's Department of Genetics.

title: Commodities Lift Bond Prices
description: Bond prices moved higher yesterday in light trading, propelled by a firmer dollar and a sharp decline in commodity prices.

title: POLLEN AND SPORES FORCE CHANGES IN TIMETABLE OF THE CONTINENTS
description: POLLEN grains and spores that settled in valleys more than 200 million years ago are reshaping scientists' views of the process that led to the breakup of the continents, separating Europe, Africa and North and South America.

title: BOYD WINS IN SEASON DEBUT
description: Dennis (Oil Can) Boyd allowed two runs and five hits in his season debut and Wade Boggs extended his hitting streak to 23 games tonight, helping Boston win a 5-2 victory over Milwaukee in a game that was called after seven innings because of rain.

description: The Economy

title: McCammon to Canucks
description: The Vancouver Canucks named Bob McCammon, a former coach and general manager of the Philadelphia Flyers, as their new head coach yesterday. McCammon, who was given a long-term contract, replaces Tom Watt, who coached the Canucks for the last two seasons. The Vancouver president and general manager, Pat Quinn, said Watt had been offered a job as assistant to the general manager. McCammon became available to the Canucks when his contract with the Stanley Cup champion Edmonton Oilers expired this month. He spent two years in the Edmonton organization, the first as an assistant coach and the second as director of player development. McCammon coached the Flyers for 50 games during the 1978-79 season, was replaced by Quinn, then returned to the club for the last eight games of the 1981-82 season. He was both coach and general manager of the Flyers for the next two seasons. The Canucks finished last in the Smythe Division last season and had a 29-43-8 record.

description: Regulations for fireworks technicians in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut vary widely.

title: Cenergy Sale
description: The Cenergy Corporation, an energy exploration and development company in Dallas, said it had agreed to be purchased by the Conquest Exploration Company of Houston for about $100 million in cash and securities. The merger requires approval of shareholders. Under the agreement, Cenergy stockholders will receive $3 in cash and between 1.15 and 1.7 shares of Conquest common stock, valued at $7.50, for each Cenergy common share owned. Snyder Operating Partnership L.P., a Fort Worth-based energy concern, and Bryson Oil and Gas P.L.C., based in Belfast, would receive notes valued at $17.9 million and $16.5 million in cash, respectively. The two companies, which had made their own bid for Cenergy, own approximately 37.9 percent of Cenergy's 9.75 million common shares outstanding.

description: McCAFFREY & McCALL has formed a McCaffrey & McCall Entertainment unit that will mainly serve the needs of United Artists.

description: Hoping to increase revenue from office products, American Brands Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire an office supplies company, the ACCO World Corporation, for $602 million in cash.

title: RESEARCH IN SPACE FALLS FURTHER BEHIND, AND SCIENTISTS ARE ALARMED
description: WITH so many spacecraft grounded indefinitely by the Challenger disaster and support for future programs uncertain, American scientists are growing increasingly frustrated and angry over their diminishing prospects for space research and exploration.

title: Canada Bank Ends Wood Gundy Talks
description: The Royal Bank of Canada, the nation's largest bank, said it had ended merger talks with the Canadian securities dealer Wood Gundy Inc. Royal Bank, which has assets of almost $100 billion Canadian ($75 billion United States), said that after several months of talks it had ''determined that an agreement between the two parties is not achievable.''

title: JACKSON URGES SUPPORT FOR 'SPECIAL INTEREST'
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson urged a group of conservative and centrist Democrats today to reject the notion that the party's problems were caused by its ''special interest'' groups.

title: A SHIFT IN DIRECTION AT PROCTOR
description: The decision by the Procter & Gamble Company to write off a good deal of its investment in the cookie business, part of an $800 million restructuring announced earlier this month, represents a dramatic shift in management style for one of America's most conservative corporations.

title: Jericho Might Become Local Stop on Golf Tour
description: The future of the Northville Invitational golf tournament for seniors is uncertain, despite the success of its first edition.

description: Union Carbide Corporation investigators, nearing the end of a 16-month inquiry, say they have found new witnesses, documents and scientific evidence proving that the 1984 Bhopal toxic gas disaster was caused by sabotage by a company employee.

The latest quarter includes only one month of the operations of Conrac Corp., acquired May 1, and that continued gains from other businesses contributed substantially to the quarter. The share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid Jan. 30.

title: Invitation Rescinded
description: For 20 years the National Science Foundation has sponsored the Joint Oceanographic Institutions for Deep Earth Sampling, undersea research in which nations like Britain, France and Japan have joined. The foundation contributes $40 million a year and the other countries $2.5 million each. Two years ago, after approval by the State and Defense Departments and the White House, the foundation invited the Soviet Union to join.

title: A Driving Desire
description: Like others who have made it big in show business, Christopher Cross, the singer-songwriter, celebrated his five Grammy awards a few years ago by buying an expensive car - in his case, a Porsche 911.

title: U.S. SOFTENS STANCE ON HIJACKING TRIAL
description: President Reagan said today that he would be satisfied to see Mohammed Ali Hamadei, the suspected Lebanese jet hijacker, stand trial for murder ''wherever he is tried.''

title: Loss Poses a Challenge To Aca Joe Executives
description: Joseph Rank, a Los Angeles clothing designer, originated the Aca Joe line in Acapulco in the 1970's. American tourists waited in line to buy the cotton leisure clothing.

title: VICTIM'S LAW: NEW DEFINITION
description: The 1982 crime victims law cited yesterday in a novel judicial ruling in the ''pizza connection'' drug case has been used in the past, chiefly to compensate direct victims of specific crimes.

title: AT GOLF'S SUMMIT, A NEW GROUP
description: Scott Simpson's victory over Tom Watson Sunday in the 87th United States Open marked the third straight major tournament in which one of the world's leading golfers was beaten by a less renowned pro. And in each case, the winning golfer was one who first had achieved recognition as a college star within the last decade.

title: 2 Mets Lead Ballots
description: The Mets' Gary Carter and Keith Hernandez hold slim leads for catcher and first baseman in the fan balloting for the National League All-Star team. Carter leads the catchers with a 28,000 vote margin over Jody Davis of Chicago, while Hernandez, had a 22,000 vote lead over the Cardinals' Jack Clark at first base. The Cincinnati Reds' Eric Davis, has extended his lead among National League outfielders. Davis has 718,737 votes, more than 140,000 votes ahead of the Mets' Darryl Strawberry.

title: Akzo Will Buy Stauffer Unit
description: Imperial Chemical Industries P.L.C. said today that it would sell the specialty chemicals part of its soon-to-be-acquired Stauffer Chemical Company to the Dutch chemical group Akzo N.V. for $625 million.

title: Imperial Trust Certificates
description: Imperial Savings and Loan Trust 1987-1, a unit of Imperial Savings and Loan of San Diego, yesterday began offering $100 million of certificates, due in 1992, through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc.

title: Tom Terrific
description: Tom Seaver started his big league pitching career 20 years ago as a New York Met. He played 10 superlative years for the team, leading it to two pennants and one world championship; he won the Cy Young pitching award three times.

title: ASTAIRE PERSONA: URBANITY AND GRACE
description: In much the same way that Evelyn Waugh's great comic novels blend together to form a single, brilliantly funny work, the individual films of Fred Astaire are not as important as the entire career they ultimately defined. Mr. Astaire never played down to the needs of even the tackiest librettos for his musical-comedy films. Instead, he threw himself into these playboy roles with such illusive elegance that their deficiencies never affected him.

title: NETS PICK HOPSON; EDMAN GUARD 18TH CHOICE
description: Even though their first two selections in the National Basketball Association draft were the 18th and 25th over all - when the most highly prized prospects were already gone - the Knicks yesterday insisted they were pleased with their acquisitions. Brendan Malone, a Knick assistant coach, said, ''We got just what we wanted: a point guard and a power forward.''

title: TREES OF INDUSTRIAL AGE
description: TREES are responding with surprising alacrity to the increase of carbon dioxide in the air, cutting back sharply on the microscopic pores that control the flow of water and gas in their leaves, a British botanist has found.

title: Advertising; Chief Creative Officer Out at Saatchi-DFS
description: Neither the newly created Saatchi & Saatchi DFS Compton nor Saatchi & Saatchi DFS Advertising, the new domestic holding company, is going to have a chief creative officer, so Robert H. Levenson, who had that post at Saatchi & Saatchi Compton, is considering other career options.

title: Scientists See Biotech Battle
description: A big shakeout among biotechnology companies is expected as the industry discovers how much time and money it takes to turn discoveries into commercial products. This was among forecasts by scientists at the fourth European Congress on Biotechnology here last week, attended by about 2,000 Western researchers.

title: Holders Fight Gillette Pact
description: Shareholders of the Gillette Company are trying to block it from enforcing a 10-year standstill agreement with the Revlon Group, a court clerk said yesterday.

title: MARKITSTAR INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: JAMAALADEEN TACUMA AND FRIENDS
description: JAMAALADEEN TACUMA, John Scofield and John Blake, whose bands performed at Town Hall on Sunday in a Jazz Festival concert sponsored by Gramavision Records, play varieties of ''fusion'' music, if that term still has meaning. Originally, fusion referred to jazz-based music with rock or pop influences, played on electronic instruments. These days there are so many approaches to electronic music, the term is too general to be of much use. And after all, it's the music, not the rubric, that counts.

title: VILLAGE'S CALM SPLINTERS OVER PAINTING
description: When Jasper Francis Cropsey painted ''A View at Hastings-on-Hudson'' almost a century ago, he depicted his hometown as a tranquil village basking in the golden light of an autumn day.

title: Yield Range 8.06-9.03% In Offerings by Unisys
description: In the corporate bond market yesterday, prices ran almost parallel with those of United State Government securities. Dealers noted that most of the activity seemed centered around intermediate-term issues, while longer-term issues drew little attention.

title: ALBANY NEARS A PACT TO END A SHORTAGE OF PRISON SPACE
description: State leaders said today that they agreed on most elements of a plan to avert a shortage of prison space, including the purchase of a British troop-barge for use as a 700-bed medium-security prison.

title: MICROPRO INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Net loss

title: JUDGE IMPOSES 99-YEAR TERMS IN SAN JUAN FIRE
description: The maintenance worker who set the hotel fire that killed 97 people here on New Year's Eve was sentenced to 99 years in prison today by a Federal judge who said Puerto Rico was ''fed up'' with violence.

title: Rhea Robinson, the Mother In 'Blood and Money' Family
description: Rhea Robinson, the mother of a socialite whose death was dramatized in the Tommy Thompson best seller ''Blood and Money,'' died in a hospital here Sunday. She was 86 years old.

title: U.S., MEXICO DIFFER ON TRADE
description: The United States and Mexico have begun negotiations on an agreement intended to set the tone for their broadening commercial relationship, but they find themselves with significant differences.

title: HIGH COURT BARS A WALL ST. APPEAL ON ROLE OF BANKS
description: The nation's banks won another battle today in their bitter competition with Wall Street as the Supreme Court left standing a ruling that permits the banks to help companies raise money through the sale of short-term debt.

title: CHESS: LARRY CHRISTIANSEN UNWRAPS A CLEVER PACKAGE OF TACTICS
description: The attitudes of organizers toward co-champions fluctuate from tolerance to tiebreak, but players generally favor a brief playoff match, especially if there are additional prizes for it.

title: Cards Extend Pacts
description: The St. Louis Cardinals announced yesterday that the contracts of Manager Whitey Herzog and General Manager Dal Maxvill have been extended. Herzog accepted a two-year extension that carries through the 1990 season and Maxvill was given a one-year extension thath runs through 1988. Financial terms were not disclosed.

title: AILING MANDLIKOVA DROPS OUT
description: Even though rain forced a postponment of play at Wimbledon today, one player has been eliminated. Hana Mandlikova of Czechoslovakia, seeded No. 4 and a finalist last year, withdrew because her injured right foot has not responded to treatment.

title: JUDGE ORDERS FOUR IN 'PIZZA' CASE TO CONTRIBUTE TO FUND FOR ADDICTS
description: Five men convicted as leaders of the ''pizza connection'' international drug ring were sentenced to long prison terms yesterday, and the judge, in what he called an unprecedented order, told four of the men to contribute $2.5 million to a fund for treatment of drug addicts.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: ''SHE makes me feel overdressed,'' Evelyn Lauder said as she watched Jacqueline Onassis arrive at the Metropolitan Opera House in a white crepe pants suit for the Paris Opera Ballet's opening night. Mrs. Onassis' understated outfit by Carolina Herrera seemed like a rebuke to Mrs. Lauder's flowered brioche-shaped dress by Scaasi.

title: SYRIAN JOINS EFFORT TO RELEASE THREE KIDNAPPED IN LEBANON
description: President Hafez al-Assad of Syria has assigned a senior officer here to intensify efforts to win the release of a kidnapped American journalist and two Lebanese seized with him.

title: HARCOURT GAINS IN DEBENTURE FIGHT
description: A Florida judge ruled yesterday that the bondholders of Harcourt Brace Jovanovich Inc. had the right to convert their debentures into common stock, but for far fewer shares than they hoped to receive.

title: Give Top Billing to Strategic Arms
description: Advocates and critics of America's current position in the talks on medium-range missiles have pretty well set out their arguments. Curiously, a more fundamental question - ''Why are we so preoccupied with intermediate-range nuclear forces in the first place'' -hasn't even been asked.

title: JOHNSON PRODUCTS CO reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-After tax credits of $184,000 for the quarter and $201,000 for the 9 months; the 9 months also included a gain of $104,000 from discontinued operations. c-Net loss and after a gain of $95,000 for the quarter and a loss of $493,000 for the 9 months, both from discontinued operations.

title: APPLIED CIRCUIT TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After net from discontinued operations of $1,183,969 and $1,335,951 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, and a tax credit of $565,950 for both the quarter and 6 months. c-Net loss and includes losses from discontinued operations of $1,392,672 and $2,886,818 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. The company said results reflect continuing operations of its Whiteworth-Towne Paulsen Inc. subsidiary from the March 21, 1986, acquisition date.

title: U.S. RELEASES AID FOR 63D ST. TUNNEL
description: The Federal Urban Mass Transportation Administration yesterday released $60 million for the completion of two long-delayed subway projects, the 63d Street tunnel under the East River and the Archer Avenue line in eastern Queens.

title: SHEARING AT THE PIANO
description: GEORGE SHEARING, who has long been a symbol of pianistic gentility, brought his elegant musical manners to Weill Recital Hall on Sunday evening in the third of the JVC Jazz Festival's early evening piano concerts.

title: CRISIS IS UNSETTLED DESPITE OVERTURES OFFERED IN SEOUL
description: President Chun Doo Hwan was reported today to have made important concessions to the opposition, but critical details remained vague, leaving the country's political crisis still unsettled.

title: Fare's Fair
description: The New York City Taxi Commission, having surrendered to higher fares, seems determined to be tough about one thing, a dress code for cab drivers. It would forbid drivers to wear tank tops, body suits, bathing suits and open-toed sandals. It's not yet clear whether a uniform will be required and, if so, what it would look like. A dress code on drivers would be welcome, yet would do no more to remedy serious taxi defects than imposing a dress code on slovenly passengers. What about a cleanliness code for taxi interiors? What about radios, turned up so high that drivers can barely hear the passenger announce the destination? What about drivers who can't, with or without radios, navigate the English language? What about drivers who, even if they speak English, can't navigate the city - or, if they can, refuse to go to places like central Brooklyn and the South Bronx?

title: Sound a Certain Trumpet for Seoul
description: Now more than ever, the United States needs to sound the call for peaceful transition to democracy in South Korea. That country has reached a pivotal moment. Its future is being settled in the streets by protesters and police, with the army ever-present in the background. Its leaders operate in a culture where compromise and restraint are not considered political virtues.

title: GROUP 1 SOFTWARE reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Marred Weekend
description: Although Pittsburgh took two out of the three games against the Cubs in Chicago over the weekend, the Pirates' manager, Jim Leyland, had mixed feelings. ''I used to say that if anybody robbed me, all they would get is experience,'' Leyland said. ''That's not true anymore. Somebody got $4,400.'' Leyland said he went to sleep in the Pirates' hotel Saturday night with $4,400 in cash in his wallet and when he woke up Sunday, the wallet was open on the floor and the money was gone.

title: Farewell, Sweet Pitcher
description: A woman named Pam working in a restaurant on Second Avenue said recently that she loved Tom Seaver so much in the fifth grade that the kids called her Mrs. Seaver.

title: Allegheny Sale
description: Allegheny International Inc. said it would sell its John Zink Company subsidiary to an affiliate of Lone Star Technologies Inc. of Dallas. Terms of the deal were not disclosed. John Zink, based in Tulsa, Okla., supplies combustion technology products and energy recovery equipment and services. It has about 775 employees in Oklahoma and in Luxembourg and West Germany.

title: EX-MARINE GUARD IN MOSCOW ACCUSED OF PERJURY
description: A former Marine guard at the United States Embassy in Moscow who was questioned by the Marine Corps during an investigation of two other marines in an espionage scandal was charged Monday with 11 counts of false statements and perjury.

title: HEALTHCARE COMPARE reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $60,000. c-Includes a tax credit of $75,000 for both the quarter and 9 months.

title: EASTGROUP PROPERTIES reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Includes gains on sales of investments of $655,000. c-Includes gains on sales of investments of $1,545,000 for the quarter and $1,922,000 for the 6 months.

title: Becor Western Gets 4th Bidder
description: Becor Western Inc., a mining equipment manufacturer, said today that it had received a $15-a-share bid from ICM Industries and the Bear Stearns Companies.

title: MARINES WILL DISCHARGE DESERTER WHO FLED VIETNAM 17 YEARS AGO
description: A Vietnam War deserter who surrendered after being at large for 17 years is being discharged from the Marine Corps ''for the good of the service'' instead of being court-martialed, the service said today.

title: DAVIS WATER & WASTE INDUSRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: Shares earnings and shares outstanding reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid last August and a 4-for-3 stock split paid in March.

title: Prefabricate Homes For Poor Families
description: To the Editor:

title: STARS GATHER IN TRIBUTE TO GEORGE ABBOTT AT 100
description: ''One hundred seems to be a very lucky number,'' said George Abbott last night. ''One of the great things is that everybody loves you.'' And indeed the entire theater world seemed to be expressing love for Mr. Abbott at a gala 100th-birthday party for the producer-director-writer-actor at Broadway's Palace Theater.

title: BRIDGE: SOME POLITICAL FIGURES HAVE EXCELLED AT CARDS
description: If one wished to identify the best bridge player of all time among statesman and major political figures, two names would come to mind. Sophocles Venizelos was a member of the French team that in 1935 lost to the United States in the first world championship match, and later became Prime Minister of his native Greece.

title: BANKS GEAR UP TO PLACE PAPER
description: Buoyed by yesterday's Supreme Court action, several leading bankers said their institutions were ready to strengthen their efforts in placing commercial paper.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the Palace Theater described its ownership incompletely. The theater is owned and managed by the Nederlander Organization and Stewart F. Lane.

title: McHale Has Surgery
description: Kevin McHale, the Boston Celtics' star forward, underwent surgery yesterday on his right foot and ankle. Jan Volk, the Celtics' general manager, said that McHale, who played on a broken foot for the last three months of the season, is likely to be ready for the start of next season ''or be very close.'' But Volk said that Bill Walton, Boston's backup center, probably would have an operation that would sideline him all next season. The Celtics said McHale's lower leg and foot would be in a cast for eight to 12 weeks. McHale had bone spurs removed from his right ankle and a screw inserted in the broken navicular bone of his right foot. He was injured March 11 in a game against Phoenix when a Suns player stepped on his foot and he pulled it away. McHale played in 77 regular-season games and was sixth in the league with a 26.1-point scoring average. He led the league with a .604 field-goal percentage and was seventh in blocked shots. In the final playoff series against the Los Angeles Lakers, he played in all six games and averaged 20.5 points and nine rebounds per game. Walton, who also has a broken bone in his right foot, played in just 10 regular-season games and saw action sparingly in the playoffs. Volk said he thought Walton probably would choose radical surgery that would enable him to play on a stronger right foot after missing next season rather than less severe treatment that might let him play next season, but wouldn't strengthen the foot as much.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE EMBARRASSMENT OF RICHES:

title: Bear, Stearns Has Stake in Caremark
description: Bear, Stearns & Company and clients disclosed in a Securities and Exchange Commission filing that they hold a 5.16 percent stake in Caremark Inc. Bear, Stearns said it acquired the Caremark stock ''as an investment in the ordinary course of its business as a broker-dealer.''

title: Accord Is Reached on Terms for North Testimony
description: Congressional leaders and Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North's lawyer reached an understanding today that apparently insures that Colonel North will testify next month before the committees investigating the Iran-contra affair.

title: Europe Fights U.S. Trade Bill
description: Willy De Clercq, the Economic Community's foreign trade commissioner, will visit Washington July 6-9 to lobby against omnibus trade legislation in Congress.

title: IN MEMORY, PEOPLE RECREATE THEIR LOVES TO SUIT THEIR IMAGES OF THE PRESENT
description: SCIENTIFIC inquiry into personal memory is revealing the forces that create, distort and sometimes erase the images that constitute each person's autobiography.

title: City to Review Cityspire Tower For Second Time
description: ''Taller than any other ultra-condominium in the city,'' the advertisement purrs, ''Cityspire soars gracefully skyward.''

title: Shelton Jones Injured
description: Shelton Jones, a 6-foot-9-inch forward for St. John's, has been admitted to a hospital for treatment of a detached retina, sources close to the team said yesterday. Jones, who will enter his senior year next season, apparently suffered retina damage while playing for an all-star team that toured Europe this spring. It was not immediately known whether Jones would require surgery. School sources report that an announcement will be made on the status of Jones's eye later this week.

title: U.S. Effort to Stop Whaling For Research Brings Protest
description: The United States moved today to stop commercial whaling that might be carried out under the guise of scientific research, provoking immediate protests from Iceland, Japan and Norway.

title: Common Market Duties
description: The European Community today extended its anti-dumping duties on imports from East Asia to imported parts of products made and assembled within the community. The measure, approved by the European Community's foreign ministers, capped months of lobbying by European manufacturers. They argued that Japanese and South Korean companies avoided anti-dumping duties by assembling their products in such low-cost community nations as Portugal, Greece and Ireland.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of a production error, a dispatch yesterday from Pusan, South Korea, on anti-Government protests was incomplete in some copies. Readers wishing copies of the complete article may write to Production Quality Control, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036.

title: Air Canada Deal
description: Air Canada has agreed to buy four Boeing 767-200ER jets worth about $220 million, the Boeing Commercial Airplane Company announced. Air Canada also said it was considering options for six more 767's. The Canadian carrier currently operates 14 767's, two of the extended-range variety. The 767-200ER can carry 169 passengers in three classes.

title: Business and Health; Doctors Invest In Office Tests
description: DOCTORS will spend several hundred million dollars this year on sophisticated diagnostic equipment and supplies to test patients in the office and provide them with the results before they leave. But this market, relatively new and growing rapidly, is still largely uncharted.

title: THE MODERN JAZZ QUARTET
description: THE featured attraction of the Modern Jazz Quartet's concert Sunday evening at Carnegie Hall was a set of music by its pianist, John Lewis, performed by the quartet and the New York Chamber Symphony. But the concert didn't perk up until its second half, when the quartet played alone.

title: Deuterium in Meteorite
description: Analysis of amino acids from the meteorite that landed in Murchison, Australia, in 1969 has shown them to be markedly enriched in deuterium in a manner typical of the interstellar environment. The finding gives new support to the theory that chemical building blocks of life were delivered to this planet from far out in space.

title: DANCE: 'HE/SHE: LOVE, SEX AND GENDER'
description: CHOREOGRAPHERS are back to sex, Joan Acocella writes in program notes to the ''He/She: Love, Sex and Gender'' festival at P.S. 1 in Long Island City, Queens. Dance is inextricably involved with sex and gender, whether consciously or by implication, but gender differences were one of the theatrical elements discarded by the postmodernists of the 1960's. Today, however, many choreographers are involved in a politicized exploration of gender and sexuality, as Ms. Acocella, curator of the festival with Valda Setterfield, observes.

title: LOSS BY MOSES BRINGS A SENSE OF RELIEF
description: Myrella Moses remembers the morning of June 4. ''I opened the door to get the paper,'' she said. ''A neighbor was picking up his paper at the same time. He said, 'When's Edwin coming home?' I said, 'He's running today.' He said: 'Oh, he's going to win. He always does.' The neighbor didn't even pick up his head. Everyone always assumed Edwin would always win.''

title: ALZA FOUNDER QUITS CHIEF EXECUTIVE JOB
description: The Alza Corporation, which makes delivery systems for the timed release of medication, said yesterday that its founder, Alejandro Zaffaroni, would step down as chief executive.

title: Retail Chain's Stock Declines
description: Shares of the Dayton Hudson Corporation fell $2.50, to $54 a share, yesterday on skepticism that the Dart Group would be able to make a merger offer.

title: Bertram Bloch Is Dead; Wrote 'Dark Victory'
description: Bertram Bloch, a playwright, novelist and Hollywood story editor, died of heart disease Friday at New York Hospital, according to his wife, Susanne Suba. He was 95 years old.

title: CONCERT: JEWISH CHORALE
description: What is held among Jews as the 20th anniversary of Jerusalem's reunification has been cause for general celebrations this year. A particular one was Sunday evening's concert by the National Jewish Chorale at Alice Tully Hall.

title: CHIRON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Martin Marietta Offers Notes at Par
description: The Martin Marietta Corporation is offering $100 million of 9 1/4 percent notes, due in 1997, at par, through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: SENATORS, IN GENEVA, CAUTION RUSSIANS ON MISSILE PROPOSAL
description: A group of United States senators said here today that the insistence of the Soviet Union on retaining part of its medium-range nuclear arsenal could impede Senate approval of any accord on medium-range missiles.

title: SHORT SKIRTS MAKE CASH REGISTERS RING
description: Short skirts are in the stores - and selling out as fast as they come in.

title: REAGAN TESTS ATTACK ON SPENDING IN FLORIDA TRIP
description: President Reagan came to this important political state today and attacked the Democrats' budget plans while previewing some of the themes he will develop in the 1988 election campaign.

title: COMPARING MORTGAGES
description: EVERY lending institution around wants to give you a mortgage these days. The problem is trying to figure out which offers the best deal. What with all the variations in closing costs, points, prepayment penalties and mortgage insurance, not to mention interest rates calculated in more different ways than there are bees in a hive, there seems no way for the consumer to calculate which mortgage option from which bank is really the choicest.

title: FORMIDABLE LEADER EMERGES FROM INDIA VOTE
description: The man who led the opposition to a trouncing of Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi's forces in the key state of Haryana has emerged as a formidable leader in northern India.

title: TEEN-AGERS AND SEX
description: CONCERN about AIDS is forcing the schools to re-examine their response to adolescent sexuality.

title: Babidugep Go Jasmine
description: With so many Democrats running for President, it's hard to keep them straight or to know what to call them. With an eye to their minuscule support in the polls, some cynics call them ''The Seven Dwarfs.'' Others, recalling the old ''Saturday Night Live'' cast, speak of the Not-Ready-for-Prime-Time Players. Reporters laboriously generalize about ''the largely unknown field of Democratic candidates.''

title: Japan Wage Growth Cut
description: The average Japanese worker received a 3.5 percent salary increase from major companies in wage negotiations last spring, a record low in the 22 years that such figures have been kept, a Labor Ministry official said today. The previous low was 4.4 percent in 1983 and the highest increase was 32.9 percent in 1974, said the official, who asked not to be identified. The small increase was attributed to the yen's steep rise against the dollar.

title: WHITE HOUSE STUDIES ADDING AIDE TO SPUR SUPPORT FOR CONTRAS
description: The Reagan Administration is considering enlarging the White House staff by one to reinforce efforts to gain wider public support for the Nicaraguan rebels, an Administration official said tonight.

title: Our Towns; Tracking no. 1: A New Legend At Roosevelt
description: When you're 7 years old, it's hard to keep track of everything. Gregory Haynes knew something major was happening to his big brother, Byron, last weekend. Byron was about to be the valedictorian, whatever that was. Sunday morning, Byron paced the living room, practicing a speech. A speech! Byron! He had written three full pages. Gregory listened, then said, ''What's 'fellow students?' ''

title: DONALD C. RINGWALD
description: Donald C. Ringwald, a historian and writer on steamboat navigation, died of cancer Friday at his home in Loudonville, N.Y. He was 70 years old.

title: Mrs. Reagan's 'Freeze'
description: Nancy Reagan, despite her background in the theater, confessed to a little stage fright Sunday night. There she was on the stage of Ford's Theatre, at its annual fund-raising gala, looking up at the box where Abraham Lincoln was assassinated in 1865, as Mrs. Reagan's husband very nearly was six years ago.

title: Abram Chasins, WQXR Executive, Dies at 83
description: Abram Chasins, a composer and pianist and the former music director of radio station WQXR, died of cancer Sunday at his home in Manhattan. He was 83 years old and had a second home in Los Angeles.

title: Vietnam's Newest Bank
description: Vietnam's first commercial bank under Communist rule is scheduled to open next month, and one of its goals will be to help check inflation, Japan's Kyodo News Service reported today. It quoted Nguyen Xuan Oanh, an economic adviser to the new premier, Pham Hung, as saying the bank would open in early July in Ho Chi Minh City, formerly Saigon. Mr. Oanh said that Vietnam now has only state-run and foreign trade banks and that the state-run banks have not succeeded in adjusting the volume of currency issued. By coordinating credit extension, the new bank will seek to check inflation and will make loans and handle personal savings accounts.

title: MAKING CARS THE VOLVO WAY
description: Today's cars may not look like Henry Ford's Model T, but most are still made pretty much according to the assembly line mass-production formula that he pioneered at the start of the century.

title: BELLI URGES CARETAKER FOR PTL
description: Melvin Belli said today that the singer Pat Boone or some other neutral person should temporarily lead PTL while its members decide between Jim Bakker and the Rev. Jerry Falwell to run the television ministry.

title: Correction Board Is Keeping Tabs on City Prisons
description: To the Editor:

title: NEWS SUMMARY: TUESDAY, JUNE 23, 1987
description: International A2-13

title: TOM'S TERRIFIC HIGHLIGHTS
description: 1966 - Seaver signs with Atlanta Braves out of the University of Southern California, but the contract is nullified by the baseball commissioner because it violates college rules. Three teams - Philadelphia, Cleveland and the Mets - indicate interest and in a special drawing held by Commissioner William D. Eckert on April 3, the Mets win and sign him. 1967 - After one Class AAA season at Jacksonville, Fla., he makes the Mets; wins 16 games and loses 13 as a rookie. Voted National League Rookie of the Year. 1969 - Wins 25, loses 7, with 2.21 earned run average and helps Mets to first pennant and upset victory over Baltimore in World Series. Wins first of three Cy Young Awards. 1970 - Strikes out 19 batters on San Diego on April 22, including final 10 in game. 1971 - Wins 20, loses 10. Later wins 20 or more games in 1972, 1975 and 1977. 1973 - Wins 19 as Mets take pennant on final day. Helps beat Cincinnati in playoff, but Mets lose Series to Oakland. Named winner of Cy Young Award second time. 1975 - Wins 22, loses 9. Voted Cy Young Award for third time. 1977 - Traded to Cincinnati on June 15 in blockbuster deal for four players. 1978 - Pitches 4-0 no-hit game against St. Louis June 16. 1982 - Traded back to Mets on Dec. 16 for three players. 1984 - Claimed by Chicago White Sox in free-agent compensation pool on Jan. 20. 1985 - Pitches 300th victory on Aug. 4, beating Yankees in Yankee Stadium. 1986 - Traded to Boston on June 29. Wins five games for Red Sox before bad knee ends season with career total of 311 victories.

title: Money and Politics: What Mix?
description: Perhaps nothing is more fundamentally political than the way candidates raise money. The campaign financing bill now before Congress is a case in point.

title: Aborted Takeoff Averts Crash
description: Two airliners in Nashville began takeoffs in opposite directions on the same runway last Thursday night, but one of the crews aborted its takeoff in time to avoid a crash, the National Transportation Safety Board said yesterday.

title: SEAVER ISSUES FINAL FAREWELL
description: Tom Seaver stood in Shea Stadium yesterday and made it official. He announced that he was ending his 16-day comeback and his 20-year career in baseball, and said farewell with the thought that ''I can say for the rest of my life, I got every ounce out of it.''

title: GETZ, TYNER AND BRECKER
description: THE Stan Getz Quartet, the McCoy Tyner Trio and the Michael Brecker Band, each of which inhabits a very different realm of jazz, shared a triple bill at Avery Fisher Hall on Sunday evening. Their three-and-a-half-hour concert presented a cross-section of styles that began unpromisingly with the flashy electronic fusion of Mr. Brecker's quintet, improved with the percussive keyboard artistry of Mr. Tyner's trio, and climaxed with the ultrapolished lyricism of Mr. Getz leading a superb ensemble.

title: Our Invaluable Grand Juries
description: The grand jury, an institution some would abolish, has again proved itself a powerful instrument of social reform.

title: MUSIC: GERMAN CHOIR
description: THE Knabenchor Hannover -which sang a program from the German Baroque at St. Bartholomew's Church Friday night - carries on a tradition in West Germany that survives most notably in the Vienna Choir Boys and in the choir schools that still dot the ecclesiastical map of Britain.

title: DOZENS HURT IN A COLLISION OF TWO FERRIES
description: Two ferryboats collided in a heavy fog off Sandy Hook, N.J., last night, injuring more than two dozen commuters who were returning home from Manhattan, the authorities said.

title: Advertising; Olsten Goes to Deutsch
description: David Deutsch Associates has become the agency for the Olsten Corporation of Westbury, L.I. The client, a employment agency for temporary help, has some 400 offices and around 80,000 clients. It formerly had its account at Ephron, Rayboy, Tsao & Kurnit. The ad budget will exceed $1 million.

title: Louisiana's Fig Leaf for Bad Science
description: Louisiana's legislature outlawed the teaching of evolution in public schools unless ''balanced'' by the teaching of something called ''creation science.'' Its followers claim scientific evidence for a supernatural origin of the universe. In other words, the state conditioned the teaching of modern biology on equal time for a religious doctrine. That's bad science. More to the point, the Supreme Court rightly holds, it's state promotion of religion and that's forbidden by the First Amendment.

title: AT AIRPORT IN SULFOLK, GROWTH BRINGS PROTESTS
description: Long Island-MacArthur Airport, once a backwater airfield for weekend pilots, has grown into a regional transportation center that is spurring both economic development and opposition from its surrounding community.

title: ENVOY WON'T SEE WALDHEIM
description: The United States Embassy to the Holy See said today that a lower-ranking official, not the Ambassador, would attend the ceremonies Thursday when President Kurt Waldheim of Austria meets Pope John Paul II.

title: NAHAMA & WEAGANT ENERGY CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
WD-40 CO reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
A Wrangle Over Ozone Policy
description: Conflict-of-interest cases usually involve accusations that a Government official has used the powers of office improperly for financial self-interest. But, an ethics charge concerning policy on ozone with no question of financial gain involved?

title: OPERA: 'BEAUTY AND BEAST'
description: In 1978, Stephen Oliver's opera ''The Duchess of Malfi'' received its American premiere in Santa Fe, N.M., under the direction of Colin Graham. Since then, Mr. Oliver, 37 years old, has been in London composing one opera after another; even he is not sure how many.

title: FULLER, H B CO reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Chairman Sells 5% Of Microsoft Stake
description: William H. Gates 3d, the co-founder and chairman of the Microsoft Corporation, has sold almost 5 percent of his common stock holdings in the computer software concern, for a total of almost $58 million. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Mr. Gates said that he sold the 520,000 Microsoft shares, representing about 2 percent of the total outstanding common stock, on the open market between May 7 and May 20 at prices ranging from $107.50 to $120.50 a share, or an average of $111.25.

title: Koch Gives La Guardia Medal To Brooklyn Catholic Bishop
description: Bishop Francis J. Mugavero of Brooklyn was awarded New York City's La Guardia Medal yesterday, the first clergyman so honored, for having ''significantly enhanced the quality of life'' in the city.

title: Going Out Guide; SUMMER IN THE CITY On Stage 400 Years
description: The area from about West Fourth Street to the Staten Island Ferry slip is considered Lower Manhattan by the Lower Manhattan Cultural Council. The council devises myriad outdoor activities to entertain the area's several hundred thousand workers and take their minds, for about an hour, off Lower Manhattan's principal product - money.

title: JUSTICE DEPT. SAYS IT WAS WRONG TO PROSECUTE GENERAL DYNAMICS
description: The Justice Department said today that it dropped a much-publicized indictment against the General Dynamics Corporation after documents were belatedly uncovered, showing that the company had properly billed the Government for millions of dollars in costs on an ill-fated Army weapon.

title: When Fred Astaire Leaves the Room
description: First, there were his looks. In truth, they didn't amount to much: medium height, skinny build, a longish nose, thinning hair. But in top hat, white tie and tails he was champagne to everybody else's beer.

title: Suspect Seized in Robbery Of $100,000 at Plaza Hotel
description: An airline maintenance worker was charged yesterday in an armed robbery at the Plaza Hotel three weeks ago in which more than $100,000 in cash and jewelry were stolen from a Texas couple, the police said.

title: Monetary System Criticized

title: Q&A
description: Q.Why do some animals, such as ferrets and hamsters, sometimes eat their newborn offspring? A.Eating of offspring is a common phenomenon among many species. Scientists believe that animals in the wild do so to increase the survival potential of the remaining offspring by lessening their competition and that the practice is more likely when resources are scarce. The killing of young may be ''retroactive birth control,'' said Dr. Henry Horn, a biology professor at Princeton University. ''It's as if the parent is making a cost and benefit analysis depending on the environment.'' Captive animals may eat newborns because of improper maintenance and stress, according to Dr. Ethel Tobach, a curator and comparative psychologist at the American Museum of Natural History. ''A cage may be pleasing to us, but such an environment may not be conducive to healthy living for the animal,'' she said.

description: Ted Bates Advertising has given up the Dr. Scholl's business, saying that the creative-only fee account was ''no longer profitable to service and has little prospect for growth.''

title: THE WITNESS FILE
description: Name: Noel C. Koch Age: 48 Position: President of International Security Management. From 1981 to 1986 Mr. Koch (pronounced cook) worked in the Department of Defense, most recently as the senior Pentagon official in charge of special operations forces. Until last week Mr. Koch was a trustee of the Secord Defense Fund but resigned after large deposits were made from anonymous sources in Switzerland. Role: Mr. Koch responded to a query from Gen. Colin L. Powell, the military assistant to the Secretary of Defense, who wanted to know the location of all Hawk missiles throughout the world. In the investigation of this question he determined that Iran had been a recipient of Hawk missiles and argued against sending military equipment to Iran.

title: INTERNATIONAL MULTIFOODS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $1,579,000.

title: SHULTZ-SHEVARDNADZE TALK LIKELY, BUT NOT CERTAIN
description: An arms-control adviser to President Reagan said today that Secretary of State George P. Shultz and Eduard A. Shevardnadze, the Soviet Foreign Minister, were planning to meet next month, but other Administration officials said the Soviet Union had not yet agreed.

title: CBS Explores the New 'Glasnost'
description: IS there no one in the Soviet Union who does not want a more humane, just and perhaps even capitalist society? ''The Soviet Union: Seven Days in May'' hints at the existence of a few sourballs, but doesn't actually find any. The atmosphere is chummy. The two-hour CBS News special, on Channel 2 at 9 o'clock tonight, is fascinating; it is also picturesque. Sometimes it feels like a guided tour.

title: Trial Avoided
description: By agreeing to pay an insurance company the amount of a check he was accused of cashing illegally, Micheal Ray Richardson has avoided a trial on forgery and theft charges. Richardson admitted no guilt but agreed to pay the State Farm insurance company $9,748, the amount of an insurance check intended to be used to reimburse a repair shop for work on his wife's Mercedes Benz. Richardson, who has been banned from the National Basketball Association because of drug use, is in the midst of an attempted comeback, playing with the Jersey Jammers of the United States Basketball League.

title: 'CAPTAIN EO' LAWSUIT
description: A lawsuit against the Walt Disney Company, the Eastman Kodak Company and Michael Jackson, the pop singer, was dismissed by a Federal District Court in Los Angeles, Disney said today. The suit charged that Disney's ''Captain Eo'' attraction, a 17-minute film starring Michael Jackson, was similar to a work copyrighted by the plaintiff, Matthew Gentry. But a Federal judge dismissed the case after a witness denied that he had signed a declaration supporting Gentry's contentions. The judge also said there was no substantial similarity between the Disney attraction and Mr. Gentry's work.

title: The Expert Can Go Astray In Suit Combination Habits
description: Experts rarely have to think about suit combinations as such. They have met almost all of them before, and rely on past experience rather than present calculation.

title: One Intelligence Panel in Congress Is Not Enough
description: To the Editor:

title: Economic Scene; 5 Guideposts For Laymen
description: THE American economy in early 1937 appeared to be recovering from the Depression.

title: SUSPENSION & PARTS INDUSRIES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Shearson Censure
description: Shearson Lehman Brothers was censured by the Securities and Exchange Commission on charges of using customer securities as loan collateral for six business days in November 1985. The S.E.C. did not state the total of customer securities involved in the transaction, but said the largest improper amount used by Shearson was $69 million on Nov. 4. A commission official said similar figures were involved on the other days. Shearson settled the charges without admitting or denying the allegations, and agreed to a number of procedures to guard against a recurrence.

title: Rimma Bravve IS Dead at 32; Soviet Emigre Fought Cancer
description: Rimma Bravve, a cancer patient who sought to emigrate from the Soviet Union for eight years before she was granted an exit visa last December, died yesterday at her mother's home in Rochester. She was 32 years old.

title: MYERSON CASE SPARKS CHANGE IN JOB SCREENING
description: New York City's Investigations Comm imissioner has decided that from now on his department would check police Intelligence Division files in conducting background inquiries into candidates for city jobs.

title: Awaiting an Interview
description: Publicity generated by the Congressional Iran-contra hearings may have cost Fereydon Pezeshkan his chance for an exclusive interview with President Reagan. Mr. Pezeshkan is a 48-year-old Iranian reporter who has broken a number of exclusive stories for the South-North News Service, a New Hampshire-based organization that distributes articles from correspondents in Third World countries to 20 newspapers in the United States.

title: Senate Democrats Halt Push for Fairness Law
description: The Senate Democratic leadership in effect conceded today that it lacked the votes to override President Reagan's veto of a bill that would write into law a policy requiring broadcasters to present divergent views on controversial topics.

title: G.M.A.C. Plans For Home Equity
description: The General Motors Acceptance Corporation said it would begin offering home-equity financing to current G.M.A.C. customers in Illinois, Maryland and Michigan as a test market to be expanded if G.M.A.C. obtains state licensing.

title: CITY CHARTER COMMISSION TO VIEW PUBLICLY FINANCED ELECTIONS ISSUE
description: The New York City Charter Revision Commission decided yesterday to consider whether municipal elections should be publicly financed.

title: JUSTICES BACK USE OF AID TO GET STATES TO RAISE DRINKING AGE
description: The Supreme Court, by a vote of 7 to 2, today upheld a Federal law aimed at encouraging states to raise the legal drinking age to 21 years by withholding some highway grants from those that fail to do so.

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: MENDING DEMOCRATIC COALITION IN SOUTH
description: John Lewis, the Democratic Congressman from Atlanta's Fifth District, finds the name evocative of another time and another struggle: the Super Tuesday Education Project.

title: HOME SITE TURNS GRAVE FOR A COUPLE'S DREAM
description: The five-acre site where Bob and Andrea Main had expected to live in their dream house is now a weedy lot where their contractor buried two elderly sisters he had killed.

title: BRITISH HAVE CAUSE TO STAND AND CHEER
description: It was suggested that the one positive aspect of Monday's rainout at Wimbledon was that it meant none of the British men could be eliminated. The country that invented tennis now appears unable to produce players capable of earning a berth in the men's draw. The lucky seven British men at Wimbledon are wild cards, the sport's equivalent to a free pass.

title: KNICKS TRY TO DRAFT COACH AND GENERAL MANAGER
description: Now that the draft is over, the Knicks will once again move on to more pressing matters, like hiring a general manager and a coach.

title: Immunity Upheld for Argentine Junta Crimes
description: The Supreme Court upheld a law today that grants immunity to hundreds of military officers accused of committing human-rights violations during military rule.

title: Japan Budget Of $14.2 Million
description: Japan announced today a supplementary budget of $14.2 billion, its biggest in 13 years, in an effort to pump up its economy and defuse overseas criticism of its huge trade surpluses.

title: 2D WASHINGTON DEPUTY MAYOR GETS PRISON TERM
description: Alphonse G. Hill today became the second Deputy Mayor in the three-term administration of Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. to be sentenced to prison. Mr. Hill received a term of 6 months to 2 1/2 years for steering contracts to a friend in exchange for kickbacks.

title: THE TALK OF CHARLOTTE: BIBLE BELT IMAGE GALLING TO CHARLOTTE
description: ''I know what the Bible Belt feels like,'' Ed Crutchfield was saying the other day from his office high atop the smoked-glass tower of the First Union National Bank building. ''I grew up in a town of 1,800 called Albemarle not far from Charlotte and my grandfather was a Baptist preacher. Charlotte never had the feel of the Bible Belt.''

title: SOUTH KOREA CHIEF MEETS KEY LEADER OF THE OPPOSITION
description: President Chun Doo Hwan met today with Kim Young Sam, president of the main opposition party, and held crucial talks aimed at ending South Korea's civil disorders.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: WEDNESDAY, JUNE 24, 1987

title: Comings and Goings
description: Dan Hampton, the Chicago Bears' defensive end, was fined $500 yesterday and sentenced to one year of court supervision after pleading guilty to charges of drunken driving in Harwood Heights, Ill. Cook County Associate Judge Howard Fink also ordered Hampton to undergo alcohol counseling and to perform community service. . . . The Jets claimed Howard Richards, an offensive lineman, from the Dallas Cowboys on waivers. Richardson has until this afternoon to decide if he will join the Jets or become a free agent. . . . Brian Tribble, who was acquitted earlier this month on a series of drug charges connected with the death of Len Bias, pleaded guilty yesterday in Prince George's County District Court to charges of speeding and eluding an officer.

title: CALNY INC reports earnings for 12wks to May 19
description: b-After a loss of $83,500 from discontinued operations.

title: 2 Banks In Alaska Rescued
description: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation announced today that it had approved a rescue package for two of Alaska's largest banks, under which they would be merged into one holding company and run by a New York-based management restructuring concern.

title: I.B.M. Optimistic On Newest PC's
description: Seeking to dispel reports that its new personal computer line had a slow start, the International Business Machines Corporation said yesterday that it had shipped more than a quarter of a million units of the PS/2 line.

title: P.L.O., IN TUNIS, IS SHADOW OF FORMER POWER
description: The Palestine Liberation Organization shows only a modest profile in this seaside capital where it now has its headquarters -far from any battle lines with Israel. This is in marked contrast with the days when the P.L.O. virtually governed large chunks of Lebanon and, earlier, Jordan.

title: REPORT ON TOXIC WASTE OFF NEW ENGLAND WARNS OF DANGERS IN REGION'S SEAFOOD
description: Chemical and other toxic wastes emptied into the ocean make some fish and shellfish from New England's coastal waters dangerous to eat, according to a report issued today by a national coalition made up largely of scientists and environmentalists.

title: RICHTON INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $2,515,000 and $2,692,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Net income and includes losses from discontinued operations of $83,000 and $142,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: IT MAY TASTE LIKE VANILLA, BUT IS IT VANILLA?
description: Scientists are working on ways to produce the flesh of a fresh cherry without growing a cherry tree. Already they are nurturing vanilla without producing a vanilla bean, and they are bent on extracting orange juice without an orange.

title: MONEY FROM IRAN SAID TO BUY ALARM FOR NORTH'S HOME
description: Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North apparently wrote fake letters to make it appear he intended to pay for a home security system financed in part by proceeds from the Iran arms sales, the Congressional committees investigating the Iran-contra affair were told today.

title: AN AMMONIA LEAK SPREADS PANIC IN BHOPAL
description: Thousands of residents of Bhopal fled their homes in panic early Tuesday morning when ammonia gas leaked from a factory near the Union Carbide pesticide plant there, Indian news agencies reported this morning.

title: Rainbow Lures Officer From Post at Showtime
description: Joshua Sapan, senior vice president for marketing at Showtime/The Movie Channel, is leaving to become president of Rainbow Program Services, a unit of Cablevision Industries that operates two pay channels, Bravo and American Movie Classics.

title: 3 Tax-Exempt Issues Attract Strong Interest
description: In the tax-exempt market, where new issues, especially of high investment grade, have been scarce, investors quickly took advantage of three offerings: a $306.2 million financing by the State of Georgia, one of $100 million by the Los Angeles Department of Water and Power, and a $50 million debt issue from the New Hampshire Housing Finance Agency.

title: JWT Group Conditions Offer of Data to WPP
description: In response to papers asking for equality of disclosure filed in a Wilmington, Del., court on Monday by Britain's WPP Group, the JWT Group has offered WPP the same information it is giving other interested corporations on certain conditions.

title: THE POP LIFE
description: Houston Follows Up

title: Paul Mejia to Head Fort Worth Ballet
description: Paul Mejia has been named artistic director of the Fort Worth Ballet. Mr. Mejia, a choreographer and the former artistic director of the Chicago City Ballet, replaces Nanette Glushak and Michel Rahn, the previous directors, who were dismissed June 12. The dismissal occurred amid public controversy over the influence of Anne Bass on the company's artistic policies. Mrs. Bass is second vice president of the ballet's board and a major arts patron.

title: MAN DIES IN BRIDGE LEAP
description: A man in his early 20's jumped to his death from the Williamsburg Bridge into the East River last night, the police said. Witnesses told the police that the man jumped from a catwalk on the bridge at 7:30 P.M. Police scuba divers recovered the body an hour and a half later. Police were still seeking the identity of the man this morning. They described him as Hispanic and said that he was wearing a green polo shirt, black pants and black shoes.

title:
FOOD & FITNESS;
Fish, for Balance
description: LEAD: TENDING to one's nutrition can be a trial. Picture yourself surrounded by a dozen small brush fires, stamping one out only to see another leap to life.

title: Chicago Police Promotions Are Blocked by a U.S. Judge
description: A Federal judge has blocked the promotion of 260 Chicago police officers to the ranks of sergeant and lieutenant because they passed tests later found to be racially discriminatory.

title: President Is Named At Business Month
description: Goldhirsch Publishing in Boston has appointed Stephen M. Blacker, 50, president and chief executive of the Business Month Corporation. Business Month magazine was acquired as Dun's Business Month from Dun & Bradstreet last year.

title: TEXAS EXECUTES MAN WHO ASSERTS HE HAD NO ROLE IN DOUBLE SLAYING
description: A man convicted of killing a jeweler in a 1982 robbery was executed early today after losing appeals for his fourth stay.

title: TORONTO HOMERS BEAT TIGERS
description: Willie Upshaw hit a grand slam and Fred McGriff and George Bell also hit homers tonight to spark the Toronto Blue Jays to an 8-7 victory over the Detroit Tigers.

title: Film: 'Growing Pains'
description: AWKWARDNESS and embarrassment are the common denominators that unite the four short films on the Film Forum 1's ''Growing Pains'' program, films that benefit greatly from being in one another's company. Sentiments like these, when viewed with the bemused spirit that these very different films somehow share, take on a disarming candor.

PANATECH RESEARCH & DEVELPMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $53,000 for the quarter and $150,000 for the year. c-Net loss and after income of $12,000 from discontinued operations. d-After a loss of $58,000 from discontinued operations. All sales figures for the quarters and years have been restated to exclude the revenue of Panatech Semiconductor, approximately $3.5 million annually, which was sold after the end of the reporting period, and is therefore treated as a discontinued operation.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: MOST people have heard the admonition ''Don't put anything smaller than your elbow into your ear'' and most people have paid it little heed. Americans seem to make a fetish of cleaning wax out of their ears, and they use just about anything handy to do it: fingernails, twisted paper or cloth, hairpins, paper clips, twigs, even crochet hooks. Probably the most popular tool - more sanitary than the rest, but little better for the ears - is a cotton-tipped swab.

title: In Paris, Pastrami Just Isn't the Same
description: ''PASTRAMI!'' declares the distinguished-looking Frenchman as the waiter approaches his table.

description: To the Editor:

title: MANY KILLED IN AFGHAN BATTLE
description: A monthlong battle around Afghanistan's second largest city, Kandahar, has left hundreds of combatants and civilians dead and wounded, guerrilla sources here said today.

title:
About New York;
'DOCKOMINIUM' A BRONX HAVEN, FOR $63,000 OR SO
description: LEAD: The man on the dock stared vacantly at the little patch of water in the boat slip, and said, ''So, that's it?''

title: The Speaker and the Thrift Scandal
description: Does Jim Wright want to be known as the Speaker of the House or as the defender of some Texas banking hustlers? Parochialism is the most charitable explanation for his campaign to prevent regulators from closing bankrupt savings and loans in his home state. Unless the Speaker reconsiders and supports the strengthening of the deposit insurance system, taxpayers will be stuck with the multibillion-dollar cleanup. * * *
