description: As the Iran-contra hearings resumed in Washington, the Congressional committees heard yesterday from Glenn A. Robinette, Noel C. Koch and Henry H. Gaffney. Here are excerpts from the testimony of Mr. Robinette and Mr. Koch, as recorded by The New York Times. GLENN A. ROBINETTE PAUL BARBADORO, a lawyer on the staff of Arthur L. Liman, chief counsel to the Senate committee. Mr. Robinette, I just want to summarize your testimony with you to date. A. Yes sir. Q. You've said so far that you paid Vatek and Automatic Door approximately $13,900 to install the security system, correct? A. Yes sir. Q. And you in turn received a total of $16,000 in reimbursement from Richard Secord, is that right?

title: A RAMPAGE IN CATHEDRAL
description: A man shouting ''I am the Holy Spirit, burn all the Bibles!'' rampaged through the St. Louis Cathedral today, destroying old statues described as priceless, the authorities said. The 35-year-old man, Joe Wayne Reno, of suburban Gretna, was arrested without incident amid the rubble. Pope John Paul II is scheduled to visit the cathedral in September.

title: REOPENING A LIBRARY, WITH LOVE
description: Like proud new parents, Sandra Priest Rose and Frederick P. Rose beamed yesterday as they greeted city officials, friends and family members at the reopening of the Yorkville branch of the New York Public Library.

title: Speeding the Design of Some Chips
description: The NCR Corporation introduced a software system yesterday that its executives said should accelerate the design time for some kinds of custom computer chips.

title: COMMERCIAL METALS CO reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
A.M.A. BACKS AIDS TESTING OF TWO GROUPS
description: The American Medical Association today endorsed mandatory testing of prisoners and would-be immigrants for the AIDS virus. It also urged that students as young as those in elementary school be taught about the deadly disease.

title: YANKEES PLANNING NO-DRINKNG AREA
description: A day after a state senator withdrew legislation to require no-drinking sections at ball parks and other arenas in New York State, the Yankees today announced plans to establish one.

title: 2 FERRYBOATS IN COLLISION EVIDENTLY DIDN'T SIGNAL
description: The two ferryboats that collided in dense fog in Lower New York Bay on Monday apparently did not sound warning horns as required, the Coast Guard said yesterday.

title: Team Canada Picks
description: Defense got equal billing with offense when Team Canada's selection committee announced its list of 37 invitees to the Canada Cup training camp for the six-team tournament beginning on Aug. 28. While Team Canada's invitees feature scorers such as Edmonton's Wayne Gretzky and Pittsburgh's Mario Lemieux, there are also players such as Philadelphia's Dave Poulin, who is known more for his checking skills. The Islanders' Mike Bossy has asked to be excused from the team to give his ailing back time to heal.

title: HEADED ILLUSTRATORS SOCIETY
description: Walter Brooks, a commercial artist and graphic designer, died of heart disease Saturday in Norwalk Hospital in Connecticut. He was 65 years old and lived in Norwalk.

title: Home Economics, Elizabethan Style
description: IN Tudor England, apples and other foods cultivated by men were well-documented in estate records. Foods cultivated by women, however, were relegated to odd notes and the occasional recipe, which were carried from father's house to husband's home.

title: Corrections
description: A Washington dispatch on Saturday about Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. of Washington incorrectly characterized the attribution of a television report by station WUSA last Thursday. The report - on investigations of the Mayor by the United States Attorney for the District of Columbia - was attributed to ''sources'' and to documents quoted on the broadcast.

title: Basketball League Starting Small
description: Basketball players as tall as Kareem Abdul-Jabbar and Moses Malone - the kind who usually bring smiles to the faces of National Basketball Association scouts - need not apply.

title: FROM TAMIL REFUGEES, TALES OF SRI LANKA TORTURE
description: The husky young refugee made a trigger motion with his right forefinger, indicating the finger that he said he saw government soldiers maim on healthy Tamil men back home in Sri Lanka.

title: Becor Receives Sweeter Offer
description: One of four groups bidding to take over Becor Western Inc., the mining equipment manufacturer, raised its offer to $16.50 a share in cash, up from a previous $15. The sweetened offer values the company at $272 million. The bid is from the Lynch

title: DOT's 9.9 Stake In Jersey Shipyard
description: DOT Partnership, an investment partnership including the Dallas investor James E. Sowell, has purchased the equivalent of a 9.9 percent stake in the Todd Shipyards Corporation and said it might seek control of the naval construction, repair and overhaul concern, based in Jersey City.

title: HOBNOBBING AND TUTORING
description: If you'd like to rub elbows with some of the world's most passionate fly fishermen, you might wish to attend Friday night's cocktail party, dinner and auction of Trout Unlimited's six-day 1987 national convention.

title: BABBITT URGES END TO GATT
description: Three 1988 Presidential hopefuls trying to score points among chief executives of American companies today offered their prescriptions for the nation's trade and economic ills.

title: POTATO PLANT PRODUCES REPELLENT
description: A team of Agriculture Department scientists has developed experimental hybrid potato plants with their own natural insect repellent.

title: On Island Off Canada's Coast, Menus Change With the Tides
description: LEAD: INSIDE Sooke Harbour House, on the southwest corner of Vancouver Island, an hour and a half by ferry from the British Columbia mainland, guests sip tea, read or look out the picture window at the water and mountains beyond. Enter the inn's owner, Sinclair Philip, a round, impish man, displaying a brilliant orange 10-pound Puget

title: HOMEOWNERS ON BEACH REACH PACT WITH TOWN
description: The owners of 239 houses on a washed-out section of Dune Road here have won access to their homes in a settlement reached after four days of trial testimony.

title: SYRIAN DENIES HOSTAGE DEADLINE
description: Force will not be used, for the time being, to free an abducted American journalist and the son of the Lebanese Defense Minister, a Syrian general said today.

title: Hearns Seeks Title
description: Thomas Hearns will apparently try for a fourth world title, this time as a middleweight. Emanuel Steward, manager and trainer of Hearns, the World Boxing Council light heavyweight champion, said yesterday that he had agreed to terms with the promoter, Bob Arum, for Hearns to fight Juan Roldan for the World Boxing Council middleweight title. If Arum is able to get W.B.C. sanction of the bout, he expects to stage the fight in September in Las Vegas, Nev., possibly on a card that would include an International Boxing Federation middleweight title fight between Michael Olajide and Iran Barkley. Hearns won the W.B.C. lightweight title from Dennis Andries earlier this year, and before that had held welterweight and junior middleweight world titles.

title: Hextall Suspended
description: Ron Hextall, the Philadelphia Flyers' goaltender, was suspended by the National Hockey League yesterday for the first eight games of the 1987-88 season as a result of a stick-swinging incident in the fourth game of the Stanley Cup finals against Edmonton on May 24. Hextall, the most valuable player in the finals despite Philadelphia's loss, by 4 games to 3, to the Oilers, received a major penalty for slashing Kent Nilsson. ''There is no justification for any player to swing his stick in retaliation and this is especially the case for a goaltender whose stick, because of its weight, can cause serious injury,'' said Brian O'Neill, the league's executive vice president, in announcing the suspension. ''There is no disputing the fact that the blow was severe and deliberate.'' A hearing on the incident was held in Toronto on June 10. ''We're not too excited about him being suspended for eight games,'' said Bobby Clarke, the Flyers' general manager. ''It isn't going to make any difference what I think,'' Clarke said. ''The league is in charge of discipline and we'll live with it.''

title: IRAN HAS HIT 3 KUWAITI SHIPS NOW AWAITING NAVAL ESCORT
description: Three of the 11 Kuwaiti tankers that the Reagan Administration plans to put under American naval escort in the Persian Gulf have been attacked by Iran in recent years, according to a report published today by the chairman of the House Armed Services Committee.

title: MERGER BILL TOO BROAD, S.E.C. SAYS
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission opposes broad legislation proposed by Senator William Proxmire, the Wisconsin Democrat, to change the rules of corporate takeovers, its acting chairman told Congress today.

title: Writers Guild Contends Producers Practice Bias
description: The Writers Guild of America West charged in a report made public today that producers discriminate against women, members of minorities and writers over 40 years old.

title: In the Spirit of Summer Fun
description: 1. Jewelry With Flair Luanne Vrattos's smart, sophisticated jewelry goes with just about anything, day or night. This sleek choker has sterling tubing with black onyx disks, for $145. The collection, manufactured by Beadworks, also includes bracelets, earrings and long necklaces that combine sterling beads or tubing with such materials as jade, ivory, turquoise or hematite. Pieces can be made to order. At Alix & Alexis, 956 Lexington Avenue, between 69th and 70th Streets. 2. Animal Napkin Rings For a festive casual dinner, here is an amusing napkin ring, hand-carved from soapstone in the shape of a cow. It was made in Kenya and costs $7.95. A sheep design is also available. At Farfetched, 110 Fourth Avenue, between 11th and 12th Streets. 3. Antique Fragments Marjorie Lawrence has transformed fragments of an antique Kurd kilim into this decorative bag. It is in shades of rust, blue, tan and black, for $75. Mrs. Lawrence also makes bags from fragments of other handwoven textiles, such as antique needlepoint and knotted rugs. At the Pillowry, 19 East 69th Street (third floor). Tank Top's New Image The tank top is going formal this summer. Kenar Sportswear's version of the warm-weather favorite is decorated with lace, sequins and pearls around the neckline. The top is 100 percent cotton and it comes in a choice of colors: pink, periwinkle and khaki. The price is $58 in Expressions on the third floor at Macy's Herald Square (not available at branch stores).

title: SIGNS OF LIFE IN OIL INDUSTRY
description: From the shores of Lake Michigan to eastern Colorado to the Gulf of Mexico, a species that was a prime candidate for the endangered list is making a comeback: the wildcatter.

title: New Ballet School Manager
description: Robert Lindgren, dean of the school of dance at the North Carolina School of the Arts, was named general manager of the School of American Ballet yesterday.

title: CONVICTED IN 'PIZZA CONNECTION' CONSPIRATOR SHIFS PLEA TO GUILTY
description: A man facing sentencing after being convicted in the ''pizza connection'' drug case changed his plea to guilty yesterday in a bid for leniency.

title: De Grassi and Shadowfax
description: WORLD music - sliced, diced, whipped, chopped and pureed - was the raw material for the ''new age'' double bill Monday at Carnegie Hall. Alex De Grassi, a guitarist with a quartet, and the six-piece band Shadowfax showed that eclecticism doesn't guarantee musical substance.

DAYTON STOCK GYRATES ON BOGUS BID
description: A bogus takeover offer for the Dayton Hudson Corporation caused the retailer's stock to shoot up $9 a share yesterday, but skepticism quickly deflated the gain, inflicting a $15 million loss on investors.

title: Quotations of the Day
description: ''It is very regrettable and worrisome that violent street demonstrations and riots continue these days. All problems should be settled through dialogue and compromise within the bounds of law and order.''

title: Dixieland And Be-Bop By Shearing
description: GEORGE SHEARING used his own jazz experiences as the basis for a JVC Jazz Festival program at Town Hall on Monday evening that focused on Dixieland and be-bop and gave him the opportunity to play some piano duets with Hank Jones.

title: No Headline
description: The Northrop Corporation is unable to account for 780 classified documents from its Stealth bomber program, according to a draft Congressional study that generally commends the company for improving its procedures.

title: Be Firm in the Gulf
description: There is confusion and even hysteria surrounding Washington's decision to allow Kuwait to place part of its tanker fleet under United States protection. Let us try to sort out some of the key issues.

title: SUN AND LENDL STRUGGLE AT WIMBLEDON
description: From the moment he takes those first soggy steps on the grass courts of England, Ivan Lendl feels less like the No. 1 player in the world and more like a survivor. Wimbledon is the vegetable on Lendl's tennis plate, good for his health, perhaps, but not particularly appetizing. Today, with the customary frown, he took another bite.

title: DENSE-PAC MICROSYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Net income The latest year loss includes one- time charges relating to inventory writedowns of about $1.5 million and costs associated with the now closed Puerto Rico manufacturing facility of about $1 million.

title: ALL-MALE CLUB ISUNDER SIEGE BY PICKETS AND LAWMAKERS
description: Inside, members of the all-male Cosmos Club lunched today in an air-conditioned dining room, while outside, members of the National Organization for Women picnicked in protest on the sidewalk across the street, where the temperature was more than 85 degrees.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Rates Rise in Brisk Trading
description: Interest rates rose slightly yesterday as market participants shrugged off a favorable report on inflation and concentrated on a weaker dollar.

title: Brazil, in Reversal, Welcomes I.M.F.
description: After being considered unwelcome here for two years, officials from the International Monetary Fund entered Brazil's Finance Ministry through the front door today in what was seen as an important symbol of this country's changing economic policies.

title: Firestone Chooses Newcomer to Tires
description: The Firestone Tire and Rubber Company said yesterday that it had named Albert E. Suter president and chief operating officer, and Mr. Suter said he already has his eye on John J. Nevin's job as chief executive.

title: William Crespinel, 96; Pioneer in Color Films
description: William T. Crespinel, a cinematographer who did pioneer work in color films, died Friday at his home in Laguna Beach, Calif. He was 96 years old.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Track and Field Bubka Breaks His Vault Mark: Sergei Bubka of the Soviet Union bettered his world record in the pole vault yesterday with a jump of 19 feet 9 1/4 inches at a meet in Prague. Bubka set the previous mark of 19-8 1/2 in the Goodwill Games at Moscow on July 8, 1986. Bubka accomplished the feat on his third attempt in cold and rainy weather, according to the Czechoslovak press agency CTK.(AP) Distance Running Programmer Wins 18-Day Event: Marty Springelmeyer, a 40-year-old computer programmer from Davenport, Iowa, who started running 10 years ago, won the Sri Chinmoy 18-day ultradistance race that concluded in Flushing Meadow Park in Queens yesterday by covering 1,250 miles. Pippa Davis, a 40-year-old nutritional consultant from Westford, Mass., who ran 832 miles, won the women's title. Yachting America's Cup 12-Meter First: Bengal, which competed in this year's America's Cup races under the name Australia III, took first place on the first day of the 12-Meter World Championship off Porto Cervo, Sardinia. Dennis Conner's Stars & Stripes, which won the America's Cup for the United States, was sixth. (AP) Harness Racing Record at Yonkers: Mike Lachance set a record for most victories at a harness track in one day, driving 12 winners during a doubleheader at Yonkers Raceway. Lachance won seven of 10 races in the afternoon, then won four of the first five in the evening before breaking the record by steering Keystone Hilton to victory in the seventh race. Lachance broke the mark of 11, set by Clint Hodgins at Dufferin Park in Toronto on Nov. 25, 1939, and equaled by Joe O'Brien at Truro Raceway in Truro, Nova Scotia, on Sept. 16, 1942.(AP)

title: ILLUSTRATED CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: Allen Atkinson, an artist who illustrated many new editions of classic children's books, died of a heart attack Monday at Danbury (Conn.) Hospital. He was 34 years old and lived in Bethel, Conn.

title: BIG WATCH CAMPAIGN FOR RADO
description: SALES of high-priced watches, an adornment of yuppies and other status seekers, are particularly good in warm marketing areas where short sleeves are popular.

title: BOY, 9, ON S.I. IS SHOT FROM PASSING VEHICLE
description: A 9-year-old Staten Island boy was shot in the back from a passing vehicle as he walked down Castleton Avenue near his home in St. George yesterday afternoon, the police said.

title: Fight Goes On
description: Simone LeVant, the captain of the women's diving team at Stanford, successfully challenged the National Collegiate Athletic Association's mandatory drug-testing policy this spring, winning a ruling in California Superior Court that permitted her to compete without consenting to testing, which she contended was an invasion of privacy.

title: CONTRACTOR GUILTY OF OVERCHARGING PENTAGON AND WILL PAY $4 MILLION
description: A major military contractor said today that it had pleaded guilty to 22 felony counts of falsifying employee time cards, resulting in overcharging the Department of Defense by $1.5 million from 1981 through 1983.

title: The General Hits, and Misses, the Mark
description: By long tradition, when old warriors make their final remarks they speak with unusual candor and utter previously unutterable truths. George Washington warned of entangling alliances. President Eisenhower called attention to the military-industrial complex.

title: Sun Ra, in Solo Performance
description: SUN RA went rummaging through his storehouse of jazz piano styles in his solo concert Monday afternoon at Weill Recital Hall. Billed as Le Sun Ra, and wearing a sequined outfit with a feathered headdress, he rambled from boogie-woogie to free jazz to Satie-tinged ballads to Ellington. He was sometimes splashy, sometimes understated, but no matter how far he stretched the music - blues licks dissolving into whole-tone chords and sweeping glissandos -his playing had a steady momentum and a lavish spirit.

title: Actors' Equity Keeps Ban on Actress in 'Phantom'
description: The council of the Actors' Equity Association refused yesterday for the second time to grant permission to Sarah Brightman to perform in the Broadway production of ''Phantom of the Opera,'' the Andrew Lloyd Webber musical that is a major hit in London's West End, unless the show's producers offer an American actor similar employment in London.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * American National Can Co., Chicago, said it would build a research center in the Southpark Industrial Center in Neenah, Wis., for its performance plastics packaging division.

title: History Can't Tell Us What Gorbachev Is Up To
description: To the Editor:

title: PARIS AND BONN START TO THINK OF A SPECIAL ALLIANCE
description: As they contemplate a sharply reduced American nuclear presence in Western Europe, some French and West German politicians have proposed an intensified two-way defense relationship to counter the Warsaw Pact.

title: Surgery for Jones
description: Shelton Jones, the St. John's forward, has undergone surgery at North Shore Hospital in Manhasset, L.I., for a detached retina in his right eye. The 6-foot-9-inch Jones, the leading rebounder for the Redmen last season, was poked in the eye while playing for an all-star team in France two weeks ago. He experienced difficulty with the eye last week and was operated on Sunday.

title: Consultant to CBS Protests Favorable Portrait of Russia
description: A consultant to CBS News has sent a letter of protest to the network disassociating himself from tonight's documentary ''Seven Days in May'' because he disagrees with what he says is its favorable portrait of the Soviet Union.

title: Clarke Hooper P.L.C. Buys Joseph Potocki
description: For a change of pace, we have a West Coast acquisition by a British company, and it is small potatoes compared with what we Eastern wheelers and dealers are accustomed to. The buyer is Clarke Hooper P.L.C., Britain's leading sales promotion company, and it has purchased Joseph Potocki & Associates, which is in the same line of work in Newport Beach, Calif., and is considered a major force in the West. It had sales last year of slightly more than $5 million.

title: NEW U.S. AIDE ON CONTRAS HINTED
description: The Reagan Administration is considering enlarging the White House staff by one person to reinforce efforts to gain wider public support for the Nicaraguan rebels, according to an Administration official.

title: High Court Didn't Rule On Ending a Treaty
description: To the Editor:

title: A REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: A HAUNTED CHERNOBYL
description: Before the bus leaves from here to take visiting journalists the 11 miles to the nuclear plant that made this town infamous, everyone is asked to fill out a dual Russian- and English-language form, promising not to open bus windows, step off the roads or to smoke.

title: NEW M.C.C. CHIEF'S STRATEGY: TO SPEED PAYOFF ON RESEARCH
description: GRANT A. DOVE built his reputation by finding ways to convert sophisticated research into money-making products during the last two decades at Texas Instruments Inc.

title: No Headline
description: A Vietnam War deserter returned home to Vermont today to see his ailing father hours after the Marine Corps discharged him.

title: Dow's Climb Ends With 5.78 Loss
description: LEAD: The stock market finally lost some ground yesterday, and its retreat had a lot in common with its recent climb to record highs: It was modest and orderly.

title: Taking Baby Along
description: To The Living Section:

title: New Increase By Continental
description: Continental Airlines yesterday raised round-trip air fares by $20 on certain discount tickets. The increase affects tickets that must be bought seven days in advance and which carry a 50 percent cancellation fee. The increase will take effect about July 1.

title: NEW YORK RENT PANEL VOTES SMALLEST INCREASE SINCE 1969
description: The New York City Rent Guidelines Board voted yesterday to let landlords of rent-stabilized apartments raise rents by up to 6.5 percent, the smallest increase since stabilization began in 1969.

title: PTL Hearings
description: The PTL ministry may have its day on Capitol Hill soon. The House Ways and Means subcommittee on oversight, headed by Representative J. J. Pickle, a Texas Democrat, began hearings Monday on the growing commercial activities of tax-exempt organizations and whether more of these activities should be subject to tax. An aide said Mr. Pickle was considering a separate hearing on PTL sometime after the current hearings conclude. PTL has a variety of income-producing activities, including a hotel, a water-amusement park and satellite television network.

title: WASHINGTON TALK: Working Profile: James C. McKay; He Who, Undaunted, Is Investigating Meese
description: Losing a case by neglecting to observe the statute of limitations is a lawyer's nightmare, says James C. McKay, the special prosecutor investigating Government officials' activities in behalf of the Wedtech Corporation.

title: NICHOLS INSTITUTE reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Net loss The company said the latest periods' results included those of Medlab Inc., of Portland, Ore., which was acquired Dec. 30, 1986.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: WEDNESDAY, JUNE 24, 1987
description: International A2-14 Oliver North wrote fake letters to make it appear he would pay for a home security system financed in part by proceeds from the Iran arms sales, the Congressional committees investigating the Iran-contra affair were told. Page A1 The South Korean president met with Kim Young Sam, leader of the main opposition party, as they began potentially crucial talks aimed at ending the country's civil disorders. It was the first time the two men had met. A1 South Korea's economy has grown over the years despite many political troubles. While the recent demonstrations have prompted fears that foreigners might shy away from the country, there is little evidence to merit such anxiety. A1 Man in the News: Gaston Sigur, the Assistant Secretary of State for East Asian and Pacific Affairs, arrived in South Korea in the midst of a major constitutional crisis. He said he wanted an orderly transition of government in Korea. A12 A U.S.-Soviet arms control accord removing medium-range and short-range nuclear missiles from Europe is ''inevitable,'' the NATO alliance's departing military chief, Gen. Bernard W. Rogers, said. But he considers it a mistake. A3 News analysis: Congressional fears about United States policy in the Persian Gulf stem from the Adminis-tration's penchant for small-scale military ventures, such as last year's air strikes on Libya. A7 Tamil refugees' claims of torture in Sri Lanka have been denied by the Government. But refugees continue to arrive in India, their lives disrupted by a conflict that has left more than 5,000 Sri Lankans dead since 1983. A4 Peru's cabinet may quit

title: Hispanic Unit at Doner
description: W. B. Doner & Company, Detroit, has established a Hispanic unit for specialty advertising and has brought in Isaac Lasky and Roberto Manzano to run it. Mr. Lasky was last at Coca-Cola U.S.A., where he was manager of Hispanic consumer marketing. Mr. Manzano, who will be creative director, last held that role at Castor Spanish International in New York.

title: A Soy-Based Business Flourishes in Brooklyn
description: IF it were not for a fresh, slightly sweet aroma that greets visitors, the worn building in a gritty industrial section of Brooklyn occupied by Appropriate Foods would seem all but abandoned.

title: Gas Bond Yield Reaches 7.985%
description: Philadelphia Gas Works is tentatively offering $142.6 million of tax-exempt revenue bonds with a maximum yield of about 7.985 percent for a 7 7/8 percent issue due in 2017. Underwriters led by Paine

title: VIDEO LINK TESTED FOR CRIME VICTIMS
description: A program being tested by law-enforcement authorities in Brooklyn allows crime victims and witnesses in the 73d Precinct in the Brownsville section to talk to prosecutors in the 84th Precinct station house, five miles away, using a two-way video hookup.

title: Toyota Venture With Volkswagen
description: The Toyota Motor Corporation and Volkswagen A.G. announced an agreement for joint production of light trucks in West Germany, giving the Japanese a way to circumvent voluntary restraints on their exports to Europe. Neither company would disclose details of the deal.

title: India's 1961 Goa Action: 'Liberation' Only to Some
description: To the Editor:

title: Morgan Stanley Wins Utility Issue
description: A $75 million competitive issue of 30-year first-mortgage bonds due in 1997 by the Indiana and Michigan Electric Company was won yesterday by a group of underwriters led by Morgan Stanley & Company.

title: WIFE HELD IN MAN'S DEATH
description: A 71-year-old woman was charged with stabbing her 75-year-old husband to death during an argument over whether he was seeing other women, the police said today. Elizabeth Becker of Hicksville was charged with second-degree manslaughter after her husband of 33 years, William, died from a single stab wound to the left thigh with a 10-inch kitchen knife, said Detective Sgt. John Nolan of the Nassau County police. The stabbing occured at about 2:10 P.M. Monday.

title: Warren Anderson vs. Court Reform
description: Opponents of court reform in New York are running out of reasons to oppose a referendum on streamlining the New York State judiciary. But time is also running out. The Senate majority leader, Warren Anderson, remains the main obstacle. He would prevent the voters from deciding whether to amend the state Constitution.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: Urban Oases

title: GENERAL SEES MISSILE PLANS AS A MISTAKE
description: The NATO alliance's departing military commander said today that he now accepted as ''inevitable'' a projected arms control agreement removing Soviet and United States medium-range and short-range nuclear missiles from Europe.

title: GALAGRAPH LTD reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss The prior year results are reclassified to conform to presentation used for the year ending Dec. 31, 1987.

title: Being in Control
description: To The Living Section:

title: SOUTH KOREA OPPOSITION: DIVERSE AND DIVIDED
description: A month ago, the only thing Kim Young Sam seemed likely to get from President Chun Doo Hwan was a jail term. Today, he got an audience at the presidential residence in Seoul.

title: DR. C.E. DE LA CHAPELLE, A NOTED CARDIOLOGIST
description: Dr. Clarence E. de la Chapelle, a cardiologist and medical educator who had been associated for six decades with New York University's College of Medicine and Medical Center, died June 13 in a nursing home after a long illness. He was 89 years old and a lifelong resident of Manhattan, where he also had his private practice.

title: Real Estate; CONNECTICUT BUSY AREA FOR OFFICES
description: IN some real estate circles the conventional wisdom has held that when a New York company relocates to the suburbs, it moves near the top executives' homes.

title: RHODEN WINS NO. 9 IN SCUFF-BALL DISPUTE
description: In the room where the umpires dress, someone neatly placed four baseballs at the feet of Dave Phillips. He scooped them up with two hands, turned them toward group of curious onlookers and nodded toward the scuff marks on each.

title: NEW YORK AREA PRICES 0.6% HIGHER
description: Rising costs for shelter helped to drive up consumer prices by six-tenths of 1 percent last month in the New York and northeastern New Jersey area, the Labor Department said yesterday.

title: GULF POLICY: FEARS LINGER
description: For 40 years, Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger argued in a report to Congress last week, the United States has sought to deny Soviet access to the Persian Gulf, insure ''free-world access'' to gulf oil and promote the stability of the gulf states.

title: Reagan Loses Banking Vote
description: Beginning a meeting on a major piece of banking legislation, House conferees today handed the Reagan Administration a defeat, voting down a proposal to consider only a provision that would inject new funds into the troubled Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation.

title: Britons' Self-Interest Demoted to Selfishness
description: To the Editor:

title: HOUSE, HEADING FOR FIGHT WITH REAGAN, PASSES A 1988 BUDGET
description: The House of Representatives, voting along party lines, today approved a trillion-dollar budget for 1988 as Congress and the White House intensified their partisan confrontation over fiscal policy.

title: PERU'S CABINET REPORTED TO QUIT
description: The Peruvian Cabinet has resigned after the decision of Prime Minister Luis Alva Castro to quit, Foreign Minister Allan Wagner said today.

title: Mondale's Farewell?
description: Walter F. Mondale is getting ready to pick up stakes and return to his native Minnesota. The former Vice President said in an interview yesterday that he bought a house last week in Minneapolis and would start work there Sept. 1 at the law firm of Dorsey & Whitney. He also plans to teach at the University of Minnesota law school. ''I've always wanted to be back there,'' Mr. Mondale said. ''And this is a good time.''

title: Corrections
description: The Gardening column in The Home Section on April 16 misstated the authorship of ''The Weekend Gardener,'' published by Harper & Row.

title: INVESTIGATION TO FOCUS ON DEMOCRAT IN HOUSE
description: The House Ethics Committee voted today to investigate accusations that Representative Austin J. Murphy of Pennsylvania was involved in ghost voting and payroll improprieties.

title: SOUTH KOREANS RIOT IN NIGHT, THEN GO DUTIFULLY TO WORK
description: Citizens take to the streets at night here and in other cities to demonstrate against the Government, but during the day they are hard at work, driving an economy that booms even amid political turmoil.

title: GOGING OUT GUIDE
description: Facing the Facts

title: CONSUMER PRICES IN NATION CLIMBED ONLY 0.3% IN MAY
description: Providing further evidence that inflation is stabilizing, the Government reported today that consumer prices rose a modest three-tenths of 1 percent in May, the smallest monthly increase this year.

title: Alex. Brown Executive Likely to Lead N.A.S.D.
description: If all goes well for Joseph R. Hardiman tomorrow, he will be named the next president of the National Association of Securities Dealers, the industry group that oversees trading in over-the-counter stocks.

title: New Texaco Panel
description: The United States trustee in the Texaco Inc. bankruptcy case said he would appoint a committee of Texaco shareholders to represent shareholders' interests in the bankruptcy proceedings. Harry Jones, the trustee, made the announcement at a meeting of Texaco officials and their creditors in Rye, N.Y. The meeting was held to answer questions of creditors who are not members of the two creditors' committees that Mr. Jones appointed in April to monitor Texaco's activities during the bankruptcy. Mr. Jones said he hoped to select the members of the committee before the end of June.

title: JOSEPH DELANO HITCH
description: Joseph Delano Hitch, an engineer who was a former vice president of the Babcock & Wilcox Company, died of kidney failure Monday at Princeton (N.J.) Medical Center. He was 83 years old and lived in Hightstown, N.J.

title: Black and White And Red All Over
description: I'm smack in the middle of a very American debate -art versus money.

title: ORDERS OFF 0.1% IN MAY IN DURABLES
description: New orders for ''big ticket'' durable goods, depressed by a slump in demand for military hardware, edged down one-tenth of 1 percent in May, the first decline in four months, the Commerce Department said today.

title: Morgan Group Asserts It Controls Burlington
description: An investor group led by the Morgan Stanley Group said last night that it had won a three-month battle for control of Burlington Industries, the nation's largest textile producer.

title: Apparent Truce In Crow Dispute
description: An apparent truce was called between the Trammell Crow Company and a group of former executives who quit six months ago to pursue a leveraged buyout of Crow's Chicago real estate holdings. The group, known as Hamilton Partners and based in Itasca, Ill., and Trammell Crow, based in Dallas, said they would exchange interests in jointly owned properties. The former executives, led by Allan J. Hamilton, said they hold majority equity positions in about 27 Chicago-area projects valued at between $620 and $1.3 billion. Neither side would disclose a listing of the properties, or details of the agreement.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: MICHAEL J. FOX, along with several dozen crew members and several tons of equipment, went to Greenwich Village to shoot a film not long ago, and even blase Villagers seemed to enjoy the movie makers' evening visits. As such things go, the events resembled relaxed block parties. A few families brought their dinner out on stoops. Business types on the way home from work lingered and leaned their attache cases and their shopping bags from Jefferson Market and Balducci against garden gates and trees. Parents permitted their children to stay out well past dusk. Pets watched and wagged tails in fascination.

title: IN TRACK, ROADS LEAD TO ROME
description: The sun is blazing. The air is warm and dry. The Santa Cruz mountains loom in the background, providing a majestic view from the stadium at San Jose City College.

title: CELLTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Auctioning Hart
description: When Gary Hart dropped out of the Democratic Presidential race last month, his campaign for the 1984 nomination still owed the National Bank of Washington $556,824. So the bank decided to sell a series of 92 lithographs placed in one of its vaults as collateral for the loan. The lithographs were donated to the Hart campaign by the American artist Robert Rauschenberg. Now, the bank says response to its plan has been so great that it expects to schedule a public auction in the next few weeks.

title: American Wives in Africa: Decades in a Strange Land
description: TWO decades have passed, but the memory is clear. At a civil rights march in Tuscaloosa, Ala., Arlene R. George heard an angry voice shout, ''Go back to Africa!''

title: THINKING ABOUT PLAN B
description: When asked if there is an alternate plan for the 1988 Summer Games, scheduled for South Korea, the leaders of the Olympic movement say there is no such thing.

title: Foreign Debt Of U.S. Soars
description: The debt owed to foreigners by Americans swelled to $263.6 billion in 1986, more than double the $111.9 billion of 1985, according to the Commerce Department.

title: INTERNATIONAL CLINICAL LABOATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
The U.N. Today
NORTH KOREA SEES DANGER IN SOUTH
description: North Korea said today that the situation in South Korea was as dangerous as when the two countries went to war 37 years ago.

title: Market Place; The Aftermath Of Bogus Bid
description: The bogus bid for the Dayton Hudson Corporation has left in its wake an official inquiry, bitter traders who lost millions, questions about news dissemination and fresh rumors concerning the Minneapolis-based retailing giant.

title: MORRIS'S STREAK IS ENDED BY JAYS
description: Rance Mulliniks drove in three runs with his second and third homers of the season and George Bell added his 25th home run tonight as the Toronto Blue Jays beat the Detroit Tigers, 5-3, and snapped Jack Morris's nine-game winning streak.

title: Agreement On Bank Bill
description: House and Senate conferees agreed today to provisions of a banking bill that would give Federal regulators permanent authority to take over banks before they fail and to merge across state lines failing banks and their holding companies if their assets were more than $500 million.

title: JOYNER-KERSEE FIRST, BUT MISSES RECORD
description: A record long jump helped America's foremost female track star, Jackie Joyner-Kersee, to win the heptathlon today in the USA/Mobil Track and Field Championships. But unexpected trouble in the javelin throw, the next-to-last event, kept her from setting the world heptathlon record a third consecutive time.

title: Report Clears VW Managers
description: Volkswagen A.G., which had said it lost more than $250 million in a foreign-currency scandal, said today that an auditors' report had cleared existing management of blame in the matter but found that a former finance chief had neglected his duties.

title: Awards for 3 Black Writers
description: Three women whose writing concerns the black experience in the United States are the recipients of the 1987 Literary Achievement Awards, sponsored by the McDonald's Corporation. The recipients, each of whom was awarded $1,000, are Sylvia Cunningham, a playwright; Lydia Elizabeth Percy Jones, a poet, and Carmel Simmons, a novelist.

title: Allegheny Sells Its Bally Units
description: Allegheny International Inc., said it had sold Bally Engineered Structures Inc. and the Bally division of the Sunbeam Corporation of Canada to the Bally Acquisition Corporation. Terms of the deal were not disclosed. Bally Acquisition was formed by the companies' senior managers. Financing for the sale was provided by Citicorp Capital Investors Ltd.

title: KOCH WARNS ABANDONED-CAR OWNERS OF $500 FINE
description: Mayor Koch warned yesterday that people who abandon cars in New York City would be hunted down and fined $500.

title: PSYCHOLOGIST JOINS '88 RACE ON NEW ALLIANCE PARTY LINE
description: Dr. Leonora Fulani, a psychologist who has previously run for Governor of New York and Mayor of New York City, yesterday announced her candidacy for President. She will run on the New Alliance Party line.

title: COLOR: THE BATTLE OF THE BLOSSOMS
description: BY no means do I count myself in their number, but I intensely admire fellow gardeners who always know what they are doing as regards combinations of color in the flowers they plant. They have visited public gardens and arboretums, making notes about which flowers work with which to please the eye and soothe the soul. They have read the British writer Penelope Hobhouse, and perhaps Louise Beebe Wilder, the American garden writer of the 1920's and 30's who is long overdue for the kind of revival Gertrude Jekyll has had in recent years and whose book ''Color in the Garden'' remains fresh and inspiring.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL YANKEES (AL) - Activated Don Mattingly, first baseman. Sent Dan Pasqua, outfielder, to Columbus of the Internationl League. Signed Martel Edward, pitcher; Dean Kelly, second baseman; Mark Mitchell, infielder-outfielder and Lewellym Hill, outfielder, and assigned them to Oneonta of the New York-Penn League. FOOTBALL TAMPA BAY (NFC) - Signed Jeremiah Castille, cornerback; Frank Garcia, punter, and Tyrone Keys, defensive end. CANADIAN FOOTBALL LEAGUE -Announced that the Montreal Alouettes had folded and that the Winnipeg Blue Bombers had been moved to the Eastern Division. HOCKEY DEVILS (NHL) - Signed Troy Crowder, right wing, to a three-year contract. TUESDAY BASEBALL BALTIMORE (AL) - Signed Doug Corbett, pitcher, to a one-year contract. LOS ANGELES (NL) - Optioned Reggie Williams, outfielder, to Albuquerque of the Pacific Coast League. METS (NL) - Sent Rick Aguilera, pitcher, to Tidewater of the International League under the 20-day rehabilitation program. Signed Todd Hundley, catcher, and Daniel Segui, second baseman.

title: KYRIL P. VASSILEV
description: Kyril P. Vassilev, a portrait painter whose subjects included European royalty and American socialites, died Sunday. He was 79 years old.

title: Easing Seen On Bell Curbs
description: A Federal judge may be ready next week to lift some legal restrictions on the business activities of the regional Bell operating companies, a consultant to the United States Justice Department said today.

title: 2 LEBANESE FREED BUT AMERICAN IS HELD
description: Two Lebanese nationals kidnapped here a week ago with an American journalist were released today, but the journalist, Charles Glass, remained missing.

title: BAKKER CALLS FOR AN END TO THE PTL 'HOLY WAR'
description: Jim Bakker called for an end to the PTL ''holy war'' today and said ''it is up to the people to decide'' whether he and his wife should return to the television ministry he founded.

title: OPPOSITION IN SEOUL REJECTS OFFER BY CHUN AIMED AT ENDING CRISIS
description: South Korea's main opposition party rejected an offer Wednesday from President Chun Doo Hwan to reopen discussions on the critical issue of constitutional change.

title: Devils Sign Crowder
description: The Devils continued to get bigger and younger with the signing yesterday of 19-year-old Troy Crowder, a 6-foot-4-inch, 217-pound wing, who was their sixth-round choice in the 1986 draft. A native of Sudbury, Ontario, Crowder played for the North Bay Centennials of the Ontario Hockey League last season, scoring 11 goals and 16 assists and being assessed 142 minutes in penalties. Max McNab, the general manager, who signed Crowder to a three-year contract, said Crowder ''fits into our mold with strength and physical size.'' Crowder said the Devils had already set up a summer program for him and he hoped to make the team.

title: THE FRESHMAN CLASS: FEW WERE EXPECTED, BUT MANY HAVE ARRIVED
description: College admissions officials are still trying to figure out what hit them.

title: EX-AIDE IN NEW YORK SUES OVER DEMOTION
description: A former New York City deputy environmental protection commissioner has filed suit in Federal court charging the city's Department of Investigation and its commissioner, Kenneth Conboy, with violating his civil rights.

title: New Hahne's President
description: The May Department Stores Company said yesterday that it had named John E. Toler Jr. as president and chief executive of its Hahne's New Jersey department store division. Mr. Toler, 44 years old, is chief executive of May's Robinson's of Florida St. Petersburg division.

title: TUNISIANS UNEASY ABOUT FUTURE AS BOURGUIBA AGES AND HIS GRIP TIGHTENS
description: The wind has risen here, unseasonably ruffling the palms and bougainvillea in a restless land that is caught between a recent past dominated by one man's life and a future clouded by that man's mortality.

title: ANTIQUES AND FUNCTIONAL POTTERY
description: Antiques Show and Sale, East Hampton Historical Society, Main Street at James Lane, East Hampton, L.I.; 516-324-6850.

title: Soviet Doctors Examine Inmate at U.S. Prison
description: Two Soviet eye doctors examined an American Indian leader today at the Federal prison here and recommended treatment with drugs they said were available only in their country.

title: The Blotches on Paul Volcker's Record
description: To the Editor:

title: As the Senate Smiles
description: The Senate floor was nearly deserted yesterday for most of the desultory, daylong debate on the budget. But suddenly, at 2 P.M., not a seat was empty in the chamber as senators crowded in to assure themselves a place in the official Senate photograph for the 100th Congress.

title: GROWING REPLY TO SOCIETY'S ILLS: 'NOT IN MY YARD'
description: In Trenton yesterday, a group called Residents Against Dumping of Noxious Soils (Radons) was trying to present a petition to Governor Kean. On Long Island, Residents Against Garbage Expansion (R.A.G.E.) was demonstrating outside Governor Cuomo's Mineola office. And a mile off Brooklyn was the otherwise nondescript garbage barge that, after leaving Long Island City, became a national metaphor for the ''not in my backyard'' syndrome and that drifts lazily in political limbo a full two months later.

title: Shearson Picks Head Counsel
description: Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. said yesterday that it had named Robert C. Dinerstein executive vice president and general counsel. Mr. Dinerstein, 44 years old, will head the legal department and supervise Shearson Lehman Brothers' outside law firms. He will also be responsible for the secretary's office and corporate insurance.

title: JURY SUBPOENAS BROKERAGE IN INVESTIGATION OF MYERSON
description: A Federal grand jury in Manhattan has subpoenaed records of a stock brokerage firm to determine whether Bess Myerson made mysterious cash deposits there, investigators said yesterday.

title: CHRYSLER IS INDICTED OVER MILEAGE SHOWN ON SOME NEW CARS
description: The Chrysler Corporation was indicted today on charges of fraud for disconnecting the odometers on at least 60,000 cars used by its executives and then selling the cars as new, without the accumulated miles showing.

title: A GOOD START FOR THE OLD GUARD
description: Martina Navratilova admitted that she has been feeling threatened by the younger women on the tour, teen-agers like Steffi Graf of West Germany, who are making the No. 1 ranking feel like 10 women trying to fit into a telephone booth. Chris Evert, on the other hand, said she is a little bit angry about the way the tennis establishment appears eager to proclaim a new order, discarding the old like the pages of a calendar.

title: Borg-Warner Chief Resigns
description: The Borg-Warner Corporation, the diversified manufacturer that was recently sold to Merrill Lynch Capital Partners for $4 billion, said today that its chief executive, Clarence E. Johnson, had resigned. Borg-Warner said that

title: Motion Filed by Deaver To Block Perjury Trial
description: An emergency motion to block the perjury trial of Michael K. Deaver was filed today. The trial is set for July 13.

title: PLAN FOUGHT TO STORE RADIUM-TAINTED SOIL
description: A group of Ocean County residents delivered a petition with 12,000 signatures to Governor Kean's office yesterday, urging him to abandon a plan to store 15,000 drums of radium-contaminated soil in a Jackson Township wildlife preserve.

title: Israeli Arabs Stage a Strike, Charging Unequal Treatment
description: Israeli Arabs staged a general strike today to protest what they call Government discrimination against the 700,000 Arabs who hold Israeli citizenship.

title: MURDER WISH HELD TO BE FREE SPEECH
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that a Texas county constable violated the free speech rights of a clerical employee when he dismissed her for saying she hoped President Reagan would be assassinated.

title: Military Hair
description: How much does it cost for a fighting man to get his hair cut? The General Accounting Office, Congress's investigative agency, has at long last provided an answer.

title: Trademark Show Is Set
description: The Fifth Annual Trademark Exposition will be held here Saturday and Sunday in the Commerce Department Building at 14th Street and Pennsylvania Avenue.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Golf

title: Advertising; New Monthly Is Aimed At Owners of VCR's
description: Some experienced magazine and direct-marketing people are involved in the planning for a new monthly, controlled-circulation magazine that will bring readers news of the world of video cassettes and advertisers an opportunity to sell the readers those cassettes by mail.

title: G.E. Unit Selling $100 Million Issue
description: The General Electric Credit Corporation is offering $100 million of 8 percent notes due in 1990 at a price of 99.80 to yield 8.076 percent through Bear, Stearns & Company.

title: RECORD NASSAU DRUG SWEEP NETS 93 OF 104 INDICTED AS STREET SELLERS
description: A five-month investigation into the sale of crack in Nassau County ended today with the biggest drug sweep in the county's history, officials said.

title: HAIG ASSAILS REAGAN POLICIES AS 'FISCAL FLABBERY'
description: Alexander M. Haig Jr. yesterday criticized the Reagan Administration's policies as ''fiscal flabbery'' that had run up a ''mindless debt.''

title: Dealing Justly With Arms Makers
description: The Justice Department says it erred in indicting James Beggs and other General Dynamics executives for fraudulently mischarging the Army on the Sergeant York gun. Mr. Beggs has been cleared; that's the good news, even though he had to resign as Administrator of NASA and spend the next 19 months defending himself. But the way the Defense Department does business with its weapons contractors remains deeply wrong, in need of overhaul.

title: A 'BIG BORE,' A LA BRASILIA, IN THE MIDDLE OF NIGERIA
description: A European contractor slowed his Mercedes to allow a herd of long-horned cattle to cross a boulevard of this future metropolis and remarked, ''It's easier to make international telephone calls than at home.''

title: COMEDIAN AND ACTOR WAS 71
description: Jackie Gleason, the roly-poly comedian, actor and musician who was one of the leading entertainment stars of the 1950's and 60's, died last night of cancer at his home in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. He was 71 years old.

title: Koreans in New York Rally Around Democracy
description: Oh Sung Chang has lived in New York 11 years, runs a flourishing green grocery and fish store in the Bronx. He owns a home in Jackson Heights, Queens, and is an elder in his church. Although he does not belong to a political party, he and his family took part last weekend in a demonstration by New York's Korean community to demand democracy for Korea.

title: MID-JUNE CAR SALES FELL 11.3%
description: Sales of American-made new cars fell 11.3 percent in mid-June, to 223,376 units, the eight domestic manufacturers reported today. The decline was partly offset by a 7.6 percent increase in sales of light trucks, which often substitute for cars, to a total of 125,193.

title: C.D. Yields Ease a Bit
description: Yields for certificates of deposit fell in the week ended yesterday, while those of bank money market accounts and money market mutual funds were up.

title: Lennon and Guns
description: Can sex be used to combat violence? Michael Beard, president of the Washington-based National Coalition to Ban Hanguns, thinks so. This Saturday at Sotheby's in New York, he said, a set of erotic lithographs by John Lennon will be auctioned off, with the proceeds going to the organization's education programs. The 1970 limited edition of 12 lithographs depicting Lennon's honeymoon with Yoko Ono was contributed by an anonymous donor.

title: ITT Division Is Indicted
description: A Federal grand jury in Boston indicted a unit of the ITT Corporation and one of its former employees on charges of conspiracy to obtain confidential Government information for use in bidding on military contracts, the Justice Department said today.

title: THE PATIENT'S RIGHT TO SELF-DETERMINATION IS THE PRINCIPLE
description: Following are excerpts from the New Jersey Supreme Court opinions in three cases regarding the rights of patients to refuse life-sustaining treatment. In each case, Justice Marie L. Garibaldi wrote the opinion for the court: JOBES CASE

title: No Need for Judicial Screening Committees
description: To the Editor:

title: In Dole's Corner
description: Senator Bob Dole was in New York this week hunting up support for his Presidential campaign. Among those he called on was David A. Stockman, the former budget director to President Reagan who now works on Wall Street.

title: Dayton Pushes Takeover Law
description: The Minnesota Legislature is expected to hold a special session, perhaps as early as this afternoon, to approve a tougher anti-takeover law to help the Dayton Hudson Corporation fend off a hostile bid.

title: EXCERPTS FROM TALKS BETWEEN SOUTH KOREA PRESIDENT AND OPPOSITION CHIEF
description: Following are excerpts from conversations today between President Chun Doo Hwan and Kim Young Sam, the opposition leader. The excerpts, taken from a text prepared by the President's press secretary, who took notes, were translated and distributed by the Government.

title: MORE FROM HEARINGS: THE EX-C.I.A. COUNSEL
description: As the Iran-contra hearings continued in Washington, the Congressional committees heard yesterday from Stanley Sporkin. Here are excerpts from his testimony, as recorded by The New York Times.

title: 10 BEACHES CLOSED BY SEWAGE SPILL
description: Ten beaches were closed as hundreds of thousands of gallons of raw sewage flowed into Hempstead Harbor yesterday when a pump at a sewage plant broke down.

title: Winning Combination
description: John Bayne of Cornell led Ivy League soccer players in scoring last fall with 9 goals and 3 assists for 21 points. The junior mechanical engineering major also led the nation's GTE Academic All-America Men's At-Large university division first team with a 4.18 grade-point average. Bayne seemingly went beyond perfection (4.00) by receiving mostly A-plus grades, which were worth 4.2 in the formulation of his average. Pablo Morales of Stanford, a gold medal-winner in swimming at the 1984 Olympics, also received GTE academic honors for the third time. The squad, chosen by the College Sports Information Directors of America: $ Student, College, Sport Avg. John Bayne, Cornell, soccer 4.18 Joel Coleman, Penn State, track 4.00 John Kerrison, Citadel, soccer 4.00 Jeff Whitman, Arizona State, swimming 4.00 Vince Hughes, Montana, wrestling 3.96 James Martin, Penn State, wrestling 3.94 Paul Gompers, Harvard, track 3.82 Joey Seivold, N.C. State, lacrosse 3.82 Sean O'Neill, Villanova, track 3.67 Pablo Morales, Stanford, swimming 3.25

title: REAL ESTATE SYNDICATOR'S GAIN
description: Winthrop Financial Associates, like many companies that make a living by investing other people's money in real estate, was badly wounded by the uncertainty preceding last year's revision of the tax code.

title: SURGE BY MORELAND KEEPS CUBS ROLLING
description: Rat tails were flying in the clubhouse. White towels - some of them wet, to attain the best results - were rolled around and around until they began to form the shape of a long tail, and then they were snapped in a direction that would create happy harm. In the first week of summer, in the room where the Chicago Cubs were dressing, the presence of the rat tails provided a sign of a happy team.

title: STAINED-GLASS REPAIR
description: WHEN Tom Venturella was a small boy, he used to sit in the choir loft in his hometown church in Indiana and stare at the stained-glass windows, wondering ''how they did that stuff.'' Now Mr. Venturella, one of the few artistans in the city who repair stained glass, knows well how the windows are made.

title: Empty Apartments
description: To the Editor:

title: A SUPPORT NETWORK OF HOSPICE GROUPS FOR DYING CHILDREN
description: ''HOSPICE care is not about death and dying,'' said Ann Armstrong Dailey, founder and executive director of Children's Hospice International. ''It is about life and living.''

title: Roster Selected
description: Lou Nanne, the general manager, and Coach Bob Johnson of Team U.S.A. named 36 National Hockey League players to the training camp roster yesterday.

title: MATTINGLY RETURNS, BUT SO DO ORIOLES
description: The familiar face in the Yankee lineup belonged to Don Mattingly, but there was no time for a celebration of the first baseman's return. Tonight, the Baltimore Orioles struggled back to life.

title: U.S. Acts to Help Ease Scarcity of Farm Workers
description: The Government, moving to ease farmers' fear that perishable crops may rot in the fields, made a concession Tuesday that could bring more migrant laborers into the United States.

title: JUSTICES NARROW MAIL FRAUD SCOPE
description: The Supreme Court today blunted the most potent weapon used by Federal prosecutors against state and local political corruption by rejecting a broad definition of ''mail fraud'' under which dozens of people have been convicted.

title: SPAIN TO ASK U.S. FOR TIMETABLE FOR WITHDRAWL OF 72 JET FIGHTERS
description: Spanish officials negotiating the future of United States military bases in this country intend to ask their American counterparts for a plan for the withdrawal of F-16 fighter planes based outside Madrid, according to Foreign Ministry sources.

title: 'No Deal' for Accused Hijacker, Bonn Assures
description: President Reagan, trying to counter a clamor of criticism from Capitol Hill, said today that Chancellor Helmut Kohl had assured him that West Germany would prosecute Mohammed Ali Hamadei ''to the fullest extent of the law.''

title: The Witness File
description: Name: Stanley Sporkin Age: 55 Position: Judge with the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia. From 1981 to 1986 he was General Counsel for the Central Intelligence Agency. Before that he spent 20 years with the Securities and Exchange Commission, leaving the commission in 1981 as Director of the Enforcement Division. Role: Judge Sporkin drafted the language of the intelligence finding that the President signed on Jan. 17, 1986, authorizing the National Security Council to begin its secret initiative with Iran. He found that certain operations consistent with the President's foreign policy could be kept secret and that notification of Congress could therefore be deferred.

title: Continental's Bid For General Tire
description: Continental Gummi-Werke A.G., West Germany's largest tire maker, said it is raising about $319 million to make a bid for the tire operations of Gencorp. Shareholders approved an increase of 130 million marks, or $71.5 million, in its authorized capital, as well as a new issue of stock warrants and convertible bonds worth up to 450 million marks, or $247.5 million. Continental said the additional money would be used to acquire the General Tire and Rubber Company. Analysts have valued the Gencorp unit at $600 million.

title: 'Witches' Finishes First In Week's Ticket Sales
description: ''The Witches of Eastwick'' sold $8.25 million in tickets last week to win top place at the box office.

title: Toward One Nation, Indivisible
description: Six months have passed since Michael Griffith was killed when he ran out onto the Belt Parkway in Howard Beach, Queens. The vision of blacks being chased by a white mob is one of the most painful in the American experience. It has been burned into our consciousness. Time must not assuage our outrage and our sense of horror.

title: Extradition for Knight?
description: Puerto Rico may attempt to extradite Bobby Knight, the Indiana University basketball coach, to serve a six-month jail sentence for slugging a police officer during the 1979 Pan American Games, an official said yesterday.

title: AT BRADLEY ROAST, BARBS ARE GOOD-NATURED (KIND OF)
description: Seven men who would be President spent several hours Tuesday night paying tribute in ridicule to one who would not - at least not right now.

title: Post-Hart Morality
description: American politics is now afflicted with the application of standards of post-Hart morality to behavior considered private before the Hart downfall. Being good or being careful while running for President is no longer enough; every candidate must now issue denials of rumors of long-ago liaisons, forgotten or imagined.

title: STAGE: 'REDTHROATS'
description: FOLLOWING in the footsteps of Spalding Gray, Eric Bogosian and others, David Cale is the latest performance art monologuist trying to carry his message to a broader audience. One difference is that Mr. Cale is English; another is that his stories have an eeriness as well as an eccentricity. ''The Redthroats,'' a one-hour anthology of four Cale tales, opened last night at the Second Stage.

title: Joy Manufacturing To Go Private
description: Shareholders of the Joy Manufacturing Company have approved a $620 million proposal to take the company private through a leveraged buyout, the company said. Under the plan, each Joy common share would be exchanged for 1.75 shares of redeemable preferred stock in the new company, which will be called Joy Technologies Inc. Each preferred share in Joy Technologies would have an annual dividend rate of $3.25.

title: THE APPLE MUFFIN GAINS IN ALBANY
description: Lobbying by fourth graders got results yesterday as the State Senate unanimously approved a resolution to make the apple muffin the state muffin.

title: SUMMING UP TO DATE: ON SHIPMENTS TO IRAN
description: Following are excerpts from a summary of earlier testimony given to the Congressional committees investigating the Iran-contra affair. The summary, on weapons shipments to Iran, was read by Neil Eggleston, deputy chief counsel to the Senate committee.

title: Reluctant Returnees Slow to Gain Form
description: They were the reluctant returnees, and the performances of most indicate the undermining effect their reluctance has had.

title: CITY BALLET: FRED ASTAIRE IS HONORED IN DANCE
description: IN 1983, Jerome Robbins choreographed and dedicated a ballet to Fred Astaire called ''I'm Old-Fashioned (The Astaire Variations)'' for the New York City Ballet.

title: STAGE: IN LONDON, 'FASHION,' 'MELON' AND 'FAMILY BUSINESS'
description: ''Suddenly, without the slightest warning, the ground opens at your feet,'' says Alan Bates, the utter wreck at the center of Simon Gray's new play, ''Melon.'' Fit, ruddy-faced and as mischievously twinkly-eyed as ever, the actor doesn't look like the ideal candidate to play Mark Melon, a ruthless book publisher headed for the loony bin. Yet before long, Mr. Bates is scuttling on his back on the floor, howling in rage and pain, searching blindly for the terra firma he's lost. The actor not only makes Melon's inner rot seem real, but, amazingly, he does so without forsaking his initial outward dignity. This unsentimental portrayal of emotional collapse is pure, honest acting with no cheap maudlin flourishes. Even Melon's Savile Row pin-striped suit remains firmly in place until the final curtain.

title: GETTING IT HOME IN 3 WEEKS
description: A MONTH ago Jack Carlson, at left above, and Josef Schreick, on sofa, opened Home, James, a furniture and accessories store in East Hampton, L.I. Since Mr. Carlson is also a co-owner of Custom Craft, a company that manufactures upholstered furniture, he guarantees delivery of sofas, sofa beds or love seats to Manhattan or the Hamptons within three weeks of ordering. He and Mr. Schreick, an advertising executive, offer 15 colors in cotton duck and 10 choices of linen. The L-shaped sofa above, the shop's most popular piece of furniture, is $2,700 in cotton and $3,442 in linen; prices include fabric. The cushions have a polyester core wrapped in feathers and down. The 14-inch-square pillows trimmed with grosgrain ribbons on the sofa are $35. The pine gateleg table, above right, is $800 and extends out from 43 1/2 inches to 63 inches; the cotton napkins are 20 by 29 inches and are $2.50 each; the 15-inch lamp on the table is $90, and the 30-inch-high candles, which can burn 24 hours, are $9.50 a pair.

title: Talking Deals; Gillette Testing Standstill Pact
description: THE ''standstill'' agreement, traditionally used to signal a truce in a corporate takeover battle, may be in for some changes because of Ronald O. Perelman.

title: 'CRIME IN THE STREETS'
description: IS white-collar crime growing worse? ''Crime in the Suites,'' part of the Channel 13 series ''Currents,'' says it is. It also says, even if it doesn't quite mean to, that there's not much we can do about this. After all, crime follows money, and money increasingly piles up in places accessible to potential white-collar criminals. Almost anyone, apparently, can steal a million. The provocative program will be shown at 8:30 tonight.

title: Takeover Group Helper Sees Own Firm Bought
description: T. Boone Pickens, Saul Steinberg, Irwin Jacobs, Rupert Murdoch, Robert Maxwell, Sir James Goldsmith, Carl Icahn - all are takeover specialists, and Donald C. Carter has worked for them all.

title: U.S. SEIZES SHOPPING MALL IN HEROIN CASE
description: To shoppers outside San Juan, P.R., the symbol of a chess piece may have meant a place for one-stop shopping.

title: CHILD SEX SCANDAL ROILS UNICEF UNIT
description: The head of the United Nations Children's Fund in Belgium resigned today after the disclosure of a child pornography case linked to the Belgian branch of the organization.

title: FOR COUNTER TOPS: OLD, NEW AND NEWLY FASHIONABLE MATERIALS
description: LEAD: THIS year 4.5 million Americans will decide to throw out their old avocado refrigerators, rip up their plaid linoleum floors and renovate their kitchens, according to the National Kitchen and Bath Association. Then they will be faced with a daunting array of choices, particularly in counter tops, where practical needs vie with esthetic considerations.

title: RELIGIOUS TV: INSTANT FELLOWSHIP, SPIRITUAL FOOD
description: Geraldine Miller says she ''grew up with Jesus'' but was a sinner for most of her life. Ten years ago, she says, she turned to television evangelism after the Lord ''beckoned.''

title: SOUP KITCHENS RISE SHARPLY, REPORT FINDS
description: The number of soup kitchens and food pantries serving meals in New York City has grown from 30 to almost 500 in the last seven years, according to a report issued yesterday.

title: A LONDON EXHIBIT OF STYLISH POTTERY
description: Ceramics designers do not often patent their creations, but in March 1933 a British designer, Susie Cooper, took out a patent on what she called her kestrel tureen, named for a small European falcon. The tureen's round base had handles at its sides, and the cover, when reversed, could stand on its own as a serving dish. ''An ingenious invention,'' declared The Pottery and Glass Record, a trade publication, at the time.

title: Crack Houses, Owned by City Hall
description: With 4,800 homeless families and countless others in search of decent housing, it's odd that New York City would tolerate the loss of apartments to drug dealers. Yet that has happened in about 20 percent of the 5,000 occupied buildings managed by the city's Department of Housing Preservation and Development. In recent months, the police and housing departments have begun an aggressive campaign to protect these buildings. But much tougher action is needed.

title: Financial Concern Might Buy Gruntal
description: The Gruntal Financial Corporation, parent of a major regional brokerage firm, announced yesterday that it was negotiating to sell the company to a financial services concern.

title: ROCK: DURAN DURAN
description: IN the five years since the English pop group Duran Duran rose to glory through a series of flashy music videos that portrayed its good-looking young members frolicking in exotic locales, the original quintet broke up, reunited as a trio and polished its perky pop-funk style to a moderately high gloss.

title: Mugabe Due in Moscow
description: Prime Minister Robert Mugabe is leaving for Moscow today for talks with the Soviet leader, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, a Government spokesman said today. The spokesman said Mr. Mugabe, who last visited Moscow in November 1985, would address the Third World Women's Congress and hold talks with other Kremlin leaders.

title: HERS
description: LEAD: I ALWAYS hated Pollyanna, the most insipid of girlish heroines at a time when the competition was stiff. The only one who came close was Beth in ''Little Women,'' whom even Louisa May Alcott recognized could not be allowed to survive the book. But Pollyanna was worse. Terrible things befell her and everyone around her -paralysis, romantic disappointment, chronic illness - and her response invariably was that they should be glad things weren't worse.

title: SUBJECT OF RUMORS, LAW FIRM ANNOUNCES IT WON'T SPLIT UP
description: Amid rumors that it was about to go the way of so many law firms in this era of breakups, mergers and defections by leading partners and entire departments, one of the largest law firms in the country announced yesterday that it would remain intact.

title: FROM PRESS AGENT TO 'BROADWAY' PRODUCER AT 71
description: The top lines on the Playbill at the Royale Theater say ''Frank Goodman presents.'' Tonight is opening night of ''Broadway,'' the revival of George Abbott's zesty 1926 melodrama about showgirls and gangsters; it's also Mr. Abbott's 100th birthday, and for the first time, Frank Goodman is the producer, not the press agent.

title: Peaceful Shooting
description: Last year, Michael McRory of Fredericksburg, Va., played some basketball games in Yugoslavia, and this summer the 16-year-old will be shooting hoops in the Soviet Union from July 8 to 24.

title: Housing Amendment Gaining
description: A bill that would significantly strengthen the Government's enforcement of the Fair Housing Act of 1968 overcame a major legislative hurdle Monday.

title: Pasqua Sent to Minors
description: Dan Pasqua, whose season with the Yankees has been little more than an ongoing slump, was sent to the minor leagues today so the club could make room on its roster for Don Mattingly, who was activated from the disabled list.

title: G.O.P. PANEL BLOCKS WOMAN
description: The rules committee of the Republican National Committee refused today to add the president of the party's biggest women's group to the national committee.

title: DOW OFF 11.32 AS MARKET MOOD SHIFTS
description: The stock market's mood turned a bit sour yesterday, as the Dow Jones industrial average lost ground for the second straight day.

title: NEW YORK MAKES OFFER TO BE HOST FOR OLYMPICS
description: New York City officials announced yesterday that they would seek to have the 1988 Summer Olympic Games relocated to the metropolitan area if they cannot be held in South Korea. Indianapolis, where the Pan American Games will be held this summer, and Los Angeles, site of the 1984 Olympic Games, have also offered to become substitute host cities if necessary.

title: Waldheim Is in Rome After Protests Are Held
description: President Kurt Waldheim of Austria arrived here quietly tonight for a visit with Pope John Paul II after a day of protests led by Jewish groups.

title: No Headline
description: At an occasionally heated and often colorful three-hour annual meeting yesterday, Steven J. Ross strengthened his grip as chairman of Warner Communications Inc., winning a vote to trim the company's board to 14 members from 15.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: West Berlin and Film

title: American Sues Pan Am
description: American Airlines has filed suit against Pan American World Airways, contending that Pan Am has not lived up to its agreement to merge the carriers' frequent flyer programs and also that it owes American $4.4 million. Pan Am declined comment on the suit, which was filed in Federal District Court in Manhattan. American, a unit of the AMR Corporation, said it would drop the suit if Pan Am paid the $4.4 million.

title: Waldheim and the Pope
description: To the Editor:

title: Uncovered Nasdaq Short Sales Increased 3.3% in Month Ended June 15
description: The National Association of Securities Dealers reported yesterday that the number of shares sold short and not yet covered rose 7.8 million shares, or 3.3 percent, to 246.8 million shares in the month ended June 15.

title: Paying Twice to Ruin a Rain Forest
description: Here's a Federal plan so wrongheaded it's likely to provoke profanity from any fair-minded person: 1. Find a rare rain forest full of magnificent old trees. 2. Set aside millions of acres in the forest for logging, even though there's plenty of timber on the market. 3. Since the value of the timber therefore can't possibly cover the costs of cutting roads deep into the wilderness, give a Government agency all the money it needs to bulldoze the forest. 4. To insure that the taxpayers don't balk, make the appropriation permanent, thus averting regular review by Congress.

title: Conseco Markets Debt and Equity
description: Conseco Inc., a holding company that acquires, owns and operates life insurance companies, yesterday priced a $300 million offering of debt and equity through underwriters led by Dean Witter Reynolds.

title: KEY RATES
Hurdles to Investing in China Are Being Toppled
description: To the Editor:

title: LONDON AGOG OVER FROLICS OF PRINCESSES
description: The British tabloid press is in the throes of one of its periodic obsessions with the younger members of the British royal family, but this time the coverage of the Princess of Wales has taken an even more sensational and potentially damaging tone.

title: Primark Picks An Economist
description: Joseph E. Kasputys, executive vice president at McGraw-Hill Inc., has been named president and chief operating officer of the Primark Corporation and will be in line to succeed Robert W. Stewart, Primark's 63-year-old chairman and chief executive. Primark, based in McLean, Va., runs four principal businesses, the largest being a gas utility serving most of Michigan. It also operates a fleet of aircraft for such overnight delivery services as United Parcel, Emery, Purolator and Flying Tiger. It runs a satellite network link for 600 hospitals that transmits medical information, and it is in financial services Mr. Kasputys, 50 years old, is an economist who has been president of Data Resources Inc. and was Assistant Secretary of Commerce in the Ford Administration. ''This will be a real test of whether an economist can run a company,'' Mr. Kasputys quipped yesterday.

title: Focusing on Iran after Khomeini
description: LEAD: Americans are understandably frustrated with the Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini. Our larger interests in the Persian Gulf demand a firm response to Iranian threats, but we also need to remember that Iran remains a strategic prize and that, inevitably, change will come after the Khomeini regime ends. We should therefore chart our policy course prudently, with regard for the long view of history.

title: Conspiracy Hearing
description: Bob Horner, the former Atlanta home-run hitter, is hitting home runs in Japan these days, and his agent, Bucky Woy, told baseball's impartial arbitrator in New York yesterday the circumstances behind his move. Woy and Gary Wichard, agent for Steve Balboni of Kansas City, testified on the second day of the hearing concerning the charge by the baseball players' union that the owners conspired against free agents last winter.

title: Q&A
description: Q.Three eight-foot-tall mirrors are on the wall in my daughter's bedroom. They were put up with only a silicone adhesive; no brackets or clips were used. The wall contains hot-water pipes to a dishwasher on the other side. I read that mirrors so mounted can come crashing down, so I am very concerned about my daughter's safety. The company that installed the mirrors says they are perfectly safe. What is your opinion? A.Adhesive is often used by itself to hold mirrors on walls, but I prefer anchors. These should go through the wall's surface, so that screws can be inserted into them through holes drilled in the mirror. Mirror brackets can be installed around the edges instead.

title: INSIDE
description: North to Testify

title: POP: LUTCHER AND MORSE
description: TWO echoes of the 1940's -Nellie Lutcher and Ella Mae Morse - have come East from California for New York club appearances, which for Miss Lutcher are extremely rare and for Miss Morse mark a club debut. They will be sharing the stage at Michael's Pub, 211 East 55th Street, through July 11.

title: KILLER OF 25 IS DENIED PAROLE
description: A parole board rejected Juan Corona's bid for freedom Tuesday after hearing a psychiatric report that said the mass murderer would be ''extremely dangerous'' if released from prison. Mr. Corona, who was convicted in the murders of 25 seasonal farm workers 16 years ago, sat impassively as the decision by the three-member board was read. The board told Mr. Corona that he must wait three years for another chance for parole, the maximum period allowed by state law.

title: 27 YEARS OF MARIO BELLINI'S DEFT DESIGNS
description: ONE of the most important objects in ''Mario Bellini: Designer,'' a retrospective exhibition of the work of the 52-year-old Italian architect and industrial designer that opens today, might very well be the drawing that hangs just inside the entrance to the show at the Museum of Modern Art.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE HOTTENTOT ROOM. By Christopher Hope. 218 pages. Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $16.95.

title: JWT's Board to Consider Offers
description: The board of JWT Group Inc. will meet within the next two days to consider proposals for the acquisition of the ''entire company,'' it announced late yesterday.

title: ADDICT IS EXECUTED IN TEXAS FOR SLAYNG OF 2 IN ROBBERY
description: A man convicted of murder who blamed drugs for his problems was executed by injection early today after apologizing to his family and friends for the trouble he had caused them.

title: Caltech Names New Head
