description: Thomas E. Everhart, chancellor of the University of Illinois, has been named president of the California Institute of Technology. Mr. Everhart, 55 years old, an electrical engineer with a background in the physical sciences, will succeed Marvin L. Goldberger, 64, who has been Caltech's president for nine years, the university said Tuesday.

title: High Court Allows Churches Widened Leeway in Hiring
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that nonprofit religious organizations may legally discriminate on religious grounds in hiring, even if the job involved is of a secular nature.

title: Not Guilty Plea in Florida
description: Elton Gissendanner, whose eight-year reign as chief of the State Department of Natural Resources ended with a criminal charge Monday, pleaded not guilty today to extortion and said he had no doubt he would be cleared. Mr. Gissendanner was charged by a Federal grand jury of using his official position to extort $80,000 in bribes from a convicted marijuana smuggler who had sought a lenient sentence. Mr. Gissendanner, 59 years old, appeared before a Federal Magistrate, who set a $100,000 signature bond for the defendant. He announced earlier this year that he would retire July 1 but resigned after the indictment was returned.

title: A Majority of Britons Lose to the System
description: To the Editor:

title: Pohl Gets 2d Term At Bundesbank
description: The West German Government named Karl Otto Pohl yesterday to a second eight-year term as president of the Bundesbank, confirming his unofficial position as the dean of central bankers among industrialized nations.

title: 2 INQUIRIES MAY BE TIED THROUGH SYRACUSE FIRM
description: An engineering firm under investigation because of possible ties to the executive director of the state's Thruway Authority has also been implicated in an investigation of the former Mayor of Syracuse, law-enforcement officials said today.

title: Michigan Legislature Bans Abortion Funds
description: The Michigan Legislature approved a ban on state financing of abortion Tuesday, but a judge stayed enforcement of the law until he could rule on a dispute over the effective date.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The Chancellor has assured us that there will be no deal, and they will not grant him clemency.'' - President Reagan, on West Germany's plan to try Mohammed Ali Hamadei. [ A9:2. ]

title: ARREST IS ENDED FOR A KEY DISSENTER
description: For the first time in 78 days, the police barricades came down late Wednesday night as Kim Dae Jung, the Government's most vocal critic, was freed from house arrest.

title: The U.N. Today: June 25, 1987
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: DRUG FEUD CITED
description: Two people were killed and another was critically wounded in a Bronx housing project early yesterday in what the police called the latest in a series of drug-related attacks between two feuding families.

title: U.S. SETS RULES ON 8 CHEMICALS IN PUBLIC WATER
description: The Enviromental Protection Agency announced rules today to protect drinking water from vinyl chloride, benzene and six other widely used chemicals that can cause cancer or other diseases.

title: Glenfed Names Coulson
description: Glenfed Inc. said yesterday that Norman M. Coulson, the president and vice chairman of the nation's fifth-largest thrift institution, would add the duties of chief executive officer, effective July 1, completing a planned succession begun in 1985. Mr. Coulson, 54 years old, succeeds Raymond D. Edwards, who will retain the post of chairman at Glenfed. The holding company is the parent of Glendale Federal Savings and Loan Association, based in Glendale, Calif. Mr. Edwards, 68, will no longer participate in day-to-day operations, Mr. Coulson said.

title: EDWARD BLANCHARD JR.
description: Edward P. Blanchard Jr., a former magazine executive, died of cancer Monday in Stamford (Conn.) Hospital. He was 63 years old and lived in Greens Farms, Conn.

title: ESKIMOS AWARDED $10 MILLION IN SUIT
description: An organization of about 2,100 Eskimos has won a $10 million judgment against a Fairbanks bank in a legal action that is considered a milestone in the evolution of Alaska's native corporations as managers of their wealth.

title: HUMANIZING ELECTRONICS AND TECHNOLOGY
description: MARIO BELLINI has an emotional attachment to objects. ''We need to touch objects,'' the Italian architect and designer said in a recent conversation about his life and his attitudes toward design. ''We filter our relationship to the outside world through our hands, our fingers, ears, eyes and nose. We need objects that relate to the senses.''

title: ASSEMBLY PANEL PASSES YANKEES TV BILL
description: A bill intended to require the New York Yankees to broadcast more of their games on standard televison channels and fewer on pay cable outlets was passed overwhelmingly by an Assembly committee today. But it is being blocked in the Senate by the lawmaker who earlier this week killed a bill requiring sports teams to set aside stadium seats where alcoholic beverages could not be consumed.

title: SHRINKING TRADE DEFICIT HERALDS ECONOMIC SHIFT
description: Thanks to the prolonged decline of the dollar, the United States has seen the worst of the extraordinary deficits in its trade, economists, businessmen and other experts are now persuaded. The shrinking deficits, they add, spell important changes in the behavior of the economy and could blunt the efforts in Congress to impede imports.

title: New York Business Relocation in New Jersey Has Its Pitfalls
description: To the Editor:

title: BALLET: WORLD CONTEST BEGINS AT CITY CENTER
description: There were official proclamations from Governor Cuomo and Mayor Koch. The stage was ringed with an international panel of judges. The tri-annual New York International Ballet Competition had returned to City Center, 131 West 55th Street, where the dancers will compete in public performances through Sunday afternoon, ending with a gala on Monday.

title: 'FIRST AMONG EQUALS'
description: JUST in time to enliven the summer schedule with a bit of harmless entertainment, a 10-part syndicated British series called ''First Among Equals'' gets under way tonight at 10 on Channel 13. This is Derek Marlow's adaptation of a novel by Jeffrey Archer, former Member of Parliament and, until a sex scandal broke in the newspapers, a minister in Margaret Thatcher's Cabinet. ''First Among Equals'' is about public politics, private lives and grubby scandals. The ring of authenticity is genuine.

title: ORNETTE COLEMAN GROUPS
description: ORNETTE COLEMAN'S music can sound festive and frantic, encompassing and overloaded. In the alto saxophonist's concert Tuesday at Town Hall with his 1960's quartet and his current septet Prime Time, it was all those things - and it was triumphant. As Mr. Coleman enters his third decade as a major figure in jazz, his blueprint for music that mirrors the complexity of 20th-century living - jazz that layers melodies and rhythms and improvisations in a dense counterpoint - has gathered an audience that hears the swirl and flux as an up-to-the-minute groove.

title: RIGHT OF PATIENTS WHO WISH TO DIE WIDENED IN JERSEY
description: In three rulings today, the New Jersey Supreme Court expanded the right of individuals to refuse life-sustaining medical treatment, and said the patients' interests must come before those of the state.

title: Federal Prisoner Wins Status as 'Employee'
description: A Federal convict who was dismissed from a prison clerical job for complaining of exposure to hazardous fumes has won lost pay and privileges in a legal settlement with the United States Bureau of Prisons.

title: Mantle Offers Expert Opinion
description: Mickey Mantle should know something about hitting home runs. He slugged 536, the seventh-highest career total, during his 18 major league seasons. So what are his thoughts about the surprising number of homers being hit this season?

title: LONG LIVES THE QUEEN: THE PASSION FOR VICTORIANA
description: HAD she not reigned for more than half a century, the frumpy little lady in lace might not have become the icon of an age. But, like a curl of pressed baby's hair in a locket, endure Queen Victoria did.

title: Jersey Housing Agency Offers Bonds in 2 Series
description: The New Jersey Housing and Mortgage Finance Agency is tentatively offering $140 million of bonds in two series through underwriters led by Bear, Stearns & Company.

title: New President Named At Viking Penguin
description: The president of New American Library, Marvin Brown, will become president of Viking Penguin on July 13, it was announced yesterday by the executive chairman of Viking Penguin, Peter Mayer, who is chief executive of the Penguin group's publishing houses here and abroad.

title: WYNTON MARSALIS
description: DIZZY GILLESPIE'S 70th birthday, which occurs on Oct. 21, was celebrated at a JVC Jazz Festival concert at Carnegie Hall on Tuesday evening by Mr. Gillespie and a specially assembled big band and by one of his trumpet successors, Wynton Marsalis, who paid homage to Mr. Gillespie with a performance that was part lecture, part demonstration but primarily a skillful and admiring re-creation, with his quartet, of some of Mr. Gillespie's more famous solos.

title: ARID MADRAS GOES TO WELL AT CITY HALL
description: Jeppiar, a much-besieged politician who runs the city waterworks, keeps his own metal flask of cold water in a side room apart from the madding crowds of constituents coming to hunt water each of these brazen days, talking in mesmerized snatches of the thirsty wait for the monsoon as if it were Godot.

title: General Kelley's Farewell
description: When the senior commander of one of the military services steps aside, the usual questions are: What mark did he leave? How will the historians recall his tenure?

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: OPERA: THREE WORKS IN ST. LOUIS
description: ST. LOUIS, June 22 - In opera, we learn repeatedly, big is not necessarily better. The Opera Theater of St. Louis, for example, which completed its 12th season last weekend, has been one of the more ambitious and lively operatic producers in the country on a budget that, at $3 million, is a fraction of what the largest American companies possess.

title: TAKING ADVANTAGE OF MUSICAL TECHNOLOGY
description: TECHNOLOGY proceeds apace at rock concerts. Recent visits to such events on both coasts have confirmed - in a way that more regular, night-after-night attendance might blur -how rapidly certain aspects of rock amplification have evolved.

title: 2 ACTORS' UNIONS WAGE TRANS-ATLANTIC BATTLE
description: Andrew Lloyd Webber has written half a dozen of the most successful shows in musical theater history and made millions in London and New York, but his wife, a British actress, can't get a job on Broadway. Mr. Lloyd Webber is angry, and his anger threatens a New York production of ''Phantom of the Opera,'' perhaps his biggest hit ever. As a result, the theater worlds on both sides of the Atlantic are in an uproar.

title: SOVIET CRITIC OF ECONOMY IN SPOTLIGHT
description: During a cocktail party at the American Ambassador's residence the other night, Nikolai P. Shmelyov found himself trying to persuade an attentive circle of Westerners that he is not a ''closet capitalist'' or someone who believes that unemployment is good.

title: END OF INCINERATOR PLAN CITED
description: The New York City Department of Sanitation has agreed to drop plans to build a controversial garbage incinerator in the Inwood section of Upper Manhattan, Bronx Borough President Fernando Ferrer announced yesterday.

title: HOLLYWOOD FILMS ENTER AIDS ERA
description: In ''Dragnet,'' an escapist summer comedy that opens at 1,330 theaters Friday, Tom Hanks rolls over in bed, casts a lustful look at his blond companion, reaches for a box of condoms, finds it empty, tosses it away and gives up on the idea of a little hanky-panky before he has to go to work. The first AIDS-influenced movie has reached the screen.

title: METS DEFEAT CUBS ON ALMON HIT IN 9TH
description: The Mets reached back into their 1986 book of memories last night and staged a pair of old-fashioned rallies that tied the Chicago Cubs in the eighth inning and defeated them in the ninth, 2-1.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: A RADIAL ARM SAW is by far the most versatile and in many ways the easiest and most convenient stationary power saw. The circular blade and high-speed motor, unlike those of a table saw, hang from an overhead arm so that for most cuts the lumber remains stationary on the table while the blade is pulled across the wood.

title: 2 Holes-in-One
description: Greg Snyder, a 17-year-old playing in an amateur golf tournament, scored holes-in-one on two par-3 holes yesterday. According to officials in East Aurora, N.Y., Snyder, a resident of Elma, N.Y. which is outside Buffalo, was playing in the international junior masters tournament on the 6,515-yard East Aurora Country Club course when he registered the two aces. His first came on the 243-yard, fourth hole with a 1-iron and his second on the 178-yard eighth hole with a 4-iron. ''It was amazing,'' said Tony Smith, the director of the tournament, which included players from 17 states, Canada and Mexico. Smith said both holes played to an elevated green and the players could see only the flagstick, not the cup.

title: AN EVENING OF BARGAINS IN A GARAGE
description: IT had the glamour of a black-tie benefit, but the irresistible allure of a drop-dead bargain. It looked like a gala, but worked like a garage sale.

title: JOSEPH S. BOLAND
description: Joseph S. Boland, an actor who appeared on the original ''Tonight Show,'' ''Love of Life,'' and ''Playhouse 90'' on television, died here Sunday. He was 83 years old.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: THURSDAY, JUNE 25, 1987
description: The Economy

title: Bridge: Certain Opening Three-Bids May Be Crazy or Aggressive
description: In favorable circumstances, not vulnerable against vulnerable, a player can be undisciplined in selecting an opening three-bid. But how far one should go in this direction has long been a matter for debate.

title: REPORT QUOTES NORTH ON WHY HE SOUGHT U.S. RAID ON LIBYA
description: Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North argued in favor of bombing Libya in April 1986, in part, he said, because of reports that Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi's Government had offered to buy six American hostages held in Lebanon for $100 million, according to a magazine article that appeared today.

title: How To Win a Million at the Track
description: A MR. BOYARS got to Belmont Park early yesterday, at 10 in the morning, three hours before the first race.

title: HELPING GARDENS TO THRIVE
description: GARDENERS are always searching for ways to improve their chances for success. Here is a roundup of some of newest products.

title: BankAmerica Study Urged
description: A top Japanese banker said today that the BankAmerica Corporation's appeal for $350 million in fresh capital should be carefully studied.

title: Travels With Reagan
description: Representative Dick Cheney, Republican of Wyoming, says President Reagan's attack on the Democratic budget in a Florida political speech on Monday was ''very useful'' to the President and Republican Party. Mr. Cheney rejects arguments that Mr. Reagan was merely trying to divert attention from embarrassing disclosures in the Congressional hearings on the Iran-contra affair.

title: SOVIET TO PUBLISH 'WE'
description: Soviet authorities plan to publish Yevgeny Zamyatin's ''We,'' a long-banned, anti-totalitarian novel that many Western critics say was a prototype for George Orwell's ''Nineteen Eighty-Four,'' a Soviet writer said.

title: ELLIS I. MEETING CENTER BACKED
description: The Statue of Liberty-Ellis Island Centennial Commission rejected plans today for a hotel on Ellis Island in favor of a conference center and museum.

title: DEADLY WEAPON IN AIDS VERDICT IS INMATE'S TEETH
description: A prison inmate who bit two guards after testing positive for the AIDS virus was found guilty today of assault with a deadly and dangerous weapon: his mouth and teeth.

title: A South African Judge Upholds Shanty Town
description: A South African court ordered a white town council today to rebuild two black shanty homes it had demolished, a ruling hailed by civil rights workers as a breakthrough for shanty-town residents.

title: Reagan Checkup Set In Capital Tomorrow
description: On Friday President Reagan will have his regular six-month follow-up examination resulting from the colon cancer surgery he had in July 1985, the White House said today.

title: Computerland Sale
description: The Computerland Corporation of Oakland, Calif., said it had sold Computerland Japan Ltd. to the Catena Corporation, an office computer automation company. Catena, which is based in Tokyo, has been Computerland's Japanese operating company, operating 36 stores, nine of which Catena owned. Retail sales for the group for 1986 were 6 billion yen, or about $33.8 million, Computerland said. While the sale price of the operating company was not disclosed, terms of the purchase include a 99-year licensing agreement for the use of the Computerland name and access to its worldwide distribution system.

title: UNIVERSITY LIBRARIAN IS CALLED EMBEZZLER
description: The head librarian at the University of New Haven has been suspended without pay following allegations that he embezzled at least $150,000 from the university.

title: LORIMAR REFOCUSING, SETS SELLOFF
description: In a retreat from its sweeping diversification strategy, the Lorimar-Telepictures Corporation said today that it would sell its advertising agencies, television stations and publishing operations.

title: Merc Fines Bache $100,000
description: The Chicago Mercantile Exchange said today that it had fined Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. $100,000 for rule infractions.

title: TAX FORM FOR CHILDREN FAR FROM CHILD'S PLAY
description: The Internal Revenue Service today introduced the complicated and lengthy new tax form that hundreds of thousands of parents must fill out for their children under the new tax law.

title: Citicorp Notes Set For 8.73% Yield
description: Citicorp began selling $100 million of four-year notes yesterday through a group of underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: Kinder-Care Seeks Florida Thrift Unit
description: Kinder-Care Inc., a day-care provider, plans to buy the American Savings and Loan Association of Miami for about $138 million, American's chairman said. Kinder-Care Inc., which operates day-care centers, owns Centerbanc Savings Association of St. Petersburg, Fla.

title: Panhandle Eastern Ends Contract
description: The Anadarko Petroleum Corporation said that the Panhandle Eastern Pipe Line Company had terminated its contract with the natural gas company after the two sides failed to agree on price. Anadarko said its subsidiary, Pan Eastern Exploration, and Panhandle Eastern had tried to renegotiate the terms of about 40 previous gas contracts since March 18.

title: Chez Shultz, a Longing For a Stately House
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz's dream for an official residence receded a bit further last week.

title: SEX-ABUSE TRIAL IN JERSEY HEARS BOY, 6, TESTIFY
description: A 6-year-old boy testified today in the sex-abuse trial of a former teacher, saying that ''many things'' had happened to him at the Wee Care Day Nursery in Maplewood, N.J., that he did not want to talk about. He then grew agitated and asked to go home when pressed with further questions.

title: Advertising; Media Man Stresses Negotiation
description: AFTER 32 years at Young & Rubicam, many of them as head of the media operation, Joseph W. Ostrow is now ensconced a couple of blocks away at FCB/Leber Katz Partners. He is both media director for that agency and, as an executive vice president, worldwide media czar for Foote, Cone & Belding Communications.

title: NORTH TO BEGIN PUBLIC TESTIMONY JULY 7
description: Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North will begin publicly testifying July 7 before the Congressional committees investigating the Iran-contra affair, according to an arrangement between the committees and Colonel North's lawyer that was announced today.

title: REPLACING CHAIR SEATS WITH TAPE
description: LEAD: REPLACING the seat of a chair with a colorful weave of cotton webbing in the style known as Shaker taping is not very demanding. Anyone with average hand skills should have no difficulty weaving an average-size seat in a couple of hours. However, a little extra time given to the making and securing of a permanent cushion makes all the difference in appearance and comfort.

title: DICK HYMAN ON SOLO PIANO
description: DICK HYMAN'S early evening solo piano performance at Weill Recital Hall on Tuesday offered a diverting change of pace from the usual format of the JVC Jazz Festival's pre-twilight series. Instead of demonstrating his own considerable improvisational virtuosity, Mr. Hyman played a tribute to Irving Berlin, with special attention to songs associated with the late Fred Astaire. More song- than jazz-oriented, Mr. Hyman's approach emphasized the fundamentals of American jazz piano in simple, deft ragtime and stride arrangements that used contemporary ornamentation only sparingly.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: THURSDAY, JUNE 25, 1987
description: International A3-17

title: Wickes to Sell Two Businesses
description: The Wickes Companies, a retail and manufacturing conglomerate, said it was selling its Nazareth/Century apparel company and certain units of its Simmons Universal Corporation. Terms were not disclosed, but the buyers are separate investor groups, which include some members of management.

title: Giuliani Seeks Larger Staff
description: Rudolph W. Giuliani, the United States Attorney for Manhattan, is seeking to expand the number of lawyers assigned to investigate insider trading on Wall Street.

title: CENTER STAGE ON COURT 12
description: For three years, he was the No. 1 singles player at Harvard, a European history major who worked in the press box at the United States Open, charting matches, running errands for the higher-ups. Today, however, Larry Scott was center stage, even if it was Court No. 12 at the All England Club.

title: Ecuador Finance Chief
description: President Leon Febres Cordero appointed a new finance minister today after accepting the resignation of Domingo Cordovez, a senior Government official said. The new minister, Rodrigo Espinosa, was general manager of Ecuador's central bank from 1976 to 1979.

title: Prison Term in Plot To Kill Husband
description: A woman who tried to borrow $2,000 from her first husband to have her second husband killed was sentenced yesterday to two to six years in prison for what the judge said was a ''very cold-blooded'' act.

title: Cooper to Spin Off Laser Operations
description: Cooper Lasersonics Inc. of Palo Alto, Calif., said it plans to spin off its laser business as a separate public company by January 1988. The proposed spinoff would create Cooper Lasers Inc., a surgical laser company with annual revenues of about $50 million. Cooper Lasersonics would become Cooper Cavitron Inc., an ultrasonics-products company with revenues of about $20 million.

title: Toshiba Plans Study of Unit
description: The Toshiba Corporation will investigate how its subsidiary Toshiba Machine illegally exported high-technology products to the Soviet Union, a company spokesman said today.

title: IMPLICATED IN GRAFT, EX-JUDGE IS A SUICIDE
description: A former Cook County judge who had been implicated in a bribery scheme and reportedly faced indictment this week shot himself in the head and died Monday.

title: Advertising; Della Femina to Handle Sunshine Biscuits
description: Della Femina, Travisano & Partners has been named agency for American Brands' Sunshine Biscuits, maker of cookies, crackers and snacks.

title: BATTLE OVER TAXES BEGINS
description: The Democratic-controlled Senate approved a $1 trillion 1988 budget today by a 53-to-46 vote, ending the first round of this year's budget battle between Congress and the White House.

title: BONN TO TRY HIM IN HIJACKING
description: West Germany announced today that it would not extradite a hijacking suspect to the United States but would try him in West Germany on charges of air piracy and murder.

title: RESTORING OLD HOUSES
description: If a family has bought a 19th- or early-20th century house that has withstood years of painting, wallpapering and repairs, the New York State Historical Association offers a weeklong seminar on how to restore and preserve this piece of history.

title: Bonds Fall in Dull Trading
description: Bond prices sagged in sluggish trading yesterday, a decline that once again was touched of by a drop in the value of the dollar overseas.

title: Champion Colt Heads Trot
description: Mack Lobell, the champion 2-year-old trotting colt in 1986, will make his first appearance as a 3-year-old Sunday night in the Yonkers Trot, the first leg of trotting's triple crown.

title: KOREA CARDINAL ASKS CHUN FOR DIRECT ELECTION
description: South Korea's Roman Catholic Primate called on President Chun Doo Hwan on Thursday to allow direct presidential elections.

title: G.O.P. CONTRIBUTIONS FALL AMID IRAN-CONTRA AFFAIR
description: The Republican national chairman said today that contributions to the party had dropped by about 8 percent this year and that the Republicans would have to cut their annual budget by about $2.9 million.

title: The Witness File
description: Name: Charles J. Cooper Age: 35 Position: Assistant Attorney General in the Justice Department's Office of Legal Counsel. Mr. Cooper started at the Justice Department in 1981 in the Civil Rights Division working as Special Assistant to William Bradford Reynolds. Before that he was a law clerk for Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist. Role: At the request of Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d, Mr. Cooper directed the Justice Department investigation of the arms sales to Iran.

title: OSICOM TECHNOLOGIES reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: The year-ago first quarter ended June 30, 1986. The company changed its fiscal year to end Jan. 31. Osicom said its initial public offering was made June 3.

title: DISTRUST BETWEEN OPPOSING FORCES LEAVES THE GAP UNBRIDGED, THE CRISIS UNCHANGED
description: On the first day in two months that he was not under house arrest, Kim Dae Jung never left his house Thursday.

title: SHL SYSTEMHOUSE reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $3,273,000 for the quarter and $8,484,000 for the 9 months. c-Includes tax credits of $1,399,000 for the quarter and $2,993,000 for the 9 months. The share earnings for latest and previous years take into account a 2-for-1 split announced in December 1986. The results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Justices to Finish Their Term Today
description: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist announced today that the Supreme Court will conclude its 1986-87 term Friday morning by issuing the rest of its decisions in cases argued this term.

title: COLUMBIA SHOWCASES 6 ARTISTS
description: A VIRTUOSIC young soprano saxophonist, Jane Ira Bloom, was the freshest musical talent to be heard Wednesday evening at Town Hall where half a dozen jazz artists affiliated with Columbia Records gathered for a JVC Jazz Festival concert that offered a potpourri of styles ranging from sultry pop-funk fusion to New Orleans boogie piano.

title: Ignored Distinction
description: To the Editor:

title: JOHN PAUL HOLDS WALDHEIM MEETING
description: Pope John Paul II received Kurt Waldheim today as an honored state visitor to the Vatican. He praised the Austrian President for a lifetime of activities on behalf of peace but made no mention of the controversy surrounding his service as a German Army officer in World War II.

title: HIGH COURT BARS SUITS BY THOSE IN THE MILITARY
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that military personnel cannot sue the Government or superior officers for damages even for gross and deliberate violations of their constitutional rights. It also held that military personnel may be court-martialed for crimes unrelated to their service.

title: ANYTHING GOES WHEN ITS HOT
description: Hot days call for drastic measures. If you are taking Bowser out for a stroll, pull your hair up off your neck - or cut it short. And wear a strapless top. Better still, wear a backless top, which looks great with toreador pants and flat shoes. It is also a good idea to stay plugged into your Walkman, to keep up with the latest developments in the weather. Is that a cold front blowing in, or is it just static?

title: Blyleven Masters Niekro and Indians
description: Dan Gladden, Kent Hrbek and Roy Smalley hit home runs in support of Bert Blyleven, who won a battle of pitching old-timers with Phil Niekro in the Minnesota Twins' 4-3 victory over the Cleveland Indians.

title: HERBIE HANCOCK TRIO
description: A BROKEN G string on the piano didn't prevent Herbie Hancock from playing a luminous set Wednesday at Carnegie Hall. With Buster Williams on bass and Al Foster on drums, Mr. Hancock's trio played mercurial uptempo pieces and - for most of the set - pensive, elliptical ballads with piano solos poised on the outer edges of tonal harmony.

title: Science Fiction
description: Star Trek, Marvel comics and science-fiction exotica are to appear in abundance tomorrow and Sunday at Creation Convention '87 at the Roosevelt Hotel, at 45th Street and Madison Avenue. Previews of coming movies, television stars and comic-book creators, outlandish costume parades and dealers selling posters, books and assorted paraphernalia are all to be there. Tickets are $15 ($12 in advance through Ticketron); $7 for children. Hours are 11 A.M. to 7 P.M. Information: (718) 343-0202.

title: SCIENTISTS RECEIVE MEDALS FROM REAGAN
description: President Reagan today presented the nation's highest awards for achievement in science and technology, lauding the winners as ''the heroes of the modern age.''

title: Art Blakey
description: Art Blakey, a drummer, will lead the Jazz Messengers tonight through Sunday at Sweet Basil, 88 Seventh Avenue South, above Bleecker Street (212-242-1785). Sets are at 10 and 11:45 P.M. and 1:30 A.M; there is a $12 cover and a $6 minimum.

title: UNIVAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: The latest first quarter results reflect the acquisition of McKesson Chemical Co., effective Nov. 1, 1986.

title: Bronfman Stake In Metals Concern
description: An investment group led by Charles R. Bronfman, co-chairman of the board of the Seagram Company Ltd., has purchased the equivalent of 11.3 percent of Campbell Resources Inc.

title: Even the Czar Faced Anchor-Draggers
description: LEAD: What a difference a year makes! A year ago in Leningrad, Soviet economists bitterly defended the economic status quo and criticized a foreign visitor who dared to suggest that radical reform might be necessary. Some of their counterparts in Moscow had begun to share foreigners' doubts, but in outlying areas the word had yet to filter down that now ''criticism'' was in and ''defensiveness'' was out.

title: GARDEN APARTMENTS FIND A NEW LIFE IN CO-OP ERA
description: In the first two postwar decades, the garden apartment became one of the most widespread forms of middle-income rental housing in the nation's suburbs.

title: 'They Have Souls Too' Looks at Mentally Ill
description: What should we do with the mentally ill? ''They Have Souls Too'' doesn't know; it doesn't pretend to. What it does do, however, is to ask the question with grace and care. The ABC News ''Closeup'' documentary, on Channel 7 at 8:30 tonight, looks, as it says, ''at the human face of madness.'' The portrait may sometimes be grim, but always it is sensitively and intelligently done.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: CELEBRATIONS all over town saluted the arrival of summer and supported some worthy causes. One of the prettiest parties was the dinner-dance Wednesday night at the Tavern on the Green that honored Selma Weiser, the founder of Charivari, and an entire neighborhood joined in.

title: PENOBSCOT SHOE CO reports earnings for Qtr to May 29
description: b-Net loss The latest 6 months' net includes an after-tax gain of $186,000 from the sale of fixed assets and an after-tax gain of $70,000 from the sale of securities.

title: U.S. INDICTS 10 COMPANIES ON ROAD BIDS
description: Ten road-construction companies and 10 of their executives were indicted yesterday on charges of conspiring to rig bids for repairing state highways and local roads in Westchester and Orange Counties.

title: Wickes Stock
description: The Wickes Companies said it planned a 1-for-5 reverse stock split, which would reduce its outstanding common stock in August to 47.8 million shares, from 239 million. The company said it would also seek a listing on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Economic Scene; Narrowing A Wage Gap
description: For the first time, American manufacturers are talking openly about a new and startling wage goal: They want to greatly narrow the gap between what they pay their factory workers and the earnings of workers in South Korea, Brazil and a handful of other third world countries.

title: Dress Is Not the Problem With New York Cabbies
description: To the Editor:

title: A Pool of 700,000
description: To the Editor:

title: New Type of Lemur Found
description: Scientists have discovered a new variety of lemur in the forests of central Madagascar, officials said Wednesday. The new animal, Apalemur Aureus, is the 36th different lemur to be identified on Madagascar, an island in the Indian Ocean that is the only habitat of these shy primates.

title: CUOMO PICKS NEW THRUWAY NOMINEE
description: Governor Cuomo today nominated the former chairman of the State Democratic Party, William C. Hennessy, to serve as chairman of the Thruway Authority.

title: Zoo Officials Expect Panda Cub to Survive
description: As officials expressed ''absolute confidence'' that a newborn panda would survive, the National Zoo said today that a second cub born to the giant panda Ling-Ling had taken a few breaths before it died.

title: HEILIG-MEYERS CO reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Gooden Tells of Cocaine Use
description: Dwight Gooden said yesterday that he had learned a bitter lesson from his involvement with cocaine, and said, ''I'll regret it the rest of my life.''

title: Film: 'Jean de Florette,' First Part of a Pagnol Epic
description: GET ready to binge.

title: Money Fund Assets Off
description: Assets of the nation's 384 money market mutual funds decreased by $98.2 million, to $235.65 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Assets of the 95 institutional funds were up $410.2 million, to $64.19 billion. Assets of the 199 general-purpose funds decreased by $202.9 million, to $67.26 billion. The 90 broker-dealer funds fell $305.5 million, to $104.2 billion.

title: RIGHT-TO-DIE RULING STIRS LEGAL AND ETHICAL DEBATE
description: The New Jersey Supreme Court rulings expanding the right of individuals to refuse life-sustaining medical treatment has renewed debate about the legal and ethical implications of the issue.

title: PERFORM-A-THON MIXES SONG, DANCE AND MEMORIES
description: SILENCE is treasured at most libraries, but tomorrow at the New York Public Library at Lincoln Center, it would be a surprise. More than 100 performers will appear on the plaza in front of the library's huge glass windows to sing, dance and recite in what organizers hope will be both spectacle and history lesson.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: MAJOR ANDRE. By Anthony Bailey. 200 pages. Michael Di Capua Books/Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $15.95.

title: 'OVER NIAGARA IN BARREL?' 'I THINK IT'S ENTIRELY APT'
description: The question of a cover-up of the Iran-contra affair figured significantly in testimony yesterday by Assistant Attorney General Charles J. Cooper. Here are some excerpts.

title: Anchor Glass to Get Diamond-Bathurst
description: The Anchor Glass Container Corporation, which manufactures beer bottles for the Anheuser-Busch Companies and other brewers, agreed to take over Diamond-Bathurst Inc., another maker of glass bottles for $191 million, the two companies said today.

title: Advertising; People
description: * Gregory J. Rathjen joined Henderson Advertising, Greenville, S.C., as senior vice president and director of research and strategic planning.

title: HOSPITAL OFFICIAL TO LEAD PRESIDENT'S AIDS PANEL
description: President Reagan today named Dr. W. Eugene Mayberry, chief executive of the Mayo Clinic, to head a new Presidential advisory commission on the AIDS epidemic.

title: INSIDE
description: T.W.A. Leaving Manhattan

title: NICARAGUAN BACKS PANAMA'S LEADERS
description: President Daniel Ortega Saavedra flew to Panama Wednesday and expressed support for Panamanian leaders, who imposed a state of emergency two weeks ago after an outbreak of political protest and street violence.

title: DAYTON HUDSON: APPEALING TARGET
description: Dozens of big companies have lopped off weaker divisions only after going eyeball to eyeball with a corporate raider. Not so the Dayton Hudson Corporation. The giant Minneapolis-based retailer has shown a willingness to shed divisions in its own style.

title: Jacob Sapirstein, 102; Founded Card Concern
description: Jacob Sapirstein, the founder of the American Greetings Corporation of Cleveland, a major manufacturer of greeting cards and related products, died Wednesday at his home in University Heights, Ohio. He was 102 years old.

title: ART: NICHOLAS MOUFARREGE LINKS PAST AND PRESENT
description: NICOLAS A. MOUFARREGE, who died in 1985 at the age of 37, was a critic, a curator and an artist. During his lifetime, he was best known for the first two roles, by which he became an important catalyst in the early 80's East Village art scene. However, the current exhibition of Mr. Moufarrege's idiosyncratic embroidered paintings, on view at the Clocktower, confirms that he deserves to be remembered most of all for his art. This is cold comfort when an artist dies so prematurely, but it is comfort nonetheless.

title: INDICTMENT CHARGES 2 MEN WITH BILKING QUEENS SAVINGS UNIT
description: Two men were indicted yesterday on Federal charges of defrauding a Queens savings and loan association of more than $1 million by falsifying financial records.

title: FOR FORMER HEAD OF NASA, A TRIAL BY ERROR
description: The Justice Department now says it was all a mistake, but the damage to a top space official - and possibly to the American space program itself - lingers on.

title: A Vigil in Washington Protests Pope's Action
description: The meeting of Pope John Paul II with Kurt Waldheim today prompted harsh words and public protest in the United States.

title: A LAWYER'S TALE: A WEEK IN NOVEMBER AND A SCRAMBLE TO DEFINE THE ISSUE
description: As the Iran-contra hearings continued in Washington, the Congressional committees heard yesterday from Assistant Attorney General Charles J. Cooper. Here are excerpts from his testimony, as recorded by The New York Times. Mentioned in Passing

title: Market Place; Aldus Drawing Guarded Praise
description: ''THE hottest I.P.O. since Microsoft.'' That's what analysts are calling last week's initial public offering by the Aldus Corporation, the Seattle-based manufacturer of Pagemaker, the leading desktop publishing software.

title: YUGOSLAVIA MAY CUT OFF AID TO STATE COMPANIES
description: As midyear approaches, the Yugoslav Government is preparing for another peak in its long economic, political and social crisis.

title: Austria's Albatross, at the Vatican
description: Pope John Paul II is a virtuoso at sending subtle signals. Consider the distance and disapproval he managed to convey in his recent meeting with Chile's dictator, General Pinochet. But the Pontiff's subtlety deserted him at the Vatican yesterday when he welcomed Kurt Waldheim - with praise for past good works and not so much as a frown about the darker past that Austria's President has struggled to hide.

title: SHOREWOOD PACKAGING reports earnings for Qtr to May 2
description: b-Includes an extraordinary charge of $175,000 relating to write-off of deferred debt acquisition costs as a result of pre-payment of certain long- term debt. Quarter periods consist of 13 weeks, and the latest year had 52 weeks, compared with 53 weeks for the earlier year. Figures for 1986 are pro forma and include the operations of the company's Canadian and United Kingdom subsidiaries as if they were acquired at the beginning of the period, as well as pro forma adjustments for the inclusion of interest expense related to the indebtness incurred in connection with the acquisitions and the reorganization of the company in 1985, where applicable.

title: DOW RISES 22.64, TO A RECORD 2,451.05
description: The Dow Jones industrial average, after taking a two-day breather, resumed its upward march yesterday and finished at a new high of 2,451.05, up 22.64. A strengthening dollar and lower interest rates fueled the rally.

title: GORBACHEV URGES 'RADICAL' CHANGES TO SPUR ECONOMY
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev called today for a partial dismantling of two linchpins of the Soviet system, central control of the economy and subsidized prices. .

title: A Private Post Affair
description: Mrs. Reagan and Mrs. Kohl are likely to see each other again Tuesday evening at a gala 70th birthday party being given for Katharine Graham, the chairwoman of the Washington Post Company, by her four children.

title: JUSTICES UPHOLD U.S. PANEL'S BAN AGAINST GAY OLYMPICS TITLE
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that the United States Olympic Committee had the legal authority to bar a homosexual rights group from calling its athletic games the ''Gay Olympics.''

title: Open the Doors, Long Island Rail Road Trainmen!
description: To the Editor:

title: Restaurants; TriBeCa bistro, Southern food.
description: WHEN Le Zinc opened in 1983 on Duane Street in TriBeCa, the notion of a hip French bistro so far off the beaten track was still a novelty, and soon it overflowed with a trend-chasing polyglot crowd. The scene, however, was more alluring than the food in those days. Eventually, as new hot spots took root in this once barren terrain, competition turned fierce, and Le Zinc had to fight back. About six months ago, I began hearing about improvements made in the kitchen, which three recent visits confirmed.

title: Lisa Merritt Weds Christopher Engel
description: Lisa Joan Merritt, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ira S. Merritt of North Hills, L.I., and Christopher E. Engel, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Engel of Harrison, N.Y., were married yesterday. Rabbi Daniel Wolk performed the ceremony at the Fresh Meadow Country Club in Great Neck, L.I.

title: U.S.B.L. Wants King
description: John Mills, the owner of the Miami Tropics, of the United States Basketball League said he hoped to meet with Bernard King this weekend to discuss the possibility of King joining the Tropics, according to a report in The Miami News. He said he will travel to New York this weekend, and hoped to talk with King then. Mills said King had mentioned an interest in playing in the U.S.B.L. to World B. Free, a former National Basketball Association player who is with the Tropics. King, whose contract with the Knicks expired, is a free agent.

title: NBD Bancorp
description: NBD Bancorp, the parent company of the National Bank of Detroit, said it had agreed to buy the State National Corporation of Evanston, Ill., for approximately $103 million. The merger must be approved by SNC shareholders, state regulators and the Comptroller of the Currency. The agreement would entitle State National shareholders to exchange each share for $25 in cash or an equivalent package of cash and NBD stock. State National operates two banks in Illinois, has assets of $684 million and shareholder equity of $46 million. NBD operates 33 banks in Michigan, Indiana and Illinois, has assets of $22.5 billion and shareholder equity of $1.3 billion.

title: What's On And When
description: This is the schedule for the Perform-a-thon at the New York Public Library at Lincoln Center. Performances will take place tomorrow on the Lincoln Center plaza in front of the library. Information: 870-1670. The rain date is Sunday. Noon to 1 P.M. Overture: Beltane (progressive Irish folk music); Fanfare; the Flying Karamazov Brothers and Avner the Eccentric; Blythe Danner, actress; George S. Irving, singer-actor, and Maria Karnilova, actress; Mary Alice, actress; Estelle Parsons's Shakespeare on Broadway-Belasco Project. 1 to 2 P.M. Lee Roy Reams, dancer; Teresa Wright, actress; Hellman's Angels, jazz trio; the New York Baroque Dance Company; Dance Theater of Harlem Workshop Ensemble; Mister Tram Associates (jazz quartet); Annabelle Gamson Dance Company. 2 to 3 P.M. Music for a While (Renaissance music); Benay Venuta, comedian; Fritz Weaver and Tony Weaver, actors; Marci Rosen, cellist; Jo Sullivan Loesser, singer; Harlem School of the Arts Suzuki Ensemble. 3 to 4 P.M. 111th Street Music and Dance Company; Viveca Lindfors, actress; Ballet Hispanico; Steve Ross, cabaret singer and pianist; Paula Laurence, singer, with Mr. Ross; Pia Lindstrom, television film reviewer; Hunter College Dance Company; Puerto Rican Traveling Theater. 4 to 5 P.M. Valerie Capers Trio (jazz); Dennis Buck, pianist, ''Alladin'' selections; Yvonne Constant, French cabaret singer; Martin Vidnovic, singer; Klez-Meydlekh Plus Two (klezmer ensemble); Larry Kert, actor-singer, in tribute to Al Jolson; Ernestine Jackson, actress. 5 to 6 P.M. Dancellington with Savion Glover; Gary Schocker, flutist; the Louis Johnson Dance Theater Ensemble; Phyllis Newman, actress; Reach Ensemble Gospel Choir; Great Lakes Theater Festival with scenes from ''The Boys From Syracuse''; the New York Swing Dance Society. 6 to 7 P.M. ''The Shubert Years,'' a revue of songs from Shubert musicals, narrated by Tony Randall; performed by Ann Crumb, Louise Edeiken, Norman Large and Thomas James O'Leary, actors. Presented by the Shubert Foundation. 7 to 8 P.M. Carole Shelley, actress; Skitch Henderson, founder and musical director of the New York Pops; Roberta Peters, soprano, and the Met in the Parks -Myra Merritt, soprano, and Vinson Cole, tenor; Patricia Elliott, actress; Betty Comden and Adolph Green, composers; Ann Reinking and Gary Chryst, dancers; Jule Styne, composer; finale.

title: 2 CHALLENGE WEDTECH COUNTS
description: Two brothers have asked a Federal district judge to dismiss indictments charging them with trying to influence an investigation into the Bronx-based Wedtech Corporation, a military contractor.

title: Diner's Journal
description: IT'S big, loud, sometimes raucous, and crowded - but the fact that I did have a few spirited pastas there lately encourages me to investigate the menu further. The new Pasta and Dreams, at 2161 Broadway (at 76th Street), is an expanded version of the original restaurant by that name on First Avenue at 58th Street.

title: MAJOR FEDERAL PROGRAM IS URGED TO CUT FLOW OF HAZARDOUS WASTE
description: A major new Federal program is needed to reduce industrial production of hazardous waste by up to 50 percent over the next few years, thereby reducing contamination at its source, according to Congress's Office of Technology Assessment.

title: AVERY INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
EXCERPTS FROM GORBACHEV'S REPORT ON RESTRUCTURING THE SOVIET ECONOMY
description: Following are excerpts from Mikhail S. Gorbachev's report today to the Communist Party Central Committee, ''On the Party's Tasks in Fundamentally Restructuring Management of the Economy,'' as distributed in translation by Tass, the Soviet press agency:

title: More Contra Follies?
description: Attempts to force some clarity on whether or not a chance exists for a political settlement in Central America are stumbling again. Evidence points to another muted fight between Secretary of State George Shultz and the National Security Council, despite the change in White House advisers.

title: Securities Sale Is Challenged
description: The Securities Industry Association filed a lawsuit against the Comptroller of the Currency in Federal District Court in Manhattan yesterday in an attempt to reverse a decision that permitted commercial banks to create and sell mortgage-backed securities.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Mel Torme, Diane Schuur and Lonette McKee, with the Mel Lewis Orchestra, Carnegie Hall (247-7800). The three singers appearing together tonight as part of the JVC Jazz Festival are each highly distinctive. The vocal epitome of pop-jazz warmth, refinement and good taste, Mel Torme has a voice that seems ageless in its buoyant flexibility. Diane Schuur combines a roof-raising volume with an open-hearted simplicity that suggests a pop-jazz answer to Kate Smith. Lonette McKee, who recently portrayed Billie Holiday Off Broadway and also appeared in ''The Cotton Club'' and '' 'Round Midnight,'' sings with a compressed grit and fiber that feels closer in spirit to Dinah Washington than Billie Holiday. Show time is 8 tonight at Carnegie Hall; available tickets, at $28.50 and $30, are for partial view seats only. * * *

title: FRANK X. SMITH
description: Frank X. Smith, president of Seven Graphic Arts Inc., a design and typesetting company in Manhattan, died of cancer Tuesday at his home in New Rochelle, N.Y. He was 51 years old.

title: Advertising; Accounts
description: * East/West Network to Shaw & Landey.

title: MANPOWER INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: Sales represent companywide Manpower sales or total system sales.

title: That Old-Time Politics
description: That old idealist, Billy Martin, stood up straight and tall the other day and stated in no uncertain terms that politics has no place in baseball. From a standpoint of pure democratic utopianism, Billy Martin is right. From a standpoint of pure actuality, he is wrong, and has been for more than one hundred years.

title: The Life of Gleason
description: Built like a bear, he moved like a cat. Born to poverty, he came to live regally and until his death half-jokingly referred to himself as ''The Great One.'' Yet Jackie Gleason is assured immortality as the bumbling blue-collar hero of a situation comedy. It was set in a drab room with bare table and wheezing refrigerator and filmed in black and white long ago, when Ike was President. Rarely has so much laughter, and money, bubbled up from simpler ingredients than in ''The Honeymooners.''

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: The Student Loan Marketing Association, known as Sallie Mae, is offering $100 million of 8 1/2 percent fixed-rate notes due in 1994 at a price of 99.60 to yield about 8.57 percent, or 45.7 basis points more than Treasury securities with a similar maturity. The offering is being made through Morgan Stanley & Company.

title: GORBACHEV ASSAILS 2 AIDES HE NAMED
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev coupled his call today for sweeping economic changes with a sharp attack, by name, on some of his leading economic planners and industrial ministers.

title: AMERICAN MEDICAL INTERNAIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Net loss Results for 1986 includes a gain, net of taxes, of $8.1 million, or 9 cents a share, in 1986 from the sale of certain health care facilities. Fiscal 1986 results also include a reserve for severance of $4.1 million, net of taxes, or 5 cents a share, in the third quarter and $7.2 million, net of taxes, or 8 cents a share, in the year to date. Shares outstanding for the year-ago 9-month period do not include common equivalent shares due to their antidilutive effect.

title: Suspicion? Rhoden Will Put It to Use
description: Now that Rick Rhoden has been all but strip-searched by one crew of American League umpires, it stands to reason the Yankee pitcher faces a summer of inspections, warnings and accusations. But he has never been ejected from a game for scuffing balls. By hurling suspicion at Rhoden, opponents and umpires are merely adding a pitch to his repertory.

title: U.S. and Soviet Experts Will Share Test Data
description: American scientists will be allowed to monitor Soviet underground nuclear tests for the first time under the terms of an agreement signed today, the scientists announced.

title: Quaker State Oil's Asset Write-Down
description: The Quaker State Oil Refining Corporation said it plans a $122 million write-down of its assets that will result in a loss for both the second quarter and the year.

title: PILLSBURY CO reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Includes after-tax restructuring charges of $21.6 million for the quarter and year; the year also includes a gain of $9.7 million from the sale of a Kansas flour mill and the sale of a joint-venture interest in an Australian food company. c-Includes a gain of $1.2 million, representing the net effect of a loss on the sale of Apollo Foods and a gain from the sale of Pioneer Rice. d-Includes a $28.4 million gain from the sale of 128 Burger King real estate properties to a master limited partnership.

title: STUDENT CANDY CURB GOES TO THE GOVERNOR
description: The Assembly gave final passage tonight to a bill that curbs the sale of soft drinks, candy and gum in public schools.

title: SERVICE CORP INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Same Team, Different Routes
description: Danny Sullivan likes fine wine while Rick Mears drinks beer, Miller please.

title: Ling-Ling's Lullaby
description: In finally giving birth to a healthy cub, Ling-Ling, the National Zoo's female panda, cheers all who worry about the future of endangered species. To those who tend to anthropomorphize, the news is also something more: Finally, the quintessential hard-luck lady has had a break.

title: Film: Kubrick's 'Full Metal Jacket,' on Vietnam
description: MORE than any other major American film maker, Stanley Kubrick keeps to his own ways, paying little attention to the fashions of the moment, creating fantastic visions that, in one way and another, are dislocated extensions of the world we know but would prefer not to recognize.

title: ART: IN RIDGEFIELD CONN., A 'POST-ABSTRACT' SHOW
description: HERE'S a pretty kettle of fish: The Aldrich Museum of Contemporary Art filled with ''Post-Abstract Abstraction.'' Actually, the kettle is pretty, being the 18th-century clapboard house that stands, enlarged by a new but equally graceful annex, on Main Street in Ridgefield, Conn. It's the fish that are in question, beginning with the term post-abstract abstraction.

title: Crafts Fair
description: Three hundred artisans are to display their creations at the Dutchess County Fairgrounds in Rhinebeck, N.Y., this weekend. Jewelry, stained glass, pottery, sculptures and other works can all be found at the fair, which runs from noon to 6 P.M. today and from 10 A.M. to 6 P.M. tomorrow and Sunday. The fairgrounds, on Route 9, are close to the Roosevelt and Vanderbilt mansions and other attractions of the Hudson Valley. Admission is $4. Information: (914) 876-4001.

title: A.M.C. Expects To Give Bonuses
description: The chief executive of the American Motors Corporation said the company might be able to give bonuses to its executives for the first time since 1979 because of what he said would be a record profit in the second quarter.

title: Film: 'Dragnet,' Parody of Television Series
description: THE surprise about ''Dragnet,'' described by its director, Tom Mankiewicz, as ''a comedic homage to one of the classic television shows,'' is not that it's less than an unalloyed delight, but that it manages to be funny at all. The film opens today at the Gemini and other theaters.

title: Emerson Electric Offering Notes
description: The Emerson Electric Company is offering $100 million of top-ranked investment-grade notes through underwriters led by Bear, Stearns & Company. Bearing an 8 percent coupon, the notes due in 1990 are priced at par and yield three-tenths of a percentage point more than Treasury securities with a similar maturity.

title: BONUSES REPLACE WAGE RISES AND WORKERS ARE THE LOSERS
description: Seeking to hold down labor costs, thousands of companies are changing the way they increase workers' pay. Instead of the traditional annual increase, millions of workers in industries as diverse as supermarkets and aerospace are receiving cash bonuses - and this new form makes a big difference.

title: PROFITING FROM THE AURA OF TWAIN
description: It's about 875 miles from here to the muddy waters of Mark Twain's Mississippi River. But as the great man himself might have counseled, let's not let a little distance spoil the fun or profits.

title: Bridge: New York Star Points Out A Benefit of 6 No-Trump
description: When a partnership has a good eight-card fit in a major suit with values for a 12-trick contract, it is seldom necessary to look further.

title: Grizzly Bear Killed After Biting Warden In Montana Forest
description: A game warden was in stable condition today after a grizzly bear took a deep bite in his right leg as he was trying to release the animal into the wild Wednesday.

title: DAINIPON IN BID FOR REICHHOLD
description: An increasingly feisty Japanese chemicals producer made a hostile offer yesterday for Reichhold Chemicals Inc., ending lengthy behind-the-scenes acquisition talks.

title: Another Student Dies at School for the Autistic
description: A 29-year-old student at a school for the autistic died today, two days after she suffered a heart attack.

title: For Senators, a Rush to Remember
description: This is the month for senators to get in their bids for National Independent Retail Grocer Week, National Immigrants Day, National Cajun Music Month -there's just one more chance in 1987.

title: BLOCK, H&R INC reports earnings for Year to April 30
description: b-Includes a one-time net gain of $2,643,000, or 10 cents a share, from the sale of the company's interest in Block Management Co.

title: LAUREL ENTERTAINMENT INC reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $423,423 and $302,800 for the latest year and year-earlier period, respectively.

title: PROFESSOR SAYS TRANSIT OFFICERS MISTREATED HIM
description: An English professor at John Jay College of Criminal Justice charged yesterday that he had been manhandled by transit officers and falsely arrested while observing another arrest at a Manhattan subway station.

title: RECOLLECTION OF 'JEWS IN GERMANY'
description: The remembrance of things past is running strong in the large room just past the 42d Street entrance of the New York Public Library at Fifth Avenue. The exhibition that opened last night is a recollection, mostly bitter, but with its sweet flavorings, of the thousand-year Reich in which the German Jews survived, sometimes even thrived, until the Nazis, whose own thousand-year Reich never materialized, put period to their story.

title: Ban of Actress Reviewed
description: The Council of the Actors' Equity Association is to meet Tuesday to reconsider a request by the producers of ''Phantom of the Opera'' to allow the British actress Sarah Brightman to re-create her leading role in the show on Broadway in the fall.

title: The Goetz Verdict Indicts a City's Leadership
description: To the Editor:

title: Massachusetts Bonds Have Top Yield of 7 1/2%
description: In the largest competitive deal in yesterday's credit market, a $200 million issue of Massachusetts general obligation bonds went to a group of underwriters led by the Bankers Trust Company.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Barry Harris and Chris Anderson, Barry Harris's Jazz Cultural Theater, 368 Eighth Avenue, between 28th and 29th Streets (502-4300). If Thelonious Monk, Bud Powell and Elmo Hope lighted the fire, then Barry Harris and Chris Anderson are keepers of the flame. Be-bop piano, for want of a better term, is an incendiary art; its purest exponents build worlds of lapidary detail and glancing filigree, only to bring them crashing down in firestorms of rhythmic and harmonic transformation. Barry Harris is at least represented on record; Chris Anderson is a musicians' musician, a favorite of the demanding Mr. Harris. They are playing solo sets on Sunday, beginning around 7 P.M. Tickets are $8 in advance, $10 at the door. students and the elderly, $7. * * *

title: Aid Satisfies Indonesia
description: Indonesia, its economy battered by a plunge in oil and commodity prices last year, said today that it would not reschedule its foreign debts and would neither devalue its currency nor impose foreign currency controls.

title: WEDCO TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: b-Includes net from discontinued operations of $899,000. c-Net loss and includes a loss from discontinued operations of $6,881,000.

title: Extradition for Knight?
description: Gov. Robert D. Orr, declaring he was ''strong for Bobby Knight,'' said yesterday that he would fight any extradition request for the Indiana University coach all the way to the Supreme Court. Puerto Rican authorities are considering requesting the extradition of Knight so he can serve a six-month jail sentence stemming from a scuffle with a police officer during the 1979 Pan American games. A Supreme Court decision earlier this week makes it possible for Puerto Rico to use Federal courts to order extradition of criminals, and a justice official there said Wednesday he would recommend that Knight be extradited.

title: Dance: Alum's 'Monte'
description: Manuel Alum describes his new work, ''Monte,'' as ''a spiral ascending ritual to the wisdom of the earth.'' That program note could have described much of the dance performed by Manuel Alum and Dancers on Wednesday at the Washington Square Methodist Church. Each of the five dances presented suggested in some degree the disparate regions of the earth and sky and the reaching that defines the space between.

title: SOFTWARE COPYRIGHT BILL MOVES AHEAD IN BRAZIL
description: In a move aimed at settling a prolonged trade dispute with the United States, Brazil's Chamber of Deputies has approved a law accepting international copyright rules for computer software programs.

title: EX-CHIEF OF TRANE WILL HEAD TRAVO
description: The Dravo Corporation, a construction and engineering company in Pittsburgh that has been seeking a new leader in an attempt to improve its performance, yesterday named William G. Roth chairman, president and chief executive.

title: The U.N. Today: June 26, 1987
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: ROCK: BRYAN ADAMS
description: BRYAN ADAMS, a Canadian pop star, is the kind of performer who makes aging rock critics wring their hands and long for the good old days when mainstream rock wasn't so formularized and television-oriented.

title: Morgan Stanley's Man Behind Burlington Deal
description: Alan E. Goldberg is not afraid of big numbers. At age 32, he has been put in a top position at Morgan Stanley, putting together billion-dollar deals.

title: SALTY TO SUBLIME: RATING THE POPCORN
description: IT'S a curious phenomenon, really, this human compulsion to devour oversized containers full of detonated corn kernels drenched in assorted yellow liquids - loosely identified as butter - while sitting in dark movie theaters.

title: Centre Court Stars: The Grounds Crew 871>
description: It has come to this at Wimbledon: After four days of rain, interrupted occasionally by tennis, the grounds crew has now logged more court time than all the players combined. In the brief periods when it was just overcast today, Martina Navratilova won her second-round match and Ivan Lendl found another reason not to mind if it continues to rain until the eve of the United States Open.

title: COMEDY, TRAGEDY AND NOODLES: A GUIDE TO SUMMER MOVIES
description: THE moviegoer becomes more suggestible when the weather gets warm. The defenses crumble. The same individual who might deliberate long and hard about venturing out into a blizzard for a blockbuster becomes willing to sit through Something, Anything, even Anything III on a hot summer night. Something in the air makes the theatrical film experience just that much more lulling. So it would be fitting - only fair, really - if the film industry took special care not to bruise the audience's tender feelings at this time of year.

title: The Bad Trade News Behind the Good
description: At last! The 40 percent decline in the dollar is finally evident in improved trade statistics. That's the good news. But without further painful actions, the present $160 billion trade deficit will level off in a few years at about $100 billion. At that point, Washington, Bonn and Tokyo will still have to make all of the unpleasant economic decisions they've been putting off for a decade - above all, to act on the reality that the world is one economy.

title: The Stage: George Abbott's 'Broadway'
description: GEORGE ABBOTT defines the word indomitability. Turning 100 yesterday and entering his second century, he has a history almost as long as that of the American theater.

title: How to Help Latin Debtor Nations
description: LEAD: The enormous Latin American loan write-offs by Citibank, Chase Manhattan and other New York banks, combined with earlier moratoriums on interest payments by Brazil and Ecuador, make it abundantly clear that attempts by the International Monetary Fund and the Administration to deal with the debt crisis have failed.

title: Advertising; Fairchild Bringing Out A Weekly on Travel
description: Fairchild Publications, publisher of Women's Wear Daily and other trade papers and magazines, got into consumer magazine publishing in 1971 and is now preparing to add a fourth title in that sector on Oct. 5.

title: QUOTA PLAN IS OPEC'S KEY ISSUE
description: OPEC's ministers were in a self-congratulatory mood as they met here today even though they found themselves heatedly debating whether to reduce production quotas to help keep oil prices from dropping.

title: 45 Are Found Dead in Burma In an Airliner That Vanished
description: All 45 people aboard a Burma Airways plane missing since Sunday died when the aircraft crashed into an 8,200-foot mountain in eastern Burma, the Government reported Wednesday.

title: Jazz Festival; EPISTEME AND JOHN CARTER OCTET
description: SEVERAL concerts of the World Music Institute's Improvisations Festival overlap with the JVC Jazz Festival, and one of those co-produced events took place Wednesday night at Merkin Concert Hall. This was a generous (nearly three hours with one intermission) double bill of Anthony Davis's Episteme and the John Carter Octet.

title: EX-TREASURY CHIEF GETS 1-MONTH TERM IN BANK FRAUD CASE
description: Former Treasury Secretary Robert B. Anderson was sentenced to a month in prison, five months' house arrest and five years' probation yesterday for evading income taxes and operating an illegal offshore bank.

title: German Photography
description: Contemporary works by 14 young West German photographers will be on view through Sept. 6 at the International Center of Photography, 1130 Fifth Avenue, at 94th Street. The show, which features about 100 photographs, was organized by the Museum Folkwang in Essen, West Germany. Shown with the exhibition will be screenings of West German video art made since 1976. Weekend hours are today, noon to 5 P.M., and tomorrow and Sunday, 11 A.M. to 6 P.M. Admission is $2 ($1 for students and the elderly). Information: (212) 860-1777.

title: A Missed Deadline
description: William A. Wilson, a close friend of President Reagan's who quit his post as Ambassador to the Vatican in May 1986, has failed to file financial disclosure reports due months ago.

title: CONDUCTIVITY REPORT RAISING SKEPTICISM AMONG RESEARCHERS
description: Some researchers said here today that they had been unable to reproduce recent work by scientists who reported they had created substances that lose resistance to electricity at record high temperatures.

title: EVELYN LEVITT
description: Evelyn Levitt, a champion bridge player, died of a heart attack Tuesday in Wilmington (Del.) Hospital. She was 67 years old and lived in Wilmington.

title: Mets Roll On Into 2d Place
description: For the fourth time in five games since he returned from therapy for drug abuse, Dwight Gooden pitched the Mets to a victory yesterday. This time he pitched them into second place in the National League's East.

title: Intel Chip Pact
description: The Intel Corporation, which is based in Santa Clara, Calif., said it would market dynamic random access memory chips, or D-RAM's, manufactured by Samsung Semiconductor, a South Korean company. According to the agreement, Samsung will supply pre-packaged and tested 64k, 256k and 12-megabit D-RAM's, which Intel will sell to distributors under its own label. Terms of the agreement were not disclosed. Like most United States chip makers, Intel discontinued D-RAM production under the onslaught of fierce price competition from Japanese manufacturers. The company has been one of the leaders in an industrywide effort to halt the predatory pricing, or dumping, of Japanese chips.

title: CELEBRATING BURROUGHS AND HIS CATSKILLS
description: ''Among these mountains there are not sharp peaks, or abrupt declivities, as in a volcanic region, but long, uniform ranges, heavily timbered to their summits, and delighting the eye with vast, undulating horizon lines.''

title: A First Lady Is Honored
description: Chancellor Helmut Kohl's decision to reject the American request for the extradition of a hijacking suspect this week has not interfered with Nancy Reagan's plans to present the West German leader's wife with an award.

title: NEW YORK STATE SEEKS TO BAR AIDS VIRUS TESTS FOR HEALTH INSURANCE
description: At Governor Cuomo's request, the state's top insurance official proposed a regulation yesterday that would bar insurance companies from requiring applicants for health insurance to submit to a blood test for evidence of the AIDS virus.

title: PROTEST IN TRIBECA: TRYING TO SAVE GREENERY
description: It was not your typical morning tableau yesterday at Shearson Park, a bucolic, 200-by-100-foot enclave in lower Manhattan.

title: PEOPLE RIDESHARING SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Dollar's Strength Buoys Bonds
description: Bond prices inched higher in lazy trading yesterday, pulled along by a stronger dollar on the currency markets.

title: 'Dragnet,' Parody of Television Series
description: THE surprise about ''Dragnet,'' described by its director, Tom Mankiewicz, as ''a comedic homage to one of the classic television shows,'' is not that it's less than an unalloyed delight, but that it manages to be funny at all. The film opens today at the Gemini and other theaters.

title: Alligator Off Endangered List
description: The now-flourishing American alligator has been removed from the endangered species list in states outside its primary territory, the Fish and Wildlife Service has announced.

title: 'SHE DEVIL,' ON A & E
description: FOR those giddy souls who consider the calculated cuteness of ''L.A. Law'' to be the height of sophistication and wit, along comes ''The Life and Loves of a She Devil'' with a challenge that borders on pure malevolence. Life, it hisses, is considerably more complicated than discovering the secret of the Venus Butterfly. There might even be worlds beyond the Bloomingdale's catalogue. With barely a kind word for anyone, ''She Devil'' casts a pox on all of our fantasies.

title: Taxi Passengers Are No Bargain
description: LEAD: When I drove a taxi for two years -through ice storms and incredibly hot, humid nights, from Kennedy Airport to Riverdale - the last thing I worried about was the acceptability of my attire. More pressing concerns: Will I survive? Will an axle fall off this poor excuse for a car? How do you not blow your cool when a Park Avenue lady stiffs you with a nickel tip?

title: Dionne Has Surgery
description: Marcel Dionne, who aggravated a knee injury while working out after the season ended, underwent arthroscopic surgery yesterday for partial removal of cartilage in his left knee. The Rangers said it will not keep him from training camp in the late summer. The club also announced that it had signed Bob Froese, the goalie, to a long-term contract.

title: Fleet Financial
description: The Fleet Financial Corporation said its Fleet National Bank subsidiary would form a new investment banking unit. The new unit, Fleet Asssociates, will handle corporate finance, mortgage banking and real estate lending transactions. Richard A. Higginbotham, executive vice president of the bank, will head the division. Fleet National is a $12 billion diversified financial services company based in Providence, R.I.

title: FLORIDA SEX CASE YIELDS CONVICTION
description: A man who ran a computerized pornography ring for homosexuals has been convicted of racketeering and other charges, including having sexual relations with a 14-year-old boy who was quarantined earlier this month as a carrier of the AIDS virus.

title: Corrections
description: The About Real Estate column on June 3, about new restaurants in the Flatiron District, incorrectly described a partnership planning to open Cafe Society on Broadway next month. The owner of Canastel's, another Manhattan restaurant, is not a partner in the new venture.

title: Stealing a Record
description: Willie Randolph is enjoying the best offensive season in his 12 years with the Yankees and is also nearing the club career record for stolen bases. Although no longer able to average 30 swipes a year, as he did in his first five seasons, the 32-year-old second baseman is only eight short of Hal Chase's record 248 steals, which has stood since 1913. But Randolph does not figure to hold the record long. In a little more than two seasons, Rickey Henderson has amassed 190. The top 10: G SB Hal Chase 1,059 248 Willie Randolph* 1,535 24 Roy White 1,881 232 Rickey Henderson* 341 190 Wid Conroy 797 184 Ben Chapman 909 184 Fritz Maisel 501 183 Mickey Mantle 2,401 153 Horace Clarke 1,230 151 Phil Rizzuto 1,661 149 *Denotes active player.

title: Gleason Had Cancer In His Colon and Liver
description: Jackie Gleason died of adenocarcinoma, a form of cancer, which spread to his liver from his colon, according to Dr. Leonard Erdman, a Fort Lauderdale internist.

title: Bavaro a Giant Among Children
description: Mark Bavaro will conclude a tour of 10 National Football League cities today in Seattle as the national co-chairman of the Colonel Sanders Memorial March of Dimes Campaign. Since May 28, the Giants' all-pro tight end has visited hospitals, meeting and chatting with afflicted children, and had made fund-raising appearances on behalf of the youngsters in Kansas City, Chicago, Dallas, Atlanta, Miami, New York, Boston, Denver, Los Angeles and Seattle.

title: THE SILOS
description: The Silos, a rock band, will perform tomorrow at 10 P.M. at the Rodeo Bar at Albuquerque, 375 Third Avenue, at 27th Street (683-6500). There is no cover or minimum.

title: LASER INDUSTRIES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a loss of $197,000 from reversal of a tax credit for the quarter and a tax credit of $113,000 for the year. The net for fiscal 1986 reflects a loss of $62,000 from an Industrial Laser subsidiary which was divested in September 1985. The company said for the year ended March 31, 1986, sales include $508,000 of sales from the Industrial Laser unit.

title: Advertising; Du Pont Sends 8 Units To Baltimore Agency
description: E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company has assigned eight business units from its Finishes and Fabricated Products Department to Richardson, Myers & Donofrio in Baltimore for business-to-business advertising. Billings could be in the $4 million range.

title: UNITED FOODS INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
POTOMAC ELECTRIC POWER CO reports earnings for 12mo May 31
description: b-After a gain of $21,680,000 from the sale of the company's Virginia service territory. The share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split effective May 4.

title: T CELL SCIENCES reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
SHULTZ IN HIS 'GARDEN'
description: The last time George P. Shultz ar-rived here was as a young Marine officer with the American forces making their way across the Pacific islands. Now, 44 years later, he was feasting on roast pig as dancers tossed about flaming torches at a state dinner in one of the world's smallest nations.

title: AMERICAN JAZZ ORCHESTRA SAMPLING
description: THE American Jazz Orchestra, the recently formed repertory group that completed its first season of four concerts last spring, presented a sampling from those concerts in a JVC Jazz Festival appearance at Cooper Union on Wednesday evening.

title: Dining Out Guide: For Vegetarians
description: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. ALO ALO, #1030 Third Avenue, at 61st Street (838-4343) -

title: A JAZZY NEW INGREDIENT FOR CARAMOOR CONCERTS
description: Something new has been added to this season's concerts at Caramoor Center for Music and the Arts in Katonah, N.Y. - jazz. On Aug. 8, Wynton Marsalis and his quintet will appear at the music festival.

title: Auctions; Celebrities' memorabilia.
description: A 1956 Austin Princess hearse used by John Lennon in his video of ''Imagine,'' a pair of the singer's gold-rimmed tinted eyeglasses and a 1968 posterboard drawing entitled ''Give Peace a Chance'' will be auctioned tomorrow at 10:15 A.M. and 2 P.M. at Sotheby's, York Avenue at 72d Street. Other offbeat collectibles up for sale include costumes worn by Marilyn Monroe, Ronald Reagan, Errol Flynn and James Cagney; Elvis Presley mementos, and celluloids of Geppetto's workshop from Walt Disney's ''Pinocchio.''

title: WORKPLACE SAFETY UNIT ASSAILED FOR LAX EFFORTS
description: The Occupational Safety and Health Administration's program to protect workers from on-the-job hazards is beset by ''systemic weaknesses,'' according to a draft report by the Inspector General's office at the Labor Department.

title: World Bank Issues 30-Year Bonds
description: In the first underwritten dollar transaction for its 1988 fiscal year that begins July 1, the World Bank yesterday offered $400 million of 9 1/4 percent bonds due in 2017 at a price of par through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: Entertainment Planned On Staten Island Ferry
description: Dancers, comedians and musicians will take to the deck of the Staten Island ferry this weekend for a series of performances sponsored by the Franklin Furnace. An appearance by Tom Murrin, a comedian, will begin the entertainment today at 6:45 P.M.; tomorrow, the show starts at 2 P.M. It's all there for the price of a round-trip ferry ride (25 cents).

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The obituary of Fred Astaire on Tuesday misstated the number of film musicals in which he and Ginger Rogers were co-stars. They appeared together in 10 films.

title: Our Towns; Spikes or Tails, Children's Salon Tries for Style
description: If you were a boy in the 1950's, you hated your head. Every six weeks they grabbed you, threw you in the barber chair, and then a man - specifically selected for the job because he despised children - took a set of electric shears and buzzed off all your hair.
