When it was over, you looked fit to be electrocuted.

title: U.C.L.A. Extends Hazzard's Pact
description: Walt Hazzard, who coached U.C.L.A. to its first conference championship in four years last season, will be given a multiyear contract extension, the university announced today. Terms were not released.

title: SENATORS TAKE UP TRADE BILL
description: The Senate began debate on a mammoth trade bill today and, after hours of speeches, approved an amendment requiring American officials to begin an investigation of ''unfair trade barriers maintained by Japan against United States construction services.''

title: WITH $1 MILLION PAYMENT, CLEVELAND GETS OUT OF HOLE
description: Nearly a decade ago this city became the first since the Depression to default on its debts, the low point in a sinking cycle that began in 1969 when the polluted Cuyahoga River caught fire downtown.

title: INDIAN TROOPS RAID SIKH TEMPLE
description: Paramilitary troops and policemen raided the main Sikh temple complex in the Punjab early today and detained more than 250 people suspected of terrorist activities, the police said.

title: Lasix: The X Factor in Alysheba-Bet Twice Series
description: Alysheba and Bet Twice will renew their Triple Crown rivalry in the Haskell Handicap at Monmouth Park Aug. 1 and in the Travers at Saratoga three weeks later. The key may be to study the local medication rules instead of the past performances.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: FRIDAY, JUNE 26, 1987
description: The Economy

title: How'm I Doing?
description: With all the bizarre and chilling testimony over these last weeks, in a way the most extraordinary thing in the Iran-contra hearings is something that has not happened. President Reagan has not expressed a word of outrage at the facts disclosed, a word of regret.

title: Al Grey Quintet
description: Al Grey and Buddy Tate, who played trombone and saxophone, respectively, in the Count Basie Band, will lead a quintet tonight through Sunday at the Village Vanguard, 178 Seventh Avenue South, below 11th Street (212-255-4037). Sets begin at 10 and 11:30 P.M. and 1 A.M.; there is a $12 cover and a $6 minimum.

title: GENERAL DEVELOPMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
MOVIE THEATERS: FACTS AND FIGURES
description: When waiting in New York's seemingly interminable movie lines, it may seem hard to believe that the city, America's No. 1 film market, has about 175,000 seats in its 300 or so cinemas. Yet as any cinephile will attest, moviegoing is not what it used to be.

title: Advertising; Kummel Easing Up At McCann
description: EUGENE H. KUMMEL, the last of the second-generation management of the 85-year-old McCann-Erickson Worldwide, will reach his 65th birthday on Aug. 2 and retire as chairman of the executive committee at the end of the year. But that does not mean that he will leave.

title: Pay to Player Detailed in Report
description: Teryl Austin, a Pitt defensive back, has told school officials that Norby Walters, an agent, paid him $250 a month but stopped the payments when Austin's potential value as a professional dropped, according to a story in The Atlanta Constitution.

title: '88 SPENDING BILL PASSED BY HOUSE
description: The House of Representatives has passed its first major spending bill for the fiscal year 1988, a $16.15 billion energy and water development package that is strongly opposed by the White House.

title: SCIENTISTS TELL OF PROMISE SEEN IN A NEW CLASS OF ANTIBIOTICS
description: Swedish scientists have developed a new class of antibiotics that promise one day to assist in the treatment of infections caused by some of the most dangerous and resistant strains of bacteria, the scientists reported yesterday.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: FRIDAY, JUNE 26, 1987
description: International A2-8

title: DESIGNCRAFT INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: The company said the latest results include a pre-tax gain of $1,989,000 on the sale of its New York City office building.

title: U.S. and Syria Agree to Hold Talks, Officials Say
description: President Reagan urged President Hafez al-Assad of Syria to begin high-level talks on a range of issues, including gaining the freedom of American hostages held in Lebanon, and Mr. Assad has agreed, Administration officials said today.

title: Advertising; McCann Wins Account After an 11-Way Battle
description: The Datacopy Corporation, a computer software and scanners company in Mountain View, Calif., has chosen McCann-Erickson/San Francisco as its agency after an 11-way competition that lasted about two months. The two other California agencies that were finalists were N. W. Ayer, San Francisco, and Ketchum, Mandabach & Simms, Oakland.

title: Realty Developer Restructuring Debt
description: The Southland Financial Corporation, a real estate development company in Irving, Tex., said it was working with Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. and La Salle Partners Ltd. in an attempt to restructure the company's debt obligations. Southland has said that it was trying to reduce its current interest expense and extend its principal repayment schedule. But a spokesman declined to say how much of the company's $932 million in total debt it hoped to restructure.

title: Conferees Act to Speed Banks' Check-Clearing
description: House and Senate conferees approved a compromise proposal today that would substantally reduce the time allowed to clear depositors' checks.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A picture caption in Business Day on June 8 with an article about the economy of the Caribbean island of Antigua misidentified the harbor shown. It was English Harbor, not St. John's.

title: Joe Niekro Works Out
description: Joe Niekro, who was hit in the shoulder by a ball thrown in warm-ups shortly after having separated the same shoulder, pitched painlessly during batting practice with the Twins in Minnesota yesterday and shouldn't miss any more starts.

title: BORMAN'S INC reports earnings for 16wks to May 23
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $910,000. The company said the results include pre-tax LIFO inventory charges of $380,000 for the latest quarter and $300,000 for the year-ago period. The company also said the 16-week first quarter includes 4 weeks for the recently acquired 60-store western operation, chiefly in Utah and Idaho.

title: Exhibition Focuses On the Art of Video
description: The young art of video is surveyed in a new exhibition at the Museum of Modern Art. ''Selections From the Video Study Collection: 1968-87'' includes documentaries, performance videos and Conceptual works by more than 40 artists. Nam June Paik's ''Global Groove'' (1973), for example, is a paean to television. Susan and Alan Raymond's ''Police Tapes'' (1976) depicts life in the South Bronx. And Michael Klier's ''Der Riese'' (''The Giant'') captures a bleak urban world with hidden surveillance cameras.

title: PRESS REFLECTS PREOCCUPATIONS: FOR WHITES, RUGBY
description: The young black newspaper vendors who present the morning headlines to commuters in the rush-hour traffic have a novel way of keeping warm in the freezing temperatures that have descended on this metropolis.

title: INFANT MORTALITY: FRIGHTFUL ODDS IN INNER CITY
description: Each year, a quarter million babies are born dangerously underweight in this country and face a 1 in 10 chance that they will not live to their first birthday. Ollie Hill's baby is one of them.

title: MATERIAL SCIENCES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Rodgers, Knicks Meet
description: Jimmy Rodgers, the Boston Celtics' assistant coach and director of player personnel who was thought to be a leading candidate for the Knicks' coaching job, met yesterday with Jack Diller, the senior vice president of Madison Square Garden, and Richard Evans, the president of Madison Square Garden Corporation and the Knicks. ''It was an initial meeting,'' Rodgers said after returning to Boston last night. ''I got to know the poeple, they got to know me.''

title: Day Care's Cosmic Crapshoot
description: Edward Zigler, who heads Yale's Bush Center in Child Development and Social Policy, recently described family day care as ''a cosmic crapshoot for America's parents.''

title: KEY RATES
'RIGHT TO DIE' INQUIRIES RISE AFTER RULINGS
description: Reacting to a set of New Jersey Supreme Court ''right to die'' rulings, families and friends of several seriously ill people in that state are preparing to move forward with requests that life-sustaining medical care be cut off, a patients' rights group said yesterday.

title: Joint Trading Plan Advances
description: Directors of the Chicago Board of Trade and the Chicago Board Options Exchange said yesterday that they had approved the framework of a joint venture agreement to allow members to trade a wide variety of new contracts on either exchange.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We have entered the most difficult period of restructuring -the period of practical deeds.'' - Mikhail S. Gorbachev. [ A1:6. ]

title: Small Choice
description: Of the 161 college players drafted by 23 National Basketball Assocation teams Monday, only 13 were not from National Collegiate Athletic Association Division I colleges. One of the exceptions was Art Sabb, a 6-foot-4-inch forward from Bloomfield (N.J.) College, a comparatively small (300 males enrolled) member of the National Association of Intercollegiate Athletics.

title: Texas Impeachment Motion
description: The speaker of the Texas House of Representatives, Gib Lewis, has reluctantly alllowed a bill for the impeachment of Governor Bill Clements to be introduced in the Texas House. The bill was introduced Wednesday by Representaives Paul Moreno of El Paso and Al Edwards of Houston and comes amid charges that the Governor tried to cover up the footbal scandal at Southern Methodist University.

title: STRIDE RITE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 29
At the Movies; Putting on Weight
description: For a film executive like Paul Heller, the proper word seems to be eclectic. After all, his first venture as a producer was ''David and Lisa'' (1963), a sensitive tale about two emotionally disturbed teen-agers. But he has also been involved with the kung fu epic ''Enter the Dragon'' (1973), starring the immortal Bruce Lee, and with such tourist attractions as ''The New York Experience'' and ''South Street Venture.''

title: Advertising; Millionaire Magazine Seeks Select Audience
description: Douglas Lambert, once publisher of Playgirl, the pioneer publication in male nudity for women, is now after a new target audience, and the magazine's title explains just who it is: Millionaire magazine.

title: CHICAGO MAYOR WINS A ROUND IN PARTY BATTLE
description: Edward R. Vrdolyak, the chief political foe of Mayor Harold Washington, was replaced as chairman of the Cook County Democratic Party today by George Dunne, an ally of the Mayor.

title: Broadway; A Success Story
description: The adage says that if at first you don't succeed, try again. But for Harve Brosten, it makes more sense to try again after you've already succeeded, because it doesn't take a genius to know that two successes are better than one.

title: CANDIDATES ARDENTLY WOOING THE POLITICAL REPORTER IN IOWA
description: Mike Glover, an Associated Press reporter in Des Moines, was having trouble paying attention to the debate on the Iowa House floor a few feet away. He was on the telephone with Gary Hart's press secretary. At his side, an aide to Representative Richard A. Gephardt was trying to get Mr. Glover's attention. Waiting to introduce himself was Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts. Such is life these days for reporters like Mr. Glover and David Yepsen, chief political writer of The Des Moines Register, whose reports on Presidential politicking appear in the newspapers that are read most by the people who will attend Iowa's Republican and Democratic precinct caucuses next February.

title: FLOWERS BY APPOINTMENT: FIVE TALENTS
description: Giacomo makes miniature meadows. Cory Davenport devises romantic combinations of old-fashioned flowers. Helena Lehane prefers to mass dozens of one kind of bloom. Sura Kayla mixes flowers, fruits, vegetables, birds' nests and butterflies. Rolf Nelson says his floral signature is his clients' taste.

title: Film: 'Dragnet,' Parody of Television Series
description: THE surprise about ''Dragnet,'' described by its director, Tom Mankiewicz, as ''a comedic homage to one of the classic television shows,'' is not that it's less than an unalloyed delight, but that it manages to be funny at all. The film opens today at the Gemini and other theaters.

title: JUSTICE OFFICIAL DETAILS PLOT BY 3 TO HIDE IRAN ROLE
description: An Assistant Attorney General described in exhaustive detail today how three senior officials tried to mislead investigators and hide facts as the Iran-contra affair became public.

title: Career Hurdle for Woodson
description: Of the hundreds of athletes competing here this week in the U.S.A./Mobil Outdoor Track and Field Championships, few had more to lose by winning than Rod Woodson.

title: Weekender Guide; FRIDAY
description: QUEENS SUMMERFEST

title: Curtis Dickey Released
description: The Cleveland Browns released Curtis Dickey, the running back, and Keith Baldwin, the defensive end. The 30-year-old Dickey, was the team's second-leading rusher last season with 523 yards on 135 carries and six touchdowns. Dickey's best game last season was the 106 yards he rushed for in Cleveland's 23-20 victory over the Vikings Oct. 26.

title: U.S. IS CRITICIZED ON TOXIC CLEANUP
description: Federal environmental officials were criticized Thursday by senators and environmentalists who said that the Reagan Administration has put cost above safety in setting standards for the cleanup of toxic waste.

title: Advertising; Spanish Venture Begun By Burson-Marsteller
description: Burson-Marsteller, the huge public relations subsidiary of Young & Rubicam, has made a deal with a Spanish news agency that should enhance its coverage of Latin America.

title: MARGARET HARRISON
description: Margaret Harrison, who served for 20 years as personal secretary to Arthur Hays Sulzberger, publisher of The New York Times from 1935 to 1961, died Tuesday at her home in New York City after a long illness. She was 72 years old.

title: REFLECTONE INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $460,631 for the quarter and $978,620 for the year. c-Net income d-After losses from discontinued operations of $785,504 and $1,202,012 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: U.S AID IN EGYPT
description: CAIRO, June 25 (reuters) - Egypt and the United States today signed three agreements giving Cairo $125 million in economic aid. Under the agreements, the public and private sectors will each get $50 million for commodity imports, the national Middle East News Agency said.

title: RULING MAY MAR GRAFT PROSECUTIONS
description: Public corruption prosecutions in the New York area in recent years were thrown into uncertainty yesterday following a Supreme Court decision that struck down a key mail-fraud provision used in scores of major convictions.

title: QUEEN LISTS THATCHER'S PLAN FOR CHANGE
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's Government disclosed an ambitious program of domestic legislation today that could make this session of Parliament the stormiest since she took office in 1979.

title: Televised Baseball Is for All the People
description: To the Editor:

title: Argentine Loans Praised
description: The Treasury Department said today that it was ''very pleased that the commercial banks have responded so quickly and positively'' to Argentina's appeal for new loans.

title: Jazz Festival; Ella Fitzgerald and Trio
description: ELLA FITZGERALD is a link to a vanished era of jazz - to Harlem's Savoy Ballroom when it was ''the home of happy feet,'' to the musically-rich 1940's and the parallel developments of late swing and early bop. People come to see Miss Fitzgerald to celebrate this heritage.

title: Home Group Adding Gruntal
description: As expected, the Home Group, parent of the Home Insurance Company, yesterday announced an agreement to acquire the Gruntal Financial Corporation, parent of Gruntal & Company, for about $145 million. Home is a major property and casualty insurer, while Gruntal is an East Coast regional brokerage firm.

title: Film: 'Straight to Hell'
description: AFTER he directed ''Sid and Nancy,'' the mercurial Alex Cox (who also made ''Repo Man'') reportedly needed a change of pace. So he co-wrote and directed ''Straight to Hell,'' a low-budget, freewheeling parody that amounts to one long private joke. On Sergio Leone's main set in Almeria, Spain -with traffic visibly whizzing back and forth in the background - Mr. Cox has assembled a cast of colorful punk miscreants and turned them loose. The result is a mildly engrossing, instantly forgettable midnight movie.

title: CUOMO URGES AUDITING PLAN IN DISPUTE WITH LEGISLATURE
description: Governor Cuomo, in the latest maneuver in a bitter dispute with the Legislature, today proposed regular outside audits of all parts of state government and hinted that he might block legislators' raises unless they agreed to the audits and to stricter ethics rules.

title: Pop/Jazz; THE VOICE OF VINTAGE JAZZ AT MICHAEL'S
description: ONE memorable night 30 years ago, Ella Mae Morse was waiting backstage at ''The Ed Sullivan Show'' to receive a gold record for her recording of ''Money Honey.'' Out front, Elvis Presley, who was also to be awarded a gold record for his version of ''Money Honey,'' growled and swiveled to a sea of shrieking adulation.

title: T.W.A. RELOCATING 500 TO WESTCHESTER uf980>
description: Trans World Airlines announced plans yesterday to move its corporate headquarters from Manhattan to Mount Kisco, a village in northern Westchester County.

title: INTERNATIONAL DAIRY QUEEN INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 29
Street Fair
description: A street fair to help preserve a cultural center on the Upper West Side will be held tomorrow from 11 A.M. to 6 P.M. on Amsterdam Avenue, from 73d to 76th Street. Proceeds from the fair, which will feature crafts, antiques, food and entertainment, will benefit a fund for the preservation of the Beacon Theater, Broadway and 76th Street; sponsors hope to keep the theater as a center of live entertainment. The rain date is June 28. Information: (212) 764-6330.

title: HUNGARY SHUFFLES ITS LEADERSHIP
description: The official Hungarian radio said today that President Pal Losonczi would retire and that Prime Minister Gyorgy Lazar would be replaced as part of a leadership reorganization.

title: Murder Sentence Delayed
description: The sentencing of Joe Hunt, the Billionaire Boys Club leader who was convicted of murder, was postponed today after his lawyer complained that he had not received Mr. Hunt's probation report in time to study it. Superior Court Judge Laurence Rittenband noted that California law requires delivery of probation reports nine days before sentencing and delayed the procedure to July 6.

title: A.M.A. Defines Policy On Drug Tests on Job
description: Employees should be tested for drug and alcohol abuse only in cases where there is reasonable suspicion of impaired job performance, the American Medical Association said today.

title: Combating International Drug Traffickers: Myth and Reality
description: To the Editor:

title: DEMOCRATS FAIL TO AGREE ON PLAN TO STOP NAVAL PROTECTION IN GULF
description: As the Reagan Administration prepares to provide American naval protection to Kuwaiti ships early in July, Democratic congressional opponents of the plan acknowledge they have failed to agree on a strategy to delay or block it, members of Congress said today.

title: Article 477087 -- No Title
description: Waste Management Inc., the world's biggest waste handler, says it has offered $2.5 million to settle a lawsuit filed over a hazardous waste landfill in this southern Illinois town.

title: And Jews?
description: To the Editor:

title: QUEENS JUDGE DEFENDS HIS INCONSISTANT TESTIMONY
description: Francis X. Smith, New York State's administrative judge in Queens, said at his perjury trial yesterday that if he gave inconsistent testimony to a grand jury investigating cable television franchises it was because he was trying to ''provide additional information'' under intense questioning.

title: GENERAL BUILDING PRODUCTS reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: The company said the current period takes into account the dilutive effect of issuing 1 million shares of common stock, the result of a public offering which took place on March 12, 1987.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Golf Levi Ahead by a Shot: Wayne Levi posted five consecutive birdies and six in his last seven holes yesterday to take the first-round lead by a stroke at the Canon Sammy Davis Jr. Hartford Open with a seven-under-par 64 on the Tournament Players Club course in Cromwell, Conn. Jim Thorpe sank a 20-foot birdie putt on his final hole to tie Dan Forsman, Wayne Levi and Bernhard Langer at 65 on the dry, 6,786-yard course that Thorpe said ''is playing like 6,200 or 6,300 yards.'' Tom Watson, who finished second by a stroke in the United States Open last Sunday, shot 67 in his quest for victory and a spot on the 12-member United States Ryder Cup team. Unless Watson wins this tournament or the PGA Championship in August he has virtually no chance to make the team, which will try to get the Ryder Cup back from the European team in the matches at Muirfield Village in Ohio Sept. 25-27. Watson missed qualifying for the 1985 Ryder Cup team by one shot at the PGA Championship that year. He is currently 16th in the standing based on points accumulated in 1986 and 1987 tour-sanctioned events through this year's PGA Championship. McLean Captures Playoff: Jim McLean of Quaker Ridge in Scarsdale, N.Y., defeated Mike San Filippo of Ridgeway, N.Y., in a playoff on the 19th hole to win the Manufacturers Hanover Westchester PGA Championship at Silver Spring in Ridgefield, Conn. McLean, a former all-American at Houston, trailed by three holes with five to play. He caught San Filippo at the 17th with an 18-foot putt for birdie. The victory, McLean's first individual title ever, earned him $1,500. San Filippo collected $1,000. Sailing Kookaburra II Is First: Kookaburra II of Australia took first place in the second race of the 12-meter world championship off Porto Cervo, Sardinia. Skippered by Peter Gilmour, Kookaburra II completed the 24.5-nautical mile course in 3 hours 23 minutes 37 seconds yesterday. White Horse Challenge of Britain finished second, 3 minutes 58 seconds behind. The Australian-Japanese boat Bengal, which won the opening race Tuesday, arrived third, 4:37 behind. Dennis Conner's Stars & Stripes, which won the America's Cup, finished fifth, 7:39 off the pace. It came in sixth in the first race. Yesterday's race will be followed by four fleet races, which together with three semifinal races, will decide the championship. Competition is scheduled to continue through July 11. Kookaburra II is the overall leader with 15.25 points.(AP) Road Racing Coates Wins Corporate Race: Budd Coates of Rodale Press, Emmaus, Pa., won the first in a series of three three-and-a-half-mile races in the Manufacturers Hanover Corporate Challenge with a time of 16 minutes 9 seconds in Central Park last night. A field of 9,674 competed. Michelle Bush of Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center set a women's meet record of 18:47.

title: Hubert Sumlin
description: Hubert Sumlin, a blues guitarist, will lead a band tonight and tomorrow at Tramps, 125 East 15th Street (212-777-5077), with sets at 9:30 P.M. and midnight. There is a $10 cover and a two-drink minimum.

title: Rocket Misses Delta Airliner
description: A small rocket glided past a Delta Air Lines jet today as it was flying over Charleston, W. Va., with 60 people aboard, officials said. The missile passed about 600 feet below the Boeing 737, according to a Delta spokesman, Bill Berry, and a spokesman for the Federal Aviation Administration, Jack Barker. The military was notified, Mr. Barker said, but the authorities were not ruling out the possibility that it was a homemade rocket.

title: Black Judge Is Sworn In
description: Robert D. Glass, the first black nominated to the Connecticut Supreme Court, was sworn in today. Gov. William A. O'Neill, who administered the oath to Judge Glass and a second nominee, Alfred V. Covello of West Hartford, called the moment historic. Judge Glass, 64 years old, of Waterbury, was named a Juvenile Court judge in 1967 and a Superior Court judge in 1978. Judge Covello, 54, was named in 1974 to the old Circuit Court, forerunner of the Superior Court.

title: AIRPLANE PLUNGES INTO BOSTON HOME
description: A twin-engine cargo plane crashed into a residential neighborhood three miles short of Logan Airport early this morning, killing the pilot and setting off a nine-alarm fire.

title:
Patents;
Radio System For NASA
description: LEAD: A RADIO communication system that is expected to lower the cost of transmission to phones in cars and receivers in spacecraft has been invented for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration.

title: DOOHAN RANKED 70TH, TOPS CHAMPION
description: Boris Becker understood that winning was not forever at Wimbledon, that one day he would make the long walk to the net on the grass courts he calls home to congratulate his opponent on a job well done. He hoped, however, to postpone that inevitability for as long as possible, perhaps even winning a third consecutive championship this year before he was forced to contemplate defeat.

title: The Course Is Clear But Some See Perils
description: Abel G. Aganbegyan, for years a maverick among Soviet economists, sat before a crowd of reporters tonight and conjured up a strange new world of Soviet socialism in which the omnipotent central planning agencies have withered, unneeded workers are dismissed, good companies are measured by their profits and bad companies go bankrupt.

title: Kemp Lone Republican At Hispanic Conference
description: Jack F. Kemp was not the only Presidential candidate to arrive in this palm-fringed, kiln-hot port on the Gulf of Mexico and address the nation's largest Hispanic political ogranization this afternoon.

title: MARIO ANDRETTI IS FAST EARLY
description: Mario Andretti went the fastest today in the first qualifying round for the Meadowlands Indy event Sunday, the auto race to be run on the access roads around the parking lots of the sports complex here.

title: RORER IN ANOTHER OFFER FOR ROBINS
description: The Rorer Group Inc. announced yesterday that it had made a new offer to merge with the A. H. Robins Company, which has been in bankruptcy proceedings for two years because of liability arising from its Dalkon Shield contraceptive device.

title: Ray Charles and Band At Avery Fisher Hall
description: Ray Charles and Grover Washington Jr. shared the bill for two JVC Jazz Festival concerts Thursday night at Avery Fisher Hall, and Mr. Charles unaccountably went on first; how, one might well ask, can Ray Charles be an opening act, especially (with all due respect) for Grover Washington Jr.?

title: BRITONS' NEW BID WINS JWT
description: The JWT Group, the world's fourth-largest advertising company, agreed yesterday to be taken over by a small British marketing company for $55.50 a share in the industry's first unsolicited acquisition.

title: Dr. Sally Feather Becomes a Bride
description: Dr. Sally Rhine Feather and William Tadd Hendrickson were married yesterday at Emerald Isle, N.C. The Rev. Elizabeth Woods Severance, a Presbyterian minister, officiated at the seaside ceremony.

title: HARVEY O. MERCIER
description: Harvey O. Mercier, an engineer and inventor of bakery machinery, died of a cerebral hemorrhage Thursday at St. Mary's Hospital in Tucson, Ariz. He lived in Green Valley, Ariz., and was 91 years old.

title: House Leaders Drop 2 Curbs On Arms From Budget Bill
description: In its first face-off on arms control this year, the Democratic leadership in the House of Representatives retreated today as it agreed to drop two key provisions from the supplemental budget for 1987.

title: BEACH PROPERTY OWNERS WIN HIGH COURT RULING
description: The Supreme Court today sharply limited the power of governments to force landowners to surrender part of their ownership rights without paying them compensation.

title: Missile Missing? Call Delta
description: The National Weather Service doubts it was theirs and the Defense Department insists it wasn't theirs. About the only thing the Federal Aviation Administration can say about the object that encountered a Delta Air Lines jet at 29,500 feet Thursday is that no one is likely to find it.

title: Music: Cabrillo Slavonic Chorus in Liturgy
description: The Roman Catholic liturgy and its Protestant offshoots have shaped -and in turn been shaped by - Europe's most important musicians. But the Russian Orthodox Church has guarded its probity, and its music comes to us today as a voice curiously fresh despite its age. Its style has both sidestepped musical evolution and reluctantly embraced it piecemeal - a fact that made Rachmaninoff's ''Liturgy of St. John Chrysostom'' at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine on Wednesday night such a fascinating study in ambivalence.

title: LEWIS LENGTHENS LONG-JUMP STREAK
description: For the first time in history, three long jumpers cleared 28 feet in the same meet today, with the best of them -hardly a surprise - Carl Lewis.

title: U.N.'s Torture Ban in Force
description: A convention seeking punishment for torturers and compensation for victims came into force today, the United Nations announced. It calls on nations to prevent torture, making it a criminal offense. It also provides for extradition of people suspected of torture and bars torturers from defending themselves by saying they acted on orders.

title:
Patents;
A Procedure to Detect A Suicidal Person
description: LEAD: A procedure for detecting a person's predisposition to commit suicide was patented this week by Dr. Stephen E. Silverman of Weston, Conn. The human voice is to be used in diagnosing and treating such psychiatric disorders.

title: Stein & Day Publishing Files for Bankruptcy
description: Stein & Day, a 25-year-old independent book publisher, has filed for protection under Chapter 11 of the Bankruptcy Code.

title: Schering to Sell Foreign Assets
description: The Schering-Plough Corporation said it had agreed to sell its Dr. Scholl's businesses in Europe and related assets in Latin America and East Asia to European Home Products P.L.C. The deal is worth $160 million.

title: U.S. Citizen From Texas Slain In China by Thieves on Train
description: A Texan was stabbed to death last week during a robbery on a train bound from Beijing to Canton, according to the American Embassy and the Chinese police. Two men have been arrested.

title: POLITBURO'S OTHER NEW FACES
description: VIKTOR P. NIKONOV

title: Allow Small Landlords to House Poor Families
description: To the Editor:

title: Kean Signs Bar Liability Bill
description: Governor Kean signed legislation today limiting the liability of bars and restaurants for damages caused by drunken customers. The bill, which takes effect in 90 days, is intended to reduce insurance costs by limiting the threat of negligence lawsuits. In a major change, the bill will make bar owners liable for damages only in proportion to their degree of blame.

title: U.S. ASSERTS CONVICTED JUDGE SHOWS NO REMORSE
description: Federal prosecutors in Brooklyn said yesterday that a former Civil Court judge who pleaded guilty to racketeering charges has shown no remorse for his acts, and they asked the sentencing judge to consider the motive of ''avarice.''

title: Bank Failures Now Total 94
description: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation has announced the 94th bank failure this year with the takeover of the South Denver National Bank of Glendale, Colo.

title: 42 SUBWAY NEWSSTANDS MAY BE SHUT BY M.T.A.
description: Riders at dozens of subway stations may soon find themselves with little to look at but one another. The Metropolitan Transportation Authority said yesterday that 42 subway newsstands would close by July 15 unless new operators could be found.

title: Church Bus Jumps Rail In Georgia, Killing Girl
description: A church bus ran off a road and plunged down a mountainside today, killing a 13-year-old girl and injuring 30 other young people.

title: A Living Legend: Talking Hangers With 'The King'
description: So, tell us, Mr. Hanger - ''Please,'' Bernie Spitz interrupts, ''call me Bernie.''

title: Bridge; Error May Draw Verbal Shot But Gunfire Is the Exception
description: Although it has not happened for almost 60 years, the possibility that a player will reach for a gun and shoot an erring partner cannot be totally discounted.

title: Dow Falls 14.19 Points In Moderate Trading
description: The stock market retreated a bit in moderate trading yesterday, moving in concert with a listless bond market.

title: How Some Films Combine Bad Reviews and Good Money
description: ''Light of Day,'' ''The Secret of My Success,'' ''Beverly Hills Cop II,'' ''Mannequin,'' ''Heartburn,'' ''Ishtar,'' ''The Name of the Rose,'' ''Tai-Pan'' and ''Ernest Goes to Camp'' have one thing in common. Most of the nation's critics gave them bad reviews.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article on Thursday about a Federal civil rights lawsuit filed by a former New York City deputy commissioner of environmental protection described the case incompletely.

title:
Patents;
Nine Children Honored
description: LEAD: The United States Patent Model Foundation is conducting Invent America!, a national education program to teach children problem-solving skills through the invention process. At the national awards ceremony held this week in the Washington Marriott Hotel, Vice President Bush presented awards to the nine elementary school winners.

title: HORSEPLAYERS' HONEYMOON
description: Everyone thought it highly amusing that the bride and groom were horseplayers, and did everything but order a pair of cooing thoroughbreds for the top of the wedding cake. When we left for a honeymoon in Britain just four days after the Belmont Stakes earlier this month, the wedding party's smug assumption was that we had timed the entire production to coincide with the opening of Royal Ascot.

title: Deja Vu Inside Out
description: The Iran-contra hearings recall an age when children's entertainment did not require buckets of gore to keep the tykes from getting restless.

title: GORBACHEV POLICY GAINS AS 3 ALLIES ADVANCE IN PARTY
description: In a major show of Mikhail S. Gorbachev's political strength, his contentious plan for restructuring the economy won formal backing today from the Communist Party's Central Committee.

title: Untapped Pool of Helpers in Bronx's Renewal
description: To the Editor:

title: ALBANY NEARS ETHICS ACCORD, CUOMO SAYS
description: Governor Cuomo said today that he had reached a ''conceptual agreement'' with legislative leaders on a new ethics code and on a system of regular outside audits of all parts of state government.

title:
Patents;
Identifying Genes To Develop Drugs
description: LEAD: A method for identifying in body tissue a gene that is related to a protein desired for pharmaceutical use has been patented for Genetics Institute Inc., a biopharmaceutical company in Cambridge, Mass. The inventors named in this week's patent 4,675,285 are Steven C. Clark, Randal J. Kaufman and Gordon G.

title: U.S. Chides Greece on Terror Group
description: A dispute developed today between Athens and Washington over United States intelligence reports saying that Athens had, for several months, conducted negotiations with the terrorist known as Abu Nidal. Greece rejected the assertions. The United States intelligence reports were presented at a meeting here Thursday between the Greek Foreign Minister, Karolos Papoulias, and the United States Ambassador, Robert Keeley, people with knowledge of the encounter said.

title: GANG MEMBERS SEIZED IN SLAYINGS OF 2 YOUTHS ABDUCTED IN QUEENS
description: Twelve to 15 members of an Asian gang have been arrested in the abduction and killing of two teen-agers whose bodies were found in the Saw Mill River earlier this year, the Westchester County police said today.

title: 2 Apparently Benign Polyps Found in Reagan
description: Two small polyps that the White House said appeared to be noncancerous were removed from President Reagan's colon today in what officials described as a routine medical checkup.

title: U.S. to Send Battleship To Help in Persian Gulf
description: The Navy has been ordered to send the battleship Missouri to the Middle East to insure that the United States can retaliate against Iran if it attacks American-flag vessels in the Persian Gulf, Pentagon officials said today.

title: Ranger 1-Hitter Stops Twins
description: Bobby Witt and Dale Mohorcic combined on a one-hitter, a solid single by Roy Smalley in the second inning, as the Texas Rangers beat the Minnesota Twins, 1-0, tonight.

title: Ms. Schwenker Is Wed To Kenneth D. Brody
description: The marriage of Carolyn Schwenker, an associate at the First Boston Corporation in New York, to Kenneth D. Brody, a partner in Goldman, Sachs & Company, took place yesterday at the Unitarian Church of All Souls in Manhattan. The Rev. F.Forrester Church performed the ceremony.

title: KILLER OF 4 IS SENTENCED TO DEATH IN CONNECTICUT
description: A Superior Court jury sentenced Michael A. Ross to death today for the murder of four teen-age girls in 1983 and 1984. The sentence was the first under Connecticut's seven-year-old capital punishment law.

title: India Cancels Silicon Plant
description: India today canceled a controversial contract with the Hemlock Corporation to set up an $80 million silicon-producing plant in India, saying that Indian producers could make the product just as efficiently.

title: PACT REACHED ON PROTECTION OF WETLANDS
description: Governor Kean and legislative leaders have reached agreement on legislation to protect New Jersey's freshwater wetlands, allowing the Governor to lift soon the moratorium on wetlands development that he signed 19 days ago and to claim a political victory.

title: YANKS, DOWN BY 9-0, WIN IN 10
description: By the third inning, it was already 9-0. The Yankees could not see themselves winning, not with Roger Clemens on the mound for the Boston Red Sox. Not with that deficit.

title: Ruotsalainen to Sweden
description: Reijo Ruotsalainen, a native of Finland who would like to compete for his country in the Winter Olympics next year, took a step toward making that possible by signing a one-year contract yesterday to play hockey with HV 71, one of the top teams in the semiprofessional hockey league of Sweden. Ruotsalainen, a 27-year-old defenseman, played five seasons with the Rangers before playing last winter in Switzerland and then, beginning in March, with the Edmonton Oilers as they won their third Stanley Cup in four seasons. ''He is a world-class player, we are expecting much of him,'' said Jan Larsson, a spokesman for the Swedish team, who explained that playing for HV 71 can qualify Ruotsalainen for the Finnish Olympic team.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: SATURDAY, JUNE 27, 1987
description: International 2-5, 28 Mikhail Gorbachev's economic plans won backing from the Communist Party Central Committee, and three of his allies were elected to full membership on the Politburo. It was a major show of Mr. Gorbachev's political strength. Page 1 News analysis: Soviet politics and policy have taken a startling turn. Mr. Gorbachev has laid to rest any doubt about whether he sides with the self-styled radicals who have pushed to quicken the pace of economic change. He is with them. 1 Man in the News: A. N. Yakovlev's promotion to the Politburo is the latest by Mr. Gorbachev of a man in his own mold. Mr. Yakovlev is an exponent of increased openness who is adroit in dealing with the West. 5 In Seoul, riot policemen struggled but ultimately managed to retain control of the city's streets against tens of thousands of anti-Government protesters. The clashes were the most ferocious in a week. 1 The South Korean protesters's goal is freedom, supporters said. In the Seoul neighborhood of Yongdungpo, the ferment of recent weeks has drawn the interest and emotions of many working-class residents. 3 A U.S. official expressed optimism about the situation in South Korea, saying President Chun Doo Hwan was amenable to changes. The State Department official, Gaston J. Sigur Jr., conferred with Mr. Chun this week. 3 William J. Casey repeatedly misled the House Intelligence Committee about the secret arms sales to Iran and the supply operation for the Nicaraguan rebels in one of his final appearances before the panel, a transcript shows. 1 OPEC is close to an agreement on a production quota for the second half of the year that is lower than originally projected. The apparent agreement is a victory for Iran, which wants to maximize prices, and a defeat for Saudi Arabia. 35 The trade status of Rumania was suspended. The Senate voted to suspend most-favored-nation trade status to the country for six months to protest Rumanian policies on human rights and emigration. 5 In a skirmish on arms control, the Democratic leadership in the House of Representatives retreated, as it agreed to drop two key provisions from the supplemental budget for 1987. 2 U.S. chides Greece on terrorists 4 Zakinthos journal 4 U.S.-Spain talks on bases recess 4 Beirut kidnappers identified 4 50 killed in Philippine air crash 28 Japanese quits whale group 28 National 6, 12-14, 32-33 Justice Lewis F. Powell Jr. retired from the Supreme Court for reasons of age and health. His surprise announcement set the stage for what is certain to be a bitter, politically charged Senate confirmation battle. 1 A successor will be named quickly for Justice Powell in the hope of finding a candidate who tips the ideological balance on key issues without generating a protracted confirmation fight with the Senate, officials said. 1 Justice Powell sat at the center of an often polarized Supreme Court for a decade and a half. The Court's balancer and compromiser, he is creating, through retirement, a particular void, in tone as well as substance. 32 In a victory for property owners, the Supreme Court, in a 5-to-4 decision, sharply limited the power of governments to force landowners to surrender ownership rights without them compensation. 33 The President had polyps removed from his colon at a medical checkup. White House officials said the two small polyps appeared to be noncancerous, but the results of pathology tests are not expected to be available until Monday. 1 The JWT Group will be purchased by a much smaller British marketing company. The purchase of theworld's fourth largest advertising company by the WPP Group is the industry's first unsolicited acquisition. 35 Jack Kemp's focus on minorities has been among the hallmarks of his Presidential campaign. He has called for his party to reach out to voters who are black, Hispanic, poor or members of other disadvantaged groups. 14 A Republican strategy to recapture the political initiative appears to be emerging. In a speech, the chairman of the Republican National Committee used the strategy, which focuses attention on Democratic tax and spending proposals. 14 A twin-engine cargo plane crashed three miles short of Boston's Logan Airport in a residential neighborhood, killing the pilot and setting off a nine-alarm fire, which gutted three buildings and seven cars. 6 Louisiana political challengers tone down ads 6 Indian and Eskimo births rising 12 House votes $350 million to combat acid rain 14 Regional 29-31 General outlines for an ethics code for New York State political leaders and a system of regular outside audits of all parts of state government have been agreed on by Governor Cuomo and legislative leaders, the Governor said. 29 42 subway newsstands may close unless contracts can be settled, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority said. An agreement with Kapoor Brothers Inc. is being terminated because the company owed back rent and fees. 31 Honors for District 4 schools in East Harlem have come from the White House, the MacArthur Foundation, and to the students, whose test scores were up yet again. ''This has been the best year the district has ever had,'' one official said. 29 A 'special independent investigator' was called for by New York State Assembly Republicans to look into allegations of improper business dealings by the executive director of the Thruway Authority, Alexander A. Levine. 30 Sale of Queens Farms Dairy's assets in New York City to John Labatt Ltd., the Canadian beer and food conglomerate, was announced by Labatt officials. 29 A law to protect freshwater wetlands in New Jersey has been agreed on by Governor Kean and legislative leaders. The agreement paves the way for the Governor to lift his moratorium on wetlands development. 29 In the Bess Myerson inquiry, the United States Attorney in Manhattan, Rudolph W. Giuliani, objected to the disclosure of secret testimony and other materials concerning the former New York City Cultural Affairs Commissioner. 31 Hotel suite named for Gleason 12 Death sentence in Connecticut 30 Kaufman to become senior judge 31 Convicted ex-judge assailed 31 Criminal to get psychiatric test 31

title: Japanese Quits Whale Group
description: Commissioner Tatsuo Saito said today that he was quitting the International Whaling Commission to protest what he called its ''constant vote against Japan.''

title: BEDROSIAN CAN SAVE THEM ALL
description: The Mets got another taste of reality tonight when they lost to the Philadelphia Phillies for the first time this year and played a part in somebody else's moment in baseball history.

title: Organ Series Canceled
description: An organ recital series that was to begin July 7 at Riverside Church, Riverside Drive and 122d Street, has been canceled because of a malfunction in the church nave's climate control system, according to Barbara Nelson, a spokeswoman at the church. While the organ can still be used for religious services, additional use of the instrument must be restricted. The series was to have taken place each Tuesday through Aug. 11.

title: British Invasion Likely to Persist
description: The spate of British takeovers of American advertising agencies will have a much greater impact on the way the agencies do business than on the content of their ads, industry experts said yesterday.

title: St. Paul Insurance Medical Policies
description: The St. Paul Fire and Marine Insurance Company unit of the St. Paul Companies said it would extend for six months, until Dec. 31, its medical liability policies for physicians in Florida. In April, the company had told 5,300 Florida doctors that their coverage would not be renewed as of July 1.

title:
Patents;
Reactor Unit Designed To Withstand Quakes
description: LEAD: A nuclear reactor fuel assembly with a large tube to carry cooling water was patented this week for the General Electric Company in San Jose, Calif. The assembly is designed to avoid damage to the fuel rods in case of a seismic event such as an earthquake.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 12.

title: INSIDE
description: OPEC May Curtail Output The oil nations moved near agreement on a smaller increase in production than they had planned for the rest of the year. An agreement would be a victory for Iran. Page 35.

title: They're Taking New York Away From Me
description: LEAD: Nothing New York has enriched my sensibilities with, nothing this city citizen is fond of, is remotely forever.

title: Key to a Cure for Ailing Retiree Health Funds
description: To the Editor:

title: A Call to Workers By United President
description: Frank A. Olson, the president and chief executive of United Airlines, has sought to rally United's 63,000 employees in a blunt and spirited letter that includes an unusally sharp slap at the labor policies of Frank Lorenzo, the chairman of the Texas Air Corporation, which owns Continental Airlines.

title: Gillette Wins Court Test
description: In a victory for the Gillette Company, a Delaware court yesterday halted an attempt by a group of shareholders to force the company to consider a takeover bid from Revlon Inc.

title: Hornets Appoint Two
description: George Shinn, the owner of the Charlotte (N.C.) Hornets, a National Basketball Association expansion club that will begin play during the 1988-89 season, has hired Carl Scheer, the commissioner of the Continental Basketball Association, and Max Muhleman, a sports marketing consultant, for key positions with the team. Scheer, the former general manager of the Denver Nuggets and the Carolina Cougars of the American Basketball Association, will become a vice president on a full-time basis when he completes his C.B.A. commitment on Jan. 1. Muhleman, who was involved in Charlotte's efforts to obtain a franchise, will serve as an executive consultant.

title: Magnifying a Few Million Dollars
description: Topic A in the new New York State budget is obviously the unforeseen surplus of unpredicted hundreds of millions, arising mostly from changes in Federal tax law. But there's also a Topic B, involving much smaller amounts of money but equally welcome good news: sensible reform.

title: Demonstrators in Belgrade Charge Albanian Persecution
description: More than 1,000 Serbs and Montenegrins from Kosovo Province protested outside Parliament today over what they said was persecution by ethnic Albanians.

title: GIULIANI OBJECTS TO DISCLOSURES ABOUT MYERSON
description: The United States Attorney in Manhattan, Rudolph W. Giuliani, objected yesterday to the disclosure of secret testimony concerning Bess Myerson.

title: L.I. Man Is Accused Of Killing His Father
description: A 48-year-old man has been charged with killing his 75-year-old father in their home early yesterday during an argument over the son's lack of a job.

title: Contract for Konroyd
description: About five days before he would have become a free agent requiring compensation had he not re-signed with the Islanders, Steve Konroyd agreed to a multiyear contract yesterday. Terms of the agreement were not disclosed. Konroyd, a veteran of 435 National Hockey League games over six seasons, came to the Islanders in March 1986 in a trade with the Calgary Flames. Last season, Konroyd, a defenseman, scored 5 goals and had 16 assists.

title: REAGAN REBUFFED ON ACID RAIN FUNDS
description: The House has voted to spend $350 million for intensified research to control acid rain, far short of the $2.35 billion President Reagan requested to support his pledge to Canada for greater United States efforts in this area.

title: Lomas & Nettleton Sets Price on Deal
description: The Lomas & Nettleton Financial Corporation said it had fixed a market value of about $263 million on its purchase of the Equitable Life Leasing Corporation, a unit of the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States. The figure is based on an average closing price of $29.46 a share for Lomas's stock during the 20 trading days ended June 25.

title: Cedar Walton At the Piano
description: Cedar Walton's solo piano concert Thursday at Weill Recital Hall had an air of utter solidity. His right hand is a marvel of speed and assurance; his left hand grounds the music in earthy, full-voiced chords. Playing standards, a Thelonious Monk medley and a few of his own compositions, Mr. Walton brought out blues and gospel underpinnings, creating a cushion of harmony while his right hand streaked around the keyboard.

title: THE POLITBURO: WHO'S IN AND WHO'S OUT
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev appointed three men believed to be strong allies to the Communist Party Politburo yesterday, raising the membership of the key policy-making body to 14 and consolidating his power. Here is the current Politburo lineup, including voting full members and nonvoting candidate members, and the members who have left since Mr. Gorbachev took office in March 1985. * Came to office or was promoted after Mr. Gorbachev came to power. FULL MEMBERS Mikhail S. Gorbachev, party leader Geidar A. Aliyev, First Deputy Prime Minister *Viktor M. Chebrikov, K.G.B. chief Andrei A. Gromyko, President *Yegor K. Ligachev, second-ranking party leader, in charge of ideology and party personnel *Viktor P. Nikonov, party secretary in charge of agriculture *Nikolai I. Ryzhkov, Prime Minister Vladimir V. Shcherbitsky, Ukrainian party chief *Eduard A. Shevardnadze, Foreign Minister *Nikolai N. Slyunkov, economics secretary Mikhail S. Solomentsev, Party Control Commission chief Vitaly I. Vorotnikov, Premier of Russian Republic *Aleksandr N. Yakovlev, party propaganda chief *Lev N. Zaikov, military industries secretary CANDIDATE MEMBERS Pyotr N. Demichev, first Vice President Vladimir I. Dolgikh, national party secretary for industry *Yuri F. Solovyev, Leningrad party chief *Nikolai V. Talyzin, chairman of Gosplan, the planning agency, and a First Deputy Prime Minister *Dmitri T. Yazov, Defense Minister *Boris N. Yeltsin, Moscow city party chief FORMER MEMBERS Viktor V. Grishin, former Moscow city chief Dinmukhamed A. Kunayev, former Kazakhstan chief Grigory V. Romanov, former national party secretary Nikolai A. Tikhonov, former Prime Minister Vasily V. Kuznetsov, former First Vice President (candidate) Boris N. Ponomarev, former national party secretary (candidate) Sergei L. Sokolov, former Defense Minister (candidate)

title: CUISINE A LA BRONX SHINES AT DINNER TO HONOR ARTIST
description: It was Bronx night at the French Culinary Institute Thursday. The artist being honored, Carlos Rodriguez, was born in the Bronx. The guest chef, Brendan Walsh, was, too, and for the occasion he produced a menu of Bronx food: knishes, cannelloni, baccala and plantains, fried chicken and collard greens, pot roast and frozen summer vegetables.

title: Abbott, Red Cross Sued Over Tests
description: Abbott Laboratories said it had been sued by the Genetic Systems Corporation unit of Bristol-Myers Inc., which contends that an Abbott contract with the American Red Cross, for the supply of AIDS tests used to screen blood donations, is a violation of antitrust laws.

title: For Gleason, a Suite and, Maybe, a Bus Depot
description: The midtown hotel suite where Jackie Gleason lived in the 1950's while creating ''The Honeymooners'' for television was named yesterday for the comedian who charmed millions of viewers as Ralph Kramden, the blustering, sashaying bus driver-dreamer from Brooklyn.

title: Raymond Impellittiere Married to Ms. Carlson
description: Stephanie Carlson, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore J. Carlson of Briarcliff Manor, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Raymond Thomas Impellittiere, the son of Agnes Impellittiere of Cold Spring, N.Y., and the late Raymond J. Impellittiere. The Rev. Joel Egge performed the ceremony at Faith Lutheran Brethren Church.

title: No Time for Generals in Panama
description: In Panama, a thuggish military regime has dropped the facade of constitutional rule and governs by emergency decree. In Washington, a flawed policy of endorsing sham democracy for the sake of stability has come unraveled. Recognizing that, the Reagan Administration now distances itself from Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, the Panamanian strongman. It's time to go further by pressing him to step aside and give real democracy a chance.

title: A Greek Drama: Tourists vs. Turtles
description: The sea turtles are coming again this year. And that, said Christos Pastras, between bouts of wind-surfing and collecting the $4 fee on his beach umbrellas, is a good thing.

title: The French Have No Monopoly on Sloth
description: To the Editor:

title: ABNER W. BERRY
description: Abner W. Berry, a former editor of the Harlem edition of The Daily Worker, died of complications of a stroke Wednesday at the Nash General Hospital in Rocky Mount, N.C. He was 85 years old and lived in Rocky Mount.

title: Pratt & Whitney
description: Pratt & Whitney, a unit of the United Technologies Corporation, said that Korean Air Lines had selected its PW4000 engine for use in new aircraft in a deal that could be worth as much as $430 million. The company said Korean Air had ordered 38 of the engines and took options on 42 more.

title: Collision of an Amtrak Train And a Truck Is Fatal to Driver
description: An Amtrak train with 32 people aboard slammed into a dump truck at an unguarded crossing today, killing the truck driver and injuring 29 people, the officials said.

title: Municipals Retain Allure
description: DURING the debate over tax revision last year, some people worried that municipal bonds would become much less popular because of the lowering of personal tax rates. But since the passage of the new tax law, municipals have continued to be a widely used alternative for many individuals who still find themselves in maximum combined Federal and state tax brackets of 40 percent or more.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Horse Racing Polish Navy Rules: Polish Navy, a leading 2-year-old of last season who missed the Triple Crown races this year while recovering from knee surgery, scored an impressive five-length victory over older horses yesterday at Belmont Park. Polish Navy shot to the lead, dueled with Basket Weave through a half-mile in 45 2/5, then pulled clear around the turn and drew off by five lengths. Parade Marshal finished second, a neck in front of Samerkand as Basket Weave trailed in the field of four. Polish Navy's time of 1:23 1/5 was very respectable, given the somewhat dull track. The horse won his first four starts last year, including the Cowdin Stakes and the Champagne Stakes, but then lost the 2-year-old championship when he ran seventh in the Breeders' Cup Juvenile. He was found to have bone chips in his knees, and underwent surgery. He returned to action three weeks ago with a second-place finish in the Riva Ridge Stakes. Golf Aaron Takes First-Round Lead: Tommy Aaron shot a six-under-par 65 yesterday to take the first-round lead in the P.G.A. Seniors Tour $250,000 Greater Grand Rapids Open. The 50-year-old Aaron, in his first year on the tour, shot his lowest round of the year to take a three-shot lead over Bill Casper, Orville Moody and Bob Charles. (AP) Richard Keeps Pace: Deb Richard had four consecutive birdies on the final holes she played yesterday, maintaining her lead in the $300,000 Rochester International tournament, whose second round was delayed by rain. Officials stopped play because of darkness as Richard was about to begin the 18th hole. Richard, who shot a six-under-par 66 on Thursday, was at 132, nine under par. Lori Garbacz, who who completed the second round with a five-under 67 on the 6,162-yard Locust Hill Country Club course, was at six-under 138. Sailing Kookaburra II Wins Again: Kookaburra II of Australia sailed to her second straight victory yesterday, winning the third race of the 12-meter world championship off Porto Cervo, Sardinia. Peter Gilmour skippered the winner over the 24.5-nautical mile course in 3 hours 7 minutes 39 seconds. New Zealand was second in 3:08.26, and Dennis Conner's Stars & Stripes took third in 3:09.56. Kookaburra II is the overall leader, with 23.50 points, followed by the Australian-Japanese boat Bengal with 19.25. The competition is scheduled to continue through July 11. (AP)

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article last Saturday about American Jewish criticism of the plan by Pope John Paul II to receive President Kurt Waldheim of Austria misstated accusations made against Mr. Waldheim. Because of an editing error, the misstatement was repeated in a Rome dispatch on Sunday. Mr. Waldheim has been linked by the Justice Department to participation in ''activities amounting to persecution'' of Jews and others, and he was an officer in a Nazi German Army unit that carried out deportations of Partisans and sent thousands of Jews to death camps, but he has not been accused of physically taking part in deportations or executions.

title: Iran Is Reported to Hit Two Tankers in Gulf
description: Iranian gunboats hit two tankers off the Persian Gulf coast of Saudi Arabia overnight, shipping sources said today.

title: 3 Are Found Guilty In Beating of a Black
description: Three young Brooklyn men, said to be members of a Hasidic patrol, were found guilty last night of assault charges for the predawn beating of a black teen-ager last July 4 in the Crown Heights section.

title: 2 Fishermen Rescued at Sea
description: Two Long Island fishermen who spent a night clinging to seat cushions in the Atlantic Ocean after their small boat overturned were rescued today by police boats and a helicopter, the authorities said. The fishermen, Richard Erny, 37 years old, of 4 Adam Place in Massapequa, and Richard Kelly, 40, of 118 Juniper Street in Islip, were three-quarters of a mile off Long Beach, the police said. They were in serious condition at St. John's Episcopal Hospital in Far Rockaway, Queens, where they were treated for shock, hypothermia and exposure, the police said.

title: Dance: 'Soldat' by Dutch Troupe
description: The Netherlands Dance Theater's second program at the Metropolitan Opera House Thursday night featured two Stravinsky works choreographed by the company's artistic director, Jiri Kylian - ''L'Histoire du Soldat'' (A Soldier's Tale) and ''Svadebka,'' also known as ''Les Noces.'' ''Stamping Ground,'' inspired by aboriginal dances Mr. Kylian saw in Australia, completed the evening.

title: Langer Up by Two At Hartford Open
description: Bernhard Langer had not played the unusual and easy Tournament Players Club of Connecticut before this week. But a man with his skills only needs to be pointed in the direction of the first tee and be told to ''play away.''

title: THE HARD-SELLING OF GOLDOME
description: Goldome has earned itself a reputation in the thrift industry for innovation and aggressiveness. If anything, its critics say, the nation's largest mutual savings bank has come too far, too fast. So it is no surprise that Goldome's push to go public involves an innovative and aggressive marketing campaign.

title: Reynolds Metals Sues Gas Supplier
description: The Reynolds Metals Company has sued Columbia Gas System Inc., contending that Columbia violated antitrust laws by refusing to supply Reynolds with natural gas sold by independent producers. The suit, filed in United States District Court here, accused Columbia of abusing its monopoly by forcing Reynolds to purchase natural gas exclusively from Columbia.

title: Indian and Eskimo Births Rising
description: America's Indians and Eskimos are experiencing a sharp increase in births, and their children are surprisingly healthy despite delayed prenatal care and a high incidence of premature births, new Federal statistics indicate.

title: U.S.-Spain Talks on Bases Recess
description: United States and Spanish negotiators ended two days of talks here today without either side budging from past positions on the future of American bases.

title: DIRECT MAIL: ENVELOPES AND ETHICS
description: WALT LUKENS says there are two things he is not: a brain surgeon or a manipulator. He is simply attentive to detail and to the first, most basic goal of the direct mailer. ''You've got to make the guy get inside the envelope,'' he says.

title: Oral Roberts Tells Conference He Has Raised People From the Dead
description: Oral Roberts, the television evangelist, says he has raised people from the dead. He also said God had told him that Mr. Roberts would return with Jesus to reign over the earth.

title: Execution Would Be The First Since 1960
description: Connecticut's electric chair, known as ''Old Sparky,'' has not been used since 1960. It has never been tested since it was moved from the former state prison in Wethersfield to the state prison in Somers in 1962. And officials say the electrical system at Somers cannot handle the power needed to make the chair function.

title: HOUSE UNIT LISTS 200 TAX IDEAS
description: The House Ways and Means Committee, facing a one-month deadline to develop a plan to raise $64.3 billion in new taxes, today released a staff-prepared list of ideas for meeting that goal.

description: The White House started looking for a new Supreme Court Justice today, hoping to tip the ideological balance on key issues without generating a protracted confirmation fight with the Democratic-controlled Senate.

title: IN THE GORBACHEV MOLD: ALEKSANDR NIKOLAYEVICH YAKOVLEV
description: During the summit meeting in Iceland last year, Aleksandr N. Yakovlev engaged in a low-key, private talk with American officials that resulted in a quick deal to stop the jamming of some American radio broadcasts to the Soviet Union.

title: The 'Toughness' Candidate in 1988
description: As we approach another Presidential election, the political commentators are again telling us what qualities the people are looking for in a candidate. High on the list is ''toughness.'' Recently I heard a guest commentator on the Voice of America explaining that if the Democrats are to recover the White House they must select a ''tough'' candidate like Harry S. Truman, John F Kennedy or Lyndon B. Johnson - all winners - and not a ''preacher'' like Adlai E. Stevenson, Hubert H. Humphrey, George McGovern or Walter F. Mondale - all losers. He said Jimmy Carter was a special case - a ''preacher'' who won, but only because the country wanted an antidote to Watergate.

title: Second Student Dies At Disputed School For Autism Sufferers
description: A 29-year-old student at a school for the autistic died Thursday, two days after she suffered a heart attack.

title: NONHUMANS EVOLVING AS STARS OF TV SHOWS
description: More and more lately, prime-time television stars are looking less and less human.

title: Man Held in 1965 Murder
description: A skeleton unearthed in the rubble of a burned-out house proved to be the remains of a girl who disappeared 22 years ago, and the police here have charged a man with her murder. Conrad Eugene Miller, 40 years old, of Prospect was arrested on Wednesday and charged in the death of Patricia Desmond, who disappeared in December 1965, when she was 15. Despite evidence that Miss Desmond had been seen with Mr. Miller on the day she disappeared, the police dropped the case in the early 1970's because they could not find her body.

title: Louisiana Challengers Tone Down Ads, a Little
description: At first, the Louisiana gubernatorial race might seem likely to produce gritty political attacks, focusing on an incumbent dogged by accusations of corruption in a state that relishes a good election fight.

title: Kenny Barron Piano Recital
description: Kenny Barron, a pianist who substituted for the ailing Dave McKenna in the JVC Jazz Festival's solo piano series at Weill Recital Hall on Wednesday, is master of a multitude of styles. As the musical associate of Stan Getz earlier in the festival, Mr. Barron delivered achingly lyrical interludes whose emotional eloquence matched the most rhapsodic flights of Keith Jarrett and Bill Evans. By himself, however, Mr. Barron offered music that was decidedly less pretty as he sought a more percussive balance between melody and rhythm.

description: The Federal Communications Commission was ordered by a Federal appeals court today to review its 1984 decision deregulating the content of children's television because it had ''failed sufficiently to justify its action.''

title: G.E. Sets Layoffs
description: The General Electric Company said it planned to lay off about 500 production employees, as well as several hundred salaried workers, next year at its aircraft engine plants here and in Everett, Mass. It pointed to the Navy's decision to switch much of its F404 engine manufacturing to the Pratt & Whitney division of United Technologies. The engine is used in F-18 fighter planes.

description: The Senate, in a slap to the Administration, voted, 57 to 36, today to suspend most-favored-nation trade status for Rumania for six months to protest Rumanian policies on human rights and emigration.

description: The chairman of the Republican National Committee today attacked Democrats for their handling of the budget, saying they ''bleed red ink'' and are ''shrinking from our role as the world's great power.''

description: MY wife and I have never qualified as true bird watchers. Appreciative observers, yes, but with no official bird walks to our credit. Recently however, and without our quite realizing it, we became deeply immersed in the doings of the bird world. It began quite casually one April morning. title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: DOING WORDS. By Katie Johnson. (Houghton Mifflin, $15.95.) In a small, cluttered classroom in rural Maine, Katie Johnson's first graders are learning to read, but not by fitting themselves into someone else's world, like the antiseptic family life of Dick, Jane, Sally and Puff. Instead, Ms. Johnson's pupils are creating their own texts - words at first, then sentences and eventually stories. The words are not imposed by adults; they come from a child's own experience, growing out of friendships, family, fears and joys. And as they write these words - these ''key words'' or building blocks - they come to possess them as easily as they possess the feelings and images that provoked them. Harnessing the raw child power she finds in abundance, Ms. Johnson leads her classes through six stages, or movements, of doing words, an adaptation of the approach outlined almost 25 years ago by Sylvia Ashton-Warner in her book ''Teacher.'' As it was with Ms. Ashton-Warner's Maori children in New Zealand, so it is with Ms. Johnson's in New England: self-expression is powerful magic. In ''Doing Words,'' Ms. Johnson, who has refined her method in the course of a dozen years, has compiled a how-to book for teachers as well as a loving, anecdotal guidebook for parents who want an insight into childhood potential.

title: EXPRESSION IN STAMFORD
description: NOW operating under the aliases of postmodernism and pluralism, Romanticism is as powerful as it has ever been in its career of some 200 years. The reason, no doubt, is that this movement-cum-state of mind that previously required only a yearning for the ineffable today aspires to nothing more lofty than self-expression. The title ''Private Expression; Personal Experience'' seems to confirm this, although the show that it designates is no exercise in narcissism.

title: WEEK OF FESTIVALS AND FIREWORKS

On the banks of the Saugatuck River in Westport, $10, or $5 for children and the elderly, will gain admission tonight to a variety show headlined by Felix Cavaliere, the former lead singer of the Young Rascals; John Sebastian of the Lovin' Spoonful; the Mikki Williams Dancers, and others.

title: THE IMPORTANCE OF BEING REMEMBERED
description: THE phone rang. Stirring a pot of sticky green-pea soup with one hand, I grabbed the receiver with the other. ''Is this Sue Allen from Ames, Iowa?'' a deep voice asked over long-distance crackling. ''Yes,'' I said, knees beginning to quiver. I knew what he was going to say next, and he did: ''This is a voice out of your past.'' A little laugh, then an awkward silence. Whoever was calling had obviously just read one of my two memoirs. ''Blooming'' covers my childhood in Ames, Iowa, in the 1940's and 1950's; ''Ivy Days'' continues the story through Smith College, in Northampton, Mass., and graduate school in Berkeley, Calif. The second book ends more than 20 years ago. ''Do you know who this is?'' the voice went on, in a nudging tone. ''No, I'm afraid I don't,'' I answered apologetically. I somehow felt I ought to know. ''Well, this is Brian Beeman. I've just read your book, and I wanted to call up and say hello.''

title: Winning Back A Child

description: From the time he was arrested, West German authorities have resisted United States demands to extradite Mohammed Ali Hamadei. The 22-year-old Lebanese is suspected of taking part in the June 1986 hijacking of a T.W.A. airliner, in which an American Navy diver, Robert Stethem, was killed. Last week, Bonn made it official: Mr. Hamadei will be tried on air piracy and murder charges in Frankfurt, where he was caught in January with three bottles of a liquid explosive.

title: Pirates Honor Kiner
description: RALPH KINER will be the focus of attention before the Mets play the Pirates in Pittsburgh on Sept. 19, when he will be stepping out of the Met broadcast booth to be honored by his old ball club. The Pirates announced yesterday that they would retire Kiner's No. 4 in ceremonies before the game. Pittsburgh will also retire Bill Mazeroski's No. 9 before the Pirates-Montreal Expos game Aug. 7. Kiner, who is 64 years old, ranks second on the Pirates' career home run list with 301 and either won or shared the National League home run title in each of his seven full Pittsburgh seasons. He was inducted into the Baseball Hall of Fame in 1975. Mazeroski, 49, is best known for being the only player to end the seventh and final game of a World Series with a home run. His bases-emtpy shot in the bottom of the ninth inning against the Yankees' Ralph Terry on Oct. 13, 1960, gave the Pirates a 10-9 victory. Mazeroski won eight Gold Glove awards during his 17 major league seasons and still holds the record for most double plays by a second baseman, 161, in 1966.

title: Coming Attraction in Soviet: Festival of India
description: With Mikhail S. Gorbachev and Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi in attendance, a gentle Hindu invocation by an Indian singer at Cathedral Square at the Kremlin next Friday will start a huge celebration in the Soviet Union of India's art, culture, history and economic and scientific progress.

But now that the United States and the Soviet Union are closer to agreement on reducing medium-range and banning shorter-range missiles, some Administration officials are finding that strict verification can be a double-edged sword.

Fifteen hundred miles later, when we returned, we had crisscrossed the deserts and mountains of Rajasthan and toured legendary palaces and fortresses.

title: Citizens Panel Will Study Ethical Questions Raised by AIDS
description: A private commission has been established by groups in New York and New Jersey to examine some of the most troubling political and social implications of the AIDS epidemic, including mandatory testing for the virus that causes the disease.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: LEAD: SPEAK TO THE EARTH: Wanderings and Reflections Among Elephants and Mountains. By Vivienne de Watteville. (Norton, $18.95.) In 1928, at the age of 28, Vivienne de Watteville set out alone from England to go ''make friends'' with the wild game of Kenya. She had been touched by the beauty of Africa five years earlier while accompanying her father on a hunting expedition.

title: BOSTON'S CHANCE FOR ITS OWN BATTERY PARK CITY
description: THERE ARE TWO WAYS OF GET-ting a lot more office space into an existing downtown: squeezing it in or adding it on. This may seem painfully obvious, but it's too often forgotten in the endless debate over the future of our major cities. There really are no empty lots in our denser and more prosperous cities; simply by being built, every large-scale project is going to disrupt something. If building a significant amount of new office space is an economic necessity, there is not going to be any painless way to put it anywhere. When massive developments are shoehorned into the existing urban fabric, they can be devastating to the scale and the quality of life of the city. When ambitious projects are built on the edges of the existing business district, expanding the downtown rather than filling it up more tightly, this growth can overwhelm very different kinds of neighborhoods, changing their character forever.

title: CORRECTION

Representative Mushinsky, a Wallingford Democrat who is co-chairwoman of the General Assembly's Environment Committee, was looking for marine life in the sediment, which was taken from Long Island Sound.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: LINES OF BATTLE: Letters From American Servicemen, 1941-1945. Edited by Annette Tapert. (Times Books, $22.50.) Generals' memoirs are all very well and so are military histories, but to convey what war is really like, one must go to the soldier whose strategic outlook is limited to the next treeline or flying mission. This book of letters from World War II, skillfully edited by Annette Tapert, who earlier produced a similar volume in Britain, paints a picture of living and fighting a war from the standpoint of the men who were doing it. The letters are the thoughts and words of men who, in the words of a Marine dive-bomber pilot, ''want to get back home . . . with their wives, or get back a job, or work on a farm.'' To John Babbitt, an artilleryman, North Africa ''looked like Florida, palm trees and all,'' but it was where he ''went many nights without sleep, many days not much to eat or drink,'' where home was a foxhole dug with hands and helmet. Officers, who censored one another's mail, had wider opportunities for description than did the enlisted men. Indeed, the letters of Brig. Gen. Theodore Roosevelt Jr. from North Africa and Europe are marvels of capsule history, sensitive and thoughtful. The book, properly, has a mosaic quality; it is an engaging footnote to history, and David Eisenhower, the grandson of one of that war's great commanders, provides a competent introduction. It is liberally illustrated with photographs, too many of soldiers reading or writing letters, but the pictures of the men who were the authors will cause veterans to pose that age-old question: ''Were we really that young?''

title: The Beatles And Youth At Auction

He bought a cheap guitar and made his rock debut at age 13 as the lead singer in a garage band called the Rat Pack, a group that fell apart soon after its teen-age members discovered automobiles.

description: LEAD: IN show business, few traditions are as venerable as the out-of-town tryout. And Bethpage has become ''out of town'' for at least one professional company - the Manhattan Class Company, giving Long Islanders a chance not only to be privy to the discovery phase of theater, but also to evaluate what they see.

description: The arrogant prima donnas at Shea didn't deserve to win it all last year. Without Lady Luck shining on them, the Mets are another ordinary club.

title: The Gold Watch
description: IT HANGS, SUSPENDED IN A glass enclosure, near my record-playing equipment, and that means that I see it every day. A gold pocket watch made in Schaffhausen, probably from the 1930's, emphatically unfashionable today but not old enough to be ''antique.'' The hands are stopped at 6:40. In all likelihood, it was P.M., because I don't remember ever rewinding it since the watch passed into my hands at the railroad station in Budapest on April 15, 1939, the last day of my ''early life.''

With its short skirt and skintight spandex, Lycra and cotton fabric, this little number is obviously not for everybody. But for some bodies it's a sure-fire attention getter.

description: An influential group within Austria's ruling Socialist Party today called on President Kurt Waldheim to resign.
