title: COUNTRY MUSIC'S YOUNG TURKS DO IT AGAIN
description: THE SUMMER OF 1987 PROMISES to be a heady season for American country music. A genre that only two years ago seemed determined to suffocate itself in the musical equivalent of wall-to-wall carpeting is being revitalized by a new generation of raw, edgy young voices reasserting the continuity between contemporary country and time-honored strains of honky-tonk, rockabilly and older Appalachian mountain music.

title: THE SECRETS OF SOVIET STAR WARS
description: FOR MORE THAN A YEAR, THE wizards of reconnaissance in the United States Government have been obsessed by the mystery of Dushanbe. As they peer into the Soviet Union with their spy satellites, what grips them is not the capital of the Tadzhik Republic itself, but an isolated site south of the city, not far from the Afghan border. There, under construction high atop the region's tallest mountain, is an elaborate complex, bristling with roads, buildings, laboratories and domes, and linked by heavy power cables to the nearby Nurek hydroelectric plant, one of the largest in the Soviet Union.

title: DEIRDRE MARIE JOYCE IS BRIDE

The bride, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard F. Joyce of Briarcliff Manor, graduated from the University of Delaware and is studying for an M.B.A. degree at the Lubin School at Pace University. Mr. Glascott, a graduate of Lafayette College who received an M.B.A. from the University of Pennsylvania, is a son of Mr. and Mr. John A. Glascott of Briarcliff Manor. The bridegroom is an associate in Morgan Stanley & Company in New York.

As American As Apple Pie - And Pizza

Delighted New York City officials celebrated these events as symbols of their success in attracting species to the parks that had not been seen in the city for years.

title: Why Bigger Isn't Better in Banking

title: A YOUNG AMERICAN DONS RICHARD II'S CROWN
description: THE SUN BEAT DOWN ON THE bowl of the Delacorte Theater in Central Park, where the actors and crew of ''Richard II'' were rehearsing. Joseph Papp, slathered in sunblock, issued stage directions and vocally supplied the drum rolls and trumpet sounds that punctuate the scenes. The set was merely a skeleton of wooden beams; the actors sported Panama hats, sunglasses and scabbards strapped on over their shorts. Peter MacNicol, a slight but commanding King Richard, moved with the assurance of royalty through the makeshift 14th-century pomp.

title: Powell's Pivotal Votes Marked '87 Court Term
description: The first term of the Rehnquist Court, which ended Friday, could more aptly be called the last term of the Powell Court. While Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist presided, it was Justice Lewis F. Powell Jr. who, more than anyone, cast the decisive votes.

title: It's a Buyer's Market in Fairfield County
description: EARLY this year, when Byron and Joyce Trefts first saw the house they eventually bought in Weston, it was priced at $649,000. ''The builder made some minor improvements preparing for the spring rush, and raised it to $675,000,'' said Mrs. Trefts. ''It had been on the market for some time, so we made him an offer and got the house for $635,000.''

description: With an anonymous gift of $51,000, a New York philanthropist has helped rescue a financially threatened program that uses flowers to help change the lives of juvenile offenders and homeless teen-agers.

description: When affirmative action officers talk about their jobs, they speak of balancing acts and delicate negotiations, fancy footwork and the art of discerning the fine line.

description: FOR THE first time since 1939, the Metropolitan Opera will perform in New Jersey this week.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LEAD: THE WIND. By Patricia Barone. (New Rivers/Talman, Paper, $7.95.) Patricia Barone is both a poet and artist, and not surprisingly her first novella is infused with the compact beauty, strong imagery and symbolic layering of a painting or poem. The story centers on Fran and Alan, a couple in their 30's, and Katherine, a 62-year-old psychotherapist with whom they share a Minneapolis duplex as they assist her while she recovers from a stroke.

title:
WHAT'S NEW ON THE SUPERMARKET SHELF;
Nevermore the Naked Lettuce - Or Chicken

''It costs millions to build factories in order to market breakfast cereals, detergents or paper towels,'' Mr. Friedman of New Product News said. ''But all you need to make salad dressings are vinegar, oil, spices and clean glass bottles.

title: U.S. TO NAME CITIES LAX ON POLLUTION
description: The Environmental Protection Agency plans to announce next week the names of 14 metropolitan areas that will face sanctions for failing to meet a Dec. 31, 1987, deadline for controlling air pollution. An additional 21 metropolitan areas are expected to be named by the end of the year.

description: One of the main influences on the framers of the Constitution was the unwritten democratic constitution under which the Iroquois Confederacy had operated since the 16th century, according to a group of American Indians and scholars.

Ailing Project Gets New Life
description: LEAD: AFTER two years of financial uncertainty, a major downtown mixed-use project on which construction had stalled is back on track after a negotiated transfer of ownership to the mortgage lender, the Chemical Bank of New York.

title: ANNE DAVID
description: Anne David, an author and the wife of Hal David, the lyricist, died of lung cancer Friday at her home in Manhattan after a long illness. She was 62 years old.

title: Vatican Cash Crisis Is Viewed as Forcing Changes on Church
description: Basic changes in the institutional character of the Roman Catholic Church may be required to resolve a deepening financial crisis at the Vatican, officials say.

title: A LITTLE LIGHT 'NIGHTCAP' MYSTERY
description: AN evening of summer fun and intrigue can be found at the the Arena Players Repertory Company's current production of ''Deadly Nightcap.'' This is the American premiere of the English playwright Francis Durbridge's murder mystery, and although the play has flaws, it is nonetheless good, solid light entertainment.

title: WHEN THE PLAYGOER'S THE THING
description: HAS IT EVER STRUCK YOU THAT OUR AUDI-ences are as versatile as our actors? We do admire versatility in our actors and are always happy to report that a James Earl Jones, who was appearing as Othello not so very long ago, is equally powerful as a baseball player born just before his time, standing bat in hand and eyes transfixed on a future that can never be, in a contemporary play called ''Fences.'' You've heard of it. And you no doubt remember the similar relish theater buffs took in watching George C. Scott do ''Death of a Salesman'' just a few years after he'd crawled out on a window ledge in the rain for Neil Simon, hilariously making his way toward a bathroom in which his daughter had locked herself on her wedding day. In ''Plaza Suite,'' that was. It's always good to know that Raul Julia can make the most of a musical comedy before slipping into the darkness of Harold Pinter's malevolent world, or that Colleen Dewhurst can be as nifty in light comedy as she invariably is in O'Neill.

title: Rural Retreat's Charity Does Not End at Home
description: Guests abound at Noonday Farm. Some, homeless and poor, visit for a few days of country air or stay for a few months to reorganize their lives. Others are city dwellers, as were once the residents of this farm, who come here to renew themselves by working the land.

title: LUCY LUCKHARDT WEDS
description: Lucy Anne Luckhardt, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Philip George Luckhardt of Easton, Conn., was married yesterday to Stephen Andrew Calder, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Stewart Calder of Cincinnati. The Rev. Douglas J. Rumford officiated at the First Presbyterian Church in Fairfield, Conn. Mrs. Calder, a graduate of Wake Forest University, is a freelance writer. Her father is a lawyer for the General Electric Company. Mr. Calder, a graduate of Hamilton College, is an assistant media director at D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles. We also found, accidentally, Trinita dei Monte on the Via Sistina, a few doors from the Hasler. The Trinita was run by an obliging family (which is more than I can say about the management at the Scalinata) at a cost of $75 a day compared to $95 at Scalinata. The rooms were clean and the breakfasts identical.

title: SCHULTZ, NEW N.C.A.A. CHIEF, WON'T DODGE BIG ISSUES
description: HE has lived, he says, according to a plan. A high school and college sports star in Iowa, he wanted to coach. And so, for 25 years, he did, on both the high school and college levels. He wanted to get a graduate degree and become a businessman, and so he went to school part time and established a home-construction business. Then he wanted to get out of coaching before he turned 50, and so, for 11 years, he was an athletic director, first at Cornell, then at the University of Virginia.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Track and Field East Germany Looks Strong: East Germany dominated both the men's and women's competition in the first day of the European Track and Field cup yesterday in Prague. The highlight was Marlies Goehr's victory in the women's 100-meter dash, with a time of 10.95 seconds. The East Germans won all but one of eight women's events, topping the standings with 62 points. The Soviet Union, West Germany and Bulgaria were tied for second at 40. East Germany also edged the Russians in the men's standings after 10 events, with 61 1/2 points to 60.

title: Headliners; In the Spotlight
description: Once again last week, the stage belonged to George Abbott as Broadway luminaries gathered to celebrate the producer's 100th birthday. The party fell on the eve of the opening of Mr. Abbott's 130th Broadway production, a revival of a half-century-old show entitled, what else, ''Broadway.'' Mr. Abbott, who went from acting to writing, directing and producing, heard tributes from Helen Hayes, Jerome Robbins, Lillian Gish, Butterfly McQueen and others whose lights he helped brighten in productions stretching back to ''Coquette'' in 1927. The winner of a Pulitizer Prize and numerous Tonys, Mr. Abbott confessed delight. ''One hundred years seems to be a very lucky number,'' he said. ''One of the great things is that everybody loves you.''

title: 6-RUN 6TH HELPS CARDS TO 15-5 ROUT OF EXPOS
description: Curt Ford hit two home runs tonight, including a two-run shot during a six-run third inning, as the St. Louis Cardinals routed the Montreal Expos, 15-5.

They contend that the structure and its influx of workers and attendant truck traffic would have a devastating effect on the community, straining roads and resources.

In the case of the first book to be made into a movie, ''Ben Hur,'' not even a financial indebtedness was acknowledged; the movie would be good publicity for the book, it was argued, and General Wallace should be acquiescently grateful. He and his lawyers disagreed, establishing a happy precedent for those of us who, as the saying goes, take the money and run. And hide, ideally. For the author owes, at least, his Hollywood benefactors a tactful silence.

title: PERSONAL FINANCE
description: PARENTS of children at the Walden School on Manhattan's Upper West Side will meet this week with school officials to ask a lot of questions about the institution's finances. Walden earlier this month sought permission to reorganize under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code, catching the families of the school's 250 students by surprise. They had already paid deposits for the 1987-88 school year - some of them as much as half the tuition, which starts at $6,000 for nursery school and runs to more than $8,000 for high school.

The new stamp features symbols of Delaware's industries flanked by two native sons. The state's motto and the ratification date also are shown. The new stamp is the second postal item issued this year for the celebration of the bicentennial of the Constitution. There will also be statehood stamps for New Jersey and Pennsylvania and a Constitution Preamble booklet pane of five stamps.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: WINTER HAWK. By Craig Thomas. (Morrow, $18.95.) When we last saw him, Maj. Mitchell Gant was stealing a telepathically controlled advanced jet fighter from a Soviet testing field. Gant, the hero of Craig Thomas's previous best-selling cold war techno-fantasies, ''Firefox'' and ''Firefox Down!,'' now returns to the Soviet Union to rescue an American agent who has evidence that the Russians are about to orbit a laser battle station. On a mission that requires enormous daring -and, from the reader, an even greater suspension of disbelief - Gant flies a captured Soviet helicopter 1,000 miles across Afghanistan, Uzbekistan and the Aral Sea into the Baikonur launching complex. Once there, he stumbles onto a military plot against the slightly dovish Soviet premier. Joining forces with a K.G.B. colonel, Gant outflies numerous crack Sovet pilots and defeats the army's security apparatus. He also kills quite a few Russians who, according to Mr. Thomas, weren't enjoying life much anyway. Gant has flown himself into a miserable country laid waste by corruption, cynicism, alcoholism, drug abuse, bigotry, etc. And, of course, plenty of cold weather. The author's portrait of the Soviet Union is harsh and myopic - in other words, about on the same level as a Soviet propagandist's view of the West. Mr. Thomas's plot is nearly as crude. He repeatedly throws one obstacle or another in Gant's path. He tells us each obstacle is an insurmountable one -then allows Gant to surmount it. This formula provides some mild excitement, but not enough to sustain a 525-page novel.

title: MALLS ARE A RESPONSE TO PUBLIC DEMAND

The livestock has been replaced by living rooms, and the railroad retired its last steam engine decades ago. Those changes mirror the fact that Long Island has undergone a dramatic transformation since the end of World War II as millions left the Island's urban neighbor to the west and created one of the most dynamic metropolitan regions in the country.

title: The Business School Brain Drain
description: WHEN it came to hiring business Ph.D.'s, universities used to operate in a buyer's market. Corporate America viewed the business doctors as too highbrow to be effective in a nuts-and-bolts business environment. And the Ph.D.'s saw the corporations as too mercenary to provide the intellectual environment for which they hungered. That left business schools sifting through torrents of applications for teaching jobs.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: WHEN BATTERED WOMEN KILL. By Angela Browne. (Free Press/ Macmillan, $19.95.) Are women who kill their abusive partners criminals, and are they somehow different from other battered women? These two questions preoccupy Angela Browne in ''When Battered Women Kill,'' her compelling study of 42 abused women charged with the murder or attempted murder of their partners. Ms. Browne wisely plants us inside the lives of her subjects - we move with them through ordinary courtships and marriages and find ourselves, chapter by chapter, facing a wild, unimaginable escalation of brutality and terror. Ultimately the victims, believing they or their children will be further harmed, kill or try to kill their abusers. Each woman has a documented history of physical abuse; all have attempted to escape and seek outside help; few have prior criminal histories. Most are charged with first-degree murder. Although Ms. Browne's use of personality theory to explain male violence reduces a complex social problem, embedded in centuries of inequality and domination, to a psychological one, her central findings are critical reading for lawyers, judges, mental health professionals and shelter providers. A psychologist and research associate at the Family Violence Research Laboratory of the University of New Hampshire, Durham, Ms. Browne adds to the growing body of evidence that battered women are neither masochists nor homicidal maniacs who engage in mutual combat with their partners. Look to the perpetrators, Ms. Browne tells us, as she documents the factors that may predict their lethality. Her findings are an important addition to the growing literature on violence against women in the family.

title: How Japan Keeps the Exports Rolling
description: MACAULEY once declared no spectacle more ridiculous than the English on one of their periodic morality kicks. The spectacle of Americans on one of their periodic guilt trips is even more so. Our sense of uncompetitiveness against the Japanese has escalated from a political peeve into a ritual penance. We have persuaded ourselves that we are no match for the Japanese - presumably because they work harder, care more about the quality of their work, show more dedication to their employers and exemplify team spirit during their predawn warm-ups in company yards.

But transportation costs can also rise, particularly when planes or guided tours are included. Seeing Japan with a rail pass allowing unlimited travel - unescorted - is the proper Yankee response.

title: A Native American Delicacy: Blue Corn
description: The first blue corn I ever had was a purple-flecked tortilla, wrapped (untraditionally, I know now) around chicken and cheese, and smothered with green chili sauce and sour cream - an enchilada at a little restaurant called Sofio's in Telluride, Colo. Recently arrived from Boston, I had never seen the stonelike shadowy surface of a blue corn tortilla against the pale soft green of chili sauce, the white of sour cream. The colors and textures seemed as Southwestern as adobe. Blue corn tortillas are coarser, grainier and crumblier than those made of yellow corn, and this tortilla fell apart on my tongue. That night I felt as if I were eating earth - not dirt, but food that was somehow connected to the richness of earth. This, compared with the tortillas I had eaten in Boston, probably prefried from a box, was like the difference between backyard and hothouse tomatoes.

title:

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: BLESSED MCGILL. By Edwin Shrake. (Texas Monthly Press, Paper, $9.95.) Set in Texas and Mexico during the years after the Civil War, this novel's intriguing combination of personal disasters and grand adventure occurs during a historical period when both were taken for granted. The action in this humorous and macabre story includes plenty of scalping, one man skewered, three others roasted alive and a narrator, Peter McGill, who concedes, ''I didn't actually kill a man until I was seventeen.'' As the book begins, McGill is being stalked and expects at any moment to be killed by a former friend, Octavio, a young Indian better known as Gotch Eye. The novel is McGill's attempt to set down the story of his life, ''hopping over the more boring parts since I am in a hurry.'' In the hands of Edwin Shrake, a screenwriter and novelist, the device works nicely, especially since he had the good sense to give McGill a quirky but well-educated mother who accounts for his literary ability. When McGill first sees his future wife, Ellen, she is a naked child, recently orphaned by Indians. He rescues her - sort of - but not in the courageous way Ellen, and most readers, might expect. Later, he pokes fun at tall tales of the West when he travels to Baltimore and rescues Ellen, for real this time, from a school for young women. McGill's misunderstandings with Octavio, which lead to murder, are the heart of the story, and Octavio lives up to their nasty reputation. The only things that don't work are the gratuitous appendices explaining McGill's ''sainthood.'' ''Blessed McGill'' is an engaging new look at the old West.

title: Headliners; Behind Bars
description: All was not forgiven last week when Terrence Peter Jackson showed up for sentencing after spending 17 years on the run. Mr. Jackson, who changed his name from Silas Trim Bissell, had been a fugitive since 1970, when he and his wife were charged with attempting to a bomb a campus R.O.T.C. building in Seattle to protest the Vietnam War. The former professor of literature, who was working as a physical therapist when he was arrested earlier this year in Oregon, asked for leniency. He said he had acted ''out of love for country and for my fellow human beings.'' Judge Walter T. McGovern was not persuaded. ''Just as you felt morally compelled to act, I am morally compelled to have you incarcerated,'' Judge McGovern said. Mr. Jackson got two years in prison.

title: Classical Music
description: July 4 inspires any orchestra or festival worth its (stars and) stripes into an extravanganza of Americana, usually with fireworks obbligato. This Saturday, there will be July 4 programs at Tanglewood in Lenox, Mass.; at Caramoor in Katonah, N.Y.; in Princeton with the New Jersey Symphony Summer Pops; at the Summer of Music on the Hudson in Tarrytown, N.J., and at the Charles Ives Center for the Arts in Danbury, Conn.

title: MARTHA'S VINEYARD
description: Martha's Vineyard, five miles off the Massachusetts coast and rimmed by sand and barrier beaches, dotted by harbors and edged by clay cliffs, is an amalgamation of stylish resort, small-town New England and undisturbed landscape. Celebrated actors, artists and writers come to the island, off the southwest corner of Cape Cod, to sail and relax in the sun. Everyone turns out to cheer fire engines and homemade floats in a Fourth of July parade, and a farmer opens his barn to curious visitors. And a visitor can wander old dirt paths and expansive beaches and sometimes barely see another soul. Attractions

But the arrival of the Andrew Lloyd Webber musical is now in question, the composer being infuriated by the refusal of the American Actors' Equity to grant working credentials to Sarah Brightman, a star of the London production and Mr. Lloyd Webber's wife.

description: The administration of Gov. Robert P. Casey, caught in a legal and political bind, has opened the door for more litigation over a 20-year-old water diversion project at the eastern edge of Pennsylvania that has taken on national significance as a battle between developers and environmentalists.

title: DISSENT BOOMS WITH KOREA'S ECONOMY

title:
DINING OUT;
DOUBLE SAMPLING OF CHINESE FARE

So difficult is its name to see from the road that I have told people meeting me there to look for a shopping center opposite a restaurant called the Chessman Bistro.

title: Exploring The Kingdom of AIDS
description: I quickly grew weary of Peter Davis's article ''Exploring the Kingdom of AIDS'' (May 31). He never entered the kingdom, but, instead, wrote about the playgrounds of the rich. Why is it that my hospital, nestled in a high-risk area, doesn't even have an AIDS program, let alone an interviewer? While he worries about those who have access to education and health care, I worry about the adolescents I see in the clinic who don't have the ability to recognize the danger, who laugh at the possibility of their mortality and who are sometimes driven by impulse and the need for affection rather than acting on self-preservation.

title: Boudleaux Bryant Dies at 67; Writer of Country Music Hits
description: Boudleaux Bryant, who with his wife, Felice, wrote numerous country music hits, including most of the Everly Brothers standards, died of cancer on Thursday at Baptist Hospital in Knoxville, Tenn. He was 67 years old and lived in Gatlinburg, Tenn.

That is certainly the case in Wanaque, N.J., where 480 acres are targeted for a $200 million, mixed-use complex in anticipation of I-287's extension through northeastern New Jersey, where it will hook up with the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway by 1992.

title: A Whistle-Stop Journey Into Umbria
description: Tucked away in the back of the Italian official railway guide are a few timetables dedicated to the handful of Italy's privately operated rail companies. In total trackage and passenger loads these lines can scarcely compare with the sprawling state system, but they provide important regional, local and even neighborhood functions for the areas they serve. For the outsider, some of these lines offer an unusual opportunity to take a leisurely rail trip through some of Italy's most attractive countryside and look in on villages, towns and crossroads settlements that visitors rarely see.

title: Data Update: June 28 1987
Jazz
description: In 1917, five white musicians from New Orleans who called themselves the Original Dixieland Jass Band, were playing at Reisenweber's Cafe on Columbus Circle when they made what are widely considered to be the first jazz recordings. The records created such a sensation that the ODJB went on to international success with a long engagement in London and provided a name, a style and a basic repertory for what has been known ever since as ''Dixieland jazz.''

title: Q and A
description: A Slow Return of Equity Question: I live in a Federal Section 213 co-op in Queens which has opted to limit resale profits, and it has taken the board up to six months to return equity to members who have sold their units and moved away. Is there a law that puts a timeframe on the return of equity to sellers of this kind of co-opapartment? E. C., Queens Answer: The terms of the Federal law that established Section 213 cooperatives, whose mortgages are insured by the Department of Housing and Urban Development through the Federal Home Administration, do not stipulate how soon equity must be returned to apartment dwellers after the sale. The New York State laws that govern co-op and condominium residences also do not address the point.

title: A FAMILY EVENT
description: CARAMOOR unquestionably offers the most glamorous summer series in Westchester; its settings are elegant, its artists world class. But it can also be an expensive family outing, with ticket prices ranging from $10 to $27.50 for the best seats at Venetian Theater events. By contrast, the Lyndhurst concerts - or Summer of Music on the Hudson Festival, to use the proper title - have been designed much more as a family festival. Here all tent tickets are $8, and (weather permitting) the great majority of listeners get an even better bargain by bringing their own blankets or chairs, and paying $5 ($2 for children less than 12 years old) to enjoy the music from the scenic lawn area.

description: AS I drove past a house that had been vacant for several months, I saw a little Japanese girl come out the front door.

description: FOUR New Jersey agencies said the death of a mentally retarded woman at a state institution in Bordentown was accidental. One state investigator, Donald Young of the Department of Human Services, suspected a cover-up.

title: IS THERE GOLD AT THE END OF THIS RAINBOW OF ROMANCES?
description: THE VIDEOTAPES - BLACK plastic cassettes with pretty pictures on the cover - hardly look like a revolution in the making. But the ''Shades of Love'' series, four romance stories that were released last month by Karl-Lorimar Home Video, are breaking some fundamental rules of the video-cassette business. The productions were not released in theaters first or previously shown on television, but were made expressly for the home video consumer. And industry insiders are watching carefully to see if the tapes are a sign of things to come.

Such suspicions reached their highest level yet last week when a Federal grand jury indicted Elton J. Gissendanner, the executive director of the state's Department of Natural Resources. Mr. Gissendanner, a former state legislator who was a close adviser to Senator Bob Graham during Mr. Graham's two terms as Governor, was charged with taking an $80,000 bribe to arrange the freedom of a drug smuggler who had been arrested by his department's Marine Patrol. After his indictment was announced, Mr. Gissandanner resigned from the influential office he had held for eight years, and then pleaded not guilty.

description: SWITZERLAND has come to the Hamptons.

description: EVIDENCE of the accelerating war in the Nicaraguan countryside is everywhere. Food and almost everything else are in even shorter supply than usual in the capital, and more young men seem to be going off to join the army.

description: To the Editor:

title: Darjeeling
description: To the Editor: Seeing the picture of the Windamere in Darjeeling (''A Hotel With a Touch of the Raj,'' Travel, May 24) took me back to my visit in September 1944. Three of us -a British tea planter, an American officer and I, a Red Cross girl - had spent 10 days in a tea packet floating down the Brahmaputra River from Dibrugarh in upper Assam, then on a regular train to Siliguri and finally the toy train.

title: Exploring The Kingdom of AIDS

title: COLLEGES SHOULD SERVE ALL, NOT JUST SOME

The N.C.A.A. Presidents Commission, which called the convention, has expressed its commitment to restoring integrity and fiscal sanity to our nation's collegiate athletics programs - a welcomed and necessary intervention.

description: Justice is supposed to be blind but blind ignorance is what some judges and court officers display toward defendants with AIDS, even those merely suspected of having the disease.

title: KATHRYN A. OLSON BECOMES A BRIDE
description: Kathryn Adele Olson, a lawyer, and Alan C. Greenberg, chairman and chief executive officer of Bear, Stearns & Company, were married yesterday at the bridegroom's home in New York. Rabbi Ronald B. Sobel performed the ceremony.

title: City Ballet: New Faces In 'Bournonville' Suite
description: THERE is something inherently new and fresh about much of ''Bournonville Divertissements,'' a suite of excerpts from ballets by Auguste Bournonville, staged by Stanley Williams for the New York City Ballet. And so it seems entirely appropriate when new faces bob up in the cast, as they did in a performance by the company on Thursday at the New York State Theater.

title: JAN TERRI TARNOFF MARRIES ENGINEER
description: Jan Terri Tarnoff, the daughter of Johel G. Tarnoff of White Plains and New Milford, Conn., and the late Norman H. Tarnoff, was married yesterday to Scott Robert Adams, a son of Dorrance Adams of Englewood, N.J., and Paul Adams of Montague, N.J. Surrogate Evans Brewster of Westchester County performed the ceremony at the Stouffer Westchester Hotel in White Plains.

title:
WHAT'S NEW ON THE SUPERMARKET SHELF;
Watermelon In Your Toothpaste
description: LEAD: MANUFACTURERS of health and beauty aids are tossing more and more exotic fragrances into their goods. ''The basic components of makeup are the same, so why use a plain cold cream when you can use one with a strange fragrance or an exotic animal oil?'' asked Susan Berry, a professional makeup artist and image consultant for television news in Miami.

title: The Pope Could Not Shun Kurt Waldheim
description: To the Editor:

title: Transforming a Military Insurer Into a Civilian Powerhouse
description: EVERY morning, Gen. Robert F. McDermott steps briskly from his sandstone Colonial house, walks 150 yards and settles into his flag-studded office in a complex that is billed as the world's second-largest horizontal office building, surpassed only by the Pentagon.

title: AN ISLAND THAT SUMS UP HAWAII
description: Other islands may be larger, have flashier hotels and restaurants and boast more shopping and golf courses. But Kauai may be the most beautiful and most varied of all the Hawaiian Islands.

title: Judge Orders New Trial in $108 Million Judgment
description: The Monsanto Company has been granted a new trial in a case in which the company had been ordered to pay $108 million to the family of a Monsanto chemical worker who died of leukemia.

title: SEX CAN SPOIL THE SCENE
description: ABOUT THREE-QUARTERS OF THE WAY through ''Devil in the Flesh,'' Marco Bellocchio's updated Italian variation on Raymond Radiguet's 1923 French novel set during World War I, Mr. Bellocchio takes a carefully considered leap toward artistic freedom but lands in an esthetic void. A hard-core sex sequence, which might initially have seemed a bold decision, turns out to have been a fatal gaffe.

description: Additional titles of interest:

title: SENATE APPROVES KOREA RESOLUTION
description: The Senate unanimously approved a resolution today warning President Chun Doo Hwan of South Korea that failure to agree on timely, democratic changes essential to free elections was endangering the peaceful transfer of power he has promised for 1988.

title: MOSES SHOWS HE'S STILL NO.1
description: Edwin Moses left no doubt today that he remains the world's best 400-meter hurdler, streak or no streak.

title: JOHN F. SAVARESE AND LYNN ASHBY ARE WED ON L.I.
description: The Sacred Hearts of Jesus and Mary Roman Catholic Church in Southampton, L.I., was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Lynn Marion Ashby, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Bill B. Ashby of Baton Rouge, La., to John Ford Savarese, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis A. Savarese of Saddle River, N.J. The Rev. William J. Remey performed the ceremony.

title: A JUDICIAL SANCTION FOR DEATH BY ASSENT
description: WHEN the New Jersey Supreme Court made three landmark rulings last week, expanding a patient's right to die, it was helping give guidance to an ad hoc system of negotiated death that has developed in recent years.

title: YANKEES DEFEAT RED SOX
description: He spent 20 days out of uniform and on the disabled list, but it was like a paid vacation for Don Mattingly. He rested a bad back, took a little batting practice, watched the Yankees from a preferred seat in the dugout and ached to play again.

title: A GAUDY 'BARNUM' IS STAGED IN DARIEN
description: THE timing for Darien Dinner Theater's production of the musicalized life of Phineas T. Barnum, the master showman and purveyor of humbug, couldn't be more propitious. In nearby Bridgeport - through next Sunday - visitors are celebrating the 39th annual Barnum Festival.

title:
ABOUT WESTCHESTER;
ERRANDS
description: LEAD: IT is Saturday morning at the Golden Horseshoe Shopping Center here, and people are engaged in a ritual as American as proverbial apple pie: running errands. They are pushing carts through the supermarket and waiting in line at the checkout counter. They are waiting in line at the bank, scrutinizing checkbooks and savings-accounts statements.

title: Opera Booms Amid Cows And Baseball
description: A brass fanfare rang out over the cow pastures at dusk tonight, signaling the opening of a $5 million opera house in this village of 300 people.

title: A DIFFERENT WAVELENGTH
description: WELL, I finally went out and bought a microwave. That may not seem earthshaking, but for me it's taken on a symbolic meaning that transcends the mere purchase of a kitchen appliance.

title: Minnesota's Skillful Potters
description: The pots of Warren MacKenzie are in the Smithsonian and the Victoria and Albert and most other major museums, but he is not impressed - he would rather his pots were full of soup. In his showroom in Stillwater, just to the north of Minneapolis (8695 68th Street North, Stillwater, Minn. 55082; 612-777-4979) a teapot by one of America's master potters costs $18, and matching mugs cost $4 each.

title: Spoleto's Aims
description: To the Editor:

title: TOO CLOSE FOR COMFORT
description: A LOT of people like to think they live in the suburbs so as to stay closer to Nature. I did myself - until Nature got too close for comfort.

title: SAVING THE WORLD BEGINS AT HOME
description: THE DIFFERENT DRUM Community-Making and Peace. By M. Scott Peck. 334 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $16.95.

title: V.A. Opposes Making Patients Take AIDS Tests
description: In the debate over how to curb the AIDS epidemic, doctors at the Veterans Administration sided last week with those who believe that requiring all incoming hospital patients to be tested for the virus would be ineffective and unfair.

title: CATHERINE M. O'HARA IS WED TO EDWARD MOSLANDER
description: Catherine Mary O'Hara, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard L. O'Hara of Roslyn Harbor, L.I., was married there yesterday to Edward Moslander, the son of Walter H. Moslander of Clay, N.Y., and Ellen Novak of Greenwich, Conn. Abbott Matthew Leavy of St. Anselm's Monastery, who is Chancellor of St. Anselm's College in Manchester, N.H., performed the ceremony at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church.

title: WARY PANEL STES STAGE FOR NORTH'S APPEARANCE
description: AT about 6 o'clock last Thursday evening, Senator Daniel K. Inouye dropped the gavel on the seventh week of the Iran-contra hearings. ''The joint committees,'' he declared with unusual flourish, ''will stand in recess until 9 A.M. Tuesday, the 7th of July, 1987, to receive the testimony of Lieut. Col. Oliver North.'' Senator Inouye's gavel ended a week of damaging evidence about Colonel North's activities, and the dramatic tone of the Hawaii Democrat's voice presaged the testimony that everyone, from the Reagan Administration's most ardent supporters to its sharpest critics, has been awaiting for months.

title: Sports of The Times; Gooden's Rescue of Privacy
description: NOW that Dwight Gooden has described his experiences with cocaine, the primary lesson that emerged is the value of drug testing. If he hadn't agreed last fall to be tested by the Mets, the 22-year-old right-hander acknowledged that he might have drifted even deeper into the drug that can kill.

title: Exploring The Kingdom of AIDS
description: Samantha Ellis may ''bitterly resent anyone attempting to crush [ the enjoyment of one's sexuality ] '' and ''resent so much what is happening,'' but I resent the fact that my tax dollars may be used for her medical care in several years. Isn't it interesting that some people want their independence only up to the point that they need social services to bail them out when they can no longer cope? REGINA COOPER New York City

title: PLANNING IS KEY TO LAW ON TOXINS
description: ON Oct. 17, 1986, the Superfund Amendments and Re-authorization Act of 1986, or SARA, was enacted into law. Title III of that Federal act, the Emergency Planning and Community Right-to-Know Act of 1986, set into motion a process for developing local chemical emergency preparedness programs and for collecting and making available information on hazardous chemicals. Each state is required, without the benefit of Federal dollars, to implement these programs in each community.

title: Prince Potemkin Built No Potemkin Villages
description: To the Editor:

title: Senate Is Pushed to Finance Radar for Nantucket Airport
description: Pointing to a recent crash at the fog-shrouded Nantucket Memorial Airport, Senator John Kerry is pushing for money to install a radar system at the airport, one of New England's busiest in the summer tourist season.

title: NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Pittsburgh
description: DURING her life, Helen Clay Frick, the daughter of one of the city's turn-of-the-century steel barons, displayed a passionate attachment to Clayton, her family's chateau-style mansion in the Point Breeze section of the city.

title: Exploring The Kingdom of AIDS
description: I am a 19-year-old woman who chooses not to sleep around. My experience is exclusive of sexual intercourse and probably will remain as such because of the ''panic'' caused by the AIDS epidemic.

title: The World Debt Crisis
description: To the Editor:

title: Cranberry Fungus Is Watched
description: A fungus is killing cranberry plants in nearly 10 percent of the bogs in Massachusetts, and state officials say they fear it could spread.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: LEAD: IT AIN'T NECESSARILY SO: An Autobiography. By Larry Adler. (Grove Press, $17.95.) This autobiography by the man who raised the chromatic harmonica to the level of a solo orchestral instrument reads like a Woody Allen film - a moxie-laden ride through the last 70 years of American musical entertainment.

title: Summer Guilt
description: Once, when June turned hot, middle-class parents fretted with guilt over the idea of allowing the kids a do-nothing summer. How nice for Ann or Andy if Mom and Dad could afford to pack footlockers and send them away to a world of canoes and campfire songs, to laugh in musty cabins and get crushes on their counselors. How regrettable if the children would have to make do with the local swimming pool and soda fountain.

title: THE BOLSHOI'S BALANCING ACT
description: THE WORD ''NEW'' HAS OFTEN BEEN SUS-pect in the temple of tradition that is the Bolshoi Ballet. Yet, ''new'' is the adjective the company's artistic director, Yuri Grigorovich, leaned on again and again when he offered his preview of the dancers and the reshaped dances he will bring to the United States beginning this week. The company opens a three-week engagement at the Metropolitan Opera House on Tuesday, the first stop on a nine-week cross-country tour.

title: Article 868187 -- No Title
description: Xavier University has received its largest single gift ever, a $6.77 million bequest from a woman who had no known connection to the institution, school officials say. Clara J. Schawe, who died in 1985 at the age of 95, left Xavier the bulk of what was a $5.48 million estate, which has grown in value in the year it took to probate the estate.

title: CHILDREN
description: How Can I Tell If I'm Really in Love? Produced and Directed by Rick Hauser. Host and Production Consultant Justine Bateman. Paramount Home Video. 51 minutes. $29.95.

title: Tracking Down Millions for Haiti
description: THREE months after Haiti's then President, Jean-Claude Duvalier, fled into exile in France, the new Government moved to recover up to $400 million in cash and property that it said he and associates had absconded with. Lawsuits were filed in May 1986 in this country and abroad.

title: Maine Land Plan Is Approved
description: The Maine Legislature has approved a $35 million bond issue to buy land for public parks, which, if approved by voters in November, will be the state's most ambitious land buying program.

title: ROSE FRANCKLIN, AN ARTIST, WEDS
description: The Old Dutch Church in Waldoboro, Me., was the setting yesterday for the wedding of Rose Xenia Francklin to Dr. George Graham Thomson 3d. The Rev. William Beaudoin, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: DOWN THE GARDEN PATH
description: DECADES BEFORE THE Hamptons became the summertime mecca they are today, the area was well-known as farm country. A working farm once stretched along the entire street where this garden now stands. That was around 1929, when the rambling shingle-style main house was built. ''I've tried to find out the history of the property,'' says Fernanda Niven, the current owner, ''to learn at what point the land was divided and who first designed the gardens.'' Sadly, the records no longer exist.

title: After the Waldheim Visit
description: LEAD: For over a quarter of a century, I have cherished the actions of Pope John XXIII and Vatican Council II for exorcising the devil of anti-Semitism from our great faith tradition.

title: PARTIES SET TO PICK 4th DISTRICT CANDIDATES
description: LEAD: THE Republican and Democratic Parties will chose their nominees this week for the Congressional seat vacated by the death last month of Stewart B. McKinney. But officials of both parties said they expected that, ultimately, the candidates would be picked in primaries July 21.

title: The Colorization of Films Insults Artists and Society
description: LEAD: In the world of potent self-annihilation, famine and AIDS, terrorists and dishonest public servants and quack evangelists and contras and Sandinistas and cancer, does it really matter if some kid snaps on his TV and happens to see ''The Maltese Falcon'' in color? Especially if he can simply dial the color out and choose to view it in its original black and white?

title: The Business Equivalent of a Full-Service Hotel
description: BUZZ YATES sells corporate jets out of a one-man office in Atlanta without even a nameplate on the door. It's a low-budget operation.

title: San Antonio Mayor in Drive To Unify Hispanic Americans
description: Mayor Henry Cisneros of San Antonio has called for developing the first unified political agenda for diverse Hispanic American groups, including Mexican-Americans, Cuban-Americans and Puerto Ricans.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: 'CABARET' IN MONTCLAIR TheatreFest, the professional Actors Equity program of Montclair State College's School of Fine and Performing Arts, opened its second season Friday with ''Cabaret.''

title: Two Held and Cocaine Is Discovered on Plane
description: Two people were arrested aboard an airplane today after one of them cut open the wall of a bathroom to retrieve $3.5 million worth of cocaine, the police said.

title: All the Goetz Verdict Says Is That There Was Room for Doubt
description: To the Editor:

title: BEETHOVEN: A WEALTH OF DISKS
description: THERE MAY BE MUSIC that has been recorded more often than the nine symphonies of Beethoven, but it certainly doesn't look that way sometimes. Consider, for instance, a stack of recent LP's and compact disks, containing performances led by Riccardo Muti, Klaus Tennstedt, Michael Tilson Thomas and Gerard Schwarz.

title: Queens Political Tools: Ad Agency and Papers
description: In a continuing political struggle among Queens Democrats, Representative Gary L. Ackerman has two potent weapons at his disposal, a newspaper chain and an advertising, printing and consulting company in which he is the majority owner.

title: Stan Lomax, 88, Sports Broadcaster In 50-Year Career
description: Stan Lomax, a radio sports broadcaster for almost 50 years, died Friday night at the Cedar Manor Nursing Home in Ossining, N.Y. He was 88 years old.

title: New Money Gives 63d Street Tunnel Somewhere To Go
description: A little light appeared at the end of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority's 63d Street ''tunnel to nowhere'' last week. The Federal Urban Mass Transportation Administration, declaring itself satisfied with solutions to construction problems that had delayed completion of both the East River tunnel connecting Queens and Manhattan and the Archer Avenue line in eastern Queens, released $60 million to help complete both subway projects.

title: CLASS TRAINS MINORITY-GROUP MEMBERS AS ARBITRATORS
description: Responding to minority workers' concerns about fairness in the handling of labor grievances, a former Federal mediator is training a class of black and Hispanic people to become arbitrators.

title: THE MITTERAND MYSTERY
description: THE BLACK AND THE RED Francois Mitterrand: The Story of an Ambition. By Catherine Nay. Translated by Alan Sheridan. 404 pp. San Diego: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $19.95.

title: A Headhunter's Guide to Reagandom
description: UNACCUSTOMED to the role of job-seeker, Paul A. Volcker recently called his friend Robert S. Strauss, the Washington lawyer and former Democratic party official. Mr. Volcker, the departing chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, mused about a future without the Fed. Where would he go? What would he do?

title: WHEN IT COMES TO DRUGS, BEWARE THE CENSOR'S FIX
description: ''TOO OFTEN,'' SAID President Reagan, ''drug use is still shown in a positive, upbeat way on our screens.''

title: Season's Windup
description: Boathouse Party June 29 - Hollywood's 100th anniversary will be celebrated with a barbecue-dance party from 8 P.M. to 1 A.M. at the Loeb Boathouse in Central Park. Horse-drawn carriages will transport guests to the boathouse from Fifth Avenue and 72d Street starting at 8. The evening will benefit the National Foundation for Facial Reconstruction, the principal sponsor of the Institute of Reconstructive Plastic Surgery at the New York University Medical Center, where children disfigured by birth defects or accidents are treated. Dress is navy and white. Tickets $125, or $75 for those under 35; 212-644-0152 or 212-340-6656. Ballet Competition June 29 - For the last month, 48 classical ballet dancers from 17 countries, ages 17 to 23, have been living in dormitories at Columbia University, touring the city and participating in the New York International Ballet Competition. The winners will perform at an awards ceremony to benefit the nonprofit program, with Tony Randall as host, at the City Center at 7:30 P.M. followed by a supper dance at the Sheraton Centre. Tickets $250; 212-496-1175. Equestrian Fair July 4 - Borderland Farms in Warwick, N.Y., in Orange County, a drive of about an hour and a half from Manhattan, is celebrating its 25th anniversary with a country horse fair and benefit and a day full of events from 11 A.M. to 5 P.M. There will be a parade of the hunt with hounds, a parade of carriages, competitive contests with horses including polo-cross (a cross between polo and lacrosse), pony rides for the children and traditional country fair foods and crafts. The day will benefit Winslow Therapeutic Riding Unlimited, which provides riding as therapy for those with physical or mental disabilities in New Jersey and New York, and the Jockey Hollow Pony Club, a group of young volunteers who work with Riding Unlimited. Admission $1. Information and directions, 914-986-1704. Five-City Benefit July 12 - Some of the nation's noted chefs will be preparing meals simultaneously in five cities for what is billed as ''America's Ultimate Dinner'' to benefit the National Center for Missing and Exploited Children in Washington and its affiliated agencies in 10 states. The event starts at 5 P.M. in San Francisco and Los Angeles, 7 P.M. in Chicago and 8 P.M. in Washington and New York. The dinners and entertainment will be linked by satellite broadcast. In New York, champagne opens the gourmet evening at Stringfellows restaurant, 35 East 21st Street. Tickets for the black-tie event $150; 800-233-7618. Lawn Party July 12 - There will be cocktails, a buffet supper and music on the lawn (indoors if it rains) of the Wainwright House in Rye, N.Y., to benefit the Children's Blood Foundation at the New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center. The mansion, at the end of Stuyvesant Avenue, overlooks Long Island Sound. Proceeds from the 5 to 9 P.M. party will go to an immunology laboratory for the evaluation of pediatric patients exposed to AIDS and associated viruses through multiple blood tranfusions. Tickets $75; 914-698-8075 or 914-698-2003. Cocktails in the Park July 23 - Founded in 1914, the Jewish Guild for the Blind is one of New York's oldest agencies serving blind and visually impaired people of all ages. The guild's Associates Division is holding a cocktail party from 6:30 to 9:30 P.M. with hot and cold hors d'oeuvres at Tavern on the Green. Tickets $55, from 212-595-2000, extension 242, or $65 at the door.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LEAD: WEEP NO MORE, MY LADY. By Mary Higgins Clark. (Simon & Schuster, $17.95.) The publishers of ''Weep No More, My Lady'' are wise to release it in June. It's the ideal book for the beach bag, picnic hamper or carry-on luggage. Mary Higgins Clark (''Stillwatch,'' ''Where Are the Children?'') has fashioned a murder mystery decorated with glamorous people set in a swank California health spa.

title: Passing On Control to Residents
description: WITHIN a year or two of moving into a newly built condominium or cooperative, buyers normally take over the operation of the complex from the developer.

title: STEIG: NOBODY IS GROWN-UP
description: WILLIAM STEIG is 79 years young. For Mr. Steig, this is not a euphemism. It is the truth. He greets me at the bus, a solid, energetic, instantly engaging fellow with a craggy face, brush-cut hair and a street kid's mischievous grin.

title: DOCUMENTARY
description: Men of Bronze Directed by William Miles. 1977. Pacific Arts Video. 60 minutes. $39.95.

title: Car Rentals
description: To the Editor: It was with great interest that I read ''Playing It Safe With a Car Rental'' by Betsy Wade (Practical Traveler, May 3). I read it on the plane on my way back from a fly-drive vacation in Arizona.

title: The Changing Home
description: ON A WARM WEDNESDAY evening, while the singles scene is thriving on beer, peanuts and the steady beat of rock-and-roll music at an outdoor cafe in Boston's Quincy Market, 10 women, ranging in age from 30 to the late 50's, gather in a building around the corner to envision the American dream house. Two are single, the rest are married. Most of them already own houses in the Boston area. The majority have incomes of at least $100,000 and considerable equity in an existing home. They are willing to commit upwards of $300,000 for a new home.

title: Summer And White Wine
description: I disagree with Frank J. Prial's ''put-down'' of all but the most expensive white wines (Wine, ''True Confession,'' June 7).

title:
ANTIQUES;
A QUIET COUNTRY HOME CUM WINERY
description: LEAD: LEAVING traffic behind for an untrammeled rural byway is only one of the pleasures of discovering Tewksbury Wine Cellars.

title: MISS MORTIMER BECOMES BRIDE
description: The Princeton University Chapel was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Caroline Virginia Mortimer, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Egbert Laird Mortimer 3d of West Hartford, Conn., to Richard Lawrence Grubman Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Grubman of Englewood, N.J. The Rev. Frank C. Strasburger, the Episcopal chaplain at Princeton, performed the ceremony.

title: What's Fair When You're Bought Out?
description: WHEN companies say goodbye to public ownership, they do not always leave their stockholders smiling. Increasingly, management-led buyouts and similar transactions are being faulted as unfair to public shareholders, who may have suffered with a company through years of adversity only to see their shares bought away -sometimes against their will - as the company's fortunes begin to improve.

title: Data Bank: June 28, 1987
Exploring The Kingdom of AIDS
description: It is striking that among Peter Davis's informants in Upper East Side singles bars, the women tend to be newly cautious about sex, while the men say ''wing it,'' ''go for it'' and ''condoms are not for me.'' Mr. Davis comments on the return to a 1950's mentality, but he says nothing about its new incarnation in the 1980's, when, suddenly it's the woman's job to bring the condom and make the guy wear it. PAULA A. TREICHLER Urbana, Ill.

title: LOKING FOR DR. RIGHT
description: DOCTORS & WOMEN By Susan Cheever. 266 pp. New York: Clarkson N. Potter/ Crown Publishers. $17.95.

title: SISTERHOOD WAS NO PICNIC
description: MOTHER LOVE By Candace Flynt. 342 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $17.95.

title: A Sutter Retiring
description: DARRYL SUTTER, one of the six Sutter brothers in the National Hockey League, has decided to retire from the Chicago Blackhawks because of injuries and will become an assistant coach for the club. Sutter, who is 28 years old, had been with the Blackhawks since the 1979-80 season, and will serve under the newly hired head coach, Bob Murdoch.

title: HOW TO
description: Paneling Home Improvement series. DIY Video Corporation. 5250 Seventy-Seven Center Drive, Charlotte, N.C. 28210. 30 Minutes. $19.95. As so often happens on television, this taped segment of the ''Do-It-Yourself'' show tries to pack too much information into a single half hour. The cassette does a good job of demonstrating most of the steps involved in cutting, fitting and installing both plywood and solid wood paneling, but because it tries to crowd in so much, some tricky working techniques are glossed over too quickly. For example, although the title doesn't indicate this, a sizable segment at the end of the tape is devoted to putting up various types of wood shelving on a paneled wall. Yet such details as how to cut small openings for electrical outlets are not demonstrated, only verbally explained. Also, the segment on putting panels up over a brick wall includes only the briefest description of the tools and techniques that are normally used for fastening wood furring strips to a masonry wall.

title: Arthur F. Burns: 1904-1987
description: Arthur F. Burns, who served as chairman of the Federal Reserve Board under three presidents, died last Friday of coronary disease at age 83.

title: Politics Clouds Outlook for Queens Medical School
description: A plan to establish a City University Medical School in Queens reached a critical point last week as legislators and community leaders tried unsuccessfully to reach agreement over which hospital should administer the program.

title: LANDSCAPES SEEN THROUGH AMERICAN EYES
description: WHAT HAPPENED TO American landscape painting between 1880 and 1900? Did it go this way, that way or nowhere in particular? ''All of the above'' would be most people's answer to that question, and most people would be right. Even so, the facts have not lately been spelled out for us in a museum exhibition. We may know, from books, about the Dusseldorf school, the Munich school and the Brittany school. We may know of the American painters who went to Giverny in hopes of picking up a thing or two from Claude Monet. We know something - quite enough, in some cases - about American Impressionism. But how to put all that disparate information together and make sense of it is another problem altogether.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: SNOW ON THE WIND. By Hugh Miller. (St. Martin's, $14.95.) Welcome back to Megan Roberts, the sensitive but indomitable heroine of Hugh Miller's previous novel, ''The District Nurse,'' taken from his BBC television series. This British writer, once a pathologist's assistant, is adept at probing the dreary lives of the small southern Welsh mining town of Pencwm. It is 1927, and ''Snow on the Wind'' opens with 35-year-old Megan, a native of North Wales, trying to wall in memories of her fiance and their child, now both deceased. Two years into an intense nursing career, she is still battling the villagers' distrust of strangers and the dangerous influence of Nesta Mogg, a questionable folk healer. The arrival of Timothy Morris, a 37-year-old physician from London, seems to threaten Megan's status as the district's sole health official; she confronts the new doctor with growing hostility, accusing him of iniquity even as he is trying to do his utmost for the poor and ailing members of this superstition-ridden community. During a whooping cough epidemic she verges on nervous collapse and Timothy orders her to take a month's leave. When, in her retreat in North Wales, Megan chances on the doctor's tragic secret, her attitude toward him softens. Eventually these two extraordinary people become friends and then lovers, drawn closer by their commitment to saving lives. Like Sherwood Anderson, Mr. Miller knows how to focus in on small-town existence, and his cameos of lonely, frustrated local figures are sparing but memorable. Megan's determination to fan the sparks of life sustains her again and again.

The latest proposal calls for an addition that will bring the building up to 17,900 square feet, but this proposal, like those that have come before, has been called into question.

From New York City's point of view, it might as well be the planet Neptune. J. C. Penney announces a move to Texas. It's another blow. NBC threatens to move to New Jersey. Even the threat transmits a reverberating shiver - and a question that almost every city must ask itself:

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: PRESERVING A PARK At a time when historic preservation is almost as popular as apple pie, Suzanne Danielson may still have her work cut out for her. The Irvington public school teacher will conduct a summer course for children 9 through 15 years old about the Old Croton Aqueduct, in preparation for the waterway's sesquicentennial in 1992. Fifteen students at a time will be enrolled for weekly sessions beginning July 6. They will be charged $30 a week or $90 for the entire program.

description: AN increasing number of towns are developing farmland- preservation programs to augment state and private programs.

title: Scandal Watch, Upstate and Down
description: An anonymous letter last week precipitated a quick switch of nominees to head the New York State Thruway Authority and prompted leading law-enforcement officials to hint at a possible statewide scandal.

title: HOMELESS, HELPLESS
description: ''THERE WAS a time,'' the young woman said, ''when I didn't think I could pull it all together, a time when I found myself all alone with two kids in tow and nowhere to turn.

title: PAY CABLE DELIVERS A VARIETY OF PUNCH LINES
description: PAY-CABLE'S COMEDY CARA-van keeps gathering speed, offering as periodic specials the kind of shows that once might have appeared weekly on commercial television or, at least, as familiar acts on ''The Ed Sullivan Show.'' With the exception of Johnny Carson and David Letterman, who can use interviews to flesh out their late-night jokes, most comedians have a tough time coming up with enough new material to fill the demands of a regular series. Pay services such as Home Box Office and Showtime provide more reasonable, less devouring showcases. Frequently, as in the case of HBO's current ''An Evening of Alan King at Carnegie Hall,'' the production is essentially a straightforward recording of a stand-up routine. And pay cable has still another advantage (depending on your point of view): censoring is extremely rare.

title: Comparing the Small Print
description: You're ready to sign for the rental car. Before you left for the airport, you called your insurance agent and learned that you are not covered for damage caused by a collision. Therefore, you decide to pay for the collision damage waiver, at perhaps $9 a day. It acts like insurance, although the renting companies say it simply waives their right to collect from you if the auto comes back in less than its original condition. Your contract is ready. Your pen is out. Then a nagging inner voice says, ''Read the small print!'' (Soon a louder voice, a real one, may shout, ''Get moving!'') The back of the contract is covered with dense type. Trying to read just the parts that affect the collision damage waiver will lead you a merry chase since the contracts say that the waiver is void if any terms of the contract are violated.

title: AID FOR LYME DISEASE DEBATED
description: LEAD: DESPITE careful scrutiny that has included some sharp exchanges during testimony, the County Board of Legislators is expected to approve at least a portion of a $240,000 package to combat Lyme disease that was submitted last month by County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke. Exactly how much and what parts of the package probably will not be determined until next month.

title: LYNN CONNOLLY WEDS
description: Lynn Connolly and Christian I. Halabi were married yesterday at the Trinity Episcopal Church in Tulsa, Okla., by the Rev. John Carter Powers. Mrs. Halabi is a daughter of Markham Connolly of Boston and Anne E. Wyant of Tulsa. The bride, president of Vanessa VanCleef Inc., a sportswear company in New York, graduated magna cum laude from the University of Michigan. Her husband, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Sami I. Halabi of New Haven, is a senior tax associate at Willkie Farr & Gallagher in New York. He graduated from the Georgetown Preparatory School and cum laude from Denison University, where he was elected to Phi Beta Kappa, and he received a law degree from the University of Wisconsin.

title: HOMELESSNESS: A GROWING 'INVISIBLE' PROBLEM
description: I was encouraged to read the article ''New Program Aids Homeless'' [ May 17 ] . Attention needs to be clearly focused on the problems of homeless families in our suburbs. Unfortunately, the plight of the homeless in Nassau County has been ignored by public officials for years.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: FOLLOW THAT KITE ''Let it out.'' ''Pull it up.'' ''Run, Rose, run.''

description: Powerboat racing, like grand prix auto racing, has seen a rash of accidents lately. The risk of death or injury is high for those competing in a world offshore circuit where speed limits continually increase. But for Stuart Hayim, a Great Neck, L.I., businessman, the sport has become his celebration of life.

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''I would characterize this as a major emergency.''

title:
ART;
SCULPTURE CAREFULLY CREATED FOR A SITE
description: LEAD: THE concept of sculpture made expressly for its site has rarely been carried out with the thoughtfulness, even tenderness, evinced at Snug Harbor, the cultural center on the north shore of Staten Island, during its outdoor exhibition this summer.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, an article last week about bicycles gave an incorrect price for the frame from Cycle Composites Inc. It costs $1,200.
