description: Kedleston Hall, a neo-Palladian mansion in Derbyshire, England, created by Robert Adam, the 18th-century architect and designer, is a treausure of the British National Trust and a must-stop for travelers in the English countryside.

title: THOMAS STRANSKY, GEOLOGIST, MARRIED TO HILLARY OLYPHANT, AN UNDERWRITER
description: The marriage of Hillary Olyphant, a daughter of Pamela Olyphant of Pittstown, N.J., and David Olyphant of New York, to Thomas Stransky took place yesterday at St. Andrew's Episcopal Church in Lambertville, N.J. The bridegroom is a son of Jan Stransky of Abu Dhabi, United Arab Emirates, and the late Constance Koven Stransky. The Rev. Richard Townley performed the ceremony.

title: Rhoden Receives 'A Clean Slate'
description: Dave Phillips, the chief of the umpires' crew that will work today's Yankee-Red Sox game at the Stadium, said yesterday he had not received orders from the American League office to warn Rick Rhoden before the game about throwing scuffed balls. Phillips had issued a warning to the Yankee pitcher last week in Baltimore, but said Rhoden would start today's contest with ''a clean slate.''

title: QUEEN VICTORIA'S QUAGMIRE
description: THE BANNER OF BATTLE The Story of the Crimean War. By Alan Palmer. Illustrated. 289 pp. New York: St. Martin's Press. $24.95.

title: CORDLESS EARPHONES FREE THE LISTENER
description: THINK OF EARPHONES and you naturally think of music on the go, with a Walkman dangling from your belt and the phones clamped around your head. But there is also a lot to be said for earphone listening at home. It's the key to acoustic privacy.

title: Torme, McKee, Schuur
description: THE opportunity to hear pop-jazz singers in a big-band setting are precious few these days. And when those voices are first-rate, the accompaniment of a band, rather than an intimate ensemble, can be a revelation. Lonette McKee and Diane Schuur, two promising young jazz singers with strongly defined musical personalities, are familiar to New York audiences from stage and club appearances. But neither has sounded more commandingly engaging than at Carnegie Hall on Friday evening where they and Mel Torme performed with the Mel Lewis Orchestra.

title:
NATURE WATCH;
TIGER SWALLOWTAIL
description: LEAD: Papilio glaucus Size: To five and a half inches.

title: Why Compromise Our Deterrent Strength in Europe?
description: LEAD: Military strength and political will are both necessary for the North Atlantic Treaty Organization to deter aggression, but the alliance has also long recognized the need for dialogue with the Soviet Union. A central element of NATO's approach is arms control.

title: Exploring The Kingdom of AIDS
description: In ''Exploring the Kingdom of AIDS,'' a schoolteacher is quoted as saying that the AIDS epidemic is now cause for concern because of its spread to the heterosexual population. This assertion, with its implication that the lives of the gay men who are dying of AIDS are somehow inconsequential, is very disturbing.

title: THE DOG IS BEING A DOG
description: This prettily produced volume involves the talents of two of the most accessible, even-keeled and easily palatable artists to achieve both critical and popular success today. Alex Katz, known for his boldly stylized paintings of leisurely, domestic scenes, has throughout his career associated with writers and poets. Ann Beattie is the literary godmother of the ''big chill'' sensibility and has in common with Mr. Katz a deliberate flatness of expression. In a prefatory note to ALEX KATZ by Ann Beattie (Abrams, $27.50), the editor suggests we may expect a text free of ''the constraints of art historical reference or criticism.'' On the subject of a double portrait called ''Roger and Sophie,'' Ms. Beattie writes: ''The dog, with its lack of narcissism, may have an advantage not often found in Katz's paintings. . . . Roger's angular haircut calls attention to the artifice of our shaped hair. It is brought out even more by the dog's natural softness and shagginess - a dog that we could reach out and touch. The dog is being a dog, and Roger - because he has summoned the dog -is allowing himself to be human and to be defined by the dog's presence.'' The passage is representative. Where Mr. Katz pictorially fuses the hairs on his sitters' heads, Ms. Beattie splits them to the point of oblivion.

title: MAKING TOO MERRY
description: IT rrwas an uneven week for the royal family. Tabloid coverage hit a peak of ferocity with reports that the Princess of Wales was romantically involved with a young banker. Then on Thursday, there was Queen Elizabeth at her regal best, opening the new Parliament by reading her annual Speech from the Throne in the House of Lords.

title: SPORTS
description: Dr. J's Basketball Stuff CBS/Fox Sports Video. 60 minutes. $19.98 Dr. J, sometimes known as Julius Erving, hung up his Converse All-Stars at the end of the last basketball season. But this is one superstar who isn't likely to fade from the scene. Smart, articulate and a genuine sportsman as well as a great player, he's an ideal role model for youngsters.

title: Ingrid Rockefeller to Marry
description: The engagement of Ingrid Rasmussen Rockefeller to Eric A. Ellisen, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur R. Ellisen of Dover, Del., has been announced by Anne-Marie Rasmussen of Westport, Conn., and Steven C. Rockefeller of Middlebury, Vt., parents of the bride-to-be. A fall wedding is planned.

title: Cable TV
description: In summertime, when thoughts turn to refreshment and escape, Hollywood stands ever ready to oblige. This week, cable offers two of last July's palliatives - the horror sequel ''Aliens'' (Wednesday at 8 P.M. and 4:20 A.M. and Thursday at 9 P.M. on HBO and Saturday at 11 P.M. on Cinemax) and the adventure-fantasy ''Big Trouble in Little China'' (Wednesday at noon and 8 P.M. on Showtime).

title: PLEASED BY THE GOOD IN TEEN-AGERS
description: MY son has a motto at his youth house that states, ''There's No Such Thing as a Bad Kid.'' I would be reluctant to make such a sweeping generalization. After all, he is my son and I remember some things he has forgotten. But I do get a little tired of the other generalizations, too, the comments that sweep all teen-agers into the rotten category.

title:
RECORDINGS;
ROYAL PHILHARMONIC DEBUTS ON ITS OWN LABEL
description: LEAD: THE ROYAL PHILHARMONIC Orchestra has had its share of ups and downs since its formation by Sir Thomas Beecham in 1946. These days, however, it is definitely enjoying a high under its latest music director, Andre Previn, and its president, Sir Yehudi Menuhin. Perhaps the most tangible gesture of the orchestra's current self-confidence was made not long ago, when it launched its own recording label - RPO Records, the first releases of which have now arrived in the United

title: DAY CARE FOR THE ELDERLY GROWS
description: HELEN HALLISSEY, a victim of Alzheimer's disease, was growing more forgetful and confused. When she realized she could no longer manage on her own, she turned to her friend Janet Sorensen, who was pleased to take in the 81-year-old woman, but worried about how to care for her.

title: PATROLLING THE BORDER AT J.F.K.
description: IN his line of work, Jack Pfeifer fingers thousands of ladies' blouses and undergarments, trying to figure out what they're made of. He comes across a great many Christian Dior ties that are not Christian Dior ties, Rolex watches that are not Rolex watches. His daily routine compels him to have an easy familiarity with Chinese medicine and switchblades.

title: FATHER OF THE BRIDE AGAIN AGAIN
description: THE mythology of planning a wedding is a lavender-and-pink blob that eats up everything in its path. You've seen the sci-fi movie, but have you lived it? Have you felt yourself caught up in that ceremonial ooze? The sweet fact that the blob begins somewhere in romantic love is no excuse for the damage it does to laws of reason and restraint.

title: Ex-Inmates Bringing Hope to Wilmington Streets
description: Two ex-convicts, with the help of the twin brother of a slain rap musician, are scoring successes with a program to fight gang violence, teen-age pregnancy, crime and drug abuse in depressed pockets of Wilmington's inner city.

title: Peasants Tell of Rights Abuses by Sandinistas
description: The Nicaraguan Army has committed serious human-rights abuses in the southern border region of Nicaragua over the last two years, according to interviews with several refugees who fled to Costa Rica last month, accounts from other peasants still in southern Nicaragua and investigations by two American human-rights groups.

title: DISABLED LEARN ON JOB AT MADISON RESTAURANT
description: LEAD: JUDY helps to keep things tidy at the Hob Nob restaurant in Madison. When the restaurant opened last month, she needed help to accomplish certain tasks. Now, with the help of a job coach, she can perform them by herself.

title: Reagan's Thumbprint
description: If you're wondering about Ronald Reagan's legacy as President of the United States, look to the courts. His domestic policies have sunk in a sea of red ink. His foreign policy is ending in scandal, but his thumbprint will be on the judiciary into the 21st century.

title: Reagan's Ability to Lead Nation At a Low, Critics and Friends Say
description: As Ronald Reagan nears his final year in the Oval Office, his ability to lead the nation has declined to the lowest point of his Presidency, according to Republican and Democratic legislators, Administration aides and friends of the President.

title: FRIEDRICH MARIACHER WEDS MISS BETTS
description: Victoria Wiswall Betts, a daughter of Archdeacon and Mrs. Darby Wood Betts of Santa Rosa, Calif., Wellesley, Mass., and Castine, Me., was married at Trinity Episcopal Chapel in Castine yesterday to Friedrich Mariacher, a son of Mrs. Hans Johann Mariacher of Mayrhofen, Austria, and the late Mr. Mariacher. The bride's father, who is retired from the Episcopal Diocese of California, performed the ceremony.

title: NEW YORKERS, ETC.
description: MARRIAGE, which sort of went out of fashion for a while, at least in Manhattan, is back among the things that are all right to do. It is, in fact, exceedingly popular with all age groups, but how those singles beyond the first flush of youth ever get to the altar, or even to a romantic supper by candlelight, is difficult to fathom. According to some of them, finding a date in New York is an accomplishment, but finding a date with what they term ''a normal person'' is a miracle.

title: HEARING JAZZ AT ITS RISKY BEST - IN THE CLUBS
description: WHEN THE JVC JAZZ Festival trundles out of town tonight, for some New Yorkers and visitors it will mean the end of 1987's allotment of jazz. For those listeners, if it's not in a concert hall, then it's not serious music. It's almost as if the jazz clubs don't exist.

title: MISS SIKORSKI HAS WEDDDING
description: Cindy Ann Sikorski, the daughter of Kathleen O'Neill Sikorski of Delray, Fla., and Silvermine, Conn., and the late Joseph Charles Sikorski, was married yesterday to Edwin Ellis Flood Stebbins, a son of Mrs. Andrew M. Blum of New York and James F. Stebbins of Syosset, L.I. The Rev. Richard Dannenfelser, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony at the River Club in New York.

title: Stage: Clifford Mason's 'Royal Oak'
description: THE acting is the whole game in the C.B.A. Theater Company's production of ''Royal Oak'' at the Triangle Theater of Long Island University in Brooklyn. Clifford Mason's play is very long and, at the end, emotionally puzzling. But through most of it, the company's producer, Cynthia Belgrave, and the dozen actors she surrounds herself with in this performance create vivid and often very funny characters entangled in amorous high jinks in a guest house in Trinidad.

title: Pacific Isles: Paradise Lost In Economics
description: This is the kind of South Pacific paradise that most Americans would love to be marooned on: lovely beaches, relaxed and friendly people, and bananas and coconuts always available for the picking.

title: Learning Russian
description: To the Editor: I read with interest the response to the question about language opportunity sources in Russian (Q & A, May 17). Unfortunately, New York University, which has the largest continuing education language program in the United States, was not mentioned.

title: ATTACKING INMATE ADDICTION
description: ''They showed me I could cry. That's hard for a tough guy.'' - Alan James, an inmate at the Nassau County Correctional Center.

title: MILLIE MARTINI IS WED TO MAJ. JOHN BRATTEN
description: Millie Martini, the associate editor of Bride's magazine, and Maj. John Drew Bratten, U.S.M.C., public affairs director for the Marine Corps office in New York, were married yesterday at the Post Chapel of the Fort Hamilton Army Post in Brooklyn. Lieut. Col. Wayne Jamison, U.S.A., a Presbyterian chaplain, performed the ceremony.

title: ABOUT BOOKS
description: WHEREVER one goes on vacation, there's usually a bookstore nearby. For example, in With Pipe and Book, a Lake Placid, N.Y., tobacco-book shop, one is likely to find a New Jersey-related mystery set in that community54 years ago.

title: BEYOND VISUAL: ALTERNATIVES TO TRADITIONAL SCULPTURE
description: LEAD: IN its comparatively short three-year existence, the East Hampton Center for Contemporary Art has gained a reputation for alertness to art at the cutting edge. Its latest efforts, ''New Sculpture,'' plus an outdoor installation, might be statistically small - there are just 12 pieces - yet the impact is sizable.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: LONGING TO STAY DEAD Raymond A. Moody collected 150 accounts of ''near-death'' experiences, and composed the typical features into a composite portrait. He is quoted in ''Otherworld Journeys: Accounts of Near-Death Experience in Medieval and Modern Times'' (Oxford University) by Carol Zaleski.

title: Sponsor Accused in SoHo Foreclosures
description: When a cooperative sponsor puts together a co-op sales package he often places a second mortgage on the property as another way of making money on the deal. These mortgages, however, can tie up the sponsor's gains for many years, and some converters try to get the mortgages prepaid by forcing a co-op into foreclosure.

title: BETWEEN BLAM AND BLOOEY
description: THE TIDEWATER TALES By John Barth. 655 pp. New York: G. P. Putnam's Sons. $21.95.

title: JENNIFER LAMBERT WEDS D. C. CHURCHILL
description: The marriage of Jennifer Lambert, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul C. Lambert of New York and Locust, N.J., to Daniel C. Churchill took place yesterday in Clayton, N.Y. The Rev. Sidney Lovett, a Congregational minister, performed the ceremony on Grindstone Island, one of the Thousand Islands. Mr. Churchill is the son of Mrs. James Farley of Cornish, N.H., and the late Creighton Churchill.

title: Jazz Festival; Leroy Jenkins, Violinist
description: LEROY JENKINS is one of the most distinctive and compelling of modern jazz violinists. But his electric band Sting!, which performed at Greenwich House Friday under the auspices of the Jazz Festival and the World Music Institute, is neither fish nor fowl. It's only intermittently convincing as jazz. Of the soloists, only Mr. Jenkins seems to improvise in a manner that relates meaningfully to the given compositional materials; the other players are content with skittering chromatic runs and arpeggiated figures that chase their own tails. The music's vernacular elements - dance rhythms, amplified textures, rocking ostinato figures -seem more tangential than endemic to the music's substance and thrust.

title: WORLD OF LAW IS OCEANA'S UNIVERSE
description: PHILIP F. COHEN, the 75-year-old president of Oceana Publications in Dobbs Ferry, needs no visual aids to stir his memory when he talks about his long life in the book business. Yet the reminders surround him: the carved goatskin portfolio from Africa, where Oceana once had an office; the many mementos from his trips to the Far East; the framed photograph of himself with former Chief Justice Warren Burger.

title: JOHN C. CARLSON TO WED CLAIRE STREETER, EDITOR

description: Chrysler and two executives face 16 charges for disconnecting the odometers on cars that were driven by employees before being sold as new. title: GUARDS WON'T PLAY BALL IF INMATES CAN WATCH

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LEAD: FUNERAL MUSIC FOR FREEMASONS. By Lars Gustafsson. Translated by Yvonne L. Sandstroem. (New Directions, Cloth, $19.95; Paper, $9.95.) The novels of the Swedish writer Lars Gustafsson are remarkable for being at once quirky and somber, offhandedly intellectual and oddly graceful. ''Funeral Music for Freemasons,'' his fifth work to be translated into English, traces the lives of three people whose attitudes were formed in the ''still idyllic'' atmosphere of Sweden in the 1950's.

title: Learning From Masters of the Wilds
description: Small boys imitate older brothers who hit home runs, and so grown-up fishermen imitate fishing guides. There are sound reasons why a city angler should avoid unfamiliar great waters unless he has a guide to keep him out of quicksand and instruct him in the mores of local fish. But the attachment of client to guide involves something deeper than reason. The satisfaction of a fishing trip depends as much on that attachment as it does on the weather, the fish, the food or even the luck.

title: Letting a PC Pick Stocks
description: THE most accurate investment adviser known to man is hindsight. It is never wrong, and it guarantees fortunes to anyone exercising it. Unfortunately, reaping the profits it promises is rather difficult.

title: 'I, PURITANI,' AND OTHER ODD FELLOWS
description: IT IS IMPORTANT TO THE CONTINUED WELL-being of the human race that words not be misunderstood. No argument there. If the road sign reads ''Slow Children,'' a driver may be distracted into musing on its double meaning and, without really intending to, run over a stray tot or two. For authors employed to compose road markers, obviously, unequivocal clarity should be the sign qua non. STOP must mean stop, or at least downshift one gear. People who write for other reasons and other audiences should aim at least as high. If they do not, they deserve to be pulled over to the curb by the word cops who unselfishly patrol our language in search of writers guilty of violating the laws of lucidity.

title: NEW OCEANFRONT ZONING MAY NOT STOP PLANS

June 8, the day before the Hempstead Town Board approved the new zoning for the two-mile oceanfront, the United States Supreme Court ruled that property owners are entitled to compensation when zoning restrictions deny them substantial use of their land.

title: DELACROIX, A QUINTESSENTIALLY FRENCH PAINTER
description: THE EUGENE DELACROIX RET-rospective at the Kunsthaus in Zurich is about as good a Delacroix show as anyone can now hope for outside France. It has to be limited. Some of Delacroix's most important works were commissions for walls and ceilings of public buildings in Paris. Paintings like ''The Massacre at Chios,'' ''Liberty Leading the People,'' ''The Death of Sardanapalus'' and ''The Women of Algiers'' are now so much a part of the French artistic patrimony that they may never leave France. The paintings and works on paper in the Moreau-Nelaton collection, given to the Louvre early in the century, are not allowed to travel.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Track and Field Soviet and East German Teams Triumph: The East German team dominated the women's standing, but the Soviet Union rallied to win the men's competition in the European Cup in Prague. The East Germans dominated the women's events from the start and finished on top of the standings with 119 points, a margin of 27 points over the Soviet Union. But the Soviet athletes, who trailed after the first day of events at the Rosicky Stadium, had a strong comeback yesterday to win the men's event with 117 points, 2 1/2 more than the East Germans. Linford Christie of Britain scored the only double of the meet. He won the men's 200 meters in 20.63 seconds yesterday after taking the 100 meters in 10.23 seconds Saturday. Francesco Panetta's victory in the steeplechase was the highlight of the meet, as the Italian won in the fastest time in the world this year: 8 minutes 13.47 seconds.(AP) Show Jumping Rookie Is Lake Placid Winner: Greg Best of Flemington, N.J., a rookie on the show-jumping grand prix circuit, picked up his third victory of the year yesterday in the $30,000 Lake Placid Grand Prix, closing event of the 18th annual Lake Placid Horse Show. A starting field of 57 horses competed in a one-round format on a 16-jump, 466-yard course. Only 12 of these horses completed the course without penalty. The fastest of these times was turned in by Best, a 22-year-old University of Pennsylvania graduate. He finished in 61.797 seconds on his 8-year-old thoroughbred, bred on Chado Farm in Neshanic Station, N.J. Best, the leader in the Rhulen Rookie of the Year standing, edged Jay Land of Atlanta, who finished in 62.474 seconds on Leapy Lad, an 11-year-old Irish-bred gelding. Yacht Racing Hood Dominates Block Island Races: Ted Hood, the veteran America's Cup skipper, sailmaker and yacht designer from Portsmouth, R.I., sailed his 15-year-old Robin to three first-place finishes, a second and a fifth in the five-race Block Island Race Week series that ended late Friday. Hood is in line to win the overall perpetual trophy for best score in his division. Another 15-year-old boat, Arcadia, owned by Robert Stone Jr. of Marion, Mass., beat several newer designs for Class 1 honors. The overall class winners in the 250-boat fleet were: Class 1, Arcadia; Class 2, Fujimo; Class 3, Pirate Twin; Class 4, Mad Max; Class 5, Houqua; Class 6, Indian Summer; Class 7, Spirit; Class 8, Smiling Banshee; Class 9, L.A. Express; Class 10, Free and Clear; Class 11, Conspiracy; Class 12, Brigadoon IV; Class 13, Robin; Class 14, Intimidation and Class A, Centauri.

title: THEATER: ''DREAMGIRLS,'' A MUSICAL, IS REVIVED
description: THE marquee at the Ambassador Theater says that Broadway's new edition of ''Dreamgirls'' is ''the Michael Bennett production,'' but one has real reason to fear that the billing is a case of wishful promotion. Mr. Bennett, disabled by illness, has been inactive as a director for well over a year. And how could his initial production of ''Dreamgirls,'' which ran from 1981 to 1985 at the Imperial, fit into the Ambassador anyway? A small house with a shallow stage, the Ambassador can't meet the physical requirements of most modern musicals, let alone those of a show whose controversial Robin Wagner set featured electronically mechanized towers and bridges. This ''Michael Bennett production'' of ''Dreamgirls'' can only be - and in fact is - a bus-and-truck touring company, stripped down by its director two years ago for fleet and economical travel on the road. When the curtain rises at the Ambassador, we see a stage nearly as bare as that for Mr. Bennett's ''Chorus Line'': a black backdrop, a few hand-twirled ''towers'' that might have been constructed with a kid's Erector set, a small constellation of theatrical lights.

description: ORLANDO, Fla., June 29 (AP) - Scientists suspect bacteria whose growth was encouraged by warm, wet weather and acid rain killed about 40 bald eagles before they could hatch, according to Steve Sherrod, director of an Oklahoma bird research center.

Davey Johnson and Whitey Herzog were trying to outthink each other as the Cardinals beat the Mets, 8-7, in 11 innings in the opener of a three-game series last night at Shea Stadium. Johnson and Herzog are two of baseball's best managers in one of baseball's best rivalries. But, surprise, they are now business partners in a Florida fish camp that will open after the World Series.

title: HANOI CURRENCY MOVE
description: Vietnam's Foreign Trade Bank has opened the first foreign currency accounts for Vietnamese who receive money from abroad, Hanoi radio said today. The report added that the change allowed Vietnamese to exchange foreign currencies at profit, use them in business transactions with one another or on trips abroad. The accounts will handle currencies of the United States, Britain, France, Switzerland, West Germany, Canada, Japan and Hong Kong.

title: MORALE SAGS AT 'FAILING' DETROIT PAPER
description: The Detroit Free Press, which has described itself as a failing newspaper in its longstanding rivalry with The Detroit News, announced major staff changes in recent weeks that have brought both uncertainty and measured optimism to the newsroom.

title: Humor
description: Washington is settling in for high judicial drama on Capitol Hill in the aftermath of the resignation Friday by Justice Lewis F. Powell Jr. from the Supreme Court. Senator Patrick J. Leahy, the Vermont Democrat who heads the Judiciary Committee's judicial screening unit, gave an indication of what might be in store when he was told that Senator Strom Thurmond of South Carolina, the committee's ranking Republican, had predicted that a replacement would be named and confirmed before Congress leaves town in August. ''Oh, that Strom,'' Mr. Leahy said. ''He has such a pixie-ish sense of humor.''

title: Q&A
description: Q.Why is varnish usually applied only to the outside wood surfaces of a violin? A.Varnish is applied to the outside surfaces of a violin to give the instrument its shiny look and to protect it from dirt and damage, said David Segal, a violin maker in New York City. The inside of a violin does not require the same protection. Nevertheless, some violin makers also apply polishes such as varnish, linseed oil or diluted glue to the inside of their violins. Mr. Segal paints a gluey solution to the inside of his violins. ''The solution strengthens the wood and insulates it from humidity and dryness,'' he said. QDoes clear glass block harmful rays from the sun, and are you protected in the shade of an awning or tree? Can the sun damage hair? A.Clear glass blocks most ultraviolet rays, which can cause sunburn, wrinkling, freckles and precancerous changes in the skin, according to Dr. Leonard Harber, director of dermatology at the Presbyterian Hospital at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center, and Dr. Allen Lawrence, chief of dermatology at the University of Chicago Medical School. Glass contains impurities, such as iron oxide, which absorb longer rays of ultraviolet light, the most harmful type. But the impurities do not absorb shorter ultraviolet rays, which are believed to be as harmful if a person is exposed to the rays over a prolonged period. The purer the glass, the less effective it is in absorbing ultraviolet rays, Dr. Harber said.

title: S.E.C. CITES TAKEOVER LAWYER
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday accused a leading Wall Street takeover lawyer of failing to advise his client to disclose confidential takeover talks promptly.

title: Baron's Legacy: A Potent Theorem
description: TODAY'S advances in the analysis and control of noise grow out of a breakthrough in the early 1800's by Jean Baptiste Joseph Fourier, a French mathematician, Egyptologist and administrator. Born in 1768, Fourier attended a military school run by Benedictine monks. He showed such talent at mathematics that upon graduation he was asked to join the school's faculty.

title: WHEN PRODUCTION JUST ISN'T ENOUGH
description: The rookie is left with happy memories of his first trip around the bases in a major-league game, and the admiration that was created with his eyebrow-raising first impression. Keith Miller is also left with an unpleasant souvenir. After two weeks in the major leagues that have been as productive as they were unforeseen, Miller needs to look no farther than the end of his right arm to remember his first night.

description: The British Petroleum Company P.L.C. has completed its merger with the Standard Oil Company, raising its holding in the Cleveland-based oil company to 100 percent, from 55 percent. The acquisition was made through B.P.'s wholly owned subsidiary, B.P. America Inc. Sir Peter Walters, B.P.'s chairman, will serve as chairman of B.P. America.

But Mr. Gore seems a pale imitation of a Southern politician when he is standing next to his Governor, Ned McWherter, as he was not long ago at the United States Conference of Mayors meeting in Nashville.

title: Breakthrough in Seoul
description: For weeks South Korea appeared to be lurching toward civil war. Now, suddenly, it seems to verge on peaceful, democratic revolution. Roh Tae Woo, designated successor to President Chun Doo Hwan, opened the door by endorsing the principal opposition demand for direct presidential elections. President Chun has accepted this ''in principle,'' but omitted critical details and implementing orders. It is now up to the President to carry out the pledge fully and fairly, opposition leaders to respond constructively, and the military to stay out of politics.

title: Sakharov Assails Body For Not Defending Him

description: A man who apparently was distraught over family health problems fatally shot his mother in a nursing home here, then killed his sister and his wife before killing himself, the police said.

There was also a line - or queue, as the English say - extending past two adjacent courts, numbering 200 people or more, waiting patiently on a very warm day for a chance to see the player who vanquished Boris Becker. Almost four and a half hours later, the line had barely moved.

title: Flynt Autopsy Inconclusive
description: Coroner's officials said today that the autopsy in the death of Althea Flynt, the co-publisher of Hustler magazine, was inconclusive and that the investigation would continue. Mrs. Flynt, the wife of the magazine's founder, Larry Flynt, was found dead Saturday in a bathtub at the couple's mansion here. Bill Gold, a spokesman for the coroner's office, said toxicological tests would be needed to determine the cause of death. Alan Isaacman, an attorney for the Flynt family, said Mrs. Flynt, 33 years old, had been ill for ''quite a long time,'' but he declined to elaborate on her illness.

The bill, which passed 55-1, would exempt playoff, World Series and All-Star baseball games played at the Chicago Cubs' ball park from Illinois' nighttime noise-emission regulations. It would not grant exemptions for regular-season games.

Whether the graduation will prove to be magna or summa cum laude, or possibly without special distinction, will not be known for a while, but the company has made plain that it intends to find its way to the top of the opera class. That the road to that goal will not be an easy one was suggested on Sunday evening by the first production in the new house, ''Eugene Onegin.''

title: Democratic Presidential Contender; Albert Gore Jr.
description: Current Job: U.S. Senator, Tennessee, since 1985. Date of Birth: March 31, 1948; Washington. title: 2 Shot and 5 Stabbed In Clinton Prison Melee
description: All prisoners at the maximum-security Clinton Correctional Facility were restricted to their cells today after a disturbance sent seven prisoners to the hospital with gunshot and stab wounds, officials said.

title: VAN GOGH'S 'BRIDGE' SELLS IN LONDON FOR $20 MILLION
description: The mood was oddly subdued in the jam-packed salesroom at Christie's tonight as ''The Bridge of Trinquetaille,'' Vincent van Gogh's view of an iron bridge over the Rhone, was sold to an anonymous telephone bidder for $20.2 million. It was the second highest price ever paid for a painting at auction, and members of the art trade were united in their agreement that the price was both impressive and fair.

title: 'When Is It Time to Let the Dying Go?'

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Horse Racing 1-10 Java Gold Loses by Nose: Java Gold became the heaviest losing favorite of the year in New York when he was outdueled through the stretch by Cutlass Reality and beaten by a nose in the featured allowance race yesterday at Belmont Park. Java Gold, making his first start since April 18, was the 1-to-10 favorite as the lone 3-year-old in a field of four, and looked as if he were home free after bounding to an easy early lead. He led by two lengths after setting fractions of 0:24 1/5 and 0:47 2/5, but Cutlass Reality, who began to gain as they rounded the stretch turn, drew even with a furlong to go. Java Gold, under Pat Day, fought back from the rail but lost the duel in the final strides. Cutlass Reality, a 5-year-old who paid $12.40 for $2 to win as the second choice in the betting, ran the mile in 1:36 4/5 under Julio Pezua, over a track called the dullest of the meeting, so it was a fine effort for both horses. El Basco finished nearly 11 lengths behind in third. Java Gold, winner of the Remsen last fall as a 2-year-old, won two allowance races at Aqueduct in April, but then was knocked out of the Triple Crown races by a virus. His main goal is the Travers Stakes at Saratoga Aug. 22. Yachting Kookaburra II Keeps Winning: Kookaburra II of Australia sailed to her third straight victory in the 12-Meter World Championship off Porto Cervo, Sardinia. Bengal, another Australian entry, was second in the race, the fourth of the series, followed by White Horse Challenge of Britain. Dennis Conner's Stars & Stripes, which won the America's Cup, took fourth, but entered port flying an infringement flag, an admission of a violation, and was dropped to seventh place. Kookaburra II, sponsored by the Royal Perth Yacht Club, holds the overall lead with 31.75 points. Bengal is second with 26.25 points, and New Zealand is third with 20 points. (AP)

JOHNNY CARSON IS WED
description: MALIBU, Calif., June 29 (AP) - Johnny Carson, the host of the ''Tonight Show,'' has married Alexis Maas, whom Mr. Carson met when she worked for a stock brokerage here four years ago, the entertainer's publicist announced today. The publicist, Jim Mahoney, said Mr. Carson and Miss Maas were married June 20, by Superior Court Judge William Hogoboom at Mr. Carson's Malibu Beach home. The couple then left for the Wimbledon tennis matches in England, Mr. Mahoney said. It was the forth marriage for Mr. Carson. Miss Maas, a native of Pittsburgh who was said to be in her 30's, and Mr. Carson, who is 61 years old, were engaged in December, Mr Mahoney said.

Each terminal can run programs written for I.B.M. and I.B.M.-compatible personal computers.

title: ALASKAN MURDER: ENIGMA WITHIN AN ENIGMA
description: Among the unanswered questions in one of Alaska's most convoluted murder cases is how material that was derogatory to the defendant got into the jury room, precipitating a mistrial, While the state police investigate that mystery, the prosecution has made a deal with Neil Mackay, a 63-year-old wealthy investor and former Anchorage lawyer who is charged with hiring someone to kill his former brother-in-law, Mr. Mackay, who spent 17 months in jail unable to post bail that had been set at $7 million, has now been released on $100,000 property surety bond. In return, Mr. Mackay has agreed to a new court date, Nov. 16, waiving his right to a new trial within 120 days. Under the bail agreement, he may live with a former law associate in Anchorage, observing a 6 P.M. to 9 A.M. curfew and notifying the Anchorage police when he goes outside the house.

description: The attitudes of organizers toward co-champions fluctuate from tolerance to tiebreak, but players generally favor a brief playoff match, especially if there are additional prizes for it.

title: The Talk of Battery Park City; BATTERY PARK CITY MOVES TO ADOLESCENCE
description: It was the heady sense of being first, of living where no one had lived before, that drew early settlers like Kathleen and Udayan Gupta to Battery Park City, a 90-acre experiment at the mouth of the Hudson and the tip of Manhattan. Built on landfill from the construction site of the World Trade Center, this new community brimmed with promise, and the Guptas found a home there within easy reach of work, a spectacular view and a sense of peace and privacy they had never known in New York.

title: INTER-TEL INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $125,000 for the quarter and $150,000 for the 6 months.

title: NBC CITES FEW PROBLEMS ON THE FIRST DAY OF STRIKE
description: With secretaries filling in as editors and vice presidents pounding out scripts for the ''NBC Nightly News,'' NBC got through the first day of a strike yesterday by 2,800 members of the National Association of Broadcast Employees and Technicians with a few on-air glitches but no major interruptions of its broadcast schedule.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE UNICORN EXPEDITION and Other Fantastic Tales of India. By Satyajit Ray. 190 pages. E. P. Dutton. $16.95. I MUST admit that I began ''The

title: THE MUMMY'S SECRET
description: Scientists who performed X-rays and a full-body CAT scan on a mummy of a temple singer who lived 4,500 years ago have determined that the she had buck teeth and a big nose, and did not look like the mask on her coffin.

title: PESTICIDES IN THE RAIN
description: AGRICULTURAL pesticides have been found to return to earth in precipitation much more than was believed. In an analysis of rainwater samples from Ohio, Indiana, West Virginia and New York, scientists found that pesticide levels varied strongly from season to season. They reached a peak in rains right after the heaviest applications in farm fields in the spring and were detectable in decreasing amounts for about two months, but were not detected in the winter. In New York and West Virginia, where pesticide use is less intense, the samples showed less frequent and lower concentrations. Herbicides now in use are not very toxic to animals, the scientists report in the journal Nature,, and herbicides and insecticides remain in the environment for shorter times than predecessors such as DDT. But dispersal of these organic compounds in the atmosphere may have unknown effects, said Dr. David B. Baker, one of the authors, in an interview.

title: CONCORD FABRICS INC reports earnings for 13wks to May 31
description: b-Includes gains from the disposal of discontinued operations of $162,000 and $432,000 for the 13 weeks and 39 weeks, respectively. c-Net loss d-After losses from discontinued operations of $111,024 and $237,773 for the 13 weeks and 39 weeks, respectively, and a loss of $585,175 from the disposal of discontinued operations for both the 13 weeks and 39 weeks.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The Evening Hours column on the Style page last Friday misidentified the beneficiary of a party at the Lesbian and Gay Community Services Center on West 13th Street. The $20,000 that was raised benefited the center.

title: German Trade Surplus
description: West Germany, which is under pressure from the United States and other trading partners to export less and consume more, turned in another strong trade surplus in May. The Federal Statistics Office said today that the surplus rose to 10.6 billion marks ($5.8 billion) from 8.9 billion marks ($4.9 billion) in April and 8.1 billion marks ($4.4 billion) in May of last year. In the first five months of this year, the trade surplus was up 15.7 percent over the corresponding period last year, to 47.2 billion marks ($25.8 billion).

title: PRECISION TARGET MARKETING reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After extraordinary gains of $85,000 for the quarter and $214,000 for the year. c-Net loss

title: STRIKE PARALYZES HAITIAN CAPTIAL
description: A general strike to protest a new election decree paralyzed the capital today and was reported successful in other Haitian cities.

title: LIFETIME CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 27
description: Share earnings are fully diluted. The company said the year-ago results are not meaningful due to its reverse merger in 1986. Results for the fourth quarter and year include a charge of $513,000 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: Crazy Eddie Tender Stalled
description: Entertainment Marketing Inc., the Houston electronics wholesaler that has made a bid for Crazy Eddie Inc., said yesterday that it would not make a tender offer for the 39-store chain without specific financial information it had requested from Crazy Eddie this month. The bid by Entertainment

title: FOR KOREANS, SIGHS OF RELIEF AS AIR CLEARS
description: The Kahwa teahouse posted a sign today offering ''free service on this delightful day.'' After three weeks of political turmoil in which the air was never free of tear gas and the streets were never free of riot policemen, the people of Seoul allowed themselves a collective sigh of relief today. They rushed to newsstands, grabbing single-sheet newspaper extras and scanning them intently as they walked.

title: BORK NOMINATION TO COURT WEIGHED BY THE PRESIDENT
description: Amid growing indications that President Reagan is moving toward nominating Judge Robert H. Bork to the Supreme Court, White House officials today spent the day sounding out the appeals court judge's prospects for Senate confirmation.

title: Corrections
description: A Boston dispatch on June 9 about a protest over denial of tenure to two faculty members at Harvard Law School incompletely described the history of student ratings for the teaching of one member, Clare Dalton. Professor Dalton's ratings, averaged over the six years of her Harvard appointment, placed her in the top half of the law school faculty.

title: Dr. Eleanor Bliss, 88, Drug Research Expert
description: Dr. Eleanor A. Bliss, former dean of the graduate school of Bryn Mawr College and a pioneer researcher in the clinical use of sulfa drugs before World War II, died of kidney failure Saturday at her home in Bryn Mawr, Pa. She was 88 years old.

title: EXCERPTS FROM SPEECH BY SEOUL PARTY CHIEF
description: Following, in official translation, are excerpts from a nationally broadcast address today by Roh Tae Woo, chairman of the governing Democratic Justice Party, proposing sweeping constitutional changes:

title: Like Putting the K.G.B. Into the Pentagon
description: Our Government has long known that the Soviet Union has had an aggressive program of acquiring American and other Western technologies and technical know-how. For example, we recently discovered that a Japanese company and a Norwegian state enterprise conspired to give the Russians the equipment and know-how to improve their submarines - with devastating consequences for our national security.

title: A SOVIET OVERTURE TO IRAN REPORTED
description: The Soviet Union, in an effort to ward off future Iranian attacks on its ships in the Persian Gulf, has stepped up its diplomatic contacts with the authorities in Teheran, Administration officials said today.

title: MET OPERA: 'BOHEME' SUNG IN PARK IN QUEENS
description: SUMMER music in the great outdoors poses an annual question that we're usually too hot and sticky to expend much energy on. Do art and nature go together, or are they hopelessly antagonistic rivals for our attention?

title: Eyebrows
description: Representative Richard A. Gephardt's leadership on the film colorization issue has occasioned some snickering among his critics, who are shocked - shocked - that there might be politics behind it.

title: THE DANCE: SIX WORKS AT DAVID HOWARD CENTER
description: SHOULD the choreography at the David Howard Dance Center grow dull, one can at least enjoy the performance space. The wall to the right of the audience in this roomy fourth-floor studio at 211 West 61st Street consists entirely of mirrors. To the left and directly in front of the audience are enormous windows looking out upon the West Side of Manhattan toward the Hudson River and New Jersey. The views are splendid. James Beaumont incorporated them into his ''Pearls,'' one of the works offered Friday night as part of the 1987 New Dance Series of programs by young choreographers presented at the center by the David Howard Foundation. To a recording of Gershwin's ''Our Love Is Here to Stay,'' Hillary Mellis and Karl Barbee danced a casual duet while the lights of apartment windows glowed behind them. The view and the dance made one understand why, despite all the problems of urban living, people still love Manhattan.

title: HANK JONES, PIANIST AND FREINDS
description: ''THE WORLD OF HANK JONES,'' which brought this year's JVC Jazz Festival to a close at Town Hall on Sunday evening, was a diverse, compendious, intensely musical concert, precisely the sort of thing the jazz festival does best.

title: O'Connor's Worship Proposal Is Rejected by Jewish Group
description: The Simon Wiesenthal Center, a major Jewish organization devoted to keeping the memory of the Holocaust alive, rejected yesterday John Cardinal O'Connor's call for Catholics and Jews to come together in worship to heal the wounds left by the recent visit of President Kurt Waldheim of Austria to Pope John Paul II.

title: BRIEFS
description: Allied-Signal Inc., Morristown, N.J., said that Schlumberger Ltd. had acquired its Neptune International unit, based in Atlanta, for an undisclosed amount. Neptune produces water meters and flow-measurement equipment.

title: COMTREX SYSTEMS reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: Chalking Up More Homers
description: If you sense that this is the year of the home run, you are in complete agreement with Dave Neale, the manager of the touring slow-pitch softball team that represents Steele's Sports Company of Grafton, Ohio, a distributor of softballs and bats.

title: APOLLO'S PRODUCTS
description: Apollo Computer Inc. introduced new computer work stations and said it had improved the performance and reduced the prices of some of its existing work stations. The company also introduced new products to allow personal computers to communicate with the work stations. The new products, the Domain Series 4000 Personal Super Work Stations, include the first color work station priced less than $19,000 that can process four million instructions a second.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: TUESDAY, JUNE 30, 1987
description: COMPANIES Texaco has apparently gained the S.E.C. as an ally in its protracted battle with Pennzoil. The agency said it would file a brief with the Texas Supreme Court asking it to review a $10 billion judgment against Texaco. Legal experts said the agency would support a key Texaco defense: that Pennzoil broke Federal securities laws when it sought to take over Getty Oil in 1983. Pennzoil, which lost out to Texaco in the takeover battle, has argued that Texaco illegally interfered with a binding deal to acquire Getty. [ Page D1. ]

title: Nuclear Arms Will Lead to War, Not Prevent It
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. URGES I.C.C. TO BAR BUS LINKUP
description: The Reagan Administration expressed strong reservations today about allowing Greyhound Lines Inc. to buy out its main competitor in the ailing bus industry, Trailways Inc.

title: KOCH OPPOSES SENATE'S PLAN TO CUT A TAX
description: Fighting to preserve his plan to restructure New York City's personal income taxes, Mayor Koch appealed to the Republican-controlled State Senate today to drop its efforts to win more favorable tax treatment for capital gains income.

title: RULE ON ALIENS EASED FOR HARVEST
description: The Immigration and Naturalization Service said today that it would allow migrant farm laborers into the United States on the basis of their word that they had worked in past harvests.

title: Police Arrest Suspect In a Manhattan Rape
description: A 34-year-old Manhattan man was arrested last night and charged with raping a 21-year-old Irishwoman after promising her a job as a jewelry salesman, the police said.

title: AIDS ANTIBODY KIT
description: The Eastman Kodak Company said it was marketing a kit, manufactured by Cellular Products Inc. of Buffalo, to test for antibodies to the virus that causes acquired immune deficiency syndrome. The company said it was the first of several diagnostic tests for certain retroviruses and infectious diseases that it plans to market to blood banks, hospitals and public health laboratories. Each kit, which yields 89 usable tests, will sell for between $1 and $1.50.

title: CITY GIVING $13.5 MILLION FOR MET WING
description: New York City announced yesterday that it would give $13.5 million to the Metropolitan Museum of Art to help finance the construction of the last major component of the museum's master plan, a five-story wing to house European sculpture and decorative art.

title: A SILENT REVOLUTION, FOUGHT BY UNSUNG WARRIORS
description: It would be easy to make light of the Mon revolution.

title: ECHLIN INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Meese Remark on Standards For the Court Draws Laughs
description: Hundreds of people laughed today when Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d said the Reagan Administration had no philosophical test for filling the Supreme Court vacancy created by the retirement of Justice Lewis F. Powell Jr. Following a speech on the Constitution to about 3,000 people at the Chautauqua Institution, Mr. Meese was asked by a member of the audience if the person President Reagan chooses to replace Justice Powell must oppose abortion.

title: UNIVERSITY GENETICS reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
CARDS KNOCK METS 7 1/2 OUT
description: The St. Louis Cardinals knocked the Mets seven and a half games out of first place last night when they rallied with four runs in the late innings, tied the Mets in the ninth and beat them in the 11th by 8-7.

title: Police Stop Taping Call-In Show
description: The New York City Police Department will stop monitoring a morning talk program on WLIB-AM, a radio station geared to black listeners, in response to protests from the station's management, civil libertarians and others, the police said yesterday.

title: KIRIN CHANGES AGENCY AS WELL AS DISTRIBUTOR
description: Kirin beer is getting a new distributor and a new ad agency as well. The Japanese brew, the third-best-selling beer worldwide, had been distributed by Kirin U.S.A., a subsidiary of the parent company. That is being changed to Martlet Imports, North Hills, L.I., which is owned by the Molson Companies and distributes its Golden Beer and Ale from Canada.

title: LORIMAR TELEPICTURES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $13,562,000 and $21,992,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. The company said the year-ago results are not presented because of the eight-month and two-month short periods reported in conjunction with the February 1986 merger of Lorimar and Telepictures.

title: A Battle Royal
description: In the Kansas City Royals' dugout Sunday, there was a reminder of the football Giants' coach-dousing way of celebrating victory, but what happened next wasn't very sporting. Bret Saberhagen, the major-league pitcher who has the best record this season, scuffled briefly with the Royals' third-base coach, Jose Martinez, following an 8-3 victory in Kansas City over the Seattle Mariners. Royals players said the incident started in the dugout after the game when Saberhagen poured water on the winning pitcher, Mark Gubicza, and inadvertently dampened Martinez.

title: 77TH PREINCT 'RINGLEADER' DRAWS A PRISON TERM
description: A 36-year-old police officer, described by prosecutors as a ringleader of a group of corrupt Brooklyn officers who regularly stole drugs and money from drug dealers, was sentenced yesterday to a prison term of three and a half to 10 1/2 years.

title: Strength At the Center
description: In June 1972, five months after he took his seat on the Supreme Court, Justice Powell delivered the Court's opinion on what he called a ''delicate question of the President's power.'' It was whether the President could order electronic surveillance in internal security matters without a warrant or some form of prior judicial authorization.

title: Ratings Changes By Moody's, S.&P
description: Moody's Investors Service and the Standard & Poor's Corporation yesterday announced actions involving the debt ratings of the Public Service Company of New Hampshire, the Scott Paper Company, Heritage Communications Inc. and the Allis-Chalmers Corporation. The actions affect about $2.8 billion of securities.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: ANGEL ESTRADA'S show of evening clothes for the winter holidays was a sort of Woodstock festival for fashion. Among the new stars watching from the audience at Rutherford House last week were the designers Kevin Emard, Roland Nivelais, Isabel Toledo, Marc Jacobs, Larissa, Maripol, Robert Molnar and Patrick Kelly.

title: Ambac-Insured Bonds To Get Triple-A Rating
description: Bonds insured by the Ambac Indemnity Corporation, one of the companies in the municipal bond insurance business, will be assigned a triple-A rating, Moody's Investors Service announced yesterday. In addition, said Freda Ackerman, executive vice president and director of Moody's municipal department, the short-term obligations insured by the company will carry a rating of MIG-1.

title: Special Labor Counsel Hopes to Mend Allegis
description: Stephen E. Tallent, recently appointed the Allegis Corporation's special labor counsel, says he is still trying ''to get up to speed'' at the turbulent parent company of United Airlines.

title: FIRST CHICAGO'S WOOD GUNDY STAKE
description: The First Chicago Corporation, owner of the 11th-largest commercial bank in the United States, said yesterday that it would buy 35 percent of Wood Gundy, a leading Canadian brokerage firm, for $270 million.

title: HISTORIC POWER PLANT REBORN AT THE GREAT FALLS IN PATERSON
description: In 1791, Alexander Hamilton, the first Secretary of the Treasury of the fledgling United States of America, came here and decided to use the power of the Passaic River and its 70-foot drop over the Great Falls to develop the nation's first manufacturing center.

title: TOMMY HILFIGER'S SPOTS LINKED TO COMPETITORS
description: With the help of George Lois and his agency team, Tommy Hilfiger, the designer and golden boy of the house of Murjani, has learned quickly that to make yourself seem larger in the eye of consumers than you really are, the thing to do is to associate yourselves with the giants in the field, even if it's in a adversarial way.

title: New Jersey Puts the Patient First
description: Hilda Peter, 65, remains irreversibly comatose after a stroke. So does Nancy Jobes, 31, after surgery. Yet sophisticated medical technology affixes them to death's threshold, unable to make the crossing they are said to want. Their wishes conflict with the policies of medical institutions.

title: DIGIORGIO SOUGHT BY GABELLI GROUP
description: An investment group led by Mario Gabelli, a New York money manager, said today that it held 2.43 million common shares, or 28.6 percent, of the DiGiorgio Corporation, and would seek control of the company. Di Giorgio, which is based here, manufactures and distributes food products and has operations in building materials and real estate.

title: Ex-Police Officer Arrested
description: A former South Carolina police officer charged with murder in three slayings in two states was arrested today after an intense search for the stabber of a motel maid. The suspect, Wade Stanford Sheffield, was arrested at an Augusta motel. The authorities said that Mr. Sheffield registered at the motel Sunday and attacked a maid who entered his room to clean it. She was not severely injured.

title: NUMBERS AND WORDS
description: WAGS say the reason Lotus 1-2-3 has no real word-processing capabilities is that spreadsheet jocks cannot put a sentence together unless at least half of it consists of numbers. Hyperbolic or even envious as this may be, it is true that, for years, if you wanted to provide explanatory wrapping for a spreadsheet, you had to exit the spreadsheet program and call forth a separate word processor.

title: AT 50, 'GUIDING LIGHT' RECALLS ITS PAST
description: Ian Ziering is too young to remember the radio era of the ''Guiding Light,'' when the Reverend Ruthledge gave solace to his parishoners. But, as an actor on the modern television version, he will celebrate the 50th anniversary with the original ''guiding light.''

title: 2 KEY FRENCH RATES CUT
description: The Bank of France cut its two key interest rates by a quarter of a percentage point today in a move that reflected Finance Minister Edouard Balladur's desire for a general decline in rates.

title: GORE, ENTERING 1988 RACE, PROJECTS 'NEW SOUTH' IMAGE
description: Standing on the steps of a red brick courthouse in this venerable farm town that is misty with the imagery of the Old South, 39-year-old Senator Albert Gore Jr. today declared himself a Presidential candidate from ''the New South'' who is ''eager to help build a new America.''

title: WELLS AMERICAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: U.S. MAY ALLOW EGYPTIANS TO BUY AND ASSEMBLE M-1 TANKS
description: The United States has agreed in principle to an Egyptian request to buy advanced American M-1 tanks and assemble them in Egypt, Reagan Administration officials said today.

title: SLIGHT RISE IN AD PAGES
description: The Publishers Information Bureau, which is affiliated with the Magazines Publisher Association, reports that ad pages for its member magazines were up a slight nine-tenths of 1 percent in May from May 1986, to 13,637, while revenues remained about the same, at $469 million. In other words, there were not enough rate increases.

description: Soviet Overture to Iran

description: To the Editor:

title: Would You Sign?
description: Should the executive branch be headed by one person? If so, should that person be directly elected by the people? Should the Constitution prohibit slavery, regardless of the political costs?

title: Lisa Weinstock Weds Dr. Richard I. Finkel
description: At the Great Neck (L.I.) Synagogue yesterday, Lisa R. Weinstock, the daughter of Israel Weinstock and Esther Weinstock, both of Forest Hills, Queens, was married to Dr. Richard I. Finkel, a son of Dr. Martin Finkel of New York and the late Dr. Elaine R. Finkel. Rabbis Shlomo Riskin and Joseph Grunblatt officiated.
